headline: End-of-Summer Business Reading: Dreamers and the Defiant
text: With just a week left before the unofficial end of what has been a relentless summer of business news — the fate of Greece, the economic woes of China and the market roller coaster in the United States — hopefully you might find the time to read a book.

headline: U.S. Open 2015: Stars Take a Beating on a Topsy-Turvy Day
text: Amid a flurry of first-round upsets, Kei Nishikori had multiple chances — two, to be specific — to sidestep disaster at the United States Open on Monday.

headline: 6 Players Get Probation in Sayreville, N.J., Football Hazing Case
text: Six of the seven teenagers charged with sexually abusing teammates in a football hazing scandal at the high school in Sayreville, N.J., last fall were sentenced to probation and 50 hours each of community service, a prosecutor said on Monday.

headline: Clash Erupts During Raid by Israelis in West Bank
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Israeli soldiers clashed with Palestinian gunmen in one of the West Bank’s toughest refugee camps overnight Tuesday, as a raid that appeared to be aimed at arresting people suspected as Palestinian militants turned into an armed confrontation.

headline: Supreme Court Says Kentucky Clerk Must Let Gay Couples Marry
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday refused to allow a county clerk in Kentucky who objects to same-sex marriage on religious grounds to continue to deny marriage licenses to all couples, gay or straight.

headline: Japan Nears Test Flight for Long-Delayed Regional Passenger Jet
text: After several years of delays, Japan’s first commercial airliner in about half a century is scheduled for its first test flight — an hourlong ride out of Nagoya Airport.

headline: California Defends Its Review Process in Appeal to Preserve Death Penalty
text: California on Monday asked a federal appeals panel to overturn a 2014 court ruling that — unless it is reversed — could bring a reprieve to the more than 740 inmates on death row in the state.

headline: TV Dinners in a Netflix World
text: SOLON, Ohio — The pizza arrived, mozzarella melting on a red crushed tomato blanket dotted with brilliant green spinach aboard a crispy, irregularly shaped crust dusted here and there with ash.

headline: Insights, and Redactions, in Latest Release of Hillary Clinton’s Emails
text: WASHINGTON — Chelsea Clinton warned her parents that international relief efforts in Haiti were a disaster and that major changes were needed in a memo released on Monday that offered a rare window into her role in America’s most prominent political family.

headline: A Wild Month on Wall St. Ends Quietly
text: For several years, parking one’s savings in the United States stock market seemed like a no-brainer. Not only did stocks steadily climb — giving investors far better returns than they could get from their bank accounts — the ride up was smooth.

headline: Nelson Shanks, Who Painted the Prominent, Dies at 77
text: Nelson Shanks, a painter known for his portraits of political leaders and prominent figures in the arts, who earlier this year revealed that he had included a visual reference to the Monica Lewinsky affair in his portrait of Bill Clinton for the National Portrait Gallery, died on Friday at his home in Bucks County, Pa. He was 77.

headline: 244 Immigrants With Criminal Records Face Deportation in California
text: LOS ANGELES — More than 240 immigrants with criminal records who are living in the United States illegally were taken into custody last week during a four-day sweep across Southern California, immigration authorities said Monday.

headline: Most Nations Miss a Goal for Women in Leadership
text: UNITED NATIONS — The corridors of the United Nations hummed on Monday as hundreds of men, in polished wingtips and natty ties, arrived here for the annual conclave of lawmakers from around the world.

headline: Wayne W. Dyer, Prolific Author of Self-Help Books, Dies at 75
text: Dr. Wayne W. Dyer, whose best-selling 1976 book decrying the vice of blame and preaching the virtue of self-reliance, “Your Erroneous Zones,” propelled him to a prolific multimedia career of advice-giving and spiritual counseling, died over the weekend in Maui, Hawaii. He was 75.

headline: Murder Rates Rising Sharply in Many U.S. Cities
text: MILWAUKEE — Cities across the nation are seeing a startling rise in murders after years of declines, and few places have witnessed a shift as precipitous as this city. With the summer not yet over, 104 people have been killed this year — after 86 homicides in all of 2014.

headline: Making American Men’s Game Great Again: Ideas?
text: On Tommy Haas’s Twitter page, in an Aug. 22 posting to his roughly 157,000 followers, he wrote: “Make America great again. Thoughts? Suggestions?”

headline: An Escalating Migrant Crisis and an Intensifying Search for Solutions
text: A mounting migrant crisis has forced members of the European Union to search for new ways to adequately house, feed and effectively screen thousands of people seeking asylum. The recent influx of migrants, mostly from the Middle East and Northern Africa, has overwhelmed some countries and exposed vulnerabilities in the continental bloc’s open-border policy.

headline: Taxis of Yesterday and Today
text: From the Darracq to the Nissan NV200, a brief history of automobile models that have served as New York City taxis.

headline: Tomorrow Arrives for New York City’s Yellow Cab Standard
text: The boxy yellow vehicle is a survivor. It won a competition to redesign New York City’s taxi. It endured a pothole-marred course in Arizona meant to replicate the city’s rugged streets. And it prevailed in a legal battle and overcame the election of a new mayor who had been a vocal opponent.

headline: An Analyst’s Seamless Injection Into ESPN’s Rotation
text: Jessica Mendoza showed Sunday night that she belongs in ESPN’s regular rotation of baseball game analysts, with a smart, understated stint in place of Curt Schilling.

headline: 1993 Murder Conviction Vacated; Brooklyn Prosecutor Says Evidence Was Withheld
text: A man who had served 24 years on a murder conviction was released on Monday, after the Brooklyn district attorney admitted his office had withheld key evidence in the case against the man, Ruddy Quezada.

headline: As Crowds for Bernie Sanders Grow, the Biggest Impact Comes in Iowa
text: BOONE, Iowa — The first person Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont met when he climbed out of a Dodge Journey here on a recent Saturday morning was Caleb Humphrey. It was for good reason.

headline: Top Officials With New York City Police Are Angered by Escapes
text: The woman, arrested after she was accused of skipping out on her bill at a restaurant and shoplifting, was taken to the hospital. She had told the police that she was pregnant and feeling ill.

headline: No Corrections: August 31, 2015
text: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: 3,000 Miles From Denali, Ohio Fumes Over Renaming of Mount McKinley
text: To be clear, President William McKinley has one of the largest grave sites of any former American president, so perhaps a mountaintop was a bit superfluous.

headline: Serena Williams Coasts Through First Round at U.S. Open
text: Serena Williams spent about an hour on a practice court in the late afternoon on Monday in preparation for her first-round match of the U.S. Open. She pounded groundstrokes and serves, smashed some overheads, punched home a few volleys and even chased a handful of drop shots.

headline: Europe Must Reform Its Deadly Asylum Policies
text: The arrival of hundreds of thousands of refugees from war-torn regions of Africa and the Middle East, as well as economic migrants from Africa and Asia, is testing the European Union as no other recent crisis has. As the human toll mounts — more than 2,500 have died so far this year — so does the moral pressure on Europe to act. On Friday, after 71 people were found suffocated in a truck in Austria and 150 others drowned off the coast of Libya, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said he was “horrified and heartbroken at the latest loss of lives.”

headline: Expert Says Manuscript Is Not Harper Lee’s Third Novel
text: A rare books expert who reviewed recently discovered manuscript pages by Harper Lee has concluded that they are from an early version of “To Kill a Mockingbird,” and not a possible third novel by the author.

headline: White House Sidesteps Hubbub About Obama’s Future Role at Columbia
text: A passing comment by the president of Columbia University on Monday touched off a flurry of expectations that President Obama would affiliate with the university, his alma mater, after he leaves office, but the White House said no decisions had been made.

headline: U.S. Tennis Association’s New Executive Waits Patiently for American Boys to Fill a Void
text: The shirt Andy Roddick was wearing when he won the 2003 United States Open was cool, so cool, with one sleeve black and the other white, and diagonal lines across the chest, and some more diagonals across the back, that Tommy Paul remembers wanting to do anything to get it.

headline: At U.S. Open Match, a Sea of Bills Blue
text: It is not often that N.F.L. apparel provides a clue of a spectator’s allegiance to a tennis player. But as play at the U.S. Open began Monday morning on Court 7, several fans in Buffalo Bills attire rallied around the 21-year-old qualifier Jessica Pegula as she sought her first victory in the main draw of a Grand Slam event.

headline: Mets’ Efficiency Pays Off in Latest Win Over Phils
text: When Michael Conforto, the Mets’ rookie left fielder, dug into the batter’s box in the fifth inning, he calmly processed the situation. The Mets were locked in a scoreless tie with the Philadelphia Phillies. The rookie Jerad Eickhoff had held the Mets to one hit, a single to Conforto, who punched a 1-2 pitch into right field in his first at-bat.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Aide on Homeless Is Resigning Amid Crisis
text: At a time when New York has taken emergency measures to help homeless residents, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Monday night that the deputy mayor overseeing the city’s response to the crisis will resign at the end of September.

text: Rafael Nadal is still a long way from reclaiming the form that once made him the most feared player on the ATP Tour, but with a solid victory against a talented young player, he moved into the second round of the United States Open.

headline: What’s On TV Tuesday
text: 6:05 A.M. (FLIX) MR. HOLLAND’S OPUS (1995) An idealistic composer (Richard Dreyfuss, above with Alicia Witt) takes a teaching job that becomes his true opus. “Mr. Dreyfuss’s taste for grandstanding could easily sink a tale of simple virtues, especially one about a music teacher who is often seen marching, dancing, conducting or otherwise registering emotions aimed at the bleacher seats,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “But in ‘Mr. Holland’s Opus,’ Mr. Dreyfuss gives a warm and really touching performance. He’s firmly in control of the film’s comic moments and just as comfortable delivering the film’s calculatingly Capraesque payoff: a good cry.”

headline: Teenage Motherhood in France
text: PERPIGNAN, France — When Viviane Dalles decided to explore the dramatic increase in teenage pregnancy in France’s Nord-Pas-de-Calais region, she knew it would be difficult. Few publications were interested in the topic, while parents and their daughters were reluctant to grant permission.

headline: Obama to Call for More Icebreakers in Arctic as U.S. Seeks Foothold
text: SEWARD, Alaska — President Obama on Tuesday proposed speeding the acquisition and building of new Coast Guard icebreakers that can operate year round in the nation’s polar regions, part of an effort to close the gap between the United States and other nations, especially Russia, in a global competition to gain a foothold in the rapidly changing Arctic.

headline: When Bosses Schedule Hours That Just Don’t Work
text: Gap announced last week that it would soon end the practice of on-call scheduling, which requires workers to call in before a shift to see if they are needed. By the beginning of next year, the company’s five brands — Athleta, Banana Republic, Gap, Intermix and Old Navy — will give employees at least 10 to 14 days’ notice of their schedules.

headline: Hillary Clinton, the Great Defender
text: Hillary Clinton has obviously had a bad summer. She’s losing in New Hampshire to Bernie Sanders, even among women. She’s barely leading him in Iowa. In a Quinnipiac poll of potential general election matchups, she’s beating Donald Trump by only four points, 45 to 41, and she’s beating Marco Rubio by only one point.

headline: Psychology Is Not in Crisis

headline: China’s Crackdown on Rumors Will Only Hurt Its Economy
text: China’s effort to prop up its stock market has taken a dangerous turn. Officials are arresting people whom they accuse of spreading rumors about the market and the unrelated industrial explosions in Tianjin that killed scores of people last month.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Putting Donald Trump on the Couch
text: AS surprising as Donald J. Trump’s political ascendance may be, it is not unprecedented. He is the latest in a long line of demagogues that have appeared throughout American history to point accusing fingers at blacks, foreigners, Masons, Jews, socialists, central bankers and others. What’s more mysterious are the roots of his vast insecurity — his compulsive need to trumpet his wealth, his smarts, his popularity. What is he compensating for?

headline: Baylor, Football and the Rape Case of Sam Ukwuachu
text: On Aug. 21, a Baylor University football player named Sam Ukwuachu was sentenced to six months in the county jail and 10 years’ probation for sexually assaulting a freshman soccer player two years ago.

text: Should the age of a presidential candidate matter?

text: Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, and her husband, Zachary Bogue, are expecting twin daughters, according to an announcement she made on Yahoo’s Tumblr.

headline: Between Iraq and a Hawk Base
text: The first sign that the Republican Party’s 17 presidential candidates might have trouble explaining what a conservative foreign policy should look like — beyond simply saying that it should not look like Barack Obama’s — emerged on May 10. That’s when the Fox News host Megyn Kelly asked Jeb Bush a rather predictable question about the Iraq war: ‘‘Knowing what we know now, would you have authorized the invasion?’’

headline: The Politics of Distraction
text: We begin, as many discussions about politics today should, with an analogy to pro wrestling. Consider the ‘‘foreign object’’ routine: One combatant produces a concealed item, usually from under his tights — a pointed stick or some hand-size tool of menace — and proceeds to jab his opponent with it. He perpetrates this atrocity in full view of everybody except the referee, who remains oblivious because a complicit third party (perhaps a tag-team partner or a manager) is distracting him.

headline: ‘Did You Ever Have a Family’ by Bill Clegg
text: Catastrophe and misfortune are a novelist’s friends, dramatic devices that provide a plot and let characters demonstrate their range. Tragedies tunnel through life, and the suspense comes from seeing how these spaces will be filled. This is what excites us about books that begin with a sorrowful bang. Grief is sad — we know that — but what now? How will these particular characters respond? What else do you have to give us?

headline: Instagram Exerts a Force in Beauty Trends
text: In days, New York Fashion Week will inspire a burst of beauty trends. But are the runways still the best place to source fresh ideas?

headline: Should Schools Give Students ‘Body’ Report Cards?
text: In an effort to fight childhood obesity, more schools are keeping track of their students’ weight and sending reports home to update students and families.

headline: An Unanswered Call for Help at Rikers Island
text: Over the years, reports of brutality and neglect at the Rikers Island jail complex have become routine. And while the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio has been working to improve conditions at New York City jails, the death of Carlos Mercado shows that the problems of the past could haunt the city for years to come.

headline: Foraging for Fashion
text: A bounty of warm-weather looks at the Union Square Greenmarket.

headline: Countdown to Death at Rikers Island
text: Carlos Mercado, 45, who was diabetic, died after 15 hours at the New York jail. Surveillance video shows him collapsed while officers step over him.

headline: Foraging for Fashion
text: Summer was in full bloom at the Union Square Greenmarket last week. There was a bounty of ripe tomatoes, sweet corn and smartly dressed shoppers, who took a break from their grocery shopping to discuss their warm-weather looks.

headline: ‘The Girl in the Spider’s Web’ by David Lagercrantz
text: There are many ways to continue a series after its author’s death. One is to wait a long time, until the original material has achieved classic status, and then find an established heavyweight willing to step up, like a great actor taking on his third King Lear. Examples would be John Banville reviving Raymond Chandler’s Philip Marlowe, or Jill Paton Walsh giving us more of Dorothy L. Sayers’s Lord Peter Wimsey. As readers we approach such attempts cautiously, with style points and degrees of difficulty in mind, as if we were judges at an Olympic diving competition, and therefore, however good the execution may be, these books will always remain to some extent interesting curiosities.

headline: As China’s Economy Falters, Military Parade Offers Chance to Burnish Image
text: BEIJING — Few things distract an anxious nation in economic trouble quite like a jaw-dropping military parade featuring a cavalcade of gleaming high-tech weaponry, 12,000 goose-stepping soldiers and fighter jets filling the skies with synchronized plumes of candy-colored smoke.

headline: Train Station in Budapest Cuts Off Service to Migrants
text: BUDAPEST — The Keleti train station in Budapest, which has emerged as a setting in the tumultuous drama of Europe’s escalating migration crisis, cut off service to migrants on Tuesday as European countries remained bitterly divided and confused over how to handle the thousands trekking northward.

headline: GE Capital’s Australian Units Said to Be Receiving Final Bids From 3
text: SYDNEY, Australia — GE Capital has three final participants in the final round of an auction of its Australian commercial lending and leasing businesses, said a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Lawyer Who Advised Churches in China Faces Secretive Detention
text: HONG KONG — A Chinese lawyer who has opposed a government campaign to tear down churches and church crosses faces up to six months in secretive detention after the police detained him and accused him of threatening state security, his colleague said on Tuesday.

headline: Today in Politics: Jeb Bush Is Still Waiting for Polling to Catch Up With Fund-Raising

Though the political world will be poring over the latest batch of emails from Hillary Rodham Clinton‘s time as secretary of state, Jeb Bush‘s campaign is hoping a new month will help bridge the sustained gap between his success in fund-raising and his lagging poll numbers.

headline: Blue Hill, a Literary Enclave, Grows in Downeast Maine
text: Rain lashed the pine boughs outside Jonathan Lethem’s summer home in East Blue Hill, Me., in June as an unseasonably chilly fog rolled among birches and firs. Inside a book-lined office, the author brushed away a tear.

headline: Louisiana Lays Bare Difficulty in Push to Cut Planned Parenthood Funding
text: NEW ORLEANS — Dr. Stephanie Taylor recently showed off the private community health center here, newly built on the site of a women’s clinic wrecked by Hurricane Katrina a decade ago, pointing out the colorful furnishings, germ-resistant flooring and, in the sunny lobby, a welcoming Tree of Life mural. So it was a tad incongruous when she added, “We’re at ground zero for sexually transmitted infections.”

headline: Morning Agenda: David Einhorn Surveys Investors
text: DAVID EINHORN SURVEYS INVESTORS | David Einhorn has a reputation as one of the savviest stock pickers on Wall Street, but even he has not been spared in the recent market turmoil. This year is shaping up to be one of the worst in the history of his hedge fund. People briefed on the matter say the Greenlight Capital fund was down 5.3 percent in August and down 14 percent for the year. And Mr. Einhorn has been trying to find out what his investors think about the fund, Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein report in DealBook.

headline: Popcast: 2015 MTV Video Music Awards
text: At the 2015 MTV Video Music Awards on Sunday night, it was the most theatrically transgressive of times, and the most honestly transgressive of times. Miley Cyrus, pop’s enfant terrible, hosted the event, but she was hardly the most shocking part of the night’s festivities, despite her best efforts. Those included outfits that looked like they had been drawn with a thin pencil, rather than cut from actual fabric (to say nothing of the moment Ms. Cyrus seemingly wore nothing at all); jokes that poked fun at her extreme persona, with little effect; and the surprise announcement of a new album, which she released just after the show.

text: MOREHEAD, Ky. — Defying the Supreme Court and saying she was acting “under God’s authority,” a county clerk in Kentucky denied marriage licenses to gay couples on Tuesday, less than a day after the court rejected her request for a delay.

headline: Gravity
text: Now that’s fun: Adam Davidson tells us about trade in the ancient Near East, as documented by archives found in Kanesh — and reports that the volume of trade between Kanesh and various trading partners seems to fit a gravity equation: trade between any two regional economies is roughly proportional to the product of their GDPs and inversely related to distance. Neat.

headline: Obama Urges Action on Climate Change
text: At a meeting of foreign ministers in Anchorage on Monday, the president said that world leaders must come to an agreement on the issue “before it’s too late.”

headline: What Should Obama Do Next on Iran?
text: As Congress returns to Washington after Labor Day, the vote on the Iran nuclear deal will be its most important since the decision to go to war in Iraq in 2003. While Republicans dominated the debate in July, Democrats regained lost ground in recent weeks with a flurry of endorsements in both houses of Congress. I testified in favor of the agreement before four congressional committees, and talked with many members individually during July and August. It now appears almost certain that President Obama has the votes to prevail in Congress.

headline: Two Exciting New Fall Shows for Richard Long
text: The trailblazing British artist Richard Long, renowned for his large-scale creations made using stone, driftwood and, in some cases, nothing more than his own footprints, is being celebrated in two exhibitions this fall. In the 70-year-old’s hometown of Bristol, the retrospective at the Arnolfini Gallery, ‘‘Richard Long: Time and Space,’’ features a number of his trademark mud murals and dry-stone sculptures. And in New York, at Sperone Westwater, ‘‘Crescent to Cross’’ will include a striking photograph of ‘‘Aconcagua Circle,’’ a ring of jagged rocks that the Turner Prize winner constructed during a 17-day trek in the Andes in 2012, as well as a new drawing created from red clay mud.

headline: The Most Wonderful Time of the Year
text: TIMES INSIDER — The summer has sped by, but even with fall approaching, we still have plenty to celebrate:

headline: Suicide Bomber in Pakistan Attacks Government Office, Killing 4
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — At least four people were killed and 50 others were wounded on Tuesday when a suicide bomber detonated his explosive-laden vest in the middle of a crowd lining up to enter a government building in northwestern Pakistan, officials said.

headline: Sharp Denials After Arrest of Vice News Journalists in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — Terrorism charges in Turkey against three Vice News journalists were denounced Tuesday as baseless by media advocacy groups and a lawyer for the men.

headline: 1940: Pilot Is Saved by Cup of Tea
text: AN AIRDROME IN SOUTHEAST ENGLAND — A cup of tea saved a young British Hurricane pilot from Nazi vengeance here today [Sept. 1] when three Messerschmitt Jaguars, painted with British markings which fooled ground defenses, swept in and bombed his machine in a corner of the field. A few minutes earlier the pilot had landed to have an oil leak plugged after shooting down a Dornier 117 into marshland near the coast. He had intended to wait in the cockpit while the mechanics worked on his plane, but instead accepted the commanding officer’s offer of a cup of tea. It probably saved him from death or serious injury. — New York Herald Tribune, September 2, 1940

headline: Alexander Sokurov: Russia as Allegory for Art and Life
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Alexander Sokurov’s 2002 film “Russian Ark,” a single 90-minute unedited Steadicam shot that weaves through the State Hermitage Museum here, is an elliptical meditation on art, power and nostalgia. In his latest film, “Francofonia,” which will debut in competition at the Venice International Film Festival on Friday, this Russian director turned his camera on the Louvre for a reflection on cultural patrimony during wartime and Russia’s vexed relationship with Europe.

headline: Daily Report: Hotel Chains Get Tough With Travel Websites

headline: A Temporary Answer to a Foster Child’s Biggest Question: Am I Going to School?
text: It rained the day we picked up our 3-year-old foster son, whom we call BlueJay, and brought him home to live with us four months ago. More accurately, it began unexpectedly pouring just moments before we opened the door of the apartment complex where he had been living and eyed up our car, parked a fair distance down the street.

headline: For Bernie Sanders, Brooklyn Roots Pose a Test, History Shows
text: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont may be making inroads against Hillary Rodham Clinton when it comes to recent polling, injecting his Brooklyn accent into the presidential campaign discourse. While voters seem to be increasingly gravitating to his message, his candidacy raises another question: Is the nation finally ready to embrace a politician from New York City’s most populous borough?

headline: Austria Discovers Syrian Travel Documents in Truck Where Bodies Were Found
text: VIENNA — The law enforcement authorities in Germany indicated on Tuesday that two suspects held in Hungary in connection with the deaths of 71 people found in a truck near Vienna on Thursday had been known to them for earlier crimes, including the smuggling of migrants to Bavaria just over a month ago.

headline: Not Just Any White Shirt
text: In honor of Charvet’s legendary shirtmaking, one man takes a sartorial journey.

headline: A Call for a Free Market
text: The worldwide turbulence of recent days is a strong indication that government intervention alone cannot restore the economy and offers a glimpse of the risk of completely depending on it. It is time to give the free market a chance.

headline: 1965: Rusk Letter Admits Spying
text: WASHINGTON — An embarrassed State Department conceded today [Sept. 1] that Secretary of State Dean Rusk had apologized to the government of Singapore in 1961 over a Central Intelligence Agency operation that went bad. Only yesterday, the State Department had firmly denied an accusation by Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew in Singapore that an American CIA agent had been arrested in 1960 for trying to buy state secrets in Singapore. Mr. Lee said that he asked $33 million in foreign aid from the United States in return for his government’s silence and the release of the agent, but that he was offered only $3 million and turned it down as an ‘‘insult.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 2, 1965

headline: Portugal, Missing Deadline for Novo Banco Sale, Turns to Second Bidder
text: MADRID — Portugal is having trouble selling the bank salvaged from the wreckage of one of the country’s biggest private lenders.

headline: Review: Janet Jackson, on Unbreakable Tour, Shows Off Her Demure Side
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — A newly demure Janet Jackson started her “Unbreakable World Tour” at Rogers Arena here on Monday night. She was dressed in white and covered, like her dancers and musicians, from shoulders to shoes. And she avoided one big subset of her songwriting: her salacious, sometimes kinky whispers. That left Ms. Jackson, 49, to play the many other, less titillating roles that have given her major hits and made her an enduring influence across pop and R&B.

headline: Protesters Storm Ministry in Beirut
text: Protesters took over the office of Lebanon’s environment minister in the capital on Tuesday, calling on him to resign for failing to find a solution to the garbage crisis.

headline: Jeb Bush Video Takes Aim at Donald Trump’s ‘Manhattan’ Mind-Set
text: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida is pulling no punches with Donald J. Trump, assailing him in a new online advertisement as a fake conservative.

headline: How the Shooting Occurred
text: A video of a fatal shooting by police officers in San Antonio last week appears to show a man putting his hands up before they fired.

headline: Aftermath of Suicide Bombing in Pakistan
text: At least four people died in an attack on a government office in the tribal region of Jamrud, Pakistan.

headline: Emails Show How Hillary Clinton Valued Input From Sidney Blumenthal
text: WASHINGTON — As secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton had access to the latest information and analysis from the nation’s premier intelligence agencies, from a corps of seasoned diplomats reporting back from every corner of the world, from a range of foreign policy experts in and out of government. And from Sidney Blumenthal.

headline: French Publisher Won’t Print Book on Moroccan King After Authors’ Arrest
text: PARIS — A major French publishing house has decided not to publish a book critical of King Mohammed VI of Morocco after its two authors were arrested last week in Paris and charged with blackmail and extortion on accusations they demanded 2 million euros, or about $2.3 million, to keep the book unpublished.

headline: The Wait
text: If you can wait in New York City, you can wait anywhere.

headline: Vice Media Lands Carmelo Anthony for New Sports Channel
text: Carmelo Anthony is Vice Media’s newest teammate.

headline: Arabic ‘Sesame Street’ Returns for First Time Since Gulf War
text: Elmo and the Cookie Monster are returning to the Persian Gulf for the first time in 25 years.

headline: Scott Walker Shows His ‘Aggressive’ Side
text: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin called himself “aggressively normal” in the first Republican presidential debate — and saw his poll numbers go backward.

headline: 2015 Fantasy Football: Tight End Preview and Rankings
text: Tight end is traditionally the thinnest of the four offensive fantasy football positions, and there seems to be even more uncertainty than usual regarding the position heading into 2015.

headline: California Agrees to Overhaul Use of Solitary Confinement
text: LOS ANGELES — California has agreed to an overhaul of the use of solitary confinement in its prisons, including strict limits on the prolonged isolation of inmates, as part of a landmark legal settlement filed in federal court on Tuesday.

headline: Second Bomb Suspect Arrested in Bangkok
text: A police spokesman, Lt. Gen. Prawut Thavornsiri, speaks about one of three suspects connected to the bombing of a shrine in Bangkok.

headline: Prisoner Who Escaped From Manhattan Hospital Is Back in Custody
text: The woman who escaped from police custody while she was in a Manhattan hospital was captured on Tuesday on the Upper West Side, the police said.

headline: Jesse Kamm’s Laid-Back Approach to Life — and Looks
text: This year, the Los Angeles-based designer Jesse Kamm — whose languid, Annie Hallish separates are cult items among the creative class on both coasts — celebrates 10 years in business. It’s no small feat considering she is the company’s sole employee and refuses to collaborate with big brands as a matter of principle. Instead, the former model has slowly built a following for her signature silhouettes — including dramatically high-waisted, perpetually sold-out sailor pants, which are being reissued in early September in new colors to commemorate the line’s anniversary. (A video celebrating the pants in all their splendor debuts here.)

headline: Superiority Burger
text: Vegetarian medium fast food in the East Village.

headline: Restaurant Review: Superiority Burger in the East Village
text: We all know restaurants where the menu changes daily. Last week at Superiority Burger, a vegetarian medium-fast-food outfit in the East Village, it changed in the middle of my meal.

headline: Pope Francis to Pass Through Central Park in Ticketed Event
text: Pope Francis is coming to Central Park, but you will need a ticket to see him.

headline: Google’s Driverless Cars Run Into Problem: Cars With Drivers
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Google, a leader in efforts to create driverless cars, has run into an odd safety conundrum: humans.

headline: Injured Vitalia Diatchenko Shows Retirement Has Its Perks
text: Vitalia Diatchenko’s hobbled performance Monday night against Serena Williams — which ended when she retired in the second set with a foot injury — stole some energy from the opening night of the United States Open and provoked more debate about how award money is handled for injured players.

headline: Ford and Fiat Chrysler Post Surprising Sales Gains in August
text: Even as auto sales have returned to prerecession levels, one kind of vehicle has been left behind: the family sedan.

headline: The U.S. Icebreaker Gap is About Arctic Needs, Not About Chasing Russia
text: Way back in the Cold War, the United States fixated on a “missile gap” with the Soviet Union. You may remember this even devolved into a “mineshaft gap” in “Dr. Strangelove.”

headline: Bloomberg News, Refocusing Its Coverage, Will Lay Off About 90
text: Bloomberg News laid off as many as 90 journalists on Tuesday in its newsrooms in New York, Washington and across the world, part of a plan to refocus the organization’s coverage on business, finance, economics, technology and politics.

headline: At Wharton, Donald Trump’s Marketing Skills Make the Grade
text: Donald J. Trump has made a few things clear to voters as he has barnstormed the country making his case for the presidency. He will build a wall; he is very rich; and he went to Wharton – the University of Pennsylvania’s prestigious business school.

headline: The Healing Power of Hugs
text: One day several years ago, I spontaneously hugged a patient of mine, Gretchen. It was during a moment in which her despair and distress were so intense that it seemed cruel on a human level not to reach out my arms to her, in the event that she might derive some relief or comfort from an embrace. She hugged me for dear life.

headline: A Stew of Peppers Dresses Up Brown Rice
text: In summer and early fall, when local sweet peppers are truly sweet and have great depth of flavor, there’s nothing I like better than a comforting stew of peppers: a simple mix of onion, garlic, peppers, tomatoes and basil cooked slowly in olive oil.

headline: The End of the Republican Party?
text: My Sunday column on Trump ended with a rather dire forecast: That if the G.O.P. fails to adapt to some of the crucial reasons for his success, “the pressure the Donald has tapped will continue to build — and when it bursts, the G.O.P. as we know it may go with it.” Erick Erickson, in part of a longer series of posts, invokes my column while making an even grimmer forecast: That the Republican Party is “dying,” that what we’re watching is the “beginning of the end.” And Ben Domenech, in yesterday’s edition of The Transom, writes the following:

headline: The Fantastic Man Editors on Their Five Favorite Magazines
text: Jop van Bennekom and Gert Jonkers, the Dutch duo also behind The Gentlewoman and Butt, share their all-time favorite publications.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 10 | Finding Freedom and Self-Love Through Running
text: For 10 weeks this summer we asked students the question, “What interested you most in The Times this week?” Below, we announce our favorite responses for the 10th and final week of our Sixth Annual Summer Reading Contest.

headline: Fung Tu Keeps Cooking, Even With Gas Shut Off
text: The gas went out at Fung Tu on July 9, a Thursday, the busiest night of the week for a Manhattan restaurant in summer.

headline: The Neverending Fight to Save Social Security
text: A trial balloon now being inflated by Republicans in Congress needs to be popped before it gets any bigger.

headline: Stocks Dive as Worries About Asia Reverberate
text: Keep the seatbelts on.

headline: Review: Chrissie Hynde’s ‘Reckless’ Details a Rocker’s Life
text: Way to go, Akron, Ohio, for giving the world Chrissie Hynde, a malcontent for the ages — or, at a minimum, for the post-punk era — with a look to match: kohl-rimmed eyes, a low hedgerow of bangs, the best sneer since Elvis’s.

headline: Serena Williams’s Links to a Pioneer Keep Growing Clearer
text: As Serena Williams left the interview room Monday evening and walked down a long corridor, I asked her if she had seen the Althea Gibson documentary that is making the rounds.

headline: Is Everyone Qualified to Be a Critic?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Adam Kirsch and Charles McGrath discuss what it takes to pass judgment on the arts.

headline: Undercover Activist James O’Keefe Plans to Step Up Political Stalking
text: Campaign rallies are crawling with hidden cameras these days as opposition researchers from rivals, activist groups or political action committees spare no expense in hopes of finding a gaffe or, ideally, signs of unlawfulness.

headline: Saucy in Brooklyn Isn’t Just for Catering
text: Saucy Przemek Adolf started with savory jams and chutneys four years ago. They quickly became the platform for his catering company, Saucy by Nature. And now he has a restaurant, Saucy. “It’s been a bit of a ride,” he said. He figured that having a restaurant in tandem with a catering company would permit him to reduce waste by using surplus ingredients, distributing leftovers and composting. Though he’s not going to the extremes of sustainability like the experiment this year by Dan Barber of Blue Hill, serving carrot peelings and fish-head tartare, he said he would dabble in it, and turn radish leaves into pesto. The restaurant is fast casual, with counter service for soups, salads and sandwiches to eat in or take out at lunchtime, and heartier fare, like Moroccan chicken, for dinner: 884 Fulton Street (Washington Street), Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, saucybynature.com.

headline: Robert Rodriguez, Film Director and El Rey Founder, on Creating a Hispanic Network
text: Back when he was participating in clinical drug trials to help raise the original $7,000 budget for his 1993 breakthrough film “El Mariachi,” Robert Rodriguez never dreamed he would one day be running his own cable channel. Now he’s the founder and chairman of the El Rey Network, an outlet he started in 2013 specializing in the grindhouse fare he favors as the director of movies like “Sin City” and “Machete.” “Usually as a filmmaker, all you can do is make product, and you have to go find a distributor,” Mr. Rodriguez said. “When you are the distributor, you have a direct pipeline into homes, and you can try things you wouldn’t get to do otherwise. You can build a network from the ground up.” El Rey now reaches 40 million households in the United States and is available on such services as DirecTV, Dish Network and Sling TV.

headline: Obama Nears Needed Votes on Iran Nuclear Deal
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama all but clinched victory for his Iran nuclear deal on Tuesday, as two Democratic senators threw crucial support behind the landmark accord.

headline: Big Leaps for Parental Leave, if Workers Actually Take It
text: Some corners of corporate America have a new message for new parents: Put down that laptop and pick up your baby instead.

headline: Police Clear ‘You Stink’ Protesters From Minister’s Offices in Beirut
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Demonstrators from the “You Stink” movement, protesting a garbage pileup and political dysfunction, occupied the offices of Lebanon’s environment minister in downtown Beirut on Tuesday, declaring that they would stay until he resigned.

headline: Donald Trump’s Shaky Grasp on Immigration
text: When Donald Trump was reaching adulthood in the mid-1960s, the United States was a less diverse place. By 1970, the share of the population born overseas had shrunk to 4.7 percent, the slimmest on record. Only about 0.4 percent of the population had been born in Mexico.

headline: The Triumph of Backward-Looking Economics
text: We don’t get to do many controlled experiments in economics, so history is mainly what we have to go on. Unfortunately, many people who imagine that they know how the economy works go with what they think they heard about history, not with what actually happened. And I’m not just talking about the great unwashed; quite a few well-known economists seem not to have heard about FRED, or at least haven’t picked up the habit of doing a quick scan of the actual data before making assertions about facts.

headline: In Asheville, a Fall Tour That Includes Farms and Wine
text: In response to guests asking innkeepers in the Asheville, N.C., area what to do beyond exploring the Blue Ridge Parkway, the Asheville Bed & Breakfast Association has created a Fall Farms and Artisans Tour Package that takes visitors along the roads less traveled. The 16 inns have partnered with three western North Carolina farms, a vineyard and five artisans in the 200-year-old farming community of Sandy Mush in Leicester, situated amid rolling hills 20 minutes northwest of Asheville.

headline: In West Bank, Speculation Abounds Over Mahmoud Abbas’s Plans
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Mahmoud Abbas, the aging Palestinian president, may be paving the way for his exit from political life — or he may be trying to consolidate power by crippling all his rivals.

headline: Bad Ideas Down Under
text: I’m heading off to Sydney, for the Festival of Dangerous Ideas. Blogging will be limited due to travel, plus blood rushing to my head from standing upside down when I get there.

headline: Inside Amazon: Reporter’s Notebook
text: Last January, when we began interviewing Amazon veterans about what it is like to work at the company, we realized that we were stepping into a heated private debate.

headline: Pope Francis Eases Path to Absolution for Abortion
text: ROME — Pope Francis announced Tuesday that all Roman Catholic priests would be empowered to offer absolution for the “sin of abortion” during the church’s Holy Year of Mercy, which begins in December.

headline: Idris Elba, Called ‘Too Street’ to Play James Bond, Gets an Apology
text: To fans, Idris Elba would make the perfect James Bond. They’ve been clamoring for years to cast the actor as the smooth action hero. So when the author of a forthcoming Bond novel dismissed Mr. Elba as “too street” for the part, the backlash was immediate, and now comes the apology.

headline: Shakespeare Gets Hip-Hop Treatment With App
text: Eminem called himself a “modern-day Shakespeare” in 2001. Now the Royal Shakespeare Company is trying to further bridge the gap between rap and the writer: They’ve created an app with Samsung, “RE: Shakespeare,” which remixes Shakespeare through a hip-hop lens.

headline: Review: ‘The Black Panthers’ Captures a Militant Movement’s Soul and Swagger
text: The beginning of “The Black Panthers,” Stanley Nelson’s excellent new documentary, includes a television news report on tensions between black citizens and the police in American cities. If not for the fuzzy, monochrome images and the voice-over’s unironic use of the word “Negroes,” the clip could have been broadcast last week, instead of almost 50 years ago. And if Mr. Nelson doesn’t strain to establish the present-day relevance of the story he has to tell, it’s partly because he doesn’t have to. The problems of poverty, police brutality and economic plunder that gave birth to the Panthers are with us still.

headline: Same-Sex Couple Confronts Kentucky Clerk
text: Kim Davis, the clerk of Rowan County, Ky., turned away David Ermold and David Moore, who were seeking a marriage license. Ms. Davis said she was acting “under God’s authority.”

headline: God vs. the Constitution in Kentucky
text: Apparently, you can appeal a Supreme Court ruling to a higher authority.

headline: Fox Lake Police Open Manhunt for 3 Shooting Suspects
text: CHICAGO — With helicopters buzzing overhead and police dogs searching on the ground, the authorities in northern Illinois conducted a sprawling manhunt Tuesday evening for three people suspected in the fatal shooting of a Fox Lake police lieutenant that morning.

headline: At Auschwitz, a Summer Precaution Is a Grim Reminder to Some
text: It was intended to provide relief from the extreme summer heat in Poland. But instead, a suspended hose that sprays visitors to Auschwitz with a fine mist is reminding some of the concentration camp’s grim history.

headline: Pope Asks Bullied Girl to Sing for Him
text: After learning that Valerie Herrera, 17, used music to cope with being bullied for a rare skin condition, Pope Francis said he would like to hear her sing. “Be courageous,” he added with a smile.

headline: British Employers Who Skirt ‘Living Wage’ Will Face Tough Fines, Cameron Says
text: LONDON — As the push for higher minimum pay builds momentum on both sides of the Atlantic, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain on Tuesday threatened companies with tough fines if they fail to pay what he called a “national living wage.”

headline: Real Madrid and Manchester United Trade Jabs After Transfer Fails
text: MADRID — Major soccer transfers almost always involve secretive talks among clubs, players and their agents haggling over large sums of money. The outcome is ultimately made public if a deal is reached, but often in trite statements in which the buying club welcomes the arrival of a top player while the seller thanks him for his contribution. Rarely is there a mention of exactly how much cash was exchanged.

headline: Phillips and Sotheby’s Announce Strategic Moves
text: Phillips and Sotheby’s auction houses are taking steps to strengthen their businesses.

headline: Marco Rubio Faults Donald Trump on ‘Make America Great Again’ Slogan
text: CARSON CITY, Nev. — The slogan is now synonymous with Donald J. Trump’s campaign: “Make America Great Again.” It is embroidered on the hats he sells for $25 and often seen printed on homemade T-shirts and signs at his rallies across the country.

headline: Uber Rolls Into Martha’s Vineyard and Finds Some Resistance
text: Operating in quaint vacation spots like Martha’s Vineyard is a new thing for Uber, but not all the locals appreciate the advancement into their communities.

headline: Missouri Teenagers Protest a Transgender Student’s Use of the Girls’ Bathroom
text: A transgender high school student in Missouri is facing backlash from her peers after requesting to use the girls’ bathrooms and locker room.

headline: Menstruation Innovation: Lessons from India
text: In recent months, a wave of period-positivity has captured headlines – from Kiran Gandhi’s bold free-bleeding run of the London Marathon, to the successful repeal of Canada’s national “tampon tax.” Donald Trump catapulted menstruation smack into the middle of  the Republican presidential debate when he ridiculed Megyn Kelly’s inquiry about his prior sexist rants, telling CNN she had “blood coming out of her wherever.”

headline: Mr. Obama’s Urgent Arctic Message
text: A presidential trip has enormous power to focus attention on a place and an issue, and President Obama’s trip to Alaska has been minutely choreographed with visits to glaciers, threatened Inuit villages and the like to provide a stunning and alarming context to his message on the urgent need to address climate change.

headline: Five Poets Receive Lucrative Fellowships
text: Five poets received unusually lucrative good news on Tuesday, as the Poetry Foundation and Poetry magazine announced the recipients of the 2015 Ruth Lilly and Dorothy Sargent Rosenberg Poetry Fellowships.

headline: The Black Panthers in Pictures
text: Images from the documentary “The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution.”

headline: Readers Recommend Where to Go Around Lake Michigan
text: One of our recent articles, “A Tour of Lake Michigan, My Inland Sea,” about the writer Rich Cohen’s travels around the lake, inspired more than 290 comments on nytimes.com/travel. Mr. Cohen, who grew up in Glencoe, Ill., about a mile from the shore, made stops in Chicago; Benton Harbor, Mich.; Ludington, Mich.; Mackinac Island and Milwaukee; just to name a few.

headline: Los Angeles to Be U.S. Bidder to Host 2024 Olympics
text: LOS ANGELES — Eight months after finishing as the runner-up to Boston, Los Angeles has officially been chosen as the United States candidate for the 2024 Olympics, city officials announced Tuesday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Hungary and Elsewhere
text: Hungary and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: U.S. Remains the ‘Great Satan,’ Hard-Liners in Iran Say
text: TEHRAN — Flexing their muscles, some of the toughest anti-American voices in Iran said on Tuesday that the United States remains their country’s top enemy, guilty of “uncountable” crimes. Their remarks hinted at a developing struggle over domestic influence because of the nuclear deal with world powers.

headline: A Recipe From the Newly Relaunched Aldea
text: On Aug. 24, the chef George Mendes’s ultramodern, Iberian-inspired restaurant, Aldea, shut its doors for 10 days. Six years after its opening (and five years after receiving its first Michelin star), the time had come, he explains, for some long-awaited updates. “The relaunch itself has probably been on my mind for the past year and a half to two years,” he says. “I wanted to take this on full force — what started out as a need for wear-and-tear renovations became an opportunity, in the summer months, to close down, do a complete renovation from head to tail, make changes at the bar and revisit the menu.”

headline: September 1, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Hungary, India, Ukraine and Cuba.

headline: Vice Urges Release of Its Journalists
text: A member of the Vice News team and a lawyer for the detainees called for the release of two British Vice News journalists and their Iraqi news assistant, who were arrested by the Turkish police.

headline: Building for Future, Ithaca Remakes Town Square
text: ITHACA, N.Y. — On Saturday, as Ithaca celebrated the official opening of its newly designed outdoor pedestrian mall, the Commons, Mayor Svante Myrick strolled through the crowd on the plaza, collecting congratulations every few feet.

headline: Union Accused of Betraying Migrant Carnival Workers
text: RICHMOND, R.I. — At summer carnivals like the Washington County Fair recently held here, migrant laborers spend long days running the Whip, the Orbiter, the Polar Express and other popular rides.

headline: Google Antitrust Inquiries Spread Over Globe, With India the Latest Problem
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google is quickly becoming the company government regulators around the world love to investigate.

headline: Review: ‘Big Blue Live’ Searches for Marine Life
text: “Big Blue Half-Live” might have been a more accurate title, and only the humpback whales seem to have gotten the memo for the initial East Coast broadcast, but at least give PBS credit for trying something different.

headline: A Fellow Outsider, Ben Carson Rivals Donald Trump in Polls, if Not in Pomp
text: The spotlight rarely found Ben Carson this summer. While other presidential candidates shot flaming arrows at rivals and sometimes the news media, the soft-spoken Mr. Carson seemed to struggle to be noticed. “Well, thank you,” he told moderators in the first Republican debate. “I wasn’t sure if I would get to speak again.”

headline: Maria on ‘Sesame Street,’ Sonia Manzano, Tells of Her Own Childhood
text: Talking to Sonia Manzano feels like catching up with an old friend.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.

headline: Explaining the Strange, Stinky Appeal of the ‘Corpse Flower’
text: A little more than a week after crowds at the Denver Botanic Gardens welcomed the smelly bloom of its resident titan arum, known as the corpse flower, another of the flowers failed to give visitors at the Chicago Botanic Garden a similar, smelly show.

headline: Questions Raised About Vietnam War Photos
text: Images by North Vietnamese war photographers that were featured in a book and exhibit have been found to have been manipulated.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: In ‘Black Mass,’ Whitey Bulger Acquires a Glimmer of Humanity
text: LOS ANGELES — Books about the unsavory alliance between the Boston mobster James (Whitey) Bulger and a corrupt F.B.I., including the best-selling “Black Mass,” serve up one horrific detail after another: a man stabbed 38 times with an ice pick, drive-by machine gun shootings, a young woman who is strangled with bare hands, the digging up of rotting corpses.

headline: A Conversation With Janno Lieber
text: Mr. Lieber, 53, is the president of the World Trade Center Properties division of Silverstein Properties, overseeing the developer’s four World Trade Center buildings.

headline: Fireball Fight in El Salvador
text: Participants in Nejapa gathered to throw gasoline fireballs at one another in an annual tradition that celebrates St. Jeronimo and has links to a 1658 volcanic eruption.

headline: Uber Rebuffed by Judge in Ruling on Drivers’ Suit
text: A federal judge granted class-action status on Tuesday to a lawsuit that questions the employment classification of Uber drivers, paving the way for a legal challenge that could strike at the heart of the ride-hailing company’s business model.

headline: Kathleen Hanna Revisits Her Riot Grrrl Past
text: When the riot grrrl pioneer Kathleen Hanna recently dug up some of her earliest work — the first demo cassette she recorded in 1991 with her band Bikini Kill, which has been remastered and is being reissued this month as “Revolution Girl Style Now” — she was a little nervous. “I thought I was going to hate it. I thought I was going to be like, ‘Oh, God, this is so embarrassing,’” she says with a laugh. “These were the first songs we ever wrote; and that tape was made primarily to send to promoters, to try to get shows. It wasn’t even made as a product that we were trying to sell in stores.”

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Sleep Arrives in Open Fields
text: With the path long, perilous, and occasionally obstructed by guards or crossed by barbed wire, refugee families like the Majids must manage their wounds along the way.

headline: How Can America Fight Unfair Work Schedules?: Reader Q&A
text: American workers need protection from unfair scheduling practices like on-call shifts, the editorial board argued on Tuesday. Below, Teresa Tritch, editorial writer on economic issues, responds to reader questions and comments about unfair scheduling and how to address it.

headline: Pessimism Pervades Mexico as Economic Promises Fall Short
text: MEXICO CITY — Jesús Rascón embodies the sort of success story that was supposed to epitomize “Mexico’s moment.”

headline: Donald Trump Meets With Javier Palomarez, Head of U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce
text: Donald J. Trump has been ruffling feathers with Hispanics with his tough talk on immigration, but on Tuesday the Republican presidential candidate took a step to try to smooth things over.

headline: CNN Alters Debate Criteria, Which Could Help Carly Fiorina
text: CNN announced on Tuesday that it would amend the criteria for picking candidates for the next Republican debate, scheduled for Sept. 16. The move followed criticism from supporters of Carly Fiorina and others that she was being unfairly excluded.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Rashomon on the West Bank: Israelis and Palestinians Debate Images of Soldier and Child
text: Not much of what happened last Friday during a demonstration near the West Bank village of Nabi Saleh is in doubt. But in thousands of social media arguments since then, Israelis and Palestinians, and supporters of the two sides around the world, have interpreted one charged encounter in very different ways.

headline: Qaeda-Affiliated Group Overruns African Union Base in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Fighters from the Shabab militant group overran an African Union military base in southern Somalia on Tuesday morning in an attack that included a suicide bombing and an intense firefight, witnesses and officials said.

headline: SFX Cancels One Tribe Festival, Citing Weak Ticket Sales
text: SFX Entertainment, the beleaguered promoter of dance music events, has canceled the One Tribe festival outside Los Angeles, the company’s first business casualty in the face of mounting financial problems in recent weeks.

headline: Representative Hakeem Jeffries Says He Will Vote for Iran Nuclear Deal
text: Representative Hakeem Jeffries, the Brooklyn Democrat known for his close ties with pro-Israel advocacy groups, announced on Tuesday that he will vote in support of President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran.

headline: Review: ‘Creep,’ a Horror Film With the Look of Found Footage
text: The actor and director Mark Duplass has come a long way from his mumblecore days, when he appeared in modest, low-budget movies like “Hannah Takes the Stairs,” often collaborating with his brother, Jay. Now he’s an indie stalwart, who helped create, and stars in, “Togetherness” on HBO. But he still has a taste for bare-bones filmmaking, as evidenced by “Creep,” a horror two-hander in which he stars, directed by Patrick Brice.

headline: Sony Altered ‘Concussion’ Film to Prevent N.F.L. Protests, Emails Show
text: When Sony Pictures Entertainment decided to make a movie focusing on the death and dementia professional football players have endured from repeated hits to the head — and the N.F.L.’s efforts toward a cover-up — it signed Will Smith to star as one of the first scientists to disclose the problem. It named the film bluntly, “Concussion.”

headline: Preparing for a Military Parade, China Deploys a Troop of Monkeys
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government has countless worries about mishaps that might besmirch its quest for a perfectly staged military parade.

headline: Review: ‘A Walk in the Woods,’ With Robert Redford, Is a Scenic Trek Spoiled
text: There’s a scene in “A Walk in the Woods,” a low-impact amble through hill, dale and cinematic nostalgia, when our two crusty trekkers face down a pair of bears. The men — Robert Redford and Nick Nolte — are slumbering in their tents when the bears descend and begin tearing into the hikers’ food, which they have failed to properly stash. The bears roar and the men thunder back, flapping uvulas and arms to chase off the animals. It’s a mildly funny scene, partly because of its light physical comedy and sight gaggery, although also because Mr. Nolte, his signature growl now often at sepulchral depths, has been doing a fair impression of a wild beast for years.

headline: Agency Reduces Estimate of Faulty Airbag Inflaters in the United States
text: A federal regulator said on Tuesday that it was still grappling with the size of the airbag crisis at Takata, the Japanese supplier, and that it expected to outline new steps in the recall process at a public meeting this fall.

headline: TV Producers of 2016 Oscars Are Selected
text: LOS ANGELES — The producers for the next Oscar ceremony will be Reginald Hudlin, a filmmaker schooled in urban comedy, and David Hill, a television producer with credits on “American Idol” and the 2011 World Series broadcast, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Tuesday.

headline: Kuwait: 26 Accused of Iran-Linked Plot
text: The judicial authorities in Kuwait have charged 25 Kuwaitis and an Iranian with illicit arms possession and secretive contacts with Iran and its ally Hezbollah, the Shiite Lebanese militant group, Kuwait’s official news agency reported Tuesday. The agency quoted a statement by Dherar al-Asousi, the public prosecutor, as saying all 26 were implicated in what it described as a terrorist plot to destabilize the country. Twenty-three of the defendants have been arrested, the statement said. It did not name any but said all were accused of having illegally obtained “explosives, machine guns, firearms, ammunition and tapping devices.” Kuwait’s Sunni monarchy is a strong ally of Saudi Arabia, which regards Iran as its main regional rival.

headline: After a Killing, Body Cameras Are Expanded in San Antonio
text: SAN ANTONIO — One day after a bystander’s cellphone video was released that appeared to show sheriff’s deputies fatally shooting a Hispanic man who had his hands raised in surrender, officials here voted Tuesday to finance additional body cameras for deputies in the field, as federal authorities said they had opened an investigation into whether the man’s civil rights had been violated.

headline: Preservationists Fight Bill Setting Time Limit on Landmarks Decisions in New York
text: What if Grand Central Terminal, the Empire State Building and the theater at Radio City Music Hall were not New York City landmarks?

headline: Can a Novelist Be Too Productive?: Q. & A. With Stephen King
text: Stephen King took questions from readers about writing and creativity based on his Sunday Review essay, “Can a Novelist Be Too Productive?” Here are his responses.

headline: F.D.A. Warns 5 Producers of Powdered Caffeine
text: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday that it had sent warning letters to five producers of pure powdered caffeine, in what consumer advocates said was a long overdue move against the product and the industry that makes it.

headline: Ruling in Uber Case
text: The ruling by Judge Edward M. Chen will allow a jury to decide whether Uber drivers should be considered employees or 1099 contract workers, named after a tax designation, which does not require the company to pay payroll taxes or apply minimum wage and overtime laws to the drivers.

headline: A Lesson in Sincerity, Trump Style
text: “Please hold for Mr. Trump,” the voice said on the telephone.

headline: Paring His Bucket List, Obama Relishes Hiking at an Alaskan Glacier
text: KENAI FJORDS NATIONAL PARK, Alaska — President Obama hiked alone up a gravel path toward Exit Glacier, gazing at a mass of flowing ice as it melted into the plain below.

headline: Micklethwait Memo
text: On Tuesday, the editor in chief of Bloomberg News, John Micklethwait, outlined a slew of changes — some organizational, some visual, and some editorial — and the thinking behind them in a lengthy email to the staff.

headline: Icelanders Use Facebook to Open Door to Refugees
text: Responding to a growing international crisis, thousands of Iceland’s residents have taken to social media to put pressure on their government to take in more migrants.

headline: With Technology, Avoiding Both Ads and the Blockers
text: When Allrecipes unveiled a revamped website on Tuesday, it billed the move as part of a broader transformation into a social network for food lovers. Among other new capabilities available to them, the site’s millions of users can now follow other cooks and share what they have made on Facebook.

text: Read all of our “Narcos” recaps.

headline: New York Attorney General Reaches Deal to End Litigation at Cooper Union
text: After a year of negotiations with warring parties at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, New York State’s attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, is expected on Wednesday to announce that his office has reached a settlement that would end litigation and create an independent monitor of the college’s management and finances.

headline: Kim Davis, a Local Fixture, and Now a National Symbol
text: MOREHEAD, Ky. — Before she ignited a firestorm over same-sex marriage, Kim Davis was known, for decades, as a woman behind the counter of a small county clerk’s office: a mild-mannered conduit for auto tag renewals, lien releases, land records and marriage certificates.

headline: Price of Crude Oil Tumbles After Soaring for 3 Days
text: HOUSTON — After three days of spiking oil prices, a barrel of crude tumbled back nearly 8 percent on Tuesday, renewing despair in the oil patch. At the same time, ConocoPhillips announced it was cutting its global work force by 10 percent.

headline: President Otto Pérez Molina Is Stripped of Immunity in Guatemala
text: MEXICO CITY — Guatemala’s Congress voted on Tuesday to strip President Otto Pérez Molina of his immunity from prosecution, a unanimous decision that acknowledged the outpouring of citizen demands for an end to entrenched impunity.

headline: Donald Young Comes From Behind by Not Looking Back
text: Gone are the days when Donald Young was considered the future of American tennis. In the 12 years since he turned professional, at 14, Young has lost more matches than he has won. He has battled nerves, critics and opponents. He has become an unabashed reader of self-help books — and pretty much anything else that might help him deal with adversity.

headline: Roger Federer, an Old Hand With a New Move, Keeps Everyone Guessing
text: Serena Williams was working out on Practice Court 1 on Monday, and between shots she glanced over at Roger Federer on the adjacent court to see for herself.

headline: Historical Symbols in Midst of a ‘Purge Moment’
text: WASHINGTON — In 1861, Union soldiers who were camped out in the Senate chamber attacked the desk of Jefferson Davis with a bayonet. Eager to destroy the symbol connected to Davis, who had resigned from the Senate to become president of the Confederacy, they were halted by an aide who insisted that the desk belonged to the government and that the military was “sent here to protect, not destroy.”

headline: Many Paths to Finding Peace
text: Maha Rose in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, offers traditional therapies, such as yoga and meditation, but also unconventional ones, like crystal bowl sound baths and tarot card readings.

headline: Free Your Mind
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — This offering from Kevin Christian and Brad Wilber rocked me out of my midweek blahs. In my view, it’s a sassy, bluesy grid that was a lot of fun to solve. This puzzle is the solving equivalent of sipping your third Scotch in a dark blues club after midnight. All you know is that you’re having a good time and the band is playing all your favorites.

headline: After Playing Down a Homeless Crisis, Mayor de Blasio Changes His Tone
text: In mid-July, facing a swelling public outcry over street homelessness in New York City, Mayor Bill de Blasio suggested that residents’ eyes were deceiving them. “Homelessness is not going up, thank God,” he said.

headline: Jets Put Jace Amaro on Injured Reserve With Shoulder Injury
text: Jace Amaro was placed on injured reserve with a torn labrum in his shoulder, costing the Jets a receiving threat at one of their weaker positions.

headline: Azerbaijan: Journalist Critical of Leader Is Sentenced to 7 1/2 Years in Prison
text: Khadija Ismayilova, an Azerbaijani investigative journalist, was sentenced Tuesday to 7 1/2 years in prison on charges including embezzlement and tax evasion. The sentence was handed down by the Court on Grave Crimes in Baku, the capital. Ms. Ismayilova is a contributor to Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, which is funded by the United States, and is known for reports questioning the sources of wealth of Azerbaijan’s president, Ilham Aliyev, and his family. During the trial, Ms. Ismayilova, 39, who was arrested in December, said she was innocent and accused the government of “lies.” Isabel Santos of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe’s Parliamentary Assembly, said in a statement that “with every journalist, human rights defender and civil society leader it harasses or jails, Azerbaijan distances itself further and further from democratic values.”

headline: Clashes Over Draft Constitution Kill 5 in Nepal
text: KATHMANDU — Violent protests over a draft of a new constitution broke out Tuesday in Nepal’s southern plains, the latest strife to imperil the new charter and draw accusations of police brutality from local leaders.

headline: Police and Pastors Seek to Curb Violence as Hartford’s Homicide Rate Soars
text: HARTFORD — On a sunny Sunday in August, the Salvation Army’s small North End congregation held its weekly worship service outside.

headline: Obama’s Alaska Tour Continues
text: On Tuesday, the president visited a melting glacier in the Kenai Mountains and bought some pastries at an Anchorage cafe.

headline: Yankees’ Betances Escapes Trouble, and Pineda Picks Up 10th Win
text: BOSTON — If many of his teammates had to be indoctrinated into the rich history between the Yankees and Red Sox, Dellin Betances, who grew up in Washington Heights, was steeped in it.

headline: New York City Reaches Deal With Bus Drivers Union on Safety Law
text: After clashing repeatedly this year over a new traffic safety law, Mayor Bill de Blasio and the city’s major bus drivers union came to a fragile truce this week.

headline: For Thousands of Exhausted Migrants, a Journey’s End in Munich
text: MUNICH — The journey for more than 2,000 migrants, who overcame border crossings, deprivation and erratic enforcement of European migration policies on a land route through southeastern Europe, ended Tuesday when the trains that had carried them from the Hungarian capital rolled into Munich’s vast main station.

headline: Mets’ Sudden Crowd Comes Up Empty
text: The Mets’ clubhouse resembled a traffic jam on the Grand Central Parkway on Tuesday.

headline: Blondell Cummings, Dancer of Life’s Everyday Details, Dies at 70
text: Blondell Cummings, a modern dancer and choreographer who mined quotidian experiences like washing, cooking and building to yield works celebrated for their rich characterizations and dramatic momentum, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 70.

headline: Nikolaus Lehnhoff, German Opera Director, Dies at 76
text: Nikolaus Lehnhoff, a German opera director who staged “Salome” at the Metropolitan Opera in New York and Wagner’s “Ring” cycle in San Francisco in the 1980s, but who was best known for his productions in Europe, died on Aug. 22 at his home in Berlin. He was 76.

headline: U.S. Stock Markets End Higher Though Global Concerns Linger
text: Stocks in the United States bounced back on Wednesday, a day after another sell-off on the global markets, even as worries about economic growth persisted.

headline: Fans, Lights and Andy Murray Beat Nick Kyrgios at U.S. Open
text: It did not take much to set off the volatile Australian Nick Kyrgios on Tuesday night at the U.S. Open. Troubled by the late-arriving fans, the positioning of the lights and the defensive range of Andy Murray, Kyrgios began to unravel. Quickly. It was precisely the sort of entertainment the crowd at Arthur Ashe Stadium was hoping to see.

headline: Noah Davis, 32, Artist and Founder of Underground Museum in Los Angeles, Dies
text: Noah Davis, a painter and installation artist who founded the Underground Museum, an exhibition space in a working-class neighborhood of Los Angeles that provides free art shows, died on Saturday at his home in Ojai, Calif. He was 32.

headline: Puerto Rico Electric Utility Is Said to Be Near Debt Deal
text: With a deadline approaching Tuesday night, the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority was close to an agreement with a group of bondholders for a restructuring of up to $5.7 billion of debt, according to two people with knowledge of the talks. The terms under consideration included a bond exchange, which would mean a permanent loss for participating bondholders, along with measures to increase the likelihood that the bondholders would be repaid on the new debt, those people said. By improving the utility’s creditworthiness, Prepa’s borrowing costs would also go down. The total face value of Prepa’s outstanding debt is about $8.1 billion; of that, about $2.4 billion has been insured. The negotiations cover only the remaining $5.7 billion. Prepa and its bondholders have been in restructuring talks for more than a year, and during that time its creditors agreed not to take any legal action to enforce their claims. The agreement was scheduled to expire at midnight on Tuesday, but people with knowledge of the talks said they expected that a deal would be announced early Wednesday.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
text: 10 P.M. (TCM) BARRY LYNDON (1975) An Irish rogue (Ryan O’Neal, above right, with James Magee) gambles, fights and seduces his way to the apex of 18th-century British society in Stanley Kubrick’s adaptation of William Makepeace Thackeray’s first novel. His undoing comes at the hand of a widowed beauty (Marisa Berenson), whose high station gives her license to be boring. This comedy of manners “is so long and leisurely, so panoramic in its narrative scope, that it’s as much an environment as it is a conventional film,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “Its austerity of purpose defines it as a costume movie unlike any other you’ve seen.” The film is part of a tribute to the Oscar-winning composer Leonard Rosenman, starting at 8 with “A Man Called Horse.”

headline: Questions Raised About Vietnam War Photos
text: PERPIGNAN, France — During last year’s Visa pour l’Image festival here, dramatic images by North Vietnamese photographers of the war with the United States were exhibited with great fanfare. The show was presented by a veteran war photographer, Patrick Chauvel, and the festival’s director, Jean Francois Leroy, as an unprecedented view of the Vietnam wars told by the virtually unknown photographers.

headline: North Korea Denies Apologizing for Land Mine Blasts
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Wednesday accused South Korea of misreading the two countries’ recent agreement on easing border tensions, insisting that Pyongyang’s expression of “regret” over the wounding of two soldiers from the South was never meant as an apology.

headline: Venezuela’s Manufactured Border Crisis
text: Late last month, President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela declared a state of emergency in areas that abut Colombia, shut down the border and ordered a mass roundup of Colombian immigrants. In a decree issued on Aug. 21, he warned that drug trafficking, contraband and rampant violence along the border made it necessary to suspend basic rights, such as public gatherings and demonstrations. After Venezuelan authorities evicted Colombians from their homes, some dwellings were marked with the letter D, meaning they would be demolished.

headline: Costly Hepatitis C Drugs for Everyone?
text: New drugs to treat hepatitis C are tremendously effective — and tremendously costly — raising fears that the high prices might outstrip the ability of public and private insurers to pay. Fortunately, competitive market forces and hard-nosed bargaining by insurers for big discounts are going a long way toward resolving the problem.

text: To the Editor:

headline: The Joe Biden Delusion
text: Many politicians seem intent on holding themselves as far back from us as possible, on parceling themselves out in only the smallest and most controlled bits. Even as they implore us to love them and insist that we trust them, they’re stingy. Cagey. Coiled.

headline: Our Radical Islamic BFF, Saudi Arabia
text: The Washington Post ran a story last week about some 200 retired generals and admirals who sent a letter to Congress “urging lawmakers to reject the Iran nuclear agreement, which they say threatens national security.” There are legitimate arguments for and against this deal, but there was one argument expressed in this story that was so dangerously wrongheaded about the real threats to America from the Middle East, it needs to be called out.

headline: Was It Cancer? Getting the Diagnosis
text: Sydney, Australia — I OFTEN wondered what it would be like to have a cancer growing inside your body. To suddenly discover you are carrying something that is eating you away, growing in an ugly, consuming mass in or around your bones or organs. To be blithely stepping through life, unaware that your insides are betraying you.

headline: What Donald Trump Understands About Republicans
text: Donald Trump’s success is no surprise. The public and the press have focused on his defiant rejection of mannerly rhetoric, his putting into words of what others think privately. But the more important truth is that a half-century of Republican policies on race and immigration have made the party the home of an often angry and resentful white constituency — a constituency that is now politically mobilized in the face of demographic upheaval.

headline: Obama, Visiting Arctic, Will Pledge Aid to Alaskans Hit by Climate Change
text: ANCHORAGE — President Obama on Wednesday will pledge to step up government aid for Arctic communities whose shorelines and infrastructure are crumbling as warming seas melt their foundations, intensifying his administration’s effort to cope with the effects of climate change where they are being felt most acutely.

headline: Living in the West Village
text: Cobblestone streets and small cafes predominate in many areas of the West Village, where about 80 percent of the neighborhood has landmark status.

headline: The West Village: Bohemian Past, Lofty Prices
text: The West Village of Manhattan is a place “where the streets are so tiny, so isolated from the hubbub of the rest of the city, they have managed to stay trapped in a time warp,” said Barry Benepe, an architect and urban planner who has rented an apartment on Jane Street since 1971 and was a founder of the city’s Greenmarket movement in 1976. Landmark designations have helped to maintain the human scale, he said. About 80 percent of the West Village has landmark status, said Andrew Berman, the executive director of the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation.

headline: Bat Flipping Draws Shrugs in South Korea but Scorn in America
text: DAEGU, South Korea — Hwang Jae-gyun, a third baseman for the Lotte Giants in South Korea’s top baseball league, received some curious text messages from his American teammates one morning in July. His name, they told him, was popping up on websites around the world. He was prominent on English-language social media websites.
