headline: Migrant Crisis Gives Germany Familiar Role in Another European Drama

headline: Stephen Colbert, the Late Night Hope
text: On a recent Monday night, Stephen Colbert was about as high atop the Ed Sullivan Theater as one can be, looking out over the 200 or so employees of his CBS “Late Show” who had gathered for a roof party as he stood on a staircase with a megaphone in hand.

headline: ‘The Silo Effect,’ by Gillian Tett
text: If you’ve ever worked for a large organization, you’ve probably had some version of the following experience: A project you’ve been working on for months is now going to be canceled because some other part of the organization was also working on a similar project, and apparently no one in your department even knew. Or: You find out some crucial piece of information or equipment you’ve been desperately searching for actually exists within your company, secretly hoarded by some rival internal faction that wanted to make sure no one else got to play with their proverbial toys.

headline: ‘$2.00 a Day,’ by Kathryn J. Edin and H. Luke Shaefer
text: From the late 1960s to the mid-1990s, a number of developments turned out to have profound effects on destitute families in the United States, which Kathryn J. Edin and H. Luke Shaefer’s “$2.00 a Day: Living on Almost Nothing in America” brings into sharp relief. Critics of welfare repeatedly argued that the increase of unwed mothers was mainly due to rising rates of welfare payments through Aid to Families With Dependent Children (A.F.D.C.). Even though the ­scientific ­evidence offered little support for this claim, the public’s outrage against the program, fueled by the “welfare queen” stereotype that Ronald Reagan peddled in stump speeches during his 1976 run for the presidency, led to calls for a major revamping of the welfare system.

headline: Passport Hints at a Uighur Link in Bangkok Bombing
text: BANGKOK — The Thai police said on Wednesday that their main suspect in a deadly attack on a Bangkok shrine has a Chinese passport indicating that he is from the far western region of Xinjiang but that they had not yet verified whether the passport was authentic.

headline: Today in Politics: Obama Has One Vote Left to Court on Iran Deal
text: Good Wednesday morning. In their arguments against the Iran nuclear deal, some Republican candidates have mocked President Obama for calling climate change the most serious threat facing the nation. It is worth noting then that the deal’s success might be assured while Mr. Obama is in the Arctic, warning of the effects of climate change.

headline: Can I Lie to My Father About Being Gay So He Will Pay for My College Education?
text: I am a young gay man in college. My father generously pays for my tuition and rent. The problem is that he does not know I am gay. He has made it very clear that if I were, he would not only withdraw all financial support but also cast himself entirely out of my life. His suspicion arose in high school when he found love letters between me and another male student. I swore they were meaningless and have since been defending my heterosexuality. Questions about my sexuality are inevitable whenever I come home. My father has demanded I produce archives of all emails and text messages for him to review, although I have successfully refused these requests on the grounds that he has no claim to my adult communications. Is it ethical for me to continue accepting financial support for my education and my career that will come from it? Could I continue to lie to accept the support and one day disclose my sexuality and pay him back to absolve myself of any ethical wrongdoing? NAME WITHHELD

headline: The Propane-Fueled Endless Summer
text: There is something wistful about a Labor Day cookout — something ever-so-slightly melancholy about putting those burgers and brats on the grill one last time before summer’s end. For many, the holiday marks the start of what Spy magazine once called ‘‘anxiety season’’ — time to ‘‘overstuff the briefcase, to yearn for a new apartment, fret about the raise, lose patience, work harder, fidget, stew, anguish, roil.’’ In anxiety season, we think there is no longer room for warm-weather pleasures like cooking outside.

headline: The Misanthropic Genius of Joy Williams
text: A few years ago, the writer Joy Williams’s favorite church needed to dispose of a few extra pews after a renovation. Williams attends the church only in April and October, when her frequent cross-country drives take her to Laramie, Wyo., but she wanted a pew anyway. She borrowed a trailer, got a friend to help her load the pew and drove a thousand miles, pulling it behind her enormous Bronco, her two German shepherds in the cab with her. Now the long, dark pew lives in her house in Tucson.

headline: Morning Agenda: Chinese Stocks Slide After U.S. Sell-Off
text: CHINESE STOCKS SLIDE AFTER U.S. SELL-OFF | Chinese stocks fell modestly on Wednesday after weak manufacturing data in the United States and China set American set American shares plummeting on Tuesday, Paul Mozur reports in DealBook. The Shanghai Composite closed down 0.2 percent, rebounding from a deeper slump earlier in the day.

headline: Bringing Tourism Back to Nepal
text: Darrell Wade, 54, is on a mission to bring tourism back to Nepal. The chief executive and a founder of Intrepid Travel recently spent a week in the country — his 14th visit — and saw firsthand how far it has come in recovering from the devastating earthquakes in April.

headline: Get Your Givenchy New York Fashion Week Tickets Now

It’s certainly a first for Givenchy.

headline: China’s Military Parades: A Look Back
text: Although the military parade in Beijing on Thursday will be the first in China to honor the anniversary of the end of World War II, major military pageants have been staged in the capital before, to celebrate the founding of the People’s Republic on Oct. 1, 1949. The parades were an annual event through the 1950s, then moved mostly to five- or 10-year intervals. Here are some glimpses of notable National Day parades from years past.

headline: Classical Music This Week: Milhaud, Jazz at Yale and Czech Baroque
text: Good morning, classical fans. The brunt of the season is just around the corner, so enjoy this last bit of summer relaxation. What will you be listening to over the long weekend? Put it in the comments section, email me at zach.woolfe@nytimes.com or tweet at @zwoolfe.

headline: 1940: New York Teems With Visitors
text: The largest Labor Day week-end crowd that ever descended on New York City began to journey homeward last night [Sept. 2], choking transport facilities with its volume and leaving behind a happy but tired legion of hotel, theater and restaurant managers to recover from the pleasant pain of being swamped by so much business that they turned away thousands of customers. Railroad stations and bus terminals were jammed when the out-of-town visitors on their way home met the horde of New Yorkers returning from summer fun to fall business. Precisely how many out-of-town visitors swarmed into the city during the three-day holiday was anybody’s guess. Maj. Benjamin H. Namm, chairman of Mayor F.H. La Guardia’s Official World Fair Housing Bureau, set the figure at 2,500,000. — New York Herald Tribune, September 3, 1940

headline: Baltimore Judge Lets Officers’ Charges Stand and Refuses to Remove Prosecutor
text: BALTIMORE — A circuit court judge ruled on Wednesday that six police officers facing criminal charges in the death of Freddie Gray will be tried separately, and denied a request by defense lawyers who wanted Marilyn J. Mosby, the state’s attorney for Baltimore City, removed from the case on grounds of conflict of interest and prosecutorial misconduct.

headline: The United Nations: Now and Then
text: The set of buildings in Manhattan has undergone a $2.15 billion renovation, known as the capital master plan. Here, recent and archival images are paired.

headline: U.N.’s Makeover Sacrifices Hammarskjold Library for Security
text: UNITED NATIONS — When the 70th regular session of the General Assembly convenes on Sept. 15, it will do so in a complex of buildings that hasn’t looked so good or felt so secure in generations.

text: Trends come and go. Technology is ever-changing. But as a new spate of films prove, boxing movies are here to stay.

headline: Austrian Police Find 24 Afghan Migrants Locked in a Van

headline: Coordinated Strategy Brings Obama Victory on Iran Nuclear Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Just before the Senate left town for its August break, a dozen or so undecided Democrats met in the Capitol with senior diplomats from Britain, China, France, Germany and Russia who delivered a blunt, joint message: Their nuclear agreement with Iran was the best they could expect. The five world powers had no intention of returning to the negotiating table.

headline: 1965: Fighting in Kashmir
text: NEW DELHI — Pakistan forces supported by tanks and jet planes advanced still further into Indian-held Kashmir territory today [Sept. 2], Indian officials said. They also acknowledged for the first time that Pakistani forces had occupied the towns of Chamb and Deva, six to eight miles inside the Indian part of the state. But the officials here said an Indian counterattack had slowed the advance, allegedly involving 3,000 men and 70 tanks. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 3, 1965

headline: Driven | 2016 Mazda CX-3
text: Diminutive crossovers are big business, and the subcompact crossover segment gains some sportiness with the 2016 Mazda CX-3.

headline: Video Review: Mazda CX-3 Is Stylish, Efficient and Fun to Drive
text: THE crossover lifestyle is appealing, even though few owners tow boats or tackle tough trails. Urban couples may find the new Mazda CX-3 to be all the vehicle they need. Daydreaming of conquering the Rubicon Trail? This is not your rig. It’s very happy on slippery streets in concrete canyons, though.

headline: Will Germany Succumb to Hate?
text: BERLIN — AMID the staccato ping of news generated by Europe’s migration crisis, perhaps nothing is more jarring than what is playing out in Germany. The country, which expects up to a million refugees to arrive this year and whose chancellor has been the Continent’s most outspoken advocate for accepting refugees, has also experienced more than 200 attacks, mostly arson, on homes for asylum seekers during the first six months of the year, according to the Ministry of Homeland Affairs.

text: Most TV viewers know Pedro Pascal as Oberyn Martell, the warrior prince who had his head caved in on “Game of Thrones.” But here’s something you might not know: He’s really good at undercover drug deals.

headline: Time-Worn Village in Moldova Springs Back to Life, Thanks to Port
text: GIURGIULESTI, Moldova — Like many rural villages throughout Europe, Giurgiulesti was shrinking. The young had left, seeking work and better futures, and they never came back. The old had stayed behind, tilling the fields and nurturing the grapes on backyard vines that they used to make wine.

headline: Iranian General Speaks of U.S. Enmity
text: The head of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, Maj. Gen. Mohammad Ali Jafari, referred to the United States as “the Great Satan” and said its hostility toward the Islamic Revolution had grown.

headline: Before the Pope’s Visit, a 180-Foot-Tall Francis Arrives in Midtown
text: On Tuesday afternoon, Van Hecht-Nielsen had just finished painting the elbow of a 180-foot-tall Pope Francis overlooking Madison Square Garden, when he took a break for lunch.

headline: College Football’s Opening Week Evolves From Mismatches to Can’t-Miss Matches
text: ATLANTA — Eight years ago, Alabama Coach Nick Saban had a football program to resurrect. So when he was approached about beginning the 2008 season, his second at Alabama, with an August game against Clemson in the Georgia Dome, Saban agreed almost immediately.

headline: Prison Officials Join Movement to Curb Solitary Confinement
text: In a sign of how far the nation has moved from supporting solitary confinement for inmates, the leading organization for the nation’s prison and jail administrators on Wednesday called for sharply limiting or even ending its use for extended periods.

headline: A Trio of New Paris Tables
text: In Paris, three new restaurants with open-air seating are just the place to get comfortable, share a meal and watch the city — and the final days of summer — pass by.

headline: Senator Voices Support for Iran Deal
text: Senator Chris Coons, a Democrat from Delaware, explained why he decided not to oppose a landmark accord on Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: New York City Council Speaker Endorses Hillary Clinton for President
text: Speaker Melissa Mark-Viverito of the New York City Council endorsed Hillary Rodham Clinton for president on Wednesday, reinforcing Democratic support for Mrs. Clinton in her home state and possibly offering her a boost in Ms. Mark-Viverito’s native Puerto Rico.

headline: Paula Deen and a Train Hero Join ‘Dancing With the Stars’
text: ABC announced the full cast of the 21st season of “Dancing With the Stars” on Wednesday morning, adding to the lineup Alek Skarlatos, a specialist in the Oregon National Guard who helped avert a train disaster in France, and the celebrity chef Paula Deen, whose reputation was stained after she admitted in 2013 to using racial slurs in the past.

headline: The Oregon Shakespeare Festival Focuses on Diversity
text: ASHLAND, ORE. — A first-time visitor to the Oregon Shakespeare Festival might be struck by any number of things. The festival’s idyllic location in this small city surrounded by vistas of rolling hills. Or the splendid Tudor-style outdoor Elizabethan theater, just one of the three spaces where performances take place six days a week for more than seven months, for an impressive total of roughly 800 shows.

headline: John Gachot’s Back-to-School Lunchbox Doodles
text: The interior designer, who has worked with Marc Jacobs, Gucci and Boucheron, shares notes to tuck into kids’ lunches.

headline: Back-to-School Lunchbox Notes From Marc Jacobs’s Interior Designer
text: The interior designer John Gachot has been responsible for decorating Marc Jacobs’s townhouse, the Tumblr founder David Karp’s Williamsburg apartment and the Smyth Hotel in Tribeca; he’s done interiors for the likes of Bottega Veneta, Gucci and Boucheron. He’s also a dedicated father: He and his wife and fellow designer, Christine, have two boys, Boris and Jackie, aged 13 and 8, who are very close despite wildly different personalities. “Where Boris is our mild-mannered peace, love and rock ‘n’ roll child, Jackie is a powerhouse of ambition and energy,” Gachot says. “He recently turned our kitchen stools into a sculpture called Jackefeller Center, and would get to work on time each day.”

headline: Jessica Raine, a Star of ‘Call the Midwife,’ on Returning to the ’50s With Agatha Christie
text: In her final year at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London, Jessica Raine was told by a teacher that she had a modern face and should expect to be cast in modern roles. And sure enough, after graduation Ms. Raine portrayed a defiant goth and a drugged-out politician’s daughter in quick succession at the National Theater.

headline: Trump Campaign: Carnival Sideshow, yes. But also dangerous and irresponsible.
text: Times editorial page editor Andrew Rosenthal on Donald Trump

headline: Is Ben Carson Really the Anti-Trump?
text: In this over-polled, over-long, over-crowded Republican presidential contest, the spin of the day is that Ben Carson, the former neurosurgeon who touts his scientific background but rejects science on little things like evolution and global warming, is challenging Donald Trump for the supposed lead in the alleged campaign.

headline: Kentucky Clerk Who Said ‘No’ to Gay Couples Won’t Be Alone in Court
text: MOREHEAD, Ky. — Of the local officials who refuse to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, Kim Davis, the clerk here in Rowan County, Ky., is the best known, at least for now.

headline: Backpack Makers Rethink a Student Staple
text: The inside of Alejandro Sarete’s backpack is jammed with the objects of a busy student life: smartphone, USB thumb drive, playing cards, lip balm. Cho Young-Uk’s shoulder bag is more minimalist in content: Lenovo laptop and adapter.

headline: Photographic Portraits From West Africa at the Met
text: From the 1840s on, European photographers traveled all over the world looking for exotic subjects, and people in the places they visited enthusiastically adopted the new medium for themselves. West Africa was one such locale. “In and Out of the Studio: Photographic Portraits from West Africa,” now open at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, presents nearly 80 pieces dating from the 1870s to the 1970s by professional and amateur photographers living and working in a region bordered by Senegal and Mali in the northwest and Cameroon and Gabon in the southeast.

headline: Executive at Struggling Rovio, Maker of Angry Birds, Pushes Silver Lining
text: STOCKHOLM — The signs are still not looking good for the maker of Angry Birds.

headline: Annie Gosfield, Scoring the Music of Machines
text: One of the composer Annie Gosfield’s favorite mementos is a faded pink ticket for a 1980 show by Planet Z, a rock band she played keyboards with, at the Hong Kong Cafe in downtown Los Angeles. The small living room in the East Village apartment where she has lived since arriving in New York in 1992 is crammed with other souvenirs of her eclectic life: a shelf with hat blocks next to shelves of records, a shortwave radio, a guitar, an old desktop computer and the small desk where she works.

headline: Jeanine Durning in Constant Motion at the Chocolate Factory
text: Jeanine Durning’s work, a labyrinth of accumulation featuring looping, half-finished thoughts and precise, nuanced movement, drives its own beat. In the solo “inging,” a 2010 piece based on unscripted speaking, her task is to talk. It’s a relentless practice in which language, more than movement, becomes the choreography. In her latest work, “To Being,” she shifts her focus from the voice to the body to explore the precariousness of a dancer moving ceaselessly in performance. Her underlying question: “How can we give more when all we feel is that we’ve met our limit?” The work, which also includes the dancers Julian Barnett and Molly Poerstel and sound by Tian Rotteveel, delves even more deeply into her research practice known as “nonstopping,” which means moving but never arriving. The Chocolate Factory, however, has arrived: This treasured performance space celebrates its 10th anniversary with the premiere of “To Being” (Sept. 9-19) and the reprisal of “inging” (Sept. 23-26).

headline: Jeb Bush’s Dig at Donald Trump Requires a Show of Hands
text: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida made his offensive against Donald J. Trump more personal on Wednesday, highlighting his fear of germs as another reason that Republicans should reconsider their summer fling with the billionaire tycoon.

headline: Hans Werner Henze’s ‘Kammermusik 1958’ Gets a New Staging
text: The German composer Hans Werner Henze, who died at 86 in 2012, wrote richly scored, emotive orchestral, chamber and vocal works that often proved a stark contrast to the avant-garde music of his contemporaries. He wrote “Kammermusik 1958,” a 12-movement chamber piece for tenor, guitar and eight instruments, during a visit to Greece that year. Set to texts by the poet Friedrich Hölderlin, the work was dedicated to Benjamin Britten; the guitarist Julian Bream and the tenor Peter Pears performed at the premiere.

headline: Masked Gunmen Kidnap 17 Turkish Workers in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — In the early morning darkness on Wednesday, masked gunmen in military uniforms rolled up in more than a dozen black sport utility vehicles to a construction site on the edge of Baghdad, subdued the guards, and roused 17 Turkish workers and their Iraqi translator from sleep and kidnapped them.

headline: Kerry Warns Against No Vote on Iran Deal
text: Secretary of State John Kerry, in a speech in Philadelphia on Tuesday, warned of the consequences if the United States walks away unilaterally from the Iran nuclear deal.

headline: Comfortable at Plate, Jackie Bradley Jr. Eases Boston’s Concerns
text: BOSTON — Jackie Bradley Jr. has a voice as gentle as an evening breeze and barely more audible. The problem was that for much of the last three seasons, his bat was just as quiet.

headline: 36 Hours in Rio
text: Rio has a new cosmopolitan edge, with a reinvigorated downtown, recently opened museums and a diverse cuisine that ranges from Amazonian to old-school European.

headline: Baltimore Protests for Freddie Gray Case
text: Demonstrators gathered outside the Baltimore City Courthouse, where six police officers were facing charges in the arrest and death of Freddie Gray.

headline: Idris Elba Responds to Author, and Lets ‘the Street’ Do the Talking
text: On Tuesday, after an interview with the novelist Anthony Horowitz was published in which he shared his belief that Idris Elba was “too street” to take over as James Bond, seemingly the entire Internet let the author know he was wrong. Mr. Horowitz, the latest in a line of writers to pen 007 books, quickly decided that the actor was in fact suave enough for the role and issued an apology.

headline: 36 Hours in Rio de Janeiro
text: For decades, Rio de Janeiro has evoked a distant fantasyland of skimpy bathing suits and Carnival spectacle wedged between the sea and a riotous upheaval of tropical mountains. All this, under the outstretched arms of Christ the Redeemer, the sculpture with the most jaw-dropping view on Earth — if only soapstone jaws could drop. But the 2010s have given Rio a chance to add a cosmopolitan edge as host of last year’s World Cup and next year’s Summer Olympics, twice making it the center of the world. The new Rio is taking shape in fits and starts: The downtown port area is in the midst of an impressive overhaul of public works, exhumed historic sites and new museums. And with it, energy has been flowing toward more central, bustling neighborhoods, away from the traditional South Zone destinations of Copacabana and Ipanema — though their beaches still give a party on the sand like no other. And with the dollar at its strongest in over a decade against the troubled Brazilian real, traditionally pricey Rio is still exuberant, but no longer exorbitant.

headline: Basketball Break
text: One apparel company’s version of a team lunch.

headline: Police and Migrants Clash in Budapest
text: The police in Budapest tried to stop migrants leaving the city’s main train station on Wednesday, which led to a large demonstration.

headline: For One Apparel Brand, Staying Fit Is Just Part of the Job
text: Once a month, while the weather still permits, the staff at the recreational activewear line Outdoor Voices has a different kind of team lunch: a friendly game of basketball, or “Friday dribble dribble,” as they call it. Around 1 p.m., they lace up and walk past Canal Street’s own lineup — countless vendors, hawking handbags and tchotchkes — to Grand Canal Court, about eight minutes away. Tyler Haney, the company’s 26-year-old founder and C.E.O., grew up in Boulder, Colo., where, she says, “casual activity is baked into everything you do.” Fittingly, the brand’s key tenet, “Doing Things,” embodies a relaxed approach to fitness; and through its signature array of crop tops, leggings, sweats and shorts in subdued hues, Outdoor Voices seeks to close the gap between your gym life and... every other aspect of your life.

headline: Switzerland Investigates Fund Executives in Malaysian Scandal
text: GENEVA — The Swiss authorities said on Wednesday that they had started a criminal investigation of two executives of a Malaysian state investment fund at the center of a corruption scandal that has led to calls for Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia to resign.

headline: Just a Book? No, More Like a Trusty Companion
text: The book I wish I could read again for the first time — and the book, I’ve long felt, I most wish I had written — is “Mystery Train: Images of America in Rock ’n’ Roll Music,” by Greil Marcus.

headline: Sharing Economy Goes Hyperlocal With a Growing Market for Household Items
text: When vandals broke into Stephanie Ciancio’s Land Cruiser in 2014 and stole her car stereo, she did not have the time and money to replace it. It was particularly vexing for Ms. Ciancio, a 34-year-old San Francisco resident, because she had been planning to take a four-day road trip to Fern Canyon, Calif., over the long July 4 weekend, and the idea of making the eight-hour drive without music was depressing.

headline: Hillary Clinton Proposes $10 Billion Plan to Combat Drug Epidemic
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday released plans for a $10 billion initiative to combat the escalating drug epidemic that she says has swept through rural America and has emerged as a regular concern among voters she has met in the early nominating states.

headline: Short Sleepers May Catch More Colds
text: Want to avoid catching a cold this winter? Start by getting more than six hours of sleep a night.

headline: Copy Roger Federer? He Has No Shot
text: It was not until I was given this assignment that I realized the embarrassing truth: I am actually trying to be Roger Federer. This would be fine if I were still a child; back then, I tried to be Julius Erving. But really, I should be past this.

headline: Julie Kent Has New Roles at American Ballet Theater
text: Julie Kent, the star ballerina who retired as a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater in June, is taking on several new roles with the company, including as the artistic director of its summer intensive programs for young dancers.

text: If mass incarceration is one of modern America’s deepest pathologies, solitary confinement is the concentrated version of it: far too many people locked up for far too long for no good reason, at no clear benefit to anyone.

But since last week, when the first of six prisoners tested positive for Legionnaires’ disease, those ramparts seem to have also turned the prison into a petri dish.

text: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan unveils a special chair ahead of the papal Mass at Madison Square Garden in New York this month.

headline: London Theater Journal: Rehab and Resistance
text: Toward the end of Duncan Macmillan’s “People, Places and Things,” a portrait of a skeptic in the church of Alcoholics Anonymous, I began to think that I had misjudged it. At that point, the scene had shifted from the rehab center, where most of the work is set, to the childhood home of the show’s central figure for the expected day of reckoning with Mom and Dad.

headline: Fool’s Gold Concert to Feature the Energy of Meek Mill and More
text: Since its 2010 debut in a SoHo parking lot, the Fool’s Gold Presents Day Off party has been an annual barometer of the fertile space where hip-hop meets dance music, a space where Fool’s Gold, the label, thrives and innovates. This year’s lineup emphasizes high energy, radiating from the vanquished hip-hop warrior Meek Mill, looking for redemption; the fiercely rumbling grime don Skepta; the saucy, wavy, trippy rapper Post Malone; the polyglot club bounce D.J.-producer Brenmar; the punchy updater of ’90s R&B Bosco; and many more. All of it will be interwoven with D.J. sets by the Fool’s Gold label founders A-Trak and Nick Catchdubs, masters of this domain and of its many copycats, too. (4 p.m., Monday, Brooklyn Live at the Inlet, foolsgoldrecs.com.)

headline: ‘Arthur & George’ Makes Sherlock Holmes’s Creator the Detective
text: In the time it took to puff on his pipe, Sherlock Holmes would have discerned everything: the eavesdropper at the private club as well as his name, political persuasion and place of birth — all from the dust on his shoes. But Sir Arthur Conan Doyle? Shockingly oblivious, a detractor declares in “Arthur & George” (Sundays on PBS). “If you pursue your interest in the Edalji case, you’ll be judged by his high standards, and judged harshly,” the man chides Holmes’s creator. “But if you fall short, as you are bound to do, you’ll taint not only yourself but the world’s favorite consulting detective.”

headline: ‘Apu Trilogy’ Screens at BAM Cinématek
text: “Everyone has their reasons” is the immortal line from Jean Renoir’s masterpiece “The Rules of the Game.” A similar openhearted humanity characterizes the films of the Indian auteur Satyajit Ray, and never more so than in “The Apu Trilogy,” at BAM Cinématek in Brooklyn from Wednesday through Saturday.

headline: Wedding Gifts That Give Back
text: Some presents for bridal couples provide assistance for those in need around the world.

headline: A Nursery for Newborn Stars in the Prawn Nebula
text: A telescope at La Silla Observatory in Chile has captured three clusters of bright newborn stars in the Prawn Nebula, a dense concentration of ionized gas and dust. Just a few million years old, the stars glow in ultraviolet light, illuminating the nebula’s gas clouds as well. The young stars form from the remnants of old stars that died in supernova explosions. The nebula is about 6,000 light-years from Earth, in the constellation Scorpius.

headline: William Buchina’s “Time to Speak a Human Language”
text: The artist will show new paintings at Garis & Hahn starting next week.

headline: Meticulously Assembled Paintings That Find Grace in the Gesture
text: The artist William Buchina is no snob: athletes in motion interest him no more than the fans who cheer or mope on the Jumbotron. The things that fascinate Buchina, he says, are “the contortions of the body, the look on the face, the strain of the muscles” in human movement. And the people he depicts are often cropped or abstracted to just that — the jutting of a jaw, the torque of a torso. Each painting in “Time to Speak a Human Language,” a new solo exhibition comprising nearly a dozen new works on canvas along with some older pieces, features images from many distinct sources. Buchina reworks these images, often altering, layering or abstracting them beyond recognition.

headline: Review: ‘Miley Cyrus & Her Dead Petz’ Puts Faith in the Weird
text: MILEY CYRUS

headline: Spielberg’s DreamWorks Studio Expected to End Distribution Pact With Disney

headline: Stephen Colbert and J.J. Abrams Team Up for Montclair Film Festival
text: Stephen Colbert may be the sort of fantasy-narrative geek who can quote at length from “The Lord of the Rings” and occasionally invoke it in just the right way to make Jon Stewart feel warm and fuzzy. But this incoming “Late Show” host is no scruffy-looking nerf herder when it comes to his worship of the “Star Wars” franchise, either, having featured its creator, George Lucas, on “The Colbert Report” and hosted him in conversation at the Tribeca Film Festival in May.

headline: Understanding Mac OS X Disk Permissions, and How to Repair Them
text: With time and use, actions like installing or uninstalling programs may inadvertently alter these permissions from their initial state, but there’s a fix to restore them.

headline: Andrew Cuomo Doesn’t Discourage Joe Biden From Presidential Bid
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York endorsed Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential bid months ago. But on Wednesday, he did not discourage Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. from entering the race.

text: Residents of Fox Lake, Ill., as well as Representative Robert Dold, expressed their grief after the shooting death of Lt. Charles Joseph Gliniewicz.

headline: Donald Trump Says Jeb Bush Should Stop Speaking Spanish
text: A day after taking steps to warm relations with Hispanics, Donald J. Trump may have taken a step backward Wednesday when he suggested that Jeb Bush was setting a bad example by speaking Spanish.

headline: Competitors Accuse Google of Using Search to Diminish Apps
text: If you have ever browsed the web on a mobile phone, you have probably encountered what technology people call an “app install interstitial” – those pop-up banners that ask: “Would you like to install the mobile app?”

headline: Universal Music Posts Strong Results, and Streaming Is a Bright Spot
text: In another sign of the growing importance of online streaming to the music business, the Universal Music Group had increased revenue and earnings for the first half of 2015, largely because of the popularity of streaming and subscription outlets like Spotify and Deezer.

headline: War Crimes Trial Opens for Bosco Ntaganda, Congolese Rebel Leader
text: PARIS — Bosco Ntaganda is not the first person accused of war crimes to appear voluntarily before the International Criminal Court, but the former Congolese rebel commander and once powerful crime boss is the first to do so after turning himself in at an American Embassy.

headline: For the Former OHWOW Gallery’s First Outing, a Provocative Show
text: The artist Nick van Woert culls inspiration from the past, frequently remixing artifacts and evoking history to build his art. His latest, “Just Dropped in to See What Condition My Condition Was In,” on view starting next Saturday at Moran Bondaroff, the just-rebranded L.A. gallery formerly known as OHWOW, borrows its title from a well-known 1968 Kenny Rogers hit.

headline: Classical Playlist: Matt Haimovitz, Avalon String Quartet and Eighth Blackbird
text: “Orbit”: Music for Solo Cello (1945-2014) Matt Haimovitz, cello(Pentatone)In this fascinating three-disc survey of music for solo cello written since the end of World War II, this ferociously talented cellist brings his megawatt sound and uncommon expressive gifts to a vast variety of styles, often with surprising results. Mr. Haimovitz finds sensuality in Pierre Boulez, Baroque stringency in Philip Glass and Verdian drama in Salvatore Sciarrino. By turns heartwarming, scary, playful and groovy, this recording reveals worlds inside a single instrument. The ghost of Bach is never far away, of course, but the specter Mr. Haimovitz conjures most vividly is that of Jimi Hendrix, whose rendition of “The Spar-Spangled Banner” he imitates in all its subversive brilliance.

headline: Satanists, Vegans and Atheists Seek Equal Opportunity in Little Rock
text: What atheists, vegans, Hindus and Satanic cultists have in common lately is an eye for the statehouse grounds of Arkansas. The groups have separately proposed public displays of their own spiritual values in Little Rock now that the state government has approved a Ten Commandments memorial for the Capitol grounds.

headline: Review: ‘Our Last Game,’ the Ultimate Locker Room Pep Talk
text: In sports dramas, the coach’s locker room talk matters more than the game.

headline: Ailing Baritone Will Return to the Met
text: The esteemed baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky, who canceled all his performances this summer to receive treatment for a brain tumor, plans to return to the stage this month for three performances of Verdi’s “Il Trovatore” at the Metropolitan Opera, the company said Wednesday.

headline: Review: Pianist Soheil Nasseri Puts a New Touch on Classical Standards
text: Soheil Nasseri, a pianist known for his unorthodox programming choices, performed a recital made up of early-19th-century standards on Tuesday at Merkin Concert Hall. The lineup included such chestnuts as Schubert’s Sonata in G (D. 894), a Chopin Ballade and Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony.

headline: Managing the Costs of Long-Term Care Insurance
text: New York consumers are among the latest to receive word of double-digit increases in the premiums they must pay to keep their insurance coverage for long-term care.

headline: A New Video From an André Saraiva-Approved Musical Duo
text: For Heather Golden Schwalb and Emma Rose Jenney, the duo behind the band Beau, music began as a collaborative hobby. The pair — who grew up in downtown Manhattan and attended PS 3 on Hudson Street — would toy with guitar riffs and songwriting in their free time together, recording the results on their phones and playing small local venues or friends’ art shows.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
text: It’s September, but you still have a few days to savor summer. Lisa Perry is having a giant sale at her summer pop-up in SoHo through Sunday with deals of up to 80 percent off on space age bits like a suede lunar dress ($461, originally $1,595). Everything must go so Ms. Perry can transform the space for her spring fashion show on Sept. 9. At 154 Prince Street.

headline: Natalie Massenet, Net-a-Porter Founder, Announces Departure
text: LONDON — Natalie Massenet, the founder of Net-a-Porter and the woman who persuaded high fashion that it had a home online, is leaving the British luxury e-commerce group she built, just five months after announcing a merger with its Italian archrival, Yoox.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
text: Italy and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: The Collapse of Band of Outsiders
text: A once-hot fashion label that abruptly shut down.

headline: Exploring Blue Hill in Maine
text: With scenery that brings out the poet within, it is little wonder that the Blue Hill peninsula in Maine has quietly become a writers’ enclave.

headline: September 2, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Italy, Greece, Hungary and India.

headline: The National Music Museum, an Unlikely Eden in South Dakota
text: As you walk toward the cello believed to be the oldest in the world, the nearly 500-year-old instrument has its back turned to you. But the discourtesy grows forgivable on approach: The Amati “King” cello’s rear side is its most seductive feature, with richly colored paintings — crowns, winged putti, columns, fleurs-de-lis, Justice hoisting a sword — that take on glowing depth beneath the varnish.

headline: Nikki Haley Says Black Lives Matter Movement Is Endangering Black Lives
text: Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina, who won accolades for swiftly moving to remove the Confederate flag from the grounds of the state capitol after the June massacre of nine black churchgoers, sharply criticized the Black Lives Matter movement on Wednesday.

headline: ‘(T)error’ Focuses on Informant and Piques F.B.I.’s Interest
text: In the winter of 2011, a former Black Panther named Saeed Torres moved to Pittsburgh, saying he was going to work undercover for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. There, he began monitoring a former convict, Khalifah al-Akili, who had been posting social media messages professing his admiration for the Taliban.

headline: Band of Outsiders: Fast Rise, Faster Fall
text: At a private dinner in Los Angeles last fall to mark its 10th anniversary, Band of Outsiders and its founder and creative force, Scott Sternberg, showed off the sensibility that GQ once called a “whimsical mix of Wes Anderson chic and California cool.”

headline: Michael Feinstein and the Club 54 Below Agree to a Partnership
text: Two of the biggest names in cabaret — Michael Feinstein and 54 Below — are joining forces. The Midtown Manhattan supper club, nicknamed “Broadway’s living room,” in the basement of the former disco Studio 54, will be renamed Feinstein’s/54 Below. And Mr. Feinstein, the singer and pianist known as the ambassador of the Great American Songbook, will play his first engagement there, Dec. 20-30. Thereafter, he will appear twice annually.

headline: At the U.S. Open, ‘Center Court Is Like a Runway’
text: Snakeskin print. Lace. Camouflage. Neon. Plaid. Stripes. Color blocking.

headline: Republican Party Asks Candidates to Sign Loyalty Pledge
text: Responding to growing pressure from party donors and officials to dissuade Donald J. Trump from mounting an independent campaign for president, the Republican National Committee on Wednesday asked each of the party’s presidential candidates to sign a statement vowing not to run as a third-party candidate.

headline: Review: ‘Thunderbitch’ Features Brittany Howard of Alabama Shakes
text: “I’m a wild child!” Brittany Howard shouts on the debut album by Thunderbitch, and she leaves no doubt about it. Thunderbitch is where Ms. Howard, who leads Alabama Shakes, gets to blow off steam playing rock ’n’ roll, whooping and hollering with no pressure to innovate or make big statements. It has self-explanatory song titles like “I Just Wanna Rock n Roll,” “Leather Jacket” and “Eastside Party,” and the music reaches back to Chuck Berry and the Rolling Stones, charged with late-1960s adrenaline. It’s a joy to hear.

headline: Review: ‘Lightless,’ About the Bratty Machine on a Spaceflight
text: However you feel about your computer — and I do not believe mine has my best interests at heart — be grateful that it has not taken this opportunity to seize control of your spaceship, flash a bunch of alarming lights on and off, and announce: “There is no god but me.”

headline: Inside a Cloistered Monastery: Joy and Love
text: A community of cloistered nuns showed Toni Greaves the intense joy and love that come from having found one’s true calling.

headline: Insurer Says Clients on Daily Pill Have Stayed H.I.V.-Free
text: Demonstrating that taking a daily pill to prevent H.I.V. infection can work in the real world, San Francisco’s largest private health insurer announced Wednesday that not one of its 657 clients receiving the drug had become infected over a period of more than two years.

headline: On Ocean Beach, Last Call Before the Ship Sails
text: “I literally just smelled every brand of cologne that exists,” Vivian Kim, 22, said to two male friends at the Fire Island Ferries port in Bay Shore, N.Y.

headline: App Smart | The Best of Windows 10 Apps
text: One of the big ideas for Windows 10 is that the same “universal” apps can run on a PC, tablet or even smartphone instead of separate versions for each. Here are some of the best ones.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: The Republican National Committee Presidential Loyalty Oath
text: The national party sent this statement to each of the Republican campaigns on Wednesday as part of an effort to dissuade Donald J. Trump from running as an independent next year. Each of the other candidates have already indicated they will support the Republican nominee.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Israel Considers Ammunition to Counter Palestinian Stone Throwers
text: JERUSALEM — The government of Israel said on Wednesday that it was considering sharper measures against Palestinians who throw stones and firebombs, including allowing more use of live ammunition and creating legislation that would impose minimum sentences on youths convicted of such actions.

headline: At Color Runs, Partying Is the Finish Line
text: It was Saturday night at the giant Aviator Sports complex at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn, and 20,000 millennials dressed in T-shirts, shorts and glow-in-the-dark necklaces were dancing to electronic music. D.J.’s kept the tempo upbeat, while dancers on stage threw confetti and beach balls into the beer-fueled and sweaty crowd.

headline: Emily Blunt Plunges Into the Drug War’s Morass in ‘Sicario’
text: As “Sicario” opens, an F.B.I. agent played by Emily Blunt leads her bristling-with-armor kidnap-response team into a dangerous mission.

headline: Video Feature: ‘Universal’ Apps for Windows 10 That Call Many Gadgets Home
text: One of the big ideas underlying Microsoft’s new Windows 10 operating system is “universal” apps, meaning the same version can run on a personal computer, tablet and smartphone — no separate version is required for each gadget.

headline: Advocates in Denver, Home to Legal Marijuana, Seek Public Place to Smoke
text: DENVER — Whether bought from a downtown shop or cadged from a friend’s basement greenhouse, legal marijuana is easy to find in Colorado. Places to smoke it, not so much.

headline: Marco Rubio Says Government Should Respect Kim Davis’s Beliefs
text: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida said on Wednesday that the government should respect the beliefs of the Kentucky county clerk who has denied marriage licenses to same-sex couples, arguing that society needs to accommodate public officials who object to carrying out duties they say violate their religious beliefs.

headline: Michigan Imam Visits Amir Hekmati, Longest-Held American in Iran
text: In a surprising development, the Iranian judicial authorities last week permitted a well-known Islamic cleric from the United States to visit with Amir Hekmati, a Marine veteran who is the longest-held American prisoner in Iran.

headline: Cycling Caps Return as a Fashion Statement
text: At the Moschino men’s show in June, the models wore either golden crowns or bicycle caps. In a few looks, crowns were worn atop the caps.

headline: Serena Williams Labors in a Win, and Then a Workout
text: Shortly after winning a surprisingly competitive second-round match against Kiki Bertens that lasted 1 hour 32 minutes in warm conditions, Serena Williams and her coach, Patrick Mouratoglou, went back to the practice court and hit balls for almost an hour.

headline: Street Dreams Magazine Flips the Script, Bringing Instagram to Print
text: If the measure of a successful party is the sidewalk overflow, then Street Dreams magazine had arrived.

headline: Mardy Fish Gives Way to a Spaniard and the Heat and Heads Into Retirement
text: Mardy Fish could barely walk by the end. As his match against Feliciano López and his career as a professional tennis player hobbled toward the finish, Fish hopped on his left leg as his right hamstring cramped in the midday heat.

headline: Vintage Cars and Rich Aficionados
text: Wealthy car lovers gathered for a week of collecting and admiring.

headline: Brutal Images of Syrian Boy Drowned Off Turkey Must Be Seen, Activists Say
text: At least 12 refugees fleeing the war in Syria, including two young boys, drowned on Wednesday while trying to reach the Greek island of Kos from the Turkish resort town of Bodrum, according to Turkey’s state-owned Anadolu news agency.

headline: Fast Feet Take the Day (or Night)
text: It was Friday night at the Attic, a rooftop lounge above a Hilton Garden Inn on West 48th Street, and contestants from “RuPaul’s Drag Race” were arriving to entertain the packed house of frisky clubgoers.

headline: ‘Time Out of Mind’ and ‘Shelter’: Next in Line at Cinema’s Soup Kitchen
text: It’s a curious fact that one of the most popular characters in motion-picture history is homeless: Charlie Chaplin’s Little Tramp. Although Chaplin’s creation took on a life of his own, he set the tone for the complex interplay between art and authenticity in the depiction of homelessness. In the decades since, the portrayals have been a decidedly mixed bag (or bindle).

headline: Another Single Week of Sales for Christie’s This Fall, With Modigliani as Its Star
text: Christie’s announced Wednesday that it would again hold its main evening sales during a single week this fall — repeating a formula that it said had proved successful in the spring — and that it would be selling a Modigliani painting that it estimated could make as much as $100 million.

headline: ‘Seventeen’ and ‘Cooley High’: No Easy A’s, but Powerful Lessons
text: “Life is nothing but high school,” Kurt Vonnegut once told an interviewer. “Class officers, cheerleaders and all.” To which, Joel DeMott and Jeff Kreines, the makers of the once-banned, now-classic made-for-TV documentary “Seventeen” (1982), out on DVD from Icarus Films, might add: substance abuse, racial tension, problematic romantic relationships and issues with authority.

headline: Private Equity Firms Circle Petco
text: First PetSmart was sold to a private equity firm. Then its main rival in the business of selling dog treats and catnip, Petco, began preparing itself for an initial public offering, nearly a decade after its leveraged buyout.

headline: How to Get the Geek Chic Look
text: Here, some options to mix and clash (and don’t forget the clunky specs).

headline: Fall’s Geek Chic Look
text: Call it geek chic, “Royal Tenenbaums” redux or Bedford Avenue granny (as Style.com did), this fall’s eccentric back-to-school look will soften the blow of summer coming to an end. The look, seen on the runways at Miu Miu and Gucci, among others, is a quirky mix of colors, prints and textures, pulled together in a way that somehow makes perverse sense. It’s a youthfully naïve approach to dressing that feels fresh and fun. Here, some options to mix and clash (and don’t forget the clunky specs).

headline: Trinity Guardrails Will Face Tests Again, This Time by the State of Virginia
text: Trinity Industries, which has been accused of producing a faulty guardrail that can jam and spear through vehicles, will face more aggressive testing of its guardrails, but this time the tests will be conducted by a state.

headline: Ukraine Weighs Autonomy for Parts of East, Already in Russia’s Thrall
text: KIEV, Ukraine — A loud, angry and violent protest this week over a parliamentary measure to grant a greater degree of self-rule to Ukraine’s secessionist eastern districts overlooked one little-recognized fact: To a great extent, the rebel areas have already achieved an autonomy surpassing that envisioned in the measure.

headline: It's a Wrap! ‘Goodnight Mommy,’ ‘Phoenix’ and Other Movies With Bandaged Stars
text: Actors bare their souls, but some must hide their faces.

headline: Yanks Demolish Red Sox Pitchers, Then Try Not to Crumble
text: BOSTON — As in home renovation TV shows in which the new owners gleefully take a sledgehammer to outdated kitchen cabinets, sometimes it is just cathartic to wreck things.

headline: In a First, Chinese Navy Sails Off Alaska
text: WASHINGTON — Five Chinese Navy ships were sailing in international waters of the Bering Sea off the coast of Alaska on Wednesday, in what Pentagon officials said was the first such foray by Beijing.

headline: Bubblewashing
text: Almost 15 years have passed since I warned about media “balance” that involved systematically abdicating the journalistic duty of informing readers about simple matters of fact. As I said way back when,

headline: Gaza: U.N. Issues Warning About Living Conditions
text: A United Nations agency has warned that Gaza may become uninhabitable by 2020 if current political and economic trends continue. The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development said in a statement released late Tuesday that eight years of effective bans on most exports, three major conflicts and tight restrictions on materials entering Gaza had “shattered its ability to export and produce for the domestic market, ravaged its already debilitated infrastructure, left no time for reconstruction and economic recovery, and accelerated the de-development” of the Gaza Strip. According to the agency, “Gaza’s 1.8 million inhabitants rely on coastal aquifers as their main source of freshwater, yet 95 percent of this water is not safe to drink.” Moreover, the unemployment rate exceeds 40 percent, and more than two-thirds of Gazans do not have reliable access to adequate supplies of food. A United Nations report in 2012 contained similar warnings, but it appears that widespread destruction caused by last summer’s conflict between Israel and Palestinian militants may have accelerated those trends. Israel and Egypt heavily restricted the movement of people and goods into Gaza after the militant Hamas group seized power of the territory in 2007.

headline: Police Officers and Other New York City Agencies Visit Homeless Encampments
text: As police officers, mental health workers, lawyers and others visit homeless encampments in New York as part of a City Hall initiative, a prime mission will be determining how people wound up on the streets.

headline: A Vacation That Ended With the Legion of Honor
text: Airman First Class Spencer Stone’s summer vacation in Europe did not begin well.

headline: Calstrs Aims to Cut Risk by Moving Up to $20 Billion Out of Stocks
text: For years, financial planners have advised their clients to reduce their stock market plays as they age. Buying and holding high-quality bonds may seem less rewarding, but it could protect retirees from gyrations when a big loss of principal would be devastating.

headline: Officials Cite Possible Knife in 2nd Video of San Antonio Shooting
text: SAN ANTONIO — A second video of two deputies fatally shooting a Hispanic man here on Friday shows the man holding an object that officials believe was a knife, but the video also makes clear the man had his hands in the air before he was shot, the authorities said Wednesday.

headline: Tears and Anger in Queens After Mother Loses Another Son to Violence
text: A weatherworn teddy bear clung to a thin tree, an aging marker of the spot on Seagirt Avenue in Far Rockaway, Queens, where Shawn Plummer, 17, died three years ago — a bystander struck in a wild hail of bullets.

headline: William McCormick Blair Jr., Envoy and Confidant of Adlai Stevenson, Dies at 98
text: William McCormick Blair Jr., a former United States ambassador to Denmark and the Philippines and a confidant of Adlai E. Stevenson, a two-time Democratic nominee for president, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

headline: Unicef Warns of Lost Generation of War Children Out of School
text: War and upheaval across parts of the Middle East and North Africa in recent years have driven more than 13 million children from school — 40 percent of the affected area’s school-age population, the United Nations said Wednesday.

headline: Some Hedge Funds Prosper in Market Tumult
text: A market sell-off that ricocheted across the globe last month reversed the fortunes of many of Wall Street’s star investors. But it is not all doom and gloom in the $3 trillion hedge fund industry.

headline: Polio Paralyzes 2 Children in West Ukraine Outbreak
text: Two children in western Ukraine have been paralyzed by polio, in the first cases of the disease seen in Europe in five years, the World Health Organization announced Wednesday.

headline: Obama Takes Climate Message to Alaska, Where Change Is Rapid
text: KOTZEBUE, Alaska — In this native village situated on a gravel spit above the Arctic Circle, life is changing more quickly than the Alaskans who have lived off the land and water here for thousands of years can keep pace with.

headline: Low-Income Workers See Biggest Drop in Paychecks
text: Despite steady gains in hiring, a falling unemployment rate and other signs of an improving economy, take-home pay for many American workers has effectively fallen since the economic recovery began in 2009, according to a new study by an advocacy group that is to be released on Thursday.

headline: Republicans Weigh New Ways to Upend Iran Nuclear Deal
text: WASHINGTON — With President Obama securing the votes Wednesday needed to assure the Iran nuclear accord will survive congressional challenge, Republicans are considering legislative options to counter the deal, including the possible reimposition of sanctions the agreement is supposed to lift.

headline: As Bodies Refuse at the 2015 U.S. Open, Players Confront a Painful Decision
text: During these first days of the United States Open, on its bright blue courts for all to see, there was so much talking.

headline: New York to Settle Suit Over Rikers Inmate Whom Guards Attacked
text: New York City has agreed to pay $450,000 to settle a civil rights lawsuit filed by a former Rikers Island inmate who was hogtied by correction officers and then, while his hands were still cuffed, brutally beaten, the man’s lawyer said on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Season 1 Finale Recap: No Surrender
text: Read all of our “Narcos” recaps.

headline: Netflix’s ‘Narcos': Watched It All? Talk About It With the Critic Neil Genzlinger
text: What have you done with nice Pablo Escobar, and who is this nasty psychopath you put in his place?

headline: Reason to Celebrate Despite a Quick U.S. Open Exit
text: A first-round defeat at the United States Open is an opportunity lost. But for Andrei Daescu, losing on Wednesday meant he would gain a wife on Saturday.

headline: A $1 Million Laptop Theft, and a Story Prosecutors Say Did Not Add Up
text: Two brothers toting more than $1 million in Apple laptops destined for two New Jersey high schools made an alarming report last year to the police in Yorktown, N.Y.: Their haul had been stolen from a parking lot near their home.

headline: 2 Men Awarded $750,000 for Wrongful Convictions in 1983 Murder
text: DURHAM, N.C. — One year to the day after a North Carolina judge threw out their wrongful murder convictions, a state commission awarded $750,000 each as compensation to two half-brothers who spent three decades in prison, much of it on death row.

headline: Clinton Ex-Aide Likely to Invoke 5th Amendment Over Questions on Email Server
text: A former aide to Hillary Rodham Clinton who helped set up the server that housed Mrs. Clinton’s private email account plans to invoke his Fifth Amendment right in response to congressional questions about the email practices, according to two people who have been briefed on the matter.

headline: California: Coal Dropped From Public Pension Funds
text: California lawmakers passed a bill on Wednesday that will force the state’s public employee pension funds to drop investments in coal. The bill, passed by the Assembly on a vote of 43 to 27, will now go to the desk of Gov. Jerry Brown. The Senate president pro tempore, Kevin de León, the bill’s sponsor, noted that stocks in the battered coal industry were losing value and said they were “inconsistent with our values as a state on the forefront of efforts to address global climate change.” The two funds, known as CalPERS and CalSTRS, manage nearly $500 billion in assets. A spokeswoman for Mr. Brown, Deborah Hoffman, said the governor had until Oct. 11 to act. “Given the serious challenge of climate change,” she said, “this bill deserves careful consideration.”

headline: Biden Pushes Free Community Colleges
text: While speaking at a Miami Dade College campus in Florida, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. promoted President Obama’s plan to make community college free nationwide.

headline: Michigan: Backlog of Sex Assault Kits Almost Gone
text: Six years after more than 11,000 untested evidence kits from sexual assault investigations were discovered in a Detroit police warehouse, that backlog has been nearly eliminated, producing thousands of potential leads in criminal cases, Michigan officials said Wednesday. More than 10,000 of the kits have undergone testing for DNA and other evidence, an effort that has cost the state millions of dollars. So far, 21 convictions have resulted from the evidence. But officials warned that the work of investigating and prosecuting cases still had years to go and would cost millions more. At a news conference with Gov. Rick Snyder, state and local officials said the tests had produced 2,616 matches with DNA samples in the F.B.I.’s national database, with evidence of 477 serial rapists and links to crimes in 39 states and the District of Columbia. An investigation by Michigan State University researchers, funded by the Justice Department, pointed to a chronic lack of resources, rapid turnover in the department and a sense of triage in a high-crime city as contributing to sexual assault cases’ not being treated seriously enough.

headline: Andy Murray Empathizes With Nick Kyrgios
text: After his U.S. Open victory over Nick Kyrgios — already a lightning rod for controversy in his young career — Andy Murray spoke about his own maturation process, the lessons he had learned about navigating the news media, and the language used in the heat of battle.

headline: Does a Number On
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — The good news is that this 17×17 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament puzzle by Merl Reagle from 1999 made me giggle and smile as I solved it. And thank you to Will Shortz for digging it out to share with us. [ A previous version of this post listed the year this puzzle was part of the A.C.P.T. as 1991. It actually appeared in 1999.]

headline: Dean Jones, Affable Star in ‘Love Bug’ and a Disney Fixture, Dies at 84
text: Dean Jones, an actor and singer who made his name in a string of popular Disney films in the 1960s and ’70s, notably as a racecar driver in the “Love Bug” franchise, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 84.

headline: Barbara Brecht-Schall, Guardian of Father’s Plays, Dies at 84
text: Barbara Brecht-Schall, a daughter of the playwright Bertolt Brecht and the guardian of his literary legacy, died on Monday in Berlin. She was 84.

headline: N.Y.U. Removes Bill Cosby’s Name From Film Workshop, Joining Other Schools
text: An intensive workshop at New York University was created to find high school students from the New York City area interested in film but who came from backgrounds underrepresented in the industry. Over a series of Saturdays, they were immersed in the medium, taught techniques and introduced to professionals.

headline: Fox Lake Mourns Police Officer as Search for Suspects Shifts
text: FOX LAKE, Ill. — The police helicopters hovering low over this waterfront community on Tuesday were mostly gone. So, too, were the dozens of dogs that scoured the ground for the scents of a police lieutenant’s killers. At the Channel Inn restaurant, Wednesday’s lunch crowd was back to its regular size.

headline: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season Finale: Who’s That Knocking at My Door?
text: Seriously, though, who’s that knocking at the door at the end of the Season 1 finale of “Mr. Robot”?

headline: Matt Harvey Lifts Mets, Then Shows Signs of Fatigue
text: On Wednesday, Matt Harvey took the mound in a September game for the first time since his rookie season in 2012, when he still carried an air of mystery but also represented so much potential for a team desperate for the kind of player who could shepherd them back to the playoffs.

headline: Venus Williams Beats Back a Challenge From a Plucky American Compatriot
text: The first time Venus Williams served for the match, she double-faulted. Then she double-faulted again. Her opponent, the plucky 25-year-old Irina Falconi, won the break, pumping dim life back into an otherwise ineffective effort.

headline: Vietnam’s Military Parade
text: On Wednesday, Vietnam also held a military parade, celebrating the 70th anniversary of its declaration of independence from French colonialism.

headline: What’s On TV Thursday
text: 10 P.M. (Fuse) ALMOST FAMOUS (2000) The director Cameron Crowe looks back on his career as a teenage music journalist in this coming-of-age story about his fictionalized alter ego, William Miller (Patrick Fugit), a 15-year-old from San Diego who makes a fairy-tale ascent from nerdy schoolboy to Rolling Stone reporter. Frances McDormand plays William’s protective mother, a college professor; Zooey Deschanel, his rebellious older sister; Philip Seymour Hoffman, the critic Lester Bangs; and Billy Crudup, Russell Hammond, the lead guitarist of the band Stillwater, to whom William is drawn. And Kate Hudson (above right with Mr. Fugit) is Penny Lane, the ringleader of a troupe of groupies who call themselves the Band-Aids. “We don’t have intercourse,” she says. “We inspire the music.” Mr. Crowe “may be the least cynical director working in Hollywood today,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Of course, rock ’n’ roll is not always about being nice.”

headline: Bryan Brothers, Five-Time Champions, Lose Opener
text: Bob and Mike Bryan, the top seeds and a doubles juggernaut for more than a decade, crashed out of the United States Open in the first round Wednesday night, falling, 7-6 (4), 5-7, 6-3, to another American pair, Sam Querrey and Steve Johnson.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Look, this guy’s the front-runner. He should be treated like a front-runner, not like some kind of alternative universe to the political system.”

headline: Inside a Cloistered Monastery: Joy and Love
text: The idea of a cloistered life strikes some as one of severity and silence, of running away from a broken heart or a broken life. But as Toni Greaves discovered when she visited a community of cloistered nuns in New Jersey, it was a joyful embrace of a life that is in many ways countercultural given the me-first society that lurks beyond the convent’s walls.

headline: China’s Military Parade Celebrates World War II Victory
text: In a world capital that had been shut down for the occasion, some 12,000 Chinese troops were expected to march through Tiananmen Square on Thursday.

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Parental Benefits Where One Parent Counts for More
text: Companies are becoming more generous with family-friendly benefits, but in many cases they have a catch. They are awarded not to all parents of young children, but to so-called primary caregivers.

headline: Progress on Democracy for Guatemala
text: To the Editor:

headline: Judges Standing Upside-Down
text: Something funny is happening on the way to the courthouse — and I don’t mean county clerks refusing to issue licenses for same-sex marriages. For decades, judicial conservatism has been defined at least in part as strict observance of the elements that make a case justiciable in federal court: a live controversy and a plaintiff with a concrete problem — as opposed to a general grievance — that can be fixed by a favorable ruling. I first learned about the doctrine of standing back when progressive law professors wrung their hands over how flagrantly justices like William H. Rehnquist were invoking standing and other jurisdictional barriers in order to close courthouse doors to meritorious lawsuits.

headline: Ratcheting Up the Rhetoric
text: Last week, Deputy Darren H. Goforth of the Harris County, Tex., Sheriff’s Department was executed at a gas station in a Houston suburb. It was a horrific scene.

headline: Australia’s Brutal Treatment of Migrants
text: Some European officials may be tempted to adopt the hard-line approach Australia has used to stem a similar tide of migrants. That would be unconscionable.

headline: The Jewish Divide Over the Iran Nuclear Deal
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Ancient Fish Is Running Out of Time
text: HELENA, Mont. — FROM an evolutionary perspective, the pallid sturgeon is a thing of beauty.

headline: A City Council Race in Queens
text: Six candidates are competing in the Democratic primary on Sept. 10 for an empty seat in the New York City Council’s 23rd District, in eastern Queens.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Payday for Ice Bucket Challenge’s Mocked Slacktivists
text: When Americans were giddily drenching themselves with ice water during the “ice bucket challenge” a year ago, the cognoscenti rolled their eyes.

headline: Clinton, Trump and the Politics of Self-Destruction
text: RIGHT now it looks very much as if the two major political parties in America are in a race to see which one can destroy itself first.

headline: Migrant Chaos Mounts While Divided Europe Stumbles for Response
text: LONDON — The struggle among European leaders to develop a coherent response to the spiraling migrant crisis intensified on Thursday as fresh calls for a blocwide plan were met with recriminations about the Continent being swamped with Muslims.

headline: Banned Cluster Bombs Were Used in Five Countries, Report Says

headline: News Q’s | Google’s Driverless Cars Run Into Problem: Cars With Drivers

headline: The Apartment Trail Winds Back to Hamilton Heights

headline: Review: Elena Ferrante’s ‘The Story of the Lost Child,’ the Finale in a Quartet
text: Elena and Lila, the two heroines of Elena Ferrante’s dazzling Neapolitan quartet of novels, are one of those unforgettable pairs who define each other and take their place in our collective imagination as a matched set — like Prince Hal and Falstaff, Settembrini and Naphta, Vladimir and Estragon, Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, Thelma and Louise.

headline: Timothy Snyder’s ‘Black Earth’
text: More than 70 years after the Holocaust, there is no sign of research on it abating. Instead, over the past few decades, historians have been extending their inquiries. Investigators who once understood the wartime massacres as a unique historical episode that mainly concerned Germans and Jews and was driven principally by ideology have increasingly produced comparative studies of regions and states, turning their attention to other victims and to what Eastern European archives are able to tell us about the dynamics of persecution and mass murder; economic issues; and the motivations of perpetrators, bystanders, women, religious and political leaders, neutrals, rescuers and others. So voluminous is this scholarly outpouring that few are able to keep up with it, although some historians continue to grapple with the subject as a whole. Notwithstanding all this effort, Timothy Snyder, a Yale University specialist in Eastern Europe, contends in “Black Earth” that our understanding of the Holocaust has failed us. We have misunderstood its lessons.

headline: ‘The Hotel Years,’ by Joseph Roth
text: Reading the 64 essays by Joseph Roth anthologized in “The Hotel Years” — dazzling, elegiac, mordant and harrowingly oracular by turn — is like roaming through the Grand Budapest Hotel and discovering that it’s merged with the Overlook, the establishment from “The Shining.” There are so many fantastic scenes, indelible characters and exquisite lines to marvel at. Yet the cumulative vision is one of ­horror.

headline: What Would You Be Willing to Wait in a Really Long Line For?

headline: Former Longtime Coach Accuses Hunter College of Age Discrimination

headline: Sold! In Monterey, the Ferrari Crowd Shells Out $402 Million

That is, if most of the cars at the 1969 music festival had been Porsches, Ferraris and Lamborghinis. Several millions of dollars worth of precision European autos, along with a passel of impressive American models, were idled, their horsepower reined in by bumper-to-bumper traffic in both directions.

headline: Is the Blue-Collar Shirt Still Blue Collar?
text: A work shirt is a dress shirt with a job to do. Accordingly, it is designed with buttonholes on its double pockets, stitched with an emphasis on strength and constructed from a sturdy material like khaki or covert or, most classically, a cotton called chambray. You can have a chambray shirt in any color you want, and if that color is blue, you also have a social construct and a rhetorical device: The shirt’s blue collar is a mass-­produced idea as durable and versatile as the garment itself. With blue-­collar identity now more a matter of cultural style than of occupational history, the term is perfectly slippery, such that the assertions that Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin has ‘‘blue-­collar appeal’’ and an ‘‘anti-­union agenda’’ are not fundamentally incompatible. The phrase ‘‘blue collar’’ has flourished precisely because it is concrete in its imagery and vague in its connotations, vividly conjuring a labor-­class scene while sidestepping such a nasty word as ‘‘class.’’

headline: Alton Brown Has Had It With Foodies
text: Ten or so years ago, you said that food in this country was like what sex was in the ’70s: our last decadent act. Are we out of the ’70s yet? I think we’ve moved into the ’80s. The decadence is being replaced by a potentially appropriate austerity. The orgy of the unfamiliar and new has given way to something more focused and thoughtful.

headline: There’s More to Cremona Than Violins
text: Cremona is a small, pretty, well-kept, bourgeois, mercantile city in the fertile Po Valley of Italy. There is no local wine region. There is no city university. There are no grandiose must-see sights. The chef Mario Batali once wrote that Cremona is “famous for its quiet, pious belief in commerce and order.”

headline: Michigan State: Fifth in the Nation, Yet Still Second Fiddle to Michigan

The walnut-size mementos celebrated the 42-41 victory as well as the team’s 11-2 record. But one small section of each ring’s limited real estate displayed something else: the score of a blowout over a team that wound up 5-7.

headline: The Swedish Museum That BabyBjörn Built
text: STOCKHOLM — Fourteen miles east of Sweden’s capital, amid the piney woods and rocky outcroppings of the Stockholm archipelago, an 8-by-11-foot photograph of the North Atlantic Ocean as viewed from space greets visitors to one of Scandinavia’s most ambitious new arts institutions. The picture, digitally constructed by the German photographer Andreas Gursky from multiple satellite images, suggests vastness, emptiness, power and fragility. It also reverses our customary perspective on the world, with an immense expanse of midnight-blue ocean occupying almost the entirety of the frame while familiar land masses — Newfoundland, Labrador, Greenland, Iceland, the coast of West Africa, the Caribbean islands — are relegated to a fringe around the edges. A similar desire to change our outlook animates the photography show this image introduces, as well as the space that’s hosting it.

headline: Inside the Mind of a Japanese Master Plant Stylist
text: You could say it’s growing season for Satoshi Kawamoto, the Japanese plant artist and creative director behind lush installations for brands like Filson, Gant Rugger and Mr Porter. In March, he relocated the New York outpost of his Green Fingers empire (five locations in Tokyo, two in Yokohama) from the East Village to a larger — but still modest — location on the Lower East Side. At a glance, the storefront reads like a plant nursery; but it’s also a boutique, and not just of botanicals. Unruly houseplants and tiny, prim succulents grow among clothes, accessories, lighting (some flea-market-sourced and some designed by Kawamoto himself) and Japanese-made housewares – all for sale. “People who are not interested in plants but who are interested in looking for plates, handbags or clothes — may end up buying plants,” he explains of the renewed interest in foliage as a home accent, among people who subscribe to a certain (Brooklynized) aesthetic. And on the flip side, “people who are looking for plants may end up buying some beautiful vintage clothes.”

headline: 1915: German Admiral Resigns
text: LONDON — According to a despatch from Amsterdam, Grand Admiral von Tirpitz, the German Minister of Marine, has handed in his resignation [Sept. 3] and will be succeeded by Admiral von Pohl. The Berlin report that Von Tirpitz is taking a prolonged holiday ‘‘for his health’’ is regarded in New York, says a cablegram to the ‘‘Daily Chronicle,’’ as an indication that there is a break in the relations of that illustrious sailor with the Kaiser. America is naturally elated over Germany’s ‘‘climb-down,’’ which is generally declared to be a triumph for the President’s diplomacy. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 4, 1915

headline: Twyla Tharp’s Troupe Prepares for a Milestone Tour

headline: The Timeless Allure of the Art of Knots
text: Last year, I wrote an article for T about, of all things, knots. To report the piece, I traveled to the Museum of Knots and Sailors’ Ropework in Ipswich, England. I also spent hours leafing though ‘‘The Ashley Book of Knots,’’ a doorstop reference work published in 1944. A year later, I’m still reading it. It’s an unusual thing: a how-to guide that’s also an eccentric literary classic.

headline: 1965: Russia Won’t Trade Exhibitions
text: MOSCOW — Russia has called off a planned exchange of exhibitions with the United States, apparently because of tension over Vietnam, U.S. officials said today [Sept. 3]. They said the Soviet Union had asked for an American hand-tools exhibition and a Soviet space-achievement display to be ‘‘suspended under present circumstances.’’ American officials disclosed yesterday that Russia had withdrawn an invitation for the American musical ‘‘Hello Dolly’’ to stage a five-week run here in October. The cancellations are seen by the Americans as first direct results of a tougher public posture by Russia over Vietnam. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 4, 1965

headline: A Song Inspired by a Bizarre Love Triangle
text: The initial concept for the psych-rock trio Unknown Mortal Orchestra’s third full-length album, “Multi-Love,” began with the title. “When I first wrote down the term ‘multi-love,’ I didn’t really know what it meant or why it resonated with me,” frontman Ruban Nielson explains. “But the meaning of it became more complex as the year went on.” Nielson set out to make a “happy record” — a seemingly painless undertaking. But when an unlikely friendship blossomed with a young woman on the road, it evolved into a love triangle between Nielson, his wife and “Woman X” — and complications set in.

headline: Problems With Supreme Court’s Ruling on Fees

headline: In Paris, a Famed Department Store Goes ‘Brooklyn’
text: They call it “Le Brook-leen,” and for the French, or Parisians at least, it is an exotic land far, far away. But there is something je ne sais quoi about Brooklyn that seduces the French — that intellectual approach to life and style, which, at its core, perhaps, is as français as Sartre and Beauvoir. So beginning this week, the Left Bank department store Le Bon Marché Rive Gauche will spotlight Brooklyn as its annual autumn cultural theme — a focus running throughout the store and its sister gourmet grocery, La Grande Epicerie. Items from more than 100 different Brooklyn purveyors will be for sale, including Catbird jewelry, Kinfolk men’s wear and Mast Brothers chocolates. The store’s commitment to the Brooklyn aesthetic is so complete as to border on caricature — they’ll even hawk Lynn & Lawrence woolen beanies and Ball mason jars (which happen to be made in Indiana).

headline: Father of Drowned Syrian Boys Speaks About Loss
