headline: In Britain, Top Artists Sell Affordable Work Straight From Their Cars
text: This weekend, the British artists Tracey Emin, Sir Peter Blake, Keith Coventry, Matt Collishaw, Polly Morgan and Jeremy Deller convened to raise money for charity. But it was a scene unlike any they tend to participate in: instead of the usual blue-chip auction, they took part in Vauxhall’s annual Art Car Boot Fair, selling special editions of their works from stalls and the trunks of their cars. “What makes this kind of event exceptional is that you are selling affordable art from different people at different points in their careers,” Emin told T as she took a brief break from selling her work, which included signed posters and limited editions of her drawings that ranged from £50-£500. “And that makes it accessible to the public.”

headline: Letters: Another Path to Peace
text: To the Editor:

headline: Biden Calls Iran Pact ‘A Good Deal’
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke to Jewish leaders in Florida on Thursday in an effort to generate support for the Iran nuclear deal.

headline: First Draft Focus: House Panel Ponders Benghazi
text: Cheryl Mills, Adviser to Hillary Clinton, Testifies on Benghazi and Email Practices

headline: Prosecutors to Seek Death Penalty for Dylann Roof in Charleston Shootings
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — After what she described as intense and emotional discussions with family members and survivors, one of the state’s top prosecutors said Thursday that she would seek the death penalty for Dylann S. Roof, who is charged with committing racially motivated murder against nine members of a storied church here.

headline: A New Name and Height for Mount McKinley
text: Last week, the tallest mountain in North America not only was renamed, but also lost a bit of stature — 10 feet. The United States Geological Survey announced Wednesday that the official height of Denali, the Alaskan mountain formerly known as Mount McKinley, is 20,310 feet. Previously, it was listed at 20,320 feet.

headline: Study Reveals Consistent Predator-Prey Pattern
text: Predators may depend on prey for food, but an increase in the number of prey animals does not bring a proportional increase in the number of predators, a new study has found.

headline: South Africa’s Naspers Backs Smartphone Start-Up Letgo
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The world of online marketplaces may already seem crowded with the likes of Amazon.com and the Alibaba Group.

headline: A West Village Space That’s Part Store, Part Light Installation
text: When the brothers Tull and Josh Price set out to design the second New York store for their shoe brand, Feit, they had a goal in mind: to, as Tull puts it, “push the boundaries of what a retail space could look and feel like.” The result is just that: a stark, cleanly geometric space — that feels simultaneously industrial and natural — opening in the West Village this week.

headline: Slave Trade Video Game Developer Alters Scene After Outcry
text: After facing mounting criticism on social media, a Danish video game developer has excised a scene from an educational game that depicts the 18th-century slave trade.

headline: Thorsten Brinkmann’s “La Vie en Rose Rock”
text: The photographer creates portraits and still lifes that echo noble, aristocratic techniques — with an absurdist twist.

headline: Donald Trump Signs Loyalty Pledge to Republican Party
text: He said yes.

headline: Witty Photos That Play With Centuries-Old Artistic Tradition
text: The photographer Thorsten Brinkmann’s portraits marry the traditional with the absurd: His subjects stand in regal poses, wearing thrift-store fabric scraps, plus vases or cloth-covered wastepaper baskets over their heads that render them genderless and ageless. Brinkmann often poses for the portraits himself; wearing a cape made of a pleated skirt or masking his face with a broken flower pot, he provides a witty take on the gestures of European aristocrats.

headline: Warming Oceans Putting Marine Life ‘In a Blender’
text: Up in Maine, lobsters are thriving. The Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission reported last month that stocks there reached a record high.

headline: Editorial Page Editor Andrew Rosenthal on Trump Campaign
text: Is Donald Trump deliberately using offensive rhetoric to fan fury from the far right?

headline: Chelsea Clinton’s Spokesman, Kamyl Bazbaz, Leaves Clinton Foundation
text: Chelsea Clinton’s spokesman of the last two years, Kamyl Bazbaz, is leaving the Clinton Foundation for the private sector.

headline: An Expedition Reveals Stunning Biological Wealth in a Bolivian Park That May Be Opened to Drilling
text: I focus a lot on hotspots for social or environmental troubles in the tropics, so it’s worth stepping back once in awhile to point to areas where the great tapestry of life is still dizzyingly rich — at least for now.

headline: Donald Trump Signs Republican Pledge
text: Mr. Trump, a Republican presidential candidate, vowed to back the party’s choice if he failed to win the nomination, ruling out an independent or third-party bid.

headline: Five Rutgers Football Players Suspended After Criminal Charges
text: Rutgers’s embattled football program came under further scrutiny Thursday after it was reported that five of the team’s players had been charged with assault. They are accused of surrounding at least four people and inflicting what the authorities called an “unprovoked attack” that broke one victim’s jaw.

headline: Some Nail Salon Owners in New York Push Back Against Increased Regulation
text: Kenny Yeh acquired J & J Fine Nail on the Upper West Side of Manhattan about three years ago. It is a tidy, narrow space that smells only faintly of polish, and where gentle piano music plays in the background.

headline: California Heat Puts Farm Workers at Risk
text: California’s drought has forced cities to cut back on water and (some) farmers to let their fields go fallow. But increasingly hot, dry weather in the state may have its most dire effect on some of the people who plant and pick its crops.

headline: Aunt of Drowned Syrian Boys Comments
text: Tima Kurdi, the aunt of two Syrian boys who drowned off the coast of Turkey, said that their mother told her she didn’t know how to swim before the family attempted to cross the Mediterranean.

headline: College Football Kickoff: A Primer on the Playoff System
text: The college football season kicks off Thursday night with an extended weekend of games that includes prominent matchups like Michigan-Utah (Thursday), Notre Dame-Texas and Alabama-Wisconsin (Saturday) and Virginia Tech-Ohio State (Monday). Marc Tracy takes a quick look at what all the teams are playing for: a chance to be a part of the College Football Playoff at the end of the season.

headline: Defense to Rest in Trial of 3 Ex-Dewey & LeBoeuf Leaders
text: The lawyers for three former executives of Dewey & LeBoeuf must feel confident that prosecutors have failed to prove that the men used accounting gimmicks to defraud lenders and creditors of the once-prominent New York law firm.

headline: Migrant Children in Need Raise Questions at Home
text: Summer vacation is almost officially over. By the Tuesday after Labor Day, even the last of the public schools will have started their calendars. The holdout preschools should finally start easing their young charges into classroom life by mid-September; soon, the ordinary ritual of family life — the constructing of the house of cards that is child care and car pool, the setting aside the work email for homework help, the parent-teacher conferences, the calls from the school nurse — should be in full swing.

headline: Ayatollah Says Sanctions Must Be Lifted
text: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, told an influential clerical council on Thursday that there would be no nuclear deal if sanctions were “suspended” rather than “lifted.”

headline: Art for the Workers’ Sake
text: Museums like the Met and the Whitney are filled with examples of pieces depicting labor.

headline: Take a Labor Day Tour of Blue-Collar Art
text: “Poor art for poor people.”

headline: Philippe Parreno’s Larger-than-Life Year
text: The artist, who staged an ambitious exhibition at New York’s Park Avenue Armory this summer, will be honored by Sculpture Center in November and has several international projects on the horizon.

headline: For Philippe Parreno, a Big Honor and an Even Bigger Year
text: The artist Philippe Parreno has never been to the Rainbow Room, where he’ll be honored this year at Sculpture Center’s annual gala on Nov. 4. In fact, it’s not even clear whether he’s heard of the landmarked Art Deco event space, which has at some point hosted almost every philanthropic endeavor in New York from its 65th floor vantage point — a world away from the nonprofit’s gritty Long Island City location. Parreno Googles the Rainbow Room and asks, laughing, “Can I come in a T-shirt, or do I have to get a tie?”

headline: Donald Trump’s Empty Promise to the Republican Party
text: Donald Trump made a big show today out of the latest in the series of meaningless gestures and self-promotional stunts that make up his political career. He signed a piece of paper saying that if he doesn’t win the Republican nominating contest, he will endorse the winner and will not mount a third-party run.

headline: Yoox Exuberance Over an Exit May Wear Thin
text: Yoox is losing Net-a-Porter know-how at an important time.

headline: Review: In ‘Blind,’ Perception and Fantasy Converge in a Writer’s Mind
text: Blindness and sight: Distinctions between the two blur, then converge in the Norwegian filmmaker Eskil Vogt’s haunting debut feature, “Blind,” whose narrator and main character, Ingrid (Ellen Dorrit Petersen), has recently lost her sight.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Hungary and Elsewhere
text: Hungary and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: September 3, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Hungary, Italy, Ivory Coast and India.

headline: Chef Michael White Closes Summer by Opening Vaucluse
text: “I worked for quite some time in Italy,” says Altamarea Group’s executive chef Michael White, but “most of those restaurants are quiet in the summertime, so I would go to France and I would work for the summer in Grasse.” The chef, who rose to fame on the strength of his Italian cuisine at Marea and Ai Fiori, finally has a chance to draw inspiration from those French summers at his new uptown brasserie Vaucluse.

headline: American Yeshiva Students Escape Attack in West Bank Town
text: JERUSALEM — Five American Jewish seminary students who strayed into a Palestinian-controlled area of Hebron in their car on Thursday were attacked by Palestinians hurling stones and a firebomb, according to the Israeli police and the military.

headline: Getty Images Announces 2015 Grant Winners
text: PERPIGNAN, France — Photographers doing personal projects on social issues that often go overlooked, if not unreported, received $10,000 each today from the 2015 Getty Images Grants for Editorial Photography. The awards were announced at the Visa pour l’Image festival.

headline: Hungarian Leader Rebuked for Saying Muslim Migrants Must Be Blocked ‘to Keep Europe Christian’
text: Hungary’s prime minister, Viktor Orban, was criticized online and in person on Thursday for writing in a German newspaper that it was important to secure his nation’s borders from mainly Muslim migrants “to keep Europe Christian.”

headline: Afghans See a Collapse of Tradition in a Spate of Devious Attacks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Abdul Latif of northern Kunduz Province vowed he would get even with the Taliban who killed his father, so he volunteered to join one of their units and spent two months trying to win their confidence. A few days ago he and a friend shot 13 of them to death, mostly while they slept, he and the police said.

headline: Justice Dept. to Require Warrants for Some Cellphone Tracking
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department will regularly require federal agents to seek warrants before using secretive equipment that can locate and track cellphones, the agency announced Thursday, the first regulations on an increasingly controversial technology.

headline: Review: Jaimie Warren, at American Medium, Mashes Up Freddie Mercury and Saints
text: JAIMIE WARREN

text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Dylann Roof Accused of ‘Ultimate Crime’
text: The South Carolina state solicitor, Scarlett A. Wilson, will seek the death penalty for Mr. Roof, who is charged with the killing of nine people at a Charleston church in June.

headline: Review: ‘Hand of God,’ on Amazon, Is a California Neo-Noir Thriller
text: The pilot of “Hand of God,” Amazon’s second original hourlong drama, was posted just over a year ago. So we’ve known all this time that the series begins with Ron Perlman — an actor of formidable size who has played characters called Hellboy and the Beast — standing naked in a public fountain, speaking in tongues.

headline: Odysseus’ Epic Journey, This Time in Central Park
text: Summer isn’t over yet, and neither are the Public Theater’s free shows in Central Park.

headline: Lineup Set for Telluride Film Festival
text: LOS ANGELES — Is the coming “Suffragette” a political movie? At first glance, it looks period and foreign, the story of Britain’s early feminist movement, with Carey Mulligan in the lead role. On second glance, it could resonate in a presidential contest that finds a woman within reaching distance of the presidency. Maybe?

text: ‘GILBERT & GEORGE’

headline: My Father’s Last Romance
text: Older adults have their own rules about marriage and cohabitation.

headline: No Judge of Character
text: I was in a deli, and a man may have cut in front of me in line. When asked if he had, I said: “I don’t argue over such things. He can go ahead.” The man replied: “You don’t argue over such things? That’s why you’re fat.” I said, “You’ll end up in a courtroom.” He replied: “Good! I’m a lawyer.” I said, “Well, I am a judge.” The conversation devolved until he accused me of racism. Apparently, he was Hispanic; I hadn’t noticed. But when did it become O.K. to pick on someone’s physical imperfections but not sexual orientation or race?

headline: Arizona News Anchor Is Drawn Into Debate on Her Accent and the Use of Spanish
text: PHOENIX — An Arizona news anchor defended her pronunciation of Spanish words during English broadcasts, saying she delivers them the way the language is intended to be spoken.

headline: Silicon Valley, Seeking Diversity, Focuses on Blacks
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — More than a decade before diversity became a hot issue in Silicon Valley, Jason Young came home on winter break from Harvard to discover that his family was being evicted.

headline: Review: In Chris Evans’s ‘Before We Go,’ a Chance Encounter With Staying Power
text: BEFORE WE GO

headline: Cory Booker, New Jersey Senator, Backs Iran Nuclear Deal
text: Senator Cory A. Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, endorsed President Obama’s nuclear agreement with Iran on Thursday, padding support for the accord, which already has enough votes in the Senate to thwart a Republican-backed resolution of disapproval.

headline: Fighting the Tank Car Invasion
text: It seemed to happen overnight for people living along the commercial rail lines from North Dakota to New York and beyond.  Instead of sleepy Amtrak passenger trains or a string of relatively harmless boxcars, the railways have been overtaken in the last year or so by thousands of matte black tank cars. These bullet-shaped tankers are mostly filled with Bakken crude oil, a combustible substance that has been responsible for numerous explosions and 47 deaths in recent years.

headline: Review: ‘Dragon Blade’ Features Jackie Chan, Romans and a Lot of Mayhem
text: All fighting, all grimacing — though sometimes all smiling, weeping and singing — “Dragon Blade” is the kind of nutsy maximalist entertainment that isn’t content merely to tap a handful of influences. Instead, it stuffs an entire encyclopedia of dicey ideas (visual, narrative, political) into a blender to create a wacky, eyeball-popping and -glazing extravaganza that suggests a Cecil B. DeMille Bible epic, a Chinese military parade and a Busby Berkeley musical, at times all at once. And while it can be tough to find the human pulse amid the spectacle noise, Jackie Chan, John Cusack, Adrien Brody and a trillion horse-riding extras are also part of the very big picture.

headline: Review: Capturing Frida Kahlo Through a Series of Portraits
text: FRIDA KAHLO

headline: Review: In ‘La Jaula de Oro,’ Riding the Rails to Reach New Lives
text: In the opening moments of “La Jaula de Oro,” three impoverished Guatemalan teenagers prepare to make the perilous journey north in hopes of slipping across the United States border into the land of opportunity. There, one boy exclaims wishfully, “everything is much better.” In a ramshackle public lavatory, Sara (Karen Martínez), the lone girl of the three, chops off her hair, tapes her breasts, and dons a T-shirt and baseball cap to pose as a boy named Osvaldo.

headline: Outside Courthouse, Kim Davis Is Seen as a Villain and a Hero
text: Outside a federal courthouse in Ashland, Ky., on Thursday, dozens of people gathered in two cacophonous groups to debate what both sides felt was history in the making, but for different reasons.

text: A surge in volatility. Plunging global stock markets. A surprise Chinese currency devaluation.

headline: ‘Sesame Street’ When It Started
text: 46 YEARS AGO

headline: Review: At Bargemusic, a Surprise Competition With Live Bluegrass
text: An element of surprise is built into any performance during Bargemusic’s Here and Now Labor Day festival. This four-day celebration of contemporary music takes a catholic approach to styles and instrumentation, and with virtually every work a New York or world premiere, there’s no telling what you’ll hear.

headline: Review: ‘Donald Blumberg Photographs,’ Observing America on the Streets and From the Sofa
text: NEW HAVEN — There’s real life, and there’s media; there are the spaces outside we inhabit together, and there is the screen we gaze at alone. Yet the photographs of Donald Blumberg, subject of a large retrospective at the Yale University Art Gallery here, make the distinction between reality and image feel overdrawn. Mr. Blumberg began his career shooting on the streets of New York, but by the late 1960s he had turned his lens away from real spaces, preferring to shoot the television in his living room. As the nearly 200 images here attest, the gap between one and the other is smaller than you’d think. Outside or inside, photographing or rephotographing, Mr. Blumberg observes an America in transition and in crisis, via a medium whose assumed veracity he never stopped questioning.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Sept. 6 to 13, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Sept. 6 to 13, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: Charenée Wade Performs Gil Scott-Heron Works
text: The defining act of alchemy on “Offering: The Music of Gil Scott-Heron and Brian Jackson” (Motéma), a persuasive new album by the jazz singer Charenée Wade, is her version of “Song of the Wind.” In its original incarnation, released in 1977, the tune has a funk-reggae lilt and an obbligato of tropical birdsong, played on a synthesizer. Ms. Wade sings it with a graver air, slow and brooding and serious.

headline: Pérez Art Museum Miami Names Franklin Sirmans as New Director
text: Aspen has a growing reputation among South Florida’s art world heavies as the perfect spot to escape the summer’s ceaseless humidity — call it a Rocky Mountain answer to the Hamptons. Turns out it’s also a good place to pick a new museum director.

headline: China Shows Off Its Military
text: China staged a military parade in Beijing on the 70th anniversary of Japan’s defeat in World War II.

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Sept. 6 to 13, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Dirty Weekend,’ Neil LaBute’s Tale of an Unexpected Layover
text: The comedy of sexual identity “Dirty Weekend” might not be the kind of thing you’d expect to see from the director and playwright Neil LaBute. Despite a reputation for slashing at the jugular, Mr. LaBute has done the equivalent of rolling over and letting his belly be rubbed with this tale of an especially eventful layover in Albuquerque.

headline: In ‘A Sinner in Mecca,’ a Gay Director Ponders His Sexuality and Islamic Faith
text: There is no doubting the courage and conviction of the New York documentarian Parvez Sharma. In “A Jihad for Love,” from 2008, he interviewed devout gay Muslims worldwide. In “A Sinner in Mecca,” Mr. Sharma, who is also gay and Muslim, takes viewers on his 2011 hajj, or pilgrimage, to Islam’s most sacred sites. The journey is fraught with risks: In Saudi Arabia, being gay can mean execution, public lashings or imprisonment. And yet Mr. Sharma has created a swirling, fascinating travelogue and a stirring celebration of devotion.

headline: ‘Treasures and Talismans,’ at the Cloisters, Puts Rings on a Pedestal
text: Why do people wear rings on their fingers? For personal adornment, of course, but as often as not because of the social meanings they bear and communicate. Perhaps the world’s oldest form of jewelry, rings symbolize love, betrothal and marriage. They represent the wearer’s status, group affiliation and ancestry. They express religious, superstitious and moral beliefs. They may be trophies, memorials and, as in the case of the signet ring, a device for sealing and authenticating letters and documents.

headline: Migrant Smuggling in Europe Is Now Worth ‘Billions’
text: BUDAPEST — With thousands of migrants pouring out of Afghanistan and the Middle East, the business of smuggling them across the Balkans into the European Union has grown even larger than the illicit trade in drugs and weapons, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Previewing New Jersey’s Fall Theater Schedule
text: Social media cannot be blamed entirely for the world’s obsessive fascination with the latest thing.

headline: Becoming a Vampire, or Almost Anything Else, in Live Action Role Playing
text: In late July, nearly 60 men and women from around the country pitched their tents in the campground at Croton Point Park in Croton-on-Hudson. They had come to inhabit the World of Darkness as players in the game “Vampire: The Masquerade.” From Friday till Sunday, they enacted their individual roles as members of a complex society of vampires — and participants in a LARP.

text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: In ‘Bedroom Farce,’ Love and Other Jokes
text: Once you’ve heard Freddie Mercury’s voice belting out Queen’s “Crazy Little Thing Called Love” a few times in the Westport Country Playhouse, you’ll have caught the splendid sense of glee that the theater is selling with its production of Alan Ayckbourn’s “Bedroom Farce.”

headline: Review: ‘Saturday Night Fever: The Musical’ at Gateway Is Old but New
text: The stage version of “Saturday Night Fever” now at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport is not the same adaptation that opened on Broadway in 1999. Ben Brantley called that earlier musical based on the hit 1977 film “dreary,” and most other critics agreed. Nevertheless, it ran for 501 performances.

headline: BB-8 Droid Offers Hint of Coming Crush of ‘Star Wars’ Toys
text: One of the first toys to emerge from a tightly held cache of merchandise tied to the next “Star Wars” movie is already the target of a viral crush online: It’s the BB-8 droid, a small, round robot that rolls along the floor at the touch of a smartphone.

headline: Gerry Hayden, Who Took Farm-to-Table Dining to Long Island, Dies at 50
text: Gerry Hayden, a chef who brought a refined style of farm-to-table dining to the East End of Long Island with his restaurant the North Fork Table and Inn, died on Wednesday at his home in Southold, N.Y. He was 50.

headline: Bounding Across Space and Time, via DVD
text: Alastair Macaulay

headline: The Top Tennis Player in the World Started Here
text: Long before he found his way to the top of the sport, where did Novak Djokovic learn to swing a racket? We visit the childhood courts of some of the world’s tennis greats.

headline: Lining Up (Early) for Boutique Pastries in Connecticut
text: At 7:49 on a recent Sunday morning, six people had already lined up in the sweltering heat outside Hen & Heifer, a small pastry shop near the Guilford Town Green. The doors would not open until 8 a.m.

headline: Review: Finca Offers Tapas, Though Not Strictly From Spain
text: Finca, in downtown Ridgewood, is a prime example of how the Spanish tapas trend has inspired small plates at restaurants not exclusively dedicated to the cuisine of Spain. The choices here feature more general Mediterranean — and some Latin-American — influences.

headline: Sotheby’s to Auction A. Alfred Taubman’s $500 Million Trove
text: The chairman’s art collection is coming to Sotheby’s.

headline: Review: Momi Ramen in East Hampton Defies Expectations
text: If you were to make a list of the things you were least likely to want to eat after a day at the beach, a big steaming bowl of ramen noodles would probably be near the top. Anita Chen, owner and manager of Momi Ramen in East Hampton, however, would beg to differ. After several members of Ms. Chen’s family opened the original Momi Ramen in downtown Miami in 2012 to much acclaim, she said, she was inspired to try her luck in another coastal community. Judging by the crowds this summer at the new branch, which opened in June, Ms. Chen’s counterintuitive thinking has paid off.

headline: A Review of Appétit Bistro in Port Chester, N.Y.
text: At the north end of Willett Avenue in Port Chester, Appétit Bistro shares a strip mall with the Nail Palace, the Super Primo Grocery and an Irish pub known for its karaoke night. From arm’s length, the name and the setting do little to set a diner’s heart aflutter, but close up, the sparkling plate-glass facade and two exuberant coleus plants (along with a flurry of five-star reviews on Yelp) raise an expectation or two.

headline: 2015 U.S. Open: As Favorites Are Upended, Many Players Are Wobbly
text: As her second-round match against Garbiñe Muguruza on a sweat-soaked Thursday afternoon dragged on, Johanna Konta caught herself glancing at the courtside clock.

headline: The Eerie Mating Sound
text: A male Attwater’s prairie chicken emits its signature cry during the courtship process.

headline: A Stained-Glass Artist Enjoys a Renaissance
text: Last month the stained-glass artist Robert Pinart revisited two windows he designed that had been installed in the 1980s at the New City Jewish Center in Rockland County, N.Y.

headline: ‘The Jemima Code’ Spotlights Forgotten Black Cooks
text: When the food writer Toni Tipton-Martin lectures about her private collection of recipe books by African-Americans, she said, the back stories have brought audiences to tears. They reveal the lives of maltreated slaves who served meals with European and African culinary roots to plantation owners, and they expose 20th-century white chefs who won acclaim for recipes developed by black colleagues, whom they never properly credited.

headline: Christie’s Puts Chinese Pedestals on the Auction Block
text: An unnamed consignor to a Christie’s sale in New York on Sept. 17 had stocked his home with empty pedestals.

headline: Scenes From Judge Diment’s Courtroom
text: In Bowdon, Ga., Richard A. Diment, a municipal court judge, told traffic violators that they had to immediately pay down fines in his courtroom, or go to jail.

headline: Times Square Topless Woman Is Arrested; 2 Others Are Assaulted, Police Say
text: A topless woman, painted on her torso and soliciting tips for photographs in Times Square, was arrested Wednesday night by undercover officers along with her boyfriend on drug and prostitution charges. Two other topless women with painted torsos were attacked by a visitor from North Carolina who accused them of robbing him, the police said.

headline: Legal Questions Aside, Much Remains Unanswered in the Tom Brady Case
text: In hitting Roger Goodell with a blow that shakes his already wobbly legacy, Judge Richard M. Berman summarized pent-up criticism of the N.F.L. commissioner when he said Goodell had administered “his own brand of industrial justice” to a player he felt had crossed a line.

text: When space tourism finally takes off and the rich and famous head off for a holiday in orbit as easily as on the Riviera, they may want to sip something stronger than Tang as they gaze down at Earth.

headline: Review: Different Thinking About Steve Jobs, the Man Behind Apple
text: The transformative impact Steve Jobs has had on culture and society has become an article of faith since his much-mourned death in 2011. The secular canonization of Mr. Jobs, the mastermind behind Apple, is the starting point for “Steve Jobs: The Man in the Machine,” Alex Gibney’s trenchant new documentary, which asks with sincere curiosity: What’s the fuss about? And more to the point: What’s wrong with this picture?

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Time Out of Mind’

headline: ‘Time Out of Mind’ (With Movie Trailer): Oren Moverman Narrates a Scene
text: He’s played a gigolo, an officer, a lawyer and many other roles over the years. But for the first time in his career, Richard Gere is playing a homeless man. He stars as a down-on-his-luck character in “Time Out of Mind,” from the director Oren Moverman. In this scene, the character is panhandling on the streets of New York.

headline: Theater Listings for Sept. 4-10
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: ‘Transmissions’ at MoMA Explores an Era When Art Upended Tradition
text: A visit to “Transmissions: Art in Eastern Europe and Latin America, 1960-1980,” a big, spirited group show that opens on Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art, is like walking into a party of extremely personable strangers conversing on subjects you can’t quite make out. For every name you recognize, there are 10 you don’t. Multiple languages — Czech, Romanian, Slovak, Spanish, Portuguese, as well as English — fill the air. As for topics discussed, art, poetry, film and theater seem to be getting about equal time.

text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

text: Why this boy?

text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Donald Trump Stumbles and Bristles During Foreign Policy Interview
text: Donald J. Trump revealed gaps in his mastery of international affairs during a radio interview on Thursday, appearing to mistake the Quds Force, an Iranian military group, for the Kurds, a Middle Eastern people, and growing testy over questions about foreign leaders.

headline: Dance Listings for Sept. 4-10
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: ‘Opus Hypnagogia’
text: Art that is born of the state between sleep and wakefulness at the Morbid Anatomy Museum, Brooklyn

headline: Review: The Morbid Anatomy Museum Presents a View From the Subconscious
text: Hypnagogia is an unfamiliar word for a common mental experience. Coined in the 19th century, it refers to the transition period between wakefulness and sleep, when, while still conscious, you might find yourself seeing images, having thoughts or hearing things that make little logical sense. This is the gateway to lucid dreaming and, possibly, astral traveling and divine revelation.

headline: Sensational Murder Case in India Stirs Media Frenzy Fed by Police Leaks
text: NEW DELHI — In the middle of last week, with the arrest of the former media executive Indrani Mukerjea on suspicion of involvement in her daughter’s death, India’s crime reporters embarked on their latest bender.

headline: To Pledge or Not to Pledge?
text: On Thursday, Donald Trump signed a pledge to support the eventual Republican presidential nominee, weeks after saying he wouldn’t. Not everyone agreed with his change of heart.

headline: Drawing a Bead
text: Sue Grafton ignored her own rule when she chose an abbreviated title for the 24th of her popular “alphabet” mysteries. Unlike the other books in this series, which began in 1982 with “A Is for Alibi,” X (Putnam, $28.95) is the big cheese that stands alone. Having made that radical change to her reliable formula, perhaps she’ll make an even bolder move and just keep writing when she ­reaches the end of the alphabet.

headline: Facebook Takes a Step Into Education Software
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook, which transformed communication with its social networking service, now wants to make a similar impact on education.

headline: Candidates Respond to Kim Davis Case With Varying Intensity
text: The fast-developing story of Kim Davis, the Kentucky county clerk ordered to jail on Thursday for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, continued to divide the Republican presidential field.

headline: In Syria’s Struggle, Memories of the Soviet Union
text: Sergey Ponomarev’s trips to Syria reminded him of his native Soviet Union: from the government security forces that kept track of his movements to destroyed areas that looked like the Battle of Stalingrad.

headline: Palestinian Expects Flag Will Fly at U.N.
text: UNITED NATIONS — The Palestinian ambassador to the United Nations said Thursday that he expected to raise the Palestinian flag at the gates of United Nations headquarters in time for the annual meeting of world leaders here at the end of the month.

headline: The Truth of ‘Black Lives Matter’
text: The Republican Party and its acolytes in the news media are trying to demonize the protest movement that has sprung up in response to the all-too-common police killings of unarmed African-Americans across the country. The intent of the campaign — evident in comments by politicians like Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky — is to cast the phrase “Black Lives Matter” as an inflammatory or even hateful anti-white expression that has no legitimate place in a civil rights campaign.

headline: One Worker Dies and 2 Are Injured in Wall Collapse at Brooklyn Construction Site
text: One worker was killed and two others were seriously injured when a wall collapsed on them at a construction site in Brooklyn on Thursday, officials said.

headline: Endre A. Balazs, Doctor Who Found a Lubricant for Arthritic Knees, Dies at 95
text: Dr. Endre A. Balazs, who transformed a syrupy natural lubricant derived from rooster combs into a palliative for arthritic knees and a skin protectant that made eye surgery routine, died on Aug. 29 at a hospital near his summer home in St. Tropez, France. He was 95.

headline: The Hague: Warlord Offers a Defense
text: The Congolese militia leader Bosco Ntaganda, whose trial on war crimes charges opened on Wednesday at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, told his judges on Thursday that “I am not a criminal” but a “trained officer” who always protected civilians. Mr. Ntaganda was allowed to address the court briefly after teams of prosecution and defense lawyers had each delivered their opening presentations on the charges he faces related to attacks in 2002 and 2003 in which villagers in Ituri, a Congolese mining area, were killed or raped. Mr. Ntaganda, 41, who was born in Rwanda, said he had joined the Tutsi forces in Rwanda that put an end to that country’s genocide in 1994, then later moved across the border to Ituri. “The word had gone out to kill all the Tutsis in Ituri, or those who looked like them,” he said. His role was to protect civilians, he said in court. “I ask you to make a distinction between a revolutionary rebel and a criminal.” Earlier, the prosecutor had called him a “notorious and powerful” fighter who enriched himself and used children as his foot soldiers and henchmen and as sexual slaves for his troops. The trial will resume on Sept. 15.

headline: Philip Falcone, Former Head of Vast Fund, Tries a 3rd Act
text: Philip A. Falcone, the brash hedge fund titan who once managed $26 billion before stumbling and running afoul of regulators, is pressing ahead on a new comeback effort, his second.

headline: 3 Corrections Deputies in California Charged With Murder in Death of Mentally Ill Inmate
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — In a rare step, the sheriff of Santa Clara County on Thursday arrested and filed murder charges against three corrections deputies who work for her, after the discovery last week that a mentally ill inmate had bled to death in his cell as a result of a blunt force trauma, according to the local coroner’s office.

headline: Friendship Between Putin and Xi Becomes Strained as Economies Falter
text: BEIJING — They have met more than a dozen times and stood shoulder to shoulder during Thursday’s military parade here. But the once-vaunted relationship between the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, and Russia’s leader, Vladimir V. Putin, has come under strain as the economies of their countries have faltered.

headline: A Terrifying Matchup Even Before It Materializes
text: How intimidating is it to stand on a court across from Serena Williams, one of the greatest tennis players in history?

headline: Indian Automaker Tata Aims to Restore Jaguar’s Cachet in U.S.
text: DETROIT — When Tata Motors of India acquired the Jaguar and Land Rover brands in 2008, the deal added a new twist to the rapid globalization of the auto industry.

headline: Health Care Rules Proposed to Shield Transgender Patients From Bias
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration proposed a rule Thursday that would forbid most health insurers and medical providers to discriminate against transgender patients, including by prohibiting insurers from categorically denying coverage of care related to gender transition.

headline: Guard for Donald Trump Hits Protester
text: In a tussle outside Trump Tower on Thursday, a member of Donald J. Trump’s security team responded to a protester, who had grabbed him from behind, by hitting him in the face.

headline: Liberia: Ebola-Free, for a Second Time
text: The World Health Organization declared Liberia free of Ebola for a second time on Thursday, several months after it was first thought to have halted the virus in May, only to experience a brief resurgence of cases that puzzled epidemiologists. “Today the World Health Organization declares Liberia free of Ebola virus transmission in the human population,” said Dr. Alex Gasasira, the organization’s representative in Liberia. But the Ministry of Health called for 90 days of “heightened surveillance” around the country to watch for any new cases. Dr. Gasasira applauded the government and Liberian communities for their quick response to the May outbreak, which left two people dead. The government has urged all Liberians to continue observing preventive measures like washing hands and is strengthening its monitoring efforts across the country, said Dr. Francis Ketteh, Liberia’s chief medical officer. More than 4,800 people have died in Liberia because of the Ebola crisis, according to the World Health Organization.

headline: Judge Who Jailed Kentucky Clerk Is No Stranger to Controversy
text: Long before he ordered a county clerk to jail on Thursday for refusing to issue same-sex marriage licenses, David L. Bunning first drew attention as a federal judge for a ruling on gay rights.

headline: For His Arrogance in Tom Brady Ruling, Roger Goodell Pays the Price
text: Ah, Roger, being king isn’t what it used to be.

headline: A Back-to-School List With Cameras, Bulletproof Walls and More Deadbolts
text: In his Cold War childhood, Bill Ferguson and his schoolmates at St. Elizabeth’s in Ozone Park, Queens, drilled for air raids that never came. “You hid under the desk, or went to certain places in the building, laid down and covered your eyes,” he said.

headline: Something to Slow-Dance To
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw David C. Duncan Dekker (a name that is incredibly fun to say out loud, unless a tour of the New York Times building is passing by your desk, in which case it’s best not to do that, not that I would know), he was doing some mighty heavy lifting, construction-wise, in a pangrammatic Saturday puzzle from March of this year.

headline: At 41, Jason Gore Brings a Different Look, and Sensibility, to the FedEx Cup Playoffs
text: NORTON, Mass. — At the Plainfield Country Club in New Jersey, Jason Gore outdrove his playing competitor, Dustin Johnson, by 13 yards on the second hole, a 445-yard par 4. Gore, who is four inches shorter than Johnson and easily 50 pounds heavier, flexed his right biceps. Gore’s gesture last week during the third round of the Barclays, the first event of the FedEx Cup playoffs, elicited laughter from Johnson, who is built like a 6-foot-4 small forward to Gore’s 250-pound beer league shortstop.

headline: Veterinary Student Expelled Over a Pet Loses a Court Fight With Cornell
text: In the eyes of his human companion, Shandor was a “playful puppy” and “Alpha Male of the household,” court papers said, known to all to protect his caretaker and be at ease among strangers.

headline: Hotel That Inspired ‘The Shining’ Builds on Its Eerie Appeal
text: ESTES PARK, Colo. — When a young Stephen King checked into the Stanley  Hotel here in 1974, he had a nightmare that inspired him to write “The Shining,” the novel that went on to become Stanley Kubrick’s 1980 cult classic film.

headline: Shooting at Sacramento City College Leaves One Dead and 2 Injured
text: A shooting on the grounds of Sacramento City College left one person dead, two others injured and the campus on lockdown Thursday night, the Sacramento Police Department said.

headline: Leon A. Gorman, Who Made L. L. Bean a Household Name, Dies at 80
text: Leon A. Gorman, who transformed L. L. Bean from his grandfather’s folksy store and catalog business into a billion-dollar global outdoor-gear retailer and made its signature rubber-soled hunting boot as synonymous with Maine as lobster, died on Thursday at his home in Yarmouth, Me. He was 80.

headline: Illinois: Chicago Mayor Weighs Major Property Tax Increase
text: Chicagoans may face a significant tax increase next year as the city, the nation’s third largest, is required to start making larger payments to some of its underfunded pension funds. Mayor Rahm Emanuel, who is expected to issue details of his budget plan for 2016 later this month, acknowledged to reporters on Thursday that he was weighing a property tax increase, which has long been expected here. “It’s going to be fair and progressive,” he said. The Chicago Sun-Times reported that the mayor was poised to raise property taxes by $500 million. He would need approval from Chicago’s City Council.

headline: Smokeless Tobacco Use Found Higher Among Student-Athletes
text: Very active high school athletes use chewing tobacco and other smokeless tobacco products at higher rates than students who do not participate in sports, but they smoke less, according to a report issued Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In 2013, about 6 percent of students who did not play sports used smokeless tobacco, compared with 12.5 percent of students on three or more sports teams. In contrast, 21 percent of students who did not play sports smoked cigarettes, compared with 15.8 percent of students on three sports teams.

headline: Jets Finally See Tebow Throw Touchdown Pass, but It’s for Eagles
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Philadelphia Eagles are expected to put up a lot of points this season, so when their third-team offense scored against the Jets’ second-team defense just before halftime Thursday night, it should not have stunned many on either sideline.

headline: Egypt: American Soldiers Are Wounded
text: Six international peacekeepers stationed in Egypt, including four American soldiers, were wounded by two improvised explosive devices on Thursday, according to the Defense Department. The peacekeepers were part of the Multinational Force and Observers, a mission stationed in Egypt’s restive Sinai Peninsula to support the 1979 peace treaty between Egypt and Israel. The six wounded soldiers were airlifted to a medical facility where they were being treated for injuries that were not life-threatening. “The safety and security of U.S. forces remains our top priority, and we are committed to taking necessary steps for their protection,” said Jeff Davis, a Navy captain who is the director of press operations for the Defense Department, which provided no further information on the soldiers’ injuries or what had happened.

headline: Aylan Kurdi’s Death Resonates in Canadian Election Campaign
text: OTTAWA — While the photograph of a 3-year-old Syrian boy’s body quickly focused the world’s attention on the migrant crisis in the Middle East and Africa, it has taken on a particular resonance in Canada with the discovery that the boy’s family had been unable to obtain immigration visas.

headline: Giants Game No Match for News Off the Field
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The Giants and the New England Patriots completed regular-season preparations on Thursday night with a preseason finale at Gillette Stadium that was insignificant compared with off-field news.

headline: California Lawmaker Is Focus of House Ethics Panel Inquiry
text: The House Ethics Committee is investigating allegations that Representative Mike Honda, Democrat of California, may have improperly used his government office staff to help his re-election efforts over the last four years, the committee confirmed Thursday, as it released a preliminary report on the inquiry. The initial review, conducted by the Office of Congressional Ethics, found that his staff appeared to have “researched a potential campaign opponent, prepared materials for the campaign, used information from the congressional office for campaign purposes and discussed campaign matters during official meetings,” in the lawmaker’s district office and at a staff retreat. Mr. Honda has denied that he formally broke the rules, but his aides have conceded that he could have done a better job separating political and government business. The Ethics Committee said it would continue to investigate the matter, but it put no deadline on its inquiry.

headline: Colorado: Pro-Marijuana Activists Pull Back on Ballot Measure
text: Pro-marijuana activists campaigning to allow the drug to be used legally in adults-only businesses like nightclubs or bars said on Thursday they were withdrawing a ballot measure that would have put the issue before voters in Denver in November. Activists said they were pulling the initiative because they believed they could reach a compromise with city  officials and business groups that would result in local legislation to allow some limited social use of marijuana in Denver. When Colorado voters in 2012 became the first in the nation, along with Washington State, to legalize marijuana for recreational use, they did so with a caveat: No public use. But advocates said the restrictions on public use were too strict and had prohibited marijuana everywhere except private homes and a handful of marijuana-friendly bed-and-breakfasts scattered around the state. The ballot proposal would have allowed people to eat edible marijuana or inhale vaporized forms of marijuana indoors, but would have relegated smoking to outdoor areas blocked from public view. Organizers said that it was still too early to know what might be included in a compromise ordinance, and that if the effort stalled, they might reintroduce the ballot measure next year.

headline: Suspect and Witness Are Sought in Fatal Brooklyn Fight
text: The two men stood outside the restaurant and bar in Bushwick, Brooklyn, last month, arguing. Then the disagreement escalated into a physical fight, leaving the police to find one of them on the sidewalk critically injured.

headline: Drone Crashes Into Seats at Armstrong
text: An unauthorized drone crashed into a section of empty seats at Louis Armstrong Stadium about 8:30 p.m. Thursday during a second-round match between Flavia Pennetta and Monica Niculescu, causing a brief delay and some fear and confusion.

headline: Dr. J. Donald Millar, 81, Dies; Led C.D.C. Mission That Helped Eradicate Smallpox
text: Dr. J. Donald Millar, a physician and former public-health official whose work helped eradicate smallpox in Africa and with it, the world, died on Sunday at his home in Murrayville, Ga. He was 81.

headline: Plane Crashes in New Jersey, Injuring 2 Pilots
text: A Coast Guard plane crashed in a field in northern New Jersey on Thursday afternoon, seriously injuring the pilot and co-pilot, officials said.

headline: A Defeat. Retirement. Then a Win. All in a Day.
text: The last point of Lisa Raymond’s career seemed as if it might go on forever. The ball went back and forth over the net on Court 6, allowing Raymond numerous chances to hit a final forehand, a last backhand or a farewell volley.

headline: ESPN Extends Curt Schilling’s Ban
text: ESPN suspended Curt Schilling, one of its “Sunday Night Baseball” analysts, for the rest of the regular season and the postseason wild-card playoff game — extending punishment that had already been imposed for sharing a Twitter meme last month about extremist Muslims and Nazis. Schilling was suspended from one Little League World Series game and last Sunday’s prime-time Major League Baseball game.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | wispy
text: wispy • \ˈwis-pe\ • adjective

headline: Transition in Guatemala
text: In a Guatemala City courtroom on Thursday, former President Otto Pérez Molina said he intends to “face up” to allegations. Meanwhile, his vice president, Alejandro Maldonado, was sworn in.

headline: Lleyton Hewitt Exits Final Open Showing the Tenacity That Defined His Career
text: It looked at first like a pure mercy killing. In what he has called his final United States Open, in the last working year of the intimate setting known as the Grandstand, Lleyton Hewitt was absorbing a routine beating at the hands of Bernard Tomic, his 22-year-old countryman.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
text: 9 P.M. (13) AMERICAN MASTERS: ALTHEA Arthur Ashe may have been the first African-American man to win Wimbledon, in 1975. But Althea Gibson (1927-2003), above, broke the color barrier nearly two decades earlier, in 1957, becoming the first African-American woman to win that tournament as well as the United States Nationals (the precursor of the United States Open). This documentary from Rex Miller traces the life of Ms. Gibson, the daughter of a South Carolina sharecropper who as a young child moved with her family to Harlem, where she progressed from paddle tennis on the streets to tennis at the Cosmopolitan Club and on to Florida A&M with the help of the bandleader Buddy Walker, the boxer Sugar Ray Robinson and two African-American doctors, Hubert Eaton and Robert W. Johnson. In the 1950s, she emerged as the queen of a sport that was still highly segregated and went on to win 11 Grand Slam titles, including six in doubles. The Wimbledon champions Billie Jean King (an executive producer of the film) and Dick Savitt; Jeanne Moutoussamy-Ashe, Mr. Ashe’s widow; and Angela Buxton, Ms. Gibson’s doubles partner, among others, offer perspective.

headline: ATP Weighs Clearer Discipline for Players’ Comments
text: Sergiy Stakhovsky, who plays his third-round match Friday at the United States Open against Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, has spent a week in restrained silence — or as close as Stakhovsky can get to silence.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Now I don’t want anything. Even if you give me all the countries in the world, I don’t want them. What was precious is gone.”

headline: Corrections: September 4, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: In Syria’s Struggle, Memories of the Soviet Union
text: PERPIGNAN, France — Sergey Ponomarev’s first visit to Syria in 2009 — as a tourist — triggered memories of his childhood in the Soviet Union: such as when government security officers questioned him and his girlfriend when they bought tickets at bus stations in Damascus.

headline: After Beijing’s Military Parade, Blue Skies Yield to Gray
text: Just hours after China’s Victory Day extravaganza on Thursday, when splendid blue skies framed a parade of thousands of troops marching through central Beijing to celebrate the end of World War II, the city’s air was filling again with dirt. An independent air-quality monitoring site showed pollution levels rising sharply from midnight.

headline: Cheeseburger, Hold the Salmonella
text: Americans eat more than 50 pounds of beef per person each year. That’s a lot of beef. It’s also a lot of risk, because about half — or more than two billion pounds — is ground beef, which can too easily harbor dangerous bacteria. There is always an uproar after serious outbreaks of illness like the Jack in the Box case in 1993, when 700 people were sickened and four children died after eating tainted hamburgers. But as a new report points out, there is more the Department of Agriculture and the Food and Drug Administration can do to keep Americans safe and some simple things consumers could do themselves.

headline: Refugee Crisis in Europe
text: To the Editor:

headline: G.E., Finish the Job on the Hudson
text: Hudson River update, September 2015: The river is still contaminated and it’s still General Electric’s fault. Toxic industrial waste is still flowing down nearly 200 miles of river from north of Albany to New York City. And though the company has spent the last six years digging up the PCBs that it dumped into the river decades ago, it is about to walk away from an unfinished job. It is getting ready to dismantle its dredging operation this fall, and leave 136 undredged acres for others to worry about.

headline: Doctor-Patient Talks About Sex
text: To the Editor:

headline: Does Down Syndrome Justify Abortion?
text: Villanova, Pa. — IT was the most heart-wrenching moment of our lives, and all I could do was stare at the tissue box.

headline: Foiling the Islamic State
text: To the Editor:

headline: Simplifying College Financial Aid Forms
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ronald Reagan, Heretic
text: In just under two weeks, the Republicans who want to be president will gather in Simi Valley, Calif., at the presidential library of Ronald Reagan for their second debate. You can expect much brown-nosing, bloviating and outright fabricating in homage to the patron saint of all true conservatives, the charming 40th president.

headline: Disband the Benghazi Committee
text: Washington — NOT long after it was formed last year, members of the Select Committee on Benghazi gathered to meet privately with family members of the four Americans killed on that dreadful night in Libya in 2012. The meetings were emotional, and the chairman assured those present that the committee would be scrupulously nonpartisan and devoted to finding out the truth of what had happened.

headline: The New Romantics in the Computer Age
text: Just once I’d like to have a college student come up to me and say, “I really wanted to major in accounting, but my parents forced me to major in medieval art.” That probably won’t happen. It always seems to be the parents who are pushing their children in the “practical” or mercenary direction.

headline: Other People’s Dollars, and Their Place in Global Economics
text: Sydney, Australia — Soon after arriving here, I stopped at an A.T.M.; I needed some dollars, and all I had were dollars.

headline: History Purged or Exposed?
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Teens in Crisis, the Next Text Could Be a Lifesaver
text: The message to the Crisis Text Line was answered by Aaron Amrich, a volunteer crisis counselor based in California. It was sent by a 19-year-old woman who wrote that she was feeling hopeless and beginning to give up on life. Amrich, a veteran who served in Afghanistan and Iraq, has himself suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder and depression. He understood the feeling.

headline: News Q’s | Backpack Makers Rethink a Student Staple
text: In “Backpack Makers Rethink a Student Staple,” Hiroko Tabuchi reports on how the backpack is being redesigned for electronics and the needs of living on the go.

headline: Online Gambling Firm Bwin.Party Favors GVC Holdings Bid
text: LONDON — The battle for Bwin.Party Digital Entertainment took another turn on Friday as the online gambling company said its board of directors would now recommend that shareholders approve an offer from its rival GVC Holdings over a previously agreed-to deal with 888 Holdings.

headline: How the Co-op Crumbles
text: For three decades, Todd Selbert has lived in a sunny one-bedroom on the Upper East Side, surrounded by books, his vast jazz record collection and several abstract oil paintings. A former advertising executive, Mr. Selbert, 75, owns the top floor of a four-story co-op at 150 East 78th Street.

headline: Exploring Havasu Falls
text: Havasu Falls are at the bottom of a narrow gorge near the southwest corner of the Grand Canyon National Park.

headline: Boise State Faces the Coach Who Helped It Grow
text: BOISE, Idaho — The words “blue collar” are painted in large block letters along one wall of Boise State’s football weight room. This would seem to be a perfectly appropriate ethos for Boise State’s football program, given that its identity is so closely tied to blue — the color of the Broncos’ quirky playing surface.

headline: What We Learned From Summer Love
text: We know love blooms in New York City in the summer; after all, we live here. But as the Metro staff of The New York Times traveled the five boroughs for our Summer Love series, we got some surprises.

headline: Remarrying the Ex: Ilze Thielmann and Aitken Thompson Try Again
text: During Aitken Thompson and Ilze Thielmann’s many years together, they have been through all kinds of relationship stages and permutations: platonic best friends; girlfriend and boyfriend; ex-girlfriend and ex-boyfriend sharing an apartment; husband and wife; divorced; friendly, sometimes flirtatious, co-parents; and exes who go on a date together.

headline: Within the Grand Canyon, the Lure of Havasu Falls
text: One has only to lay eyes on a picture of the incandescent pools of Havasu Falls, somewhere between beryl and cerulean, to feel its pull. The vibrant basins of the rippling natural pool are a study in contrast with the stunning force of the waterfall that crashes into them, spilling 90 feet over red rocks. It is, simply, beatific. And the falls, at the bottom of a narrow gorge near the southwest corner of the Grand Canyon National Park, are about a two-mile hike north of Supai Village in one of the most remote indigenous-American enclaves in the country.

headline: Rihm to Replace Boulez as Lucerne Academy Director
text: The German composer Wolfgang Rihm will succeed Pierre Boulez next summer as the artistic director of the Lucerne Festival Academy, which trains young musicians, composers and directors in music of the 20th and 21st centuries, the festival announced on Friday.

headline: Conducting a Field Test on Pheromones
text: In a room full of strangers, who are you drawn to? I enjoy rueful laughter, and thus, in any given setting, will gravitate toward a man who looks like Jeff Goldblum or a woman with a throaty Sambuca rasp.

headline: Learning to Live With Vitiligo
text: Everyone has a sort of avatar, a mental image of an ideal self that sits in the corner of your consciousness, sneering or smiling, as you surf the day. You, walking the city streets. You, skulking out of the movies. You, riding the mechanical bull at Gilley’s.

headline: Billy Eichner, Off the Street and Into the Museum of Sex
text: “This is like a terrible ‘Sex and the City’ episode,” said the comedian Billy Eichner, standing in the lobby of the Museum of Sex on a recent afternoon while peering at pleasure devices both manual and electric, metal and plastic, large and small, contoured and classically cylindrical.

headline: Exodus of Syrians Highlights Political Failure of the West
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Arresting images of desperation on the West’s doorstep have brought Syria, for the moment, back to worldwide attention: refugees cramming into train stations and climbing border fences; drowned Syrian toddlers washing up on beaches, a girl in polka dots, a boy in tiny shoes.

headline: What Heroic Acts Have You Performed or Witnessed?
text: Last month, the account of three men subduing a gunman on a Paris-bound train made headlines around the world.

headline: ‘Star Wars’ Fans Flock to Midnight Store Openings for New Toys
text: Unlike the typical costumed characters in Times Square, these Stormtroopers did not ask for money.

headline: Yoda, as a Toy
text: Hundreds of toys are hitting the market in a huge marketing push for the coming “Star Wars” movie. This interactive Yoda doll from Spin Master ($180) says it will teach children to be a Jedi.

headline: Chinese Company to Buy Avolon in $7.6 Billion Deal
text: HONG KONG — Bohai Leasing of China plans to buy the Irish aircraft leasing firm Avolon in a deal with worth $7.6 billion, the companies said.

headline: Jobs Report Gives Ammunition to Both Sides of Fed Rate Debate
text: Despite disappointing job growth last month, the unemployment rate fell to its lowest level since early 2008, sharpening the debate within the Federal Reserve over whether to raise interest rates when policy makers meet in two weeks.

headline: Migrants Cross Austria Border From Hungary
text: NICKELSDORF, Austria — Thousands of migrants who have been bottled up in Hungary, demanding passage to the West, will be allowed into Austria and Germany, the Austrian chancellor said late Friday. Early Saturday, the first buses carrying them arrived at the Hungary-Austria border.

headline: Bayer to List Polymer Business Covestro in 4th Quarter I.P.O.
text: LONDON — The German drug maker Bayer said on Friday that it planned to list its newly spun-off polymer business, Covestro, in an initial public offering in Germany this year.

headline: Resort and Tour News: Winter Trips in Yellowstone; Beer History in London
text: Our morning travel news digest, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

headline: Stephen Schwarzman of Blackstone Feels the Agony of Victory

headline: London Theater Journal: A Scorching Momma Rose
text: LONDON – The small, determined woman who is sharing her obsessions so enthrallingly from the stage of the Savoy Theater here is unmistakably a product of the United States. She’s as American as apple pie — or perhaps the homemade blueberry kind she says she’s so tired of; as American as the Great Depression, marathon dancing and another desperate soul who took his country’s myth of success too much to heart, Willy Loman from “Death of a Salesman.”

headline: ‘The Moon’
text: This poem, translated from the original Spanish, unfolds as a litany of the many ways the moon has been described. One long, complex sentence links all the previous iterations, while a second, much shorter sentence isolates the image of yet another moon. The prose-poem form seems to contain the patch of night sky from which that new apprehension — the moon reflected in the vision of a solitary witness, the poem’s speaker — arrives.

headline: How to Fight Fires From a Plane
text: ‘‘Your job is to slow the fire down and buy time for the firefighters on the ground,’’ says John Gallaher, a pilot who travels the country dropping fire retardant from the air. Every morning, check out of your hotel, and be prepared to check into another one thousands of miles away at day’s end. Always keep your packed bags loaded in the plane.

headline: Today in Politics: Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton Have an Island All to Themselves
text: Good Friday morning. Donald J. Trump had a big day on Thursday, but on Friday, other candidates, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Hillary Rodham Clinton, will find themselves in Puerto Rico at the same time. And Mr. Rubio is wasting little time previewing his idea of what the general election might look like.

headline: The Intruder
text: My friend Pierre recently bought a house in Popenguine, a small seaside town in Senegal. Determined to mold the house into more of his dream and less of its previous owner’s, he has gutted and remodeled its interior, broken up the pavement outside, replaced the wiring (after he was electrocuted in the shower) and even uprooted and transplanted full-grown trees.

headline: Morning Agenda: Markets Slide Ahead of U.S. Jobs Report
text: MARKETS SLIDE AHEAD OF U.S. JOBS REPORT | Markets were cautious on Friday ahead of the latest United States labor market report, Reuters reports. Asian markets extended their losses on Friday morning, with the Nikkei 225 closing down 2.15 percent. Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday. European stocks were also down in early trading.

headline: How Economists Can Be Just as Irrational as the Rest of Us
text: Retailers know that the items they place at eye level of store shelves will sell faster than those that are down low. The top headline on a news website will usually be clicked more often than the ones down lower. So maybe it shouldn’t be surprising that the same logic applies to economics research, with long-lasting implications for what ideas are propagated.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Fanny Packs
text: My maternal grandmother, Helen, was a fashion icon of her own making. The daughter of a master tailor, she became an eager seamstress herself. Once, as a teenager, sneaking into her father’s sewing room to whip together a fancy dress, she was so overcome with enthusiasm that she ran a needle straight through her finger. In later years, she abandoned dresses for velour track suits, which made her look like an early-’80s M.C., except she covered hers with every single item in stock from Michaels Arts & Crafts — floral appliqué, rhinestones, puffy paint, embroidery, ribbons, sequins, confetti, ‘‘Proudest Grandma’’ patches. If she could have decorated her clothes with fresh fruit, I think she would have.

headline: The Fight to Save a Prairie Chicken
text: EAGLE LAKE, Tex. — Every spring during mating season, the few dozen remaining male Attwater’s prairie chickens gather to perform an elaborate courtship ritual.

headline: On Stockholm’s Islands, Chasing Insects and Literary Inspiration
text: I came to Runmaro to meet a peculiar entomologist with a gift for digression, and to try to understand the secret life of the Baltic island he has lived on for nearly 30 years — a place just one hour away from Stockholm but accessible only by boat, whose complicated natural and literary history is encoded in a landscape of deceptively simple beauty.

headline: Weeks After Tianjin Blasts, Many Residents Await Compensation for Damaged Homes
text: The chemical blasts that rocked the northeastern port city of Tianjin last month damaged an estimated 17,000 homes, shattering windows, overturning furniture and knocking down walls. But more than three weeks after the explosions, many Tianjin residents have yet to receive compensation for their losses, and some say they have been pressured into dropping their claims.

We go to the office to be efficient, not to form bonds. We have plenty of productive conversations but fewer meaningful relationships.

headline: 1915: Maker of Tape Machine Dies
text: LONDON — In newspaper offices, in clubs and in large hotels, is kept a little wizard under a glass case, and it is called a tape machine. All night through it sings a metallic song about things that have happened at the ends of the earth — and in the street round the corner. To people without the mechanical faculty this machine is a perpetual wonder, for the wheels that seem to hesitate and change their mind about a letter appear to hide a divinity. But the only divinity is that of the operator at the central office, where all news is gathered and tapped out. The man who perfected this instrument, Mr. Frederick W.H. Higgins, has died at his house at Stamford Hill, London. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 5, 1915

headline: A Surreptitious Courtroom Video Prompts Changes in a Georgia Town
text: An explosion of cellphone videos has brought renewed attention to police practices, provoking criticism, indictments and talk of criminal justice overhaul. Courtroom videos of judges in action, however, are far rarer.

headline: Apple Kuchen for a Sweet Jewish New Year
text: Aunt Edith was the best cook I knew when I was a boy. Everything that came from her kitchen was sensational. Dinner at her house was unlike other dining, better than most restaurants. The food was so intoxicatingly delicious, and so abundant, I always ate and ate like there was no tomorrow. And oh, my, could this lady bake.

headline: A Critic’s Guide to New York City’s Best Climbing Trees
text: A few ideas on where to hang out during the waning days of summer.

headline: Ann Beattie’s ‘The State We’re In’
text: Ann Beattie’s first collection of new short stories in a decade is mostly set in the state I’m in. This means I read “The State We’re In: Maine Stories” with the kind of suspicious diligence one uses in scouring a dog for ticks: looking for regional missteps, out-of-tune phrasings, any sign she had committed the special literary felony of getting Maine wrong. That she had committed the kind of sins summer people — one of which Beattie, who divides her time between Key West and Maine, has long been — might be prone to commit. You know, throwing out the Cabot Cove “ayuhs” while the curtains at the cottage windows billow in the shore breeze and the colorful lobster buoys bob in the harbor.

headline: Prose on Poetry
text: THE OCEAN, THE BIRD, AND THE SCHOLAREssays on Poets and PoetryBy Helen Vendler444 pp. Harvard University, $35.

headline: Inside the Walls
text: “We should not be tolerating overcrowding in prison,” President Obama said in July. Against the backdrop of a growing national debate about incarceration rates in America, Phaidon is republishing Danny Lyon’s “Conversations With the Dead,” a book of photographs taken inside six Texas prisons in the late 1960s.

headline: ‘A Clue to the Exit,’ by Edward St. Aubyn
text: “Those of us who are dying,” Charlie Fairburn writes toward the end of this sparkling and morbid confession of a novel, “as opposed to those who are lounging around in their studies making dinner engagements, and then reluctantly disconnecting the phone for 20 minutes in order to browse through a medieval textbook and look up some realistic details — those of us who are really dying haven’t got time to ponder the past. The present is scintillating with horror and precision.”

headline: ‘The Wake,’ by Paul Kingsnorth
text: What happens after the end? Since the portrayals of world-destroying deluges in early writings (“Gilgamesh,” the Matsya Purana, Genesis, the “Timaeus”), narratives of apocalypse have structured our understanding of time and history. Religious eschatology looks to the end of days as a prelude to the absolute finality of the kingdom of God. Secularized as “the Singularity,” a similar idea drives the imagination of Silicon Valley entrepreneurs and cybernetic doomsayers, who believe we are approaching a technological punctum beyond which humanity as we know it will no longer exist. In the face of economic crisis and anxiety about climate change, postapocalyptic science fiction, long a genre staple, is undergoing one of its cyclical peaks of popularity. Our screens and pages are crowded with survivors, grimly coping with the aftermath of plagues, wars, natural disasters, zombie attacks and alien invasions.

headline: ‘The Making of Asian America,’ by Erika Lee
text: Early in Erika lee’s sweeping “The Making of Asian America: A History” she suggests that Asian-Americans constantly cycle between being labeled “good Asians” versus “bad Asians,” depending on the shifting and often contradictory politics behind their immigration and settlement. We were a “despised ­minority” when Asian immigrants threatened 19th- and early-20th-century white labor, yet since the Cold War we’ve been described as a “model minority,” valorizing the promise of American meritocracy. The capricious ease with which those labels get swapped highlights how our precarious social position rests on our perceived utility: as cheap labor, as anti-­Communist soldiers, as overachievers meant to ­success-shame other communities of ­color. In doing all of this “work,” Lee argues, Asian-­Americans have redefined not only immigration politics and racial categories but also “the very essence of what it means to be ­American.”

headline: ‘Trigger Mortis: A James Bond Novel,’ by Anthony Horowitz
text: James Bond is a synchronic spy. From the day that the first Bond thriller, “Casino Royale,” was published in 1953, all the way through to this year’s forthcoming “Spectre” movie, Bond has always been thoroughly modern, with all the latest toys. In “Trigger Mortis: A James Bond Novel,” however, Bond ventures somewhere Ian Fleming, or the movie producer Albert Broccoli, would never go: back, into the past.

headline: ‘You Too Can Have a Body Like Mine,’ by Alexandra Kleeman
text: Edgar Allan Poe’s unnamed narrator in “The Man of the Crowd” sits in a coffee shop referred to as “D,” looking toward the street and its never-ending stream of passing strangers. At nightfall, amid the multitude, he spots a man who absorbs his attention. He decides to pursue him, until at last the sun begins to rise again and the narrator realizes that he has been following nothing but a man of the crowd — a man, the reader suspects, who mirrors the narrator in his banal pursuit of others and in his incapacity for being alone.

headline: Inside the List
text: The 11th Coming: “The Nature of the Beast,” Louise Penny’s 11th novel about the Québécois detective Armand Gamache, hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 3. Penny started the series in 2005 after two decades as a CBC radio host, and its popularity caught her by surprise. “It’s difficult to learn from success. I’ve learned more from my mistakes,” she told the author and critic Joel Yanofsky in 2013. “Fortunately, I’m capable of manufacturing my own problems.” In her 20s and early 30s those included a battle with alcoholism, and later a five-year bout of writer’s block that was, according to Yanofsky, “mainly spent watching Oprah, eating gummy bears and lying to everyone, including her husband, about how well her writing was going.” Things have improved since then. “Now I know that if I’m not in the top five on the Times best-seller list, I’m going to feel like a failure,” she said in the same interview. No worries here! But that doesn’t mean Penny’s life is challenge-free: In the past few years she’s had to care for her husband as he slides into dementia. “I find now that the writing is a safe harbor,” she told The Vancouver Sun last month. “It’s a place I go to that is mine.” You have to wonder if Penny had her husband’s condition in mind when she quoted Yeats’s “The Second Coming” in the new book — that’s the poem about things falling apart and the center not holding, which concludes, “And what rough beast, its hour come round at last, / Slouches towards Bethlehem to be born?” Maybe. But mostly, Penny told The Sun, “the beast is ourselves.”

headline: Donald Trump Golf Course Seeks to Ease Tax Bite With Lower Valuation
text: For Donald Trump, it is typically good business to be optimistic about the worth of his extensive portfolio of golf courses and real estate developments. But in one instance, the Republican presidential hopeful is apparently seeing benefits in minimizing the value of a property.

headline: Donald Trump’s Gomorrah Problem
text: This past week, in an effort to make his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination seem less somnolent, Jeb Bush released an ad attacking Donald J. Trump. Using years-old footage of interviews with Mr. Trump, the ad intends to show us that the Republican presidential campaign’s current front-runner is an ideological phony — an espouser of liberal beliefs who has variously declared himself in favor of abortion rights, single-payer health care and more aggressively taxing the very rich. (This last position is one he hasn’t even tried to conceal, given that as recently as two weeks ago, he appeared on “Face the Nation” arguing that current tax policy left hedge funders “getting away with murder.”)

headline: A Day After 71 Migrants Died, 81 Escaped the Back of a Truck in Austria

But those migrants saved their lives by breaking open a truck door with a crowbar and were eventually abandoned near a traffic circle in eastern Austria.

Donoghue’s 2010 novel “Room” followed a mother and child who develop a loving and imaginative existence despite their punishing captivity. Here, the author reimagines a real-life unsolved murder from 1870s San Francisco. Blanche, a French prostitute, befriends Jenny, a cross-dressing vendor of frogs’ legs. After Jenny is murdered in the room they share, Blanche suspects that she herself was the intended target.
