text: In The New York Times Book Review, Kaui Hart Hemmings reviews Bill Clegg’s first novel, “Did You Ever Have a Family.” Ms. Hemmings writes:

headline: Blocked by Rail, Migrants Set Out for Germany on Foot
text: Hundreds of migrants who had been stranded at a train station in Budapest began walking toward Germany.

headline: Blue Claws: The Tasty Embodiment of Crabby
text: At first glance, an adult blue claw crab is a creature with claws and spines at every joint — with a few extras thrown in for good measure. It does not seem to have many good moods and is inclined to fits of anger, which it expresses like a cartoon Tasmanian devil: blood-crazed and claw-waving.

headline: How I Spent My Summer: With Bernstein and Stravinsky
text: Given that Stravinsky’s “The Rite of Spring” has long been a staple of orchestra programs, it’s hard to convey how radical this 1913 shocker was still considered to be during the mid-1960s, when I was a high school student. The score was thought to be playable only by major orchestras equipped to grapple with its difficulties. In contrast, most conservatory ensembles today can perform it capably.

headline: Hillary Clinton on Bernie Sanders: Waving Your Arms Doesn’t Mean a Lot
text: In the third sit-down national TV interview of her presidential campaign, Hillary Rodham Clinton said the candidacy of Donald J. Trump was a “bad development for our American political system,” rejected the implication that her campaign was irrevocably damaged by the email controversy and took a veiled jab at Senator Bernie Sanders, whose populist message has drawn big crowds and given him a lift in recent polls in Iowa and New Hampshire.

headline: Carbon Cuts So Sharp Even California Democrats Are Divided
text: SACRAMENTO — With President Obama back from a trip to Alaska in which he portrayed the fight against climate change as an urgent international priority, California is showing how hard it can be — even in a state overwhelmingly controlled by Democrats — to get an ambitious carbon reduction bill passed.

headline: Giants Cut Weatherford, One of the Last of Their Super Bowl Winners
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants on Friday released punter Steve Weatherford, a popular player and one of the few remaining links in the locker room to the franchise’s last Super Bowl-winning team. Giants Coach Tom Coughlin had been sparse in his praise of Weatherford this preseason and frequently hinted that the team might be in the market for a new punter.

headline: Obama and Saudi King Sidestep Dispute Over Iran Nuclear Deal
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and King Salman of Saudi Arabia moved to put their differences behind them on Friday in a long-delayed White House meeting amid months of tension over the nuclear agreement with Iran and a continuing schism over the way forward in Syria.

headline: A Lamp That Brings the Cosmos Indoors
text: This lamp is called Helios and seems to conjure celestial bodies in motion. The sun is a naked bulb, burning bright or barely glowing, depending on how you deploy the dimmer or position the 12-inch hand-spun brass dish that serves as a planetary lampshade — angled in front, it creates a full eclipse. Designed by Robert Highsmith, a co-founder of the Brooklyn-based Workstead studio, known for a spare, industrial aesthetic warmed by luxurious materials (they did the interiors of the Wythe Hotel in Williamsburg), the lamp’s luminous components hover above a 4-inch cube base, available in three types of stone: pale Italian Carrara, deeply veined green Connemara and creamy gray travertine. Tethered yet flexible, it would have looked at home in Galileo’s lab.

headline: ‘Grandpa Woodstock’ Spreads Peace and Love on a Village Green
text: “Peace and love,” repeated Grandpa Woodstock. “I spread peace and love, that’s what I do.”

headline: Judge’s Ruling Offers Peek Into Private Equity’s Secret World
text: Infiltrating the supersecret world of private equity is difficult, so any glimpse into how these firms operate is worth highlighting.

headline: A Notorious 19th-Century Kidnapping in Brooklyn
text: Q. I am trying to locate the residence of a Brooklyn judge where two burglars were once gunned down.

headline: Rikers Island Captain and Officer Are Charged With Beating Inmate, 18
text: A Rikers Island captain and a correction officer were charged on Friday with assaulting a teenage inmate in a storage room where there were no video surveillance cameras, and then filing false paperwork to conceal their actions.

headline: Piercing the Denial on Refugees
text: Photographs of a lifeless little boy, dressed in a red shirt and dark shorts, lying face down on a beach, and then, minutes later, cradled in the arms of a police officer, have taken the world by storm. These heartbreaking images of 3-year-old Aylan Kurdi, who drowned when the rubber dinghy that was to carry him and his Syrian family to safety in Greece capsized off the coast of Turkey on Wednesday, have succeeded, finally, in bringing home the terrible human cost of Europe’s failure to deal with a surging refugee crisis.

headline: Obama Meets With Saudi King
text: The president and King Salman of Saudi Arabia met at the White House to discuss topics including the Iran nuclear deal and the conflict in Syria.

headline: Ernest Logan’s Sunday Routine Goes From Church Back to School
text: While New York City’s principals, assistant principals and district supervisors rinse off the sand and sunblock to get their schools student-ready this week, the head of their union, Ernest A. Logan, is on call. A former Brooklyn principal, Mr. Logan, 64, has led the 6,500-member Council of School Supervisors and Administrators for the past 10 years. He lives in Brooklyn’s Crown Heights North Historic District with his wife, Beatrice Logan, 68, a retired guidance counselor. For them, Sunday is all about church, a daylong event filled with prayer, song and service. “I encounter a lot of crazy stuff on this job,” Mr. Logan said. “I have to stop and pause.”

headline: National Humanities Medal Winners Include Larry McMurtry and Alice Waters
text: The authors Larry McMurtry, Annie Dillard and Jhumpa Lahiri are among the 10 recipients of the National Humanities Medal, which will be bestowed by President Barack Obama at a White House ceremony on Thursday.

headline: Restaurants Take the Din Out of Dining
text: From the outside, Untitled looks like one of those places where intimate conversation gets lost in the din.

headline: New Books on the City After War and After Buffalo
text: Father Duffy’s monument is in the middle of Times Square, but it’s unfamiliar to most New Yorkers and few can identify its honoree. That’s just one of many reasons to read “New York and the First World War: Shaping an American City” (Ashgate).

headline: Peoria Settles Suit Over Parody Twitter Account That Mocked Mayor
text: Public officials are easy targets for parody accounts on Twitter.

headline: Chinese Navy Ships Entered U.S. Waters Legally, Pentagon Says
text: WASHINGTON — Five Chinese Navy ships that sailed this week off the coast of Alaska entered United States territorial waters, but they have since left the area, Pentagon officials said on Friday.

headline: Emails Give Insight Into National Youth Theater Leader Decision to Cancel Play
text: LONDON — An email sent by the artistic director of the National Youth Theater, that has been made public offers insight into why his company abruptly canceled its production of “Homegrown” — a play about young Islamic State recruits — before its planned opening in August.

headline: College Football Games to Watch This Weekend
text: Saturday

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: Hearings on email, presidential trips to Alaska, Donald J. Trump and other candidates on the road.

headline: Food Choices Expand Near Grand Central
text: A permanent new indoor food hall on Vanderbilt Avenue next to Grand Central Terminal is set to open Sept. 14. It’s from UrbanSpace, which runs outdoor pop-up markets of vendors (not just the food type) in London and New York. This time, it’s all food. Kiosks from about 20 producers line the perimeter, with some booths, including Red Hook Lobster Pound’s, in the center. There are communal tables. Whet your appetite for Roberta’s pizza, Toby’s Estate Coffee, La Palapa tacos and Amali Mou for wines by the glass: UrbanSpace Vanderbilt, 230 Vanderbilt Avenue (45th Street), 646-747-0822, urbanspacenyc.com.

headline: U.N. Official Urges Stronger Action by Peacekeepers in Central African Republic
text: GENEVA — United Nations peacekeepers should take tougher action against armed groups to restore stability to the crisis-torn Central African Republic, the United Nations human rights chief said Friday, but they need to be reinforced with more men and attack helicopters to fulfill their mission.

headline: The Many Pitfalls of Private Student Loans
text: Mallory Rego, the first member of her family to attend college, says she now sees that she put too much blind faith in the power of education.

headline: The Narcissist in Chief
text: WITH the presidential campaign in full swing, a perennial question has resurfaced: How much weight should voters give to candidates’ personalities? The political rise of Donald J. Trump has drawn attention to one personality trait in particular: narcissism. Although narcissism does not lend itself to a precise definition, most psychologists agree that it comprises self-centeredness, boastfulness, feelings of entitlement and a need for admiration.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Quarterback’s Headache Solved!
text: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 15-year-old boy with the worst headache of his life. I thought it was a fascinating case and apparently so did many of you. More than 120 readers offered some very thoughtful possibilities and nearly two dozen of you got it right.

headline: On Beyoncé’s Birthday, a ‘Bey Day’ Celebration Fit for a Queen
text: For most Americans, it’s merely the Friday before Labor Day weekend, a dull smattering of hours that stands between them and a hard-won three days off.

headline: New Type of Drug-Free Labels for Meat Has U.S.D.A. Blessing
text: As meat companies scramble to eliminate antibiotics from their products to address consumer and regulatory concerns, the federal Agriculture Department has quietly opened a new front in the debate over the use of drugs in the livestock and poultry industries.

headline: Talk in G.O.P. Turns to a Stop Donald Trump Campaign
text: Quiet conversations have begun in recent weeks among some of the Republican Party’s biggest donors and normally competing factions, all aimed at a single question: How can we stop Donald Trump?

headline: Scott Boras and the Mets Disagree About Matt Harvey’s Innings Limit
text: MIAMI — Over the winter, as the Mets prepared for Matt Harvey’s first season back from Tommy John surgery, General Manager Sandy Alderson and Scott Boras, Harvey’s agent, discussed how the Mets would handle Harvey’s health.

text: Photos from France, Spain, India and Hungary.

headline: BlackBerry to Buy Good Technology, Getting Deeper Into Security
text: OTTAWA — As part of its shift away from phones toward software, BlackBerry announced on Friday that it would buy a rival, Good Technology, for $425 million.

headline: For College Students, Choosing a Bank Account Can Be a Minefield
text: Students heading to college are often barraged with offers to open special accounts to manage their money. But they should be aware that not all the accounts are alike.

headline: Nissan Recalls 300,000 Versa Sedans
text: Under pressure from federal regulators, Nissan is recalling almost 328,000 of its Versa sedans because a trim piece on the center console could snag the driver’s foot and interfere with braking or accelerating.

headline: New Bars in New York City Explore Spirits of Latin America
text: The many spirits pouring out of Central and South America will continue to fill New Yorkers’ cocktail glasses this fall.

headline: Review: ‘Arthur & George’ and the Longest Case Ever
text: Not content to be the American home of “Sherlock,” PBS is cornering the market in Holmesiana with the debut on Sunday night of “Arthur & George,” a three-part British series that puts Arthur Conan Doyle in the role of master detective.

headline: Iowans Question G.O.P. Talk on Illegal Immigration
text: MUSCATINE, Iowa — Like many voters in Iowa, Ben Hoopes has been listening closely to all the tough talk about illegal immigration coming from the Republican presidential candidates who have crisscrossed his state every week.

headline: At Visa Pour l’Image Festival, Photojournalists at the Ramparts
text: PERPIGNAN, France — The prestigious World Press Photo contest caused an uproar in March and damaged its standing when it bestowed, then revoked, a top prize to an Italian photographer who had misrepresented the location of an image. Amid an intense debate about the line between photojournalism and art photography, many photojournalists were outraged that images in which the photographer, Giovanni Troilo, had intervened — by using a remote-control flash, for example — had been categorized as reportage.

headline: New Health Care Rule Offers Key Protections for Transgender Americans
text: In a major step forward, the Department of Health and Human Services on Thursday proposed a rule barring health care providers and insurers from discriminating against transgender patients.

headline: In Los Angeles, a Downtown Believer
text: LOS ANGELES — Huffing and puffing, Andrew Meieran burst into a fifth-floor office here in mid-July. He was running 20 minutes late.

text: A president. A pope. A princess. A prime minister.

headline: Treetop Falls in Bryant Park, Injuring 5
text: With the workweek meandering to a close and a long holiday weekend ramping up, the lawn and walkways of Bryant Park in Midtown Manhattan were abuzz late Friday afternoon. Friends gathered to chart the evening ahead. Others, alone, found respite in books.

headline: Islamist Rebels and the Police Clash in Tajikistan, Killing 17
text: MOSCOW — Long-simmering unrest and infighting in the leadership in Tajikistan flared on Friday when the government accused a deputy defense minister of siding with Islamists in clashes with the police that killed 17 people.

headline: We’re All Artists Now
text: OUR best selves are merely one doodle away.

headline: Lost in One Burglary: Heirlooms, a Wedding Ring and a Sense of Security
text: Bit by bit, the 28-year-old bride-to-be absorbed the telltale signs of the burglary of her Brooklyn apartment: The gouge in the doorframe where the intruder had shoved a crowbar to get inside, the police officers talking in the dining room and, beyond them, her ransacked bedroom with the contents of her dresser drawers piled on the bed.

headline: Astronauts Welcomed Aboard Space Station
text: Crew members at the International Space Station gave new arrivals from the Russian Soyuz spacecraft a warm welcome on Friday.

headline: ‘North Woods Law’ Offers a Gentler View of Law Enforcement (and More Bears)
text: RANGELEY, Me. — “Are you filming?” the first boater pulled over on Rangeley Lake here asked. He had recognized the two Maine game wardens who were maneuvering their boat abreast on a sunny August Saturday.

headline: Mark Teixeira Limps to D.L., but Yankees Don’t Break Their Stride
text: Returning home after a six-game trip, the Yankees found that the interior design of their clubhouse had been altered. Four temporary lockers belonging to recent call-ups were set up in the middle of the room, away from those lined against the walls.

headline: Venice Film Festival Offers a Chance to Watch Suffering, Then to Quaff Champagne
text: VENICE — “The things of this world reveal their essential absurdity when they are put in the Venetian context.” So wrote Mary McCarthy in her charming, philosophical travel essay “Venice Observed.” It can be argued that the essential absurdity of movies is never really in doubt, but the Venice Film Festival — the oldest such event in this world — puts its own stamp on the marvelous, magical and perhaps fundamentally preposterous activities of making, displaying and watching movies.

headline: Alleviating Pain, Delivering Love
text: A photojournalist learns what it is like for a family to care for a critically ill child while spending time at a pediatric palliative care program.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Late Summer Scenes
text: Around Labor Day, the colors of the outdoor market at Union Square take on more autumnal hues.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Late Summer Scenes
text: Around Labor Day, the colors of the outdoor market at Union Square take on more autumnal hues. Shoppers’ light summer clothes were often replaced with black pieces. Also sighted: one of the artist Priscilla Snyder’s animal bags, made of thread. Cascades of hydrangeas surrounded houses along the Eastern Seaboard. Zinnias, dahlias and sunflowers added their vibrant colors.

headline: Review: Zhang Huoding Makes American Debut in Two Operas
text: For New Yorkers who basked in regular productions of Chinese opera at the tiny Taipei Theater of the Taiwanese Chinese Information and Culture Center in the 1990s, it has since been feast or famine. Mostly famine.

headline: Refugees Who Could Be Us
text: WATCHING the horrific images of Syrian refugees struggling toward safety — or in the case of Aylan Kurdi, 3, drowning on that journey — I think of other refugees. Albert Einstein. Madeleine Albright. The Dalai Lama.

text: A visit with the employees of the short-form blogging platform at their Manhattan office.

headline: Review: Two Bergman Films, Adapted on a Philadelphia Stage
text: PHILADELPHIA — The performers’ bodies were slick with sweat, and so were ours. It wasn’t a sexy, dewy dampness, either. These were rivulets of perspiration, soaking through hair and bleeding through clothes in wide, dark patches.

headline: Second City Cancels More Shows After Fire
text: The Chicago comedy theater and school Second City has canceled or moved all of the performances on its Mainstage, e.t.c. and UP Comedy Club theaters through Sept. 20 because of damage from a fire in its building last week, it announced on its website Friday.

headline: Race Pulls Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton to Puerto Rico
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — It is an unusual sight, these presidential candidates sweating under the sweltering late summer sun of the Caribbean, rather than jetting to Iowa, New Hampshire and other swing states.

headline: Unionization Important to Closing Racial Wage Gap, Study Says
text: A study released on Friday, noting the gains made by black union workers in New York City, said that raising the rate of unionization among black workers across the country would help narrow the racial pay gap.

headline: John McEnroe Saw Talent, and Now Ingrid Neel Is Fulfilling a Dream
text: The first question for Ingrid Neel — or at least the first one John McEnroe would have asked five years after she intrigued and even amazed him as a tennis-playing 12-year-old — would be whether she was still daring to be different.

headline: Young Methodists Plant Churches With Environmental Gospel
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Growing up in nearby Eden Prairie, Minn., Tyler Sit felt called to be a minister. But he was not sure what kind.

headline: Aretha Franklin Thwarts Screening of Documentary Featuring Concert Footage
text: TELLURIDE, Colo. — Aretha Franklin prevailed on Friday in an 11th-hour legal bid to stop the Telluride Film Festival from screening Sydney Pollack’s posthumous documentary “Amazing Grace,” which shows the making of Ms. Franklin’s album of the same name more than four decades ago.

headline: For Labor Day Drivers, Lowest Gasoline Prices in 11 Years
text: HOUSTON — Despite the recent tumult in global stock and energy markets, American travelers can count on bargains at the pump this Labor Day weekend, with prices for gasoline at their lowest levels in 11 years.

headline: Treatment of Migrants Evokes Memories of Europe’s Darkest Hour
text: BUDAPEST — In Hungary, hundreds of migrants surrounded by armed police officers were tricked into boarding a train with promises of freedom, only to be taken to a “reception” camp. In the Czech Republic, the police hustled more than 200 migrants off a train and wrote identification numbers on their hands with indelible markers, stopping only when someone pointed out that this was more than a little like the tattoos the Nazis put on concentration camp inmates.

headline: New Orleans Mayor May Face House Arrest in Pay Dispute
text: NEW ORLEANS — A judge here on Friday threatened the mayor with house arrest if the city did not quickly reach an agreement with the firefighters’ union over millions of dollars owed in back pay and benefits.

headline: Renovation at Javits Center Alleviates Hazard for Manhattan’s Birds
text: For years the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center loomed over a desolate stretch of the West 30s in Manhattan, its dark facade and severe angles earning it the nickname Darth Vader. For bird lovers, the appellation was apt since the building was a major site of bird fatalities, as the unwitting creatures smashed into the mirrorlike facade.

headline: Nepali Women in Queens Challenge Tradition, Taking Lead With Quake Aid
text: Cooks, nannies and college students walked through the red door, painted the color of Nepal’s flag. Men and women alike, they came to this agency in Queens on a recent weekday seeking legal help that could allow them to visit family in Nepal after the devastating earthquake there.

headline: Venus Williams, Long in Shadow, Is Not to Be Forgotten
text: Serena Williams has a big sister who plays tennis.

headline: Bank of America Board Under Fire for Combining Chairman and Chief Jobs
text: Momentum is building toward forcing Bank of America to undo its decision last year to name the bank’s chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, as chairman as well.

headline: At West Point, Annual Pillow Fight Becomes Weaponized
text: For generations, freshmen cadets at the United States Military Academy have marked the end of a grueling summer of training with a huge nighttime pillow fight that is billed as a harmless way to blow off steam and build class spirit.

headline: Eugenie Bouchard’s Star Returns to Its Lofty Trajectory
text: Eugenie Bouchard had not been enjoying the most fruitful year of her professional tennis career. At one point, she lost 10 of 11 matches. Entering the United States Open, she had not won consecutive matches since March.

headline: The Minimum Wage: Getting to $15
text: The debate over the federal minimum wage in the nascent presidential campaign is really two debates: one among Democrats and one among Republicans.

headline: The New Jersey Psychic With a Box of Swiss Gold
text: Detectives entered a Wells Fargo branch in Cliffside Park, N.J., in April with a search warrant authorizing them to open safe deposit box No. 679. The box’s contents led them to Manhattan’s diamond district, uptown to a frail woman’s apartment in Washington Heights, then back across the river, revealing a multilayered, multistate network of deception and crime.

headline: Kentucky Clerk’s Stance Tests County Where Opposing Views Are Welcomed
text: MOREHEAD, Ky. — As the protesters faced off outside the Rowan County courthouse, one sign held by gay-marriage supporters read, “Law of the Land.” Another, held by opponents, read, “Welcome to Sodom and Gomorrah.” The amplified voice of a preacher described, in terse but explicit terms, a homosexual act. “Is that a little too graphic for you?” he asked, as if to provoke.

headline: Ouster of Don Orsillo, Beloved TV Announcer, Fuels a Red Sox Firestorm
text: BOSTON — Emily Elmore stood by her seat along the third-base line at Fenway Park on Wednesday holding a simple sign that signified the latest twist in a miserable Boston Red Sox season.

headline: A Chance to Fix Parole in New York
text: On Tuesday, the New York Court of Appeals, the state’s highest court, will hear oral arguments in a case that may provide a rare chance to reform New York’s antiquated, ineffective and unfair parole system.

headline: Many Obstacles Are Seen to U.S. Taking in Large Number of Syrian Refugees
text: WASHINGTON — In late spring, with the war in Syria grinding into its fifth year amid an ever-deepening humanitarian catastrophe for millions of refugees, 14 United States senators wrote a letter to President Obama urging that at least 65,000 of the displaced Syrians be allowed to resettle in the United States.

headline: Jason Day and Jordan Spieth Moving in Opposite Directions
text: NORTON, Mass. — The argument about which comes first, confidence or results, misses the point. The work always comes first. Preparation is the security blanket, the calming influence, of any top performer.

headline: Russian Moves in Syria Pose Concerns for U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — Russia has sent a military advance team to Syria and is taking other steps the United States fears may signal that President Vladimir V. Putin is planning to vastly expand his military support for President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, administration officials said Friday.

headline: Why Is Science So Straight?
text: Baltimore — MANY years ago, over lunch at our university cafeteria, I came out as gay to a colleague in the engineering department. “I didn’t realize you were so unconventional,” he said. I tried explaining to him that being gay was innate and had nothing to do with wanting to subvert convention, but he refused to retract his label. Looking back, perhaps he was correct.

headline: Thomas Sobol, 83, Dies; Education Advocate as New York State Commissioner
text: Thomas Sobol, a courtly railway worker’s son who became a leading educator and fervent advocate for imposing broad academic standards, subsidizing poor urban districts, empowering parents and teachers to make policy, and promoting a multicultural curriculum, died on Thursday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 83.

headline: U.S. Open 2015: Serena Williams Survives; Rafael Nadal Does Not
text: Serena Williams and Rafael Nadal are two terrific champions who have won multiple major tournaments, Williams 21 and Nadal 14. At various times over the last decade, both have dominated their sport, but at this major event their fortunes appeared to have reversed.

headline: Like Grenada, but Not Granada
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I tend to travel, crossword-wise, in a sort of rarefied circle, in that most of my friends in the community are the super-solvers you see hoisting trophies over their heads at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.

headline: Trades and the Tides of Time
text: As a kid, I was not a Dodgers fan by any stretch. In 1977 and 1978, Los Angeles knocked off my beloved Philadelphia Phillies in consecutive National League Championship Series. They went on to make a legend out of Reggie Jackson over two World Series while falling to the Yankees. But for me, there was no satisfaction in their defeat, because all I wanted was the Phillies to make it, to beat the Yankees and secure me bragging rights in the halls of Emerson Elementary School, in Teaneck, NJ.

headline: The Tao of a Corncob Pipe
text: BUSHKILL, Pa. — EVEN now, when I conjure him and he deigns to come, I always see him the same way. He’s encircled in sweet blue smoke, standing on the cool stone of the walkway around midnight. A little man, ancient, almost swallowed by the vivid articles of clothing that his devoted daughter always bought for him. They were nothing like the slate-colored clothes my grandfather would have chosen for himself. But they covered him and kept him warm.

headline: As Vote Looms, Some in Guatemala Foresee More Frustration
text: GUATEMALA CITY — Guatemalans united to force their powerful president to step down. But now, many who joined the demonstration movement worry that creating lasting change, and rewriting the rules of their fragile democracy, may prove even harder.

headline: A Silver Lining to Brazil’s Troubles
text: Of all the BRICS, Brazil would seem, on the face of it, to be in the worst shape.

headline: Mets’ Conundrum: Matt Harvey’s Health Versus a Playoff Run
text: ST. LOUIS — So many parties have a reason to want Matt Harvey pitching in October. The Mets and their fans yearn for a championship. Major League Baseball craves the chance to showcase a rising star. The competitor in Harvey surely burns to prove himself.

headline: Worker Who Died in Wall Collapse Warned of Problems at Construction Site
text: The construction worker, a slim man of 18 who had arrived in New York City from Ecuador less than a year ago, returned to his home in Queens one day last month and told his mother about a close call.

headline: Alberta Wright, Restaurateur and Soul-Food Pioneer, Dies at 84
text: Alberta Wright, the owner of Jezebel, which brought soul food with panache to Manhattan’s theater district and helped make sophisticated variations of Southern dishes a culinary trend, died on Friday in the Bronx. She was 84.

text: Holiday Observed on MondayNEW YORK

headline: Clinton Speaks on Puerto Rican Debt
text: At an event in San Juan on Friday, the Democratic presidential candidate said that Puerto Rico could not solve its current crisis through austerity alone.

headline: On a Seesaw Night, Mets Teeter, Rally, Then Fall
text: MIAMI —  On Friday, the Mets fell behind early, took the lead late, lost it, then tied the score when they were down to their final out.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) WILD (2014) Reese Witherspoon, in an Oscar-nominated performance, portrays Cheryl Strayed, who copes with the aftermath of her heroin use, her marital infidelity and the death of her mother by hiking the Pacific Crest National Scenic Trail, spanning more than 1,000 miles, from the Southern California desert to the forests of Oregon. Her routine — walking, thinking, pitching her tent at night and packing it up in the morning — is punctuated by montages of memories and encounters in the wilderness, mostly with men. Some are scary; others are kind; but almost all are intrigued by the presence of a solitary woman so far from civilization. “ ‘Wild’ may be full of natural beauty — Yves Bélanger’s cinematography unostentatiously captures the infinite colors and vistas of the West — but it is also a celebration of the power of art,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about Jean-Marc Vallée’s adaptation of Ms. Strayed’s memoir, from a script by Nick Hornby. And the film has its shortcomings, he added, with too much montage in the middle and too much voice-over at the end, and maybe not quite enough detail about some of Cheryl’s relationships. “But you wouldn’t want a movie that celebrates imperfection, improvisation and the importance of mistakes to be slick or seamless. What makes its heroine worth caring about — what makes her a rare and exciting presence in contemporary American film — is not that she’s tidy or sensible or even especially nice. It’s that she’s free.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I’m as prejudiced as the day is long. It’s a bad thing that all these illegal Mexicans are here. But they’re hard workers. They’re doing jobs that lazy Americans won’t do.”

headline: Player Ratings: United States (2) vs. Peru (1)
text: WASHINGTON — The United States men’s national team responded well to its first test after a disappointing Gold Cup, coming from behind to defeat a strong Peru on a hot and humid night at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

headline: Making Jobs Satisfying
text: What makes workers happy? Pay, meaningful work, flexible hours, personal responsibility.

headline: The Disconnected Undercut Hairstyle Mixes Long and Short
text: Short on the sides, longer on top.

headline: An Encore for Alex Sharp and Phillipa Soo at Juilliard
text: The Juilliard School has one of the most prestigious acting schools in the United States, with a roster of alumni that includes Patti LuPone, William Hurt, Robin Williams, Christine Baranski, Kevin Spacey and Jessica Chastain.

headline: Why Do We End Summer So Early?
text: There are rules, at least unofficial ones, dictating that summer ends this weekend.

headline: A Basketball Arena Battles for San Francisco’s Heart
text: Prosperity is the sound of jackhammers and pile drivers in the morning.

headline: Bucking a Trend, Some Millennials Are Seeking a Nun’s Life
text: SUMMIT, N.J. — It’s been a rough year for the mechanicals at the Dominican Monastery of Our Lady of the Rosary. The lawn mower died, along with the chaplain’s car, the compressor for the kitchen refrigerator and one of the “new” washers (that is, a machine bought sometime in the mid ’80s).

headline: Hillary Clinton Relying on Southern Primaries to Fend Off Rivals
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign is methodically building a political firewall across the South in hopes of effectively locking up the Democratic nomination in March regardless of any early setbacks in the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted by @nytimes took Instagram followers from the waters of Resurrection Bay to Keleti train station in Budapest.

headline: A Sharing Economy Where Teachers Win
text: What kind of tunes do you think Iago, the villain in William Shakespeare’s “Othello,” would listen to if he had an iPhone?

headline: Seneca Art and Culture Center to Open in October
text: Seneca Center The Seneca Art and Culture Center opens Oct. 24 at Ganondagan State Historic Site in Victor, N.Y., 20 miles southeast of Rochester. The center is built on the site of the original Seneca settlement, destroyed in 1687. The gallery will offer changing exhibitions conveying the story of the Seneca and Haudenosaunee (also known as Iroquois) people through centuries of artistic and historical artifacts and will also include work from contemporary Native American artists.

headline: Germans Welcome Migrants After Long Journey Through Hungary and Austria
text: MUNICH — Germans waving welcome signs in German, English and Arabic came to the train station here Saturday to greet the first group of what is expected to be about 8,000 migrants to arrive in Germany by early Sunday, after an arduous and emotional journey through Hungary and Austria.

headline: Is Trump the Candidate Reform Conservatives Are Seeking?
text: For the last few years, a small but prominent group of conservative writers and thinkers has urged the Republican party to rethink its economic agenda with a greater focus on the needs of the middle class. The so-called reform conservatives have criticized the G.O.P.’s economic prescription of cutting entitlement programs and tax rates (especially on high earners) as unresponsive to the concerns of workers earning stagnant wages.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Beijing Speech on Women Resonates 20 Years Later
text: Just days after Hillary Rodham Clinton left her post as secretary of state in early 2013, she assembled a group of longtime female aides to discuss what she wanted to do as she contemplated another presidential run.

headline: Mike and Quentin’s Week in Tech: Amazon’s Offline Game Changer
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the industry. Mr. Manjoo is off this week, so Mr. Isaac is conversing with fellow tech reporter Quentin Hardy.

headline: Migrants’ Journey
text: Thousands of migrants arrived in Austria on Saturday morning after Hungary helped them travel in safety.

headline: A University of Illinois Professor Joins the Fight
text: Bruce M. Chassy, now a professor emeritus at the University of Illinois, is another academic who was recruited to help out with GMO Answers.

headline: A Florida Professor Works With the Biotech Industry
text: Kevin Folta, chairman of the horticultural sciences department at the University of Florida, began to correspond regularly with executives at Monsanto in early 2013. He soon teamed up with the company and other industry representatives to defend their genetically engineered crop technologies as they lobbied Congress and other government authorities. Dr. Folta has said he worked as an independent scientist. But Monsanto helped cover his costs.

headline: Washington State Professor Allies With Organics Industry
text: Charles M. Benbrook, formerly the chief scientist at the Organic Center, left the nonprofit organization in 2012 after concluding that he could get more traction for his research, which has questioned G.M.O. crop safety, by joining a university.

headline: A Mississippi State Administrator’s Ties to Monsanto and Dow
text: David R. Shaw, vice president for research and economic development at Mississippi State University, has received a steady stream of research support from Monsanto, as well as grant money. Monsanto and Dow Chemical have asked him to help move their agendas in Washington, emails show.

headline: Opera School Noise Complaints
text: No Fan of Singing School

headline: Food Industry Enlisted Academics in G.M.O. Lobbying War, Emails Show
text: WASHINGTON — At Monsanto, sales of genetically modified seeds were steadily rising. But executives at the company’s St. Louis headquarters were privately worried about attacks on the safety of their products.

headline: As Germany Welcomes Migrants, Some Wonder How to Make Acceptance Last
text: BERLIN — As tens of thousands of asylum seekers now pour into Germany, their desired destination, they will be met here by bowls of steaming soup and bread rolls, working bathrooms and an efficient bureaucracy to move them to temporary housing and, possibly, legal immigration status.

headline: 1915: Fashion Fancies
text: The hitherto unpublished drawings by M. Drian, which the Herald is reproducing today through the courtesy of M. Lucien Vogel, the director of the “Gazette du Bon Ton,” in which paper they will appear this week are wittily and fancifully illustrative of the latest fashions.

headline: Nissan May Repeat Recall Over Airbags
text: Federal regulators have indicated they are worried that Nissan’s recall last year of almost one million vehicles did not correct a malfunction of the passenger airbag, raising the possibility that the automaker might have to recall the vehicles again.

headline: Kathleen Finch: Get Better Ideas With a ‘Pile On’ Meeting
text: This interview with Kathleen Finch, chief programming officer of HGTV, Food Network and Travel Channel, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Variety: A Hard-Working Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Well, this acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon got me all riled up. I am a card-carrying member of a union, and now I want to march or hold up a placard or something. Happy Labor Day weekend, everyone.

headline: Uneasy Truce on Gay Marriage Is Shaken by Kentucky Clerk’s Defiance
text: WASHINGTON — Kim Davis did more than register a protest when she went to jail last week after defying a federal court order to issue marriage licenses to gay couples. Ms. Davis, the clerk in Rowan County, Ky., also helped unravel an uneasy détente in the nation’s culture wars that had prevailed since the Supreme Court declared a constitutional right to same-sex marriage in June.

headline: Brian Wilcox: A Voice for Car Lovers
text: Brian Wilcox, 30, is a customer service specialist for K40 Electronics, in Elgin, Ill.

headline: When to Tell a Prospective Employer That You’re Pregnant
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Smart Workers Seek Out Advice, Study Suggests
text: Every day, employees have the opportunity to learn new information that could improve their performance, yet many fail to take advantage of it. They are afraid to ask for advice.

headline: T. Eugene Thompson Dies at 88; Crime Stunned St. Paul
text: T. Eugene Thompson’s paid obituary on Tuesday nebulously described him as “a multifaceted person” and concluded with a quotation from Oscar Wilde: “Every saint has a past, and every sinner has a future.”

headline: Notre Dame Football Job Requirement: Fiery Spirit, if Not Beard
text: The most distinctive trait of the person who becomes the Notre Dame leprechaun mascot is not the ability to leap, tumble, scream, orate or mug for the camera.

headline: Joy Golden, Who Made Ads With Punch Lines, Dies at 85
text: Joy Golden, an advertising executive who wrote copy for Maidenform bras and Talon zippers during the “Mad Men” era but found her true calling in the 1980s when she created the humorous radio spots for Laughing Cow cheese, died on Aug. 29 in Manhattan. She was 85.

headline: Rutgers Kicks 5 Players Off Team, Then Wins Its Opener
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — Minutes before the start of its season-opening 63-13 victory against Norfolk State on Saturday afternoon, Rutgers announced the dismissals of five players. Two days earlier, they had been arrested and indefinitely suspended from the program after an investigation into separate cases by the Middlesex County Prosecutor’s Office and the New Brunswick Police Department.

headline: For Andy Murray, Supporting British Tennis Is Important Role
text: In his latest conversation with The New York Times, Andy Murray spoke about his support for lower-ranked players, following tennis in his free time, and how to improve the reputation and results of British tennis. Murray plays Thomaz Bellucci in a third-round match Saturday night.

headline: A Collector Sees the Potential in a Humble Paper Clip
text: James Ward began collecting office supplies about 10 years ago, but he has always loved pens, pencils and paper. They remind him of walking into class at the beginning of the school year with a brand-new pencil case “and at that moment everything’s perfect.” To this day, empty notebooks beckon to him with their potentiality.

headline: Cucumbers Recalled in Salmonella Outbreak
text: A California distributor has begun recalling cucumbers imported from Mexico after they were linked to a salmonella outbreak that has killed one woman and sickened at least 285 others, health officials said.

headline: U.S. Warns Russia Over Military Support for Assad
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry told his Russian counterpart on Saturday that the United States was deeply concerned by reports that the Kremlin may be planning to vastly expand its military support for President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, warning that such a move might even lead to a “confrontation” with the American-led coalition, the State Department said.

headline: Unrest Mounts in Southern Syria After Druse Cleric Dies in Blast
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An unusual wave of unrest mounted Saturday in a normally quiet southern Syrian province, according to residents and activists there, after a double car-bombing killed a prominent Druse cleric who had challenged the government by supporting young men who refused to serve in the national army.

headline: Robert Whaley
text: Robert Whaley is a professor of finance at Vanderbilt University’s Owen Graduate School of Management and the developer of the two major so-called fear indices — the VIX and VXN on the Chicago Board Options Exchange — that are used to make bets on market volatility.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: The Architecture of Segregation
text: Fifty years after the creation of the Department of Housing and Urban Development — and nearly that long after the passage of the Fair Housing Act of 1968 — the fight against the interlinked scourges of housing discrimination and racial segregation in America is far from finished. Economic isolation is actually growing worse across the country, as more and more minority families find themselves trapped in high-poverty neighborhoods without decent housing, schools or jobs, and with few avenues of escape.

headline: Rising to Your Level of Misery at Work
text: EVERYONE has heard of the Peter Principle: Managers rise to the level of their incompetence. Today, however, a whole class of hyper-competent Americans will never find their level of incompetence. Instead, they will suffer a similar principle in which they rise to their level of misery.

headline: Foreign Journalists Under Fire
text: A kangaroo court in Egypt recently sentenced three journalists from the Al Jazeera English network to three years in prison for committing journalism.

headline: Getting a Grip on Football
text: “Deflategate” always sounded so childish: Did the star quarterback know that air had been secretly leaked from footballs he was throwing to help him win a big game? There’s still no firm answer to that question after an exhaustive court fight. But here comes the National Football League season nevertheless, and there is the star quarterback, Tom Brady, free to throw footballs again for the New England Patriots, having prevailed last week against an attempt by the league commissioner, Roger Goodell, to suspend him for four games.

headline: Blessed Be My Freshly Slaughtered Dinner
text: COULD you look through a rifle’s scope into the long-lashed eyes of an elk and pull the trigger if it would be the only meat you ate for the year? Would your conscience be more or less troubled if instead you slit the necks of animals you planned to eat after they were nurtured like adored pets on an idyllic farm?

headline: The Refugee Crisis Isn’t a ‘European Problem’
text: THOSE of us outside Europe are watching the unbelievable images of the Keleti train station in Budapest, the corpse of a toddler washed up on a Turkish beach, the desperate Syrian families chancing their lives on the night trip to the Greek islands — and we keep being told this is a European problem.

headline: The Internet of Way Too Many Things
text: At a design conference recently, I was introduced to Leeo, a new product that I initially understood to be a reboot of something really in need of a redesign: the smoke detector. As the designer explained his process, I quickly came to understand that Leeo was nothing of the sort. It was a gadget, a night light that “listens” for your smoke detector to go off and then calls your smartphone to let you know your house might be on fire.

headline: Who Failed Aylan Kurdi?
text: THE image of a dead Syrian boy washed up on a Turkish beach has inspired a wave of Western soul-searching, with much talk about how “the world” failed 3-year-old Aylan Kurdi, who drowned along with his mother and brother while trying to escape their country’s civil war.

headline: The Myth of Quality Time
text: EVERY summer for many years now, my family has kept to our ritual. All 20 of us — my siblings, my dad, our better halves, my nieces and nephews — find a beach house big enough to fit the whole unruly clan. We journey to it from our different states and time zones. We tensely divvy up the bedrooms, trying to remember who fared poorly or well on the previous trip. And we fling ourselves at one another for seven days and seven nights.

headline: Awash in Data, Thirsting for Truth
text: Mark Twain complained about “lies, damned lies and statistics” more than a century ago. “Figures often beguile me,” he wrote, “particularly when I have the arranging of them myself.”

headline: A Doctor at His Daughter’s Hospital Bed
text: Omaha — I’VE been watching the monitor for hours. Natalie’s asleep now and I’m worried about her pulse. It’s edging above 140 beats per minute again and her blood oxygen saturation is becoming dangerously low. I’m convinced that she’s slipping into shock. She needs more fluids. I ring for the nurse.

headline: The Collateral Victims of Criminal Justice
text: SINCE the financial crisis, complaints that corporate wrongdoers suffer light penalties have become routine. One reason is the Department of Justice’s longstanding policy that prosecutors must consider the “collateral consequences” that pursuing a corporation might have on innocent employees, shareholders, pensioners and even the financial system at large.

headline: Australian Leader, Opposing Gay Marriage, Faces Party and Family Opposition
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Even the prime minister’s sister is unhappy with him.

headline: Times Magazine Editor on ‘Creative Apocalypse’ Article
text: Are creative artists thriving in the digital age? A recent magazine cover story makes the case that they are, and that a “creative apocalypse” never happened, despite fears and predictions that it would.

headline: Adult, Autistic and Ignored
text: TWO months before she died of pancreatic cancer in November 2010, my normally strong, stoical mother broke down weeping in my arms over the fate of my autistic older brother.

headline: A.F.C. East Teams on a Quest to Dethrone the Patriots
text: Before becoming the Miami Dolphins’ executive vice president for football operations, Mike Tannenbaum joined the organization as a consultant. He traveled to Europe to research how professional soccer teams use science to optimize performance, and now the Dolphins monitor sleep patterns, revitalize players with customized smoothies and employ a director of sports performance.

headline: With a Paddle, Tennis Stars Find They’re Up the Creek
text: With his fluid, rhythmic strokes, it is clear that Sam Querrey has a knack for table tennis. But when he hits a backhand with two hands, as he does on the tennis court, it becomes obvious that it is not his sport of choice.

headline: Wealthy Gulf Nations Are Criticized for Tepid Response to Syrian Refugee Crisis
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Arab nations of the Persian Gulf have some the world’s highest per capita incomes. Their leaders speak passionately about the plight of Syrians, and their state-funded news media cover the Syrian civil war without cease.

headline: A King of Sliders Surmounts a Fall
text: A recent player poll in Baseball America judged Chris Archer, the young ace of the Tampa Bay Rays, to have the best slider in the American League. Archer, a right-hander, has used the pitch to establish himself as an All-Star, and last month he fired a one-hit shutout with 11 strikeouts against the Houston Astros.

headline: Weary Migrants Show Relief as They Reach Austria Safely
text: NICKELSDORF, Austria — The safer they finally felt, the calmer the thousands of refugees who crossed into Austria from Hungary on Saturday became.

headline: A Spurt of No-Hitters May Not Be All That Exceptional
text: When Jake Arrieta of the Chicago Cubs threw a no-hitter last week, it was the sixth in 81 days and the 250th no-hitter of the modern era. The major league record for no-hitters in a single season is seven.

headline: U.S. Open 2015: Once Again, a Late Burst Propels a Spotlight Grabber
text: Saturday’s matches at Arthur Ashe Stadium began around 11:10 a.m., about 10 hours after Rafael Nadal and Fabio Fognini departed it.

headline: Confederate Flags Crash Nascar’s Plan for a Homecoming
text: DARLINGTON, S.C. — Throwback paint schemes on racecars and retro logos and signs welcomed Nascar fans when they arrived at Darlington Raceway this weekend for the Bojangles’ Southern 500 Sprint Cup race. The marketing campaign was designed to make one of the most storied tracks on the circuit look like the early 1970s all over again.

headline: Nathan Eovaldi’s Shaky Inning Proves Too Damaging as Yanks’ Offense Stalls
text: Before his first pitch at Yankee Stadium on Saturday afternoon, starter Nathan Eovaldi scooped up a rosin bag and patted it against his arms, creating clouds of powder. He then vigorously dug in with his foot around the pitching rubber and kicked dirt in the air, ruining the layout of a mound that was perfectly manicured just moments earlier.

headline: Jets Cut 2 Quarterbacks, Leaving Rookie as Backup
text: The Jets released both of the veterans who had been vying for the backup quarterback job, for now leaving the rookie Bryce Petty as the only healthy option behind Ryan Fitzpatrick for next week’s season opener against Cleveland.

headline: The Pirates’ Winning Path Is Blocked by a Familiar Foe
text: ST. LOUIS — Francisco Cervelli was raised by the Yankees, who traded him to the Pittsburgh Pirates last fall after parts of seven seasons in the majors. Cervelli reported to his new team in spring training, and it was as if nothing had changed.

headline: In Case You Missed It: Top Articles of the Week
text: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from Aug. 28 to Sept. 3.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Rhoda Lerman, Writer Who Defied Labels, Dies at 79
text: Rhoda Lerman, whose critically praised novels melded history with contemporaneity, mythology with social criticism, feminism with a Jewish sensibility and snark with seriousness, died on Aug. 30 at her home in Port Crane, N.Y., near Binghamton. She was 79.

headline: Hillary Clinton Urges Cooperation on Inquiry Into Her Emails, as She Finds Joy Elsewhere
text: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — Hillary Rodham Clinton said Saturday that everyone involved in the investigation into her email practices as secretary of state should cooperate and insisted that she was running her campaign with joy even as questions persist around why she conducted government business on a private server.

headline: Ben Kuroki Dies at 98; Japanese-American Overcame Bias to Fight for U.S.
text: Ben Kuroki, a decorated Japanese-American gunner in the Army Air Forces of World War II, who was hailed on the American homeland at a time when tens of thousands of Japanese-Americans were confined to internment camps as supposed security risks, died on Tuesday in Camarillo, Calif. He was 98.

headline: On the Trail of a Mentally Ill Brother, Lost in Brooklyn
text: Ever since they were children, Aukejshia Boyce-Gaskins made sure to look out for her younger half brother, Birshon Daley.

headline: Scenes of Departure and Arrival
text: On Saturday, migrants in Vienna crowded onto trains headed for Munich.

headline: Pope Francis’ Visit to U.S. Is His First Ever, for Several Reasons
text: During his first private meeting with Pope Francis in the Vatican two years ago, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan said, the pope took out an atlas with a map of the United States and asked Cardinal Dolan, the archbishop of New York, to point out the various regions and cities and talk about how they differed.

headline: Matt Harvey Weighs In (Gingerly) Over Talk of His Being Shut Down
text: MIAMI — Dr. James Andrews, the surgeon who performed Tommy John surgery on Matt Harvey in 2013, called him recently to check in. Andrews had been in contact with Scott Boras, Harvey’s agent, and he told Harvey that he was now recommending limiting him to 180 innings this season, his first full year back pitching after the surgery.

headline: Powerful Auburn Overcomes Its Quarterback’s Misadventures
text: ATLANTA — Auburn’s defense was a marauder for three quarters on Saturday.

headline: Rickie Fowler, at Four Shots Back, Relishes Thrill of the Chase
text: NORTON, Mass. — If Rickie Fowler did not have two more rounds to play at TPC Boston, he would be perfectly at home at Jumptown, a sky-diving club in Orange, Mass., about an hour west of Boston. Fowler is an adrenaline seeker, and when his golf game is in high gear, the rush he gets rivals any feeling he experienced on the motorcycle dirt tracks or Pacific wave sets of his youth.

headline: Guatemalans Ousted President Otto Pérez Molina. Now What?
text: GUATEMALA CITY — Sergio Bacini is a music producer, a tattoo artist and a D.J. When the five-month protest movement that swept out Guatemala’s president last week seemed to flag during the summer, he knew how to revive it: He organized a rock concert.

headline: Women’s Films Do Not Tell the Whole Tale of Telluride
text: TELLURIDE, Colo. — Film festivals have sharply different personalities. The one that got underway here on Friday is wealthy and white, and it is the Tiffany of festivals, as its promotional materials accurately maintain.

headline: Michael Mmoh Is a Rising Hope for Several Countries
text: Novak Djokovic was a little late to his hitting date with the young American player Michael Mmoh at Wimbledon in July. But Boris Becker, Djokovic’s coach, was there, and he and Mmoh reminisced while waiting for Djokovic to arrive.

headline: Pope Francis’ U.S. Visit Schedule
text: Daily events during the pope’s East Coast trip.

headline: Mets’ Bartolo Colon Extends Scoreless Streak With Shutout of Marlins
text: MIAMI — Bartolo Colon sat on a bench in the Mets dugout and smiled as his teammates celebrated and showered Wilmer Flores with pats on the helmet. Colon looked like a proud father.

headline: News Quiz: What You May Have Missed This Summer
text: This was a summer when the news did not stop. Test your knowledge about important international events that you may have missed.

headline: Playoff Pursuit Is the Mets’, but the Career Is Matt Harvey’s
text: Matt Harvey has the stuff and the strut of an ace. He pitches like a leading man and carries himself that way. The Mets seem bound for the postseason, and nobody should crave that stage more than Harvey.

headline: Julissa Mejia, Marcos Ortiz Jr.
text: Julissa Mejia and Marcos Orlando Ortiz Jr. are to be married Sunday at Jellyfish Restaurant in Punta Cana, the Dominican Republic. Cristian Castillo, a cousin of the groom who is a councilman of the Peravia Province of the Dominican Republic, is to officiate.

headline: Rebecca Morrow, Matthew Farrell
text: Rebecca Morrow, the daughter of Eve Morrow and Dr. Richard B. Morrow of Searingtown, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Matthew Thomas Farrell, a son of Dr. Deborah M. Farrell and Dr. Leo D. Farrell of Mechanicsburg, Pa. Caroline Z. Bazzini, who was appointed by Brookville, N.Y., as the village’s marriage officer, is to officiate at the Glen Cove Mansion in Glen Cove, N.Y.

headline: Meredith Wing, Michael Lazar
text: Meredith Allison Wing, the daughter of Joan W. Wing and Darman A. Wing of Boxford, Mass., was married Saturday evening to Michael Eric Lazar, a son of Carol A. Lazar and Dr. Harold L. Lazar of Chestnut Hill, Mass. Rabbi Albert Axelrad officiated at the Crane Estate in Ipswich, Mass.

headline: Erica Beal, John Barnhardt
text: Erica Mae Beal, the daughter of Valerie Lancaster Beal and Bernard Beal of New York, was married Saturday to John Anthony Barnhardt, a son of Diana S. Barnhardt and Michael J. Barnhardt of Lake Hallie, Wis. The bride’s father, a Baptist minister, officiated at Pippin Hill Farm and Vineyards in North Garden, Va.

headline: Sophia McKinley, Gregory Jordan
text: Dr. Sophia Kim McKinley and Gregory Eric Jordan are to be married Sunday at the Mass Audubon Habitat Education Center and Wildlife Sanctuary in Belmont, Mass. Dr. Jessica Hu, a friend of the bride who received a one-day solemnization certificate from Massachusetts, is to officiate.

headline: Emily Pitlick, David Mallen
text: Emily Rachel Pitlick and David Jay Mallen are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Lyle Fishman at the Park Hyatt Hotel in Washington.

headline: Noah Drezner, Oren Pizmony-Levy
text: Noah Daniel Drezner and Oren Pizmony-Levy are to be married Sunday evening at the Brooklyn Grange, a rooftop farm in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Rabbi Lauren Grabelle Herrmann is to officiate.

headline: Susan Lieu, Marvin Kim
text: Susan Lieu, a daughter of Tom Lieu of Santa Rosa, Calif., and the late Jennifer Ha, was married Saturday to Bukyung Kim, a son of Okjin Kim and Jeong Bon Kim of Waterloo, Ontario. Gayle Hasley, a friend of the bride and a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Ballard Bay Club in Seattle.

headline: Danielle Weisberg, Adam Heller
text: Danielle Merriah Weisberg, a daughter of Gabrielle A. Weisberg and Donald J. Weisberg of Chicago, was married Saturday evening to Adam Robert Heller, the son of Cathy S. Heller and Lloyd J. Heller of New York. Rabbi Michael Sternfield officiated at the Bridgeport Art Center in Chicago.

headline: Rebecca Kendrick, Gioele Mancini
text: Rebecca Linsey Kendrick, a daughter of Karen V. Grant and Kendall Kendrick Jr. of Freeport, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Gioele Mancini, the son of Cesaria Ratano Mancini and Luigi Mancini of Offenburg, Germany. Sean Lofton, a minister of the Christian Congregation of Jehovah’s Witnesses, is to officiate at the NoMad Hotel in New York.

headline: Brooke Smith and Umut Ozaydinli: The Trans-Atlantic Acid Test
text: Brooke DeVard Smith and Umut Hilmi Ozaydinli were married Monday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Edwina Townes, a staff member of the New York City Clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Christina Chennat,  Ravi Goel
text: Christina Megan Chennat and Dr. Ravi Desh Goel were married Saturday in Marlton, N.J. Pandit Sudhir Jha performed a Hindu ceremony at the Indian Cultural Center of South Jersey.

headline: Caitlin Boyce, Michael Naft
text: Caitlin Ryan Boyce and Michael Jaison Naft were married Saturday at the Harvard Club in New York. Anna Saulwick, a friend of the couple who became a minister of the Universal Life Church for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Emma Glidden-Lyon and Derek Birkner
text: Emma Glidden-Lyon, a daughter of Katharine H. Lyon and William T. Glidden Jr. of Topsham, Me., was married Saturday to Derek James Birkner, the son of Nancy Halpin-Birkner of Moneta, Va., and the late James R. Birkner. The Rev. Raymond Clothier performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Bridgton, Me.

headline: Meimay Law,  Ryan Moreno
text: Meimay Liu Law and Ryan James Moreno were married Saturday at Montgomery Place, a house museum in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. Bobby Moreno, a cousin of the groom who became a minister in the American Fellowship Church for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Kerry Minchinton, Brian Tucei
text: Kerry Ann Minchinton and Brian Matthew Nichols Tucei were married Saturday. The Rev. Michael P. Hilbert performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York, where he is an associate pastor.

headline: Christina Seib and Jonathan Eccles
text: Christina Dacey Seib, a daughter of Joan Dacey Seib and Karl E. Seib of New York, is to be married Sunday in Ketchum, Idaho, to Jonathan Andrew Eccles, a son of Leni Eccles and Marriner C. Eccles of Belvedere, Calif. The bride’s father, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate at the Sun Valley ski resort. He will lead the bride in her vows; the groom’s father will take part in the readings and lead his son in his vows.

headline: Samantha Leyco, Paul Zamudio
text: Samantha Ramos Leyco, a daughter of Violeta R. Leyco and Virgilio A. Leyco of Middle Village, Queens, was married Friday to Dr. Paul Anthony Jimenez Zamudio, the son of Marilyn J. Zamudio and Romeo N. Zamudio of Jamaica Estates, Queens. The Rev. Theophane Cooney, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Immaculate Conception Church in Jamaica, Queens.

headline: Chelsea Reed, Jon Radler
text: Chelsea Reed and Jon Ian Radler were married on Friday at the Broward County Circuit Court in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where Mark A. Speiser, the administrative judge in the court’s probate division, officiated.

headline: Kerry Brennan and John Lee II: Their Love Went South, Then North
text: Kerry Jane Brennan and John Joon Lee II were married Saturday by the Rev. Thomas A. Enneking at Nativity of Our Lord Catholic Church in St. Paul.

headline: Stevie Glaberson, Eduardo Ortiz
text: Stephanie Kaufman Glaberson, the daughter of Judith A. Kaufman and William B. Glaberson of Scarsdale, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Eduardo Francisco Ortiz, the son of Cristalia A. Blanco of Silver Springs, Md. Evan Glaberson, a Universal Life minister and the brother of the bride, is to officiate at Camp Kinder Ring in Hopewell Junction, N.Y.

headline: Charlene Ong and Amar Dhand
text: Dr. Charlene Jennifer Ong and Dr. Amar Dhand are to be married Sunday. Harris Bloom, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Soho Grand Hotel in New York.

headline: Ann Vale, Benjamin Schmidt
text: Dr. Ann Sheridan Vale, the daughter of Elizabeth S. Vale and Anthony C.H. Vale of Haverford, Pa., was married Saturday at her parents’ house to Benjamin Moshe Schmidt, the son of Susan E. Schmidt and Azriel Schmidt of Bryn Mawr, Pa. They were joined under Pennsylvania’s self-uniting marriage statute.

headline: Lindsey Healy,  Stephen Lambers III
text: Lindsey Catherine Healy, a daughter of Donna M. Healy and Christopher J. Healy of Troy, Mich., was married Monday to Stephen Lambert Lambers III, a son of Marion G. Lambers and Mr. Lambers Jr. of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. Earl Bolam, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Detroit Boat Club, where the couple met six years ago.

text: Monica Melissa Arcila and Dr. Scott Bryan Grant are to be married Sunday in Shrewsbury, N.J. The Rev. Idida Rodriguez, a minister ordained by the OneSpirit Interfaith Seminary, is to officiate at Shadowbrook at Shrewsbury, an event space.

text: Timothy Carter Neumann and Thomas William Mershon were married Saturday in the Preserved Smith Memorial Chapel of the Rowe Camp & Conference Center in Rowe, Mass. The Rev. Douglas Wilson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Deborah Rogal, Wei Hu

Charlotte White, a minister of the United Church of Christ and an aunt of the bride, led a nondenominational ceremony at Audrey’s Farmhouse Bed and Breakfast in Wallkill, N.Y.

Isaac Sr., of Washington ,are to be married Sunday by the Rev. Raphael G. Warnock, the senior pastor at the Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta.

Johnson of Wayzata, Minn., was married Saturday to Dr. Andrew Frederick Miller, the son of Mary Helen Dye Miller of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late David H. Miller. The Rev. Gary L. Langness, a Lutheran pastor, officiated at the home of the bride’s parents.
