text: Jaclyn Falice Gilman and Benjamin Douglas Reich are to be married Sunday at Temple Beth Elohim in Wellesley, Mass. Rabbi Henry Zoob is to perform the ceremony.

headline: Abigail Feuer, Daniel Blum
text: Abigail Eve Shanus Feuer and Daniel Jason Blum are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Jeffrey Segelman at the Boscobel House and Gardens, a museum in Garrison, N.Y.

headline: Peri Rosenstein, Jeffrey Yaffa
text: A veterinarian in New Castle, Del., is to marry an associate with a law firm.

headline: Brooke Raphael, Jeffrey Gewirtz
text: Brooke Silver Raphael and Jeffrey Brian Gewirtz are to be married Sunday evening by Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz at Temple Adath Yeshurun in Syracuse.

headline: Pooja Badlani, Tom Chuaypradit
text: Pooja Gopal Badlani and Tom Chuaypradit are to be married Sunday. Madhu Sharma, the Hindu chaplain at Duke University, will officiate at the Lofts at Union Square, an event space in High Point, N.C. In August, the couple had a Thai marriage ceremony at the Vajiradhammapadip Temple in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

headline: Grace Lo and Kevin Kim
text: Dr. Grace Chuoyan Lo, a daughter of Joanne Lo and Yue-Kai Lo of Shanghai, is to be married Sunday to Kevin Daejin Kim, a son of Soonbin Kim and Jae Deok Kim of Brooklyn. Drew Hyun, a pastor affiliated with the Evangelical Covenant Church, is to officiate at the Roundhouse at Beacon Falls, in Beacon, N.Y.

headline: Erin Murray, John Manning
text: Erin McInerney Murray, a daughter of Catherine M. Murray and Edward F. Murray of Cheyenne, Wyo., was married Friday to Dr. John Daniel Manning, a son of Lee A. Manning and James G. Manning of Bozeman, Mont. The Rev. Carl Beavers performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Mountains Catholic Church in Jackson Hole, Wyo.

headline: Eliza Swift and Andrew Welborn: The One Who Didn’t Get Away
text: Eliza Anne Swift and Andrew Michael Welborn were married Friday evening on the rooftop of Lacuna Artist Studio Lofts in Chicago. J. F. Harris, a Universal Life minister, stand-up comedian and friend of the groom, officiated.

headline: Thailand’s Military Junta Rejects Draft Constitution
text: BANGKOK — Thailand’s military junta on Sunday extended its rule by at least seven months when its handpicked reform council rejected a constitution written by its own drafting committee.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “This has to be an eye-opener on how messed up the situation in Europe is now.”

headline: Editors’ Note: September 6, 2015
text: BOOK REVIEW

headline: Flicker of Hope for Children With Rare and Devastating Disease
text: LEESBURG, Ala. — Once a year, Crystal and Jonathan Bedford drive 1,000 miles from their home in Texas to rural Alabama, their three children in tow. Beside a wooded lake, they huddle with other families whose children have the same extremely rare genetic disorder that their 5-year-old daughter, Marley, has.

headline: Hope for Rhizo Kids
text: Parents of children with RCDP, a very rare, terminal form of dwarfism, hope a potential new drug originally developed to treat Alzheimer’s will help their kids, too.

headline: As Europe Grasps for Answers, More Migrants Flood Its Borders
text: HEGYESHALOM, Hungary — Throughout the day on Sunday, train after packed train arrived at this border town from Budapest, the passengers smoothly shifting to a gleaming Austrian train on the opposite side of the platform and being whisked on to Vienna and beyond — 13,000 of them in the first 36 hours after Hungary allowed throngs of refugees and migrants to travel toward Germany.

headline: On the ‘Barbecue Patrol,’ a Summer Ritual for New York Police
text: After hours of checking on boisterous barbecues and other loud gatherings in the Bronx, making sure none grew out of control, Officers Joseph Helgerson and Edwin Vega stopped alongside their lieutenant’s car to check in. It was 11:07 p.m. on a Saturday.

headline: ‘Steve Jobs’ Receives Warm Reception at Telluride Film Festival
text: TELLURIDE, Colo. — Before the world premiere of his new film on Saturday night, Danny Boyle told a crowd of 650 here at the Telluride Film Festival not to expect a representational biopic. Rather, he said, his “Steve Jobs” is a meant to be a direct signal from inside the Apple co-founder’s mind, “with all of its wonders and all of its horrors.”

headline: Migrants on the Move Across Europe
text: The decision by Austria and Germany to throw open their borders and take in thousands of refugees does not seem to have stilled the movement or refugees across the continent.

headline: Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Head of D.N.C., Backs Iran Nuclear Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, announced on Sunday that she will support the nuclear agreement with Iran that has roiled many in her Florida district.

headline: Family Balks at Talk by Russia to Move Rachmaninoff’s Remains
text: VALHALLA, N.Y. — It was quiet beneath the mountain laurel shrubs shielding the grave of the composer Sergei Rachmaninoff from the late-summer sun. The furor is 4,500 miles away, in Russia, its indelible voice in every melodic line he wrote — a different Russia, a different sensibility, a different life, different time.

headline: Ousted as Gay, Aging Veterans Are Battling Again for Honorable Discharges
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — When the Army discharged Pvt. Donald Hallman in 1955 for being what it called a “Class II homosexual,” the 21-year-old was so scared of being an outcast that he burned all his military records, save for a single dog tag he hid away.

headline: Netanyahu Rejects Calls for Israel to Accept Syrian Refugees
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday rejected calls from opposition politicians for Israel to accept refugees from Syria, saying that Israel was “a very small country that lacks demographic and geographic depth.” He also said that plans to construct a fence along the eastern border with Jordan would go ahead.

headline: 1940: United Regime Is Antonescu’s Rumanian Goal
text: BUCHAREST — Following the abdication this morning [Sept. 6] of King Carol II in favor of his eighteen-year-old son, Prince Michael, Rumania has been thrown into a state of wild excitement, and the general feeling here is that anything may happen within the next forty-eight hours.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (13) ARTHUR & GEORGE In the time it took to puff on his pipe, Sherlock Holmes would have discerned everything: the eavesdropper at the private club, as well as his name, political persuasion and birthplace — all from the dust on his shoes. But Arthur Conan Doyle? Shockingly oblivious, a detractor declares in this three-part “Masterpiece Mystery!” presentation. “If you pursue your interest in the Edalji case, you’ll be judged by his high standards, and judged harshly,” the man chides Holmes’s creator. “But if you fall short, as you are bound to do, you’ll taint not only yourself but the world’s favorite consulting detective.” Edalji is the titular George, an Anglo-Indian solicitor imprisoned for mutilating livestock — and threatening schoolgirls with worse — in 1903 Staffordshire. He longs to be exonerated for crimes he maintains he did not commit, and Conan Doyle wagers his reputation that Edalji’s conviction was racially motivated. Martin Clunes, above, and Arsher Ali star in this adaptation of Julian Barnes’s fact-based novel, which unveils Conan Doyle’s personal life as he contemplates a future with his true love after his wife’s death. Charles Edwards plays Conan Doyle’s secretary, Alfred Wood — in other words, his Dr. Watson. “There’s just enough Sherlockian fun — Conan Doyle’s deductive abilities’ being compared unfavorably with those of his creation, Wood’s alarm when Conan Doyle considers a false beard as a disguise — to make the case for ‘Arthur & George,’ ” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times.

headline: For Now, Taubman Sale Means No Gift for Detroit Museum
text: Few institutions have benefited more from the generosity of A. Alfred Taubman, a businessman from Michigan, than the Detroit Institute of Arts, where a wing bears his name. Before his death in April, Mr. Taubman, a philanthropist and shopping-mall magnate who at one point was the principal owner of the auction house Sotheby’s, provided the museum with tens of millions of dollars and about two dozen artworks that are part of its permanent collection.

headline: Alleviating Pain, Delivering Love
text: Casey Barnes was born with multiple life-limiting conditions, among them quadriplegia cerebral palsy. She cannot move, suck, swallow, gag or blink. To the untrained or uncomprehending eye, she looks uncommunicative, inert, a small person with extreme breathing problems (her airway must be suctioned every 15 minutes or so). When we met, I had no idea how to interact with or even how to be around her, let alone how to approach her with a camera.

headline: Vienna Welcomes Refugees
text: Austrians received refugees with food, drinks and applause as they arrived by train from Hungary this weekend.

headline: 1890: Whisky and Tea Drinkers Worried
text: Western distillers are protesting against the increases made by the Senate on imported liquors. They fear the next step will be a rise of the internal revenue tax on domestic whiskies, in order to meet a possible deficit in the revenues of the Government. The Senate to-day adopted an amendment to the Tariff bill offered by Mr. Evarts as follows. It relates to stock held in London particularly: — ‘‘All teas the growth or produce of countries east of the Cape of Good Hope when imported from places west of the Cape of Good Hope shall pay duty 10 per centum ad valorem. Teas entered for consumption or for warehouse in any country intermediate between the country of export and the United States shall be treated as teas imported from such intermediate country and berated for duty accordingly.’’  — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 7, 1890

headline: Republicans Criticize Hillary Clinton and Discuss Kentucky Clerk’s Case
text: It was a relatively quiet Sunday on the talk shows, with candidates likely saving their energies (or enjoying a holiday) before a burst of activity on Labor Day, the traditional start of the campaign season. In truth, the presidential campaign has been blowing at near gale force for months.

headline: Montreal Symphony Orchestra Plans U.S. Tour
text: The Montreal Symphony Orchestra will embark in March on its most extensive tour of the United States in 25 years, the ensemble announced on Sunday, with concerts planned in 10 cities from coast to coast under the baton of its music director, Kent Nagano.

headline: Workers Organize, but Don’t Unionize, to Get Protection Under Labor Law
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — Jorge Porras used to report to his carwash job here most mornings at 8:15 a.m., but he said that his boss often did not let him clock in until 11, when customers frequently began streaming in. Many days he was paid for just six hours, he said, even though he worked nine and a half hours.

headline: Lynn Walker Huntley, Lawyer in Prominent Civil Rights Issues, Dies at 69
text: Lynn Walker Huntley, a lawyer who was deeply involved in a wide spectrum of civil rights cases and causes, including capital punishment, race relations and employment discrimination, died Aug. 30 at her home in Atlanta. She was 69.

headline: Taliban’s New Leader in Afghanistan Moves to Quash Dissent
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In one of the first tests of his leadership, the head of Afghanistan’s Taliban militants is moving aggressively against a breakaway faction in the south of the country, according to Afghan and Taliban officials.

headline: At New York Live Arts, Thomas O. Kriegsmann Is Ready to Take Risks
text: Maverick. Radical. Transformer. Socialist. Re-animator.

headline: Carrie Brownstein, Carly Rae Jepsen and Others on First-Time Cultural Experiences
text: What would you see for the first time, all over again? The critics have already weighed in. The Times asked cultural figures, as well as readers, for their choices. Read about their first encounters with “The Rite of Spring,” dinner at Momofuku and . . . cat videos.

headline: Review: Lauren Groff’s ‘Fates and Furies’ Features a Wife Who’s Full of Surprises
text: “Fates and Furies” is Lauren Groff’s third novel, and it’s sure to be regarded as her most approachable book thus far — if only as some measure of the others’ extreme peculiarity. In “The Monsters of Templeton,” she wrote a genealogical mystery about a thinly disguised version of Cooperstown, N.Y. (Ms. Groff’s birthplace), and put a dead, 50-foot-long prehistoric monster in the local lake for good measure. “Arcadia” followed a hippie commune, mostly through the 1960s and ’70s, so vividly that the smells of the place wafted off the page.

headline: Buzzr Presents the Evolution of Game Shows and Ourselves
text: A new channel called Buzzr might seem to have the fairly modest aim of catering to viewers who enjoy watching old game shows, but a programming stunt it is running this week suggests a much more ambitious purpose. This channel, if inadvertently, is documenting a startling acceleration in the pace of human evolution.

headline: Review: ‘The Odyssey’ Takes a Populist Turn as a Musical
text: A selfie with a celebrity has replaced the autograph as a coveted prize, but a selfie with a legendary hero, the great Greek warrior Odysseus? Well, that would beat Beyoncé, hands down. A lucky young prince gains such a digital trophy in the brash, funny and heart-stirring musical version of Homer’s “The Odyssey” being presented by the Public Theater at the Delacorte Theater through Monday night.

headline: Steven Matz Has Strong Start, but Mets Fall to Marlins
text: MIAMI — Steven Matz, sweat dotting his forehead, marched off the mound and paced the infield grass. With a stern expression, he watched the ball clear the wall in left-center field, then returned to the mound.

headline: ‘Sherpa’ and ‘Winter on Fire’ Display Good Timing at Telluride Film Festival
text: TELLURIDE, Colo. — There is something spooky about “Sherpa” and timing.

headline: Eugenie Bouchard Withdraws From U.S. Open
text: Eugenie Bouchard’s entry into the second week of the United States Open was supposed to have coincided with the return of her new coaching consultant, Jimmy Connors, who had planned to rejoin her if she reached the fourth round.

headline: West Indian American Day Parade Comes Together One Costume at a Time
text: Reisha Maynard-Holder meticulously cut patterns for a collar out of foam rubber as a fan whirred in the sweltering heat. Next, she turned her attention to feathers, attaching them to the collars one at a time with a glue gun. It was another grueling evening in a monthslong effort to create some of the most elaborate and spectacular costumes seen on the streets of New York.

headline: Marin Cilic, an Unsung Champion, Finds His Rhythm and Reaches the Quarterfinals
text: Marin Cilic is the defending United States Open champion. Remember that.

headline: Having Debts
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Labor Day! Wordplay wishes everyone a relaxing holiday.

headline: Serena Williams’s Victory Sets Up a Showdown With Her Sister
text: At age 35, Venus Williams has been making a gallant effort to win an eighth major tennis title, her last one coming seven years ago at Wimbledon. But if she is to do it at this year’s United States Open, it will come at a heavy cost. She will have to deny her younger sister the rare opportunity to win a Grand Slam.

headline: Jeb Bush Recommends Tony Campos for a White House Job
text: In the 1980s, Jeb Bush encountered a number of local Republicans in South Florida who were eager to eager to be associated with him and his powerful family, including Tony Campos.

headline: The Bushes Thank Tony Campos
text: In 1999, two members of the Bush family wrote to Tony Campos to share their appreciation for his plans for a tribute to Dorothy Walker Bush.

headline: Dorothy Walker Bush Honored as a ‘Great Floridian’
text: Tony Campos sought and gained a special recognition from the state of Florida for Dorothy Walker Bush, Jeb Bush’s grandmother, about a decade after her death.

headline: Review: Electric Zoo, a Menagerie Designed for Dancing
text: The seventh annual Electric Zoo, the Labor Day weekend electronic dance music festival on Randalls Island, was billed as Electric Zoo: Transformed. The sound-and-lights superstructure of its redesigned main stage was shaped like a phoenix. Actually, it was Electric Zoo persevering and slightly shrunken, with fewer performers, fewer stages and shorter schedules on most of them — a lineup of 85 acts, not the more than 100 at Electric Zoos since 2011.

headline: Ivan Nova Leads Yankees Over Rays
text: During the 2013 off-season, Yankees scouts homed in on Brian McCann, envisioning a plethora of home runs off his bat soaring into the short right-field porch in Yankee Stadium.

headline: Electric Zoo
text: Scenes from the music festival on Randall’s Island.

headline: Apple Unveils New Products, and Stephen Colbert Returns to Late Night
text: China reports a basket of monthly data this week that is expected to provide a clearer picture of how much its economic growth is slowing. On Tuesday, it will release trade figures for August; exports have been flat so far this year, and imports declined 15 percent in the first seven months of 2015. Other reports include inflation figures on Wednesday and industrial output, investment and retail sales on Saturday. Investors will also be watching on Monday for August data on China’s foreign exchange reserves. While still the world’s largest, China’s reserves are expected to have declined after the surprise devaluation last month of its currency, the renminbi, which has raised concerns over capital outflows. — Neil Gough

headline: Jeb Bush, Family Ties and a Museum That Never Materialized
text: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — When Jeb Bush set out to build a political base of his own in South Florida three decades ago, he did not lack for new friends. He was a magnet for a long line of Republicans eager to be associated with him and his powerful family, including a Cuban immigrant and former corrections officer named Tony Campos.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 7
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: Productivity and Pay
text: Still in Sydney (next stop Tokyo), where it’s much too beautiful a day to sit inside blogging. But I did want to flag an excellent report by Josh Bivens and Larry Mishel on the productivity-pay gap.

headline: Judd Winick’s Age-Appropriate Return to Comic-Strip Roots
text: Judd Winick is ready for his reboot.

headline: Caijing Journalist’s Shaming Signals China’s Growing Control Over News Media
text: HONG KONG — When the Chinese Ministry of Public Security arrested nearly 200 people at the end of August for “spreading rumors,” one of the most prominent targets was Wang Xiaolu, a reporter for the respected business magazine Caijing.

headline: New Apple TV Is Said to Focus on Games, Challenging Traditional Consoles
text: Apple stumbled into the games business almost by accident not long after it released the iPhone in 2007, igniting a new multibillion-dollar mobile games industry in the process.

headline: A Train Journey From Communism to Freedom, Almost Ended in Hungary
text: More than three decades ago, my mother, grandmother and I boarded a train in communist Romania, armed with the papers my mother had painstakingly gathered in an effort to give me a better life. I was 5 years old, and I had been told we were going on a holiday to Paris. I realized something was wrong when my surrogate grandfather Tata Geo (Father Geo) broke into sobs as we left the house.

headline: China’s Military Cutbacks
text: China announced that it would cut 300,000 troops, its largest reduction in nearly two decades.

headline: Celebrating Bud Collins, a Tennis Treasure Told in Words and Pants
text: Across the decades, Bud Collins had a standard line for when someone — typically a newspaper competitor — would rush over and wonder if he had a moment to answer a question. He would cheerily look up from his keyboard and say, “Ask two.”

headline: German Quota System Highlights Possible Path and Pitfalls for Handling Crisis
text: MUNICH — Rania al-Hamawi had gone to sleep on Saturday on a clean, bright blue cot alongside her three sons and another 1,700 people who had made the arduous journey to the Bavarian capital from Syria and other strife-ridden countries. But when she woke on Sunday, half the beds in the cavernous conference center-turned-migration camp were empty.

headline: Out of Perceived Weakness Is Born an Act of Aggression
text: Hit to your opponent’s backhand. For generations, that was considered the most foolproof tactic in tennis.

headline: The Crowding-Out Effect of Gargantuan Movies
text: Hollywood had one of its best summers ever at the domestic box office, but it was a sharply lopsided victory. Studios either thrived or withered, an outcome that reflects the winner-take-all nature of the mass-appeal movie business.

headline: Another Hot Stroke: The Drop Shot
text: The inside-out forehand is not the only high-risk, high-reward shot in vogue on the ATP Tour. The drop shot has also become a weapon of choice.

headline: Greenland’s Farmers Torn Over Tapping Pristine Land for Mineral Riches
text: QASSIARSUK, Greenland — Carl and Ellen Frederiksen gazed anxiously at a spot on the snow-flecked mountain behind their village. The sheepdogs had been running back and forth, and they feared a lamb was trapped on one of the slopes.

headline: Activists Say Police Abuse of Transgender People Persists Despite Reforms
text: New Year’s revelers clamored outside the window of Shagasyia Diamond’s apartment in the Bronx the day she was arrested.

headline: Time Warner Cable Plans Channel Dedicated to Pope Francis’ Visit
text: Pope Francis will not be hard to find on television during his visit to the United States.

headline: When Finding Housing Is a Job in Itself
text: Six years ago I went into the New York City shelter system. For 11 months, I searched for apartments like crazy. I had few options. I had just come out of a psychiatric hospital. I had a 4-year-old son and was pregnant with my daughter. I had a housing voucher and was living off of Supplementary Security Income (a Social Security program) and food stamps. I went in and out of real estate offices until I found an apartment at the western edge of the Bronx, in the River Park Towers.

headline: Experts Reject Official Account of How 43 Mexican Students Were Killed
text: MEXICO CITY — An international committee of experts reviewing the case of 43 missing college students whose disappearance last fall traumatized Mexico said Sunday that there was no evidence to support the government’s conclusion that the students were executed by a drug gang that then burned the bodies to ashes in a garbage dump.

headline: Threat to Arizona’s Salt River Horses Spurs New Battle Over Western Lands
text: PHOENIX — Soon after federal officials announced the imminent capture of 100 or so horses within the boundaries of a national forest near here — to be sold at auction, “condemned and destroyed, or otherwise disposed of” — a resourceful cadre of self-appointed guardians issued a desperate call for action.

headline: Visiting 99 Counties in Iowa Doesn’t Get Candidates as Far as It Used to
text: ROCK RAPIDS, Iowa — In a state that prizes retail campaigning, nothing is more revered than “the full Grassley” — a politician’s visit to all of Iowa’s 99 counties, named for the state’s peripatetic senior senator, Charles E. Grassley.

headline: Yoenis Cespedes Wows the Mets Underhand, Overhand and Many Other Ways
text: During spring training in 2012, when Yoenis Cespedes had just arrived in the United States from Cuba and was still getting to know his teammates on the Oakland Athletics, he started doing a trick they had never seen: He would throw the ball underhand with stunning velocity, movement and accuracy. Like a softball player.

headline: Appeal Filed in Kim Davis’s Contempt Ruling
text: Lawyers for Ms. Davis, the Kentucky county clerk who was jailed last week, filed a notice of appeal on the grounds that her right to due process had been violated.

headline: Jailed Kentucky Clerk Starts Federal Appeal
text: The Kentucky county clerk who was jailed for defying a federal court order to issue marriage licenses to gay couples has begun the process of appealing the judge’s ruling that landed her there, her lawyers said on Sunday.

headline: Guatemalans Head to Polls Days After President’s Ouster
text: MIXCO, Guatemala — Guatemalans voted on Sunday in presidential elections, disgusted by corruption and disheartened by their choices just five days after a wave of mass protests forced President Otto Pérez Molina from office.

headline: Matt Harvey Says He Will Pitch On
text: For three days, the debate over Matt Harvey’s innings limit raged on in the news media. His agent, Scott Boras, and his boss, General Manager Sandy Alderson, laid out their sides publicly, and Mets fans hammered Harvey on social media for not definitively saying, during a news conference Saturday, that he would pitch into the postseason.

headline: Jean Darling, Child Actress in ‘Our Gang’ Series, Dies at 93
text: Jean Darling, who appeared in the “Our Gang” comedy films as a child and performed in the original Broadway production of “Carousel,” died on Friday in Rödermark, Germany. She was 93.

headline: Best Move for Matt Harvey: Shield Arm, and Ears
text: Good God, the kid has gone pusillanimous on us. A coward, a phony, a fugazi. As a wealthy 60-something tabloid columnist puts it, Mets pitcher Matt Harvey is quitting on his stool.

headline: The Train to Germany
text: Syrian migrants took a train from Austria to their final destination: Germany.

headline: Beyond 2 Black Champions, a Void for the U.S.T.A.
text: Identifying the next great African-American talent is tricky business for the United States Tennis Association.

headline: U.S. Revamping Rebel Force Fighting ISIS in Syria
text: WASHINGTON — In an acknowledgment of severe shortcomings in its effort to create a force of moderate rebels to battle the Islamic State in Syria, the Pentagon is drawing up plans to significantly revamp the program by dropping larger numbers of fighters into safer zones as well as providing better intelligence and improving their combat skills.

headline: Where Both Shredders and Sharpshooters Go to Shop
text: CHURUBUSCO, N.Y. — Three miles from the Canadian border, along a remote stretch of highway where giant wind turbines fill the sky, Dick’s Country Store & Music Oasis is a hardy survivor. Better known as Dick’s Groceries, Gas, Guns & Guitars, this North Country mainstay has been in business since 1962 thanks to its hybrid retail strategy and its role as a community hub.

headline: Kendall Fuller’s Ties With Virginia Tech Are Rooted in Family
text: BLACKSBURG, Va. — Kendall Fuller said that his earliest experience playing football was the flag football league his parents put him in at age 6 or 7. To hear his parents tell it, though, it is not an unequivocally happy memory.

headline: No. 1 Is Slipping From a Fading Rory McIlroy
text: NORTON, Mass. — It was like watching the tennis superstar Roger Federer practice hours before a night match at the United States Open, only every stroke that Rory McIlroy, a friend of Federer’s, took on Sunday morning counted. Several dozen fans made it to the first hole at TPC Boston in time to watch McIlroy, the world No. 1 for at least another 24 hours, begin his third round at the Deutsche Bank Championship.

headline: No Foul Mouths on This Field: Football With a New Age Twist
text: RENTON, Wash. — Jimmy Graham, an all-star tight end, quickly learned things were different with the Seattle Seahawks after he arrived this spring from the New Orleans Saints in an off-season trade.

headline: Andy Murray Keeps Winning, and Resting and Recuperating
text: As he marches through the United States Open while battling a cold, Andy Murray talks to The New York Times about rest, recuperation and recovery. Murray has defeated Nick Kyrgios, Adrian Mannarino and Thomaz Bellucci, and he plays Kevin Anderson in a fourth-round match Monday.

headline: ‘Masters of Sex’ Recap: Libby’s Last Stand and Bill’s Admission
text: Season 3, Episode 9, “High Anxiety”

headline: Shaped by Camp, Alumni Fight to Prevent Its Move
text: RED HOOK, N.Y. — They were teenagers spending a summer or two at sleepaway camp, but the memories never left them. Decades later, with those campers in middle and old age, the memories are stoking a fight to keep Camp Rising Sun where it is for other generations of youngsters.

headline: Heisman Trophy Watch
text: A look at the top players in contention for college football’s highest honor.

headline: Life on the Streets
text: Visits with dozens of homeless New Yorkers reveal how job losses, mental health issues, substance abuse and problems with the city shelter system drove many to the streets.

headline: New Yorker Festival Announces Lineup
text: The 2015 New Yorker Festival will cover comedy, race and technology with some of the leaders in each field. Featuring interviews with Toni Morrison, Lin-Manuel Miranda, Billy Joel and Jason Segel, the 16th annual festival will run from Oct. 2 to 4 in New York and include live performances, film previews and a new tech conference.

headline: Obama Orders Federal Contractors to Provide Workers Paid Sick Leave
text: BOSTON — President Obama signed an executive order on Monday requiring federal contractors to provide up to seven days of paid sick leave a year, even as he accused Republican congressional leaders of endangering the economy and Republican presidential candidates of undercutting American workers.

headline: Pertussis Passed to Newborns From Siblings
text: A new study has found that siblings, not mothers, are now the most common source of pertussis infection in newborns.

headline: Jets Sideline Injured Dee Milliner
text: The Jets placed cornerback Dee Milliner (wrist) on short-term injured reserve on Sunday. The move prevents him from practicing for six weeks and from playing for eight. Milliner would be eligible to return for the Nov. 8 game against Jacksonville.

headline: Carl Edwards Wins at Darlington
text: Carl Edwards led for only 15 laps but won the Southern 500, a Nascar Sprint Cup race, at Darlington Raceway in South Carolina, edging Brad Keselowski and Denny Hamlin.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 8:15 P.M. (Cinemax) LOST IN TRANSLATION (2003) An American movie star (Bill Murray), cashing in on his celebrity to make a lucrative ad in Japan, meets a young woman (Scarlett Johansson, above, with Mr. Murray) who has been temporarily deserted by her husband (Giovanni Ribisi), in this comic melodrama written and directed by Sofia Coppola, who won an Oscar for best original screenplay. As they escape the confines of the Tokyo Hyatt, something like love ensues. Mr. Murray, who received an Oscar nomination, “supplies the kind of performance that seems so fully realized and effortless that it can easily be mistaken for not acting at all,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “For us, getting another month with your child or another year or another five years — that’s kind of everything.”

headline: Corrections: September 7, 2015
text: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: Reforms Follow Protests in Ferguson
text: It has been a year since the police shooting of an African-American teenager in Ferguson, Mo., ignited the community protest and street turmoil that ultimately laid bare local government’s exploitation of citizens, particularly blacks. It is no small achievement that Missouri began enforcing a series of tough new court reforms last month aimed at ending one particularly flagrant abuse: the systematic fleecing of accused traffic offenders in a revenue scheme to bolster the budgets of local governments.

headline: Help for the Way We Work Now
text: WITH the presidential race well underway, Labor Day is a good time to consider how our political leaders are grappling with the many challenges facing American workers. While the next president will confront a host of important labor and economic issues, one is poised to be a particularly significant factor in 2016 and beyond: the freelance economy.

headline: You Deserve a Raise Today. Interest Rates Don’t.
text: For most Americans, paychecks determine living standards. Unfortunately, wages in America have long stagnated or declined for most working people, including college graduates.

headline: Trump Is Right on Economics
text: So Jeb Bush is finally going after Donald Trump. Over the past couple of weeks the man who was supposed to be the front-runner has made a series of attacks on the man who is. Strange to say, however, Mr. Bush hasn’t focused on what’s truly vicious and absurd — viciously absurd? — about Mr. Trump’s platform, his implicit racism and his insistence that he would somehow round up 11 million undocumented immigrants and remove them from our soil.

headline: Sexual Attraction and Fluidity
text: Recently, Miley Cyrus told Elle UK, “I’m very open about it — I’m pansexual.”

headline: Patent Law Shouldn’t Block the Sale of Used Tech Products
text: American patent law should not be used to prevent consumers from reselling, altering or fixing technology products. A federal appeals court will soon hear a case that could clearly establish this principle.

headline: We Don’t Need Kim Davis to Be in Jail
text: KIM DAVIS, the clerk in Rowan County, Ky., went to jail last week, and there was no good reason for her to be there. Americans can expect more conflicts over religious conscience and same-sex marriage if we don’t find a way to coexist peacefully. Ms. Davis has become a symbol of what happens when we don’t.

headline: Tesco Sells South Korean Business Homeplus for Over $6 Billion
text: LONDON — Tesco, one of the biggest British grocery store chains, said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its South Korean operations to a consortium of investors led by the Asian private equity firm MBK Partners for more than $6 billion.

headline: The Whitney Taps Frank Stella for an Inaugural Retrospective at Its New Home
text: Now that the Whitney Museum of American Art has left its longtime digs on Madison Avenue for an all-new, terrace-laden building in Chelsea, its fall schedule seems likely to be read as a mission statement. What does it mean, for instance, that Frank Stella, 79, the champion of abstract art, has been tapped for the inaugural retrospective at the new building? Perhaps abstract painting is hot again, or perhaps the Whitney has entered a mature phase, celebrating not just the rise of art stars but the feat of staying artistically elevated over the years.

headline: Hotel Room Work Spaces Go Casual
text: As workers become less tethered to their desks, hotels are giving their old in-room work spaces the pink slip.

headline: On ‘The Muppets,’ Miss Piggy Has a Talk Show and a Chatty Staff
text: LOS ANGELES — Last winter, Miss Piggy found herself doing what many middle-aged actresses are forced to do when they hit the box office skids: looking for work.

headline: Melting Ice Isn’t Opening Arctic to Oil Bonanza
text: TERIBERKA, Russia — The warming Arctic should already have transformed this impoverished fishing village on the coast of the Barents Sea.

headline: Unwelcome Mat Is Out at Some of New York’s Privately Owned Public Spaces
text: Like many who work on Broadway, Peter Wolf, a stage manager for 25 years, hates the Great White Way packed as it is with tourists and traffic.

headline: Lung Screening May Not Push Smokers to Quit
text: The results of an admittedly small but telling new study suggest that Medicare and other insurers could be spending billions of dollars on screening smokers for lung cancer that would be better spent on helping them quit and keeping others from starting.

headline: A Steady Flow Staggers Into Europe, Outpacing Pledges of Shelter
text: ROSZKE, Hungary — Fraying tensions snapped along Hungary’s southern border on Monday as thousands more migrants staggered into the country from Serbia while European leaders scrambled to figure out what to do with them and how to stanch the flow.

headline: After Fatal Attack, Turkey Strikes at Kurdish Rebels
text: ISTANBUL — The Turkish military carried out airstrikes against Kurdish insurgents on Monday, a day after what appeared to be the deadliest rebel assault since the breakdown in July of a fragile peace process with the Turkish state.

headline: Novak Djokovic: The Unloved Champion
text: Novak Djokovic has spent most of the last four years as the world’s No. 1 ranked tennis player, but he is not necessarily the people’s champion. Having finally overtaken the affable, urbane superstar Roger Federer and his longtime foil, Rafael Nadal (a popular underdog), Mr. Djokovic knows the crowd is not always on his side. But that has only steeled his resolve.

headline: As the Complaint Box Fills, Mayor de Blasio Adopts a Mr. Fix-It Approach
text: New York City mayors have not generally taken kindly to criticism.

headline: Pakistan Says Its Drone Killed 3 Militants
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan said on Monday that three high-profile militants had been killed in the country’s violence-plagued northwest in the first strike by a locally manufactured drone.

headline: China, Trying to Bolster Currency, Taps Foreign Reserves
text: HONG KONG — China is burning through its huge stockpile of foreign exchange reserves at the fastest pace yet as it seeks to prop up its currency and stem a rising tide of money flowing out of the country.

headline: Barclays Sells Loan Portfolio to Investor Group Led by Goldman Sachs
text: LONDON — Barclays said on Monday that it had sold a portfolio of loans that included its secured lending business in Britain to a consortium of investors led by Goldman Sachs.

headline: China’s Turmoil May Stall Rebound in Watch Sales
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — After nearly three years of government austerity and slow economic growth, sales of luxury watches in China are showing signs of rebound — although many factors, including the recent weakening of the renminbi and stock market turmoil, could stall that momentum again.

headline: Review: On ‘HitNRun Phase One,’ Prince Plays Well With Others
text: In 2010, Prince said “the Internet’s completely over” as a method for distributing his music. He has changed his mind.

headline: New Retro by De Grisogono, a Watch Worthy of Elegance Past
text: LONDON — Think “The Thomas Crown Affair” (the first one, with Steve McQueen) or Yves Montand or Alain Delon strolling through a Marbella Club room. The playboys of the 1950s and ’60s didn’t let humdrum reality get in their way when it came to exuding sophistication and sex appeal.

headline: 36 Hours in Barcelona: Hidden Gems
text: “36 Hours,” a television program inspired by The Times’s 36 Hours column, airs Mondays at 8 p.m. Eastern on Travel Channel. The next episode on Barcelona dovetails with our column from last year.

headline: Lightning Kills at Least 28 as Storms Batter India
text: NEW DELHI — At least 28 people, many of them agricultural workers in fields, were killed by lightning when storms lashed southern and eastern India, officials said on Monday.

headline: European Leaders Grapple With Response to Migrant Crisis
text: The relentless stream of migrants continued to flow into Europe, prompting France, Germany and Britain to pledge more support.

headline: Times Critics’ Guide: What to Do This Week

headline: Scented Leather Goods, Made the 17th-Century Way
text: The cult French perfumer Francis Kurkdjian, who co-founded his eponymous fragrance house in Paris in 2009, introduces his first line of leather goods today — and, unsurprisingly, they smell quite nice. “Scented leather was very obvious to me since it is a direct link to the origins of perfumery,” says Kurkdjian in a reference to the 17th century, when gloves were perfumed to mask the odors left behind from the tanning process. Back then, a mixture of fragrant spices, blooms and natural oils were rubbed into the leather repeatedly to ensure staying power. But for his debut collection of scented cardholders, Kurkdjian developed a long lasting, pure-oil-based formula.

headline: Back-to-School Worries for Gay Parents
text: “Oh, you’re Mia,” the camper from the other bunk said. “You’re the one who’s adopted and has two moms.”

headline: The Horses of the Salt River
text: Floating along with the current, kayakers and paddleboarders on the Salt River in Arizona might catch a glimpse of a special sight: a herd of wild horses out for a swim.

headline: Israel in a Post-Deal World
text: HAIFA, Israel — THE day after six world powers reached a nuclear agreement with Iran in July, the Israeli Knesset’s foreign affairs and defense committee called on Israel’s government to “continue to closely follow the precise and strict implementation” of the agreement “to ensure that Iran is not continuing to fool the international community as it did in the past, while strengthening the historic alliance between the United States and Israel.”

headline: Britain Says It Killed 3 ISIS Suspects in First Drone Strike in Syria
text: LONDON — Crossing a significant threshold in its battle with jihadist groups, Britain announced on Monday that it had conducted an armed drone strike for the first time inside Syria, killing three suspected members of the Islamic State, including two British citizens.

headline: Anish Kapoor Work at Versailles Is Vandalized (Again)
text: The artist Anish Kapoor’s temporary installation at the Palace of Versailles was vandalized this weekend for the second time since June, this time covered in graffiti that included anti-Semitic slurs.

headline: 1965: India and Pakistan Bombed
text: NEW DELHI — Jet bombers carried death and destruction to Indian and Pakistani cities today [Sept. 7] as the threat of all-out war spread across the vast subcontinent of 590 million people. Pakistan reported Indian bombers attacked cities in both East and West Pakistan, including Rawalpindi and Karachi. India said Pakistani planes attacked near Calcutta and several other cities. Thus the Indian-Pakistani confrontation — originally over the control of the small vale of Kashmir — had spread from Karachi, on the Arabian Gulf, to Calcutta, 2,000 miles east. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 8, 1965

headline: Summery Cocktails From Bars Around New York City
text: T’s online managing editor Alainna Lexie Beddie celebrates the unofficial end of summer with seasonal drink recipes from bars around New York City.

headline: U.S. Denies an Airstrike Killed 11 Afghan Narcotics Officers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An American airstrike may have mistakenly killed at least 11 narcotics officers in southern Afghanistan on Sunday night, Afghan officials said on Monday. But the American military denied that such an airstrike had taken place.

headline: Sun, Surf and Horses’ Thundering Hooves Keep a Tradition Alive in Spain
text: SANLÚCAR DE BARRAMEDA, Spain — Local fishermen first started racing cart horses on the beach here while waiting to unload the day’s catch from their boats.

headline: Pop-Up Shop at Barneys to Feature a Billy Sullivan Drawing
text: It started with a casual lunch in Bridgehampton, N.Y. The textile designer Madeline Weinrib was hosting Billy Sullivan, an artist who has been a fixture of the New York art scene since the 1960s. He wanted to keep a visual diary of the scene, so he made some pastel drawings.
