headline: New York Chef Brothers Return Home to Detroit (and to Hot Dogs)
text: ‘‘THIS IS THE TICKET, folks,’’ says Eli Sussman. ‘‘This is the jam right here.’’ A coney has been placed in front of him on a table at American Coney Island, a red-and-white rockabillyish restaurant in downtown Detroit that could have easily doubled as the set of a White Stripes music video. In Michigan parlance, ‘‘coney island’’ essentially signifies a Greek diner, and a coney is a hot dog. And in this city, it’s only served one way: smothered in chili, yellow mustard and a fistful of raw white onions — no substitutions. ‘‘When you look at it, you say, ‘Oh, man, this is a terrible idea,’ ’’ says Eli’s older brother, Max. ‘‘Then you eat it and you’re like, ‘I kind of want another one.’ ’’

headline: Cuomo Administration Lawyer Is Shot in Head Before West Indian Day Parade
text: The revelers were crowded onto Bedford Avenue in Brooklyn partaking in the annual West Indian American Day celebration early on Monday when the bullets began to fly in all directions.

headline: Can You Crack the 24 Puzzle, and the 10 Puzzle That Went Viral in Japan?
text: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Nishant Pappireddi, a senior at the University of California, Berkeley, where he studies math as well as molecular and cell biology. I’d recently been introduced to Nishant by Ken Ribet, a professor at Berkeley famous for paving the way to a proof of Fermat’s Last Theorem. Ken considered Nishant to be one of his best students, so I asked Nishant if he had a favorite simple puzzle he might like to share on Numberplay. He responded with —

headline: Humanizing Technology: A History of Human-Computer Interaction
text: The march of progress in computing is a climb. Each big step forward is also a step up, so that communication is further away from the machine, more on human terms.

headline: 1940: Berlin Takes Savage Attack
text: LONDON — Returning blow for blow and bomb for bomb with interest, the Royal Air Force countered with sledge-hammer attacks against Berlin early this morning [Sept. 7] in one of the heaviest raids that the focal point of Hitlerism has yet received. As the docklands of London were burning tonight in so-called retaliation raids, new forces of R.A.F. bombers swung off from their airdromes, heading eastward to let the Germans know that the fighting power of this country has only begun to make itself felt. The British bombers were still restricted by their belief that bombs should be dropped at least within the bomb sight of the target. — New York Herald Tribune, September 8, 1940

headline: Exhibitions Where Moral Force Trumps Market Forces
text: The most important art events of the coming season are likely to be of a kind that don’t appear on lists like this, because they aren’t announced far in advance. Their medium is surprise. I hope this year they’ll include guerrilla actions by groups like Gulf Labor and Black Lives Matter aimed at shaking up a politically torpid art industry. I fear they’ll include further assaults by ISIS on art itself. Constructive or destructive, these examples of politically motivated activism have one thing in common: They acknowledge, as our corporate-minded museums and art schools don’t, that art is more than just market fodder. It is, or can be, a moral force.

headline: Chosen by Mississippi Democrats, Shy Trucker Is at a Crossroad
text: JACKSON, Miss. — Only three people who had ever met this man, Robert Gray, knew that he was running in the primary for governor of Mississippi.

headline: Experiencing Architecture Through ‘Hippie Modernism’ and Retrospectives
text: In 1965, four artists bought seven acres in southeastern Colorado, intending to make live-in works of art. Their communal project came to be known as Drop City, where residents lived in zonohedron domes of their own creation, sometimes constructed of automobile roofs and other scavenged materials. One dome, made of a fluorescent-painted lattice filled in with Mylar panels, made the trip east in 1968 to the Brooklyn Museum, filled with a five-foot-wide, round, spinning, “collaborative” work of art — “The Ultimate Painting” — that changed composition when illuminated by strobe lights.

headline: The Weeknd Tops the Billboard Charts
text: Abel Tesfaye, the once-shadowy Canadian R&B singer better known as the Weeknd, has completed his evolution from Internet triumph to full-blown pop star, hitting No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week.

headline: Will Ryman Prepares His New Exhibition at Paul Kasmin Gallery
text: A recent visit to Will Ryman’s cavernous two-story sculpture studio on Bowery, upstairs from a restaurant supply store, delivered a jolt of drama from the first encounter, when the artist opened the door to a back room.

headline: Museum of Food and Drink to Open Permanent Space in Brooklyn
text: The Museum of Food and Drink, which is opening its first brick-and-mortar location this fall, wants to change how you think about what you eat.

headline: A Western Showdown With Mussels
text: COUTTS, Alberta — At an inspection station here on the border with Montana, a black dog in an orange vest briskly scoured the hull of a motorboat, her nose twitching as she investigated every crevice.

headline: A Feast of Egyptian Treasures, Picasso Sculptures and Eye-Catching Toys
text: The fall exhibitions are looking very three-dimensional, and as David Letterman often used to say, I couldn’t be more excited. Seriously. The shows that intrigue me most range from masterworks created in Middle Kingdom Egypt to Swedish wooden toys, the latest in “Afropolitan” architecture and beach-friendly kinetic sculptures. There should be a prize for anyone who sees every show.

headline: National Sawdust Prepares for an Oct. 1 Opening
text: Paola Prestini, the creative and executive director of National Sawdust, stood in the space’s balcony one recent afternoon, looking over what would soon be a bustling concert hall. “The speakers just came in,” she said cheerfully, pointing at a rig hanging from the ceiling, still in its filmy protective covering. A geometric metal framework crisscrossed the room’s far wall, next to the hydraulic platforms that will make for a flexible stage.

headline: The Tardigrade: Practically Invisible, Indestructible ‘Water Bears’
text: When scientists at the American Museum of Natural History mounted an exhibit about creatures that survive under conditions few others can tolerate, they did not have to go far to find the show’s mascot.

headline: Ought’s ‘Sun Coming Down’: Polar Opposites, but Hand in Hand
text: “Beautiful Blue Sky,” a new song by the Montreal post-punk band Ought, might be the quickest way to understand what the group is all about.

headline: Janet Jackson’s ‘Unbreakable’ Is Right on Time
text: Beyoncé, Rihanna, Britney Spears, Janelle Monáe, F.K.A. twigs, Tinashe, Kelela — they’d probably all admit that Janet Jackson established their 21st-century archetypes decades in advance. So in a way, Ms. Jackson’s timing is appropriate for the release of “Unbreakable,” her first album since 2008 and the resumption of her collaboration with her longtime co-producers Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis.

headline: Republicans Fear Donald Trump Is Hardening Party’s Tone on Race
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans are growing increasingly concerned that Donald J. Trump’s inflammatory language is damaging the party, fearing that his remarks are hardening the tone of other candidates on racial issues in ways that could repel the voters they need to take back the White House.

headline: Premature Babies Study Raises Debate Over Risks and Ethical Consent
text: Two years ago, researchers in a clinical trial involving oxygen levels for the tiniest premature babies were accused by a federal watchdog agency of not properly disclosing the risks to families who participated.

headline: Guatemala Comedian Wins First Round of Presidential Vote
text: GUATEMALA CITY — A comedian won the first round of voting in Guatemala’s presidential election, five days after a wave of protests forced the country’s president from office.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Former Leader of Chad Hauled Into Court as Trial Resumes
text: PARIS — Shouting in protest, Chad’s former president was hauled by masked guards into a special court in Senegal on Monday as he began a new struggle with its judges over their right to try him on charges of crimes against humanity, torture and war crimes.

headline: Flies Want Your Blood, Too
text: Q. Mosquitoes are seeking blood, but what do flies get out of biting people?

headline: Networks and Cable Channels Go Mano a Mano
text: The confoundingly persistent fall television season is upon us, when the broadcast networks present their new shows like shiny toys, most of them soon to be lost or thrown away.

headline: On ‘Scream Queens’ and ‘American Horror Story,’ Being Scary Is Terrifying
text: I can remember the last time television made me laugh, and the last time it made me cry. But I can’t remember the last time a scripted TV show scared me, and that worries me, because I like a good scare. So do I have hopes for the fall season, which brings the high-profile newcomers “Scream Queens” and “Ash vs. Evil Dead” along with returning fright fare like “American Horror Story”?

headline: ‘Empire’ on Fox Has Become a Star Attraction
text: If your TV show is called “Empire,” there is no such thing as too much.

headline: After Deflategate, the Sequel on Wheels
text: An important sporting event. Charges of impropriety involving deflation. Lots of references to “pounds per square inch.”

headline: Jesse Plemons Moves On and On From ‘Friday Night Lights’
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Growing up in Mart, Tex., a small town of 2,000 outside of Waco, Jesse Plemons grew up on 34 acres roping and riding and playing football. But for the most part, from before he was old enough to walk, he lived life on the edge of his sofa, a play gun at his side, rewatching the mini-series “Lonesome Dove,” about Larry McMurtry’s retired Texas Rangers and their epic adventure pushing cattle north. “I was always kind of by myself wishing I was Gus,” he said. “The older I got I started to try and trace just how Robert Duvall and Tommy Lee Jones did what they did to me, how they made me believe they were those people. I bought every part of their world. I guess I’ve sort of been chasing that honesty of theirs ever since.”

headline: Review: ‘Stoned: A Doctor’s Case for Medical Marijuana’
text: Two-legged or four-legged, some guinea pigs have more fun than others.

headline: Big-Budget Blockbusters Dominate Fall Video Games
text: The twin rise of digital distribution and a robust independent scene has made video games more diverse, more rewarding and more unpredictable than at any time in the medium’s history. It’s usually hard to see much evidence of that, however, in the fall release schedule, which is dominated by big-budget blockbusters that too often play it safe.

headline: Jets’ Geno Smith Is Up for Drills, but Not for Questions
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The last four weeks have given quarterback Geno Smith ample time to reflect — on his future with the Jets, on the Aug. 11 altercation that left him with a broken jaw, on his standing among his teammates — and he said he learned a valuable lesson.

headline: London Theater Journal: Firebrands
text: LONDON — The plight of the immensely talented 17th-century dramatist Sister Juana Inés de la Cruz is, on one level, sadly familiar to female playwrights of today. Though it is widely acknowledged that she wrote wondrously witty and accomplished works, she could not get them produced.

headline: The Detroit Graduates
text: Attention shifted away from Detroit after the bankruptcy. But for five high school students, life has moved on, sometimes in unexpected ways, as the city struggles to get back on its feet.

headline: Fresh Face on TV: Yasmine Al Massri of ‘Quantico’
text: When Yasmine Al Massri read the part of Nimah Amin in Joshua Safran’s “Quantico,” she was shocked.

headline: Sandy Alderson Proposes Compromise for Mets’ Matt Harvey
text: WASHINGTON — Hours before the Mets began their biggest series of 2015 against the Washington Nationals on Monday, General Manager Sandy Alderson met with the team’s ace, Matt Harvey, and outlined a compromise plan designed to keep Harvey as a viable, if less active, member of the starting rotation in the season’s final weeks.

headline: Fresh Face on TV: Lee Jones of ‘The Bastard Executioner’
text: The key to a clean beheading, according to Lee Jones, is to come in at just the right angle. “You want to come in flat,” he said, “so you don’t have to go in and do extra chopping.”

headline: Fresh Face on TV: Jaina Lee Ortiz in ‘Rosewood’
text: That police officer hovering in the corner of a crime scene? In real life, he’s the father of the actress Jaina Lee Ortiz. That salsa partner she’s burning up a dance floor with? None other than her husband.

headline: Oysters May Serve as Link in Transmission of Norovirus
text: Oysters appear to be an important link in the transmission of norovirus among humans, according to new research from China.

headline: Prospect of Another Shutdown Looms as Congress Girds for Fights Over Spending
text: WASHINGTON — When Congress returns for business on Tuesday, lawmakers have scheduled a mere 12 legislative days to find a bipartisan compromise to keep the government open, vote on one of the most contentious foreign policy matters in a generation, reconcile the future of funding for Planned Parenthood and roll out the red carpet — and a few thousand folding chairs — to greet Pope Francis.

headline: The Iran Nuclear Deal: Congress Has Its Say
text: At the top of the agenda for Congress this month is a resolution disapproving President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran. Democrats have enough votes to sustain a presidential veto of the resolution and ensure that the deal will go into effect, but the debate will still be heated about an agreement that eases economic sanctions against Iran in exchange for new limits on its nuclear program. Here are some nuts and bolts on the situation about to unfold on Capitol Hill.

headline: Crowdfunding a $500 Million Ferris Wheel, With a Wall Street Spin
text: Investing in stocks is at times compared to a thrill ride — a rocket ship taking off, or a roller coaster rushing down.

headline: Israeli Film Director Delves Into Killing of Yitzhak Rabin
text: JERUSALEM — In one scene, a group of Jews wrapped in prayer shawls begin reciting a mystical death curse known as the Pulsa Dinura. A man in a suit who has urged them to invoke the angels of destruction promises that their prime minister, Yitzhak Rabin, “will be dead within a month.”

headline: Marketing to Sports Fans Online, With Help From Google and Social Networks
text: When the National Football League season begins on Thursday, Google will not be merely sitting on the sidelines.

headline: Palestinian National Council Meeting Is Postponed Amid Boycotts
text: JERUSALEM — A conference of the Palestinian National Council that had been scheduled for next week has been indefinitely postponed amid boycotts by some political factions and debate about the agenda and structure of the meeting. The 700-plus-member council, which has not had a regular session since 1996, was slated to convene in the West Bank city of Ramallah next Monday and Tuesday to consider, among other things, the membership of the Palestine Liberation Organization’s executive committee. The P.L.O. chairman, Mahmoud Abbas, who is also president of the Palestinian Authority, was to submit his resignation along with 10 of the executive committee’s 18 members, though it was unclear whether he and his colleagues would actually step down or stand for re-election. Whether Mr. Abbas truly plans to withdraw from political life or is trying to shake up the leadership in order to curtail criticism and consolidate power has been the subject of speculation for weeks.

headline: Patrick Drahi Positions Himself to Be a Player in U.S. Cable
text: PARIS — When the French-Israeli billionaire Patrick Drahi bought a St. Louis cable TV company in May and was mentioned as a potential suitor for Time Warner Cable, it may have been the first time many Americans had heard his name.

headline: Readers’ Summer Highlight Reel
text: The New York Times asked readers on Twitter and Facebook to finish the sentence, “The best thing I did in New York City this summer was.” Here is a selection of the responses.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Compete For Union Support
text: NEWTON, Iowa – Bernie Sanders recalled his days on picket lines. Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke out against privatizing government jobs.

headline: Companies Struggle to Comply With Rules on Conflict Minerals
text: A pink My Little Pony balloon does not usually evoke images of rifle-toting warlords in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Still, Party City Holdings, the decorations and costumes retailer, recently disclosed a possible link to securities regulators, helping to put it near the bottom of a list ranking companies on their compliance with laws against using minerals mined in war-torn regions across Africa.

headline: Apple and Other Tech Companies Tangle With U.S. Over Data Access
text: WASHINGTON — In an investigation involving guns and drugs, the Justice Department obtained a court order this summer demanding that Apple turn over, in real time, text messages between suspects using iPhones.

headline: Italy’s Highest Court Explains Decision to Clear Amanda Knox
text: ROME — Italy’s highest court said Monday that the case against the Seattle resident Amanda Knox and her former boyfriend — whose convictions in the 2007 murder of a British student were definitively overturned in March — was marked by “culpable omissions of investigative activity” and “contradictory evidence” that raised reasonable doubt of their guilt.

headline: For Online Sports Videos, the Action Is No Longer on the Field
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Anyone who went to the Apple iTunes store to buy a movie in mid-August might have noticed that sitting in the digital queue, next to blockbusters like “Mad Max: Fury Road,” was the seemingly obscure title “We Are Blood,” which was not exactly a movie, but a video consisting mostly of skateboarders performing tricks.

headline: FIFA Ruling Forces Ben Lederman Back to U.S.
text: Ben Lederman, the teenage soccer player whose career at Barcelona was cut short by FIFA transfer regulations, has returned to the United States and plans to enroll at the IMG Academy in Bradenton, Fla.

headline: Jon Batiste Will Lead ‘The Late Show With Stephen Colbert’ Band in a Style He Sees Fit
text: There comes a point in almost any scheduled performance by Jon Batiste when he pops up from the piano and strides into the crowd, tootling his melodica, a toylike wind instrument, with bandmates in tow. It’s a trademark shtick that happens to carry a whiff of the authentic, given Mr. Batiste’s lifelong familiarity with New Orleans second-line parades. Naturally, it was one of the factors that led to his role as bandleader on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert,” which makes its debut on CBS on Tuesday.

headline: Mets’ David Wright Says It All: ‘What a Game’
text: WASHINGTON — David Wright rounded third base, chugging as fast as he could with a bad back, and saw Tim Teufel, the Mets’ third-base coach, swinging his left arm like a windmill, waving him on. The Mets had just built a two-run lead in the top of the seventh, and now Teufel, going for the kill, wanted to make it three.

headline: Plague Cases in U.S. on the Rise
text: There have been 13 cases and three deaths from plague in the United States in the past five months, but researchers do not know why the disease appears to be on the rise.

headline: Photo Zines Explore Singapore’s Identity
text: A series of zines produced by photographers in Singapore offer insider’s views of the country, its history and its eccentricities.

headline: Erica Jong’s ‘Fear of Dying’ Defies the Sunset of Sex
text: Two words have vexed Erica Jong for the last 42 years. The first is “zipless,” and the word that follows is not printable in this newspaper.

headline: Sara Little, Peripatetic Product Designer, Dies at 97
text: Sara Little Turnbull, an innovative product designer who found inspiration for her work in geisha styles, a Kenyan game park, an American prison and other unlikely places, died on Friday at her home in Seattle. She was 97.

headline: Martin Milner, Clean-Cut Star of ‘Route 66’ and ‘Adam-12,’ Dies at 83
text: Martin Milner, an actor who broke out of supporting movie roles as the quintessential clean-cut young man to achieve television stardom as one of two road-hungry bachelors in “Route 66” and later as a veteran police officer in “Adam-12,” died on Sunday at his home in Carlsbad, Calif. He was 83.

headline: Review: ‘Fortune Smiles,’ Stories From Dark Places, by Adam Johnson
text: Adam Johnson set his deeply affecting Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, “The Orphan Master’s Son,” in the hermit kingdom of North Korea, where government oppression and propaganda combine to make daily life as strange and harrowing as anything dreamed up by a dystopian satirist on hyperdrive. Mr. Johnson’s earlier writing — his 2002 story collection, “Emporium,” and his first novel, “Parasites Like Us” — also had a surreal, even sci-fi feel. And while many tales in his potent new collection, “Fortune Smiles,” have recognizable, contemporary settings, they, too, feature characters reeling from displacement, dislocation or emotional and cultural vertigo.

headline: Affinity and Inflation
text: Brad DeLong marvels at Peter Schiff insisting to Josh Barro that US inflation is far higher than the official statistics acknowledge, and hence that the economy is actually shrinking. Incidentally, the independent Billion Prices index — which is internet-based, and places a higher weight on goods as opposed to services including housing — is actually showing deflation right now.

headline: Timothy Snyder’s ‘Black Earth’ Puts Holocaust, and Himself, in Spotlight
text: NEW HAVEN — When Timothy Snyder’s book “Bloodlands: Europe Between Hitler and Stalin” was published in 2010, it quickly established its author as one of the leading historians of his generation, a scholar who combined formidable linguistic skills — he reads or speaks 11 languages — with an elegant literary style, white-hot moral passion and a willingness to start arguments about some of the most fraught questions of the recent past.

headline: Review: ‘They Are Gone’ Is Kathryn Hamilton’s Play About Protest and Apathy
text: A bare-breasted woman was gently beating a shirtless man with nunchaku sticks. Another woman was stapled to the wall by her hair, long strands of it wrapped across her eyes, mouth and throat.

headline: Review: Satellite Collective Mixes Media and Messages at BAM Fisher
text: Satellite Collective is an admirably cooperative endeavor and a peculiar one. Its program at BAM Fisher on Thursday included a poetic monologue, a stop-motion film and three dance pieces, with and without video accompaniment. Everything had live musical accompaniment, and there were standalone musical selections, too. Seven composers, three choreographers, one filmmaker, two writers, one lighting designer and three costume designers contributed, with some of those people wearing multiple hats. Even for a sampler, that’s a lot of creative voices.

headline: Children Tossing School Lunch Fruits and Vegetables
text: You can lead a child to vegetables, but it appears you can’t make him eat.

headline: Expecting Little, Simona Halep Finally Reaches Round of 8
text: Simona Halep is the No. 2 seed at the United States Open, and she entered her round of 16 match with more hardcourt victories this year than any other woman in the main draw, having compiled a 35-5 record.

headline: Plutonium Is Unsung Concession in Iran Nuclear Deal
text: At first glance, the metals that give atom bombs their destructive fury might seem interchangeable: Uranium and plutonium are both more valuable than gold. Both captivate would-be atomic powers. And both fueled bombs that leveled Japanese cities — uranium at Hiroshima and plutonium at Nagasaki.

headline: West African Child Is Paralyzed by Vaccine-Derived Polio
text: A case of vaccine-derived polio has paralyzed a child in Bamako, the capital of Mali, and an emergency vaccination drive is being organized to forestall an outbreak, the World Health Organization announced Monday.

headline: European Farmers Demand Aid as Produce Prices Sag
text: BRUSSELS — Thousands of farmers snarled traffic and pelted the police with eggs on Monday in a protest to demand emergency aid to offset falling prices for milk, pork and other agricultural products.

headline: Migrant Influx May Give Europe’s Far Right a Lift
text: LONDON — As Europe basks in good feelings over its generosity to thousands of migrants and asylum seekers last weekend, critical voices from the political right and far right are poised to become among the biggest beneficiaries of the continuing flow.

headline: Hillary Clinton: Puppy Mills Can be Cruel
text: NEWTON, Iowa – It was not the Iran deal, or her private email server, that a woman at a crowded coffee shop wanted to question Hillary Rodham Clinton about on Sunday.

headline: Russia Answers U.S. Criticism Over Military Aid to Syria
text: MOSCOW — The Foreign Ministry here expressed surprise on Monday over an American warning to Russia against escalating the conflict in Syria, saying that the Kremlin’s Syrian policy — in particular furnishing military aid to help the government confront extremist forces — had been consistent for years.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Show More Humor and Heart, Aides Say
text: There will be no more flip jokes about her private email server. There will be no rope lines to wall off crowds, which added to an impression of aloofness. And there will be new efforts to bring spontaneity to a candidacy that sometimes seems wooden and overly cautious.

headline: ‘The Fix,’ a Ribald Musical About Political Showmanship
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — Even against the backdrop of a circuslike election season replete with investigations of a private email account and mudslinging by a billionaire reality television star, the plot of the “The Fix,” a musical about the dark arts of campaigning, is sordid enough to give political operatives pause.

headline: Greg Bird’s Walk Aids Yankees, and His Homer Wins Game
text: With the Yankees mounting a fifth-inning rally Monday, Greg Bird wanted to reach base by any means necessary. The Orioles’ Wei-Yin Chen threw Bird an inside pitch, and Bird, a 22-year-old rookie, winced as if he had been hit.

headline: Mindy Kaling: By the Book
text: The actress, producer and author, most recently, of “Why Not Me?” secretly read in bed as a child. “My parents encouraged reading, but they didn’t anticipate me reading Michael Crichton’s ‘Sphere’ until 2 a.m. on a school night.”

headline: Dispute at Coke Bottling Plant Could Signal Labor Challenges for E.U.
text: FUENLABRADA, Spain — Can a Spanish court force a multinational company to bottle Coca-Cola against its will?

headline: Raymond Kelly, Ex-Police Commissioner, Blames Mayor de Blasio for Rise in Killings
text: Former Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said last week that Mayor Bill de Blasio’s constraints on the stop-and-frisk strategy of the Bloomberg administration was to blame for the uptick in murders in New York City. Mr. Kelly also attributed the rise in homicides in other cities to a backlash to the killing last year of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo.

headline: India’s Middle-Class Revolt
text: Protests by members of a relatively prosperous caste in India who want to be included in affirmative action programs highlight a major problem: India isn’t creating enough good jobs. This is a big challenge to Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who has built his political career on promises to reform and modernize the stalled economy.

headline: A Jogging Biden Hears Calls to ‘Run, Joe, Run!’
text: PITTSBURGH — The calls of encouragement could be heard on nearly every block as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. jogged his way through the Labor Day parade here.

headline: Serpico, Seeking Seat on Town Board, Sees Corruption and Pledges to Fight It
text: STUYVESANT, N.Y. — He no longer looks like the young, full-haired, wild-eyed officer played by Al Pacino in the 1973 film “Serpico.” But the real Frank Serpico, 79, was still energetic and loquacious as he headed from his secluded cabin in this small upstate town to visit the local county fair last week on its opening day.

headline: A Los Angeles Plan to Reshape the Streetscape Sets Off Fears of Gridlock
text: LOS ANGELES — This city of fast cars and endless freeways is preparing to do what not long ago would have been unthinkable: sacrificing car lanes to make way for bikes and buses.

headline: Palestinians Pay Homage to a 3rd Firebomb Victim
text: DUMA, West Bank — Palestinians in Duma held their third funeral in six weeks, as they buried victims of an arson attack in which Jewish extremists have been accused. First, they buried a toddler, Ali Dawabsheh, then his father, and on Monday, they buried his mother, Riham Dawabsheh, each dying of injuries sustained in the fire on July 31.

headline: Clinging to Blinders, Victoria Azarenka Closes In
text: Oh, look, Victoria Azarenka won her fourth-round match on Monday at the United States Open, letting our vision of a final against Serena Williams live on.

headline: What Are a Hospital’s Costs? Utah System Is Trying to Learn
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Only in the world of medicine would Dr. Vivian Lee’s question have seemed radical. She wanted to know: What do the goods and services provided by the hospital system where she is chief executive actually cost?

headline: Judy Carne, ‘Sock It to Me’ Girl on ‘Laugh-In,’ Dies at 76
text: Judy Carne, a sprightly British actress and comedian who rocketed to pop culture fame as the “sock it to me” girl on “Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In,” a landmark of television zaniness, before her career was derailed by drug arrests and a near-fatal automobile accident, died on Thursday in Northampton, England. She was 76.

headline: Decoding Steve Jobs, in Life and on Film
text: Nearly four years after Steve Jobs died, a debate is still raging.

headline: Rehab, Degree, Playoffs. Two Down, One to Go.
text: PAWTUCKET, R.I. — Marcus Stroman cried when a doctor told him in March that he had torn his anterior cruciate ligament after falling in a spring training fielding drill. He called his father, his mother and Ryan Bahnsen, his best friend from high school on Long Island.

headline: Rail Biking Arrives in Adirondacks, but Future of Track Is in Doubt
text: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y. — Hoots, hollers and laughter echoed through the air as passengers aboard a mechanical device, previously unknown to the Adirondacks, made their way through the woods.

headline: Cardale Jones Settles Question and Ohio State Provides Exclamation Point
text: BLACKSBURG, Va. — The greatest trick play that Coach Urban Meyer has so far devised may have been letting all the focus be on who would start at quarterback when Ohio State opened the season against Virginia Tech on Monday night.

headline: Second Review Says Classified Information Was in Hillary Clinton’s Email
text: WASHINGTON — A special intelligence review of two emails that Hillary Rodham Clinton received as secretary of state on her personal account — including one about North Korea’s nuclear weapons program — has endorsed a finding by the inspector general for the intelligence agencies that the emails contained highly classified information when Mrs. Clinton received them, senior intelligence officials said.

headline: Migrants Who Survived Shipwreck Are Grateful, but Disillusioned
text: SANDVIKEN, Sweden — As tens of thousands of migrants run the gantlet of dangers to reach Europe, Natanael Haile, a refugee from Eritrea now living in Sweden, is struggling to get over his nightmarish journey.

headline: Andy Murray, Blanked in Tiebreaker, Falls at U.S. Open
text: Andy Murray had built a record of consistent excellence since the beginning of 2011. He had played in 18 major tournaments and reached the quarterfinals each time, winning twice, including at the 2012 U.S. Open.

headline: Yazidis Settle in Nebraska, but Roots Run Deep in Iraq
text: LINCOLN, Neb. — They came to America seeking the freedom to pray and work in peace. But in death, many hoped to be buried among the hills of their homeland, in northern Iraq.

headline: Rebecca Livengood, Nathaniel Wenstrup
text: Rebecca Jane Livengood and Nathaniel Christian Wenstrup are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Charles Kroloff at the vacation home of the bride’s parents in Culver Lake, N.J.

headline: Rickie Fowler Edges Henrik Stenson as Playoff Field Narrows
text: NORTON, Mass. — The day before the start of the Deutsche Bank Championship, Collin MacDonald, a teenage volunteer, caught up to his favorite player, Rickie Fowler. He had met Fowler two years ago, when he carried a scoring standard for Fowler’s group. He had returned to do the same job this year, and on Thursday he said he told Fowler, “Maybe on Monday afternoon everything will click together.”

headline: J’ouvert and the Annual West Indian Parade
text: Thousands of revelers line the streets in Brooklyn each year for the event, which celebrates Caribbean culture.

headline: Somewhat Family-Friendly
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — The day that The Boy could go “legally” see a PG THIRTEEN movie with us was a happy day indeed. I don’t even remember the movie. I just remember the distinct lack of whining when we didn’t have to leave him behind.

headline: Jason Pierre-Paul Visits Giants Two Months After Injury
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — About two months after a Fourth of July fireworks accident cost him his right index finger, Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul flew to the New York area on Monday to meet with the team’s medical personnel. It was the first time the Giants had seen the damage to Pierre-Paul’s hand.

headline: Vulgar Videos Lead to Ouster of 2 Canadian Candidates From Ballot
text: OTTAWA — The governing Conservative Party of Canada on Monday dropped two of its candidates for the House of Commons because of embarrassing videos featuring them.

headline: South Korea: North Agrees to Reunions
text: South and North Korea agreed Tuesday to arrange for hundreds of relatives separated during the Korean War to meet siblings and other family members next month in those families’ first reunions in more than six decades. The 1950-53 Korean War — which was halted by a truce, not by a formal peace treaty — left the Korean Peninsula divided and numerous Koreans separated from their relatives. The so-called separated family members have never been allowed to exchange letters or meet each other, unless both governments arranged occasional reunions limited to a few hundred people. The last such reunions took place in February last year. After an overnight negotiation at the border village of Panmunjom, the two Koreas signed an agreement on Tuesday to hold a new round of family reunions at the Diamond Mountain resort in the southeast of North Korea on Oct. 20-26. The nations agreed in principle to a new round of reunions during an Aug. 25 deal to defuse a military showdown along the border.

headline: Verizon to Offer Free Mobile TV, With an Eye on Millennials
text: Verizon Communications is hoping that millennials will start flipping their mobile phones 90 degrees and streaming live and on-demand television.

headline: Doctors’ Association Sees Harm in Insurance Mergers
text: WASHINGTON — Doctors and hospitals are stepping up their criticism of proposed health insurance company mergers.

text: multilingual • \ˈməl-te-ˈliN-gwəl, -ˈliN-gyə-wəl\ • adjective

headline: Roger Federer Solves John Isner’s Serve, Finally, and Advances
text: Roger Federer saved the break of serve for last, doing what no man had managed to do at the U.S. Open against John Isner since 2013.

headline: Jean-Georges Vongerichten Has Designs on South Street Seaport
text: The chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten is planning an ambitious new food market to anchor the culinary offerings at the South Street Seaport starting in 2017.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “In this country — in Soviet times, in czarist times — nobody thinks about the next generation.”

headline: Corrections: September 8, 2015
text: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: What’s On TV Tuesday
text: 11:15 A.M. (HBO Signature) GHOST TOWN (2008) After a near-death experience during a colonoscopy, Bertram Pincus (Ricky Gervais, in bed), a misanthropic Manhattan dentist, starts to see spirits — namely, Frank Herlihy (Greg Kinnear), a two-timing yuppie who was hit by a bus while avoiding a falling air-conditioner. He wants Bertram to befriend his widow, Gwen (Téa Leoni), and prevent her from remarrying. She hates Bertram, and then she doesn’t. “A latter-day hybrid of ‘Topper’ and ‘Blithe Spirit’ and a visual ode to autumn in New York, ‘Ghost Town’ is a screwball comedy with no big surprises or hidden metaphors,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this romantic froth, directed by David Koepp. But instead of becoming “mired in sentimentality like flies in molasses,” the film “tiptoes to the edge of that sticky mess, but it doesn’t get caught there.”

headline: Photo Zines That Explore Singapore’s Identity
text: For years, Sim Chi Yin had felt unique, if out of place, within her family. Since starting out at Singapore’s The Straits Times in 2001, and later switching careers to become a full-time photographer, she never seemed to gain their approval.

headline: Teachers Aren’t Dumb
text: ONE of my colleagues at the University of Virginia, a world authority on how culture influences personality, almost didn’t become a professor. He wanted to teach high school, but went for his Ph.D. because it seemed easier; he thought he would fail the exacting admissions test for teacher candidates. Perhaps I should mention that my colleague is from Japan.

headline: The Price for Lowering Cholesterol
text: Two new, powerful and expensive drugs to treat very high cholesterol are raising concerns about the ability of public and private insurers to pay and whether the benefits the drugs bring will outweigh their long-term costs.

headline: When Congress Puts NASA on Hold, Planets Don’t Wait
text: THE United States asks NASA to do an extraordinary amount with very little money. Explore Mars, document climate change, stop doomsday asteroids, find life on Europa — all for less than one-half of 1 percent of the federal budget. But budget uncertainties on Capitol Hill, including delays in federal appropriations legislation and temporary government shutdowns, measurably harm the American space program. Even the threat of a shutdown can have a far-reaching impact on scientific projects, often in unexpected ways.

headline: The Pointless Banishment of Sex Offenders
text: It’s a chilling image: the sex predator skulking in the shadows of a swing set, waiting to snatch a vulnerable child.

headline: Zuckerberg’s Expensive Lesson
text: It’s just hitting bookstores, but Dale Russakoff’s new book, “The Prize: Who’s in Charge of America’s Schools?,” has already become a source of enormous contention, both in Newark, where the story takes place, and among education advocates of various stripes.

headline: Love, Hate and Suicide
text: There are times when I like my therapist. When she is supportive and understanding, it’s easy to like her. Sometimes the like turns to love because she means so much to me. It is at these times when I value our relationship the most.

headline: What Ideas Do You Have for Enhancing Your Community?
text: In many communities, individuals and groups work to create things for everyone to enjoy, such as public art projects and free concerts.

headline: Shinzo Abe of Japan Re-elected as Leader of Ruling Party
text: TOKYO — Japan’s governing Liberal Democratic Party re-elected Prime Minister Shinzo Abe as its president on Tuesday after his potential rival, Seiko Noda, failed to achieve enough support from lawmakers to contest the post. Mr. Abe will remain party leader for a second three-year term.

headline: Mitsui Sumitomo of Japan to Acquire British Insurer Amlin
text: LONDON — The Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance Company said Tuesday that it would acquire the British insurer Amlin for 3.5 billion pounds.

headline: The Anti-Party Men: Trump, Carson, Sanders and Corbyn
text: Political parties are civic institutions. They are broad coalitions built for the purpose of creating a governing majority that can be used to win elections and pass agendas. This summer three American politicians have risen to the fore, and they all sit outside or at the margin of the party they are trying to lead.

text: Can companies excel without making workers miserable?

text: In “No Foul Mouths on This Field: Football With a New Age Twist,” Ken Belson writes about a different approach to coaching on the Seattle Seahawks.

headline: Headphones’ Emergence in Tennis Puts Some in a Zone, and Others on Edge
text: When Serena Williams takes court at the U.S. Open with the weight of history on her shoulders, there is also a half-pound of shiny product placement around her neck.

headline: Idris Elba’s Toughest Role Yet: Going Brutal With Grace for ‘Beasts of No Nation’
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Neil Cross, creator of the hit BBC show “Luther,” starring Idris Elba, says a discomfiting thing happens whenever he socializes with his leading man.

headline: When Wine Tasting Becomes a Party
text: About once a month since the Napa Valley Wine Train began chugging through California’s wine country in 1989, the sound of clinking stemware has been accompanied by the spectacle of passengers being removed from the train.

headline: A Door-to-Door Push to Get Parents Involved at Struggling Schools
text: At Public School 298 in Brooklyn, where the principal invites parents to visit classrooms once a month, typically fewer than 10 percent of them will.

headline: Donald Trump Likens His Schooling to Military Service in Book
text: Donald J. Trump, who received draft deferments through much of the Vietnam War, told the author of a coming biography that he nevertheless “always felt that I was in the military” because of his education at a military-themed boarding school.

headline: The Stylish Men of Tumblr
text: Worker bees buzz through Tumblr’s headquarters in the Flatiron district of Manhattan. With so many young employees, who move between glass-walled conference rooms and a rooftop patio, the place is vibrant. Founded by David Karp in 2007 as a medium for short-form blogs and acquired by Yahoo for $1.1 billion in 2013, Tumblr has hosted more than 115 billion posts. Its users, nearly half of whom are ages 13 to 34, according to the company, add 85 million more each day. People use their Tumblrs for all sorts of things, from old-fashioned cat appreciation to sad-kid blogging, but fashion is the platform’s largest area of interest. We visited Tumblr recently in search of tech chic.

headline: Camp for Migrants in Hungary
text: Several hundred people, including children, spent the night in tents at a reception center in an open field in Roszke, Hungary, after crossing into the country from Serbia.

headline: Scott Shane’s ‘Objective Troy’
text: Some of the most difficult political, legal and moral issues in counterterrorism involve the use by the United States of unmanned aerial vehicles, commonly known as drones, to kill suspected terrorists in faraway places. These issues arose in especially salient and acute form regarding Anwar al-Awlaki, who became the first American citizen since at least the Civil War to be hunted down and intentionally killed overseas by his own government without his case’s ever being considered in a court. At the time he died in September 2011, Awlaki was probably the most prominent jihadi terrorist in the world apart from Osama bin Laden. The president who announced that death, Barack Obama, has become identified with drone strikes since they are the principal tool his administration has used to fight international terrorists. Scott Shane’s “Objective Troy” (the title refers to the military’s code name for Awlaki) is a lucid and richly informed account of how these two men came to occupy their respective places in the history of the drone age.

headline: Lauren Groff’s ‘Fates and Furies’
text: There’s always the danger, with novels structured around a marriage, that they’ll be perceived as centrally concerned not only with that particular relationship but with the nature of marriage itself. A domestic union set prominently in a work of fiction has the sometimes unfortunate capacity to obscure whatever else is going on. Yet “Fates and Furies,” Lauren Groff’s remarkable new novel, explodes and rages past any such preconceptions, insisting that the examination of a long-term relationship can be a perfect vehicle for exploring no less than the nature of existence — the domestic a doorway to the philosophical.

headline: Hotel and Resort News: Music in Paris, Coffee Lessons in Orlando
text: Our morning travel news digest, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

headline: Odds Are, Your Sport-Playing Child Isn’t Going Pro. Now What?
text: Parents investing large amounts of time and money in their athletic offspring with the belief that they’re nurturing a possible professional player should take note: Odds are, you’re wrong.

headline: China’s Export Data Points to a Deepening Industrial Downturn
text: HONG KONG — China’s industrial slowdown is showing signs of worsening, as the country’s trade slump deepened further in August in the face of weaker demand from overseas buyers.

headline: New York Today: Lights, Camera, Colbert
text: Updated 7:51 a.m.

headline: Yanis Varoufakis: How Europe Crushed Greece
text: ATHENS — Since the beginning of Greece’s financial crisis in 2010, two prime ministers have been swept from office after they were forced to adopt an unfeasible package of austerity measures in exchange for a bailout from the troika, as the eurozone authorities — the European Commission, the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund — are known. It pains me to watch the same fate befall a third prime minister, my friend and comrade Alexis Tsipras.

headline: ScienceTake | The Hummingbird’s Tongue
text: Drinking nectar requires a tongue that fits the flower and works like a pump.

headline: The Hummingbird’s Tongue: How It Works
text: Hummingbirds are great subjects for evolutionary biologists because they are so extreme. They live at a fast pace, wings a blur, tongue darting in and out of flowers at a frenetic pace, often 15 or 20 times a second.

headline: As European Migrant Crisis Grows, U.S. Considers Taking In More Syrians
text: WASHINGTON — Facing mounting pressure to respond more aggressively to the migrant crisis unfolding across Europe, the White House on Tuesday said it was re-examining whether it should increase its assistance, including resettling more Syrians in the United States.

headline: Morning Agenda: More Signs of a Sharper Slowdown in China
text: MORE SIGNS OF A SHARPER SLOWDOWN IN CHINA | Once the world’s workshop, China’s exports are facing their most protracted declines since the global financial crisis, Neil Gough writes in The New York Times. China’s trade slump deepened in August — an indication of a sharper industrial slowdown at home and weaker demand from overseas. Exports fell 5.5 percent in August and 1.4 percent in dollar terms in the first eight months of the year.

headline: Britain Won’t ‘Hesitate’ on Drone Strikes in Syria
text: LONDON — Brushing aside objections to its lethal drone strike last month in Syria, the British government said on Tuesday that it would not hesitate to carry out similar attacks against militants suspected of plotting assaults against Britain and its allies.

headline: Today in Politics: Summer Lull Ends as Old Fights Greet Congress and Campaigns
text: Good Tuesday morning. Lawmakers return from their breaks well rested and ready to pick up the gauntlets from where they had dropped them. With Labor Day behind them, Congress and the presidential candidates have a chance to reassess their battle plans and to gird for the next stage of the fight.

headline: What Is the Point of College?
text: I gave my first university lecture in philosophy at the University of Ghana, Legon, when I was a freshly credentialed 21-year-old. My audience was a couple of hundred students gathered in a vast hall, with ceiling fans to move the hot and humid air. Above the murmur of the fans and the muttering of students, I tried to explain why Descartes thought the mere possibility that there was an Evil Demon deceiving their senses meant they couldn’t know for sure that I was really there. Ah, Cartesian skepticism! I remember diagraming the structure of the argument in huge chalk letters on an enormous blackboard.

headline: Is College Tuition Really Too High?
text: To understand the feeling of crisis that many see in higher education right now, it’s useful to start with some figures from 40 years ago. In 1974, the median American family earned just under $13,000 a year. A new home could be had for $36,000, an average new car for $4,400. Attending a four-year private college cost around $2,000 a year: affordable, with some scrimping, to even median earners. As for public university, it was a bargain at $510 a year. To put these figures in current dollars, we’re talking about median family income of $62,000, a house for $174,000 and a sticker price of $21,300 for the car, $10,300 for the private university and $2,500 for the public one.

headline: Why There’s Disagreement Over Screening Every Child for Autism
text: Few would dispute that children who are exhibiting signs or symptoms of autistic spectrum disorder should be referred and tested. It is when we talk about screening every child for autism that the debate becomes heated.

headline: On Europe’s Goth Trail, From the Brontës to Byron
text: Dracula not enough for you? Need more literary scares? Here are some other spots to follow in the footsteps of other Gothic writers.

headline: Where Dracula Was Born, and It’s Not Transylvania
text: From its quay in early summer, Whitby was a sun-scrubbed idyll, fluttering with the trimmings of a typical English seaside holiday. Souvenir shops hawked postcards and sand toys, pub bartenders poured midday pints of beer, and the smell of fish and chips hung on the breeze. Along the shore, a row of rainbow-hued beach huts sheltered swimmers brave enough to take a dip in the North Sea. A group of sunburned schoolchildren raced through cobblestone streets, past antiques shops and tearooms, toward the 199 steps ascending to a cliff. I followed them, listening as their excited chatter gave way to dead silence. “Please, Miss,” a little girl appealed to her teacher in an unnerved tone, “I can’t go up there.”

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Sept. 1-7, 2015

headline: Sotheby’s Auction Coming to an Art App Near You

headline: Turkish Troops Enter Iraq in Pursuit of Kurdish Rebels

headline: In a New Show, Lanvin’s Process Comes Into Focus
text: Alber Elbaz is, perhaps, the least high-tech designer working in fashion today. “You know, I don’t drive, I don’t have computers, I don’t use the Internet,” the 54-year-old Lanvin designer says. “Technology brings everything to us fast, but I find it makes things more flat — you don’t hear the voice, you don’t know the truth.” Because of this, Elbaz says he finds clothes today more “flat” than ever: “hard edges, bright colors, prints — things that look good in the 2D.” But, he emphasizes, fashion is a 3D art: “It’s not only about the front and back. It’s everything in between.”

headline: Eastern Europe’s Compassion Deficit
text: Sofia, Bulgaria — COMMENTING on the flow of migrants making their way through Hungary to Austria and Germany, a Hungarian journalist told me recently: “We don’t have cities anymore. Only an extended railway station.”

headline: Venus vs. Serena Williams: A Long, Uncomfortable Rivalry
text: It is a rivalry that in terms of importance and longevity compares with Chris Evert-Martina Navratilova and Steffi Graf-Monica Seles. Venus and Serena Williams have met 26 times, 13 in Grand Slam events and eight in Grand Slam finals. The 13 Grand Slam meetings are the most of any pair save for Evert and Navratilova, who met 22 times.

headline: 1915: Tsar Stimulates Russians

headline: A New Wave of Migrants Flees Iraq, Yearning for Europe

headline: Will the World Come To Europe?
text: My Sunday column took up the question of the world’s obligations to Syrian refugees, and looked back to an earlier column to question the wisdom of Germany’s present open door policy. Given the demographic pressure facing Europe over the next half-century— the aging of the native population and the rapid population growth to Europe’s southeast and (especially) south — I argued that the continent needs to manage migration policy very carefully, or risk a dramatic escalation of its existing assimilation problem (and the nativist backlash associated with it).

headline: 1940: East End Poor Suffer in Raids
text: LONDON — For nearly ten miles in the East End of London there was a scene of devastation today such as is not often seen in the course of history. It is the result of the hellishness which broke loose yesterday afternoon and last night, when mass formations of Nazi bombers dropped load after load on military objectives in the dock areas and civilian homes alike. For every military objective hit, there are two or three civilian buildings smashed to smithereens. The grim thing about this war is that the poor people are getting the worst of it. For it is the working-class people, living and toiling for a couple of pounds a week, who live in the dock areas behind the factories and warehouses and gas and oil tanks which the Nazis are attempting to destroy. — New York Herald Tribune, September 9, 1940

headline: Kylie Jenner’s Beauty Routine: How She Keeps It Real

headline: Setting Aside Shame and Blame in Financial Decisions
text: I’m a huge advocate of the “no shame, no blame” rule when it comes to money. But I think there’s some confusion about how the rule works. It’s not that you won’t feel guilt. It’s also not about avoiding responsibility. Instead, it’s about recognizing the zero-sum game of relying on shame and blame to make better money decisions.

headline: ‘Black Mass’ Resurrects Boston’s Long Memories of Whitey Bulger
text: Whitey Bulger, the Boston crime boss who is the subject of “Black Mass,” Scott Cooper’s new movie starring Johnny Depp and opening on Sept. 18, is probably the most mythologized gangster since Al Capone. Mr. Cooper, who took over the project from Barry Levinson, said recently that he had been fascinated by the Whitey story for years, and that in 2011, when Mr. Bulger was discovered hiding in Santa Monica, Calif., of all places, it seemed like a filmmaker’s godsend. “I was gobsmacked,” he said. “And to think he had been living just miles from my house.”

headline: Review: Bill Clegg’s ‘Did You Ever Have a Family’ Heaps One Tragedy Upon Another

headline: Review: ‘Welcome to Leith,’ a Documentary About a Town Fighting a Racist Takeover
text: There are a few moments in “Welcome to Leith,” a documentary about a North Dakota town that resists being taken over by white supremacists, when the film might be mistaken for a horror movie about an alien invasion. Only one business operates in this village of 24 residents, mostly farmers and ranchers, in Grant County. Three years ago, a scruffy gray-bearded stranger with beady eyes appeared and began buying properties in the area. When his real estate spree ended, he had accumulated at least a dozen plots of land.

headline: Facts & Figures: Cutting Carbon Could Save Cities Almost $17 Trillion
text: The world’s cities could save nearly $17 trillion between now and 2050 by adopting a variety of carbon-cutting strategies like improving public transit and investing in efficient lighting and heating systems, according to a report by The New Climate Economy.

headline: Inside the Artist Joan Jonas’s SoHo Loft
text: It was in 1974 that Joan Jonas, the American artist who represented the U.S. at the 56th annual Venice Biennale this May with the triumphant multimedia installation “They Come to Us Without a Word,” moved into a vast, light-filled loft on Mercer Street. And for the past 40-something years, it has served the many purposes you might imagine for an artist’s space in SoHo: a home, a studio, a theater stage (Jonas would perform for a room full of friends and artists in the ’70s) — even a film set, on which her dogs have been known to wander randomly and end up as part of the final product. “My dogs are all a bit mystical,” Jonas says about the three she has owned over the course of her career, while her current dog, a dashing white poodle named Ozu, sleeps on a large green pillow nestled in front of a small library reserved for Jonas’s “absolute favorite books.”

headline: Andrew Bolton Chosen to Lead the Met’s Costume Institute
text: After 14 years of overseeing ambitious, crowd-pleasing shows like “Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty” in 2011 and the recent “China: Through the Looking Glass,” which have helped put the Metropolitan Museum of Art at the crossroads of glamour, fashion, scholarship and art, Harold Koda is retiring as curator in charge of the museum’s Costume Institute.
