text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge ruled Wednesday that the House had the right to sue the Obama administration over billions of dollars in health care spending, a decision that poses a new legal threat to the health care law and gave congressional Republicans a victory in their claims of executive overreach by the White House.

headline: Debt Collectors to Pay $61 Million in Consumer Refunds and Amend Their Practices
text: Federal consumer regulators on Wednesday announced an enforcement action against two big debt-buying companies for using deceptive tactics to collect delinquent accounts.

headline: What to Expect Today at Paris Fashion Week
text: Fashion week continues in Paris, where our editors share highlights from the shows.

headline: Looking for Men’s Wear Designers This New York Fashion Week? Come Back in January
text: There will be about 200 designers showing during New York Fashion Week, but some familiar faces will be missing, including Duckie Brown, Michael Bastian and Tim Coppens. Those men's wear designers, among many others, showed their collections in July, at the first New York Fashion Week: Men. (The next one is in January 2016.) Five designers who chose to participate in July reflect on that experience.

headline: Hands-On Experience With Apple’s New Devices
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Just in time for the back-to-school and holiday shopping seasons, Apple on Wednesday announced a series of hardware upgrades for the iPhone, iPad and Apple TV.

headline: Harold Koda on Passing the Torch at the Costume Institute
text: When Harold Koda, 65, retires in January, after 14 years heading the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, he will leave behind a legacy of ambitious and crowd-pleasing shows like “Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty” and the recent “China: Through the Looking Glass,” exhibitions that not only set attendance records but also reflected radical shifts in our understanding of the sociocultural, ethnographic and even anthropological dimensions of fashion and costume.

headline: No Charges for Washington State Officers in Hispanic Man’s Death
text: DENVER — Three officers involved in the February death of a Hispanic man in Pasco, Wash., will not face criminal charges, the Franklin County prosecutor’s office said Wednesday.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Tax Plan Is a Large Tax Cut for the Wealthiest
text: In recent weeks, Donald Trump has torn up the usual Republican script on taxes. He has called for tax cuts for the middle class while complaining of “outrageous” tax breaks for multimillionaires, especially hedge fund managers.

headline: Cuomo Set to Back $15 Minimum Wage Across New York State
text: After devising a way to raise wages for fast-food workers, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is preparing to announce his support for a $15 minimum wage for all workers in New York State.

headline: What Puerto Rico’s New Plan Means
text: Puerto Rico issued a five-year plan on Wednesday to restructure about $47 billion of its $72 billion in bond debt and carry out an economic overhaul under an independent financial control board.

headline: Clothing Retailer Totokaelo Has High Hopes for Manhattan
text: Totokaelo (TOH-toh-KYE-yo, a corruption of the Latin, meaning, more or less, “the sky’s the limit”), all 8,400 square feet of it, is preparing to open its doors on Crosby Street.

headline: ‘The Martian’ Brings a Nerd Thriller Into the Mainstream
text: Andy Weir started writing a book about an astronaut stranded on Mars. He hadn’t had any success with publishers in the past, so he started posting chapters to his website. That was 2011.

headline: Hooray for Hollywood! (No, Really.)
text: The system is broken. High-quality, mid-budget prestige movies are an endangered species. Television is better. Audiences are fleeing. Film is dying. Sequels are ruining everything. These are some of the familiar objections that surface whenever critics, media journalists and other entertainment pundits take stock of the big picture, an appraisal that often turns into agony over the (inevitably worsening) state of the art and industry. What everyone agrees on is that “they” don’t make movies like they used to.

headline: Matt Jacobson, Facebook’s Gatekeeper for Hollywood
text: In 2005, Matt Jacobson was 44 and looking for a new job after leaving Quiksilver, the surf brand. A friend suggested that he meet with an unknown start-up based in Palo Alto, Calif.

headline: New Night Life Spots to Drink After the New York Fashion Shows
text: Whether you spent the summer cliff-diving on the Amalfi Coast or sweltering in the city, September signifies the social season’s return.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening During New York Fashion Week
text: Even if you are not one of the 820 lucky souls who scored the tickets that Riccardo Tisci made available to the general public for Givenchy’s much-anticipated New York Fashion Week debut, you can still visit the luxury Givenchy temple he has opened on Madison Avenue. There you’ll find beautiful objets like a Nightingale top-handle bag in a multicolor carpet print ($2,395) that’s sure to make you stand out from the street-style scrum. At 747 Madison Avenue.

headline: Pennant Races Can’t Match Williams Sisters on TV
text: Tuesday night was packed with three major events for New York-area sports fans: important pennant-race games involving the Mets and the Yankees, and the quarterfinal match between Venus and Serena Williams at the United States Open.

headline: Report Renews Hope and Doubt on Missing Students in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — When the government told Cristina Bustamante that her son had been murdered and incinerated in an enormous pyre, that should have been it, the final chapter in the search for her child and the 42 other college students who vanished last September.

headline: A Fashion Week Debut, With a Little Help From Lady Gaga
text: Growing up in Longview, Tex., in the 1990s, Brandon Maxwell used to go to the local beauty supply store and the Goodwill, buy cheap hair extensions and secondhand dresses with which to style his girlfriends, and then photograph them around town with disposable cameras from CVS.

headline: The Intimate and Infinite Along the 100th Meridian
text: Combining aerial and large-format photography, Andrew Moore aimed to capture the vast landscape of the 100th meridian line, and the stories of families connected to the land.

headline: Mexican TV Network Uses Trump to Hype Soccer Showdown With U.S.
text: Seeking to promote its broadcast of an important soccer match between the United States and Mexico next month, a Mexican television network has remixed Donald J. Trump’s comments about the death of the American dream into a commercial mocking the chances of the United States team.

headline: Why Did So Many Famous Couples Break Up This Summer?
text: Summer lovin’, had me a blast. Or that’s the idea, anyway.

headline: Thabo Sefolosha, Atlanta Hawks Player, Spurns Lenient Plea Bargain
text: Thabo Sefolosha, the basketball player, was offered a lenient plea bargain on Wednesday to resolve criminal charges against him arising from a scuffle with the police in Manhattan: Do a day of community service, stay out of trouble for six months and the charges would be dismissed.

headline: Justice Department Sets Sights on Wall Street Executives
text: WASHINGTON — Stung by years of criticism that it has coddled Wall Street criminals, the Justice Department issued new policies on Wednesday that prioritize the prosecution of individual employees — not just their companies — and put pressure on corporations to turn over evidence against their executives.

headline: President Obama to Greet Pope Francis at Andrews Air Force Base
text: President Obama will take the rare step of heading to Andrews Air Force Base outside of Washington to personally greet Pope Francis when he arrives for a visit on Sept. 22, the White House said on Wednesday.

headline: Lawyer for Ex-Dewey Executive Seeks to Sow Doubt on Evidence Against Him
text: A lawyer for Stephen DiCarmine, the former executive director of the once-prominent law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, told a New York jury on Wednesday not to convict his client based solely on dozens of emails.

headline: André Saraiva Adds Breakfast to His Portfolio
text: André Saraiva, the rakish graffiti artist and international club owner, has historically focused his ambitions at entertaining between dusk and dawn. For his next trick, he’s taking aim at a new frontier: breakfast.

headline: New Justice Dept. Guidelines
text: “One of the most effective ways to combat corporate misconduct is by seeking accountability from the individuals who perpetuated the wrongdoing,” wrote Sally Q. Yates, the deputy attorney general, in the memo on new guidelines.

headline: United Airlines and the Port Authority
text: Reverberations from the traffic jam engineered two years ago by aides of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey have now hit United Airlines. Jeff Smisek, United’s chief executive, and two senior officials resigned this week “in connection with the company’s previously disclosed internal investigation related to the federal investigation associated with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey,” according to the official company statement.

headline: Report Finds Most Nations Hinder Women
text: The United States is one of four countries around the world with no national laws requiring paid parental leave for new mothers.

headline: Maine: Speedy Hiker Will Pay Fine After Champagne Celebration
text: Scott Jurek, the ultramarathon runner who set a speed record this summer for hiking the Appalachian Trail in 46 days, agreed Wednesday to pay a $500 fine for public drinking at the trail’s terminus on Mount Katahdin. In exchange, the state of Maine agreed to drop charges that he was littering when he spilled celebratory Champagne on the mountaintop and that he was traveling with an oversize group. Baxter State Park, the location of Katahdin, has said that so many hikers were breaking the rules, it might move the Appalachian Trail out of the park. That matter, which was not part of the case against Mr. Jurek, remains a question. Walter McKee, Mr. Jurek’s lawyer, said that while Baxter was hoping the charges might limit the number of hikers, “as a result of the attention, there will probably be more people on the trail and in the park.” R. Christopher Almy, who prosecuted the case, said the $500 fine — up from the normal $200 — reflected the seriousness of the charge.

headline: Queen Elizabeth II: Key Moments in Her Reign
text: Key moments highlighted during the reign of Queen Elizabeth II.

headline: Seattle Teachers Go on First Systemwide Strike in 30 Years After Talks Collapse
text: SEATTLE — Elias Lawrence’s first day of kindergarten did not turn out as planned. With teachers walking the picket lines and classes across the city canceled, Elias, 5, instead got a day at a city community center near his home and a brief lesson in labor relations from his father, Noah Lawrence.

headline: A Senseless Delay on the Iran Deal
text: The bruising battle over the Iran nuclear agreement should be over, now that 42 Democratic senators declared their support for the deal and made it clearer than ever that efforts to kill it will fail. But the Republican-led Congress seems determined to drag out the fight, even if it means neglecting other business, including legislation to fund the government.

headline: In Making ‘Everest,’ Filmmakers Embrace Towering Ambitions

headline: Toyota Fashions a Bolder Image for the Practical Prius

headline: Saudi Diplomat in India Is Accused of Rape
text: NEW DELHI — The Indian police are investigating allegations that a Saudi diplomat imprisoned and repeatedly raped two Nepali maids who worked in his home. The Saudi Embassy has denied the allegations.

headline: The Rail Executive United Airlines Tapped to Lift Its Fortunes

headline: Stanton R. Cook, a Chief of the Tribune Company, Dies at 90
text: Stanton R. Cook, who as chief executive of the Tribune Company in the 1970s and ’80s transformed it from a privately held, conservative family enterprise into a publicly traded, more centrist media empire, died on Sept. 3 at his home in Kenilworth, Ill., near Chicago. He was 90.

headline: Kerry Favors an American Commitment to Bringing in More Refugees
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry told lawmakers in a closed-door session on Wednesday that he favored significantly increasing the number of refugees the United States is willing to accept, possibly to as many as 100,000 next year, according to congressional staff members and Obama administration officials.

headline: James Blake, Retired Tennis Pro, Says Police Pushed Him Down; Inquiry Is Opened
text: The New York Police Department is investigating an episode in which James Blake, a retired top-10 professional tennis player, said he was pushed to the ground outside his hotel by a police officer on Wednesday and handcuffed by several officers who had mistaken him for a suspect in a fraudulent credit card operation.

headline: Dennis Greene, a Singer With Sha Na Na, Dies at 66

headline: Minneapolis Fighting Terror Recruitment
text: MINNEAPOLIS —  This city’s struggle with terrorism recruitment showed itself on two fronts Wednesday. In the morning, a Somali-American teenager admitted in court here that he had tried to flee the country and join the Islamic State. Hours later, federal prosecutors and some leaders among the region’s large Somali population announced about $1 million in funding for programs meant to combat just that type of radicalization.

headline: New York City Health Board Repeals Rule on Consent Forms for Circumcision Ritual
text: The New York City Board of Health voted on Wednesday to ease regulations on a controversial circumcision ritual practiced in the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community, fulfilling a priority of Mayor Bill de Blasio.

headline: California Democrats Drop Plan for 50 Percent Oil Cut
text: LOS ANGELES — In a major setback for environmental advocates in California, Gov. Jerry Brown and Senate Democrats abandoned a 50 percent cut in petroleum use by 2030 that was a centerpiece of emissions legislation, blaming an intense campaign against the mandate by the oil industry.

headline: Auto Safety Agency Sets Date for Update on Airbag Recall
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration will hold a public meeting on Oct. 22 to provide updates on the latest progress, or lack thereof, in the sweeping recall of defective Takata airbags. The airbags, linked to at least eight deaths and scores of injuries, contain faulty inflaters that can explode and spray metal into the cabin of a vehicle. Last week, the safety agency said the recall affected 23.4 million inflaters in 19.2 million vehicles. So far, only 4.4 million of those inflaters have been replaced. In a statement on Wednesday, the agency’s administrator, Mark R. Rosekind, said the meeting would be “an opportunity to provide the information we’ve gathered since launching the coordinated remedy proceeding in May.”

headline: Senate Republicans Balk at Iran Deal
text: As President Obama will, in all likelihood, obtain the votes needed to avoid a veto, Republican senators continued to frame the deal as dangerous and destabilizing.

headline: Review: ‘The Legend of Georgia McBride,’ From Elvis Impersonator to Drag Queen
text: A young Elvis impersonator barely eking out a living finds an unlikely path to prosperity in “The Legend of Georgia McBride,” a stitch-in-your-side funny, if improbable, new comedy by Matthew Lopez that opened on Wednesday at the Lucille Lortel Theater. The salvation of Casey, the play’s beleaguered hero, portrayed with winning boyish (and girlish) charm by Dave Thomas Brown, turns out to be equipment already in his proverbial toolbox: sequins, makeup and a highly developed skill in lip-syncing.

headline: BMI to Announce It Surpassed $1 Billion in Revenue

headline: Blab
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — It will surprise absolutely no one who has been reading this blog for more than a month that I had an extremely slow start on this one. If I find myself glaring menacingly at the grid with very little filled in even after gaining a toehold, I automatically assume that the theme has a rebus element. Then I go about looking for places to squeeze letters into individual squares.

headline: Gabrielle Burton, Feminist Novelist and Screenwriter, Dies at 76
text: Gabrielle Burton, a feminist novelist, memoirist and screenwriter who considered conventional marriage lopsided but identified with the pioneering Donner Party wife who perished protecting her husband, died on Sept. 3 at her home in Venice, Calif. She was 76.

headline: New Jersey Man Pleads Guilty to Pledging to Join ISIS
text: A 21-year-old New Jersey man pleaded guilty in federal court on Wednesday to planning to travel abroad with other men from New York and New Jersey to join the Islamic State.

headline: Putin and Pope May Hold Talks at United Nations
text: UNITED NATIONS — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia could have an audience with Pope Francis on the sidelines of the development summit meeting here this month — but only, the Vatican envoy to the United Nations said Wednesday, if Mr. Putin gets here in time.

text: Richard Gasquet, ragged and panting, sweat cascading down his face, reached out and barely got his racket to the ball. It seemed to take every bit of energy he had just to do that.

Shortly after the accident, he turned away team officials who arrived at his hospital in Florida. The Giants later withdrew a $60 million contract offer.

A lawyer and a former member of the Marine Corps, Alderson flashed a rare wide smile Wednesday afternoon before the Mets completed their sweep of the Nationals with a 5-3 win.

headline: Irving Harper, Creator of the Marshmallow Sofa, Dies at 99
text: Irving Harper, who pioneered Pop Art furniture design with whimsical mid-20th-century modernist classics like the marshmallow sofa, the ball clock and the sunburst clock, died on Aug. 4 at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 99.

headline: What’s On TV Thursday
text: 12:45 P.M. (Sundance) AMERICAN BEAUTY (1999) Lester Burnham (Kevin Spacey, above), a middle-age suburbanite, trades in his bourgeois trappings for a red Pontiac Firebird and a job at a fast-food restaurant after going wild for his teenage daughter’s cheerleader friend (Mena Suvari) and discovering that his wife (Annette Bening) has been unfaithful. “As these characters struggle viciously — and hilariously — to escape the middle-class doldrums, the film also evinces a real and ever more stirring compassion,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times about Sam Mendes’s Oscar winner for best picture, director, actor (for Mr. Spacey), screenplay (Alan Ball) and cinematography (Conrad L. Hall). “As it detects increasingly vital signs of life behind the absurd surfaces that Mr. Mendes presents so beautifully, the film takes on a gravity to match its evil zest. There’s a haunting power to Lester’s last narrative note to the viewer: that if you don’t share the film’s piercing vision of what really matters, someday you will.”

text: Looks from Ms. Comey’s spring 2016 presentation.

Perhaps that’s why a visit to North Dakota in 2005, and an encounter with the arid, expansive and mostly desolate lands of the 100th meridian, appealed to him as it had homesteaders in years past.

headline: The Quieter Gun Death Toll
text: The grisly carnage from mass shootings regularly attracts the nation’s focus as a public safety issue, if only fleetingly. But the highest death toll from guns by far continues to be the far less noticed wave of suicides — nearly 20,000 a year — by Americans whose easy access to guns presents an irresistible temptation in a critical moment of despair.

headline: Compassion for Refugees Isn’t Enough
text: Bravo to Pope Francis, Angela Merkel and so many ordinary Germans and Austrians who have welcomed refugees into their lands. Kudos to those American politicians acknowledging that we should accept more Syrian refugees — the U.S. has admitted only 1,500 since the war started four years ago, which is pathetic.

headline: Hillary Is Hobbling, for Now
text: I must say that I’m starting to feel bad for Hillary Clinton. There is a sense surrounding her candidacy of building doom and imminent disaster.

headline: A Presidential Primary Cheat Sheet
text: The presidential campaign is getting serious, people. Just four months to the Iowa caucuses! You’re supposed to be concerned citizens, and your friends are going to expect you to update them regularly. If you can’t, be prepared to take an active part in discussions about the Tom Brady divorce rumors.

headline: A Smarter Way to Raise Paychecks
text: LOCAL and state minimum-wage increases are in style this season, with cities nationwide moving toward a $15-an-hour floor. But simply mandating that employers pay more is a clumsy and potentially counterproductive way to help the poor. Although some workers gain, others lose out on jobs altogether, while consumers — many poor themselves — face higher prices.

text: In “The Hummingbird’s Tongue: How It Works,” James Gorman reports on new research about how hummingbirds drink nectar.

headline: The Target Neighborhood: Hamilton Heights
text: Many years ago, Janet Aschkenasy’s grandfather bought the five-story townhouse near Gramercy Park that housed his dental practice. He later moved his practice to the 1963 white brick co-op building diagonally across the street.

headline: ‘My Father’s Last Romance’: Readers (and Arlene Herself) Respond
text: Last Sunday’s Modern Love column elicited a wide range of opinions on elderly love and Arlene’s decision not to live with the author’s father. Most notably, we heard from Arlene herself.

headline: Europeans Seek to Use Force Against Smugglers at Sea
text: UNITED NATIONS — European countries are pushing for a United Nations Security Council resolution to allow their military forces to apprehend human-smuggling vessels in the international waters of the Mediterranean Sea, diplomats here said.

headline: Notre Dame President Stands Firm Amid Shifts in College Athletics
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — Now is a good time to take a reflective walk with the president of the University of Notre Dame, through the woods behind his office in a golden-domed building, beside two lakes named after saints. A good time, and a serene setting, to ponder a sacred matter of profound moral implications: college athletics.

headline: Review: Mike Kelley Uncorks Superman’s Kandor City in a Bottle
text: During his last decade, Mike Kelley (1954-2012), one of the most influential artists of his generation, devoted an extraordinary amount of time and effort to a theme from Superman comics: the city of Kandor, capital of Superman’s home planet, Krypton. Before Krypton was destroyed by a chain reaction in its radioactive core, the space archvillain Brainiac shrank Kandor and put it and its live inhabitants into a bottle. Years later, the grown-up Superman wrested the bottled city away from Brainiac. Unable to restore Kandor to its original size, he kept it in his Arctic Fortress of Solitude, along with all his other memorabilia.

headline: Afghans See American General as Crucial to Country’s Defense
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Gen. John F. Campbell holds several titles: top NATO commander in Afghanistan, commander of the Resolute Support Mission coalition, commander of United States Forces-Afghanistan.

headline: Homo Naledi, New Species in Human Lineage, Is Found in South African Cave
text: Acting on a tip from spelunkers two years ago, scientists in South Africa discovered what the cavers had only dimly glimpsed through a crack in a limestone wall deep in the Rising Star Cave: lots and lots of old bones.

headline: What Does it Mean to Be ‘a Real Man’?
text: Do you think American men — and maybe men elsewhere in the world — are confused about what it means to be a man? A professor at Stony Brook University does, and he has founded a Center for the Study of Men and Masculinities to study the problem.

headline: Minotaur in His Maze
text: No one, observing MacDonald ­Harris, would have taken him for a literary genius. He did not dress head to toe in black. He never posed for a photograph in a wrestling singlet, in Zen robes or atop a granite outcrop whose austere majesty was echoed by his windswept quiff. By September 1985, when I became his student and his friend, there was no hair at all to invite the wind’s attention. The luster of his pate gave his head the appearance of the polished ball end of some precision-­engineered chrome socket, or an observatory dome. You might have supposed that the mind inside that dome was busy working up new techniques of heat dissipation in airplane engines, but not new plots, new characters. He wore button-down shirts, tucked into jeans that were belted and pressed. His preferred footwear was the kind of tan hybrid of sneaker and Oxford shoe favored by Elderhostelers. Sometimes, it is true, he would wear a floppy-brimmed bucket hat and a funny kind of jacket, vaguely suggestive of an interest in trout fishing or photo safaris. But — as with the high, lustrous cranial dome — if you saw him in his goofy hat and jacket, you would have been less likely to think, “There goes a literary innovator gifted with an original and unfettered artistic imagination” than “There goes a chemical engineer who enjoys cultivating succulents.”

text: Our morning travel news digest, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

headline: Migrants Meet Rain, Resistance and Confusion at Border Crossings
text: BUDAPEST — Rain, misery and more confusion marked the continuing trek of migrants and refugees from Syria and other Middle Eastern nations across Europe on Thursday as thousands endured a drenching downpour, growing opposition in some countries and potential obstacles at various borders.

headline: Today  in Politics: Hunting for Clues in Joe Biden’s Stroll Through Hillary Clinton’s Turf
text: Good Thursday morning. The debate over the Iran nuclear deal in Congress and among the candidates continues to pull focus onto the national stage. But a major character still waits in the wings as speculation will attach itself to his every move until he decides whether to stay out of view or to step into the campaign lights.

headline: Japan Faces Severe Flooding After Heavy Rain in the East
text: TOKYO — Heavy rain from a tropical storm caused severe flooding in eastern Japan on Thursday, and television footage showed rescuers airlifting people who were stranded after river embankments collapsed.

headline: Who’s Responsible for the Refugees?
text: Policy paralysis over the refugee crisis is convulsing Europe: Of course we want to help, but if we’re too generous, more will come.

headline: If You Build It, They Will Come ... Won’t They?
text: When you think of a classic American college campus, you probably envision a set of pastoral images: a demure brick rowhouse crowned with a white steeple, a gargoyle perched on a limestone archway, a domed library on a sunlit grass quadrangle. Often far from cities or shielded from them by gates and walls, campuses exude a sense of refuge. Thomas Jefferson famously wanted the University of Virginia to resemble a kind of ‘‘academical village.’’

headline: Teaching Working Students
text: Students are generally passive when talking about the law, but Ellie, a sophomore at CUNY’s John Jay College of Criminal Justice, leapt into the discussion of the constitutionality of capital punishment in my death-­penalty course. When she eviscerated the Supreme Court ruling upholding Texas’ death penalty law, I knew I had met a special student. On the midterm, she earned the highest grade anyone had ever gotten on the exam. Later, I learned that she had scored 1,480 on her SAT. Ellie wanted to be an attorney; it seemed inevitable that she would end up at an Ivy League law school. She had a prodigious, nimble intellect and, as I saw it, a limitless future.

headline: At Hawaii Resort, Yoga by Day, Party by Night
text: It may have been the most beautiful setting for a yoga class anyone ever imagined, the view out the plate glass window framing a dream-perfect slice of Oahu’s North Shore: elegantly arching palm trees, the fabled surf crashing against the rocky shoreline, a set of wispy clouds floating across an azure sky. The teacher of the class, the impossibly named Noelani Love, strummed a ukulele while the class sang a mantra, eyes closed, and she said we sounded like angels.

headline: On Alaska’s Ferries, Beloved Bars No Longer Make the Trip
text: For decades, the ferries of the Alaska Marine Highway System have been home to some of the most gloriously quirky bars in the 49th state. As the ferries, 11 of them now, make their runs along Alaska’s south central coast, the Aleutian Islands and the Inside Passage of southeast Alaska and British Columbia, they collect all manner of passengers, from fishermen, oil workers, military personnel and adventure travelers to big fans of the ferries’ communal watering holes. The bars came with names like the Pitch & Roll aboard Motor Vessel Tustumena, and some had deliciously divey décor, as on Motor Vessel Columbia: shiny lamé wallpaper, gold Naugahyde booths and dimmer bulbs across the ceiling.

headline: In N.F.L Opener, Tom Brady Gets Another Victory, This One on the Field
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Amid all the accusations, innuendo and speculation about Tom Brady and whether he was part of a supposed scheme to deflate footballs in last year’s A.F.C. championship game, few doubted his throwing skills.

headline: The Return of the Sex Wars
text: Last summer, the Harvard law professor Janet Halley sat down at her dining-room table to look through a set of policies that her university created for handling complaints of sexual assault and harassment. Halley had taught this area for years, and she was interested to see what the university came up with. The new rules were released amid pressure from student-led groups of rape survivors and their advocates, who demanded that schools across the country do more on behalf of victims. Harvard was also responding to years of calls for change by the Obama administration. Just eight months earlier, Valerie Jarrett, a senior presidential adviser, called for a ‘‘more victim-centered’’ campus approach to dealing with the problem of sexual assault.

headline: Donald Trump Finds Defenders and Detractors Among Conservatives
text: It could be the three marriages, but especially the one that ended after he was said to have started romancing his soon-to-be second wife during church.

Consider it the college professor of the clan in a dynasty filled with brain surgeons, diplomats and chief executives. Successful in its own right? Sure. But surrounded by overachieving siblings and a legendary lineage including 250 GTOs and F40s, the spotlight eludes it.

headline: 1940: Churchill Visits East End
text: LONDON — With part of its East End blasted, blackened and leveled by fire and explosions and its West End pock-marked by bombs dropped indiscriminately, far from legitimate objectives, London survived today [Sept. 10] its third night of terror and prepared for another. Thousands of newcomers swelled the tide of the homeless from the working-class district behind St. Paul’s Cathedral, its magnificent dome standing unscathed against a fiery background. Grim-faced firemen turned from their hoses to cheer when they suddenly found Prime Minister Winston Churchill standing beside them on the charred and sodden debris which littered a street near the cathedral in which those British heroes of another day are entombed. — New York Herald Tribune, September 11, 1940

headline: 1965: Fancy Presidential Footwear
text: WASHINGTON — Twelve-inch cowboy boots made of black alligator leather from Brazil! Six rows of gold silk stitching! And on the front of the boots, in red, white and blue, the presidential seal! President Johnson may be clumping around the White House in just such a pair of dazzling boots. He was presented with them by a Texas bootmaker. Quite recently a panty girdle resembling the Stars and Stripes was taken off the market after a protest by the Daughters of the American Revolution. The DAR has not yet been heard from on the boots, but is it proper for the presidential seal to appear on the presidential feet? — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 11, 1965

headline: This Pooch Has a Tony: Annaleigh Ashford on Playing a Poodle in ‘Sylvia’
text: Annaleigh Ashford was walking through Central Park, keeping an eye out for dogs. It was a sunny early evening in August, and the park was bustling, but the busy city dogs didn’t seem to realize there was a celebrity — a role model, even — among them. Ms. Ashford is about to play the title role in “Sylvia,” A. R. Gurney’s play about a Manhattan love triangle (husband, wife and pet), which is finally making it to Broadway, beginning previews on Oct. 2 at the Cort Theater.

headline: In Bed With Bruce Willis (on Broadway)
text: On a recent afternoon, Bruce Willis slipped into a two-bedroom suite on the 11th floor of the Trump International Hotel Central Park, at Columbus Circle. The room was decorated in taupes, grays and sedate purples, so tasteful it nearly came back around to tasteless. Mr. Willis looked pretty tasteful, too, in an off-white shirt, tan corduroy pants and gray sneakers. He had a handsome scruff of salt-and-pepper stubble and a bald head that shone like the dome of some well-tended mosque.

headline: FIFA Official Proposes Reforms to Its Executive Committee
text: Domenico Scala, the independent chairman of FIFA’s audit and compliance committee, on Thursday unveiled an aggressive eight-point overhaul plan that he had presented to the organization’s powerful executive committee. The proposals, he said, offer top FIFA officials a chance to enact meaningful reforms for world soccer’s governing body as it navigates corruption investigations in the United States and Switzerland.

text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats delivered a major victory to President Obama when they blocked a Republican resolution to reject a six-nation nuclear accord with Iran on Thursday, ensuring the landmark deal will take effect without a veto showdown between Congress and the White House.

headline: ‘Never Enough: Donald Trump and the Pursuit of Success,’ by Michael D’Antonio
text: As pure entertainment, the race for the Republican presidential nomination has been a resounding success. Donald Trump, the star, has been by turns witty, provocative, outrageous — and always telegenic. He helped draw an estimated 24 million viewers to the first televised Republican debate, a record, and a ratings bonanza for Fox News, with which he nonetheless publicly feuded. Blithely flouting all conventions of presidential debate and decorum, Trump indulged in the name­-calling, personal attacks and one-liners that have vaulted him to the top of the polls.

headline: Alessandra Ferri to Return as Juliet for One Performance

headline: Mitsuko Uchida Among Winners of Praeamium Imperiale Awards

headline: Moncler’s “Art for Love”

headline: The Pink and the Black
text: In these boom times for biographies written for children, the 20th-century fashion designers Elsa Schiaparelli and Coco Chanel make good subjects: Their lives were filled with drama and intrigue, not to mention stunning visuals. Both worked hard and succeeded against long odds, defying convention on the way to making a real impact on the world. Each honed her craft and rose to prominence in 1920s Paris, but they had little in common, background-wise or personality-wise: The down-to-earth yet flamboyant Schiaparelli came from a cultured, well-off Italian family, the theatrical but restrained Chanel from a dirt-poor French one. The two women developed a tense rivalry, capped off by their choices during World War II, when Schiaparelli did relief work for the French and trained as a Red Cross nurse’s aide, while Chanel became a Nazi agent. So it’s fitting that two new books intended to plant their life stories in the imaginations of a new generation, “Hot Pink: The Life and Fashions of Elsa Schiaparelli” and “Coco and the Little Black Dress,” take completely different approaches.

headline: When Homework Stresses Parents as Well as Students
text: Educators and parents have long been concerned about students stressed by homework loads, but a small research study asked questions recently about homework and anxiety of a different group: parents. The results were unsurprising. While we may have already learned long division and let the Magna Carta fade into memory, parents report that their children’s homework causes family stress and tension — particularly when additional factors surrounding the homework come into play.

headline: Police Officers Charged in Freddie Gray’s Death to Be Tried in Baltimore
text: BALTIMORE — Six police officers charged in the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who sustained a fatal spinal cord injury in police custody, will be tried in Baltimore, a circuit court judge ruled here Thursday, saying defense lawyers had “not met their constitutional burden” for moving the trials to another jurisdiction.

headline: Welcome, Illustrator Allison Steen
text: The Motherlode blog welcomes our new artist-in-residence, the illustrator Allison Steen. Allison is a recent graduate of Pratt Institute and lives in Colorado with her two cats.

headline: British Panel Urges Tate to Return Looted Constable Painting, Again
text: PARIS — For the second time in a year and a half, a British government panel is pressing the Tate Gallery in London to return an oil landscape by John Constable to the heirs of a Jewish aristocrat whose art works were looted by the Germans during World War II from his homes and bank vault in Hungary.

headline: Presidential Race in Taiwan Reflects Women’s Rise in Politics

headline: In Prague, Riding the Wave of a Cocktail Revolution
text: The drink looked like a whiskey sour, topped with a light cloud of foamy egg whites, much like the Boston sour variation of the classic cocktail. But the first sip was much lighter and fruitier than I had expected. Instead of whiskey, the bartender had used Zufanek Hruskovica, a type of pear brandy that had been aged in oak barrels, as well as house-made chocolate bitters. The taste was as acidic and sweet as the classic, but still noticeably different, making it both internationally recognizable and location-specific.

headline: New Seamus Heaney Translation to be Published Next Year

headline: Banksy and the Problem With Sarcastic Art
text: The day Banksy unveiled “Dismaland” — a sprawling exhibition of conceptual art that is itself a concept, with mock security guards and mouse-eared employees instructed to frown instead of smile — its ticketing website was so overwhelmed it crashed. Hours before the opening of the park, which is built on a disused resort in Weston-super-Mare, England, hundreds of people had lined up outside in the rain. “Dismaland” is a heartening display of public interest in conceptual art, even if the concept is “What if Disneyland were as bad as real life?”

A long list of events needs to unfold at Levi’s Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif., before it hosts the big game on Feb. 7: like an entire N.F.L. season, for instance.

headline: Change to Bank Rules Could Spur Political Fight in a Crisis
text: Global bank supervisors are tying themselves in knots over T.L.A.C. This ugly initialism – for total loss-absorbing capacity – is supposed to mean that regulators ensure creditors pay for cross-border bank busts. The emerging rules look likely to be watered down for banks like HSBC, to make sure they aren’t disadvantaged against their less sprawling rivals. But what’s being proposed will make the final system even more prone to political standoffs.

headline: New Data Gives Clearer Picture of Student Debt
text: An air of mystery has long surrounded student debt. We know the total number of borrowers and their combined debt — 40 million people owe $1.2 trillion — but beyond these headline numbers, the data has been frustratingly thin. Who borrows? Who defaults? Why are so many borrowers in distress? The answers have been unclear, leaving analysts and policy makers to prescribe remedies without an accurate diagnosis of the disease.

text: General Electric has already been moving to shed its huge lending arm. Now the industrial conglomerate is potentially becoming even smaller.

headline: Northern Ireland Faces Crisis as Unionist First Minister Resigns
text: DUBLIN — The fractious power-sharing provincial government in Northern Ireland came perilously close to collapse on Thursday as Peter Robinson, leader of the majority party, followed through on his threat to resign as first minister. It was the latest chapter in a political crisis prompted by police claims that the Irish Republican Army is still active a decade after it said it had disbanded.

headline: India Seeks Saudi Cooperation to Investigate Rape Allegations Against Envoy
text: NEW DELHI — The Indian government summoned the Saudi ambassador on Thursday to convey a police request for his embassy’s cooperation in an investigation of allegations that two Nepali women were repeatedly raped and confined by a Saudi diplomat in the city of Gurgaon, a suburb of Delhi.

headline: Rain Postpones U.S. Open Women’s Semifinals
text: With the forecast calling for persistent rain, United States Open organizers postponed Thursday evening’s women’s singles semifinals until Friday morning, with play scheduled to begin at 11 a.m.

headline: Teaching ‘Mockingbird,’ ‘Watchman’ and Harper Lee With The New York Times
text: Updated | Feb., 2016

headline: Jeb Bush Boasts of Florida House Speakers’ Backing Him — Except for Marco Rubio
text: Jeb Bush has a message for Marco Rubio: Your former colleagues like me better.

headline: A Pregnancy Souvenir: Cells That Are Not Your Own
text: Recently, a team of pathologists at Leiden University Medical Center in the Netherlands carried out an experiment that might seem doomed to failure.

headline: Breaking Good News Can Be as Hard as Breaking Bad
text: I was standing at a counter on the medical ward, having my afternoon coffee, when one of the residents threw her hands up in the air.

headline: Brother Vellies: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The latest from Aurora James’s sustainable shoe label.

headline: The Surf Is Always Up at This NoLIta Boutique
text: The arrival of cooler weather doesn’t mean that summer has to end. Warm, a boutique in NoLIta that caters to men and women, has a beachy feel all year. An alcove near the entrance is where the shop’s owners, the husband-and-wife team Rob Magnotta and Winnie Beattie, stock their men’s wear from obscure Japanese and French labels, not to mention their men’s wares, like candles in tin cups and knives handmade from reclaimed disk plows. While the couple redesigns Warm’s interior for each season, certain staples, like flip-flops and swim trunks, are available year-round. Stepping into the store, you feel as if you’ve been transported from New York City to the Venice section of Los Angeles. Here, Mr. Magnotta talks more about Warm.

headline: Answers to Questions About Apple’s New Products
text: We asked readers to send us questions about Apple’s new products on Wednesday when the company unveiled updated iPhones, a bigger iPad, an upgraded Apple TV and accessories. Many readers had queries about the new devices and how they work. Brian X. Chen and J. D. Biersdorfer answered the most frequently asked ones.

headline: Match the Artists with Their Childhood Works: Round Two
text: In the second installment of a series for T, artists pair a piece of their past with the present.

headline: Fashion Week Parties Warm Up
text: In a prelude to New York Fashion Week, Target hosted a party Wednesday that paid homage to vintage Vogue covers as well as high and low fashion. Guests included Emily Ratajkowski, dressed in Balmain and a Target necklace, who said she was not quite a fashion week veteran. “I’m kind of like a sophomore or junior,” she said.

headline: Police Release Sketch of Suspect in Shooting of Cuomo Administration Lawyer
text: New York police officials have released a sketch of a man who they say is being sought for questioning in connection with the shooting of a Cuomo administration lawyer in Brooklyn early on Monday.

headline: As Head-Up Displays Become Common, Distraction Becomes an Issue
text: When Manish Undavia took delivery of the 2016 Audi A7 sedan — list price, about $71,000 — it came with technology rarely found in automobiles, even five years ago: collision avoidance systems, sensors to keep the car from drifting and, perhaps most baffling to Mr. Undavia, a head-up display.

headline: No Surf, but Maybe Dunes in NASA’s Latest Pluto Photos
text: Dunes on Pluto?

headline: On Set | They Made New York
text: As 28 legends of the downtown scene gather for a special portrait, Chuck Close remembers SoHo in the late ’70s and early ’80s.

headline: Bernie Sanders Has a Fan in the James Bond Actor Daniel Craig
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton has been busy rounding up Democratic endorsements, but her chief rival, Senator Bernie Sanders, can now boast a powerful supporter of his own: James Bond.

headline: Why Tennis Transcends Nationalism
text: With the towering exception of Serena Williams, who is on the cusp of completing a calendar grand slam and tying Steffi Graf’s mark of 22 major singles titles, these are pretty lean times for American tennis. Williams is one of just two Americans in the women’s Top 20. John Isner is the only American in the men’s Top 20, and it has been 12 years since an American man won the U.S. Open.

headline: Staying Signed Into Gmail
text: Q. I keep checking the box to stay signed into my Gmail account when I log into the Firefox browser on my Mac, but when I quit the program, the browser never retains the information and I have to keep logging in and typing in the security code that gets texted to my phone. How can I get Firefox to remember me?

headline: Next Steps in Putting Iran Nuclear Deal Into Effect
text: WASHINGTON — With Senate Democrats blocking passage of a resolution disapproving of the Iran nuclear deal, the attention will shift from the halls of Congress to the nations and international agencies that must put the accord into effect. Here’s what happens next.

headline: N.F.L. Week 1 Schedule and Picks
text: Seahawks at Rams

headline: They Made New York
text: On July 14, 2015, T magazine assembled some of the artists, writers, performers, musicians and intellectuals who defined New York’s inimitable and electrifying cultural scene of the late 1970s and early ’80s. There were longtime friends (and some rivals) in the group, but overall, the mood was one of celebration. And why not? Every generation thinks it’s uniquely special, but this generation really is: These are the people who came to, and stayed in, New York when it was at its worst, and in so doing, created what was arguably the most important multidisciplinary artistic movement that the city has ever seen.

headline: Why Can’t We Stop Talking About New York in the Late 1970s?
text: The late 1970s were some of the darkest, bleakest years in New York’s history. So why can’t we stop talking about them?

headline: ‘Longmire,’ Revived on Netflix, Continues Its Embrace of Western Traditions
text: “Longmire” is the third major show Netflix has picked up following its cancellation on television, after “Arrested Development” and “The Killing.” At first glance, it might seem like an odd choice: a popular but old-fashioned crime procedural that was dropped by A&E after three seasons because its audience was north of the 18-to-49 demographic.

headline: Review: Louise Lecavalier Is a Typhoon of Physicality in ‘So Blue’
text: In the first half of “So Blue,” Louise Lecavalier is like a one-woman typhoon, twisting and snapping her slender, androgynous body while contorting wildly to Mercan Dede’s lurching, pulsating beat. Ushering in the fall season at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, this Canadian dancer — best known as a leading member of Édouard Lock’s La La La Human Steps (from 1981 to 1999) — comes out, arms and legs swinging, in loose track pants and a skin-hugging top. Often during this moody, 60-minute work, it seems that Ms. Lecavalier is engaged in battle, but with what is hard to say.

headline: A New Concept Store in SoHo Boasts Basquiat — and Foosball
text: Perched on a second-floor loft on Wooster Street, an ambitious new concept jewelry store brings high-end pieces — the kind you find around 50th Street, where Madison and Park Avenue giants like Tiffany’s reign — to SoHo. And it’s buying into the downtown, stay-awhile vibes of its neighboring shops. A custom-made Douglas Little light fixture hangs above a long dining table, not far from a shearling daybed, a dining room table, a custom foosball table and a kitchen. But the walls are lined with gold, silver and diamonds. “It’s unforced luxury,” says Rob Ronen, a co-owner, about the homey loft. “I want people to be able to come in, and, you know, enjoy a cup of coffee or a glass of Champagne, not necessarily just to buy something. Just to hang out.” But if they are in the market, there’s no shortage of items to choose from: In addition to high-end jewelry and watches (Ronen, alongside the store’s other co-owner, Michael Herman, are authorized dealers for Audemars Piguet and Richard Mille), there are vintage watches, bought at auction houses like Christie’s and Sotheby’s; custom-made furniture by designers such as Prouvé or Charlotte Perriand; and contemporary art, including works by Jean-Michel Basquiat and Andy Warhol.

headline: “The Downtown Decade: NYC 1975 – 1985”
text: A new exhibition celebrates the New York underground’s most interesting 10 years.

headline: Review: ‘A Brilliant Young Mind’ Facing Infinite Obstacles
text: “A Brilliant Young Mind” refuses to soft-pedal the infuriating arrogance and coldness of its protagonist, Nathan Ellis (Asa Butterfield), a British math prodigy with autism. More than most films that address that condition, this one shows the amount of patience, understanding and commitment required from caring parents and friends who deal with someone who, however gifted, may appear selfish and unfeeling.

headline: A Time Capsule From Downtown New York’s Most Interesting Decade
text: As Edmund White notes in T’s Fall Men’s issue, our current culture is fascinated by the late ’70s and early ’80s in New York, a period when the city was veering toward financial ruin and downtown looked like a war zone. “The was a reason there was a bar called Downtown Beirut,” says the curator Lauren Miller Walsh. But downtown New York was where artists, actors, musicians and playwrights could afford to live and work, forming a vibrant artistic community.

headline: Review: Twin Terrors Haunt ‘Goodnight Mommy’
text: Like many foreign movies that venture outside their home countries, “Goodnight Mommy” must live with an English title far inferior to its Austrian original, which literally translates as “I see, I see.” Eyes — and what we think they see — are everything in this carefully controlled creep-out, gazing into mirrors and peering through shutters and tightly wrapped gauze. When it’s over, even those who have guessed its final twist (because we have seen it before) will immediately want to watch again, if only to check the logic of its shifting points of view.

headline: Bratton on Arrest of James Blake
text: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton said he wanted “to extend a personal apology’’ to James Blake, a retired tennis player, after his mistaken arrest on Wednesday.

headline: Review: Annaud’s ‘Wolf Totem,’ Set in Inner Mongolia in the 1960s
text: In “Wolf Totem,” the French director Jean-Jacques Annaud, no stranger to animals (“The Bear”) or turbulent Chinese history (“Seven Years in Tibet”), adapts a novel that grew into a controversial phenomenon in China. The book, written by a Beijing professor, Lu Jiamin, under the pseudonym Jiang Rong, was second in circulation only to Mao’s little red book, according to a 2008 review in The New York Times.

headline: Australia Pulls Out of Soccer Friendlies With U.S. Women’s Team
text: Australia on Thursday pulled out of two exhibition matches that were to be part of the United States women’s national team’s World Cup victory tour, but U.S. Soccer said the games in Detroit and Birmingham, Ala., would go ahead as scheduled with Haiti as a replacement opponent.

headline: Avon Is Said to Be in Talks About Selling a Stake
text: Avon Products is in talks with investment firms about selling a stake in itself, potentially bringing in a partner to help the cosmetics maker turn itself around, a person with direct knowledge of the matter said on Thursday.

headline: Review: ‘Listening,’ a World Where Your Thoughts Are Not Your Own
text: It’s been a while since there has been as loopy a techno-paranoia fable as Khalil Sullins’s “Listening.” This quasi-philosophical treatise on mind control and hard-wired telepathy begins as a fitfully intriguing character study before flying off the rails as a nightmarish vision of government encroachment on free thought.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Sept. 11 to 18, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: White House Wants to Admit More Refugees
text: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, said that President Obama wants the United States “to accept at least 10,000 Syrian refugees in the next fiscal year.”

headline: Fiat Chrysler Recalls Nearly 1.7 Million Ram Pickups
text: Fiat Chrysler is recalling almost 1.7 million Ram pickup trucks over airbag or steering problems, the automaker said on Thursday. Just two months ago, Fiat Chrysler was assessed $105 million in civil penalties to settle regulators’ accusations that it jeopardized public safety by failing to comply with federal laws in 23 other recalls.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
text: Japan and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: September 10, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Japan, Greece, Germany and Afghanistan.

headline: Biden Discusses Minimum Wage in New York
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. applauded Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday for approving plans to raise the minimum wage for fast-food workers to $15 an hour.

headline: A Plan to Save Refugees and Europe’s Open Borders
text: Jean-Claude Juncker, the president of the European Commission and the highest official of the European Union, has laid out a plan to  distribute 160,000 refugees among E.U. members by mandatory quotas. It is a plan Europe simply must adopt if it is to get a handle on the crisis and remain true to its history and values.

headline: Bill de Blasio Opposes a Joe Biden Presidential Bid
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York has held out on endorsing his former boss, Hillary Rodham Clinton, in the presidential race, saying he needs to hear more about her vision for the country.

headline: A Tiki Bar in Queens With an Off-the-Menu Daiquiri
text: At first glance, End of the Century is very much within the Queens Neighborhood Watering Hole genotype. There are exposed brick walls, a red-felt pool table,and a signed photo of the former Mets captain Keith Hernandez with Rodney Dangerfield.

headline: Review: ‘The Moving Creatures,’ Three Tales of Family Ordeals
text: “The Moving Creatures,” written and directed by Caetano Gotardo, is a small-bore examination of three Brazilian families beset by wrenching ordeals.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Sept. 11 to 18, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Sprawling Art Shows in Brooklyn Bridge Park and on Governors Island
text: The work of more than 100 artists will grace two of the city’s waterfront sites this weekend, giving New Yorkers the opportunity to become better photographers, take home pieces and meet their creators.

headline: U.S. Makes Final an Array of Rules on Food Safety
text: Far-reaching food industry rules aimed at reducing food-borne illness in the United States have become final, the federal government announced on Thursday, nearly five years after Congress passed a law requiring an overhaul of the nation’s food safety system.

headline: Palestinians Get Approval to Fly Flag at United Nations
text: UNITED NATIONS — Palestinians overwhelmingly won the right on Thursday to fly their national flag in front of United Nations headquarters, a symbolic step opposed by Israel and the United States.

headline: At Venice Festival, the Wisdom of Lunatics, the Wildness of Age
text: VENICE — There is a character in “Sangue del Mio Sangue” — the Italian director Marco Bellocchio’s strange and wonderful new film — known as Il Pazzo, which translates as the Madman. He’s an unshaven, excitable fellow who wears a mismatched plaid suit, guzzles the aperitif Aperol and spouts barely comprehensible conspiracy theories. If you believe a possibly tongue-in-cheek interpretation Mr. Bellocchio offered at a news conference on Tuesday, he may be the only sane person in the movie. The lunatic-as-truth-teller is a venerable literary conceit (found in “King Lear” and, more locally, in the harlequins and zanni of commedia dell’arte) and also a notion that has a particular relevance to this festival.

headline: Nick Jonas, at Terminal 5, Sings His Hits and Covers, Too
text: Nick Jonas came onstage Wednesday night at Terminal 5 in a conspiratorial crouch, not to look smaller, as if he wanted to hide himself, but to move more slowly, emphasizing the creeping movements of his muscles, as if he were about to pounce.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Salman Rushdie and Bear Grylls
text: Bear Grylls and Salman Rushdie take shelter in an inflatable tent while considering doorstep drugs and a rodent romance.

headline: Donald Trump Denies Attacking Carly Fiorina’s Looks
text: Donald J. Trump said Thursday he was not referring to Carly Fiorina’s looks when he was quoted as saying, “Look at that face” and, “Would anyone vote for that?”

headline: Review: ‘Paul Taylor: Creative Domain’ Shows a Choreographer at Work
text: “Paint doesn’t talk back,” Paul Taylor muses in Kate Geis’s absorbing new documentary, “Paul Taylor: Creative Domain.” But dancers do, and choreographers need dancers. Mr. Taylor seems to have figured out how to make this work: His dancers, as seen here, don’t talk back much, either. They’re too busy working and trying to please him, to give him something more than he asks for.

headline: Review: ‘Negroland,’ by Margo Jefferson, on Growing Up Black and Privileged
text: Margo Jefferson’s memoir, “Negroland,” possesses a refrain, a series of sentences that are repeated, as if out of a Duke Ellington composition, so the author can hang onto them and so can we.

text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Clinton Rips Trump After Fiorina Insult
text: The Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton criticized Donald Trump’s remarks on women on Thursday after he insulted the looks of his Republican rival, Carly Fiorina.

headline: Inside Christian Marclay’s World of Words
text: Entering Christian Marclay’s newest work, “Surround Sounds,” is like walking into a particularly loud comic book. Inside a large, darkened room, cut-out sound effects whizz by on all four walls. Though the room is silent, words like “SHEEEE” and “TIC “crawl across the space. “BAM!” flashes aggressively. “I hope,” Marclay told this T reporter, “that you don’t have epilepsy.”

headline: Review: ‘The Visit’ Is ‘Hansel and Gretel’ With Less Candy and More Camcorders
text: In “The Visit,” an amusingly grim fairy tale, floorboards creak, doors squeak and lights lower and sometimes shriek to black. The story, a “Hansel and Gretel” redo for Generation Selfie, has the virtue of simplicity and familiarity: A young brother and sister travel into the deep, dark woods, but where they once innocently held hands, they’re now holding camcorders to record an adventure quickened by anxious laughs, yelps and screams and one shivery long knife. These children don’t need someone else to immortalize their once-upon-a-time; they just point and shoot.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, Sept. 11 to 18, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: In ‘Meet the Patels,’ a Son Submits to a Marriage Quest
text: “Meet the Patels” is a tidy, easygoing documentary in which peripheral players prove more intriguing than its central focus. That would be Ravi Patel, a successful actor (“Transformers”; the coming TV series “Grandfathered”) in Los Angeles who has separated from his redheaded girlfriend, Audrey, lacking the nerve to tell his Indian-born parents about their relationship.

headline: To Glimpse Pope Francis, Ticket or Patience Is Required
text: When he visits the United States this month for the first time, Pope Francis will meet with the mighty (world leaders, members of Congress, archbishops) and the meek (homeless people, schoolchildren, day laborers).

headline: Review: Come to American Beech for the Sea and Sun, Stay for the Chicken
text: American Beech Restaurant, Bar & Suites has taken over the 19th-century horse stable in Greenport’s Stirling Square that previously housed Main Restaurant and Oyster Bar and, a few years before that, North Fork Oyster Company. The new establishment is light, airy and appealing. The old rustic look, along with the oyster shucker at the front of the restaurant, is history. Now it has a sparkling white bar, dove-gray walls and a floor painted in wide strips of gray and white.

headline: A Venezuelan in Silicon Valley Finds a Niche in Finance
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Jonathan Gheller went from selling tequeños, a Venezuelan fried, cheese-filled appetizer, in Caracas to building a company that he sold to Facebook. Now, working at its placid Menlo Park, Calif., headquarters, he credits mostly one person for his change in fortune.

headline: As a Boom Fades, Brazilians Wonder How It All Went Wrong
text: BRASÍLIA — The president of Brazil should have been ecstatic. She had just won re-election after an intense campaign in which she fiercely defended her role in making Brazil, for a few fleeting years, a rising star on the global stage.

headline: Review: In ‘Home From Home,’ a Blacksmith’s Son Dreams of a Different World
text: Jacob, the blacksmith’s son in the German historical epic “Home From Home,” is the rare reader in his poor village, and a formidable anthropologist. The same tag could be given to Edgar Reitz, the director of this thick slice of life in 1843 Germany and its landmark predecessor, the 50-plus-hour “Heimat” film series.

headline: New Leader for Atlanta Symphony
text: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, which has been led by an interim president since its last one resigned last year in the midst of a two-month lockout during a heated labor dispute, announced Thursday that it had selected a new leader: Jennifer Barlament, currently the general manager of the Cleveland Orchestra.

headline: As Lobsters Dwindle in Long Island Sound, Oysters Thrive
text: To see some of Connecticut’s most industrious food producers, you will need to move beyond its many orchards and cornfields and head past the shore. Beneath the briny waters along the rocky coast and sandy shoals of Long Island Sound, you will find a thriving oyster industry.

headline: Restaurant Review: Fogama in Rye Helps Customer Work Up to Sushi
text: Fried calamari is available just about anywhere in Westchester County, from high-end seafood restaurants to Italian neighborhood joints. But the version at Fogama, a nearly two-year-old “neo-Japanese” spot in Rye, still has the power to surprise.

headline: Searching for the Best Bar Burgers in New Jersey
text: Finding a simple cheeseburger is difficult these days. Gastropubs, for example, take enormous pride in offering fancy burgers with novel-like back stories.

headline: Review: ‘Breathe,’ the Story of a Scary Teenage Romance
text: The scary, spellbinding performance of Lou De Laâge in “Breathe,” the story of a high school friendship that goes bad, is so gripping that Ms. De Laâge’s dangerous mixture of sensuality and bravado brings to mind Angelina Jolie in “Girl, Interrupted” and Jeanne Moreau’s Catherine in “Jules and Jim.” She is the kind of seductive daredevil who challenges admirers to follow her into the fire, no matter what the consequences.

headline: Tome: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Looks from Ryan Lobo and Ramon Martin’s spring 2016 collection.

headline: Review: The Three Sopranos, at the Resonant Bodies Festival
text: For new-music lovers, Wednesday evening’s performance at Merkin Concert Hall outdid any of those old Pavarotti, Domingo and Carreras three-tenor spectacles. Presented by the indispensable Resonant Bodies Festival, here were the Three Experimental Sopranos, given the freedom to program their own 45-minute sets.

headline: Review: A Kingston Painter, Chronicler of the Hudson River School
text: Jervis McEntee’s legacy moment arrives at last, if 125 years after his death. Two exhibitions celebrate this influential and prolific 19th-century painter, best known until now for his personal journals, a treasure trove for scholars studying the early days of what is considered the United States’ first native art movement, the Hudson River School.

headline: Review: ‘The Beauty Inside’ Features 123 Actors for One Leading Man
text: Who plays the leading man in this quirky romance?

headline: Review: In ‘Sleeping With Other People,’ Star-Crossed Sex Addicts Make a Pact
text: Gee, it’s tough for straight women and men to lock lips and fates together on screen. One obvious problem is that virginity, marriage and children are no longer necessarily compulsory, which has complicated the happily-ever-after thing. The writer and director Leslye Headland gets this, but she apparently enjoys a challenge, so she has worked hard to complicate her romantic comedy “Sleeping With Other People,” about a man and a woman who do everything to stay apart even though they and everyone else know they were, sort of, made for each other.

headline: Remembering ‘Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In’
text: 47 YEARS AGO

headline: Meet the Orleys of Orley
text: After impressing critics and industry people, it’s time to start selling clothes.

headline: A Poet Shaped by a Bleak Childhood in Ireland
text: Connie Roberts endured a harsh childhood in Ireland, including an abusive father and a dozen years in a bleak Irish orphanage. Now, in a near-miraculous transformation, she is an adjunct assistant professor at Hofstra University in Hempstead, the mother of an 11-year-old son, and the author of “Little Witness,” a book of poetry published this year by Arlen House, a literary press in Dublin.

headline: In Ridgefield, a Movie Theater With a Lofty Mission
text: When Debbie Kadagian and her parents, Dale and Joan Learn, headed out for a Friday matinee of “Ricki and the Flash” recently, they did so with a simple goal.

headline: Orley, a Tastemakers’ Gem, Looks to Turn Praise Into Sales
text: The Orleys of Orley, a fledgling fashion label, tend to call one another by their full names. “That is a bad habit that we all have,” Matthew said. Even among themselves, they are Matthew Orley, 29, the oldest sibling; his brother Alex Orley, 27, who spearheads design; and Matthew’s wife, Samantha Orley, 30 (nee Florence).

headline: Review: ‘The People Before the Park,’ a Family Clash Rich in New York History
text: Once the exposition has been delivered and the plot is established and the characters are sketched out, a fairly good play emerges in “The People Before the Park.” Still, it takes some time to get there.

headline: Review: ‘90 Minutes in Heaven,’ Then a Long Road Back
text: Caveat emptor: “90 Minutes in Heaven” does not in fact depict a full hour and a half of the afterlife, as the travel-guide-like title might suggest. Rather, Michael Polish’s cinematic homily dwells on the physical and spiritual recovery of a Texas pastor, Don Piper (Hayden Christensen), after he is declared dead in a car crash. It’s based on Mr. Piper’s best-selling book.

headline: A Mash Note to New York at Photoville
text: New York Times photographers will be highlighted in projections at the Photoville festival. Also featured will be work by Eli Reed, Ernesto Bazan, Tanya Habjouqa, Joni Sternbach and others published on Lens.

headline: Review: Picasso, Completely Himself in 3 Dimensions
text: Many exhibitions are good, some are great and a very few are tantamount to works of art in their own right — for their clarity, lyricism and accumulative wisdom.
