text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Sleeping with Other People.”

headline: Fighters in Yemen Agree to Talks With U.N. Mediator
text: UNITED NATIONS — The warring parties in Yemen have agreed to hold direct talks mediated by the United Nations envoy next week, the United Nations announced Thursday.

headline: British Airways Jet That Aborted Takeoff Had Multiple Engine Breaches
text: Federal accident investigators said on Thursday that they found multiple breaches in the engine of a British Airways aircraft that was forced to abort its takeoff on Tuesday at the Las Vegas McCarran International Airport, suggesting the airplane had suffered an uncontained engine failure.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Time Out of Mind’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Time Out of Mind.”

headline: Review: ‘Laugh It Up, Stare It Down,’ on Love and Marriage
text: If an existentialist philosopher ever attempted a light romantic comedy, it might sound a little like “Laugh It Up, Stare It Down,” Alan Hruska’s quaintly absurdist play at the Cherry Lane Theater. An amiable, if surface-skimming approach to love, marriage and all that sort of thing, it follows Joe (Jayce Bartok) and Cleo (Katya Campbell) from first date to probable death after a storm surge threatens to obliterate Rhode Island.

headline: Review: Charles Swedlund’s ‘Buy Photographs’ Highlights His 1970s Work
text: Charles Swedlund’s exhibition of playful images from the early 1970s offers an amusing trip back to a time when conceptually minded photographers were looking for ways beyond the Modernist, black-and-white print. Now 80 and having his first solo exhibition in a New York gallery, Mr. Swedlund is a Chicago native who taught for many years at Southern Illinois University until his retirement in 2000.

headline: Review: ‘Everything, Everyday’ Explores Affinities at Studio Museum in Harlem
text: “Everything, Everyday,” the title of this year’s artist-in-residence show at the Studio Museum in Harlem, catches the assemblage character of much of what three artists made during their stay. Eric Mack has worked out a deft combination of painting and sculpture using swatches of fabric, distressed clothing, rope, clamps, pegboards, packing blankets and paint. The result is a threatening-to-fall-apart choreography of heavy and light. In one piece, “Alldayz,” a big paint-spangled industrial blanket looks pretty enough to curl up in. In another, “Metal (jacket),” a quilted cold-weather coat, has been pierced with holes like wounds.

headline: A Ralph Lauren Workout Shirt, Punky Vans Sneakers And Other Items for the Fall Shopping List
text: An eclectic collection of fall must-haves.

headline: Review: Eduardo Paolozzi’s Sculpture and Prints Visit Brooklyn
text: The gap between art and life might best be summed up as the difference between public sculpture and playground equipment. Despite the seemingly obvious disparities between those objects, the Internet brims with stories of people — primarily children, but adults, too — who have climbed a sculpture and become stuck in it. In the best Pop Art tradition — that is, blurring the boundary between art and life — the three Eduardo Paolozzi sculptures here actually did time as playground equipment.

headline: Joe Biden’s Trip to New York Smacks of Campaign Visit
text: As he contemplates whether to run for president, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is continuing his day job. And along the way, he is offering a peek into the kinds of issues that might animate a White House campaign, many of which have been at the center of his political identity for decades.

headline: Ellen Pao Ends Legal Battle, Citing Personal Resources
text: Ellen Pao, a tech industry executive who brought an unsuccessful discrimination lawsuit against her former employer, the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, said on Thursday that she would not pursue an appeal.

headline: Review: Jeanine Durning’s ‘To Being,’ a Dance Premiere in Queens
text: How will they get themselves out of this? I kept wondering that during Jeanine Durning’s “To Being,” which had its premiere on Wednesday at the Chocolate Factory in Queens, and not because I wanted it to end. This marathon of a dance enmeshes the dancers so wholly in doing, doing, doing that you can’t imagine them being done. It’s like watching people live, right in the thick of passing time.

headline: The Architect Poy Gum Lee Finally Has a Retrospective
text: A few months after his descendants retrieved his archive from storage, the Chinese-American architect Poy Gum Lee is receiving his first retrospective. They have lent stacks of drawings and documents, which had lain largely unknown since his death in 1968, to the Museum of Chinese in America for “Chinese Style: Rediscovering the Architecture of Poy Gum Lee, 1923-1968,” opening on Sept. 24.

headline: Review: A Garden Idyll for Noguchi’s Stones and Steel
text: It’s a great and rare occurrence to see art installed in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Some might argue that this is where you go to look at nature rather than art — although tags and labels on the plants remind you that humans made this garden and bred plenty of the species in it. The Japanese-American artist Isamu Noguchi (1904-1988) is an excellent choice for a show here, since he himself created parks, playgrounds and gardens around the world, drawing heavily from a Japanese art tradition that considered aesthetics in relation to nature.

headline: A Fish Caught by Hemingway Is Being Restored
text: A chipped and scuffed blue marlin hangs in a gallery at the L. C. Bates Museum in Hinckley, Me., above preserved sea creatures arranged in wooden display cases. The marlin’s skin, wrapped around a wooden core, came from a 12-foot-long fish that Ernest Hemingway caught off the Bahamas in the 1930s. This fall visitors to the museum will be able to watch Ronald Harvey of Tuckerbrook Conservation in Lincolnville, Me., repair the deteriorated marlin, which he will access by maneuvering along a platform.

headline: Rudolf Hulka Photos Show Europe and North Africa in the 1920s
text: Five years ago, librarians in Prague started sorting through about 4,400 images that the Czech photographer Rudolf Hulka took in Europe and North Africa, mostly in the 1920s. Two-dozen prints from his negatives, found in storage at the National Library of the Czech Republic, go on view Wednesday in the Harriman Institute Atrium at Columbia University.

headline: Tom Wesselmann Nudes, and the Collection of the ‘Baron of Botox’
text: WESSELMANN’S NUDES UNCOVERED AT SHOW

headline: Series of Highway Shootings Unnerves Phoenix
text: A series of shootings over nearly two weeks along highways in the Phoenix area, most involving the same stretch of Interstate 10, has alarmed residents and confounded the police.

headline: Prosecutor in Dewey Case Appeals to Common Sense
text: For more than two days, lawyers for three former Dewey & LeBoeuf executives on trial for cooking the law firm’s books picked holes in the prosecution’s case by pointing out the unreliability of email evidence and the paucity of accounting experts called to testify during the lengthy trial.

headline: The Dubious Case of Dewey & LeBoeuf
text: The names Enron and WorldCom are synonymous with accounting fraud and an era in which top executives turned to desperate measures to inflate company earnings, mislead investors, prop up share prices and supercharge their already exorbitant compensation.

headline: Cuomo Pivots Again as He Seeks a $15 Minimum Wage
text: With Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at his side, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York presented himself as a champion of the working class on Thursday, pledging to campaign for a statewide minimum wage of $15 an hour.

headline: ‘Mamma Mia!’ Is Closing, and Super Troupers Give Thanks for the Music
text: Sorry, Chiquitita, but after 14 years, the Abba musical is closing on Broadway.

headline: For California, El Niño’s Dark Clouds Could Mean Rain but Also Trouble
text: LOS ANGELES — A soaking El Niño weather system is in the forecast, promising to pummel California with torrents of rain by the end of the year. That would seem like Champagne-popping news as this state suffers through its worst drought in a millennium.

headline: Partisan Tussle Keeps Top U.S. Aid Job Vacant
text: WASHINGTON — As the international community confronts a refugee crisis, the nominee to head the American agency responsible for overseas humanitarian issues is stalled in the Senate, leaving the Obama administration with a critical vacancy as it grapples with how to assist those displaced by conflict in the Middle East and Africa.

headline: House Hearing on Insurers’ Mergers Exposes Health Care Industry Divide
text: WASHINGTON — Doctors, hospitals and health insurance companies clashed Thursday over the merits of mergers planned by four of the five biggest insurers in the United States.

headline: Inquiry’s Trail: From George Washington Bridge to United’s Executive Offices
text: It was a traffic jam that, in the end, rerouted the career of the chief executive of the world’s fourth-largest airline, and how one led to the other is a tale of power, politics and New Jersey wheeling-dealing.

headline: Evans Bank Settles New York ‘Redlining’ Lawsuit
text: Redlining, the practice of denying mortgages to predominantly African-American neighborhoods, was supposed to be a relic of a long-gone era. But a settlement on Thursday between the New York attorney general and a small bank near Buffalo suggests that the practice persists.

headline: Review: Summation Dance’s ‘At the Hour’ Elevates the View From Below
text: At the start of “At the Hour,” the hour appears to be early. Light is slowly dawning. Birds are beginning to chirp. A woman in a loose shift might be doing her morning exercises, bending and twisting with her feet in ballet positions, and if you watch her closely enough, you may soon be surprised to realize that she is not alone. Others have appeared — some on the balconies that run along two sides of the stage area, some directly above your own head.

headline: Duke Energy to Pay Fine Over Power Plant Violations
text: Duke Energy, the nation’s largest electric utility, agreed on Thursday to pay nearly $5.4 million to settle a 15-year legal battle with federal regulators over whether its power plants skirted Clean Air Act regulations in the 1990s.

headline: Four Years After a Fire, a Congregation Returns to Its Synagogue
text: Four years ago, Rabbi Haskel Lookstein gazed with fear and sorrow at the smoke billowing from the roof of the synagogue in Manhattan he had presided over for more than three decades. But instead of lamenting what had been lost in the fire, he recalled, he found himself wondering what the building that would replace the structure would look like.

headline: CNN Sets Lineup for Republican Presidential Debate
text: CNN released on Thursday night the lineup for its Republican presidential debate next week, showing Donald J. Trump once again squarely in the middle of the stage, the spot reserved for the top performer in the polls, with the retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson to his right and Jeb Bush to his left.

headline: In Second Republican Debate, Donald Trump’s Rivals Seek Points, Not Knockout
text: The Republican presidential candidates, increasingly certain that their televised debates can have make-or-break consequences for their campaigns, are preparing aggressive new tactics for their next face-off on Wednesday, hoping to draw voters away from the surprisingly durable Donald J. Trump as the 2016 race enters a more combative phase.

headline: Stan Wawrinka Rises, Challenging Roger Federer’s Swiss Supremacy
text: Famously smooth with a tennis ball in play, Roger Federer likes the rest of his professional life to move along smoothly as well: minimal controversy, minimal complications.

headline: New York City Prosecutor Using Millions Taken From Banks for Rape-Kit Testing
text: The Manhattan district attorney is sending $38 million taken in civil forfeiture from international banks in New York to cities and counties across the country to pay for testing 56,000 rape kits that have been collecting dust in police storage rooms for years.

headline: Joe Biden, in Colbert Interview, Expresses Doubts About Bid for President
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., in an emotional, wide-ranging interview on Stephen Colbert’s “Late Show” on Thursday, expressed doubt about the likelihood that he would run for president, saying that “I’d be lying if I said that I knew I was there.”

headline: Netanyahu Makes Quick Pivot From Loss on Iran Deal
text: JERUSALEM — In the week since it became clear that Congress would not block the Iranian nuclear deal he loathes, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has largely toned down his rhetoric on the issue and pivoted to others.

headline: Merv Adelson, Las Vegas Developer-Turned-Daring TV Producer, Dies at 85
text: Merv Adelson, a real estate and resort developer who pivoted to become one of television’s most successful producers in a roller-coaster life involving the mob, the Teamsters’ pension fund, a marriage to Barbara Walters and a huge fortune made and lost, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 85.

headline: Influential Pro-Israel Group Suffers Stinging Political Defeat
text: WASHINGTON — Officials at the American Israel Public Affairs Committee knew the odds were against them in the fight to block President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran from surviving a congressional vote. But the influential pro-Israel group threw itself into a nearly $30 million advertising and lobbying effort to kill the accord anyway.

headline: Dan Tepfer Plays Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola With Seasoned Elders in Tow
text: After putting the finishing touch on a delicate, rapturous ballad at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Wednesday night, the pianist Dan Tepfer reflected on his present circumstance. He was leading a trio with musicians more than 40 years his senior: the drummer Billy Hart, 74, and the bassist Gary Peacock, 80. Working in such company, “I’m constantly reminded of the amazing people they’ve played with over the years,” Mr. Tepfer said.

headline: Blue Jays’ Swift Rise in the A.L. East Was Built on Patience and Prospects
text: Alex Anthopoulos had been general manager of the Toronto Blue Jays for two seasons when he welcomed a reporter to his office in Dunedin, Fla., in the spring of 2012. The topic was Brandon Morrow, an inconsistent pitcher with alluring potential who had just signed a modest three-year contract. The premise of the story was that the Blue Jays were wise to gamble on such players as a way to compete in the rugged American League East.

headline: A Stolen Car Found, With the Help of Cold War Technology
text: A police car headed the wrong way down Smith Street in Brooklyn, three young officers inside, one of them thumbing through a smartphone and calling out directions.

headline: New York Police Focus on Fraud Involving Credit Cards
text: The undercover investigators arranged to meet at a hotel near Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan around the lunchtime rush on Wednesday. They were looking for men they believed had used stolen credit card information to go on a shopping spree, spending about $18,000 on 16 transactions — mostly on luxury designer shoes.

headline: Review: Richard Maxwell’s ‘Isolde’ Returns With Starry Eyes
text: “Isolde,” which played at the Abrons Arts Center in April 2014, reopened last night at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center, Fort Greene, Brooklyn; 866-811-4111, tfana.org. Here are excerpts from Ben Brantley’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 14; the full text is here.

headline: Review: ‘Empire Travel Agency’ Guides Adventurers on a New York Odyssey
text: Is the 4 train a place of mystery and danger? It feels that way when you are slinking around a subway car, whispering code words in an anxious attempt to locate a shadowy Manitoban. When you have fled kidnappers, buskers and more than one sinister cabal, there is much more to stand clear of than just the closing doors.

headline: Review: ‘Desire,’ Six Plays That Second-Guess Tennessee Williams
text: “Desire” makes for a generic if apt title for a collection of short plays adapted from stories by Tennessee Williams, the playwright who has anatomized that emotion — its pleasures, tortures, dangers — more thoroughly and with more lyric eloquence than any other. This production from the Acting Company, which opened on Thursday at the 59E59 Theaters, directed by Michael Wilson, features works from six notable playwrights, based on tales mostly written by Williams in the 1940s.

headline: Tremble With Indignation
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Crossword puzzle constructors are a competitive lot. You’ve got your faction who are constantly trying to construct a puzzle with the fewest number of words in it. You’ve got your faction of constructors who try to “outstack” each other in terms of having long entries piled on top of each other. And then there is the faction of constructors who try to get lively and unusual entries into their puzzles before anyone else does.

headline: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Scott Walker Over Unions at Event in Wisconsin
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton has picked up a string of early support from labor unions in recent weeks and on Thursday took her pro-union message to Gov. Scott Walker’s backyard.

headline: 3 Men Laundered Over $5 Billion for Drug Cartels, U.S. Says
text: A group of Colombians used the Chinese counterfeit market to launder more than $5 billion for drug traffickers in the United States, Europe and Asia, federal prosecutors said Thursday.

headline: Candida Royalle, 64, Dies; Filmed Erotica for Women
text: Candida Royalle, a former star of pornographic movies who became a self-styled feminist filmmaker spurning what she called a misogynistic “wham, bam, thank you, ma’am” genre to create erotica that would appeal to women, died on Monday at her home in Mattituck, N.Y., on Long Island. She was 64.

headline: Dickie Moore, Child Actor Known for a Screen Kiss, Dies at 89
text: Dick Moore, a public relations executive who was known as Dickie when he was a Hollywood child star, playing the movies’ first talking Oliver Twist and later giving Shirley Temple what was widely publicized as her first on-screen kiss, died on Monday in Connecticut. He was 89.

headline: Eli Manning Said to Be Near Deal With Giants
text: Entering the final year of his contract, Eli Manning on Monday did not rule out continuing the negotiations for a new deal during the regular season. But Manning’s expression seemed to say otherwise, and he meaningfully added, “I’m not a fan of contract negotiations during the season.”

headline: Adam Selman: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The latest collection from Mr. Selman, a designer who has worked on many of Rihanna’s tour costumes.

headline: Yeshiva University President to Step Down in 2018
text: Yeshiva University said on Thursday that its president would leave his post at the end of his current term in 2018, the same day that it announced a deal involving ownership of its prestigious but money-losing medical school.

headline: Girardi Sees Yanks’ Rainout as a Help and a Hindrance
text: If the Yankees had been harboring a great deal of anticipation about their most significant series in three years — a four-game visit from the Toronto Blue Jays with first place at stake — then what’s waiting another 24 hours?

headline: Corrections: September 10, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: The Things They Left Behind
text: Artifacts that remain in a hangar at Kennedy International Airport paint a poignant picture of everyday life at the World Trade Center before Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Support Erodes in National Poll
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s national lead over her rivals for the Democratic nomination has shrunk, and she is in a statistical tie with leading Republicans in head-to-head surveys, a new CNN/ORC poll released Thursday evening showed.

headline: Yoenis Cespedes Launches an Unlikely M.V.P. Candidacy
text: It is hard to say if the deadline trade that sent Yoenis Cespedes from the Detroit Tigers to the Mets has been better for the player or the team. The Mets have built a commanding division lead while perched atop Cespedes’s broad shoulders, and Cespedes, an outfielder from Cuba, has opened the door for a contract extension well into nine figures.

headline: Virginia Sheriff Releases Video of Effort to Subdue Inmate Who Died
text: The sheriff’s office in Fairfax County, Va., released a graphic video on Thursday showing the struggle between officers and a mentally ill woman that preceded her death, and said it was conducting an internal affairs investigation into the episode, in which the officers used a stun gun four times on the woman.

headline: ‘Sleeping With Other People’ (With Movie Trailer): Leslye Headland Narrates a Scene
text: Two people with issues around sex become buddies in Leslye Headland’s romantic comedy “Sleeping With Other People.” This scene features Alison Brie as Lanie, a woman sexually obsessed with Matthew (Adam Scott). They have been having an affair and she spots him running in a park.

headline: Anatomy | ‘Sleeping With Other People’
text: The writer and director Leslye Headland narrates a sequence from her film.

headline: Venezuelan Opposition Leader Leopoldo López Sentenced to Prison Over Protest
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — A judge on Thursday found the Venezuelan opposition politician Leopoldo López guilty of inciting violence and other charges stemming from his leading role in a large antigovernment protest, according to government television reports.

headline: Longer Lunch Periods Mean Fuller Students
text: In schools with short lunch periods, children eat less and discard more than in schools where they are allowed more time to eat, a new study has found.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | witless
text: witless • \ˈwit-ləs\ • adjective

headline: Prison for Man Who Slashed U.S. Ambassador in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean man who attacked the American ambassador to Seoul with a kitchen knife this year was sentenced on Friday to 12 years in prison for attempted murder.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
text: 8 P.M. (Starz) INTO THE WOODS (2014) After being cursed by a witch (Meryl Streep, above, in an Oscar-nominated performance), a baker (James Corden) and his wife (Emily Blunt) find their fates bound to Cinderella (Anna Kendrick), Little Red Riding Hood (Lilla Crawford), Rapunzel (MacKenzie Mauzy) and other fairy tale characters in this Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine musical, directed for the screen by Rob Marshall. This “splendid” Disney adaptation “infuses new vitality into the tired marketing concept of entertainment for ‘children of all ages,’ ” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “That usually translates to mean only children and their doting parents. But with ‘Into the Woods,’ you grow up with the characters, young and old, in a lifelong process of self-discovery.”

headline: Corrections: September 11, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I was standing there doing nothing — not running, not resisting, in fact smiling.”

headline: Mets and Bartolo Colon Wait Out a Rain Delay and Swamp the Braves
text: ATLANTA — Around the time the Mets’ game against the Braves was supposed to begin on Thursday night, thunder clapped from above, and a heavy rain fell. After a while, the outfield looked like a swamp. Water poured down the Mets’ dugout steps like a fountain, creating a small moat that kept the players from peeking outside.

headline: Bon Jovi Adds Taiwan Show After China Cancellations
text: Bon Jovi has been frozen out of China, apparently because of the band’s homage to the Dalai Lama, but its lead singer, Jon Bon Jovi, will still have a few chances to try out the Mandarin-language song he’s been practicing.

headline: Singapore Voters Give Ruling Party a Resounding Victory
text: JAKARTA — Voters in Singapore delivered a resounding mandate on Friday to the governing party, which had been working to overcome its worst showing ever in an election four years ago.

headline: A Mash Note to New York at Photoville
text: Newspaper photographers are somewhat captive to the city where their employers originally set up printing presses. Sure, New York Times staff photographers travel occasionally, and a few of us are stationed overseas or in Washington, but most of us work in New York.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Hungary Today, and in 1956
text: To the Editor:

headline: United Arab Emirates’ Aid to Syrians
text: To the Editor:

headline: Homeless in New York: Ways to Help
text: To the Editor:

headline: Japan’s Economy, Crippled by Caution
text: TOKYO — Visitors to Japan are often surprised by how prosperous it seems. It doesn’t look like a deeply depressed economy. And that’s because it isn’t.

headline: Will We Always Remember 9/11?
text: Soon after the horrific destruction of the World Trade Center towers 14 years ago, bumper stickers abounded in parallel with the nation’s grief. “Never Forget,” one proclaimed with great resolve. “We Will Always Remember,” promised another.

headline: Abortion, a Personal Choice
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Russia I Miss
text: St. Petersburg, Russia — People who came of age after the end of the Cold War may not realize how powerfully Russia influenced Western culture for 150 years. For more than a century, intellectuals, writers, artists and activists were partly defined by the stances they took toward certain things Russian: Did they see the world like Tolstoy or like Dostoyevsky? Were they inspired by Lenin and/or Trotsky? Were they alarmed by Sputnik, awed by Solzhenitsyn or cheering on Yeltsin or Gorbachev?

headline: The House Stretches Legal Logic on Health Reform
text: Once again congressional Republicans are trying to manipulate the courts into overturning health care reforms that they have been unable to block in the normal political process.

headline: How to Cheat on Taxes in China
text: Beijing — WHEN the accountant at one of the companies I work for as a teacher asked me to evade taxes, she posed it as a challenge.

headline: For Students With a Mission, a Little Capital Goes a Long Way
text: Rose Wang wants you to eat bugs. Two billion people in the world already do. Her new company, Six Foods — so named because six legs is better than four — sells Chirps: snack chips made from cricket flour. Insects are an environmentally sustainable source of complete protein: Producing a pound of beef uses 2,000 times the water and creates 100 times the greenhouse gas emissions of producing a pound of cricket meat, and crickets are higher in protein and lower in fat.

headline: Fosun to Raise $1.5 Billion to Finance Acquisitions
text: HONG KONG — Fosun International, the Chinese conglomerate, said on Friday that it planned to raise up to 11.7 billion Hong Kong dollars, or $1.5 billion, by issuing rights shares to pay for deals in the banking and insurance industry.

headline: News Q’s | Homo Naledi, New Human Species, Is Found in South African Cave
text: In “Homo Naledi, New Human Species, Is Found in South African Cave,” John Noble Wilford reports on a previously unidentified species of the early human lineage.

headline: Quota Proposal Fails to Gain Traction as Germany Prepares for More Arrivals
text: BERLIN — Germany on Friday failed to persuade Hungary and three other Central European partners to accept joint European Union action and a quota to distribute migrants from the Middle East.

headline: Telenor and TeliaSonera Call Off Merger of Danish Operations
text: LONDON — The Nordic telecommunications companies Telenor and TeliaSonera said on Friday that they had called off plans to merge their Danish businesses after they were unable to win approval from Europe’s antitrust authorities.

headline: Document Submitted to Hong Kong Police Department
text: A copy of a document purports to show deposits that the Malaysian prime minister, Najib Razak, directed into Swiss bank account.

headline: An Affordable Country House Sampler for New Yorkers
text: Disappointed by what their budget will buy in the city, some New York City renters are heading to second-home markets, from the Catskill Mountains to the Jersey Shore, to live the American dream, if only on the weekends. Here’s a look at what $350,000 or less will buy in second-home markets within a three-hour drive of New York City.

headline: Buying a Second Home First
text: Some New York City renters are skipping the typical first rung on the urban homeownership ladder: Instead of investing in an apartment, they are buying a country house. Disappointed by what their budget will buy in the city, they are still living the American dream of having a place of their own, if only on the weekends, in the Catskills, at the Jersey Shore or in Connecticut.

headline: Sanctions Debate Emerges From Shadow of Iran Nuclear Accord
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, in advance of his victory in Congress on Thursday on the Iran nuclear deal, focused on centrifuge numbers, uranium stockpiles and the breakout time to build a bomb. But now, as the agreement is carried out, he will face a new battle over how stringently to impose economic sanctions on Iran.

headline: When in Rome, Learn to Cook Italian
text: If you go to Rome to dine, you’re getting only a taste of Italian culture. For a full immersion, you’ve got to make some pasta and traditional sauces yourself.

headline: In the Studio | Thom Browne
text: Thom Browne talks with Vanessa Friedman about the virtues of minimalism, the color gray and having his staff members dress as if he’s their father.

headline: In the Studio: Thom Browne
text: In the first episode of Season 3 of our video series that goes inside the private offices and behind the scenes of the working lives of designers, Thom Browne reveals that the extreme aesthetic discipline apparent in his collections extends to his environment, too.

headline: For Jets’ Todd Bowles, a Lifetime of Calmly Facing Challenges
text: The day Todd Bowles was almost attacked while coming home from football practice, he was 8, maybe 9.

headline: What Do You Wish You Could See, Hear, Read or Experience for the First Time All Over Again?
text: What cultural experience — a concert, a movie, a book, a visit to a museum or restaurant, a play or anything else — has been so meaningful to you that you wish you could experience it for the first time all over again?

headline: On the Iran Deal
text: Senate Democrats blocked a Republican resolution to reject the nuclear accord.

headline: Turkey’s Military Rulers
text: GOTHENBURG, Sweden — Many commentators have interpreted the decision of Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, to restart the war against the Kurdistan Workers’ Party, or P.K.K., as designed to undo the results of the June 7 general election. The ruling Justice and Development Party, also known as the A.K.P., was deprived of its majority in Parliament when the pro-Kurdish Peoples’ Democratic Party, or H.D.P., surged at the polls.

headline: Tour News: Rugby in England, Fall Photography in Maine
text: Our morning travel news digest, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

headline: Ask Well: Choosing the Right Grain for Your Morning
text: Question:

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: New York Today: A Day to Remember
text: Updated at 9:17 a.m.

headline: Morning Agenda: Avon in Talks to Sell a Stake
text: AVON IN TALKS TO SELL A STAKE | Avon Products is discussing selling a stake in itself and bringing in a partner to help turn the company around, Michael J. de la Merced reports in DealBook. The cosmetics maker considered bringing in a private equity firm for what is known on Wall Street as a private investment in public equity, or PIPE, — essentially a negotiated stake sale by a publicly traded company. It has also explored other options. Bids are expected within the next few weeks.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Sept. 11
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include an image of the first day of school, the West Indian American Parade in Brooklyn and homelessness in the city.

headline: Japan Flooding Kills 3 and Leads to Release of Tainted Water
text: TOKYO — At least three people were killed in extensive flooding this week in eastern Japan, the authorities said on Friday, with the deluge prompting the release of an unknown amount of contaminated water from a shuttered nuclear power plant. An additional 23 people were still missing, according to the public broadcaster NHK.

headline: ‘Anne of Green Gables’ Was a Terrible Mother
text: She is a terrible mother.

headline: Nuclear Deal Clears Hurdle, but Iranian Reaction Is Muted
text: TEHRAN — Iranians waiting a long time for their country to shed its role as perpetual global outsider greeted the news that a landmark nuclear accord had cleared a crucial hurdle in Washington with a temperate response on Friday.

headline: Today in Politics: Sept. 11 Anniversary Offers a Pause Amid the Clamor
text: Good morning on Friday, Sept. 11, 2015, 14 years later. CNN has released its lineup for the Republican debate next week: Carly Fiorina will be promoted to the prime-time event, and the soft-spoken Ben Carson will share center stage with Donald J. Trump, offering a split-screen study in contrasts of the current Republican front-runners. But that is for next week. On Friday, there will be a relative break from the typical campaign noise as candidates and public officials attend memorials and read the names of the dead.

headline: M.T.A. Chief Presses New York City for Funding After G Train Derails
text: After a subway train derailed in Brooklyn, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Friday issued a scathing statement that sought to call attention to New York City’s reluctance to pay more toward the agency’s capital infrastructure plan.

headline: Teaching Slavery to Reluctant Listeners
text: One thing is certain as I prepare to teach another course on U.S. history. Invariably, at least one student evaluation will complain that ‘‘Professor Baptist only talks about slavery.’’ It’s an annual reminder that while I’ve been trying to teach the history of slavery for two decades in American classrooms, America has tried to evade thinking about that history for far longer. Twenty-­four decades have passed since the Continental Congress deleted Thomas Jefferson’s criticisms of slavery from his first draft of the Declaration of Independence, and college students today arrive knowing little about the way America’s history of slavery has shaped their lives. Avoidance of the topic is deeply ingrained.

headline: The First Day of College
text: It is a late-summer rite: A convoy of shambling family vehicles descends on clean-scrubbed, iron-gated villages whose sole recent inhabitants, it would seem, have been lawn mowers and paintbrushes. The cars have license plates from distant places, clattering bike racks and the occasional cumbersome item (lacrosse stick? longboard?) secured to the roof with straps. Their interior contents are more disorderly still: typically a pair of adults well past the age of footloose road trips and a veteran teenager on the slippery cusp of a new world. The previous few years of test-taking, application-filing and hand-wringing have been aimed at learning the name and address of the site where this rift would occur. In short order the travelers will part ways; it’s a long-awaited, inescapable and horrible fact — and if all goes well, it will be more or less permanent. But fortunately, with so many families going through this drama at once, the ensuing chaos has a way of tempering emotions — at least initially.

headline: Teaching a Different Shakespeare From the One I Love
text: My first encounter with Shakespeare — ‘‘As You Like It,’’ in Miss Gillespie’s eighth-grade English class — left me cold. I still remember the words ‘‘I pray thee, Rosalind, sweet my coz, be merry,’’ which I must have been compelled to recite out loud, with a shudder. But not long afterward, I fell in love with him, not through the charm of performance but through the hallucinatory power of his language.

headline: The 8.30.15 Issue
text: RE: SERENA WILLIAMS

headline: Uber Would Like to Buy Your Robotics Department
text: In the center of the lab, CHIMP stretched out one huge arm, then gracefully unfurled its three metal fingers, as if about to beckon someone. On its head, two rapidly rotating laser scanners enabled it to monitor its surroundings, but the engineers standing nearby were wary nonetheless. If the robot — a five-foot-tall, crimson-colored humanoid machine designed to emulate the complex movements of the human body — moved suddenly and hit one of them accidentally in the chest, it could easily break some ribs. The contraption weighs 407 pounds and is powerful enough to bench-press 150 pounds.

headline: Buzzing About Jim Harbaugh While Cutting Hair in Ann Arbor
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — It could have been any of the thousands of afternoons at Coach and Four Barber Shop over the past 43 years — ever since Jerry Erickson bought this State Street storefront halfway between downtown and what is now the University of Michigan football complex known as Schembechler Hall.

headline: Film Club | ‘Rent-a-Foreigner in China’
text: In this short documentary, housing developers in China hire ordinary foreigners to pose as celebrities, boosting flagging property sales.

headline: Empathy and Angst in a German City Transformed by Refugees
text: ERFURT, Germany — The mood in the school gymnasium was turning. City officials had invited people from the nearby tower blocks, to explain that a group of migrants, mostly Syrians, had been housed in the neighborhood the night before.

text: The Tribute in Light’s twin beams first pierced the sky over Lower Manhattan, six months after the attack.

headline: Tribute in Light Captures Grief and Joy of 9/11 Anniversary
text: What are we to feel?

headline: Bioluminescence in Battery Park
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Simpler, Less Expensive 401(k) Options Emerge for Small Businesses
text: The way Jon Stein sees it, receiving financial advice for retirement should be a fundamental right.

headline: Charlatans, Cranks, and Apparatchiks
text: The Jeb! tax plan confirms, if anyone had doubts, that the takeover of the Republican Party by charlatans and cranks is complete. This is what the supposedly thoughtful, wonkish candidate of the establishment can come up with? And notice that the ludicrous claim that most of the revenue effects of huge tax cuts would be offset by higher growth comes from economists who, like Jeb!, are very much establishment figures – but who evidently find that the partisan requirement that they support voodoo outweighs any fear of damage to their professional reputations.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Erica Jong
text: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from Erica Jong, the writer and feminist icon whose 11th novel, Fear of Dying, is out this week.

headline: Health Savings Accounts Growing, Especially Among the Better Paid
text: THE number of people with health savings accounts has ballooned, but higher-income families are much more likely to fund the accounts, a new analysis found.

headline: Indian Court Convicts 12 in 2006 Bombings of Mumbai Trains
text: NEW DELHI — After a trial lasting more than seven years, aspecial antiterror court in Mumbai convicted 12 men on Friday in connection with near-simultaneous bombings in 2006 on seven commuter trains in the city, an attack that killed more than 180 people and left 800 wounded, a prosecutor said.

headline: Architect’s Dream Home Roils Rowayton, Conn.
text: Last month marked two years since Bruce Beinfield, a 63-year-old architect, bought the property on which he hoped to build a house he had designed for himself. The 0.64-acre tract, in Rowayton, Conn., a coastal section of Norwalk, consisted of a long strip of land, just 50 feet across at its widest point, that extended away from the shore into the middle of a serene tidal estuary called Farm Creek. A modest single-story cottage sat at the tip, a rustic throwback to 1949.

headline: Hobo Chic From the Bindle Bros. of Brooklyn
text: The Bindle Brothers, Josiah and Dusty, have a name that sounds like one of those banjo-plucking decidedly old-timey musical groups. With their suspenders, floppy caps and cotton work clothes, you may imagine them playing a foot-stomping rendition of “Big Rock Candy Mountain.”

headline: Pittsburgh Steelers’ Headsets Malfunction Against New England Patriots
text: The N.F.L. season is only one game old, and already a league eager to move past controversies has its first one. Once again it involves the New England Patriots and strange doings at their stadium.

headline: Poland Versus Greece
text: Yannis Ioannides and Christopher Pissarides, in a new Brookings Paper, talk about the ways lack of structural reform hurts Greek productivity and competitiveness. I have no reason to doubt that there are big things that should change, and that Greece would be much better off if it could somehow break the political barriers to making these changes.

headline: Adam Selman Spring/Summer 2016
text: Scenes from the show.

headline: The Daily Do: Adam Selman
text: At last night’s Adam Selman show, the hair maestro Jimmy Paul added to the youthful, ‘90s vibe of the collection — watercolor florals, oversized Hawaiian shirts, custom Converse sneakers — with two joined ponytails, each fastened with a simple swatch of fabric that matched the models’ clothes. (It is, after all, that back-to-school time of year.)

headline: 1940: Royalty Visits Ruined Homes
text: LONDON — King George VI and Queen Elizabeth took refuge in an air-raid shelter below a police station in a devastated district of South London today [Sept. 11] when Nazi bombers broke through the city’s defenses on another expedition of destruction. The King and Queen had been visiting some of the areas where homes of working people had been blasted by heavy-caliber bombs. The sovereigns went where danger was gravest and suffering most intense. They talked with Air-Raid Precaution workers, demolition squads working on the debris of the latest raid and homeless people trying to salvage their belongings. Wherever they went, they were cheered by their people as their car, preceded only by a police guide car, made its way through shattered streets. The way the people felt about it was summed up by one woman who said to the King and Queen, ‘‘Hitler has to have a bodyguard wherever he goes, but you come down here just like this. God bless you and keep you safe.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, September 12, 1940

headline: What’s on This Week Around the World
text: Rio de Janeiro

headline: Migrants Receive Aid in Brussels Camp
text: A camp beneath skyscrapers in the Belgian capital is run almost entirely by volunteers. Residents have donated tents, food, toys and even electricity.

headline: Readers’ Turn: Return of Robo Restaurant
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Donald Trump Leads in Iowa in New Quinnipiac Poll
text: Republican presidential candidates spent much of the summer canvassing Iowa to court the state’s caucus-goers and, so far, Donald J. Trump and Ben Carson seem to have made the best impressions.

headline: Migrants Scramble for Food in Hungary
text: Hungarian police officers were filmed throwing packs of sandwiches to migrants at a reception center in Roszke. The authorities told Reuters they had started an “emergency inquiry” into the matter.

headline: Tome Spring/Summer 2016
text: Ryan Lobo and Ramon Martin riffed on the nautical, presenting fish bone earrings and gowns with mesh sleeves.

headline: Cloud Gate Dance Theater: A Roving, Bounding Symbol of Taiwan
text: NEW TAIPEI CITY, Taiwan — Most people in Taiwan are probably aware of the island’s pre-eminent performance group, Cloud Gate Dance Theater, even if they have no interest in modern dance.

headline: Baltimore’s Mayor, Stephanie Rawlings-Blake, Won’t Seek Re-election
text: BALTIMORE — Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake, who has come under withering criticism since riots tore through this city in April, announced Friday that she would not seek re-election next year, saying she wanted to focus “on the city’s future, and not my own” as Baltimore prepared for the racially charged trials of six police officers in the death of a 25-year-old black man, Freddie Gray.

headline: White House Holds Moment of Silence
text: The president and first lady held a tribute at the White House on Friday, honoring the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks of 14 years ago.

headline: Inside the List
text: The Plague: Is there any way, at this point, to separate Jonathan Franzen’s work from his polarizing public image? Most readers will recall that Franzen’s fame problem began in 2001, when he openly squirmed after Oprah Winfrey picked his novel “The Corrections” for her book club, then escalated through no real fault of his own when media outlets (including The Times) hailed his 2010 follow-up, “Freedom,” as a masterpiece. Both were best sellers, but they also fostered an enthusiastic backlash among people who objected less to Franzen’s writing than to Franzen himself, as an emblem of literary ambition and elitism. (Laura Miller put her finger on this in a recent essay for The New Yorker’s website: “Franzen’s persona,” she wrote, “has its own audience, one that seems to derive great pleasure from hating it. Although his fiction is the occasion of his fame, it is now no longer necessary to have read any of it to have an opinion about Franzen.”)

headline: From 'No, Thanks!' to Separate Bedrooms, Comments on Remarrying the Ex
text: Readers shared personal stories of rekindling romance with their exes and expressed concern as to whether people really change.

headline: Alaska: Aided by Governor, Medicaid Coverage Grows
text: Alaska expanded federal Medicaid coverage after the state’s highest court on Monday refused an appeal by the State Legislature to halt Gov. Bill Walker’s expansion order. Mr. Walker, an independent, said that the expansion could save the state about $100 million and bring 20,000 or more residents into health care coverage, and that he did not need legislative approval. The Republican-controlled Legislature, in filing a lawsuit and seeking a temporary restraining order, said Mr. Walker had violated the State Constitution’s separation of powers provisions. The expansion will, among other changes, increase federal reimbursement to 100 percent from 50 percent for medically necessary travel for Medicaid-eligible Alaska Natives and American Indians receiving care in Indian Health Service facilities, which is a major medical expense and care concern in rural Alaska. The Alaska Supreme Court upheld a lower court decision, issued last week, not to halt the plan while the Legislature’s lawsuit proceeds.

headline: When Family Members Run Foundations, Scrutiny Never Ends
text: JAY RUDERMAN went to work in his family’s foundation after careers as a lawyer, political lobbyist and captain in the Israel Defense Force. He hadn’t imagined that he would become a professional philanthropist, charged with giving away $8 million to $10 million a year. But he found that he liked the role immensely.

headline: Megan Barry Becomes First Female Mayor of Nashville in Runoff
text: NASHVILLE — Megan Barry, a liberal member of the consolidated city-county council here, was elected mayor Thursday, besting a more conservative opponent in a contest in which bouts of mudslinging threatened to overshadow pressing issues of growth and development in the booming city.

headline: A Lull After Apple‘s Event
text: After the Apple product event on Wednesday, tech news slowed down.

headline: Arizona Official on Freeway Shootings
text: Tim Case, a spokesman for the Arizona Department of Public Safety, discussed the latest in a long string of shootings that have happened on highways in the Phoenix area since Aug. 29.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Brother Vellies
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Lower Blood Pressure Guidelines Could Be ‘Lifesaving,’ Federal Study Says
text: Declaring they had “potentially lifesaving information,” federal health officials said on Friday that they were ending a major study more than a year early because it has already conclusively answered a question cardiologists have puzzled over for decades: How low should blood pressure go?

headline: London Theater Journal: Nowhere Man
text: LONDON — There’s not a lonelier sight in town at the moment than that of the naked man in a naked room on a stage at the Young Vic Theater. The name of this chillingly solitary soul is Willem. And he has just returned to New York from spending time with his family in Amsterdam, an experience that leaves him more than ever with the sense that he belongs nowhere and to no one.

headline: Matt Damon Is Taking Your Questions in Toronto
text: “The Martian,” directed by Ridley Scott and based on the novel by Andy Weir, features Matt Damon as an astronaut stranded on Mars and struggling for survival. While the actor has tackled many leading roles over the years, few have included this much solo screen time.

headline: Donations for Refugees Surging, American Charities Report
text: Leading aid organizations in the United States are reporting a surge in charitable donations for helping refugees in the week since a photograph of a drowned Syrian toddler on a Turkish beach rocketed around social media worldwide.

headline: Ai Weiwei, in London for Exhibition, Softens Tone Toward Beijing
text: LONDON — The dissident artist Ai Weiwei, in London to attend an overseas exhibit for the first time in five years after his travel ban in China was recently lifted, abandoned his usual combative style toward the authorities on Friday in favor of a conciliatory tone.

headline: Ending Marketing Agreements Between Lenders and Brokerages
text: Marketing agreements between mortgage lenders and real estate brokerages have been commonplace for years. But federal regulators are cracking down on some of these arrangements as violations of anti-kickback laws, and two major lenders have taken steps to end the practice.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Oysters, Antibiotics and Older Runners
text: Take the Quiz

headline: The Fashion News to Know Today
text: For a good time, call Hermès

headline: A Quiet End for the U.S. Open’s Beloved Grandstand
text: The Grandstand’s grand finale could not have been more fitting.

headline: Safety Suffers as Stock Options Propel Executive Pay Packages
text: Outsize executive pay packages have frequently been a flash point for stock market investors. Lavish executive compensation at publicly traded companies should be a significant concern for consumers, too.

headline: Subway Station to Open This Weekend, Bringing 7 Line to Far West Side
text: In his final weeks as mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg took a ceremonial ride to a new subway station on the Far West Side of Manhattan. For people who live and work in the neighborhood, the wait has been longer.

headline: Colin Myler, Top Editor, Is Leaving Daily News
text: Colin Myler, the editor in chief of The New York Daily News, is stepping down after less than four years on the job, according to a memo sent to staff members on Friday.

headline: Matthew Levey’s Charter School Quest
text: Late last month, on a warm, luminous morning, Matthew Levey, a 48-year-old former McKinsey consultant, stood on Willoughby Street in Downtown Brooklyn and shook hands with his new charges: 65 kindergartners, a sea of neon sneakers, starched dresses and cotton golf shirts. It was the first day — ever — for the International Charter School of New York. And Mr. Levey, who had spent the last 36 months planning, developing and hiring for his new elementary school, was in high spirits. The kindergartners would be joined a few days later by 70 first graders. Ultimately, plans call for the school to run through fifth grade, educating students in topics that Mr. Levey cares about: how Francis Bacon developed the scientific method, why Aristotle matters and what led to the decline of the Roman Empire.

headline: Paperback Row
text: SOME LUCK, by Jane Smiley. (Anchor, $15.95.) Smiley returns to the familiar terrain of Iowa in this novel, the first in a trilogy. Its multi­generational story of a Midwestern farming family unfolds against the backdrop of American cultural and economic upheaval, spanning the time from before the Depression through the years after World War II.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE GIRL IN THE SPIDER’S WEB, by David Lagercrantz. Translated by George Goulding. (Knopf, $27.95.) This posthumous sequel to Stieg Larsson’s Millennium series brings the beloved antihero Lisbeth Salander back to life, almost.

headline: 1965: Astronauts to Tour Africa
text: WASHINGTON — Gemini-5 astronauts L. Gordon Cooper and Charles Conrad will leave Wednesday [Sept. 15] on a six-nation, 12-day tour through the Near East and Africa, the White House announced yesterday. The trip will mark the first time that any nation of the developing world will have the chance to see in person Americans who have traveled in space. Before the astronauts leave the United States, they will come to Washington on Tuesday for a day of honors which will be highlighted by a meeting with President Johnson. Their tour will take them to Greece, Turkey, Ethiopia, the Malagasy Republic, Kenya and Nigeria. Accompanying them will be their wives; Lt. Col. Cooper’s teen-age daughters; Dr. Charles Berry, who is chief of medical programs at the Manned Space Flight Center in Houston, and Maj. Hugh Robinson, a Negro who serves as one of the White House military aides. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 12, 1965

headline: Turning to Religion in Prison, Brazilian Ends Up on Other Side of the Bars
text: SAPÉ, Brazil — Stories of fervent religious conversions are frequent in Brazilian prisons, where desperation, abuse and visiting teams of evangelical Christians abound.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Fates and Furies’
text: This week, Lauren Groff talks about her new novel, “Fates and Furies”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Scott Shane discusses “Objective Troy”; feedback from listeners; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Fates and Furies’
text: This week, Lauren Groff and Scott Shane.

text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: SoHo Townhouse at $16.3 Million
text: An impeccably refurbished Federal-style SoHo townhouse at 27 Vandam Street, built in 1823 as part of a quaint row of four brick dwellings and later home to the choreographer Paul Taylor, is poised to enter the market at $16.3 million. The 20-foot-wide-by-100-foot-deep property is on a leafy block between Avenue of the Americas and Varick Street in the Charlton-King-Vandam Historic District.

headline: Review: PBS’s ‘Walt Disney’ Explores a Complex Legacy
text: Before his name became synonymous with a staid, whitewashed version of Americana, Walt Disney was considered a boundary pusher, expanding the possibilities and ambitions of his art form. Making your way through the two-part treatment of him on PBS’s “American Experience” on Monday and Tuesday nights, you may find yourself wishing that some boundary pushing had gone into the program.

headline: Exclusive | 27 Vandam Street
text: A luxuriously appointed 1823 Federal-style townhouse is about to enter the market at $16.3 million.

headline: Does Donald Trump Really Need Ideas?
text: Jeb Bush told CNN’s Jake Tapper on Thursday that Donald Trump can’t “insult his way to the presidency” or even the Republican Party’s 2016 nomination. I certainly hope he is right.

headline: ‘Black Man in a White Coat,’ by Damon Tweedy
text: On average, black women can expect to live three years less than white women; the difference between black and white men is nearly five years. These and other racial disparities led Damon Tweedy to announce in his memoir, “Black Man in a White Coat,” what many of us already knew: “Being black can be bad for your health.” This is an inescapable fact, especially when you consider the following people and circumstances surrounding their deaths: Kathryn Johnston, Tarika Wilson, Trayvon Martin, Eric Garner, ­Michael Brown, Tamir Rice, Walter Scott and Freddie Gray. It seems strange that none of them are mentioned in this book.

headline: CG by Chris Gelinas: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The label’s spring 2016 show.

headline: ‘The Marvels,’ by Brian Selznick
text: What’s fiction made of? Do true stories “matter” more than invented ones? These are heady questions for any book to ­tackle, especially one aimed at young readers. But Brian Selznick’s “The ­Marvels” takes them on and, like the best children’s literature, doesn’t shy away from complex answers. The book revels in complication, echoes and mirrorings, and peeling back its layers makes for a rich and surprising reading experience.

headline: Bookshelf: Letting Go
text: New picture books include “Boats for Papa” and “Bug in a Vacuum.”

headline: First Draft Focus:  Remembering  9/11 at the White House
text: The Obamas marked the 14th anniversary of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001 at a White House ceremony on Friday.

headline: Greenwich Village Townhouse Sold for $22.3 Million
text: A vintage four-story Greenwich Village townhouse with a separate studio in the rear has quietly sold for $22,300,000 — the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records — amid speculation that the new owner might be from the upper echelons of Facebook’s past or current corporate offices, even the chief executive and co-founder, Mark Zuckerberg.

headline: ‘Beyond the Pond,’ ‘The Tea Party in the Woods’ and ‘The Little Gardener’
text: On my walk to the studio each morning, I pass a busy playground. Recently I overheard one mother telling another: “Thank God! I found him! He was hiding.” She held the sheepish child firmly by the wrist. I have felt the intense panic of temporarily losing a child, but nonetheless I shot the kid a sympathetic glance. It’s hard to be an explorer these days. Summer camps and preschools tout “exploration” as part of their agenda, as long as you wear a brightly colored uniform T-shirt, never stray out of sight and explore only things that have already been thoroughly explored.

headline: ‘George,’ by Alex Gino
text: Prepare yourself, Alex Gino: You’ll be receiving lots of feedback when readers discover your timely, touching novel.

headline: ‘The Boys Who Challenged Hitler’ and ‘Somewhere There Is Still a Sun’
text: Heroism is not in fashion right now. We prefer our heroes smudged and compromised; it’s more comforting, less demanding. Yet two new nonfiction portraits of young people during World War II remind us that bravery, defiance and generosity of spirit are possible even in the direst circumstances.

headline: Justice Dept. Shift on White-Collar Crime Is Long Overdue
text: It took only 16 years, but the Justice Department’s horribly misguided “Holder Doctrine” has finally been relegated to the dustbin of history where it belongs.

headline: At Toronto Restaurant, Unfussy, but Fish Aplenty
text: This restaurant does one thing exceedingly well: seafood, both finned and shellfish. That may sound like damning with faint praise, but it’s what John Bil envisioned when he opened his fish counter and sit-down restaurant in the scruffy Toronto neighborhood called the Junction in January.

headline: A Borscht for Vegetarians That’s Light and Comforting
text: Nose around for borscht recipes, and you’ll find that most classic hot borschts call for beef stock or a beef or veal shank to simmer along with the vegetables.

headline: ‘Appleblossom the Possum’ and ‘Firefly Hollow’
text: Appleblossom is the smallest of Mama Possum’s babies. She may be little, but by the time she’s just a few months old she must be prepared to face, on her own, the great big world and the many dangers it holds for possums. Appleblossom is timid, but she’s also curious — and skeptical of Mama’s warnings, which is how she becomes interested in a small monster (a human girl) and falls down a chimney into the monster’s house. This is just the beginning of the wild and wholly engaging adventure on which Appleblossom unwittingly sends two of her brothers. It takes them from the safety of their neighborhood all the way to big-city night life. More important, it shines a spotlight on Mama’s teachings about the solitariness of possums.

headline: Friday Night Music: Bob Fosse on Fiscal Policy
text: I know, not night yet in New York, but I’m still traveling — and still making the case for more spending, which Bob Fosse got:

headline: In California, Olive Oil Tourism Is on the Rise
text: Olive oil tourism in California is growing. The state produces 99 percent of the extra-virgin olive oil in the United States and 4 percent globally, according to the California Olive Oil Council, a trade association. Many artisan labels are within a few hours’ drive of San Francisco and have recently opened their estates to the public.

headline: Erica Jong’s ‘Fear of Dying’
text: In Erica Jong’s “Fear of Flying,” published 42 years ago, Isadora Wing invented the notion of “zipless” sex, that is to say, no-strings sex with a near stranger. Thus Jong presented millions of women readers with the possibility of — the great joys of — agency in place of soporific and joyless passivity in life and, of course, sex. Isadora nudges her way onto the sidelines of Jong’s latest novel, not coincidentally titled “Fear of Dying.” On display is the author’s characteristic mix of salty language and broad humor, warmth and truth-telling.

headline: Joe Meno’s ‘Marvel and a Wonder’
text: “Do you ever have a thought you keep to yourself?” Jim asks his grandson, Quentin, as the boy explains that he “can talk to animals and some trees,” and is able to hear things “most other mortals cannot.”

headline: ‘Can I Go Now?’ by Brian Kellow
text: Even the brightest star is occasionally eclipsed by a moon. Sue Mengers was a moon. Photographs from the 1970s show her looming, lipsticked and luminously coifed, at the elbows of the A-list ­movie actors she represented (considering television and theater somewhat lesser forms, for losers): Faye Dunaway or Ryan ­O’Neal or her especial favorite, Barbra Streisand. For a time beaming brighter even than Swifty Lazar, with his bald head, black-rimmed glasses and parties at Spago, Mengers inspired characters in “The Last of Sheila,” the shadowy cult movie with a screenplay by Anthony Perkins and Stephen Sondheim; and very likely also in the novels “Myra Breckinridge,” by her pal Gore Vidal, and “The Love Machine,” by Jacqueline Susann.

headline: ‘The Long Emancipation,’ by Ira Berlin
text: Ira Berlin ranks as one of the greatest living historians of slavery in the United States, in no small part because of his commitment to readers beyond academia. For almost four decades, he has been the moving force behind the Freedmen and Southern Society Project, based at the University of Maryland. He and his colleagues at the project have combed through millions of documents generated by emancipation and Reconstruction. They have found amazing characters, like the newly commissioned, recently liberated black soldiers who sent letters to their former masters, demanding that these white Southerners hand over still-­enslaved family members.

headline: Debut Novels
text: THE MOUNTAIN CAN WAITBy Sarah Leipciger311 pp. Little, Brown, $26.

headline: No Slouch
text: At 80, Joan Didion has never been cooler, which in her case is really saying something. Earlier this year, she was featured in an ad for the luxury fashion brand Céline. The Los Angeles bookstore Book Soup recently floated the idea of putting her image on the $10 bill.

headline: ‘The Making of Home,’ by Judith Flanders
text: There’s no place like home, as Dorothy told Toto somewhere between Oz and Kansas. Home is where the heart is, and that’s where the trouble starts. “Home” is what we think we know best already, wherever and however we live. It’s the most intimate of subjects, involving privacy, comfort, childhood memories, somewhere clean and protected from the street and modern times, a woman’s own place. (Or so men insisted, thoughtfully providing ­labor-saving devices that made housework even more difficult for middle-class women who took on work once done by servants or other women in other houses.)

headline: ‘A Nation of Nations,’ by Tom Gjelten
text: Over the past half-century, immigration to the United States has radically transformed. In his prologue to “A Nation of Nations,” the NPR correspondent Tom Gjelten describes how his 19th-century Norwegian ancestors arrived in America and homesteaded their way across the upper Midwest, striking out into the wilderness. For the first 200 years of the country’s history, most of the foreigners who settled here voluntarily were ­European and white. In 1965, however, legislators rewrote our restrictive immigration laws, and over the past 50 years, the foreign-born population has become far more diverse, with new immigrants hailing from South America, Asia and Africa.

headline: ‘The Last Love Song,’ a Biography of Joan Didion
text: In a spiky little essay on the painter Georgia O’Keeffe, Joan Didion writes ­coded instructions for would-be biographers. “Where I was born and where and how I have lived is unimportant,” she quotes ­O’Keeffe. “It is what I have done with where I have been that should be of interest.” In other words, study the particulars of the paintings, not the particulars of the life. In the next sentence, however, Didion tells the story of her 7-year-old daughter, who, on seeing one of O’Keeffe’s sublime “Sky Above Clouds” paintings in the Art Institute of Chicago, runs toward it and whispers: “Who drew it? . . . I need to talk to her.” The longing to corroborate one’s own feelings with the facts of an artist’s life — the assumption “that the glory she saw in the work reflected a glory in its maker” — is a primal one, Didion suggests. But there is a paradox inherent in the encounter with art: Even as it may touch us acutely, it is essentially mysterious. It carries only a trace of its maker, and this is style. “Style is character,” Didion declares, throwing down the gauntlet: Find me if you can.

headline: ‘The Story of My Teeth,’ by Valeria Luiselli
text: On its not-so-placid surface, Valeria Luiselli’s second novel is the tale of a guy named Gustavo (Highway) Sánchez Sánchez, who auctions off his old teeth, claiming they are from the mouths of Plato, Montaigne, Virginia Woolf and Borges, among others. Then he takes his profits and buys a set of teeth that supposedly belonged to Marilyn Monroe, implanting them in his own mouth. After that, things go well for a while until Highway’s son, Siddhartha, knocks him out and steals Monroe’s teeth, leaving his dad chopperless. Eventually Highway runs into a man named Voragine (an abyss?) who helps him, and who later appears to be the person telling this story. Along the way, the names of Proust, Unamuno, Foucault, Walser, Cortázar and Raymond Roussel burst out of random paragraphs like startled grouse.

headline: ‘The President and the Apprentice: Eisenhower and Nixon, 1952-1961’
text: Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., someone who unquestionably understood charisma, considered Vice President Richard Nixon “one of the most magnetic personalities” he had ever encountered. “When you are close to Nixon,” King observed in 1958, “he almost disarms you with his apparent sincerity.” But King also worried that there might be a hidden duality to Nixon, or worse, a facade. If the vice president was actually insincere, King warned, he could be “the most dangerous man in America.”

headline: On 9/11 Anniversary, a Small and Somber Ritual in Lower Manhattan
text: At 8:48 a.m., 14 years and two minutes after a plane crashed into the north tower of the World Trade Center, the recitation of the names began.

headline: Marc Jacobs Hosted a Heck of a Party Last Night
text: Despite the host Marc Jacobs’s encouragements, not one guest rode astride a white horse to the book party for “Gloss: The Work of Chris von Wangenheim” last night at the resurrected Tunnel nightclub in Chelsea. A galloping equine sculpture instead overlooked the bar, where lemon- and orange-flavored “Marctails” were served to a thirsty throng of black-and-sequined clotheshorses.

headline: What I Learned in the Locker Room
text: BOSTON — TOWARD the end of my sophomore year in college, I secured a summer internship with the sports department of my hometown newspaper, which was located just south of San Francisco.

headline: For New York’s Pools, It’s Not the Heat, It’s the Politics
text: On the day after Labor Day, as so many people uploaded moody pictures of empty meadows and forlorn marine birds, indulging the ritual mourning of summer’s end that social media has amplified, the temperature in Central Park reached 97 degrees. This surpassed a record for the day (set in 1919 when it was 4 degrees cooler), making Sept. 8, 2015, the hottest September day in New York City in 32 years. Among the masses already returned from Nantucket or Vermont or Beach 108th Street, complaint and distress proceeded accordingly.

headline: Winning Her Back, Using a Little Political Clout
text: A former United States senator helps re-form a union after a regrettable split.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Sotheby’s S.E.C. Records Confirm Taubman Sale Guarantee
text: Sotheby’s has confirmed in records with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has guaranteed roughly the full $500 million it expects to take in from its sale of the art collection of A. Alfred Taubman, its former chairman who died in April.

headline: A New York Hotel Inspires a Scarf Design for Rodarte
text: Collaborations between prolific fashion designers and luxury hotels aren’t a novel concept, but the latest such partnership, debuting in time for New York Fashion Week, has a more personal touch.

headline: House Rejects Iran Nuclear Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Following the playbook of their crusade against the Affordable Care Act, congressional Republicans on Friday showed no sign of letting up in their effort to pressure the White House over the Iran nuclear accord, even after the Senate effectively settled the matter and blocked a Republican resolution aimed at stopping the deal.

text: This week’s properties are co-ops in Chelsea and Clinton, and a condo in the Columbia Street Waterfront District, Brooklyn.
