text: Mr. Gordon’s spring 2016 collection.

headline: Remembering the 9/11 Attacks, One More Time
text: Fourteen years later, the memory remains, but the ceremony is muted.

headline: Argentine Ants Carry Virus Deadly to Honeybees
text: The Argentine ant, already known as one of the world’s most widespread and damaging pests, may be infecting honeybees with a deadly virus, a new study finds.

headline: Biden Talks to Colbert About His Son
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said he was overwhelmed at times by his son’s death and unsure he could fully commit to being president, in an interview on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert.”

headline: Sussman Brothers Expand in Berg’n
text: The chefs and brothers Max and Eli Sussman this week opened Ed & Bev’s Detroit-Style Coney Island, a stand in Berg’n, the beer hall in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, where they already run a shawarma stand called Samesa. In Detroit, where the two men grew up, a “coney island” is a Michigan spin on a Greek diner; coney islands are ubiquitous in and around that city.

headline: Reactions to Mumbai Bombing Convictions
text: Lawyers and a victim reacted after a court in India convicted 12 of the 13 men accused of bombing commuter trains in Mumbai in 2006.

headline: House Tour | James Ivory
text: The Merchant Ivory director’s 19th-century mansion in New York’s Hudson Valley is filled with memories and ephemera from over 50 years of filmmaking with his late partner Ismail Merchant.

headline: James Ivory’s White Castle
text: After four decades spent patiently restoring his early 19th-century mansion, the director James Ivory finally has a home befitting his extraordinary life.

headline: At Jason Wu, Don’t Let the Red Lips Fool You
text: “I think beauty’s becoming less about piling on, and more about what’s underneath,” said the makeup artist Yadim about his minimalist-inspired beauty look for Jason Wu’s spring/summer 2016 collection. Don’t let the red lips fool you. Beyond that one standout feature, faces were clean — literally. “We didn’t use any foundation, just a tiny bit of concealer where they needed it,” he went on. Same goes for blush (none) and mascara (transparent), which played to Wu’s particular kind of “polished” girl this season. Moments before curtain call, Yadim applied a ruby red powder pigment over a layer of Maybelline’s Vivid Matte Liquid in Rebel Red, for a deep, velvety appearance and texture — and a timeless, low-maintenance look for any season.

headline: As the Nation Watches, Joe Biden Struggles With Whether to Run for President
text: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. looks like a man running for president, but he does not sound like it.

headline: The Stylish Streets of New York Fashion Week
text: As models and guests rushed between fashion shows, photographer Craig Arend captured some looks of the day.

headline: It’s My Nervous System That’s Lazy
text: The human nervous system ensures that the body reserves its energy and expends as few calories as possible with every movement. Now, a new study reports that the nervous system performs this optimization in real time.

headline: A Week of Insults as Candidates Turn Nasty and Personal
text: When Republican presidential candidates gather in California for their second debate next week, it could be a little awkward. The ability to deliver a well-crafted political insult is a necessary skill when it comes to running for office, but this week the zingers have rapidly zagged from the political to the personal to the nasty.

headline: After Death of Family of Five in Minnesota, a Search for Answers
text: Five members of a family who were found dead in their home in a Minneapolis suburb died of gunshot wounds in an apparent murder-suicide, the police said Friday.

headline: As Hungarian Camerawoman Apologizes, Video of Food Tossed at Penned Migrants Stirs Fresh Outrage
text: Hungarian officials opened a police investigation on Friday into conditions at a migrant camp near the country’s border with Serbia, as video circulated on social networks showing officers throwing food to detainees held in pens.

headline: Scores Killed in Mecca as Crane Crashes Into Grand Mosque
text: IZMIR, Turkey — A large construction crane toppled over and crashed into the Grand Mosque in the holy city of Mecca on Friday, killing at least 107 people and raising fears about the safety of the site before the yearly hajj pilgrimage that is expected to bring in millions of visitors to Saudi Arabia this month.

headline: Jeremy Corbyn, Unlikely Front-Runner for Labour Leader, Poised to Win Party Vote
text: LONDON — He wants to scrap Britain’s nuclear missiles, nationalize key industries and print money to bolster the economy. He is a critic of NATO and seems less than enthusiastic about the European Union.

headline: James Ivory’s Home Befits His Extraordinary Life
text: The director’s early 19th-century mansion on the Hudson is where, for 40 years, he and his longtime friends and collaborators gathered to feast, drink, argue and make movie magic. At 87, he’s still creating beauty.

headline: Review: ‘Johnny Cash: An American Rebel,’ Even if You Already Know the Story
text: “Johnny Cash: An American Rebel,” a documentary debuting on CMT on Saturday, the 12th anniversary of Cash’s death, includes a fair amount of image-burnishing and hagiography. This is expected, given that it was made in association with the John R. Cash Revocable Trust and counts Cash’s son, John Carter Cash, among its executive producers.

headline: Motion Picture Academy Settles Dispute Over Planned Museum
text: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and its planned movie museum cleared a hurdle as the academy reached a settlement with a neighborhood group that had been expected to challenge the project in court.

headline: Donald Trump Says He Has Bought NBC’s Miss Universe Stake
text: Donald J. Trump said on Friday that he had bought  NBC’s stake in the Miss Universe Organization, the group that produces the beauty pageant, which the network refused to broadcast this summer.

headline: Study Predicts Antarctica Ice Melt if All Fossil Fuels Are Burned
text: Burning all the world’s deposits of coal, oil and natural gas would raise the temperature enough to melt the entire ice sheet covering Antarctica, driving the level of the sea up by more than 160 feet, scientists reported Friday.

headline: Justice Department Releases Letters to Congress
text: In response to a Freedom of Information Act request by the New York Times, the Department of Justice has released three batches of letters it sent to lawmakers on congressional oversight committees between 2011 and 2013. The letters cover a wide variety of topics, including enforcement of civil rights laws, leak investigations, antitrust matters, spending on conferences, and criminal prosecutions.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Long Road to ‘Sorry’ Over Email Use
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton did not want to apologize.

headline: Cuba to Release 3,522 Prisoners Before Pope Francis’ Visit
text: MEXICO CITY — The Cuban government announced Friday that it would release 3,522 prisoners from its jails before the pope’s visit this month, a gesture the nation also took before the last papal visit, in 2011.

headline: On Set | Michael Fassbender
text: Bruce Weber photographs the actor Michael Fassbender in Montauk, N.Y. for T magazine’s fall men’s issue cover.

headline: Kathleen Chalfant to Portray Rose Kennedy in New Play
text: Kathleen Chalfant will play Rose Kennedy in “Rose,” a one-woman show about the political matriarch written by the longtime Kennedy watcher Laurence Leamer that will have its world premiere at the Clurman Theater at Theater Row in Manhattan this fall.

headline: How Jeffrey Immelt Is Staking His Legacy on Alstom
text: It has taken 14 years, but Jeffrey R. Immelt has finally been emancipated – by the French.

headline: Death, Sex and Money: This Senator Saved My Love Life
text: Anna Sale explains how she wound up in the kitchen of Alan and Ann Simpson, getting advice on maturity, commitment, and of course, sex.

headline: Jason Wu: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Looks from Mr. Wu’s spring 2016 show.

headline: Yale Grapples With Ties to Slavery in Debate Over a College’s Name
text: NEW HAVEN — When Maya Jenkins was accepted to Yale, her family erupted in joy. Still, her mother confessed a concern: that her daughter might be assigned to Calhoun College, one of the 12 residential colleges at the heart of the university’s undergraduate life. It is named for John C. Calhoun, a Yale valedictorian-turned-politician from South Carolina and one of the 19th century’s foremost white supremacists, who promoted slavery as “a positive good.”

headline: The Case of the Missing Jewels
text: Daniel Terna’s photographs of empty diamond district storefronts.

headline: Michael Fassbender, Nobody’s Fool
text: “I HAD ALREADY been turned down by two drama schools,” Michael Fassbender was explaining over breakfast in one of those New York hotel restaurants where beautiful people add wheatgrass to their smoothies. That rejection at 19 led him to London to try his luck auditioning for the Drama Centre there. He had prepared an Iago monologue, had gone over it hundreds of times, but he was still nervous. He had been replaying the words of a director from one of the other drama schools, who had told him that he could recognize an actor from the way he enters a room. ‘‘I still hate that,’’ said Fassbender. Before the audition, he was trying to get the director’s words out of his mind. ‘‘I went to the urinal, and as I was pissing, I saw that someone had written ‘Hi, Cookie!’ on the wall. Those words were staring at me, as I stood there. I had just finished playing the Cook in a production of ‘Mother Courage,’ and I had done it with a Scottish accent. Cook; cookie. ‘I’ll do the Iago monologue in a Scottish accent,’ I decided, even though that wasn’t how I had prepared it.’’ After the audition, Fassbender was asked why he’d chosen that accent, to which he answered something about it being a way to bring mischief into the piece, which seemed true enough. ‘‘It’s funny. I haven’t thought about that for years and years. I’m not saying what I saw was a sign or anything. But maybe I did sort of take it that way, and that helped me.’’

headline: Anna Sale and Arthur Middleton: A Political Favor Wins Her Back
text: The season was to be the “Summer of Anna.” So proclaimed Anna Sale, a New York City-based radio reporter, in 2011. “One of the rules of the Summer of Anna was if something seemed intriguing, I would just say, ‘Yes,’ ” Ms. Sale said.

headline: When the Jewels Are Unseen in the Diamond District, but Beauty Remains
text: A gold necklace can be a pretty thing. But a missing gold necklace is something more interesting. It is a story.

headline: Donald Trump’s Immigration Plan Is Laughable. But . . .
text: Maybe you thought Donald Trump was speaking rhetorically, or joking, when he promised, as president, to expel all 11 million unauthorized immigrants from the United States. He has just put a time frame on his proposal: The deportations would take 18 months to two years, he said in a Thursday conference call with supporters in Alabama.

headline: A Go-Ahead on the Iran Nuclear Deal: Cheers and Fears
text: To the Editor:Re “Democrats Hand Victory to Obama on Pact With Iran” (front page, Sept. 11):

headline: NCR Is Said to Resume Attempt to Sell Itself
text: The NCR Corporation’s efforts to sell itself may not be done after all.

headline: New Study: Burn it All (Fossil Fuel), Lose it All (Antarctic Ice and Today’s Coasts)
text: A new analysis of Antarctica’s vast ice sheet in a world heated by unabated greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuel burning comes to a stark, if unsurprising, conclusion: Burn it all, lose it all.

headline: Step Aside, Turkey. Finding the Next Great Vegetarian Main Course for Thanksgiving
text: Every fall, Well celebrates Thanksgiving by focusing on the best part of the meal — the vegetarian side dishes.

headline: Roberta Vinci Ends Serena Williams’s Grand Slam Bid at U.S. Open
text: The Grand Slam seemed there for the taking. The Grand Slam will have to wait.

headline: T City Guides: New York
text: Five leaders in creative fields share their favorite places to eat, drink, shop and play.

headline: The Other Side of the Counter
text: Tumbleweed Tuesday is what Hamptons locals call the day after Labor Day. It’s always refreshing. The summer people have disappeared. Parking spaces reappear. Stress levels dip.

headline: Pope Wants Poor Helped in Climate Debate
text: Pope Francis, meeting with the foundation for Sustainable Development at the Vatican, called for inclusion of the world’s poor in the climate discussion.

headline: Pynchon Intrigue Abounds Over ‘Cow Country’
text: “Cow Country,” a 540-page satirical novel about a dysfunctional community college, landed with a thud when it came out in April. It has amassed all of two reviews on Amazon in the months since its publication, and has been largely overlooked by critics.

headline: Review: Israeli Chamber Project Offers an Emotive Mix of Old and New
text: A new chamber ensemble can make its mark in several ways. A high level of refined and exciting playing is a good start. Interesting programs, including overlooked historical gems and terrific new works, help. So does outreach driven by an appetite for developing new audiences in out-of-the-way places. And having a budding superstar in your lineup never hurts.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Sculptural Earrings
text: By the second day of fashion week, there had already been bucket hats, fishnets and furry shoes on the runways. But one accessory that stood out among the rest were the big statement earrings at a handful of shows. At Creatures of Comfort, elegant tiered white discs came down the runway; at Tome, models wore two different pairs — one in the shape of silver fish, the other in the shape of fish bones. Rounding out the trio was Rosie Assoulin, who collaborated with her mother-in-law, Roxanne Assoulin of Lee Angel, on a series of large-scale sculptural baubles in blue, pink, white and metallic.

headline: Times Was Right to Change Insensitive Graphic
text: Many Times readers wrote to me Thursday about a graphic that appeared online and in print accompanying a story about the Iran nuclear deal. They protested a column in the graphic that identified whether lawmakers were Jewish, with a one-word heading: “Jewish?”

headline: Grilled Rib-Eye Steak
text: Melissa Clark grills rib-eye steak, and tops it off with blue cheese, butter and chives.

headline: Grilling Thick Steaks, a Leisurely Approach
text: For our close family friend Dr. Ruby, cooking steak was a meditative and ritualistic act. As a child visiting the Ruby family’s country house, about an hour north of Manhattan, I’d watch him stand over an enormous porterhouse on the charcoal grill, icy martini in one hand, tongs in the other, staring at his watch.

headline: For Widows, Social Security System Can Provide Rude Shocks
text: WITHIN weeks after her 78-year-old husband, James, died last year, Jo Etta Brown, 75, came face to face with the financial realities of being a widow living on Social Security.

headline: Shiite Militia Releases Video of Turkish Workers Kidnapped in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — A previously unknown Shiite militia released a video Friday that shows more than a dozen Turkish construction workers who were kidnapped in Baghdad recently and demands that Turkey stop the flow of jihadists into Iraq and lift a siege of several Shiite-dominated villages in Syria.

headline: Popcast: Jon Batiste and ‘The Late Show With Stephen Colbert’
text: Jon Batiste, the 28-year-old musical director of “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert,” is a serious people-pleaser: as our guest Nate Chinen attests, his gigs can have the same effect on small children that it does on grown adults. They often involve parading through the audience and other kinds of interaction; he’s from New Orleans, and understands music as a nourishing, everyday social function. But he has intensified the social aspect of performing into a modern virtuosic act, using the dynamics of flash mobs and viral videos.

headline: How David Oliver Cohen, Co-Creator of @WhiteGrlProblem on Twitter, Spends His Sundays
text: In 2010, the writer David Oliver Cohen and two collaborators created the Twitter account White Girl Problems, which chronicled the musings of the fictional Babe Walker. It was meant to be a tongue-in-cheek “platform for our grievances,” said Mr. Cohen, 35. Since then, Babe and her issues (“Why do I always feel fat after I eat a banana?”) have inspired two books and yielded a movie deal (a third book is to be published next year). A wine, White Girl Rosé, was introduced over the summer, and about 120,000 bottles have been sold since July. Mr. Cohen lives with his wife, Cristi Andrews, 35, an actress, and their children, Penelope, 5, and Hal, 3, in the West Village.

headline: The 38-Year-Old Frat Boy
text: “WERE you in the Army or something?” a tall kid in khakis and a polo shirt asked as I refilled my Solo cup for the fifth time that night. “You look old for an undergrad.”

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 1
text: Rihanna’s block party at the New York Edition hotel, Moncler hosts a dinner for amfAR, Marc Jacobs brings back the Tunnel Club, and more.

headline: Arro, a Ride-Hailing App, Connects Directly With Yellow Taxis
text: Uber is a behemoth in New York City. The shared-ride service has more than 20,000 drivers in the city who can be summoned with the tap of a smartphone. Taxi medallion owners have seen the value of their licenses drop precipitously, largely because of Uber’s rapid spread.

headline: Giants and Eli Manning Agree on Four-Year, $84 Million Extension
text: Rushing to prevent Eli Manning from entering this season in the final year of his contract, which would raise the prospect of Manning’s becoming a free agent in 2016, the Giants agreed on Friday to make him one of the highest-paid players in the N.F.L., with a four-year, $84 million contract extension.

headline: Jason Wu Spring/Summer 2016
text: Sculptural silhouettes were balanced out by safe colors.

headline: The New Jersey Jackals’ Trumpet Guy
text: Scott Freier is not on the New Jersey Jackals roster, but he does play for the team.

headline: 1968 | The Washington Bureau Chief Who Wasn’t
text: “Abe, do me a favor,” James L. Greenfield said to A. M. Rosenthal, the assistant managing editor, as they huddled in a windowless office just outside The Times’s main newsroom.

headline: Baltimore Mayor Won’t Seek Re-election
text: Stephanie Rawlings-Blake said she would not seek re-election, nearly five months after the city erupted in rioting following the death of a man injured in police custody, Freddie Gray.

headline: Future-Proofing, With Beer, at Crown Victoria
text: Some pessimists might argue that summer is over. But literalists, pointing to the calendar, can counter that the season doesn’t really end for another week and a half. It certainly seemed summery enough one night last week at Crown Victoria, on South Second Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where, in the record-breaking heat, dozens of late-season al fresco diners were breathing in the balmy air while seated around picnic tables in the beer garden. Though September had arrived, the atmosphere seemed more mid-July, with plenty of cold drinks and fried food, a hot breeze blowing off the river and a carefree crowd of revelers.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: This week’s homes include a three-bedroom in Mount Kisco, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Westport, Conn.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: New York Comptroller Clashes With Mayor de Blasio Over Shelter Contracts
text: Millions of dollars in payments to dozens of nonprofits that shelter homeless people in New York are being held up by the city comptroller, who said the city was potentially placing shelter residents in unsafe conditions under existing contracts.

headline: Penny Arcade is Still a Force in Edinburgh
text: EDINBURGH — In certain ways, Penny Arcade is a quintessential New Yorker. She’s a pink-haired former Warhol superstar who can say “been there, done that” about a great many things (and does).

headline: Hungarians Say Images of Harshness Toward Migrants Are Unfair
text: BUDAPEST — More than 170,000 migrants have crossed the border of Hungary so far this year, taxing its police, transportation system, commerce and finances. With all that, the image that is likely to linger is that of a Hungarian camerawoman sticking out her foot to trip a migrant carrying his young daughter as they ran from the police.

headline: Artisanal Satire Straight Out of Brooklyn
text: Two entrepreneurs say they’re ‘trying to build adventures,’ one stick at a time.

headline: A Yankees Speedster With a Surprising Tutor
text: With three weeks left in the regular season, a tight playoff race, like the one between the Yankees and the Toronto Blue Jays, can turn on the most trifling plays, ones that might easily be overlooked on a weeknight in May: a groundout that advances a runner, a bobble that kills a chance to turn a double play, or an outfielder’s hitting (or missing) the cutoff man.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: A Labor Day parade, a rally against the Iran nuclear deal and campaign cookies in this week’s political pictures.

headline: Officer Who Arrested James Blake Has History of Force Complaints
text: In 2012, a Queens man said, Officer James Frascatore pulled him over for a broken taillight, opened his car door and punched him three times in the mouth, unprovoked.

headline: Catalans Campaigning for Independence March in Barcelona
text: BARCELONA, Spain — More than half a million pro-independence Catalans on Friday took over one of Barcelona’s main avenues, as their separatist leaders began their latest attempt to break loose from Spain.

headline: What I Love | Kenneth Richard
text: The fashion-designer-turned-publisher lives and works in a modernist house in Connecticut.

headline: A Midcentury Retreat for a Fashion-Designer-Turned-Publisher
text: Standing by the pool behind his midcentury house in the backwoods of Weston, Conn., Kenneth Richard was taking a breather from preparing for another New York Fashion Week. It’s been 18 years since his last runway show, when he was a designer with his own label who showed in the Bryant Park tents and sold his collection to stores like Barneys New York.

headline: Kathy Savitt, Yahoo’s Head of Media, Leaves for Movie Studio
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The executive who expanded Yahoo’s ambitious efforts to make itself a digital media force is leaving the company after some of its recent projects have struggled to gain attention from viewers and advertisers.

headline: Historically Black Colleges and Universities
text: Fall enrollment in 2013 at historically black colleges and universities.

headline: Surveillance Video of James Blake Arrest
text: Video footage released by the New York Police Department shows Officer James Frascatore’s rough handling of the retired tennis star while mistakenly arresting him on Sept. 9.

headline: Obama Plans to Host Meeting With Netanyahu
text: Washington — President Obama plans to host Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel for a meeting in November, the White House said on Friday, marking the start of efforts to repair a troubled relationship between the United States and Israel badly frayed over the nuclear agreement with Iran.

headline: Gabriela Hearst’s Art-Filled Presentation
text: Gabriela Hearst’s presentation was as good a way as any to ease into the second official day of fashion week. Held this morning in the designer Lindsey Adelman’s SoHo studio, Hearst’s models walked around a room filled with an impressive lineup of works by Sol Lewitt, Ad Reinhardt, Robert Ryman, Jasper Johns — and under Adelman’s constellation of branching bubble chandeliers.

headline: Rosie Assoulin’s Colorful Pool Party
text: Plenty of maxi skirts to go around for spring/summer 2016.

headline: The 9/11 Anniversary Gets Fashion Week Off to a Somber Start
text: New Yorkers huddled in front of their TV screens Friday morning were greeted by a haunting sight: a wrenching replay of the “Today” show live coverage of the 9/11 terror attacks, broadcast in the post-dawn hours on MSNBC.

headline: A Military Base in Brooklyn, Still Active, Has an Unparalleled View
text: Short of removing your shoes, negotiating the checkpoint at Fort Hamilton is a bit like passing through airport security. A photo ID must be presented, followed by a brief background check. The payoff for this minor hassle is admittance to the only active-duty military base in New York City and the Harbor Defense Museum, not to mention an unparalleled view of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.

headline: High-Tech Lights to Help Baby Sleep, or Students Stay Alert
text: Like many expecting parents, Tracy Mizraki Kraft in Portola Valley, Calif., worried about how her newborn would sleep. So she paid attention when her doctor handed her a light bulb that he said would help her son do just that.

headline: College Football Games to Watch This Weekend
text: Saturday

headline: Islamic State Ordnance Shows Traces of Chemical Agents, U.S. Says
text: The United States has confirmed the presence of traces of sulfur mustard, a chemical warfare agent, on fragments of ordnance recently used by the Islamic State in attacks in Syria and Iraq, according to two American officials familiar with the results of laboratory analysis of the samples.

headline: Serena Williams Lost, and Her Fans Got Very Mad at Drake
text: After Serena Williams’s hopes for a Grand Slam were dashed by an unseeded player at the United States Open on Friday, her fans decided to take their frustration out on Drake.

headline: The Political Crisis in Northern Ireland
text: DUBLIN — Northern Ireland was thrown into turmoil this week when the province’s pro-British first minister resigned from the executive branch, taking his party’s ministers with him and leaving the government unable to function. Here are answers to some questions about the developments:

headline: Officer in Biden Motorcade Is Hurt When Motorcycle Falls in Queens
text: A New York police officer traveling with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s motorcade was injured on Friday when the motorcycle he was on fell as the caravan entered Queens, the police said.

headline: Garbo, Gloss and ‘Hir’
text: In the new dark comedy “Hir,” a soldier returns stateside after fighting in the Middle East to find a maelstrom back home, including a transgender brother and mother on a radically feminist mission. This being a play by Taylor Mac, the downtown writer and performer known for his flamboyant club-kid-meets-drag-mother persona, neither the patriarchy nor gender norms stand a chance.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
text: New York and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Rick Perry Ends His Run for President
text: Former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, his campaign effectively out of money, withdrew from the presidential race Friday afternoon, becoming the first Republican to quit the 2016 contest.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 1

headline: U.S. Drops Charges That Professor Shared Technology With China

headline: Lesbian Love Blossoms in New Screen Dramas
text: TORONTO — Loud and proud, “Freeheld” wears its politics on its working-class sleeve. Subtle and sophisticated, “Carol” wraps its message in meticulous period costumes and clouds of cigarette smoke.

headline: Two Weeks in New York
text: The path to a Grand Slam had been weed-whacked of obstacles, and Serena Williams, maybe the greatest women’s tennis player in history having her greatest season, needed to do nothing more than win two matches against two aging Italian players ranked outside the top 20.

headline: The Complicated World of Luxury Watches
text: With the rise of digital devices that tell time, track your steps and even pay the dinner bill, it would seem that the demise of the mechanical watch would be fast approaching. But in fact, high-end timepieces are doing just fine. Last year, Switzerland exported a record $24.3 billion worth of them (which says nothing of the equally booming vintage business). And while the Apple watch, which launched in April and sold an estimated 2.5 million units in its first quarter, is likely to affect those numbers, most traditional producers are taking their smart competition in stride. After all, they survived the ravages of the 1970s, when quartz technology made 60,000 watchmakers obsolete. Indeed, the Swiss are in the midst of a horological renaissance in which dedicated collectors wait years — and pay millions — for timepieces that make up for their lack of digital functionality with analog elegance and a promise: Given regular servicing, they’ll run in perpetuity.

headline: A Promising New Policy for Transgender Inmates
text: Prisons and jails across the country have typically moved to protect the rights and safety of transgender inmates only in response to lawsuits. But the San Francisco Sheriff’s Department has taken a proactive step: On Thursday, it unveiled a new policy that will ultimately allow transgender jail inmates to be housed according to their gender identity.

headline: For an Immersive Installation, an All-Star Soundtrack
text: When the artist duo Jonah Freeman and Justin Lowe decided they wanted a sound installation to accompany their newest immersive environment, they called on their friend Jennifer Herrema, the frontwoman of the Black Bananas, formerly of Royal Trux. Herrema assembled an impressive group of musicians for the soundtrack, reaching out to her network rather than taking the formal route of going through managers and agents. “I kind of just wanted to go at it alone,” Herrema says. “Just get people that I knew who were fans of Justin and Jonah’s work that were predisposed to wanting to be part of it anyway.”

headline: Blue Jays Rattle Yankees; Mark Teixeira Is Out for the Year
text: If this is how the Yankees began what they acknowledged was their biggest series in three years, they might want to cover their ears and close their eyes for the rest of the weekend.

headline: Trump’s Campaign Hat Becomes an Ironic Summer Accessory
text: An old-school, wide-brimmed rope hat — some in white and navy, others in red and white — has seemingly become the ironic must-have fashion accessory of the summer.

headline: Review: The Resonant Bodies Festival Completes Its Third Year
text: “Yeah, we’re going there,” said Amanda DeBoer Bartlett, just before she gave the premiere of Jonathan Sokol’s “Basic Lands” on Thursday at the Abrons Arts Center.

headline: Report Finds Vulnerabilities in Guardrails Lining U.S. Roads
text: Thousands of guardrails on American roads, made under an old safety standard, may experience problems if hit by vehicles at certain angles or if they were improperly installed, according to federal and state transportation officials.

headline: Review: BEAT Festival Opens With a Potpourri
text: It can be hard to follow the BEAT — or at least it was on Thursday, when that annual festival, whose name stands for Brooklyn Emerging Artists in Theater, opened at the Brooklyn Museum with an array of brief performances in comedy, dance, opera, theater and the spoken word. Artists appeared in various museum spaces, but what was the point of it all? Ostensibly meant as a primer for the festival, now in its fourth year, the opening-night presentation came off more like a haphazard trade show.

headline: Berlin Airport Used in Cold War Airlift Gets a New Humanitarian Mission
text: BERLIN — The planes touched down every five minutes for months, often cutting through a thick fog to bring food, coal and other supplies to those marooned on an island in a red sea of communism, as the grim joke went.

headline: Review: In ‘The Perfect Guy,’ a Stalker Is Stirred
text: Michael Ealy has a very ominous stare and Sanaa Lathan sells her inconsistent character pretty well, but “The Perfect Guy” is still just a boilerplate stalker story that proceeds more or less as you suspect it will.

headline: Donald Trump Says Ukraine Crisis Reflects Obama’s Weakness
text: KIEV, Ukraine – Donald J. Trump made a brief, unusual foray into foreign affairs on Friday, appearing at a conference here via a video link to suggest that the Ukraine crisis was rooted in weakness on the part of President Obama.

headline: Amid Violence, Journalists in Turkey Vow to Remain Resilient
text: Journalists covering Turkey’s latest military campaign against Kurdish rebels have been been detained, deported and maligned. This week, mobs vandalized the headquarters of Hürriyet, one of the country’s largest newspapers, two days in a row.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Fates and Furies’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Robin Black reviews Lauren Groff’s third novel, “Fates and Furies.” Ms. Black writes:

headline: Model-Morphosis: Mica Arganaraz at Jason Wu
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2016 Fashion Week in New York.

headline: Rick Perry’s Campaign: High Points and Low Points
text: Rick Perry’s second presidential bid lasted a little more than three months, and while he never reclaimed the top-tier status that he briefly held four years ago, the former Texas governor did have his moments.

headline: Russia Fined $44 Million for Refusing to Hand Over Jewish Books
text: In a decision likely to prolong a Russian ban on lending art to American museums, a federal judge on Thursday ordered Russia to pay a fine of $43.7 million for refusing to return a collection of Jewish books and documents to the Hasidic Chabad-Lubavitch group.

headline: 4 Pentagon Labs Face Inquiry on Handling of Deadly Germs
text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is investigating four Defense Department labs for mishandling deadly germs used in bioterrorism research, a spokesman said Friday.

headline: Review: Koosil-ja Embraces Revolution in ‘I Am Capitalism’
text: Near the end of the first section of “I Am Capitalism,” the choreographer Koosil-ja explains the work’s quixotic aim. Capitalism, she says, is a delirium from which she wishes to awake. She was born into capitalism; it is in her body. But she wants to exorcise it, to erase herself entirely to discover within herself “a new type of revolutionary potential.”

headline: Review: All Beethoven, All Evening, on Period Instruments
text: Critical acclaim for the vital performances and typically adventurous programming of the period-instrument American Classical Orchestra, founded and directed by Thomas Crawford, often comes with a sensible suggestion: It is high time that the ensemble scrap its longstanding motto, “Music as the masters heard it.” Past time, in fact.

headline: Picturing Men
text: HISTORICALLY, images of the male form project strength and power, from heroes in the military and politics to titans of industry. But there is very little imagery depicting men simply going about their lives as men. What of the rich and varied moments that make up real life? Are these not fodder for art?

headline: Ex-Officer Seeks Bond in Shooting Death of Walter Scott
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Saying that he hoped to spend time with his young son, a former police officer asked a judge on Friday to release him on bond while he awaits trial in the shooting death of an unarmed black man after a traffic stop in April.

headline: Patrick Janelle Is Better at Instagram Than You
text: The account @AGuyNamedPatrick is having a great time, and so is the photographer.

headline: California Legislature Approves Assisted Suicide
text: SACRAMENTO — In a landmark victory for supporters of assisted suicide, the California State Legislature on Friday gave its final approval to a bill that would allow doctors to help terminally ill people end their lives.

headline: Making Order From Anguish
text: PASTORALFor T’s ongoing series, the poet David Baker and the artist Soo Sunny Park make punctuated order of boundless grief.

headline: Blast Kills 7 at Nigerian Camp for People Fleeing Boko Haram
text: A bomb hidden in a tent exploded on Friday at Nigeria’s largest camp for people who have been displaced by the Boko Haram insurgency, killing at least seven residents, including five children, emergency officials and witnesses said.

headline: T Fall Men's Style Issue
text: The latest issue from T focuses on the rich and varied moments that make up the lives of real men — in all their complexity.

headline: Alexander McQueen’s Turbulent Life
text: Lee Alexander McQueen chose to kill himself, with perhaps unintentional resonance, on Thursday, Feb. 11, 2010.

headline: Burning Man Ends, and an Event for Law Enforcement Begins
text: BLACK ROCK DESERT, Nev. — The flaming poi sticks, faux-fur leg warmers and silt-caked tents are all gone; the art cars shaped like beasts or boats have driven off, now that yet another Burning Man, the eclectic art party held last week in the Black Rock Desert, has wrapped up for the year.

headline: Ohio: Report Says Killing by Officer Was Preventable
text: A University of Cincinnati police officer “was not justified in using deadly force” in a July 19 traffic stop in which he fatally shot a driver, a consultant hired by the university reported Friday. The security firm Kroll reported that video shot by Officer Raymond Tensing’s body camera contradicts his central claim, that his arm was caught in Samuel DuBose’s car, and he was being dragged. It said Officer Tensing, who has been charged with murder, appeared to have his arm free, and the car had not moved, or had barely moved, when he fired at Mr. DuBose. Calling the shooting “entirely preventable,” the report faulted both men for needlessly escalating the situation before that point — Mr. DuBose by disobeying the officer’s instructions and restarting his car, as if to drive off. Kroll also said the university police were unsuited to street-level policing, especially off campus, and should consider narrowing their mission.

headline: Djokovic Reaches Fourth Major Final of Year and Will Face Federer
text: The women’s final of the United States Open will be an all-Italian matchup that very few people had dared to predict. The men’s final, however, is a more predictable matchup of heavyweights.

headline: Births to Undocumented Parents Decline
text: About 295,000 babies were born in 2013 to undocumented parents, about 8 percent of all births in the United States that year, according to a study by the Pew Research Center.  The number of babies with at least one parent in the United States illegally declined from a peak of about 370,000 in 2007, Pew found.  In all, at least 4.5 million children who are American citizens because they were born in the United States have an undocumented immigrant parent. Donald J. Trump, a contender for the Republican presidential nomination, recently stirred debate by calling for a repeal of the constitutional right to birthright citizenship. He said he would deport the 11 million undocumented immigrants in the country and their children, even if they are citizens.

headline: 9 Men on Why They Love Their Man Buns
text: The hairstyle is now mainstream, and it can be spotted adorning the crowns of fashion kids, Park Slope stroller dads and Wall Street finance bros.

headline: Center to Give Trauma Care on South Side of Chicago
text: CHICAGO — The city’s South Side will become home to a medical center able to handle adult patients with some of the most urgent, traumatic health problems, officials announced on Friday, answering what has been a yearslong fight over inequities in health care and the dearth of nearby care for people living in some Chicago neighborhoods.

headline: Banks to Settle With Investors in Suit Over Financial Crisis
text: Large banks are preparing to pay $1.865 billion to settle accusations that they conspired unfairly to control a derivatives market that stood at the center of the financial crisis, a lawyer suing the banks said in court on Friday.

headline: U.N., Facing Abuse Scandal, to Withhold Pay of Peacekeepers Accused of Misconduct
text: UNITED NATIONS — In his most extensive public remarks since a string of sexual abuse allegations against peacekeepers in the Central African Republic, Hervé Ladsous, the United Nations under secretary of peacekeeping affairs, said Friday that he had taken the unprecedented step of suspending the salaries of troops accused of misconduct and had proposed sending soldiers on “rest and recreation” breaks every few months to relieve stress.

headline: In New York, a Win and a Loss on Health
text: The New York City Board of Health reached two important decisions on Wednesday, one decent and one that could have dreadful consequences for some infants.

headline: Russia’s Risky Military Moves in Syria
text: Over the last few months a series of diplomatic meetings from Moscow to Washington raised hopes for a serious new push toward a political solution to the vicious war in Syria that has killed more than 250,000 people and forced thousands more to flee to Europe. That optimistic idea has been put in doubt by Russia’s recent moves to significantly bolster military support for Syria’s ruthless dictator, Bashar al-Assad, whose hold on his country is weakening.

headline: Oklahoma Inmate the Focus of Renewed Attention as Execution Date Nears
text: Richard E. Glossip was at the center of a major Supreme Court case this year, arguing along with two other men on Oklahoma’s death row that the state’s choice of lethal injection drugs could cause unconstitutional suffering.

headline: Save Fetal Tissue Research, and Save Lives
text: The scurrilous attacks on Planned Parenthood — based on hidden-camera videos falsely purporting to show that it illegally sells fetal issue — have turned into attacks on fetal tissue research in Congress and in several state legislatures.

headline: Hawking CDs on the Street, Swindlers Find Being Pushy and Persistent Pays
text: Do you like hip-hop?

text: Ms. Roche’s latest collection.

headline: Automakers Will Make Automatic Braking Systems Standard in New Cars
text: DETROIT — Federal regulators said on Friday that 10 automakers had agreed to install automatic braking systems, which use sensors to detect potential collisions, as standard equipment in new vehicles.

headline: A Mojave Solar Project in the Bighorns’ Way
text: TWO important environmental imperatives, ecosystem protection and renewable energy development, are squared off against each other in the Soda Mountains of California’s Mojave Desert.

headline: Obama Talk With Troops Covers Syria and China
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — President Obama said Friday that the presence of Russian military advisers and equipment in Syria would not change American military strategy in the region, but that Russian support for the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, could make political reconciliation impossible.

headline: Givenchy Show, spring 2016
text: Exquisite variations on a tuxedo dressing theme.

headline: Google, Twitter and Publishers Seek Faster Web
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In a world where many people read everything on mobile phones, a few seconds of load time can mean the gain or loss of millions of readers and advertising dollars.

headline: Nuclear Deal Sealed, Obama Must Now Make It Work, and Mend Fences
text: WASHINGTON — Having beaten back a congressional campaign to derail his nuclear agreement with Iran, President Obama now faces a panoply of challenges that may be just as daunting: making the deal actually work while repairing relations with disaffected allies and constraining Tehran’s regional ambitions.

headline: Cheerleaders, Until They See Their N.F.L. Paychecks
text: AS the National Football League starts a new season, millions of Americans will settle in for the next five months to enjoy the thrill of pro football. Forty-five percent of those fans are female, and the league has spent millions of dollars in recent years trying to increase its appeal among women.

headline: What a Compelling Blood Pressure Finding Means for Patients
text: A large blood pressure study, funded exclusively by the federal government and using almost entirely generic drugs, ended abruptly more than a year ahead of schedule because the accumulating data were so compelling. Participants who got their systolic blood pressure below 120 had a markedly lower death rate and fewer heart attacks and strokes than those whose goal was a blood pressure below 140.

headline: Obama Addresses Troops About 9/11
text: The president, speaking at Fort Meade, reflected on the 14th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline: Police Officer Beaten to Death in Nepal Amid Protests Over Draft Constitution
text: DHULIKHEL, Nepal — An injured riot police officer was dragged from an ambulance in southern Nepal on Friday and beaten to death, officials said, the latest flash of violence in several weeks of protests over a draft constitution.

headline: With an Invitation, a Gender Barrier at Harvard Falls
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — As exclusive all-male clubs at Harvard go, the Spee Club may have seemed relatively progressive. The 163-year-old organization admitted Catholics at the turn of the 20th century, Jews in the 1930s and blacks in the 1960s.

headline: Opposition in Venezuela Is Unsettled by Leader’s Sentence
text: CARACAS — A year ago Leopoldo López, a Venezuelan opposition leader, walked at the head of rallies of tens of thousands of people, calling for the exit of President Nicolás Maduro and setting off a wave of demonstrations and unrest as the country boiled with discontent. But on Friday, only a few hundred people showed up at a demonstration to support him, a day after he was convicted and sentenced to nearly 14 years in jail for his role in leading last year’s protests.

headline: All-Italian Open Final Is an Unlikely First
text: Flavia Pennetta sat in the main interview room at the United States Open an hour after her stunning semifinal romp over No. 2-seeded Simona Halep, as Serena Williams smoothly won the first set of her semifinal match against 43rd-ranked Roberta Vinci.

headline: Hometown Salute for 3 Boyhood Friends Who Thwarted Train Attack in France
text: SACRAMENTO — In bursts of fluttering ticker tape and amid peals of cheers on Friday, this city reclaimed the somber date of Sept. 11 as a day of celebration. Under the blazing California sun, an exuberant parade unfurled through the streets in honor of the three young natives who last month tackled a would-be terrorist on a speeding train in France, likely preventing untold casualties.

headline: Notre Dame’s Big Bluff
text: Has there ever been a university whose success was more dependent on football than Notre Dame?

headline: New Orleans Mayor Avoids House Arrest in Labor Dispute
text: NEW ORLEANS — Mayor Mitch Landrieu narrowly avoided being placed on house arrest after the Louisiana Supreme Court granted a stay late Friday on a court order that would have sanctioned him for the city’s failure to come up with a plan to pay New Orleans firefighters $75 million in back pay.

headline: Rick Perry Meets His Alamo
text: Rick Perry — out!

headline: Lack of Respect for Obama Emboldened Putin, Donald Trump Tells Ukrainians
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential candidate, made a brief, unusual foray into foreign affairs on Friday, appearing at a conference here via video link to suggest that the Ukraine crisis was rooted in what he called weakness by President Obama.

headline: Justice Dept. Says Hillary Clinton Had Authority to Delete Certain Emails
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department said in a court filing this week that Hillary Rodham Clinton had the authority to delete emails that she did not believe were government records from the personal account that she exclusively used while secretary of state.

headline: Three the Hard Way
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Philosophical question: Are you willing to set aside less-than-desirable fill in a crossword puzzle if there are some absolutely stunning long entries screaming at you from the grid? And does that stunning fill make up for the less-than-desirable fill, or do you see it as merely a distraction from things that are “wrong” with it?

headline: Newark Boy, 3, Is Fatally Struck by Suspect’s Car in Police Chase
text: NEWARK — A 3-year-old boy, carrying his new Spider-Man book bag, stopped with his mother at an intersection here Friday morning as they were walking to his day care center. He was excited and wore a blue-and-yellow uniform, his family members said.

headline: William H. Grier, Psychiatrist Who Delved Into ‘Black Rage’ in 1960s, Dies at 89
text: William H. Grier, a psychiatrist whose book “Black Rage,” written with his colleague Price M. Cobbs, drew widespread attention to the psychic damage inflicted by racism and the causes of black anger, a topic of intense interest in the aftermath of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., died on Sept. 3 at a hospice in Carlsbad, Calif. He was 89.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Fashion Kaleidoscope
text: Four important ideas from the past spring and summer.

headline: Givenchy: Spring 2016 RTW
text: See the first Riccardo Tisci collection shown at New York Fashion Week.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Fashion Kaleidoscope
text: An army of promoters and press agents are determined to turn New York Fashion Week into entertainment and build their own power base in the money-making industry. But the simple fact remains: Fashion is about commerce, not entertainment. Once the show is over, and the celebrities have left in their borrowed (or free) clothes, it’s the private women who pay for their own clothes who are the final arbitrators of fashion. Shown here are four important ideas from the past spring and summer.

headline: Queen Betrays No Relief in Defeat
text: After losing in the United States Open semifinal to Roberta Vinci, an unseeded Italian, Serena Williams should have exhaled with such force that the grandstands surrounding her rumbled.

headline: Chromat: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Designs from Becca McCharen, focusing on swimwear, lingerie and “architectural cages.”

headline: Evening Hours | Summer’s Sunset
text: The party season begins in earnest.

headline: Kyle Busch Overcomes Injury and Missed Races to Be a Favorite in the Chase for the Sprint Cup
text: The final Sprint Cup race of Nascar’s regular season, to be run Saturday night at Richmond International Raceway in Virginia, will set the field for the 10-race playoff that begins next week. But it is not hard to pick the favorites and the long shots for this year’s championship.

headline: Obama Won’t Stay at Waldorf Astoria for U.N. Event; Security Concerns Are Cited
text: WASHINGTON — With Chinese spies rummaging through White House emails, President Obama has decided not to risk making their spying any easier: He will break with tradition and abandon the Waldorf Astoria, which was bought last year by Chinese investors with deep ties to Beijing’s ruling elite, when he attends the United Nations General Assembly next week.

headline: Steven Matz Struggles, but His Mets Teammates Pick Him Up
text: ATLANTA — As soon as Steven Matz saw his sinker miss the strike zone for Ball 4, he turned and grimaced. He had loaded the bases with two outs in the fourth inning of a one-run game. He stomped around the mound, picked up the rosin bag for a moment and immediately hurled it down. He looked upset, as if he knew that he knew better.

headline: After Lottery in New York to See Pope Francis, Some Winners Scalp Tickets Online
text: About 40,000 New York area residents learned on Thursday that they had won two tickets in a city-sponsored lottery to watch Pope Francis’ procession through Central Park on Sept. 25.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 10 P.M. (HBO) FERRELL TAKES THE FIELD On Sept. 8, 1965, the shortstop Bert Campaneris of the Kansas City Athletics became the first person to play every position in a single major league game as part of a stunt to draw crowds during a losing season. On March 12, Will Ferrell recreated the feat by visiting five Arizona ballparks during spring training and playing every position for 10 teams on the same day. Mr. Campaneris joins Mr. Ferrell in this special, a collaboration between Funny or Die and Major League Baseball to benefit organizations dedicated to fighting cancer. (Image: Mr. Ferrell taking the field.)

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “But today is my day. Sorry, guys.”

headline: Editors’ Note: September 12, 2015
text: A chart published on Thursday about Democrats in Congress who opposed the nuclear agreement with Iran oversimplified a complex aspect of the debate — the views of Jewish members of Congress and the divisions among American Jews over the deal.

headline: Bwahahahaha
text: If only.

headline: A Look Back and A Nod to Others
text: While writing my farewell piece, I had a good time revisiting some of my favorite columns from over the years:

headline: Man Buns Are Holding On in Brooklyn
text: Initially popularized by Brooklyn bartenders, professional athletes and, of course, Jared Leto, the man bun bestowed its wearer with a certain cachet: He was stylish, comfortable with his masculinity and needed to keep his mane out of harm’s way while changing Marconi light bulbs.

headline: Todd Oldham’s Life After Fashion
text: Todd Oldham can recall the precise moment he lost interest in fashion. It was back in 1997, and he was working on an emerald green silk satin shift that Cindy Crawford would wear in his spring runway show. The dress looked sweet and simple, but its construction was anything but. With ribbon straps made in France and fabric woven in South Korea, the piece was silk-screened with a print of a cherry tree made by Mr. Oldham on acetate, over which the designer painted a spray of cherry blossoms that were embroidered with freshwater pearls back in Texas, where his clothes were put together in his family’s factory.

headline: Karlie Kloss and Christy Turlington: Supermodels Then and Now
text: Technically, the term “supermodel” predates the 1980s, but that is when we civilians first knew who they were: Linda, Naomi and Christy. (Evangelista, Campbell and Turlington.) Famously called the “Trinity,” they were the first fashion models to challenge the celebrity of movie stars. And they were everywhere: not only modeling, but also appearing in music videos, on talk shows, and palling around together in the pages of celebrity magazines.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted by @nytimes took Instagram followers from Lower Manhattan to the hilltop village of Civita di Bagnoregio.

headline: With Jeremy Corbyn Elected as New Leader, Britain’s Labour Party Takes a Hard Left Turn
text: LONDON — After three decades as a political outsider and clarion of the left, Jeremy Corbyn on Saturday won the leadership of Britain’s opposition Labour Party with an emphatic victory and a program that includes expanding the economy, scrapping nuclear missiles and dismantling the centrist policies of his predecessors, including former Prime Minister Tony Blair.

headline: A Decline in the Nutritional Value of Crops
text: Q. Is today’s food less nutritious than it was in the past because agricultural soil is being depleted of minerals?

headline: Sailing Was More Than Respite for Roosevelt and Kennedy
text: Politicians who sail may be vulnerable to complaints that the sport seems expensive and elitist. But there were two presidents in the last century who were serious sailors, and both succeeded in weaving the pastime into their political identities.

headline: Warm, Cozy Knits at Ryan Roche
text: Pretty in a palette of pinks, beige and pale taupe for spring/summer 2016.

headline: Explosion in India Town Kills Dozens
text: NEW DELHI — A powerful explosion ripped through a shop in a town in central India on Saturday, causing the collapse of nearby buildings, including a restaurant, and killing at least 89 people, police and medical officials said Saturday.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Android Pay and Apple Products
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the industry.

headline: Restricting Access to a Roof Deck
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Givenchy
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Givenchy’s Bejeweled Masks and (Almost) Bare Faces
text: Givenchy’s spring/summer 2016 show last night was every bit the spectacle, and the makeup was no exception — most notably on the faces of four models, who wore elaborate bejeweled masks that were applied directly onto their skin. If Tisci’s tuxedo-inspired black-and-white collection suggested a night at the opera, then these were his take on the four horsemen of the apocalypse. A painstaking process comprising gold, pearl and white beading, pieces of fabric, and professional adhesive, the entire undertaking required nearly seven hours to complete makeup artist Pat McGrath’s vision.

headline: Why the Fed Raised Interest Rates
text: Officials said the economy was strong enough to keep growing with a little less help from the central bank. They said rates would rise slowly, but borrowing costs already have started to climb.

headline: The Fed’s Policy Mechanics Retool for a Rise in Interest Rates
text: It’s easy to take for granted the Federal Reserve’s ability to raise interest rates. Even among the legions who doubt that Fed officials will pick the ideal moment to start increasing rates for the first time since 2008, few question the Fed’s technical competence. The central bank has a long history. The engine is known to work.

headline: Eastern Bloc’s Resistance to Refugees Highlights Europe’s Cultural and Political Divisions
text: WARSAW — Even though the former Communist countries of Central and Eastern Europe have been asked to accept just a tiny fraction of the refugees that Germany and other nations are taking, their fierce resistance now stands as the main impediment to a unified European response to the crisis.

headline: Variety: Spiral Puzzle
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — It’s tough to call, but these Spiral puzzles by Will Shortz rank pretty highly on my list of favorite variety puzzles. I really like watching the words and phrases come together as I toggle back and forth between the Inward and Outward clues.

headline: Scenes from Givenchy’s New York Spectacle
text: Last night’s show on Pier 26 brought out beaded face masks, a 9/11 tribute and Nicki Minaj.

headline: Givenchy’s Giant New York Spectacle
text: Guests were told to bring government-issued identification to the Givenchy show, which was held last night on Manhattan’s Pier 26 — an enormous space jutting into the Hudson River and in the shadow of the Freedom Tower. They were greeted by a set of recycled industrial materials crafted into giant pillars where performance artists (under the direction of Marina Abramovic) stood. Atop one pillar, a couple moved in different stages of embrace; under another, a woman in a white dress shirt stood quietly under a running shower. A monk chanted through the loudspeakers. “The 11th of September is the most sad day in recent American history,” wrote Abramovic in her notes for the show. “As the artistic director, I want to create something respectful and humble.”

headline: Special Offer, Time Machine Not Included
text: In this episode, a small rebate debacle, one that the Haggler idiotically assumed would be resolved with a polite nudge. To this, dear reader, you are no doubt muttering, “Rebates are always complicated, Haggler. You are an idiot.” Yes, concurs the Haggler. That is why he used the word “idiotically” in the first sentence.

headline: The Daily Do: Zimmermann
text: Nicki and Simone Zimmermann, the sisters behind the romantic and always-pretty line Zimmermann, complemented their Victorian-inspired collection yesterday with a rebellious twist: messy updos with purposeful flyaways. The careless knots beautifully offset the collection and were framed on both sides with metallic gold-and-silver-leaf barrettes created by Brent Lawler.

headline: Patty Stonesifer of Martha’s Table: Zigzag Your Way to the Top
text: This interview with Patty Stonesifer, chief executive of Martha’s Table, a provider of food and clothing for low-income people, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: With Website to Research Colleges, Obama Abandons Ranking System
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Saturday abandoned his two-year effort to have the government create a system that explicitly rates the quality of the nation’s colleges and universities, a plan that was bitterly opposed by presidents at many of those institutions.

text: Kim knew she was dying, but she believed that cryonic preservation had a “1 or 2 percent chance” of offering her another shot at life. And for that, it was worth trying.

headline: The Neuroscience of Immortality
text: New efforts to understand the brain are generating methods that make “mind uploading” seem at least a bit more plausible. Here is a look at how close, and far, we are to each requirement for keeping the brain alive after death.

headline: Scenes From Givenchy’s Raucous After-Party
text: After the show, revelers including Kim Kardashian and Steven Tyler celebrated long into the night.

headline: Investigations Stymied in Malaysia, Critics of Najib Razak Take Their Case Global
text: PENANG, Malaysia — Since reports first surfaced alleging that hundreds of millions of dollars had been transferred into the personal accounts of the Malaysian prime minister, investigations into the scandal have met stiff government resistance.

headline: Phillies’ G.M. Exits on Down Note
text: In his last act as the general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, Ruben Amaro Jr. was left to dismantle the decaying team he had helped build. A year ago, the Phillies were still stocked with stalwarts from their championship teams, like Chase Utley, Cole Hamels and Jimmy Rollins. But Amaro traded them all — plus Jonathan Papelbon, Ben Revere and others — before the team fired him on Thursday.

headline: At Michigan State, Thriving on Saturdays With Help of Sundaes
text: EAST LANSING, Mich. — For years, the most popular flavor at the Michigan State Dairy Store was Blueberry Pie: vanilla ice cream, blueberry swirl and pie flakes. Then, 10 years ago, the store introduced Sesquicentennial Swirl in recognition of Michigan State’s founding in 1855 and began concocting flavors to represent the other Big Ten colleges.

headline: Walt Disney, a Visionary Who Was Crazy Like a Mouse
text: Here is something that might surprise you: Walt Disney, that icon of American ingenuity, was in financial straits through most of his career. You probably thought he would have been a business genius — a model for others to study. But Disney was an atrocious businessman, constantly running his company into the ground. At the same time, though, he was a corporate visionary whose aversion to typical business practices led to the colossus that the Walt Disney Company became.

headline: Playing the Confidence Game
text: We take it as a truism that confidence is a prerequisite for success, and we struggle to look confident even when we are not.

headline: Jenna Miller: Demystifier of Genetic Disorders
text: Jenna Miller, 25, is a genetic counselor with Recombine, a genetic testing company in New York.

headline: Body of U.S. Tourist in Spain Is Found, and Arrest Is Made
text: BARCELONA, Spain — The Spanish police on Saturday identified a body found on a farm in northern Spain as that of an American tourist who disappeared  five months ago as she walked along the Camino de Santiago, an ancient Catholic pilgrimage route.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: The ‘Golden Age for Women in TV’ Is Actually a Rerun
text: Los Angeles — NOT long ago, I recommended a young woman for a job in late-night TV and when we met face to face to celebrate her getting hired, we made a charming discovery: She was born in 1987, the same year that I got my first job on a late night show.

headline: G.O.P. Anti-Gay Bigotry Threatens First Amendment
text: This past June, in the heat of their outrage over gay rights, congressional Republicans revived a nasty bit of business they call the First Amendment Defense Act. It would do many things, but one thing it would not do is defend the First Amendment. To the contrary, it would deliberately warp the bedrock principle of religious freedom under the Constitution.

headline: Miss America, My Guilty Pleasure
text: Sunday night, I will do what I’ve done ever since I was a girl. I’ll turn on the TV, settle into the couch and then, with the remote at my side, guilt in my heart and, possibly, an actual scorecard in my hand, I will judge other women as I watch “Miss America.”

headline: The Pope’s Marriage Endgame
text: IT’S been 18 months since Pope Francis invited Cardinal Walter Kasper to raise anew the argument that divorced and remarried Catholics should be allowed to receive communion. That invitation touched off a civil war within the church’s hierarchy, pitting cardinal against cardinal, theologian against theologian; the conflict has reverberated across books, speeches, and op-ed pages, and it’s dominated the church’s synod on the family, whose second meeting looms this fall.

headline: Northern Ireland Must Resist Pull of the Past
text: Ending the power-sharing provincial government in Northern Ireland will serve no good purpose, either for Protestant unionists or Catholic nationalists. The only ones who gain are the dark forces on both sides who remain consumed by sectarian hatred and violence, nearly two decades after the Good Friday peace agreement promised a better future.

headline: Candidates Afloat on a Sluice of Money
text: When the Republican presidential candidates debate this week, it would help if voters could hear them offer detailed proposals for dealing with the 800-pound fat cat in the room — superrich donors who are making enormous, often untraceable contributions that undoubtedly tie candidates to special-interest agendas.

headline: A Farewell
text: THIS is my last regular opinion column on food for The Times. I’m leaving to take a central role in a year-old food company, to do what I’ve been writing about these many years: to make it easier for people to eat more plants. (“Oh,” say my friends, “you move to California and join a start-up.” Yup. Corny as can be.) I see it as putting philosophy into action and will talk about details soon.

headline: How to Measure a College’s Value
text: WE know all too well which colleges are the hardest to get into. The news media swoons over and trumpets this information, which is advertised as well by the most selective schools themselves.

headline: The Next Genocide
text: New Haven — BEFORE he fired the shot, the Einsatzgruppe commander lifted the Jewish child in the air and said, “You must die so that we can live.” As the killing proceeded, other Germans rationalized the murder of Jewish children in the same way: them or us.

headline: Tovah Klein
text: Tovah Klein is the director of the Barnard Center for Toddler Development. Her research focuses on how toddlers as well as their parents develop and thrive.

headline: Are College Lectures Unfair?
text: DOES the college lecture discriminate? Is it biased against undergraduates who are not white, male and affluent?

headline: What the Privileged Poor Can Teach Us
text: SELECTIVE colleges look nothing like they did 20 years ago. In the late 1990s, they began adopting no-loan policies to promote socioeconomic diversity. Princeton kicked things off in 1998. Amherst College followed in 1999 and has been a leader in creating diverse classes ever since. Spurred by a combination of blistering reports that documented the loss in human capital caused by financial barriers to college attendance and by politicians like Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, who admonished colleges for not spending more of their endowments on access, 48 schools adopted similar policies in 2007 and 2008. Many people celebrated the opening of college doors to a broader array of students. I benefited myself from these new policies.

headline: There Is No Theory of Everything
text: Over the years, I have had the good fortune to teach a lot of graduate students, mostly in philosophy, and have noticed a recurring fact. Behind every new graduate student stands an undergraduate teacher. This is someone who opened the student’s eyes and ears to the possibility of the life of the mind that they had perhaps imagined but scarcely believed was within their reach. Someone who, through the force of their example, animated a desire to read more, study more and know more. Someone in whom the student heard something fascinating or funny or just downright strange. Someone who heard something significant in what the student said in a way that gave them confidence and self-belief. Such teachers are the often unknown and usually unacknowledged (and underpaid) heroes of the world of higher education.

text: Tennis has spent the last decade in a blue period that even Picasso would have marveled at.

Trump, and he has taken the unusual step of canceling major speeches in Michigan and California this coming week to spend time in those two crucial states.

headline: A Journeywoman Hopes to Lead a Protégée Beyond Her Footsteps
text: There was a time, only a few years ago, when Ann Grossman had to buy tickets to the United States Open. If she had advanced one round further in 1994, to the quarterfinals, she would have earned a lifetime pass to the grounds for the tournament.

headline: With Words at Play, Tom Coughlin Motivates the Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was just before 8 a.m. Wednesday in the auditorium at the Giants’ training complex. Somewhat sleepily, more than 50 players were assembled in wide rows and cozy seats as Coach Tom Coughlin marched briskly across the stage to a lectern in front of a 20-foot-wide projection screen.

headline: From Somaliland to Harvard
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — OF the millions of young men and women settling into college dorms this month, one of the most unlikely is Abdisamad Adan, a 21-year-old beginning his freshman year at Harvard. Some of his 18 siblings are illiterate and never went even to first grade, and he was raised without electricity or indoor plumbing by an illiterate grandmother in a country that doesn’t officially exist.

headline: The Google Art Heist
text: PARIS — JUST seeing the Crayola colors painted on the tall iron fence of the 18th-century hotel particulier made me shiver. The big panda in flip flops in the lobby, arms up in greeting, scared me. And the petite ham sandwiches getting wheeled around to Google staffers looked positively menacing.

headline: Flavia Pennetta Defeats Roberta Vinci for U.S. Open Title
text: Storm clouds were gathering overhead and the wind was kicking up as Flavia Pennetta and Roberta Vinci walked off the court together, having played the first all-Italian women’s final in the history of the United States Open. While they sat in their chairs waiting for the trophy ceremony to begin, Pennetta leaned over to whisper a secret to Vinci, her friend of more than 20 years.

headline: To Put It Differently
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — There does not appear to be an “official” name for the type of puzzle I’m thinking about, but Joe DiPietro’s crossword reminded me of the puzzles I solved as a kid, in which words were configured in unusual ways and were meant to convey an entirely different word or phrase. I loved those, and today’s puzzle took me back to that fun time.

headline: Why Russians Hate America. Again.
text: MOSCOW — ON a warm August evening, I found myself sitting with three educated young Russians at the Beverly Hills Diner, a chain restaurant whose gaudy décor includes human-size figures of Porky Pig and Marilyn Monroe.

headline: Blue Jays Counter Yankees’ Every Move in an Emphatic Doubleheader Sweep
text: It took 4 hours 32 minutes to complete Game 1 of a single-admission doubleheader at Yankee Stadium on Saturday, and by the end of it, the Yankees looked exhausted and deflated. They had expended six relievers, two pinch-runners and a pinch-hitter. The Toronto Blue Jays had answered every strategic move.

headline: Review: The Broad Is an Old-Fashioned Museum for a New Gilded Age
text: LOS ANGELES — Traditional art museums are some of the most conservative and controlling institutions on earth. They are built as vaults to preserve the past, and as monuments to edited histories. In the Gilded Age America of a century or so ago, many new museums were also monuments to private collectors — Henry Clay Frick, J. P. Morgan, Isabella Stewart Gardner — who strove to shape and fix an image that history would have of them, as enlightened power brokers of their day and benefactors to the future.

headline: Body Blow on Texas Referee Shakes School and Sport
text: SAN ANTONIO — In a state where football rules the sports world, where Friday night lights blaze over hundreds of high school stadiums at the start of every autumn weekend, the John Jay Mustangs have seldom been on center stage.

headline: In Pakistan, U.S. Aid Agency’s Efforts Face Skepticism
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — The ads are a staple of Pakistani television: footage of water gushing through dams, farmers standing in green fields, a girl using a computer. At the end, the red, white and blue logo of an aid organization flashes on the screen with its slogan, “from the American people.”

headline: Justice Breyer Sees Value in a Global View of Law
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Justice Stephen G. Breyer’s modest study in his home here is nothing like his grand chambers at the Supreme Court. Cluttered and lived in, it bears signs of a restless intellect and a doting grandfather. The bookshelves are stuffed with volumes of law and literature, and a large dollhouse sits on the floor.

headline: A Hunting Ban Saps a Village’s Livelihood
text: SANKUYO, Botswana — Lions have been coming out of the surrounding bush, prowling around homes and a small health clinic, to snatch goats and donkeys from the heart of this village on the edge of one of Africa’s great inland deltas. Elephants, too, are becoming frequent, unwelcome visitors, gobbling up the beans, maize and watermelons that took farmers months to grow.

headline: Nashville’s Mayor-Elect Finds Path Between Liberalism and Commerce
