headline: Emily Mazzaferro, Andrew Maier III
text: Emily Margaret Mazzaferro, a daughter of Margaret M. Winsch Mazzaferro and Aldo J. Mazzaferro Jr. of Port Washington, N.Y., was married Saturday to Andrew Maier III, the son of June T. Maier and Mr. Maier II of Reading, Pa. The Rev. Daniel O'Reilly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel in New York.

headline: Alyshia Ledlie, Sumedh Joshi
text: Alyshia Marcus Ledlie and Sumedh Mohan Joshi were married Saturday at the Paniolo Ranch in Boerne, Tex. Pandit Achala C. Bapat, a Hindu priest, officiated. Later that day, the couple had a second ceremony that was led by Matthew G. Ledlie, a brother of the bride, who incorporated Christian traditions, and Sarang Joshi, the groom’s brother, who assisted in leading the bride and groom in an exchange of vows and rings.

headline: Katherine Abbey, Derek Prill
text: Katherine Taylor Abbey, the daughter of Nancy R. Abbey and Douglas D. Abbey of San Francisco, was married Saturday to Derek Collins Prill, a son of Janet C. Prill and David A. Prill of New Canaan, Conn., at St. Paul’s Episcopal Church on Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Gale Davis, the interim rector at the church, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Frannie Hall Kieschnick, an Episcopal priest from San Francisco, delivering the homily.

headline: Elisa Li, Karl Lubin
text: Elisa Li, the daughter of Suet Ping Li of Brooklyn, was married Saturday to Karl Gustaf Lubin, the son of Elizabeth Warner Lubin and David M. Lubin of Winston-Salem, N.C. Catherine M. Ballone, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Farm at Pond Lily, an events space in Elizaville, N.Y.

headline: Alexander Wang: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Wang’s spring 2016 show.

headline: At Alexander Wang, Athleisure Meets ’90s Grunge
text: For his 10th-anniversary collection, the designer brought out crop tops, overalls and bucket hats.

headline: Altuzarra’s Play on Luxe Fabrics
text: For his spring/summer 2016 collection, the designer showed everything from beaded dresses to crocodile-skin coats.

headline: Michigan State Survives Oregon With Late Defensive Stand
text: EAST LANSING, Mich. — This was the early-season college football equivalent of a blockbuster movie sequel, with No. 5 Michigan State and No. 7 Oregon hoping the new edition would be as good as the original.

headline: Floyd Mayweather Finishes Bout, and Maybe His Career, With Lopsided Win Over Andre Berto
text: LAS VEGAS — Even as he said that Saturday night was his boxing swan song, Floyd Mayweather Jr. continued to show the swagger and the skill that have been the hallmarks of his 19-year career.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (13) ARTHUR & GEORGE Arthur Conan Doyle (Martin Clunes) puts his reputation and that of his creation, Sherlock Holmes, on the line as he continues his efforts to exonerate George Edalji (Arsher Ali), an Anglo-Indian lawyer imprisoned for mutilating livestock — and threatening schoolgirls with worse — in 1903 Staffordshire. Charles Edwards plays Conan Doyle’s secretary, Alfred Wood — that is, his Dr. Watson — in this adaptation of Julian Barnes’s novel. In “Sherlock, Series III: The Sign of Three,” at 9, Holmes (Benedict Cumberbatch), the best man at the wedding of Watson (Martin Freeman) to Mary Morstan (Amanda Abbington), finds his attention diverted as a murder is plotted. (Image: Mr. Freeman, left, and Mr. Cumberbatch.)

headline: Corrections: September 13, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Here I am, driving on a road that was built with European Union money. It was built with money taken from taxpayers in Italy and Germany and France. Now we refuse to do our part?”

headline: Labour Party’s Jeremy Corbyn May Help Tories in Next British Elections
text: Jeremy Corbyn, the new leader of the opposition Labour Party, has stopped wearing T-shirts in public and now favors blue shirts and darker jackets. But even with his more prime ministerial attire, it is difficult to imagine a British electorate that just handed Conservatives a parliamentary majority turning to a party that has lurched so far to the left.

headline: TV Bundles Challenge Apple to Make a Deal
text: Never let it be said that Apple releases products quietly. In an event on Wednesday  that lasted more than two hours, the Silicon Valley giant unveiled new iPhones, a really large new iPad and — for the fashionable among us — nice, new watchbands.

headline: Why You Shouldn’t Pay Children for Grades
text: “My kid’s job is school. So why shouldn’t I pay her for good grades? After all, I get paid for the work I do.”

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start your week.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here are the week’s top stories.

text: Giants at Cowboys

text: Ravens at Broncos

text: Packers at Bears

text: Lions at Chargers

text: Colts at Bills

text: Panthers at Jaguars

text: Browns at Jets

headline: A Smooth Recovery
text: A model takes a tumble at Givenchy and rises with aplomb.

headline: Gaps in Earnings Stand Out in Release of College Data
text: Colleges give prospective students very little information about how much money they can expect to earn in the job market. In part that’s because colleges may not want people to know, and in part it’s because such information is difficult and expensive to gather. Colleges are good at tracking down rich alumni to hit up for donations, but people who make little or no money are harder and less lucrative to find.

headline: Stacy Martin Follows Her Nose
text: As a rule, the French-British actress Stacy Martin eschews wearing fragrance while on set: “I try to leave myself behind. I’m not going into a role to show myself,” she says of her technique. “The same for my jewelry: I will only bring certain things on set with me, like a book I’m reading, to kill time between takes.” On the power of a scent, she says, “It influences me when I don’t realize it. Almost every smell makes me stop and think about the past, a person or an event.”

headline: 1890: Switzerland’s Unexpected Revolt
text: BELLINZONA — The following are the leading facts about yesterday’s revolution [Sept. 11] in Ticino, as gathered on the spot. The movement was commenced by a band of Radicals entering the arsenal and arresting the manager. All the bells in the town were immediately set ringing, shops and cafés were closed and the gendarmes scattered about the place were surprised, disarmed and locked up. The Prefect was arrested.

headline: At Alexander Wang, It’s Back to the Natural Look
text: “Alex said he wanted to get back to his roots. Go back to a natural look,” said lead makeup artist Diane Kendal backstage at the Alexander Wang spring/summer 2016 show. With the exception of a little concealer here and there, the models’ faces were completely devoid of makeup. The starring product on the makeup tables: Nars Luminous Moisture Cream, which lent a fresh, dewy finish to complexions. “There’s no real one definition of beauty these days,” Kendal later said, another reason why she chose to let the models’ individual features shine through.

headline: The Daily Do: Baja East
text: Brunette, spiky mullets came down the runway at the psychedelic Baja East show yesterday. The designers, Scott Studenberg and John Targon, said they were inspired by three-day raves for their spring/summer 2016 collection — which translated into psychedelic prints, flowing tunics and fanny packs worn over parachute pants. Models kept their faces bare, with only a few coming down the runway in remnants of glittering eye shadow. The effect, indeed, felt like the remains of a desert party — like models had just woken up the day after Burning Man.

headline: Subway Station for 7 Line Opens on Far West Side
text: In a West Side neighborhood long isolated from the rest of Manhattan, crowds gathered on Sunday for a truly rare sight in New York City: the opening of a new subway station. Train aficionados and local families streamed in, squealing in delight and snapping photos of the city’s first new subway station in a quarter century.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Alexander Wang
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Germany Orders Curbs at Border in Migrant Crisis
text: BERLIN — With record numbers of migrants pouring across the Hungarian border and rushing west, Germany, the country that had been the most welcoming in Europe, suddenly ordered temporary border restrictions on Sunday that cut off rail travel from Austria and instituted spot checks on cars.

headline: On Eve of Holiday, Israeli Police and Palestinians Clash at Al Aqsa Mosque
text: JERUSALEM — Palestinian youths, some of them masked, clashed with Israeli police officers who entered Jerusalem’s Al Aqsa Mosque compound early Sunday in what has become an increasingly familiar occurrence on the eve of Jewish holidays.

headline: Moses Malone, 76ers’ ‘Chairman of the Boards,’ Dies at 60
text: Moses Malone, the N.B.A. center known as the Chairman of the Boards for prodigious rebounding that propelled him to the Basketball Hall of Fame and acclaim as one of the top 50 players in the league’s first half-century, died during the weekend in Norfolk, Va. He was 60.

headline: A Watch With Lifetime Access to Ebbets Field Has Mysterious Origins
text: On Thanksgiving Day in 1990, a customer sat down in a restaurant on the East Side of Manhattan and plopped a gold watch on the table.

headline: ‘The Perfect Guy’ Tops the Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES – For the fifth consecutive weekend, a movie with a predominantly black cast topped the North American box office. And, the horror film “The Visit” overperformed, ending a prolonged cold streak for M. Night Shyamalan.

headline: Alexander Wang Show, Spring 2016
text: Alexander Wang’s 10th anniversary show finale.

headline: Guarded Optimism as Cease-Fire Holds in East Ukraine
text: BERLIN — Buoyed somewhat by the relative success of a two-week-old cease-fire in eastern Ukraine, the foreign ministers of Germany, France, Russia and Ukraine have urged fighters and mediators to build on that progress and withdraw weapons and remove land mines as well as prepare for local elections later this year.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 3
text: Alexander Wang celebrates his 10th anniversary at strip-club-themed party with Lady Gaga, ASAP Rocky, Lil Wayne and others.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Debating Style
text: Highlights from political debates featuring Jeb Bush, the cerebral, halting former governor of Florida with an aversion to sound bites.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 3
text: Alexander Wang celebrates his 10th anniversary at strip-club-themed party with Lady Gaga, ASAP Rocky, Lil Wayne and others. See the photos.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Cerebral Debate Style Faces a Test: Donald Trump
text: On the debate stage, Jeb Bush has committed the sin of over-explanation, answering a pithy 1994 attack on his business career with so many details about leases and debts that a baffled crowd erupted into boos.

headline: Alexander Wang’s Raucous After-Party
text: The designer hosted a mega-fete in honor of his 10th anniversary.

headline: Scenes From Alexander Wang’s All-Night Rager
text: As soon as the lights had dimmed on Alexander Wang’s 10th-anniversary show on Pier 94 last night, a wall pulled back to reveal a party: a cavernous space filled with ice luges, pink-neon lights and six acrobatic dancers gyrating up and down poles. The room was littered with fake currency emblazoned with Wang’s likeness — $10 bills bearing the unofficial signature of Treasurer “Spend Lyka Dem” in honor of his clothing line’s first decade in business. The currency was scattered on the concrete of a roped-off VIP section, where Lady Gaga, Kanye West, Nicki Minaj, Mary J. Blige, Kylie Jenner, Tyga, Miguel, the Weeknd and the Fat Jew mingled and danced on banquettes. Waitstaff from Hooters served chicken wings and sliders while an ice sculpture spelled “Wang10.” A DJ mixed together an irregular-heartbeat-inducing medley that included Missy Elliott’s “Lose Control,” David Banner’s “Play” — until early in the morning, Tinashe, Lil Wayne and Ludacris took the stage for a surprise set.

headline: Victoria Beckham: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Ms. Beckham’s spring 2016 designs.

headline: Ben Carson and Bernie Sanders, on the Rise and on the Talk Shows
text: Summer might be over, but the summer of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s discontent continued on the Sunday talk shows, as the political class continued to chew on the challenges facing her candidacy — including the continuing investigation into her private email, the rise of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont in Iowa and New Hampshire, and the potential threat of a candidacy from Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: At Derek Lam, ‘I Don’t Care’ Hair
text: There has been no shortage of minimalist, stripped-down makeup on the runways this season, but for Derek Lam’s spring/summer 2016 collection, makeup artist Tom Pecheux gave us effortless-looking beauty that required at least a little bit of effort. “The key word was natural,” he said, “but with something twisted.”

headline: 1940: Nazi Government Bills Vichy 8 Million a Day
text: The Nazi government has decreed that France must pay 20,000,000 marks daily ($8,000,000 at the official rate of exchange) for the upkeep of the German army of occupation, it was revealed tonight. This figure was disclosed by the French Ministry of Finance, which stated that the “Journal Officiel” would publish tomorrow a law opening a special account to be called “Expenses of Maintaining the Army of Occupation.” This law approves an agreement concluded between the French state and the Bank of France, putting at the disposal of the former an advance of 50,000,000,000 francs (nominally $1,000,000,000) to cover this charge.

headline: Moving Fast, Fire Scorches Community in California
text: LOS ANGELES — The fire moved fast, faster than even veteran firefighters had seen. As it ripped down a hill toward Middletown, two hours north of San Francisco, some residents hardly had time to dress before they fled.

headline: This Week’s Movies | September 11, 2015
text: The New York Times film critics review “Time Out of Mind,” “Sleeping with Other People” and “The Visit.”

headline: Public School: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Dao-Yi Chow and Maxwell Osborne’s latest collection.

headline: Review: In ‘Genet Porno,’ Yvan Greenberg Leaves Little to the Imagination
text: If you have ever longed for a play starring a pair of fake penises, I have a show for you. These outsized appendages are easily the most credible and intriguing performers in “Genet Porno,” a misbegotten mash-up of Jean Genet’s novel “Our Lady of the Flowers” and a pornography star’s YouTube diary.

headline: Fashion Week’s Opening-Day Star Is Jason Wu
text: Pity the poor designer who shows at the beginning of New York Fashion Week. There’s so much competing action around — in culture (the Venice International Film Festival), sports (the United States Open, the start of football season) and national memory (Sept. 11) — that a label has to work very hard for attention.

headline: Shinzo Abe Is Re-elected as Leader of Japan’s Liberal Democrats
text: “Abenomics is still halfway through,” Mr. Abe said.

headline: Elie Tahari: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The spring 2016 collection from Mr. Tahari.

headline: 7 Train Extension Opens
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio was among the first riders to enter the 7 line station at 34th Street and 11th Avenue.

headline: Ad Contrasts Ronald Reagan’s Views With Republicans’ Words on Immigration
text: Timed to this week’s Republican presidential debate, a pro-immigration group will run a television ad that juxtaposes Ronald Reagan’s upbeat tone in welcoming people to the United States against the words of the current party candidates.

headline: A Look Back at the Sixth Avenue Subway Line Opening
text: The Sixth Avenue line was the last subway line in Manhattan to be built and one of the most challenging ones. It opened in 1940.

headline: Review: In ‘Judy,’ Societal Regression, Circa 2040
text: The title is a tease in the new play “Judy,” by Max Posner. We never meet a woman by that name, but that’s the least of the oddities in this ponderous puzzle, set in 2040. Generally dramas taking place in the future push hard on the futurism, but Mr. Posner’s 25 years ahead doesn’t seem wildly more exotic than today, except that everyone apparently lives in basements, most people have forsworn profanity (fat chance) and Internet connections are worse (a disturbing thought).

headline: Rivalry Builds Off the Field as Talent Agencies Turn to Sports
text: LOS ANGELES — As the National Football League begins another season, almost a third of its starting quarterbacks — including Peyton Manning and Drew Brees — will be represented by Creative Artists Agency. And as Novak Djokovic won the U.S. Open on Sunday, his team from William Morris Endeavor was in the stands cheering him on.

headline: From Givenchy and Alexander Wang, Competing Visions of New York
text: On Sept. 11, as the sun set over the Hudson and bathed 1 World Trade Center in silver and rose, Givenchy held a fashion show on Pier 26, on the far western edges of TriBeCa, in the shadows of the skyline.

headline: “Shear Madness” Opening in New York for the First Time
text: After 36 years of performances in Boston, Washington, and all around the globe, the play “Shear Madness” is coming to New York for the first time. The long-running farce about a murder in a beauty parlor will begin performances Off Broadway on Oct. 22nd at Stage 4 at New World Stages, with an official opening of Nov. 11.

headline: Tracy Reese: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The spring 2016 collection from Ms. Reese.

headline: Rodriguez Screams, Blue Jays Fall Silent, and Yankees Rebound
text: It was not a particularly deep fly ball, but this was not a particularly normal game for Alex Rodriguez, who steadied himself at third base, poised to pounce toward home. His body, after 2,698 career regular-season games, could still cover plenty of ground.

headline: Big Win but Bigger Worries for Jets
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Jets wanted to celebrate but could not, at least not the way they wanted. They wanted to smile but did not, at least not as wide. They wanted to crow about all the touchdowns they scored and all the turnovers they forced, their second-half dominance in a 31-10 season-opening victory against Cleveland, but they did not, at least not much.

headline: Derek Lam’s Play on Texture
text: The designer’s spring/summer 2016 collection featured eyelet, fur and suede.

headline: Derek Lam: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Lam’s spring 2016 collection.

headline: Thakoon: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Thakoon Panichgul’s spring 2016 collection.

headline: Zippered Denim and Chunky Platforms at Hood by Air
text: The designer Shayne Oliver introduced large-scale sunglasses, padlock necklaces and miniature backpacks in his spring/summer 2016 collection.

headline: The Concert Hall as Refuge in a Restless, Web-Driven World
text: For all the wonders of the web, it “threatens habits of deeper inquiry,” Ian Leslie argues in “Curious: The Desire to Know and Why Your Future Depends on It.” This book is among a growing number exploring what might be lost as we “lean on search engines and offload our memories to cloud storage,” to quote a review of four contributions to the topic last year by Jacob Silverman in The New York Times.

headline: Joshua Roth Takes United Talent Agency Into the Art World
text: LOS ANGELES — The office of Joshua Roth, a lawyer-turned-agent at the United Talent Agency headquarters here, has all the trappings of a Hollywood player: the expensive swivel chair, the big flat-screen TV. It also boasts the outward signs of an art dealer. Issues of Artforum and Art in America are fanned out on his desk, alongside entertainment industry publications. On the wall hangs an ’80s-pink portrait by the Los Angeles artist Alex Israel. Works by the painter Jonas Wood and the ceramist Shio Kusaka line the space. And Mr. Roth’s assistant is busy planning his trips to scout talent — not just at Cannes and Sundance, but at Art Basel Hong Kong and the Frieze Art Fair in New York.

headline: Review: Carlos Henriquez Radiates Gratitude in a South Bronx Homecoming
text: Nearly every note from Carlos Henriquez, the bassist for the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, is cool, clear, judicious, full of body and intent. His sound doesn’t grasp or rush; informed by the economy of Afro-Latin tumbao bass patterns, it connects and assists. It has its moral priorities straight.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 14
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Review: Cantata Profana Revives a Henze Cycle Inspired by German Poems
text: A penchant for dramatizing chamber music is central to the mission of Cantata Profana, a group of adventurous young instrumentalists and singers whose core members met as students at the Yale School of Music. The ensemble opened its fourth season on Friday night at St. Peter’s Church in Midtown with an imaginative new semi-staged version of Hans Werne Henze’s “Kammermusik 1958.” This piece is an hourlong song cycle for tenor, guitar and eight other instruments that alternates vocal settings of six feverish, strangely haunting German poems by Friedrich Hölderlin with seven instrumental interludes.

headline: Review: Jeanine Durning’s ‘To Being,’ a Dance Premiere in Queens
text: How will they get themselves out of this? I kept wondering that during Jeanine Durning’s “To Being,” which had its premiere on Wednesday at the Chocolate Factory in Queens, and not because I wanted it to end. This marathon of a dance enmeshes the dancers so wholly in doing, doing, doing that you can’t imagine them being done. It’s like watching people live, right in the thick of passing time.

headline: Basilica Soundscape: A Festival of Pop, Punk and So Much Else
text: HUDSON, N.Y. —  “I always wanted to be less subculturally lonely,” declared Jenny Hval, the Norwegian avant-pop polymath, at Basilica Soundscape on Saturday night. “But here I see no subculture.”

headline: Review: Arvo Pärt and 9/11, Paired at the Metropolitan Museum
text: Sept. 11 was, of course, many things before it became 9/11. For one, it was the birthday of the Estonian composer Arvo Pärt.

headline: Royal Topper
text: Administrivial Merl Reagle Memorial Alert! If you live in or plan to be in the Tampa, Florida area on Sunday, September 27, Marie Reagle will be hosting a memorial for Merl from 5:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m. at the University of Tampa in the Vaughn Center (9th floor). The event is open to the public.

headline: Review: In ‘Black Man in a White Coat,’ a Doctor Navigates Bruising Terrain
text: As a student at Duke University Medical School in the mid-1990s, Damon Tweedy once treated a black teenager who was hysterical and having a late-stage miscarriage. He made a flailing attempt to take her history — she denied being pregnant and said she had no bad habits — whereupon his supervisor barreled in and barked, “When is the last time you smoked crack?”

headline: Review: Melanie Martinez Performs ‘Cry Baby’ and Other Songs From Her Debut Album
text: Melanie Martinez, a 20-year-old songwriter who performed on Friday night at the Highline Ballroom, could teach career politicians how to stay on message. She single-mindedly and thoroughly explores one scenario: What happens when childhood illusions give way to bitter adult realities.

headline: Review: ‘Available Light’ Takes Over an Armory at Philadelphia’s Fringe Festival
text: In the midst of an extensive European tour, “Available Light,” a 1983 collaboration among the choreographer Lucinda Childs, the composer John Adams and the architect Frank Gehry, made an American stop over the weekend. Presented by FringeArts in Philadelphia as part of the 2015 Fringe Festival, the work took over the Drexel University Armory, a space vast enough to accommodate its grand if minimalist proportions. Ms. Childs was among the revolutionaries of Judson Dance Theater in the 1960s, and like some of her fellow postmodernists she has found a more ardent audience — and more funding, presumably — in Europe than in the United States. But as the writer Suzanne Carbonneau notes in a program essay, Philadelphia has been good to her, with the Pew Center for Arts & Heritage supporting the reconstruction of her early works and giving them a handsome online platform, the exemplary archival project “A Steady Pulse: Restaging Lucinda Childs, 1963-78.” You can enjoy that from anywhere.

headline: A Rabbi From Uber
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Selected Works of David Carr
text: 15 memorable articles, columns and video clips from Mr. Carr, a prolific media columnist for The New York Times, including his last piece that was published the day before he died.

headline: Discovering Shaken Baby Syndrome
text: The pediatric neurosurgeon who first identified shaken baby syndrome has a surprising take on the very syndrome he’s credited with discovering.

headline: The Nanny Murder Trial
text: In 1997, a young British nanny charged with murder brought shaken baby syndrome into the national spotlight, and raised a scientific debate that continues to shape child abuse cases today.

headline: The Anatomy of a Murder Case
text: The anatomy of a shaken baby case from the perspective of defense attorney Adele Bernhard.

headline: Shaken Baby Syndrome: A Diagnosis That Divides the Medical World
text: Perhaps no crime staggers the mind, or turns the stomach, more than the murder of a baby, and so it is not a surprise when law enforcement comes down hard on the presumed killers. Often enough, these are men and women accused of having succumbed to sudden rage or simmering frustration and literally shaken the life out of a helpless infant who would not stop crying or would not fall asleep.

headline: The New Mets: They Finish a Sweep, Then Grumble About Their Miscues
text: ATLANTA — Daniel Murphy shook his head, muttered something to himself and kicked the dirt near second base, perhaps trying to forget the last play. Freddie Freeman had driven a hard-hit ball that took a high bounce just in front of him, and Murphy had turned and held out his glove backhanded, trying to snatch the ball out of the air. But it screamed by him.

headline: Cities United, de Blasio’s Immigration Coalition, Has Big Goals but Modest Start
text: The coalition of the nation’s mayors was envisioned as a powerful advocacy machine, banding together to put President Obama’s executive actions on immigration into effect and to “amplify the progressive vision” by pushing for wholesale immigration reform.

headline: Frank D. Gilroy, Who Had Smash Debut With ‘Subject Was Roses,’ Dies at 89
text: Frank D. Gilroy, whose 1964 Broadway debut, “The Subject Was Roses,” won the theater’s triple crown — a Pulitzer Prize, a Tony and a Drama Critics’ Circle Award — but proved to be the high note in his life as a playwright and television and Hollywood dramatist, died on Saturday at his home in Monroe, N.Y. He was 89.

headline: Diane von Furstenberg: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Ms.von Furstenberg’s latest spring designs.

headline: U.S. Wants Former Salvadoran Ally to Face Justice in 1989 Massacre
text: Early in the morning on Nov. 16, 1989, soldiers from an elite battalion of the Salvadoran Army walked into the religious center of a Jesuit university and killed everyone they found inside.

headline: Nicopanda: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Nicola Formichetti’s spring 2016 collection for his label.

headline: Details on Bowe Bergdahl, Soldier Freed by Taliban, May Emerge at Hearing
text: In the 15 months since American commandos whisked Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl from an Afghanistan hilltop in a trade with the Taliban, he has been portrayed as both a traitor and a hero, even as most facts uncovered about what happened when he left his outpost six years ago have remained officially under wraps.

headline: Consumers and Lawmakers Take Steps to End Forced Labor in Fishing
text: WASHINGTON — Federal lawmakers, State Department officials, fishing and pet food companies, and class-action lawyers are stepping up efforts to combat forced labor at sea.

headline: 4th Inmate Dies After Oklahoma Prison Brawl
text: An inmate hospitalized after a weekend outburst of violence at a prison in Oklahoma died of his injuries, the company that owns and operates the prison said on Sunday, bringing the number of dead from the episode to four.

headline: Etsy Welcomes Manufacturers to Artisanal Fold
text: Molly Goodall’s store on Etsy, the online crafts marketplace, started as a creative solution to a parenting problem.

headline: Stanley Hoffmann, Who Brought Passion to Foreign Policy Analysis, Dies at 86
text: Stanley Hoffmann, a French-educated political scientist and foreign-affairs analyst who perceptively interpreted France and the United States to each other, and who, in a series of influential books, explored the forces that govern the relations between states, died over the weekend at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 86.

headline: Ben Carson Works His Way Up the Donation Ladder
text: First came the grass-roots support. Now Ben Carson, the retired neurosurgeon who has quietly arrived near the front of the Republican presidential field, is scooping up $100,000 a night from wealthy donors in Texas and California — evidence that he is fast transforming from a novelty candidate into one to be taken seriously by rivals and party leaders alike.

headline: Edun: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The label’s spring collection.

headline: East Village’s Birdman Abandoning His Nest of CDs and Cassettes
text: “Hello, this is Rainbow Music,” said the stooped man in the rumpled clothes, as he answered the phone in the middle of what could safely be described as a Grand Canyon of CDs.

headline: Jonathan Simkhai: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The spring 2016 collection from Mr. Simkhai.

headline: Fed’s Decision on Interest Rates, Autoworkers’ Contract Talks and a Greek Election
text: Airbus, the European airplane maker, will formally open a jet assembly plant in Mobile, Ala., on Monday, its first such factory in the United States. The move into the heart of Boeing’s home turf is part of a long-term strategy by Airbus aimed at doubling its share of the American market for 150-seat airplanes, which is currently dominated by Boeing’s top-selling 737. Airbus plans to build as many as 36 of its competing A320 and A321 models a year by 2018 and says the Mobile plant has the capacity to double that production. All of the aircraft produced at the site are destined for delivery to American carriers, which are expected to need as many as 4,700 new single-aisle planes over the next 20 years. —Nicola Clark

headline: William Becker, Who Transformed Janus Films, Dies at 88
text: William Becker, a theater critic and financier who acquired Janus Films with a partner in 1965, expanded its catalog of art-house and Hollywood classics and broadened their distribution to university audiences and home viewers on DVD, died on Saturday at his country home in Southampton, N.Y. He was 88.

headline: Russian Local Elections Draw Charges of Fraud

headline: U.S. and Iran Both Conflict and Converge

headline: Martina Hingis’s Doubles Comeback Yields Fifth Major Title of Year
text: Martina Hingis won the Grand Slam in women’s doubles in 1998, part of a remarkable year when she also won the Australian Open singles title and the WTA Tour championship. She did not accomplish all that this year, but what she did was still quite impressive.

headline: Early College Season Holds No Sway? Some Hope It Does
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Walking through the quad here Saturday an hour before Alabama’s kickoff was practically as good as listening to a radio play-by-play of the Auburn game’s closing minutes. Cheers indicated good news for Jacksonville State, which plays in the second-tier Football Championship Subdivision and was shockingly leading the Tigers with minutes to go. Disapproving murmurs indicated plays made by Alabama’s archrival.

headline: Baidu and CloudFlare Boost Users Over China’s Great Firewall

headline: Boston Enlivens City Hall Plaza by Rolling Out Green Carpet

headline: One Symptom in New Medical Codes: Doctor Anxiety
text: TERRE HAUTE, Ind. — The nation’s health care providers are under orders to start using a new system of medical codes to describe illnesses and injuries in more detail than ever before. The codes will cover common ailments: Did a diabetic also have kidney disease? But also included are some that are far less common: whether the patient was crushed by a crocodile or sucked into a jet engine.

headline: Cardinal Dolan Condemns Scalping of Pope Procession Tickets

headline: ScienceTake | Zombie Spiders
text: How a parasitic wasp larva turns an orb weaver spider into a slave that builds a web to host the larva’s cocoon.

headline: A Wasp That Turns a Spider Into the Walking Dead
text: If spiders had nightmares, the larvae of ichneumonid wasps would have to star in them. The wasp lays an egg on the back of an orb weaver spider, where it grows fat and bossy, and occupies itself with turning the spider into a zombie. As Keizo Takasuka and his colleagues point out in The Journal of Experimental Biology, this is a classic case of “host manipulation.” Using more colorful language, he described the larva turning the spider into a “drugged navvy.”

headline: Which Fed Leaders Fear Inflation? Look at When They Grew Up
text: If you are an 18-year-old college freshman in the United States, inflation in your lifetime has averaged less than 2 percent. If you are a 30-year-old millennial, you experienced inflation above 5 percent for only one year — when you were in kindergarten, perhaps in the form of the coins in a piggy bank buying fewer pieces of candy the longer they sat unspent.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 6:20 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE SKIN I LIVE IN (2011) Robert Ledgard (Antonio Banderas), a Spanish plastic surgeon whose wife has died of burns, experiments on a patient named Vera (Elena Anaya, above, with Mr. Banderas), whom he keeps locked in his isolated mansion, in what Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called Pedro Almodóvar’s “intoxicating, lush mystery.” But how did Vera get there, and why? The subplots involve a rapist (Roberto Álamo), the doctor’s housekeeper (Marisa Paredes), his daughter (Blanca Suarez) and a young man she has met (Jan Cornet). “Despite all these moving, spinning parts,” Ms. Dargis added, “Mr. Almodóvar’s control remains virtuosic and the film hangs together completely.”

headline: On Verge of Inspiring Win, Giants’ Defense Collapses Against Cowboys

headline: Panel Studying Racial Divide in Missouri Presents a Blunt Picture of Inequity

headline: Austerity Success Stories
text: One thing you encounter a lot in Europe these days are assertions that the “success” of Spain and Portugal proves that the critics of austerity were all wrong. To make this sort of claim, however, you have to do two things. First, you need to define success way, way down. Second, you have to willfully misread what Keynesians have been saying from the beginning about about the process of internal devaluation.

headline: How Congress Can Help Puerto Rico
text: Gov. Alejandro García Padilla of Puerto Rico has offered a comprehensive proposal for reversing the territory’s downward spiral. Unlike prior proposals, which focused solely on restructuring Puerto Rico’s debt or cutting its spending, the new plan recognizes the urgent need for both. It could actually work, but only with a major assist from Congress.

headline: Labour’s Dead Center
text: Jeremy Corbyn, a long-time leftist dissident, has won a stunning victory in the contest for leadership of Britain’s Labour Party. Political pundits say that this means doom for Labour’s electoral prospects; they could be right, although I’m not the only person wondering why commentators who completely failed to predict the Corbyn phenomenon have so much confidence in their analyses of what it means.

headline: Don’t Trust Putin on Syria
text: LONDON — SYRIA is being destroyed. The civil war, now more than four years old, has left the country in ruins. The implacable Islamic State controls vast areas of the north and east, and the barbaric regime of President Bashar al-Assad maintains its Damascus stronghold.

headline: Russian Moves in Syria Widen Role in Mideast
text: WASHINGTON — Russia has sent some of its most modern battle tanks to a new air base in Syria in what American officials said Monday was part of an escalating buildup that could give Moscow its most significant military foothold in the Middle East in decades.

headline: A Helping Hand for the Homeless Helps a Luxury Developer, Too
text: When she found herself on the subway on a sweltering August night two years ago, her two young children and their few belongings squeezed onto the hard plastic seats beside her, Nichelle Way had no idea where they were going. Her abusive ex-boyfriend had just thrown them out of his apartment, where they had been living for three months. When she called her family in York, Pa., they offered no help, only scolding.

headline: Jewish Man Dies as Rocks Pelt His Car in East Jerusalem
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — A Jewish man died early Monday morning after attackers pelted the road he was driving on with rocks as he was returning home from a dinner celebrating Rosh Hashana, the Jewish New Year, the Israeli authorities said. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called an emergency meeting to discuss rock-throwing, mostly by Palestinian youths.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 14, 2015
text: Updated: Sept. 18, 2015

headline: Stephen Breyer’s ‘The Court and the World’
text: In all the fanfare surrounding the Supreme Court’s end-of-term rulings this past June, a little-noticed passage in an opinion by Justice Stephen Breyer quietly revisited a debate that has roiled American law for nearly two decades. Dissenting on the final day of the term from a decision to uphold Oklahoma’s new lethal injection protocol, Breyer (joined by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg) observed that 137 countries — a full 70 percent of member states in the United Nations — have abolished the death penalty either formally or in practice. Breyer noted further that in 2013 the United States was one of only 22 countries in the world to carry out any executions at all.

headline: Wil Haygood’s ‘Showdown’
text: Thurgood Marshall sits in Room 2228 of the New Senate Office Building on July 13, 1967, a month after Lyndon Johnson has named him to the United States Supreme Court. Facing him are, among others, four arch-segregationist Southerners on the Senate Judiciary Committee: John McClellan, Sam Ervin, Strom Thurmond and its chairman, James Eastland. Marshall is determined to become the first black man ever to sit on the nation’s highest court. The senators are equally determined to block him.

headline: ‘Sisters in Law’ Looks at Sandra Day O’Connor and Ruth Bader Ginsburg
text: Two young women, near age-mates, grow up in very different corners of the country, one in near isolation on a vast Southwestern cattle ranch and the other on the crowded streets of Brooklyn. They obtain superb educations, enter into early marriage and motherhood, and set out to make their way in a man’s world. Decades later, we find them, having broken through more than a few glass ceilings, sitting together on the United States Supreme Court.

headline: Malcolm Turnbull Defeats Tony Abbott to Become Prime Minister of Australia
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Malcolm Turnbull, a former investment banker and lawyer, was sworn in as prime minister of Australia on Tuesday, after defeating Tony Abbott in a vote of Liberal Party lawmakers.

headline: Morning Agenda: Pitfalls on the Frontiers of Banking
text: PITFALLS ON THE FRONTIERS OF BANKING | Upstart online lenders have taken on big, lumbering banks with outdated branches and skittish risk departments. They have won plaudits for their low costs and straightforward terms. But now, they are starting to exhibit their own troubling traits, Michael Corkery reports in DealBook.

headline: What Comes After the Heimlich Maneuver

headline: Plants That Are Predators

He experimented with them and wrote a major treatise about them. He called the Venus flytrap, with its elaborate hair-trigger snap trap and its lethal brew of digestive juices, “one of the most wonderful plants in the world.”

headline: 1940: Buckingham Palace Bombed
text: LONDON — The belief that the German air attack on Buckingham Palace was a deliberate attempt on the lives of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth was great in force today as expressions of horror and disgust poured in from all over the empire. The rails and stone lamp pillars in front of the palace were hurled down when a time bomb dropped in a recent raid exploded this morning with terrific force, hurling debris over the forecourt and the memorial to Queen Victoria, and gouging a deep crater in the sidewalk. — New York Herald Tribune, September 15, 1940

headline: Turnbull on Ousting Abbott as Premier
text: Australia’s prime minister-elect, Malcolm Turnbull, spoke on Monday after Prime Minister Tony Abbott was ousted from power in an internal party ballot.

headline: Older Children More Likely to Be Injured in a Car, Less Likely to Have Car Seats Checked for Safety
text: Booster seat-aged children — that is, children in forward-facing child seats, including those who use the car safety belt and those who have built-in harnesses — are twice as likely to suffer serious injury or death in a car crash than younger children, but a new study shows they may be less likely to have car seats inspected for safety. Researchers from the University of Michigan found that although only 1 in 10 of the car seat inspections performed free at inspection stations in Michigan covered booster seat-aged children, ages 4 to 7, 30 percent of those children were in what they called a “sub-optimal restraint.”

headline: Apple Says iPhone Pre-Orders Are Beating Last Year’s Pace
text: Apple said Monday that global pre-orders for its latest iPhones were on track to beat last year’s sales of 10 million devices in the first weekend, which was a record for the company.

headline: Carolina Herrera’s Rosy Outlook (and Makeup)
text: It’s Miss Herrera this season. That’s not to say clients above the age of, say, 30, were excluded from Carolina Herrera’s vision for her spring/summer 2016 collection, but the beauty looks created by the hairstylist Orlando Pita and the makeup artist Diane Kendal did convey a distinct air of youthfulness. “The clothes are very light and airy, and the colors of flowers, so hair is kinda young — infantile,” explained Pita backstage. The room behind him revealed several diaphanous gowns in variations of ballet pink; and rose sculptures and bouquets installed throughout the Frick Collection set the scene for the show.

headline: Clashes at Jerusalem’s Al Aqsa Mosque
text: Israeli police officers and Palestinian youths clashed at the mosque compound on Sunday on the eve of the Jewish New Year, Rosh Hashana.

headline: Newly Risen From Yeast: THC
text: In August, researchers announced they had genetically engineered yeast to produce the powerful painkiller hydrocodone. Now comes the perhaps inevitable sequel: Scientists have created yeasts that can make important constituents of marijuana, including the main psychoactive compound, tetrahydrocannabinol, or THC.

headline: When the Venus Flytrap Snaps Shut
text: A snail’s journey through a Venus flytrap comes to a predictable conclusion, courtesy of The Naked Landscaper.

headline: London Theater Journal: The Greeks All Over Again
text: LONDON – There’s more than one way to rebuild a haunted mansion. The House of Atreus, world literature’s most enduring home of horrors, is now receiving visitors on both sides of the Thames in this city, in different, retrofitted versions of Aeschylus’s “The Oresteia,” the revenge-driven trilogy in which the bloody lair for a damned family figures so oppressively.

headline: Eight Great Round Mirrors
text: Appreciation for the simple, classic form has come full circle.

headline: U.S. Attorney General Predicts More Charges in FIFA Case
text: Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch said Monday that the United States’ crackdown on corruption in global soccer was expanding, with new charges expected in the coming months.

headline: ‘I Am Cait’ Season 1 Finale Recap: The Show Tried. It Really Did.
text: Season 1, Episode 8: “A New Beginning”

headline: Traces of Themselves
text: As a number of migrants use the Balkans as a route to pursue a better life in Europe, one photographer captures what many leave behind.

headline: The Luxury Industry Embraces Virtual Reality
text: Once solely the obsession of gamers and tech geeks, virtual reality has found sexy new bedfellows in the worlds of high-end cosmetics, cars and air travel. Dior Eyes, an in-the-works VR device with hi-def video and immersive surround sound, will take prospective consumers on a trip backstage at one of the house’s runway shows. From the outside, the wraparound goggles evoke Darth Vader; from within, the wearer finds herself amid the fizzy whirl of makeup artists, photographers and models in various states of undress — all the while being seduced into buying beauty products. Similarly, Lexus has a new device that sends you careening down Spain’s mega-exclusive Ascari race track in a Lexus RC F, and on certain Qantas flights, first-class passengers can go snorkeling in the Great Barrier Reef from 40,000 feet.

headline: 1965: Planning for the Apollo Mission
text: ATHENS — Today in the Athens Hilton Hotel where the 16th International Astronautical Congress is meeting, Wernher von Braun, director of the Marshall Space Flight Center at Huntsville, Ala., said the U.S. Apollo program was more than 50 percent completed and should achieve its goal of landing a man on the moon before 1970. Mr. Braun said three men would go to the moon in the Apollo spacecraft, consisting of a command module, a service module, a lunar excursion module and a launch escape system. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 15, 1965

headline: The Artistry in Jill Bialosky’s Pastry Brush
text: Jill Bialosky’s kitchen was immaculate, but still she could not find her little wooden pastry brush.

headline: The Daily Do: Edun
text: Natural beauty has appeared at several shows this week — in the form of natural faces and un-fussed-with hair. Edun’s show yesterday continued that trend: Models wore their faces bare and many had elegant updos. There were low, half-up styles (tied in the back as a bun) and simple ponytails. A few models even wore their hair in natural waves. The effect played up the movement of the collection (which featured fringe and flowing silhouettes) — and yet felt completely laid back.

headline: Lynch Says More Soccer Arrests Expected
text: Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch, speaking in Zurich on Monday, said that she anticipated pursuing additional charges in the continuing investigation into corruption in international soccer.

headline: Facts & Figures: 43 Percent of Republicans Think Obama Is Muslim
text: Twenty-nine percent of Americans and 43 percent of Republicans believe President Obama is a Muslim, according to a CNN/ORC poll released on Sunday. And 20 percent of Americans think he was born outside the United States.

headline: Study Finds Snowpack in California’s Sierra Nevada to Be Lowest in 500 Years
text: The snow that blanketed the Sierra Nevada in California last winter, and that was supposed to serve as an essential source of fresh water for the drought-stricken state, was at its lowest levels in the last 500 years, according to a new study.

headline: Visually Arresting New Tables, Mirrors and Lamps
text: Complex geometry makes these five pieces look good from every angle.

headline: Matt Enlow’s Bag-Stuffing Problem
text: This week’s puzzle is an original suggested by Matt Enlow, a math teacher at the Dana Hall School in Wellesley, Mass. We’ve seen Matt before — he’s the brain behind Marking the Ruler and Dividing a Rectangle. As with his previous challenges, this week’s is a bit more challenging than it seems at first. Let’s try —

headline: Athens Democracy Forum
text: The Athens Democracy Forum (September 13-15) explores the state of liberal democracy across the world. The event features diplomats, scholars, corporate executives, politicians and intellectuals from around the world. Contributors include the Op-Ed columnists, Paul Krugman (Tuesday at 10:15 AM and 7:30 PM, local time) and Roger Cohen (Tuesday at 12:15 PM and 7:30 PM), and the contributing op-ed writer Nikos Konstandaras (Monday, 12:45 PM).

headline: Ceres’s Bright Spots of Mystery
text: New images captured by NASA’s Dawn spacecraft provide the best view to date of bright spots on the dwarf planet Ceres — though nobody yet knows what they are. Ceres is thought to hold water beneath its surface. The bright spots, spangled across the bottom of the Occator crater, may be ice formed by water leaking from below, or perhaps salt left after the water evaporated. Mission scientists also produced a 3-D topographic map of the crater, finding that in places, the rim rises almost vertically for one mile.

headline: Condé Nast Names Robert Sauerberg New C.E.O.
text: Condé Nast announced an executive shake-up Monday, appointing its president, Robert A. Sauerberg Jr., as its chief executive, and moving Charles H. Townsend from C.E.O. to chairman of Condé Nast U.S.

headline: Dear Parent: If Your Child Left It Home, Don’t Bring It In
text: A school in Seminole County, Fla., has a rule, clearly posted in the front office: “Attention students and parents: We do not accept items for dropoff such as lunches, backpacks, homework, sports equipment. Please plan accordingly.”

headline: Glencore Model Is Battered, but Not Broken
text: Glencore’s chief executive, Ivan Glasenberg, has been wrong-footed. His reputation has taken a hit by the slump in minerals prices and China’s slowing appetite for commodities. Most painfully, he has had to adjust to shareholder worries about debt. Yet he was — and is — right to insist that Glencore’s unusual mix of mining with trading makes sense.

headline: Djokovic Comments on His U.S. Open Win
text: The winner of the men’s competition at the 2015 U.S. Open, Novak Djokovic of Serbia, posed in New York with his trophy on Monday and said winning it felt “amazing.”

headline: Egyptian Military Fires on Mexican Tourists During Picnic
text: CAIRO — The convoy of four sport utility vehicles full of Mexican tourists was about three hours southwest of Cairo on a typical adventure trip through the White Desert, an otherworldly landscape of monumental chalk-rock formations. Around midday on Sunday, a diabetic passenger complained that she needed to eat.

headline: A First Look at Design Miami’s 2015 Entry Pavilion
text: As designers know all too well, for every finished project — what gets walked down a runway or stocked on a shelf — there are dozens, if not hundreds, of unrealized ideas that never make it out of the studio. This work, often frustrating and messy, is so central to the design process, yet so often goes unseen — until this December, when it will be presented front and center at Design Miami’s entry pavilion.

headline: George Zimmer Takes On Men’s Wearhouse With Tuxedo Start-Up
text: Last year, George Zimmer was ousted from Men’s Wearhouse, the company he founded. His latest start-up, an online tailoring platform, is not doing so well. But now, Mr. Zimmer is sure he has a winner.

headline: Noma’s Former Pastry Chef Is on a Taco Mission
text: COPENHAGEN — Rosio Sanchez gets a lot of questions as she cranks out tortillas by hand here in the heart of the Torvehallerne market. Danes, it seems, aren’t exactly up to speed on the whole concept of tacos.

headline: René Redzepi Plans to Close Noma and Reopen It as an Urban Farm
text: COPENHAGEN — “Welcome to the new Noma,” the chef René Redzepi said on a bright summer day. “This is it.”

headline: Carolina Herrera and the Softer Side of Spring
text: The designer’s latest collection included full, textured skirts and sandals with laces.

headline: Review: In ‘The Bastard Executioner,’ a Warrior Switches Blades
text: A sampling of prominent images in the first three hours of “The Bastard Executioner”: a spear slowly penetrating a throat; a dagger entering the back of a head and exiting, dripping, through the mouth; a finger with its nail pulled off; a disemboweled woman; a severed nose, and the severing thereof; a bird feasting on a corpse’s innards; sundry slit throats; a soiled chamber pot rag.

headline: Joyce Mitchell, Who Helped Prisoners Escape, Says She Was Driven by Fear and Depression
text: Joyce E. Mitchell, a former prison employee who is set to be sentenced this month for helping two killers escape from a unit in northern New York, has given a national television interview in which she apologizes for her actions but asks for understanding, saying she was driven by depression and fear that the men would hurt her family.

headline: Jerry Lewis Archive Goes to Library of Congress
text: The Nutty Professor has moved a few steps closer to academic respectability with the announcement that the Library of Congress has acquired the personal archives of Jerry Lewis.

headline: Carly Fiorina Ad Digs at Donald Trump’s Focus on Her Looks
text: The “super PAC” supporting Carly Fiorina, the lone woman running for the Republican presidential nomination, has put out a web ad ahead of this week’s debate that seeks to turn the tables on Donald J. Trump for appearing to poke fun at her looks.

headline: The Fashion News to Know Today
text: Listen to the kids, bro

headline: 3 Major California Wildfires Remain Largely Out of Control
text: CALISTOGA, Calif. — Despite the efforts of 8,800 firefighters, three major blazes whipping through California’s tinder-dry forests and brush had consumed a combined 270,000 acres and remained largely out of control, state officials said on Monday, forcing thousands of people to flee and destroying up to 1,000 buildings.

headline: In Midst of Migrant Crisis, Cruises Change Course in Greece
text: At least three cruise lines have changed their itineraries in Greece to avoid the island of Lesbos, where some 20,000 migrants from the Middle East and Africa are living in camps.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 4
text: Michael Kors promotes a new fragrance, Opening Ceremony parties with Jessica Alba, Purple Fashion dines at Narcissa, and Public School goes burlesque at the Box.

headline: Carolina Herrera: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Ms. Herrera’s spring collection.

headline: Officials on Death of Mexican Tourists
text: Mexico’s foreign minister, Claudia Ruiz Massieu, and Prime Minister Ibrahim Mahlab of Egypt responded to the accidental killing of tourists in the Egyptian desert, including two Mexicans.

headline: Arnold Schwarzenegger Is New Host of ‘The Celebrity Apprentice’
text: NBC had said it wanted the new host of “The Celebrity Apprentice” to “make noise” and possess a similarly outsize personality like the show’s previous host, Donald Trump.

headline: John Podesta, Head of Hillary Clinton’s Campaign, to Speak at ‘Super PAC’ Event
text: The chairman of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign will meet with a group of prospective donors to the “super PAC” supporting her in New York City this week, according to an invitation to the event.

headline: The Prospects for Pursuing Corporate Executives
text: The Justice Department wants the message to go out that federal prosecutors will be taking aim at executives over their role in corporate misconduct by issuing a new policy that requires companies to identify every wrongdoer within the organization, regardless of rank, or be considered uncooperative.

headline: Taliban Storm Prison and Free Hundreds
text: Taliban insurgents attacked the main prison in Ghazni, Afghanistan, killing police guards and releasing more than 300 inmates.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 4
text: Michael Kors fetes new fragrance, Opening Ceremony parties with Jessica Alba, Purple Fashion dines at Narcissa, Public School goes burlesque at the Box. See the photos.

headline: Democrats Lay Groundwork to Expand Use of ‘Super PACs’
text: Democrats are laying the groundwork for an ambitious reorganization of their struggling network of “super PACs“ that would exploit the loopholes and legal gray areas that Republicans have already used to raise hundreds of millions of dollars for the 2016 campaign through such groups.

headline: Trump Sells Miss Universe Organization to WME-IMG Talent Agency
text: Donald J. Trump has sold the Miss Universe Organization to the talent agency WME-IMG, the company announced on Monday.

headline: New Leader Turns British Labour Party to the Left
text: LONDON — After three decades on the far-left fringes of British politics, the new leader of the Labour Party in Britain, Jeremy Corbyn, confronted several unfamiliar problems on Monday, including whether to give top jobs to internal opponents and whether to kiss the hand of Queen Elizabeth II.

headline: Scott Walker Details Plan to Curb the Power of Labor Unions
text: Returning to his political roots as his campaign struggles, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin called on Monday for anti-union measures that, if carried out, would greatly reduce the influence of organized labor in public and private workplaces.

headline: Measles Outbreak in Democratic Republic of Congo Kills 400
text: More than 23,000 people, mostly children, have been infected with measles in the Katanga region of the Democratic Republic of Congo. More than 400 have died, according to United Nations agencies and Doctors Without Borders.

headline: N.B.A. Stars Carry Their Countries’ Hopes at EuroBasket 2015
text: It is only September, but for some N.B.A. players, the meaningful games have already begun. A lot is at stake in the EuroBasket tournament in Lille, France, as the two finalists will qualify for the 12-team field in the Olympics.

headline: Inside Eckhaus Latta’s Casting
text: The designers Mike Eckhaus and Zoe Latta filled their spring show with friends.

headline: The Cool Kids of Eckhaus Latta’s Spring Show
text: Zoe Latta and Mike Eckhaus, the designers behind Eckhaus Latta, have been known to stage unconventional runway shows. (Last season, for example, their show featured a model knocking down a sheetrock wall with a hammer.) For their spring/summer 2016 collection, which shows today, they have enlisted several friends and nonmodels to walk alongside professional faces. The designers shot Polaroids at their casting last week and shared the images exclusively with T. From Grace Dunham to the artist Bjarne Melgaard, click through the slideshow to see the faces of today’s Eckhaus Latta show.

headline: Celebrity-Filled Show to Precede Pope Francis’ Mass at Madison Square Garden
text: To persuade the thousands of Roman Catholics who will attend Pope Francis’ Mass at Madison Square Garden next week to arrive early, the Archdiocese of New York announced on Monday that the Mass would be preceded by a two-hour show with prayer and devotional music performed by stars including Harry Connick Jr., Gloria Estefan and Jennifer Hudson.

headline: Wall Street Banks Reach Deal With Regulators on Data Retention
text: Four of Wall Street’s biggest banks on Monday agreed to cooperate with New York regulators and retain copies of communications sent through the messaging platform known as Symphony.

headline: Sanders Speaks at Liberty University
text: The Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders, in Virginia on Monday, acknowledged differences on abortion and gay marriage in a speech to conservative Christian students at Liberty University.

headline: Shannon Lamb, Suspect in 2 Mississippi Killings, Kills Himself
text: A professor at Delta State University who was suspected of fatally shooting his companion and then another professor at the school was found dead Monday night, apparently with a self-inflicted gunshot wound.

headline: Tommy Hilfiger: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The latest collection from Mr. Hilfiger.

headline: Injuries to Two Jets Are Not as Devastating as First Feared
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — One day after the Jets’ 31-10 rout of the Cleveland Browns at MetLife Stadium had been dampened by injuries to the rookie linebacker Lorenzo Mauldin and cornerback Antonio Cromartie, the team’s overriding emotion was relief after it received encouraging news about both players.

headline: A Report Card the Doctor Doesn’t Want to Take Home
text: I got my report card the other week, and I must say I didn’t do very well. I’m pulling around a B, better than average but not by much. My parents would be appalled.

headline: Street Style: Dressing For the Weekend Frenzy
text: A round-up of street style photos from the whirlwind weekend of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Dine Like Plato, Try Buffalo Jerky, Celebrate Mexican Independence
text: For an idea of what may have been on Plato’s table, Maria Benardis, the owner of a food company called Greekalicious, is teaching about the foods of ancient Greece in sessions that include dinner. Among the dishes will be barley and pomegranate salad with herbs and walnuts, and lamb Myma-style with a feta crust. Ms. Benardis incorporates some New World items like quinoa and chocolate into her recipes to show students how to use modern foods in the dishes: Ancient Greek class, $130, Sept. 23 from 6:30 to 9 p.m. at Coco-Mat, 49 Mercer Street (Broome Street); ancient Greek dinner and demonstration, $140, Sept. 29 from 6:30 to 9 p.m. at Natural Gourmet Institute, 48 West 21st Street; greekalicious.com.au.

headline: Bernie Sanders Makes Rare Appeal to Evangelicals at Liberty University
text: LYNCHBURG, Va. – Senator Bernie Sanders took his message of confronting inequality to unfamiliar ground on Monday at Liberty University, a leading evangelical Christian college, where he sought to build what he called “common ground” with students, beginning with the foundations of Christianity itself: the Bible.

headline: Kathleen Turner to Multitask as Director and Star
text: Kathleen Turner will both direct and act in a new transgender-themed Off Broadway play after the show’s director and one of its stars left the production.

headline: Democratic Lawyers Seek Clearer Rules on 'Super PACs'
text: In requesting an advisory opinion from the Federal Election Commission, the Democrats' leading election lawyers say they believe that much of the collaboration between Republican candidates and their super PACs is illegal, but that if the F.E.C. rules otherwise, their party will follow the Republicans' lead.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 10:55 A.M. (Encore) SAVING MR. BANKS (2013) Tom Hanks stars as Walt Disney in this Disney movie directed by John Lee Hancock about the making of “Mary Poppins,” which at the time of its creation in the early 1960s was the most expensive live-action film the studio had produced. It eventually became one of the most beloved, too, and one of the biggest moneymakers. Emma Thompson is the author P. L. Travers, who conjured the magical nanny and is something of a crank. “I won’t have her turned into one of your silly cartoons,” she says of her creation, lips pursed. There’s a back story, too, in which Travers is a little girl (Annie Rose Buckley) in a dusty Australian town, where her hopelessly alcoholic father (Colin Farrell) can barely hold on to his bank job. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called this movie “part of the Disney brand, of course: fun for everyone, with a spoonful of therapeutic medicine to help the sugar seem nutritious.” (Image: From left, Lily Bigham, Ms. Buckley, Ruth Wilson and Mr. Farrell.)

headline: $30 Million Settlement in Insider Trading Ring Linked to Hacking
text: Jaspen Capital Partners and its chief executive, Andriy Supranonok, have agreed to pay $30 million to settle allegations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that they illegally profited from stolen corporate information that was stolen from newswire services.

headline: ’90s Icons Share What They Miss the Most
text: It was a decade of neon, Pauly Shore, Coolio and no cellphones. On Saturday it was recreated at a one-day music festival in Williamsburg.

headline: Clintons Celebrate Church Anniversary
text: Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton and Chelsea Clinton attended a service to celebrate the 200th anniversary of their church, Foundry United Methodist Church, in Washington.

headline: On Social Media, Portraits of Life Amid a Fast-Moving Fire
text: After a wildfire rolled down a hill and swallowed much of the town of Middletown, Calif., residents of the area, known for its farmlands and hot springs, remained under a state of emergency on Monday.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch This Week
text: Get out your maps, everyone. Time to refresh your memories on just where exactly to find places like Wolfsburg and Eindhoven, Piraeus and Ghent. It’s Champions League time again.

headline: Expanding Cruise Options Through the Galápagos Islands
text: The small-ship cruise operator Ecoventura, known for its expedition cruising through the Galápagos Islands, is expanding into a higher level of luxury service with the introduction of its fourth ship, the MV Origin.

headline: Do Humans Have a Future in Deep Sea Exploration?
text: HONOLULU — Entering the Hawaii Undersea Research Laboratory hangar is akin to stepping onto the set of a Spielberg film. The dull metal shell, perched on the Makai pier along the Windward Coast of Oahu, is nondescript, but the inside bristles with Zodiac boats and a dizzying assortment of hoists and tools, and the walls are festooned with 30 years of snapshots. At the center of it all, two 20-foot-long Pisces submarines sit atop skids like alien spacecraft, their robotic arms outstretched, beckoning for another mission.

headline: Stripe Introduces New Tools to Simplify Mobile Shopping
text: Since the early days of the dot-com era, people have been buying more stuff — from pet food to diapers — on the Internet. The process was straightforward: Fire up your web browser, fill out your shipping and payment information, and receive your products in a week or two.

headline: Model-Morphosis: Vanessa Moody at Public School
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2016 Fashion Week in New York.

headline: North Korea Plans Rocket Launch That Could Lead to Missile
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea indicated on Monday that it was preparing to put a new satellite into orbit using a rocket that is widely seen as an intercontinental ballistic missile in the making.

headline: Russian Authorities Rule Google Broke Antitrust Regulations
text: Russian antitrust authorities ruled on Monday that Google broke the country’s competition rules, adding to the regulatory headaches the search giant is facing worldwide.

headline: Pope’s Visit Poses a Security Test for New York
text: For hours on Monday morning, scores of law enforcement officials, police commanders and representatives from at least 48 agencies sat in a room on the second floor of Police Headquarters in Lower Manhattan and imagined the worst.

headline: When Did Jeb Bush Become the Smarter Brother?
text: Jeb Bush’s presidential campaign has brought with it a resurgence of the idea that he’s the smarter of the two political Bush brothers. Experts on the Bush family say it’s an old idea, but it may not be correct.

headline: Algerian President Fires Intelligence Chief in a Shake-Up of Security Forces
text: TUNIS — In a move that has surprised and enthralled many Algerians, the ailing President Abdelaziz Bouteflika has replaced his powerful intelligence chief in a shake-up of the security forces.

headline: In Bushwick, a Live-In Gallery That’s an Art Bellwether
text: Four years ago, real estate dictated fate for friends Kyle Clairmont Jacques, 27, and Alexander Johns, 28, when a search for an affordable joint studio turned into the opening of Signal — an independently minded art gallery in Bushwick, Brooklyn. “Four or five years ago, everything around here felt slapdash. Sometime during our search for a space, it became very clear that we could present things in this area at a level that was more professional and respectful,” says Clairmont Jacques, an artist-turned-designer who has recently added gallerist to his résumé. “There was nowhere showing art that fit in with the mature contemporary discourse that was happening elsewhere in the city.” Opportunity came in the form of a vaulted industrial space that had been previously used for rug storage, and the duo seized the moment — transforming the warehouse into a live-in gallery space with a coat of white paint and elbow grease.

headline: Hispanics in Congress Ask Treasury to Prevent ‘Catastrophe’ in Puerto Rico
text: A group of Hispanic members of Congress called on the Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew, to take a more muscular role in Puerto Rico’s debt crisis and prevent what they said could become “an economic catastrophe” on the island.

headline: 732,000: American Lives Saved by Vaccination
text: The vaccination of children from 1994 to 2013 will prevent 732,000 early deaths in the United States, according to a recent estimate by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Hillary Clinton Vows to Confront Sex Assault Issue on Campuses
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged on Monday to take extra steps to end sexual assaults on college campuses, saying during a trip to Iowa that she would try to “ensure a fair process” in such cases and increase support for victims.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: In a First, Aspirin Is Recommended to Fight a Form of Cancer
text: For years, doctors have recommended daily aspirin to lower cardiovascular risk in certain men and women. Now, for the first time, an expert panel is recommending aspirin therapy to prevent heart attacks and colorectal cancer.

headline: A Vinyl LP Frenzy
text: Six decades-old presses are being refurbished at a plant in New Jersey to meet the exploding demand for vinyl records.

headline: The Rocky Revival of Vinyl Records
text: The owners of Independent Record Pressing expect to churn out up to 1.5 million records a year. Their challenge won’t be finding business, it will be keeping the antiquated machinery running.

headline: ‘Hedwig’ Broadway Run Closes on a Box-Office Upswing
text: Fans of “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” gave the show a nice box-office bump in its final week, boosting its grosses as the show ended a 76-week run on Broadway and prepared to start a tour in San Francisco.

headline: Listening to the Book Review
text: Inside The New York Times Book Review is the oldest and most popular podcast at The New York Times. The debut episode “aired” on April 30, 2006, (first guest: Gary Shteyngart) and the show has been recorded weekly ever since.

headline: California’s Gavin Newsom Chides Donald Trump on Immigration Plan (and Comb-Over)
text: Donald J. Trump is getting a chilly welcome to California from Gavin Newsom, the state’s lieutenant governor.

headline: Vinyl LP Frenzy Brings Record-Pressing Machines Back to Life
text: BORDENTOWN, N.J. — The machines at Independent Record Pressing whirred and hissed as they stamped out a test record. The business’s owners waited anxiously for Dave Miller, the plant manager, to inspect the still-warm slab of vinyl.

headline: A Sense of Instability Settles Over Turkey as Conflict With Kurds Flares
text: ISTANBUL — Nationalist and pro-government throngs filled the streets of Istanbul and Ankara for two nights last week, chanting “God is great” as they stormed a prominent newspaper and set fire to the offices of a Kurdish political party.

headline: Review: In ‘Pas de Detour,’ Cornfield Dance Plays With Obstacles
text: Ellen Cornfield has been choreographing since at least 1982, when she left Merce Cunningham’s company. The 25th anniversary of her own troupe, Cornfield Dance, came and went last year without much fanfare. What inspires her to keep making works? One answer can surely be found in the dancers she is able to recruit.

headline: Review: Sonia Olla Flamenco Company, Passionately Blending Cultures
text: It’s all too easy for a flamenco dance troupe that believes in tradition but wishes to explore new directions to go astray. There was a moment in “Por los Caminos,” a program presented at the Theater at the 14th Street Y over the weekend, when the Sonia Olla Flamenco Dance Company, performing in front of projected images of paths through dark woods, seemed on the verge of getting lost. But this troupe knows its way home.

headline: Review: In ‘Takehisa Kosugi: Music Expanded,’ Violinist Uses More Than Strings and a Bow
text: For the final piece of his performance on Sunday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Takehisa Kosugi picked up a bow and an electric violin and proceeded to play. It was the last thing I expected him to do at that point, the end of the museum’s two-day retrospective of his work, “Takehisa Kosugi: Music Expanded.” His biography may identify him as a composer, violinist and improviser, but during the weekend’s two shows he had mostly used everyday objects: bicycle spokes, for instance, an inflatable ball, a sheet of paper, or a bag of Japanese soup mix. Some of his compositions unfolded in almost complete silence.

headline: Turtle Maternity Ward
text: The Ostional Wildlife Refuge in Costa Rica is a crucial nesting site for the olive ridley turtle.

headline: Brandy Clark and Shane McAnally on ‘Moonshine: That Hee Haw Musical’
text: DALLAS — Brandy Clark and Shane McAnally sat across from each other at one end of a long conference table in a long conference room on a high-up floor at the Wyly Theater here. It was an early September morning, and they were tired.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Stop Deflating Grades
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tom Hanks Joins Panel Trying to Build Eisenhower Memorial
text: The proposed memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower got a boost of star power when the commission in charge of the project announced on Monday that the Hollywood heavyweight Tom Hanks would be joining its ranks.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Greece and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Review: In ‘Photograph 51,’ Nicole Kidman Is a Steely DNA Scientist
text: LONDON — When Nicole Kidman steps out of the shadows, breaking off from a wall of men, and onto the edge of the stage at the Noël Coward Theater, where Anna Ziegler’s “Photograph 51” opened here on Monday night, her eyes beam undiluted willpower. It is a gaze that both chills and warms, radiating and demanding trust in this singularly self-possessed presence. Ms. Kidman makes it clear that she is in charge here, and woe unto those of us who doubt it.

headline: Review: ‘Once in a Great City’ Chronicles Detroit’s Glory Days
text: Detroit in the early 1960s was a symbol not of urban decline and Rust Belt blight, but of high hopes and youthful dreams. Coveted cars didn’t have model numbers then but names that spoke of flight and fantasy and raw animal power — the Ford Galaxie, Thunderbird and Mustang, the Plymouth Barracuda, the Chevrolet Impala — and they were rolling off the Detroit assembly lines at a record pace. The country was dancing to the beat of Motown’s irresistible pop-soul groove, and with hit after hit by Stevie Wonder, Smokey Robinson, Marvin Gaye, the Temptations and the Four Tops rolling off his assembly line, Berry Gordy would proudly proclaim Motown “the sound of young America.”

headline: Debating Style, Courtesy of Jeremy Scott and Carolina Herrera
text: Is Jeremy Scott the Donald Trump of American fashion? Not in terms of politics — definitely not in terms of politics — but in terms of positioning? Mr. Scott, after all, is an oft-dismissed polarizing outsider who built his brand beyond the system by mocking fashion’s orthodoxies. He has been categorized as an entertainer and a disrupter, with emphasis on show rather than substance. Yet his approach — Instagram-ready, direct to pop culture consumers — has resulted in a documentary “The People’s Designer”; a stint redesigning the Video Music Awards Moonman statuette, and a second job as creative director of the global brand Moschino. Plus, this week: Mr. Scott’s largest show to date, in front of the singer Rita Ora and the actress Lucy Hale and a chunk of the cast of the TV show “Empire,” including Bryshere Gray.

headline: These Public Libraries Are for Snowshoes and Ukuleles

headline: Stanford Business School Dean to Resign Over a Lawsuit
text: Garth Saloner, the dean of the Stanford Graduate School of Business, announced his resignation on Monday, saying he did not want “a baseless and protracted lawsuit related to a contentious divorce” to hurt the school’s reputation. The divorce involves two Stanford professors. Mr. Saloner began a relationship with the wife shortly after the couple separated, Stanford acknowledged on Monday. The husband is suing the university, saying he was discriminated against. Stanford said he was treated “fairly and equitably.” Mr. Saloner, who has been dean since 2009, told the Stanford community he had become “increasingly concerned that the ongoing litigation and growing media interest will distract all of you.” After Mr. Saloner steps down at the end of the current academic year, he will return to teaching. He did not respond to a request for an interview. U.S. News & World Report rated Stanford’s business school the best in the nation last spring.

headline: Trauma Needs a Witness
text: The thing about Paul, I realized some weeks into our work together, was that he seemed to exist outside of time. He was anchored well enough in the present, with his marriage and friends, his career and daily obligations, but when he spoke of the past, it was with such cool composure that he gave the impression that it wasn’t his history he was talking about. He was only in his mid-30s when he first came to see me, so the remoteness of his childhood was striking. This quality, along with his air of culture and sophistication, made it seem as if he had entered the world fully grown, sprung from the head of Zeus.
