headline: Margo Jefferson’s ‘Negroland: A Memoir’
text: The phrase “Black Lives Matter,” which emerged as a rallying cry during a year of frequent deadly showdowns between police officers and unarmed black citizens, has almost always been pointed at whites. It’s a way of saying, Stop discounting us. Stop mowing us down with your hatred, fear and disregard. But “Black Lives Matter” might just as easily have been the mantra of America’s black elite who, as far back as before the abolition of slavery, sought to establish themselves in communities characterized by privilege and extreme class consciousness. Of course for them, the phrase would have been transmitted insularly, from one to another, as a reminder of how much was riding upon their success at not merely performing gentility but also believing in the inviolable dignity that gentility has always been thought to confer. Why? Because believing a thing like that will make you less susceptible to everything America has concocted to turn you right back into chattel.

headline: Who Qualifies for ‘Asylum’?
text: It’s an ancient promise: When outsiders flee to a new place in desperate need, they will not be turned away. The Hebrew Bible speaks of six cities of refuge where someone who caused a death unwittingly would be protected from being killed in revenge. The Greeks allowed slaves who ran away from abusive masters and even some criminals to seek sanctuary in certain temples; ‘‘asylum’’ comes from their word for inviolable. According to legend, Romulus, the founder of Rome, extended asylum to people we would call migrants, choosing a spot between two groves on Capitoline Hill for his city’s temple of asylum. ‘‘A crowd of commoners, both free and enslaved, poured in from the neighboring territories, eager for new conditions,’’ the historian Livy wrote. ‘‘This was the first step towards the strength Romulus envisioned for Rome.’’

headline: Will Crime Return as an Election Strategy for Republicans?
text: Over the last few weeks, a number of Republican presidential candidates have begun to criticize President Obama and the Black Lives Matter protest movement, saying they are encouraging crime. headline: TheAudience, a Social Media Company, Is Sold to Al Ahli Holding Group
text: LOS ANGELES — TheAudience, a social media publishing company and marketing agency with backers that include the William Morris Endeavor talent agency, said on Tuesday that it had sold itself to Al Ahli Holding Group, a Dubai-based conglomerate striving to play a bigger role in the global entertainment business.

headline: ‘Night of the Living Dead’ to Live Again in 10 — Yes, 10 — Comic Books
text: How many zombies comic books are too many?

headline: Hungary Declares ‘State of Crisis’
text: Zoltan Kovacs, a Hungarian government spokesman, said on Tuesday that the mass influx of refugees has created a crisis in two of the country’s southern counties.

headline: San Francisco 49ers’ Carlos Hyde Upstages Minnesota Vikings’ Adrian Peterson
text: Before the final N.F.L. game of Week 1, there was certainly an expectation that a running back might have a big game.

headline: Officials Discuss Utah Flash Flooding
text: Officials discussed the victims, many of them mothers and children, who were caught in sudden floods on Monday in Hildale, Utah, near the border with Arizona. At least eight people were killed.

headline: The Weeknd, Thanks to Streams, Stays Atop Billboard Chart
text: How much is streaming changing the music business? For one answer, look at this week’s Billboard album chart.

headline: Al-Aqsa Clashes Continue Into Third Day
text: Israeli police armed with stun grenades and tear gas clashed on Tuesday with Palestinians throwing rocks and barricading themselves inside Jerusalem’s al-Aqsa mosque.

headline: Thom Browne’s Spin on the Springtime Suit
text: The designer reworked lightweight men’s wear for his spring/summer 2016 women’s collection.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Tommy Hilfiger
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Aunt of Syrian Toddler Urges Migrant Aid
text: Fatima Kurdi, the aunt of Syrian boys who drowned trying to enter Turkey, spoke on Monday at a demonstration in Brussels and called on European Union leaders to welcome refugees.

headline: Signs of Hillary Clinton’s Troubles, in Charts
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton was inevitably going to lose some of her aura once she started campaigning. The high favorability ratings she earned as secretary of state simply weren’t sustainable.

headline: A Bohemian Feel at 3.1 Phillip Lim
text: For spring/summer 2016, the designer showed draped silhouettes and cloth headbands.

headline: The Daily Do: Thom Browne
text: Thom Browne has become one of the most anticipated shows during New York Fashion Week — not only for his beautifully focused designs, but for his shows’ theatricality. This season, his set design took a simple, sweet reference — a schoolroom — and turned it on its head, literally: A fenced-in schoolyard and swing set hung upside-down from the ceiling. Models received the same sentimental-but-twisted treatment with nostalgic pairs of braids that stood straight up (and pierced through topless top hats), and geisha-inspired makeup with a gothic spin.

headline: Subway Dancers Find New Stage
text: Dayrome Wright, 21, of the Bronx is part of a pilot program called It’s Showtime NYC that provides subway and street dancers outdoor space to perform for tips, as well as other opportunities.

headline: T.M.Q. Joins The Upshot
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Tuesday Morning Quarterback: Eli Manning Outsmarts Himself
text: What did Eli Manning know and when did he know it? This seems to be the question as the New York Giants — the last time you will see that name in this column — face the aftermath of their botched outing at Dallas, the team’s worst epic fail since the 2010 contest in which they allowed the Eagles to score four touchdowns in the final seven minutes to overcome a seemingly bulletproof 31-10 mid-fourth-quarter advantage.

headline: Twyla Tharp’s Final Rehearsals: Creating a Company
text: Twyla Tharp is writing about rehearsing, touring and creating new work, 50 years after her first dance concert.

headline: Instead of Arrests, Subway Dancers Are Getting a Stage Above Ground
text: For years, it was the sight that stopped “showtime”: a plainclothes officer, rising to identify himself aboard a New York City subway car and greeting tip-seeking break dancers with handcuffs.

headline: New England Patriots Lead A.F.C. East to a Rare 4-0 Week
text: In Week 1, the Bills, the Dolphins, the Jets and the Patriots emerged victorious. That was the first time the four teams in the A.F.C. East had a clean sweep in the same week since Week 10 in 2010, and the first time any division was 4-0 in the season’s opening week since the A.F.C. West did so in 2002. With the Patriots as defending Super Bowl champions and the Dolphins, the Bills and the Jets having made key additions in the off-season, the A.F.C. East figures to be one of the most competitive divisions. And in Week 1, the four teams played true to form.

headline: Tory Burch: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Ms. Burch’s spring 2016 collection.

headline: Stuck With Low Polling, Bobby Jindal Swings at Donald Trump
text: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana, who has been trying to move from a lower-tier poll standing in the Republican presidential contest, is continuing to assail Donald J. Trump ahead of Wednesday’s debate.

headline: Donald Trump Is Target of Conservative Ad Campaign
text: A deep-pocketed conservative organization with a long list of Republican scalps said on Tuesday that it would launch a major ad campaign aimed at Donald J. Trump in an effort to weaken him among the voters who have made him an unlikely but powerful force in the Republican presidential race.

headline: Microbeads: The Very Tiny Troublemakers
text: The Great Lakes are being threatened by an invasion of tiny plastic orbs called microbeads, but lawmakers for one state that depends on this huge freshwater ecosystem have failed to do anything about it. That state is, of course, New York, where lawmakers this year sat on a good bill to ban these unnecessary bits of plastic.

headline: Bringing Seafood Charcuterie to the Table
text: Across the country, chefs are expanding the definition of the traditional meat plate, swapping out fatty pork for the catch of the day. At Cure in Pittsburgh, Justin Severino has reimagined classics like ’nduja (a spreadable spicy pork sausage) with sockeye salmon, and finocchiona (a fennel-seed salami) with swordfish. At Greenpoint Fish & Lobster Co. in Brooklyn and at Seamore’s in Manhattan, diners can smear rich pâtés of smoked bluefish onto crusty bread. Matt Jennings, the owner of Townsman in Boston, delivers a clever spin on mortadella by substituting scallops for pork. And when Norah in West Hollywood opens next month, Angelenos can dig into smoked trout rillettes and shrimp boudin.

headline: Republicans Vow to Erase Obama’s Record, but Such Promises Are Rarely Kept
text: LOS ANGELES — For all the talk of Republican fractiousness, the party’s 2016 presidential field has united around one principle: erasing President Obama’s record.

headline: French Economists Protest Hollande’s Nomination of Central Bank Chief
text: PARIS — Nearly 150 leading economists on Tuesday criticized President François Hollande’s plan to appoint a former executive of France’s largest lender to head the country’s central bank by calling on legislators to block the appointment over concerns about potential conflicts of interest.

headline: Next Test for Guatemala’s Protest Movement: Improving Citizens’ Lives
text: GUATEMALA CITY — Shortly after 5 a.m. one day last week, a security guard opened the entrance of Roosevelt Hospital here to patients who had been lining up in the dark mountain chill for more than an hour.

headline: China Building Airstrip on 3rd Artificial Island, Images Show
text: BEIJING — New satellite images show that China has started construction of an airstrip on a third artificial island in the South China Sea that will strengthen Beijing’s military capacity in the contested waters, Western analysts say.

headline: CNN Hopes to Capture Candidates’ Combative Spirit in G.O.P. Debate
text: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — The leading Republican presidential hopefuls have spent the weeks since their first debate provoking one another, with distant taunts and tweeted insults.

headline: Ahead of Pope Francis’ Visit, Survivors of Sexual Abuse Take Stock
text: Dan Ogrodowski stayed silent into middle age. He expected to go to the grave, he said, without speaking out about the Milwaukee priest who had raped him as a child.

headline: 1940: Vichy Arrests Former Premier Leon Blum
text: VICHY — Leon Blum, twice Premier of France and leader of the French Socialist party, was arrested today [Sept. 15] and ‘‘administratively interned,’’ as an official communique put it, in Chateau Chazeron. There he joined the distinguished company of two other former French Premiers, a former generalissimo of the Allied armies, and a former French Minister of Interior who believed in making war on the Germans to the bitter end, Georges Mandel. Of the five eminent Frenchmen now under ‘‘guarded residence,’’ only one — Mandel — so far has been indicted. He was charged with plotting against the security of the state. — New York Herald Tribune, September 16, 1940

headline: What to Do Before Deployment? There’s No Crying at Disneyland
text: My husband, finally finished with the year of work-ups (short deployments preparing for the “big one”) and about to deploy, sat with me on the curb at Disneyland, watching our two children gape in awe at the Paint the Night Parade. Lightning McQueen revved his engine and the Princesses twirled before us, and the air was filled with the music’s repeating refrain: “When can we do this again? I never want this to end.”

headline: Putin Defends Russian Stance on Syria
text: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Tuesday defended Russia’s continued military support of the Syrian government, saying that without it, the refugee crisis in Europe would be worse.

headline: Rodarte’s Poetic, Less-Is-More Beauty Look
text: Unlike past seasons, when models sported eyebrow piercings and rhinestone-dappled lids, there were no arresting beauty looks in Rodarte’s spring/summer 2016 show. Or as the lead makeup artist James Kaliardos put it, “It’s not tricky.” Instead, styles skewed neutral with sandy, monochromatic makeup, which, from Rodarte, felt quite revelatory — not to mention pretty.

headline: F.D.A. Bans Sales of 4 Cigarette Products by R.J. Reynolds
text: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration halted the sale of four types of R. J. Reynolds cigarettes on Tuesday, saying the company failed to prove that they were not more harmful than products already on the market.

headline: Migrants Protest Hungary’s Border Fence
text: Hundreds of migrants staged a sit-in on a Serbian motorway to protest a new wire barrier that is preventing them from crossing into Hungary.

headline: Casa Mono
text: Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich’s Spanish tapas restaurant near Union Square.

headline: Restaurant Review: Casa Mono in Gramercy Park
text: Casa Mono has a lot to answer for. Founded by Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich in 2003, it was among the earliest and most influential restaurants to twist the Spanish tapas idiom into what New Yorkers learned to call small-plates dining. The Casa Mono style has spread far and wide, leaving in its wake a trail of cluttered tables, unpredictably sequenced dishes, and diners reduced to asking pathetically, “Will that be enough food?”

headline: Uber Case Highlights Outdated Worker Protection Laws
text: A dispute in California over whether Uber’s drivers are employees or contractors shows that labor laws that were passed decades ago just don’t work in the smartphone world.

headline: Nina Tassler, CBS’s Head of Entertainment, Is Stepping Down
text: Nina Tassler, the longtime head of entertainment programming at CBS, is stepping down at the end of the year, the network said on Tuesday.

headline: The Détente That Wasn’t: Putin’s Call to Elton John
text: LONDON — It was a story that seemed almost too good to be true. Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, celebrated for his macho bravura, and the pop star Elton John, known for his elaborate costumes, ballads and gay activism, coming together in a phone conversation that the singer said had been initiated by the Kremlin.

headline: Head of Mental Health Institute Leaving for Google Life Sciences
text: Dr. Thomas R. Insel, the director of the National Institute of Mental Health, announced on Tuesday that he planned to step down in November, ending his 13-year tenure at the helm of the world’s leading funder of behavioral-health research to join Google Life Sciences, which seeks to develop technologies for early detection and treatment of health problems.

headline: The Roots of Organic Farming on Campus
text: Mark Bittman learns about an innovative apprenticeship program that is aiming to improve the way we eat, farm and garden.

headline: Eastern Europe’s Short Memory
text: Even as Europe’s greatest refugee emergency since World War II grew more acute, prompting Germany and some other nations to temporarily shut their borders, European Union interior ministers failed on Monday to agree on even a limited mandatory distribution of refugees for resettlement among member states.

headline: ‘The Roots of Organic Farming on Campus’
text: This is the seventh in a series of videos about sustainable agriculture and healthy eating. The series was produced in collaboration with the Global Food Initiative at the University of California.

headline: Trump Addresses Cheering Crowd in Dallas
text: The Republican presidential candidate, Donald J. Trump, spoke at a campaign rally in Dallas on Monday and shared his thoughts on women’s health care, climate change and other issues.

headline: Brother of Jason Rezaian, the Reporter Held in Iran, Appeals to U.N. Panel
text: GENEVA — The brother of a Washington Post journalist imprisoned in Iran for more than a year appealed to a United Nations human rights panel on Tuesday to intercede with the Iranian authorities to obtain his release.

headline: Neo-Classical Pieces, Reinterpreted
text: Modern designers rethink the languid luxury of daybeds, candlesticks and more.

headline: Malcolm Turnbull Takes Helm as Australian Prime Minister
text: SYDNEY, Australia — When Malcolm Turnbull was sworn in on Tuesday, he did not only become Australia’s 29th prime minister — he also became its fourth in just over two years. His three immediate predecessors were ousted by their own parties, including Tony Abbott, who was forced out Monday in a leadership challenge led by Mr. Turnbull.

headline: 1965: Americans Flee to Iran
text: TEHRAN — More than 600 American women and children were evacuated to here today [Sept. 15] in a massive airlift from war-torn West Pakistan. Seven giant C-130 planes airlifted them from Lahore. In Washington, the State Department said a similar airlift of Americans from the Dacca area of East Pakistan would begin shortly, possibly tomorrow. There are about 900 Americans in the Dacca area but a State Department spokesman said he did not know how many would leave. The spokesman said another airlift may be made from West Pakistan. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 16, 1965

headline: Changes in Credit Default Swap Market Bode Well for Transparency
text: The credit default swap market is the latest bank activity to encounter Libor-style market abuse shame. Twelve banks on Friday agreed to a $1.9 billion settlement in the United States after investor accusations that they had abused their market-making position in credit default swaps, which enable investors to protect themselves against losses. Even so, the market is mending itself.

headline: Bull’s Gory Killing at Spanish Festival Draws Protest
text: LONDON — Bullfighting has a long history in Spain, but there seems to be something especially grim about the Toro de la Vega in Tordesillas.

headline: Study Says Women Are Still Underrepresented on TV in Front of the Cameras and Behind the Scenes
text: While the television industry now counts producers like Shonda Rhimes, Jenji Kohan (“Orange Is the New Black”) and Jill Soloway (“Transparent”) among its most celebrated showrunners, progress has stalled overall when it comes to equal representation for women both on screen and behind the scenes.

headline: Washington’s Plan to Lampoon Cuban Politicians Is a Joke
text: The American government is looking for a comedy troupe to produce a “uniquely funny” variety show lampooning Cuban politicians and other public figures.

headline: A View From the Top on Preventing Financial Valleys
text: I love climbing in the mountains and try to do it as often as possible. Four hours north of my home sits one of my favorite places to climb, the Teton Range. It’s a beautiful area, one of the most striking mountain ranges in the continental United States.

headline: Rodarte: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The spring 2016 collection from Kate and Laura Mulleavy.

headline: Banjo Innovator Wins Steve Martin Bluegrass Award
text: As if dedicating your life to an instrument like the banjo wasn’t sufficiently avant-garde, the winner of this year’s Steve Martin Prize for Excellence in Banjo and Bluegrass is a musician recognized for his experimental approach to that seemingly quaint stringed instrument. Danny Barnes, the Texas-based banjo player and a founder of Bad Livers, the nonconformist roots-music group, has been named the recipient of the Steve Martin Prize, its organizers said; in a news release, they hailed Mr. Barnes as “one of bluegrass music’s most distinctive and innovative performers,” and for the “raw and unpolished musical breadth of his compositions” that have “propelled him across the industry today.”

headline: Fred DeLuca, Hands-on Co-Founder of Subway Sandwich Chain, Dies at 67
text: Fred DeLuca, who in 1965, at 17, borrowed $1,000 to open a sandwich shop in Bridgeport, Conn., to help pay college expenses and parlayed that experience into building Subway, the world’s largest chain of fast-food franchises, died on Monday. He was 67.

headline: Tory Burch’s Day at the Beach
text: For spring/summer 2016, the designer included tunics, fringe detailing and strapless dresses.

headline: At Rodarte, Romance With a Touch of Darkness
text: The spring/summer 2016 collection featured soft hues and fabrics spiked with a glam-rock edge.

headline: The Fashion News to Know Today
text: A Kate Spade ad without a bicycle

headline: Reaching Europe
text: Huge numbers of people continue to arrive at Europe’s borders.

headline: Defiant Baruch Fraternity Pledge Fought Back in Fatal Hazing, Report Says
text: POCONO SUMMIT, Pa. — The fraternity brothers decided that Chun Hsien Deng had a bad attitude.

headline: Cheesy Ice Cream, Please
text: A Parmigiano Reggiano base gets amped up with balsamic vinegar, olive oil and sea salt.

headline: China Releases Guo Yushan, Scholar Who Helped Activist Gain Asylum in U.S.
text: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities on Tuesday released a founder of a research institute who was instrumental in helping the legal activist Chen Guangcheng gain asylum in the United States after he escaped house arrest three years ago.

headline: Ruth Reichl Recharges in the Kitchen
text: SPENCERTOWN, N.Y. — Ruth Reichl was in the kitchen she designed as both command center and comfort station, making a salami sandwich for her husband, Michael Singer, 75, a former CBS News producer who has been recovering from back surgery.

headline: What Can Airline Passengers Do About Bad Behavior?
text: On Friday, CNN reported that a JetBlue passenger en route from Anchorage to Portland, Ore., stood up and urinated on passengers sitting in front of him and others around him. When the plane landed, he was arrested by Portland police, charged with criminal mischief and offensive littering, two misdemeanors, and later released.

headline: Rodarte Show, Spring 2015
text: Sound and light at the Rodarte New York Fashion Week runway show.

headline: Raising Rates Too Soon: The Mistake Central Banks Keep Making
text: Central banks, to boil their job down to its simplest level, face this perpetual dilemma: Should they push for easier money, to try to support a nation’s economic growth, or for tighter money, to try to head off inflation?

headline: Celebrating the Flavors of Eataly With Ice Cream (Not Gelato)
text: Five years ago, Eataly opened its doors on Fifth Avenue and 23rd Street, and ushered in the era of the high-end, themed, culinary mega-store. Since then, massive shrines to all things Italian have popped up around the globe, in places like Chicago, Dubai and, as of late last month, Seoul.

headline: Disney-ABC Names Cindy Davis and John Frelinghuysen to Senior Posts
text: LOS ANGELES — As it works to shore up its non-ESPN television division in a time of tremendous industrywide challenges — perhaps with the eventual introduction of a direct-to-consumer streaming service — the Walt Disney Company on Tuesday named a former Walmart executive and a former AOL leader to senior posts.

headline: Interview: Ellen Page
text: The actress discusses her roles in two films showing at the 40th Toronto International Film Festival, “Freeheld” and “Into the Forest.”

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 5
text: Mariah Carey shows up at W magazine’s dance; the Kardashian/Jenner sisters party with Galore; and Karolina Kurkova celebrates the Slowear opening.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 5
text: Mariah Carey shows up at W magazine’s dance; the Kardashian/Jenner sisters party with Galore; and Karolina Kurkova celebrates the Slowear opening.

headline: When the Mission Is to Be an Outcast
text: On a stifling day last month, the designer Rio Uribe sat in his basement-level, midtown studio wearing shorts, Reeboks, and a yellow basketball jersey emblazoned with a planetary “Haturn” logo that has become the emblem of his three-year-old label, Gypsy Sport. The studio is a physical manifestation of the brand: exploding with color and pattern, every surface is covered in red and gold paper lanterns, bamboo plants and the vibrant remnants from past collections. Over the past five seasons, Uribe’s vividly eccentric designs have made the brand famous for its irreverent, gender-fluid take on men’s wear.

headline: Egypt Rejects Criticism Over Airstrike That Killed Mexican Tourists
text: CAIRO — Mexico’s foreign minister traveled to Egypt on Tuesday to demand answers about a mistaken military airstrike over the weekend that hit a picnic full of Mexican tourists, killing a dozen people, while her Egyptian counterpart defended the professionalism and sacrifice of the Egyptian security forces.

headline: Vera Wang: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The latest spring designs from Ms. Wang.

headline: House Vote Said to Be Near on Repeal of Oil Export Ban
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California and majority leader, said on Tuesday that the House was preparing to vote later this month to repeal a 40-year-old ban on the export of crude oil. The plan was immediately celebrated by the oil industry but is already drawing fire from environmental groups.

headline: Timeline: Democracy in Recession
text: Charting the rise, and stall, of democracy in the last 40 years.

headline: Tough Going for Health Co-ops
text: Late last month, the Nevada Health Co-op became the third casualty among 23 insurance start-ups created under the federal health care law to inject competition for coverage in certain parts of the country.

headline: Model-Morphosis: Frederikke Sofie at Vera Wang
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2016 Fashion Week in New York.

headline: Blue Origin, Jeff Bezos’ Rocket Company, to Launch From Florida
text: Blue Origin, a secretive rocket company started by Jeffrey P. Bezos, the chief executive of Amazon, made a splashy public announcement on Tuesday, saying it will build rockets and send them into orbit from Florida.

headline: Bruce Springsteen and Jon Stewart to Perform at ‘Stand Up for Heroes’ Event
text: Bruce Springsteen and Jon Stewart will return to Madison Square Garden to headline the ninth annual Stand Up for Heroes performance on Nov. 10. Presented by the Bob Woodruff Foundation and the New York Comedy Festival, the performance also stars Seth Meyers, John Oliver and Ray Romano and will raise money to support wounded veterans and their families.

headline: ‘London Fields’ Premiere in Toronto Troubled by Creative Rift
text: TORONTO — It has not been hard to spot Johnny Depp at the giant film festival here. Monday night, he walked the red carpet with his wife, Amber Heard, to celebrate a showing of his movie “Black Mass.” Two days earlier, it was Mr. Depp on Ms. Heard’s arm, at a screening of “The Danish Girl,” of which she is a star.

headline: Brooklyn Man Sought in Similar Deaths of 2 Women at Hotels
text: It was July 23 when the first woman was discovered dead in Room 3 of a Brooklyn hotel, her body bearing the telltale signs of strangulation, the police said. On Sept. 8, a second woman was found dead, this time at a hotel in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Street Style: A Colorful Mix
text: The style on the street during New York Fashion Week is a changeable as the weather.

headline: David Chang Opens Fuku+ in Midtown
text: Fuku+ Across the street from Harry Winston’s rocks, you can now get a heaping bowl of crisp chicken nuggets with jade-green hot sauce for just $6. It’s one of the items at the new Midtown edition of Fuku, the fried-chicken-sandwich cubbyhole that David Chang recently opened in the East Village. Crunchy salt-and-pepper head-on shrimp, several salads and flatbread slathered with nubbly Sichuan pork are served along with beer, wine and cocktails. The space, inside the Chambers Hotel, is at street level, behind the Milk Bar stand and overlooking Má Pêche below. Set menu packages, serving up to eight people, can be ordered ahead online. The little restaurant has some unexpected extras, like waiter service and Bob Dylan and Waylon Jennings on the playlist to ramp up the energy of the crowd at the counter and high-top tables: 15 West 56th Street, momofuku.com.

headline: Russia Resisting Europe Request for Tough U.N. Anti-Smuggling Step
text: UNITED NATIONS — A European bid to obtain Security Council approval for a military operation against boats suspected of human smuggling on the Mediterranean Sea is running into opposition from Russia, which wants to ensure that it cannot be used to justify a broader military intervention, diplomats here said.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 2: Waiver Wire Picks
text: The N.F.L. had a fair number of injuries in Week 1, some more significant than others. Injuries are a main contributor to the emergence of waiver wire darlings, and because nobody wins a fantasy football league on draft day, it is crucial to be on top of the free-agent pool. Here are the best waiver wire picks after the first week (ownership percentages based on Yahoo leagues).

headline: Extreme Downhill Biking
text: The mountain biker Primoz Ravnik rode down a steep 200-foot dam spillway in Zirovnica, Slovenia.

headline: The Fixers Who Rescue Dye Jobs Gone Wrong
text: Jennifer Humphrey sat rigidly on a couch at the Sally Hershberger Downtown salon, her eyes darting across the waiting area.

headline: New High-Shine Lip Glosses for Fall
text: This fall, a handful of companies are offering alternatives to the stainlike matte lipsticks that have been popular for the last few seasons: shiny lip glosses, some in highly pigmented formulas that add a surprisingly vivid swipe of color.

headline: Coming Soon to Facebook: A ‘Dislike’ Button
text: Facebook’s famous “like” button, with its silhouette of an upturned thumb, will soon be accompanied by an alternative: a way to “dislike” a post.

headline: Ted Cruz Ad Uses Scorpion to Depict Threat of Islamic Terror
text: For aficionados of political ads, the line “There’s a bear in the woods” still brings a shivery memory of a 1984 spot for Ronald Reagan that helped define his foreign policy of peace through strength.

headline: Cuomo and Christie Say States Can Pay Half of Hudson Rail Tunnel Project
text: The governors of New York and New Jersey sent a letter to President Obama on Tuesday offering to line up funding for half of the costs of new Hudson River rail tunnels if the federal government pledges grants for the other half.

headline: Protests at Annual Bull-Killing Festival
text: Demonstrators attended the annual Toro de la Vega festival in the Spanish town of Tordesillas last year to protest the traditional bull-spearing event.

headline: Charlie Hebdo Mocks Europe’s Response to Migrant Crisis With Cartoons of Dead Syrian Boy
text: French illustrators have been denounced on social networks in recent days for publishing editorial cartoons inspired by photographs of Aylan Kurdi, a 3-year-old Syrian boy whose drowning in the waters off Greece this month prompted an outpouring of sympathy for refugees.

headline: Looking for Conventions, Cities Add Hotel Rooms
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — When Kansas City failed to make the cut for the 2016 Republican National Convention, some officials chalked it up to politics.

headline: Online Ad for Jeb Bush Paints Dark Picture of Donald Trump
text: [Video: Watch on YouTube.]

headline: Reactions Vary to News of New ‘Mary Poppins’ Film
text: LOS ANGELES – Disney is developing a new “Mary Poppins” film. Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious? Or something quite atrocious?

headline: ‘The Nightly Show With Larry Wilmore’ Renewed Through End of 2016
text: Larry Wilmore and his staff at “The Nightly Show” now have certainty that they will be keeping it 100 through the end of next year and for the duration of the presidential election: Comedy Central said on Tuesday that it had renewed the news-satire series through the end of 2016, confirming a report that first appeared on CNN.com.

headline: Police Discuss Charges in Baruch Hazing
text: Chief Chris Wagner of the Pocono Mountain Regional Police Department said Tuesday that a grand jury had recommended that fraternity members face charges in the death of a Baruch College freshman.

headline: Rand Paul to Run Ad During Debate Calling Himself ‘a Real Conservative’
text: Senator Rand Paul is not betting that his time on the stage during the Republican presidential debate on Wednesday night will be enough to get his message out and re-energize his campaign. So he is buying time on CNN, the network hosting the debate, so he can run an ad during the commercial breaks.

headline: Diesel Black Gold: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The latest collection from the label.

headline: Legislators in Missouri Take Aim at Union Dues
text: AFFTON, Mo. — During a recent visit to this working-class suburb of St. Louis, Gov. Jay Nixon told cheering union workers that he would fight to preserve a bedrock of labor organizing: the right to require workers, including those who opt out of joining a union, to pay dues or their equivalent.

headline: Chinese-American Cleared of Spying Charges Now Faces Firing
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Government officials say they intend to fire a Chinese-American hydrologist who was prosecuted but eventually cleared of espionage-related charges.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.

headline: Review: Comedy Central’s ‘Moonbeam City’ Recalls the World of ‘Miami Vice’
text: If you were a graphic artist, a Duran Duran fan or, really, just someone with eyes during the late 1970s and early ’80s, you know the work of Patrick Nagel. His flat, Art Deco-ish illustrations of women, their features reduced to pouting lips and dramatic eyes, were ubiquitous for a time, gracing the pages of Playboy, the cover of Duran Duran’s “Rio” album and, as the art critic Peter Plagens wrote in The New York Times, “hairdressing salons and white-shag-carpet condos from Coral Gables to La Jolla.”

headline: Review: ‘Peace Officer’ Explores Military-Style Raids by Law Enforcement
text: “Peace Officer,” a documentary about the militarization of law enforcement, is nothing if not timely, though its focus is mostly confined to one state.

headline: Review: ‘Tree of Codes,’ an Explosion of Energy in a Sea of More
text: Arrive early to “Tree of Codes,” the dance spectacle at the Park Avenue Armory, and you can spend some time observing your shadow, psychedelically multiplied, along the walls of the 55,000-square-foot Wade Thompson Drill Hall. Audience members lingered there, Instagramming, at the New York premiere on Monday. That installation, by the Danish-Icelandic visual artist Olafur Eliasson, turns out to be one of the more subtle elements in this high-profile collaboration, which features Mr. Eliasson’s visual design, a score by the English composer Jamie xx and choreography — lots of it — by Wayne McGregor.

headline: New Website Aims to Provide Guidance to Theater Fans
text: There are web sites that aggregate film reviews, and those that compare prices for all kinds of products. But the theater business has traditionally been seen as too small, and the shelf life of shows too short, to sustain such technology for Broadway.

headline: A Migration Juggernaut Is Headed for Europe
text: European leaders probably don’t want to hear this now, as they frantically try to close their borders to stop hundreds of thousands of desperate migrants and asylum seekers escaping hunger and violence in Africa and the Middle East. But they are dealing with the unstoppable force of demography.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Surfer Vibes on the Runway
text: Memories of the beach are, evidently, still lingering in the minds of New Yorkers: So far this season, several designers have included nods to surf culture in their spring/summer shows. At Altuzarra, an acid-green tie-dyed dress came down the runway, unbuttoned to expose a bra underneath. At Victoria Beckham, the inspiration was more literal: abstract drawings of surfers appeared on zip jackets, low-cut dresses and skirts. And at Tommy Hilfiger, the island-themed runway featured colorful, striped Baja pullover sweaters — a tried and true surfer staple.

headline: Bezos Announces Rocket Launch Site
text: Jeffrey P. Bezos, the founder of Amazon and the chief executive of Blue Origin, revealed plans to build a rocket manufacturing plant and use a launch site in Florida.

headline: Democrats Move to Beef Up Fund-Raising With Staff Overhaul
text: The Democratic National Committee is moving to drastically beef up its fund-raising arm, adding a finance co-chairman to the current one, who has at times prompted controversy, and announcing six others to leadership positions to help raise money for the 2016 presidential race.

headline: G.O.P. Discord Over Ex-Im Bank Intensifies, as G.E. Shifts Jobs Abroad
text: WASHINGTON — General Electric announced plans on Tuesday to move 500 jobs overseas, and Boeing said it had lost a second foreign satellite contract in weeks, developments that both corporate giants blamed on the Republican-led Congress’s failure to keep the federal Export-Import Bank open to help finance new deals.

headline: The GoPro That Fell to Earth
text: In June 2013, members of the Grand Canyon Stratospheric Balloon Team launched a balloon with a camera into the stratosphere, where it burst. It was found by a hiker two years later.

headline: Milly: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The spring 2016 collection.

headline: Review: Circuit des Yeux, With Haley Fohr’s Deep Vocals, Seeks an Essential Truth
text: A full-band Circuit des Yeux show these days is a forceful and elegant process with resonance and harmony and drones, a gathering force around its deep-voiced pressure center, the singer, guitarist and songwriter Haley Fohr. I’ve seen two over the last month. I could see another right now.

headline: Sale of Twombly Work to Help Fund Expansion of Wilshire Boulevard Temple in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES — It’s become something of an art-market trope to say that for the price of a single painting by a blue-chip artist you could pay for an entire building by a well-known architect.

headline: Review: Making Connections at Istanbul’s Biennial
text: ISTANBUL — Three years ago, the American-Italian curator Carolyn Christov-Bakargiev garnered ecstatic reviews for her edition of Documenta, the superexhibition that takes place every five years in Kassel, Germany. Challenging and disorderly, it dissolved borders among art, history and science, placing contemporary art alongside Afghan antiquities, objects from Hitler’s apartment and meteorites.

headline: Martin McDonagh’s ‘Hangmen,’ a Mordant Stage Homecoming in London
text: LONDON — In 2000, the bad-boy playwright Martin McDonagh accused the Royal Court Theater here of cowardice for declining to stage his ultraviolent Irish Republican Army-themed play, “The Lieutenant of Inishmore.”

headline: Review: ‘Pawn Sacrifice,’ Another Take on the Royal Game
text: It was a challenge to play Bobby Fischer in chess, and it’s a challenge for an actor to play him on the screen. Anyone taking on the task needs to be careful not to get carried away with the man’s eccentricities, to make sure to retain the pathos beneath the sideshow.

headline: Review: ‘Storm, Still,’ a Riff on ‘King Lear’ in a Brooklyn Backyard
text: The playwright Gabrielle Reisman has taken that “All the world’s a stage” business to heart. And she has taken it home: Her tumbledown backyard in the wilds of Bushwick is the setting for her minor but likable “Storm, Still.”

headline: Nicolas Berggruen Wants to Bridge the East-West Gap
text: Western universities and private philanthropists have poured resources into China in recent years, funding scholarships, campuses and other initiatives to bridge the gap between East and West.

text: The photographer Robin Hammond traveled to seven countries to make portraits of L.G.B.T. individuals who had been attacked because of their sexual orientation.

headline: Video Retrieved From GoPro Balloon That Soared to Nearly 100,000 Feet
text: Strapped to a weather balloon bound for space, this GoPro camera soared almost 100,000 feet, into the stratosphere, to capture high-resolution footage of the Grand Canyon in 2013. An hour and a half into its flight the balloon burst and the camera plummeted back to earth.

headline: Hewlett-Packard to Cut About 10 Percent of Work Force
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — A year ago, Meg Whitman announced she was cutting Hewlett-Packard in two. On Tuesday, she detailed job cuts expected at the company.

headline: Paul Taylor American Modern Dance Announces New Season
text: The reinvented Paul Taylor American Modern Dance, which had its inaugural season at Lincoln Center earlier this year, will return next spring to present the fruits of its latest venture, Taylor Company Commissions.

headline: Review: ‘The Fool’ Is Yuri Bykov’s Look at Corruption
text: The dreary unidentified Russian town that is the setting of Yuri Bykov’s devastating film, “The Fool,” is an outpost of hell. If you can bear to look at it, I recommend you pay a visit and study it from behind bulletproof glass, because similar places aren’t all that uncommon.

headline: How the New York Times/CBS News Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 9 to 13 with 1,261 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 1,021 said they were registered to vote.

headline: More Republicans See Donald Trump as a Winner, Poll Finds
text: Republicans increasingly think that Donald J. Trump has the best chance of winning the 2016 presidential election as their nominee as confidence fades in traditional politicians like Jeb Bush and Scott Walker, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: A Conversation With Steven Rutter
text: Mr. Rutter, 56, is the director of Stribling Marketing Associates, a division of the Stribling & Associates boutique brokerage firm, which focuses on new residential developments in New York City. Among the projects currently being marketed are 252 East 57th Street, 210 West 77th Street and the Philip House at 141 East 88th Street.

headline: Champions League Comes Before Domestic Ones for Some Top Clubs
text: PARIS — One of the great, if occasionally confusing, aspects of European soccer is the sheer number of opportunities that exist for someone — anyone — to win something. It has not gotten so bad that associations are handing out participation trophies (yet), but in many of the big soccer countries, so many competitions run concurrently in any given season that it can sometimes feel like an exercise in memorization to simply keep track of them all.

headline: A New York Times/CBS News Poll on the State of the Presidential Race
text: Republicans increasingly think that Donald J. Trump has the best chance of winning the 2016 election as their nominee, but support for Ben Carson is up since August, according to a New York Times/CBS News nationwide poll.

headline: De Blasio to Announce 10-Year Deadline to Offer Computer Science to All Students
text: To ensure that every child can learn the skills required to work in New York City’s fast-growing technology sector, Mayor Bill de Blasio will announce on Wednesday that within 10 years all of the city’s public schools will be required to offer computer science to all students.

headline: Why Is That Dog Looking at Me?
text: Among the deep and intriguing phenomena that attract intense scientific interest are the birth and death of the universe, the intricacies of the human brain and the way dogs look at humans.

headline: London Theater Journal: Getting Giddy
text: LONDON – There was a time when “caper,” used as an adjective, signaled an especially sprightly form of entertainment. It usually meant a movie or play that involved a heist or a theft, or some sort of illicit deception, and bristled with lively counterplots and sexual intrigue. Caper is now an anachronistic word, and the light-handed, light-fingered genre it once stood for has been largely eclipsed, at least on screen, by more adrenalized, special-effects-heavy fare.

headline: A Chinese Social Media Star Comes to Fashion Week
text: With a name like Leaf Greener (a literal translation of her Chinese name, Ye Zi) and clothing that ranges from a  yolk-yellow Rosie Assoulin pantsuit at noon to a lacy Ronald van der Kemp evening gown after dark, surely you can make an impression during New York Fashion Week.

headline: Norman L. Farberow Is Dead at 97; Took Study of Suicide to Academic Fore
text: Norman L. Farberow, a psychologist who was a founder of the nation’s first comprehensive suicide prevention center and helped bring the study of suicide into the academic mainstream, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 97.

headline: Sophie Theallet: Spring 206 RTW
text: The spring 2016 collection.

headline: Analysts Detail Claims That Reports on ISIS Were Distorted
text: WASHINGTON — A group of intelligence analysts have provided investigators with documents they say show that senior military officers manipulated the conclusions of reports on the war against the Islamic State, according to several government officials, as lawmakers from both parties voiced growing anger that they may have received a distorted picture about the military campaign’s progress.

headline: David Feherty Moves From CBS to NBC and Golf Channel
text: Golf announcers do not often defect from one network to another, so David Feherty’s move from CBS Sports to NBC and Golf Channel is unusual.

headline: Dentsply to Acquire Sirona Dental for $5.5 Billion
text: Two of the biggest makers of dental products said on Tuesday that they had agreed to combine, betting on bigger scale to take advantage of growing demand for dentistry work.

headline: How to Use a Standing Desk Without Annoying Your Co-Workers
text: As with any new piece of automated equipment, navigating the proper etiquette of standing desks can involve a bit of a learning curve.

headline: What to Wear at a Standing Desk
text: Lisa Raphael, who leads the editorial team at the website Brit & Co, tried out a standing desk in the hope it would help her scoliosis and back pain. “It’s been a big health trend readers are responding to,” she said. “And I’ve read all the studies that sitting is the new smoking for our generation.”

headline: BTG Pactual Is Cleared to Acquire Swiss Private Bank BSI
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Brazilian investment bank BTG Pactual has received approval from the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority to acquire the Swiss private bank BSI, and in doing so concluded the transaction, the firm, based in São Paulo, said on Tuesday.

headline: Off The Runway: Day 6
text: Scenes from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Back to School With Thom Browne and Rodarte
text: One of the weirder coincidences of New York Fashion Week is that it starts, almost exactly, on the first day of school in most of the city. The parallels of children going back to class and fashion going back to shows are hard to ignore. There’s something about the beginning of the season that feels like a continuing education course: The subjects, broadly, are the same, but the curriculum has been updated. It’s a week of cramming.

headline: Closing the Back Door to Europe
text: In recent months European nations have worked to block the main route taken by migrants fleeing war and upheaval.

headline: Senate Democrats Again Block Vote to Reject Iran Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats on Tuesday blocked another vote on a resolution disapproving of the Iran nuclear deal, reprising the result of a vote last week.

headline: Grim Search in the Aftermath of a Flood
text: Residents of Hildale, Utah, looked for the victims of Monday’s flash fooding.

headline: Msgr. Mark Miles, Pope’s English Translator, Braces for the U.S. Spotlight
text: ROME — On a blustery day in January this year, Pope Francis appeared before thousands of worshipers in Tacloban City, the Philippines, and asked for permission to give his address in Spanish.

headline: Misidentified and Tackled by the New York Police, but No Tennis Star Treatment
text: It was February and the streets were crusted with winter, not a September day steeped in high-noon mugginess. The scene was the street outside a barber shop on Teller Avenue in the Bronx, not the entrance to the Grand Hyatt New York hotel on East 42nd Street in Manhattan. And the person taken to the ground was an 11-year-old girl, not an internationally known former tennis star.

text: Peter Copping’s spring collection.

headline: Cardiologist Nominated to Be Head of F.D.A.
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday nominated Dr. Robert Califf, a cardiologist and clinical researcher long affiliated with Duke University, to be the commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: Autoworkers’ Union Reaches Tentative Deal With Fiat Chrysler
text: DETROIT — Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and the United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative agreement on Tuesday on a new contract that could establish a pattern for labor deals at the other two American carmakers, General Motors and Ford.

headline: Oklahoma: Governor Refuses Request to Delay Execution
text: Gov. Mary Fallin said Tuesday that she would not delay the execution of Richard Glossip, who is to die on Wednesday for arranging a murder in 1997. Mr. Glossip’s defense lawyers, the anti-death penalty campaigner Sister Helen Prejean, the Innocence Project and others had publicized what they call significant new evidence casting doubt on his guilt. His conviction rested largely on the testimony of the admitted killer, who was spared the death penalty in return for testifying that Mr. Glossip was the mastermind. But Ms. Fallin said she had seen “no credible evidence of Richard Glossip’s innocence.” Late Tuesday, his lawyers filed a new request for a stay of execution with the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals, arguing that in view of the new evidence, he “would be acquitted at trial today.”

headline: Charities Say U.S. Should Take Tens of Thousands of Syrians
text: Executives from leading American aid groups, watching the muddled international response to the migrant crisis with dismay, called on the United States government on Tuesday to multiply many times over its recent commitment to take 10,000 displaced Syrians in the next year.

headline: Suit Accusing Dakota Co-op Board of Bias Against Blacks and Hispanics Fails
text: A judge in Manhattan has dismissed a lawsuit brought by the financier Alphonse Fletcher Jr. against the Dakota building, ruling that Mr. Fletcher had failed to provide evidence that the celebrated building’s co-op board had discriminated against him because he is black.

headline: Patrick Kane’s Status Is Shrouded in Silence
text: Patrick Kane skates with grace, a raw-boned little man with a preternatural feel for the game and an asp’s bite of a backhand shot. He has hoisted the Stanley Cup over his head three times, most recently when the Chicago Blackhawks won the championship in June.

headline: Attitudes Shift on Paid Leave: Dads Sue, Too
text: WASHINGTON — For decades, women who believed their employers had punished them with lower wages and missed promotions after they had become mothers have been filing gender discrimination complaints and bringing lawsuits.

headline: Frantic Evacuation in California Left Animals to Face Wildfire Alone
text: MIDDLETOWN, Calif. — When the Valley Fire blew up in this rural area 100 miles north of San Francisco last weekend, many residents fled with only the clothes they were wearing. The suddenness of the fire’s surge — half an hour from warning to life-threatening conflagration in many parts of Lake County — sent people scattering, their homes undefended and possessions left to fate or luck.

headline: Obama Weighing Talks With Putin on Syrian Crisis
text: WASHINGTON — For more than a year, President Obama has resisted meeting one on one with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and only reluctantly taken a phone call, freezing out the Kremlin leader over his intervention in Ukraine in their own personal cold war.

headline: In Search for Athletic Directors, Women Are Neglected in Texas and Beyond
text: Now that the front door has slammed on Steve Patterson, who had been Texas’ athletic director for nearly two years before he and the university decided to part ways on Tuesday, it should have been simple for Greg Fenves, the university’s president, to find an immediate replacement.

headline: Striking Seattle Teachers Poised to Return to Classroom
text: Teachers in Seattle public schools suspended a nearly weeklong strike on Tuesday, announcing that they had agreed on a new contract with the city’s school board. Classes are to resume on Thursday.

text: Florals mingled with leather biker jackets on the spring/summer 2016 runway.

text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I liked this puzzle by Joel Fagliano and Finn Vigeland very much and I’ll get to that in a minute. But first, a personal note to younger constructors from solvers of “a certain age”:

headline: Adam Purple, Eccentric Environmentalist and Gardener in New York, Dies at 84
text: The man with the flowing white beard was a familiar presence for decades on the streets of the Lower East Side of Manhattan where he squatted in an abandoned building, created an elaborate, renowned garden and often wore royal-hued clothes that reflected the best known of his many adopted names: Adam Purple.

headline: Retribution Increases Against Those Aiding Human Rights Inquiries
text: GENEVA — Those who give evidence to United Nations human rights investigators are facing increasingly severe reprisals, the United Nations Human Rights Council said Tuesday in a report naming 20 countries that took action against rights defenders and activists in the past year.

headline: U.S. Judge Upholds Right to Scrawl Nasty Note on Speeding Ticket Payment
text: It began with a speeding ticket given in upstate New York to a man whose response was, to put it mildly, less than polite. He sent back a payment form with a scribbled five-word expression of vulgarity, and crossed out the town’s name.

headline: Marlins Rock Jacob deGrom, and the Mets’ Playoff Express Stalls for a Night
text: The Mets gathered in center field dressed in their pearly white pinstriped uniforms for their annual team picture Tuesday afternoon. They took their places, with their hands behind their backs — the young pitchers, the midseason acquisitions and the veterans who had posed for several of these before. This group would be commemorated, at the least, as the team that ended the Mets’ streak of six consecutive losing seasons.

headline: Struggles at Plate Continue as Yanks Lose to Rays
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Jacoby Ellsbury stood outside the cage, waiting for his turn during batting practice and bouncing a baseball off the head of his bat over and over.

headline: Melvin Bernhardt, Tony-Winning Director Who Helped Stars Shine, Dies at 84
text: Melvin Bernhardt, who directed two Pulitzer Prize-winning dramas and won a Tony himself for Hugh Leonard’s Tony-winning play “Da,” died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Who’s Winning the Presidential Campaign?
text: History suggests that each party’s eventual nominee will emerge from 2015 in one of the top two or three positions, as measured by endorsements, fund-raising and polling.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) BREATHLESS (1961) Turner Classic Movies pays tribute to the director Jean-Luc Godard, starting with this New Wave classic about two erratic days in the lives of star-crossed young lovers — Jean-Paul Belmondo, as a French hoodlum on the lam after killing a cop, and Jean Seberg, as an American expatriate newspaper vendor — living in Paris. As sordid as the film is, “and sordid is really a mild word for its pile-up of gross indecencies,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times, it is no cliché — rather “more a chunk of raw drama, graphically and artfully torn with appropriately ragged edges out of the tough underbelly of modern metropolitan life.” The evening continues with “Pierrot le Fou” (1968), featuring Mr. Belmondo as an unhappily married man who abandons his bourgeois life for a crime spree with an ex-girlfriend (Anna Karina), at 10:15; “Masculin Féminin” (1966), about an aspiring writer (Jean-Pierre Léaud) who becomes involved with a rising pop star (Chantal Goya) and her roommates, at 12:15 a.m.; “Alphaville” (1965), in which a private investigator (Eddie Constantine) is sent to rescue a scientist from a future world ruled by computers, at 2:15; and “A Woman Is a Woman” (1964), about an exotic dancer (Ms. Karina) intent on finding a man to father a child, at 4. (Image: Ms. Seberg and Mr. Belmondo.)

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “We hope that the messages we have been sending migrants for a long time have reached them. Don’t come.”

headline: A Very Unusual Subway Stop in New York
text: New York City’s long-suffering commuters might be wise to avoid a glittering new subway stop on the No. 7 line that opened Sunday at Hudson Yards on the West Side of Manhattan. After seeing the $2.4 billion station that has ignited a burst of development in this once-grim industrial area, riders may find it hard to return to the grime so typical of New York City’s vast 660-mile public transit system. And while no single station can be as sleek, efficient and “air tempered” as this one, commuters will almost certainly find themselves asking why the system as a whole cannot be greatly improved.

headline: Iran Deal Players’ Report Cards
text: The Iran nuclear deal is now sealed — from Washington’s end. But since this has been one of America’s most important foreign policy shifts in the last four decades, it’s worth looking back and grading the performance of the key players.

headline: Constitutionally, Slavery Is No National Institution
text: THE Civil War began over a simple question: Did the Constitution of the United States recognize slavery — property in humans — in national law? Southern slaveholders, inspired by Senator John C. Calhoun of South Carolina, charged that it did and that the Constitution was proslavery; Northern Republicans, led by Abraham Lincoln, and joined by abolitionists including Frederick Douglass, resolutely denied it. After Lincoln’s election to the presidency, 11 Southern states seceded to protect what the South Carolina secessionists called their constitutional “right of property in slaves.”

headline: Can Anything Be Done About All the Money in Politics?
text: Nearly everyone in America agrees that there is too much influence-seeking money in politics, except for the people who benefit from it. Public concern over the potential for corruption in this flood of cash has resulted, over the past half century, in five separate approaches to the regulation of campaign finance.

headline: In Yemen, Death From Above, Grief Below
text: SANA, Yemen — LEWZA was my sister-in-law. She was a good person, one of the kindest I have ever known.

headline: With Possible Shutdown Nearing, Obama Looks to Take Budget Fight to G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — Congress hurtled toward a government shutdown on Tuesday, with Republicans threatening to block a budget deal if it includes financing for Planned Parenthood, as President Obama prepared to join the fight by pushing Republicans to scrap a multibillion-dollar tax advantage for private equity managers.

headline: Should Fraternities and Sororities Be Coed?
text: Making Greek brothers and sisters one big family on campus.

headline: My Silver Hair
text: In this short animation, a New Yorker explains why she wears her hair in its natural color.

headline: ‘My Silver Hair’
text: When I was in college, I met a beautiful woman in her early 20s who had a full head of gray hair. At first, I pitied her for being so radiant and yet cursed with such a glaring blemish. But after talking with her for just a few seconds I realized it wasn’t her appearance that I was attracted to — gray hair or not — but her confidence and poise. Her clear self-acceptance, regardless of how others might view her, impressed me so deeply that 30 years later, I still remember the chance meeting. Today, all I remember about her was her hair color and her confidence.

headline: News Q’s | Instead of Arrests, Subway Dancers Are Getting a Stage Above Ground
text: In “Instead of Arrests, Subway Dancers Are Getting a Stage Above Ground,” J. David Goodman and Matt Flegenheimer write about a new police strategy.

headline: Migrants Clash With Police in Hungary, as Others Enter Croatia
text: HORGOS, Serbia — In one of the worst bursts of violence that this tense refugee summer has seen, Hungarian riot police responded on Wednesday to rocks, taunts and small fires set by agitated migrants at the border crossing here with water cannons, head-cracking batons and both tear gas and pepper spray.

headline: Living in Midwood, Brooklyn
text: Families are attracted to Midwood, Brooklyn, which offers relatively inexpensive homes and tree-lined streets.

headline: Midwood, Brooklyn, Where Urban and Suburban Meet
text: The tree-lined streets of Midwood, with many single- and multifamily houses at prices that are relatively inexpensive for Brooklyn, naturally attract plenty of families. In fact, the basketball hoops dotting the driveways, and the Cozy Coupes and tricycles scattered along the sidewalks, might make visitors wonder if they were still in New York City.

headline: The Travel Jacket Geeks Adore
text: I hate my kettle.

headline: Donald Trump Adds Something Unexpected to His Campaign: Discipline
text: Donald J. Trump, once a great improviser, has started relying on prepared notes when he gives speeches.

headline: A Building That Resembles What It Stores: Salt for New York City’s Roads
text: Imagine a coarse chunk of gray salt 69 feet high.

headline: Clive Owen, Suave and Roguish, on Making His Broadway Debut in ‘Old Times’
text: Clive Owen has chosen Fanelli Cafe in SoHo as the place to submit to an interview, and there’s a logic to that. He’s the star of “The Knick” — a television series set in Lower Manhattan at the turn of the 20th century that has featured opium dens and race riots — and Fanelli sits in a 168-year-old building that at various times served as brothel, African-American boardinghouse and speakeasy.

headline: Which 2016 Presidential Candidates Interest You Most?
text: More than a dozen Republicans and a handful of Democrats have announced that they are running for their party’s 2016 presidential nomination, and the second Republican presidential debate airs on Sept. 16.

headline: U.N. Urges Sri Lanka to Establish Court to Investigate War Abuses
text: GENEVA — Rejecting Sri Lanka’s offer to set up a truth and reconciliation commission to address grievances from its 26-year civil war, the United Nations on Wednesday called for it to set up a special court, including international judges and lawyers, to investigate what it called “horrific” abuses committed by both sides.

headline: Elizabeth Gilbert’s ‘Big Magic’
text: Elizabeth Gilbert’s memoir “Eat, Pray, Love” sold 10 million copies and became the kind of cultural touchstone that makes its author famous, wealthy and controversial. To the book’s fans, including Oprah Winfrey and Julia Roberts (who starred in the movie adaptation), Gilbert’s tale of overcoming a bad divorce and deep depression by traveling to Italy, India and Indonesia in search of pleasure, devotion and balance felt like an authentic and moving search for happiness and enlightenment. To her critics, many of whom never even read it, “Eat, Pray, Love” was a cannily constructed narrative with a pat happy ending that preached personal satisfaction as the highest goal, one you could attain by throwing money around, especially in the third world.

headline: ‘Finale,’ by Thomas Mallon
text: Readers of “Finale,” Thomas Mallon’s sly and penetrating ninth novel, are well aware that the book’s protagonist, the nation’s 40th president, is destined to be revered as the Republican Party’s patron saint, his very name synonymous with conservative virtue. However, none of the novel’s characters know this in real time. “Finale” takes place primarily in 1986, two years after Ronald Reagan’s final triumphant campaign and two years before he vacates the White House for good. His presidential legacy is on the line, and the events of 1986 — a fateful nuclear arms meeting in Reykjavik with Mikhail Gorbachev and the brewing Iran-contra scandal — threaten to undo it. The sense of foreboding, bordering at times on panic, that pervades this work of historical fiction stands as an arresting contrast to today’s notion of the unassailable Teflon president.

headline: A Sprained Ankle May Have Lifelong Consequences
text: Tens of thousands of Americans sprain an ankle every year. But ankle sprains get little respect, with most of us shrugging off the injury as inconsequential and soon returning to normal activities.

headline: Sri Lanka Official on Reconciliation

headline: Fate of Corfu Airport Puts Greek Bailout Deal to the Test
text: CORFU, Greece — In the running debate over how to revive the Greek economy, there is one thing that locals and foreigners can agree on: The airport on this resort island, like many others in tourist-dependent Greece, does not befit a eurozone country.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Approaches SABMiller on Possible Takeover
text: At a time when investors are nervous and antitrust regulators are suspicious, the prospect of a $100 billion-plus merger on the horizon may seem remote.

headline: The Rituals of Modern Death
text: Before I was an intern standing in the middle of the night over a pale, motionless woman about to certify her death, I had a very different vision of what a person’s final moment would be like. Like many young people, my exposure to death was confined to stories others had told me or depictions of deaths on television. I didn’t see the true face of death until I was the one filling out the death certificate.

headline: Today in Politics: Republicans Are Set to Grapple Again Under Reagan’s Wing
text: Good Debate Day morning. As the Republican candidates prepare for their second showdown, a New York Times/CBS poll shows that the party’s primary and caucus voters increasingly think that Donald J. Trump has the best chance of winning the general election. The poll results could give the other candidates further reason to direct their attack plans toward him, starting, perhaps, tonight.

headline: Watching the Planet Burn
text: Unearthly images of fire in the West.

headline: Kate McKinnon Hates Letting Her Hair Down
text: You spent your summer filming the new ‘‘Ghostbusters’’ movie in Boston. Do you believe in ghosts? Absolutely not.

headline: Netromancy
text: When Bri Luna started her website, the Hoodwitch, she intended to carry on the legacy of her grandmother, who was a curandera: a traditional spiritual healer from Mexico. Luna, a beautician in her 20s who lives in Seattle, uses the site to publish tutorials on topics like how to cleanse a new home by burning sage and how the lunar cycles affect your daily life. What started out as a hobby became so popular that Luna turned it into a business, opening an online shop where she sells crystal clusters, bundles of dried herbs and vintage tarot guides.

headline: Should I Help a Classmate Who Sexually Harassed My Friend Get a Job?
text: At work, we fill a lot of vacant positions through word of mouth. I recently posted a job on my college’s career network and received a résumé from someone in my graduating class. I’ve never met this person, and I know him to have been a diligent student who won a prestigious fellowship during senior year. He would probably be a leading candidate, and by passing his résumé on, I would be implicitly giving my stamp of approval. The problem is that freshman year he sexually harassed and attempted to sexually assault a good friend of mine. A third party intervened before it escalated and brought her to me and another friend. She decided not to take the incident to any authority, and she eventually worked through the experience. The thought of working with the man who brought so much pain to a good friend is hard to swallow, but I do not know what the ethical thing to do is. It is not my story to share, and I do not want to bring the question to my friend for fear of opening old wounds. Am I allowed to share this information with the head of human resources? Can I take an act committed five years ago by somebody I never met and use it to determine his future job status? Is there a way to bring up my discomfort without outing him? NAME WITHHELD

headline: Barbie Wants to Get to Know Your Child
text: It looked like a child’s playroom: toys in cubbies, a little desk for doing homework, a whimsical painting of a tree on the wall. A woman and a girl entered and sat down in plump papasan chairs, facing a low table that was partly covered by a pink tarp. The wall opposite them was mirrored from floor to ceiling, and behind it, unseen in a darkened room, a half-dozen employees of the toy company Mattel sat watching through one-way glass. The girl, who looked about 7, wore a turquoise sweatshirt and had her dark hair pulled back in a ponytail. The woman, a Mattel child-testing specialist named Lindsey Lawson, had sleek dark hair and the singsong voice of a kindergarten teacher. Microphones hidden in the room transmitted what Lawson said next. ‘‘You are going to have a chance to play with a brand-new toy,’’ she told the girl, who leaned forward with her hands on her knees. Removing the pink tarp, Lawson revealed Hello Barbie.

headline: The California Wildfires: Trying to Take Control
text: Wildfires continued to simmer in bone-dry acres in Northern California on Wednesday, but firefighters said they were gaining control in some areas. The state Department of Forestry and Fire Protection, known as Cal Fire, estimated Wednesday that the Valley Fire, which had torn through more than 67,000 acres in Lake, Napa and Sonoma counties, was about 30 percent contained, with 585 homes destroyed.

The Mets would gaze to the west and see two looming figures towering over the playoff landscape. Terry Collins does not even have to use their names.

headline: How the G.O.P. Race Has Changed Since the First Debate

With the second debate scheduled for Wednesday night, we wanted to look at what has changed. (We’ve also added a Democratic scoreboard to the page, and we’ll update both every day.)

headline: Steve Rannazzisi, Comedian Who Told of 9/11 Escape, Admits He Lied

headline: Handcuffed for Making Clock, Ahmed Mohamed, 14, Wins Time With Obama
text: HOUSTON — Ahmed Mohamed’s homemade alarm clock got him suspended from his suburban Dallas high school and detained and handcuffed by police officers on Monday after school officials accused him of making a fake bomb. By Wednesday, it had brought him an invitation to the White House, support from Hillary Rodham Clinton and Mark Zuckerberg, and a moment of head-spinning attention as questions arose whether he had been targeted because of his name and his religion.

headline: The Rolled R’s of Vanessa Ruiz
text: AMHERST, Mass. — RATHER than simply delivering the news, Vanessa Ruiz, an anchor for 12 News in Arizona, recently became news herself when her pronunciation of Spanish words drew complaints. The feeling was that, in an English-language TV newscast, she ought to be pronouncing these words the way a majority of English speakers do — and not as Spanish speakers would.

headline: For U.S. Pilots, the Real War on ISIS Is a Far Cry From ‘Top Gun’
text: ABOARD THE U.S.S. THEODORE ROOSEVELT, in the Persian Gulf — Soon after this aircraft carrier arrived here for its Middle East deployment, two F/A-18 Super Hornets catapulted off its deck for a six-and-a-half-hour bombing run toward Islamic State targets in Iraq. In one of the fighter jets was Navy Lt. Michael Smallwood, 28, call sign Bones, and in the other was his friend and roommate, Navy Lt. Nick Smith, also 28, call sign Yip Yip.

text: White clothing adds inches to the hips; it gets along with neither public transportation nor lunch. To wear it is to telegraph confidence. You either believe yourself to be thin enough, rich enough and neat enough to pull it off, or you simply don’t deign to care.

headline: 1915: New York Gasps in Heat Wave
text: NEW YORK — To-day [Sept. 16] is a sizzler. The streets in the lower part of Manhattan between the towering skyscrapers of steel and masonry are stifling with the heat reflected from all sides as well as poured down from above. Despite the busy whirring of thousands of electric fans, offices are like stokeholds, and work is subordinated to the effort to keep cool. Café bars and soda-water fountains are besieged by crowds clamoring for cool drinks, and all pretence at correct dress has been given up in the attempt to reduce discomfort. The Herald is continuing its free distribution of ice and will keep it up indefinitely as long as the hot spell lasts. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 17, 1915

text: Over a hundred people have committed suicide in Texas county jails since 2010, and the state’s jails aren’t adequately screening inmates for mental health problems, according to a report by Erica Hellerstein at ThinkProgress.

headline: 1965: Russians to Shift Space Crews
text: ATHENS — A Soviet cosmonaut who walked in space said today [Sept. 16] that his country plans to try a midspace exchange of crews on a permanent satellite before landing a man on the moon. This disclosure by Alexei Leonov indicates that the Soviet Union is attaching a different priority than the United States to the goals of putting a man on the moon. It also opens the possibility that the Russians are thinking of sending a much bigger ship to the moon than the U.S. three-man Apollo vehicle. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 17, 1965

text: “I’m the least experienced person on my engineering team at Google,” Kelly Marchisio, a 25-year-old computer programmer, told me recently. “I frankly might be one of the least experienced engineers at Google, period.”

headline: Health Care Gains, but Income Remains Stagnant, the White House Reports
text: WASHINGTON — Nearly nine million people gained health insurance last year, lowering the ranks of the uninsured to 10.4 percent of the population. But there was no statistically significant change in income for the typical American household in 2014, the Obama administration said on Wednesday.

headline: After Nepal Quakes, Worries in the Water
text: The 2015 Nepal earthquakes threatened to exacerbate the ongoing struggle with waterborne diseases by damaging already fragile sewer systems that leak pathogens into the water supply.

headline: Earthquakes Compound Nepal’s Water Worries
text: Nepal may be infamous for its dangerous peaks, but in its valleys lies a far greater threat to human life: contaminated water.

headline: SABMiller Takeover Would Shake Up Beer Industry
text: After years of speculation, Anheuser-Busch InBev has at last approached its rival SABMiller about a takeover that would create the world’s largest beer company. A deal would crown years of global consolidation of the brewing industry and incite a climactic round of regional disposals, spins and amalgamations.

headline: Promoting Inclusiveness Over Cattiness
text: For 32 years, the Peridance Capezio Center in Manhattan has welcomed everyone from Broadway professionals to absolute beginners to pursue their love of movement.

headline: A School With Room for Everyone at the Barre
text: Inside Peridance Capezio Center, a 32-year-old dance school near Union Square, things can get a little crowded. The space was once a horse-auction market, and the lobby and hallways are often sardined with dancers stretching before class or catching up over blueberry chia muffins baked in the small on-site cafe. The floor-to-ceiling mirrors in each of the six dance studios reflect a constant blur of legs and leotards.

headline: Review: ‘Best Time Ever With Neil Patrick Harris’ Tries to Reinvent the Variety Show
text: An improv class, an automobile crash test and your cousin’s home videos somehow interbred, and on Tuesday night the result turned up on NBC in the form of “Best Time Ever With Neil Patrick Harris,” a live variety show. How can three things interbreed? Hey, if you really want to reinvent something, you have to think outside the box.

headline: 10 Charged in Crackdown on Synthetic Marijuana Ring
text: Citing a surge in the use of K2, a popular synthetic drug, federal and city authorities said on Wednesday that they had begun a sweeping crackdown, with charges against an international trafficking ring and a warning that more arrests were on the way.

headline: Jaimie Alexander on a Job Where the Tattoos Are Fake but the Training Is Real
text: When Jaimie Alexander, a. k. a. Jane Doe in NBC’s “Blindspot,” crawls out of a duffel bag in the middle of Times Square, you can’t help but gawk. Virtually every inch of her body is inked in images, symbols and words, like an otherworldly treasure map.

headline: Why Americans Still Think the Economy Is Terrible
text: If your entire understanding of the economy comes from headlines about the latest economic data, you would be forgiven for thinking these are the best of times. The unemployment rate is down to 5.1 percent, after all!

headline: Two Refreshing, Cool Cocktails From Fashion Week
text: “It’s more of a party,” said the designer Jake Sargent about this season’s Simon Miller presentation. It was late last week, and he and his co-designer Daniel Corrigan were finalizing the one remaining detail of their spring/summer 2016 show: the drinks. “This season we’re heading back to the Southwest — but bringing in this Southwest Modernist vibe, so drawing a lot of inspiration from artists’ communities like Marfa and Santa Fe. We’re going to be offering a mezcal-based cocktail that really plays on that, and we’re also going to be offering a sake-based cocktail to speak to our Japanese side.”

headline: France Says It Will Join Air Campaign Against ISIS in Syria
text: PARIS — France will join the coalition of Western and Middle Eastern countries carrying out airstrikes against the Islamic State in Syria, the country’s defense minister said on Wednesday, with the first strikes likely to come in the next couple of weeks.

headline: Erroll Garner’s ‘Concert by the Sea’ Gets a New Sound
text: There’s no way Erroll Garner could have foretold, from his perch at the piano on a Monday evening almost exactly 60 years ago, that he was creating one of the most popular albums in jazz history. He probably didn’t even know tape was rolling.

headline: Panel Urges More Time on Train Safety Technology
