text: WASHINGTON — By any measure, President Obama’s effort to train a Syrian opposition army to fight the Islamic State on the ground has been an abysmal failure. The military acknowledged this week that just four or five American-trained fighters are actually fighting.

text: Milo Hamilton, who called baseball for seven major league teams over 60 years and was best known for calling Henry Aaron’s 715th home run, died on Thursday in Houston. He was 88.

text: Once upon a lifetime ago, Epiphanny Prince scored 113 points in a high school basketball game. Her phenomenal performance in 2006 broke a record set by Cheryl Miller, who had scored 105 points.

text: ROCHESTER, N.H. — As Republican presidential candidates tried to put their best spin on Wednesday night’s debate, Gov. headline: Warren Murphy, Writer and Creator of Remo Williams, Dies at 81
text: “Everyone knew why Remo Williams was going to die,” was how Warren Murphy and Dick Sapir began “Created, the Destroyer,” their first gritty thriller, in 1963.

headline: Review: A Modern Makeover for ‘Iphigenia in Aulis’
text: Enter flouncing, the ladies of the chorus. They are wearing flower-festooned headgear that Carmen Miranda might have thought appropriate for an Easter parade, with festive smiles to match. Granting that a few of these women are men in skirts, they otherwise would have fit right into a Broadway musical frolic of the 1930s, harmonizing and hoofing cheerfully behind a star like Ethel Merman.

headline: Review: ‘Hamlet in Bed’ Is Michael Laurence’s Shakespearean Take
text: A former actor with a bleeding passion to play Shakespeare’s Danish prince — and to find his mother, who gave him up for adoption — leads us on his peculiar personal odyssey in “Hamlet in Bed,” a two-character play written by and starring Michael Laurence at the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater.

headline: Review: In ‘The Christians,’ a Schism Over Fire and Brimstone
text: Religious beliefs evolve, just as people do, in ways good and bad. But they rarely change quite as suddenly as in “The Christians,” Lucas Hnath’s softly mesmerizing drama about a schism that arises in an evangelical megachurch. In this terrific play about the mystery of faith, and how religion can tear people apart just as it can bring them together, a revelation experienced by the pastor causes a potentially disastrous rupture in the congregation.

headline: 2 Rikers Guards Set Up Attack on Inmate, Officials Say
text: Two Rikers Island correction officers face charges that they settled a personal score against an inmate by orchestrating an assault on him by a group of four other inmates and falsifying paperwork to cover up their role in the attack, officials said on Thursday. The four inmates were also charged.

headline: Judge’s Ruling Awards $600,000 to Exploited Workers
text: More than six years after their rescue from virtual servitude, in which they worked for little pay in a turkey processing plant while living in a decrepit Iowa schoolhouse, more than two dozen men with intellectual disabilities will share nearly $600,000 owed to them, after a federal court order issued Thursday in Dallas.

headline: Woman Testifies That Manhattan Prosecutor Choked Her at Bar
text: The quarrel came in a long night of drinking and carousing at an Irish pub in Manhattan last Halloween, and as is often the case, the cause was trivial. An assistant district attorney, dressed as Clark Kent, was searching fruitlessly for his coat after hours of partying with friends and he picked up a woman’s purse and scarf.

headline: Bridgeport Mayor Vows to ‘Fight Like Heck’ After Losing Primary Election

headline: Lana Del Rey: She’d Be Sad, if She Cared (Which She Doesn’t)
text: Lana Del Rey looks out into the world and all she sees are stares. Cold faces, eyes hard with judgment. And lights, too — sharp beams that poke like needles and cut like lasers. For years, she has been scrutinized as intently as she’s been listened to. You would not blame her even a bit for wilting.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
text: 9 P.M. (Starz) FURY (2014) An American tank crew — its leader, Sgt. Don Collier (Brad Pitt), a.k.a. Wardaddy, and his motley crew (Michael Peña, Jon Bernthal, Shia LaBeouf and Logan Lerman) — fights its way across Germany in the spring of 1945 as the Nazis retreat toward Berlin in Hitler’s suicidal last stand. Children are conscripted and uncooperative parents murdered. And while the Allies may have momentum, the Germans still have plenty of tanks, many superior to the Americans’. David Ayer, whose drama is less an epic than a series of tense episodes, “has a way of filming violence that is both intense and matter-of-fact,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Like many other post-‘Saving Private Ryan’ combat movies, this one emphasizes the chaotic immediacy of battle, staking its claim to authenticity on the unflinching depiction of bloodshed: Heads are vaporized by mortar rounds. Limbs are severed by bursts of automatic-rifle fire. Human flesh is charred by flames and shredded by shrapnel. But within this gore-spattered, superficially nihilistic carapace is an old-fashioned platoon picture, a sensitive and superbly acted tale of male bonding under duress.” (Image: Mr. Lerman, left, and Mr. Pitt.)

headline: Mexico’s Fruitless Hunt for Justice
text: MEXICO CITY — Sept. 26 will mark a year since one of the most heinous crimes in modern Mexico, when police officers and drug cartel hit men are believed to have abducted 43 students and killed another six students or passers-by in the town of Iguala. There have been even bigger mass killings by cartels in the past, also involving the security forces who are supposed to be fighting them. But the Iguala attacks caused far more outrage because they targeted students, the police were on the front line, and they were close to the capital.

headline: The G.O.P. Plays Loser’s Poker
text: You can’t out-crazy Donald Trump. You can’t best him in half-truths that sound plausible just because you say them with forceful bluster. You can’t be scarier to Latinos than the man who threatens to round them up like stray cattle. And you can’t offend half the population more than the puffer-fish-faced plutocrat who dismisses less-attractive females as “fat pigs,” while bragging that he used to sleep with “the top women in the world.”

headline: Fantasies and Fictions at G.O.P. Debate
text: I’ve been going over what was said at Wednesday’s Republican debate, and I’m terrified. You should be, too. After all, given the vagaries of elections, there’s a pretty good chance that one of these people will end up in the White House.

headline: A Card That Gives Migrant Workers a Name
text: Almost every day, Pannalal Meghwal parks his scooter on the edge of the informal work hubs called nakkas in Ahmedabad, India, armed with registration forms and a fine-tuned sales pitch. The good-humored social worker makes his way through hundreds of lanky construction workers clustered around a chai peddler as they wait for contractors to ride up on motorcycles and hire them for the day.

headline: My Crush on Pope Francis

headline: Europe’s Dangerous Ambivalence

For us Greeks, however, as we prepare to vote on Sunday in our second national election this year, the prospect of our political impasse continuing makes us almost oblivious to the human river flowing northward through our country.

headline: How to Draw Like a Police Sketch Artist
text: Sketching a likeness for a wanted poster is the easy part, according to Stephen Mancusi, a detective who worked as a forensic artist for the New York Police Department for almost 27 years. Getting a witness to describe the face of a perpetrator is the more difficult and nuanced skill. Start by taking five or six minutes to pencil in the shape of a head of average proportions. A face tends to equal five eye-lengths across, while the width of a mouth is about the distance between pupils. Draw quickly: The movement of graphite on paper can be hypnotic. ‘‘People lose themselves watching,’’ Mancusi says. As they do, they relax and remember.

headline: Life on the Papal Beat

headline: When Is a Lease Not a Lease? When It’s an iPhone
text: APPLE is offering a new way for consumers to purchase iPhones, and while the company is calling the new system a “financing” plan, it is essentially a lease. The idea is to get people to constantly trade in their one- or two-year-old phones for the newest models. And Apple is employing a tactic similar to one that luxury carmakers use to get more people driving Mercedes-Benzes, BMWs, Audis and Lexuses that they could otherwise not afford to buy: creating a monthly payment that is appealingly low.

headline: What I Love | Julie White
text: The Broadway star lives with her dog, LuLu, in a lakefront house in Cortlandt Manor, N.Y.

headline: Julie White’s Fairy Tale Cottage
text: The Tony Award-winning actress Julie White closed on her house in Cortlandt Manor, N.Y., last year on Valentine’s Day, and really, the timing couldn’t have been more appropriate. After all, this is a love story: Girl meets boiler.

headline: In Sierra Leone, Giving the Stigma of Ebola a Good, Swift Kick
text: KENEMA, Sierra Leone — Under the hot midday sun, Erison Turay was lecturing his teammates before their first game. “Do not look happy,” he told them, as they stood there in their matching black T-shirts with the words “I Survived Ebola” in large white and red letters. “We must be serious. We must play as a remembrance for those that aren’t here.”

headline: First U.S. Airbus Factory Gives Wings to Revival in Mobile, Ala.
text: When the first convoy of airplane parts snaked through the streets on a sultry June day, it seemed as if Mardi Gras had come early to the Gulf Coast city of Mobile, Ala.

text: LONDON — As the first Russian combat aircraft arrived in Syria, the Obama administration reached out to Moscow on Friday to try to coordinate actions in the war zone and avoid an accidental escalation of one of the world’s most volatile conflicts.

headline: 1890: Actor Dion Boucicault Dies
text: NEW YORK — Mr. Dion Boucicault, the well known actor and dramatic author, died of pneumonia to-night [Sept. 18] at his residence in this city. He had for many years dwelt among us and his genial face and flowing white locks were a familiar feature at every first night. For some time past Mr. Boucicault had conducted a school of dramatic art from which he turned out some of our most promising young actors and actresses. It had been noted within the last two or three years that the veteran was getting a little stiff in his movements, but the cheery voice and jaunty Irish manner never left him to the last. His death will prove a severe shock to the profession, of which during a lifetime he was a leading ornament. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 19, 1890

headline: Steve Paxton to Receive Bessie Award for Lifetime Achievement
text: Steve Paxton, a postmodern dance pioneer and founding member of Judson Dance Theater, will receive this year’s lifetime achievement award from the New York Dance and Performance Awards, known as the Bessies.

headline: U.S. Eases Some Limits on Cuban Travel and Commerce
text: WASHINGTON — The White House on Friday announced wide-ranging changes to loosen travel, commerce and investment restrictions on Cuba, moving to fulfill President Obama’s goal of breaking down barriers between Washington and Havana even as the American embargo remains in place.

headline: A Metal Bracelet That Hurt
text: For many years, “Eugene M. Jewell” was just a name inscribed on a metal bracelet that I, like so many others, wore in the 1970s.

headline: Popcast: Jen Shyu Explores the Unknown
text: Times critics discuss the jazz artist whose music incorporates poetry and dreams.

headline: Inside the List
text: Female Acts: Chrissie Hynde’s rock ’n’ roll memoir, “Reckless,” about life as the lead singer of the Pretenders, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 7, taking its place in a wave of recent titles from the women of rock: Patti Smith’s “Just Kids,” which won the 2010 National Book Award, spent 46 weeks on the hardcover and paperback lists; Kim Gordon’s “Girl in a Band” logged a month this year; and Jewel’s “Never Broken” has just been released. Books are also on the way from Carrie Brownstein, Sinead O’Connor and others. “This is the era of the female act,” the former Rolling Stone editor (and current president of Blue Rider Press) David Rosenthal told The Washington Post this month. “Maybe that has caused overall a hunger for reading about female artists.” Maybe it has. But Hynde told The Post that gender isn’t a big part of the equation for her. “A good book is a good book. A good song is a good song,” she said. “Let me hear it, let me read it. I’m not very gender-driven.” Hynde grew up in a fairly conservative family in Akron, Ohio, and managed, apparently, to hide the more lurid elements of her rock ’n’ roll lifestyle from her mother and father. “I couldn’t have told this when my parents were alive,” she writes in a brief prologue to the memoir. “I would have had to leave out the bad language and tell a lot of lies about what I’d been doing all that time I was gone.”

headline: Burkina Faso Military Says Ousted Leaders Have Been Released
text: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Burkina Faso’s interim president, Michel Kafando, and prime minister, Isaac Zida, who were ousted in a coup this week, have been released from detention, a military spokesman said on Friday. Protests continued in the capital, Ouagadougou.

headline: Popcast: Jen Shyu and Musical Inspiration
text: Jen Shyu, whose new album “Songs and Cries of the World” comes out this week, is an improvising singer of great accomplishment who leads a band including some of the best improvising musicians in the United States: the trumpeter Ambrose Akinmusire, the violist Mat Maneri, the bassist Thomas Morgan, the drummer Dan Weiss. But she gets much of her inspiration and source material from far outside jazz. Not from pop or classical music or avant-garde traditions. But from music that she has to travel great distances to learn about, like Southern Taiwanese folk songs; or pansori, the South Korean musical storytelling tradition; or sindhenan, the improvisational singing of Javanese gamelan music. (A lot of the music she’s looking for has something to do with her own background: raised in Illinois, her parents are from Taiwan and East Timor.) She achieves fluency in new languages in order to improvise within them; she studies their narrative traditions in order to write within them.

headline: The College Access Index: A Promise to Critics
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: U.S. Repatriates Fugitive Businessman Long Sought by China
text: HONG KONG — A businessman accused of corruption has been returned to China from the United States, where he had been living for the past 14 years, the Chinese authorities said Friday.

headline: Construction in Buildings Declared Vacant Surprises Some: The Tenants
text: The complaints to the city from 292 Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, read like dispatches from chaos.

text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Coming-of-Age Novels
text: THE STAR SIDE OF BIRD HILL By Naomi Jackson 298 pp. Penguin Press, $25.95.

headline: ‘The Social Sex: A History of Female Friendship’
text: Friendship is a bond that is uniquely defined by the people who exist within it. Unlike relationships such as marriage or parenthood, which have clear timelines and boundaries, friendships have no ceremonial beginning or end, no biological definition. They are not sanctioned by any church, nor recognized officially by any state. This is perhaps why women, historically diminished by the government and burdened by the family, find such fulfillment and power among friends.

headline: Friends of Long Standing
text: With Ann Friedman taking on friendship in nonfiction (in her review of Marilyn Yalom’s “The Social Sex: A History of Female Friendship”), I thought I’d ask several women at The Times to recommend their favorite fiction on the same theme.

headline: Friend of Dylann Roof Pleads Not Guilty to Charges in Charleston Shooting
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — A friend of Dylann S. Roof, the man charged in the June 17 massacre at an African-American church in Charleston, S.C., entered a plea of not guilty on Friday to charges of lying to investigators and concealing information about the attack, which killed nine people.

headline: Alison Light’s ‘Common People: In Pursuit of My Ancestors’
text: This is a richly peopled book. Alison Light prefaces it with nine family trees, and these include some 200 names — the host of Georges and Arthurs and Walters and Alberts, as well as the Mary Anns and the Sarahs and the Elizas that we shall find traced and placed, saved from anonymity, identified, set in the context of their times.

headline: ‘The Lost Landscape,’ by Joyce Carol Oates
text: Joyce Carol Oates is an ambivalent memoirist. In “The Lost Landscape: A Writer’s Coming of Age,” she repeatedly ex­presses her doubts about first-person autobio­graphical writing. For one thing, she’s deeply wary of the confessional voice. For another, she has little faith in the reliability of memory. While she can vouch for the accuracy of “A Widow’s Story,” her 2011 account of the aftermath of her first husband’s death, which she based on contemporaneous journals, she can hardly back up this latest memoir with documentation. No small child, not even a Joyce Carol Oates, could be expected to take notes all day. Yet another problem: The memoirist is obliged to leave things out. “To charges of distortion,” she writes, “I can only say — mea culpa.”

headline: ‘Succession,’ by Livi Michael
text: The Wars of the Roses might be having a moment. George R.R. Martin cheerfully admits to tailoring his “Game of Thrones” novels after the events of the 30-year conflict between the House of York and the House of Lancaster, whose “sigils,” as Martin would have it, were the white rose and the red. The United States could be heading for a dynastic collision, Clinton versus Bush. And the full-pomp reinterment last March of Richard III’s remains, discovered in 2012 beneath a parking lot in Leicester, placed a sad punctuation mark on a saga that’s now more than half a millennium old.

headline: A Song for Naldo
text: A song from Jen Shyu courtesy of Pi Recordings.

headline: Ceridwen Dovey’s ‘Only the Animals’
text: Ceridwen Dovey studied social anthropology at Harvard before writing her debut novel, the celebrated “Blood Kin” (2007). She continued her studies at New York University afterward, and has now brought an anthropologist’s eye to her second book, the story collection “Only the Animals.” Her subject is not human societies, however, but the relationship between humans and other species. And why not? As J.M. Coetzee says in one of Dovey’s epigraphs, “Each creature is key to all other creatures.”

headline: ‘Sweet Caress,’ by William Boyd
text: It’s always interesting to see an author write against his or her own experience — an Asian writing as a European, a civilian woman writing as a male Marine or, really, any writer suddenly adopting a distinctly different voice. So it’s very interesting to read William Boyd’s “Sweet Caress,” written not only in the voice of a woman but of a woman born more than four decades before the author.

headline: Matt Bell’s ‘Scrapper’
text: The haunting jacket of Matt Bell’s memorable second novel, “Scrapper,” features the skeletal silos and shafts of a factory through the broken windows of the Fisher Body Plant No. 21, not far from the cloverleaf interchange of I-75 and I-94 in Detroit. Like many locations in the city, this decaying site contains a multitude of histories: Built in 1919, it originally manufactured Buick and Cadillac bodies; during World War II, it produced parts for bombers, tanks and other military equipment; at one point, the factory held a soup kitchen and homeless shelter. Today it stands vacant, most of its metal innards stripped by scrappers, and the monolithic structure is deemed contaminated by the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: Kyung-sook Shin’s ‘The Girl Who Wrote Loneliness’
text: Kyung-sook Shin’s “The Girl Who Wrote Loneliness” begins with an unnamed novelist writing in isolation on Korea’s Jeju Island. She informs us of a recent call from an old friend, someone who has read her work and says, “You don’t write about us. . . . You seem to write quite a lot about your childhood, and also about college, and about love, but there was nothing about us.” Rattled, the novelist looks back on her teenage years. Why indeed hasn’t she written about her classmates and friends from that time?

headline: School for Slaughter
text: Cover your eyes — this one’s really nasty. Not even cookie-­baking moms and their innocent children are spared in THE KILLING LESSONS (St. Martin’s, $25.99), Saul Black’s thriller about an interstate manhunt for a killer whose modus operandi is so bizarre even his own accomplice can’t figure it out.

headline: Elliptical/Wayward Son
text: A song from Jen Shyu courtesy of Pi Recordings.

headline: Big Tech Has Become Way Too Powerful
text: Berkeley, Calif. — CONSERVATIVES and liberals interminably debate the merits of “the free market” versus “the government.” Which one you trust more delineates the main ideological divide in America.

headline: ‘Daddy Long Legs’ at the Davenport
text: Arachnophobes have no reason to fear “Daddy Long Legs,” the small and by most accounts quite cuddly production that opens at the Davenport Theater on Sept. 28. Staged by the British director John Caird (“Les Misérables,” “Nicholas Nickleby”), this two-character chamber musical concerns not a creepy-crawly but a plucky orphan girl and her anonymous, avuncular benefactor.

headline: In ‘Quantico,’ Bollywood’s Priyanka Chopra Seeks an American Foothold
text: MONTREAL — The golden hour on this late September afternoon was anything but. The air was hot and hazy, the sky the color of the industrial concrete buildings doubling as the set of the F.B.I. Academy.

headline: Fewer Underwater Mortgage Holders
text: The share of underwater mortgage holders — those who owe more than their homes are worth — has dropped by more than half since peaking in early 2012, according to new data from Zillow.

headline: Protests Against Japanese Security Bill
text: Thousands gathered on Friday outside Japan’s parliament in Tokyo to protest a bill that would allow the country’s military to fight in wars overseas.

headline: ‘Mikado’ Production Canceled Over Racial Concerns
text: A production of Gilbert and Sullivan’s “The Mikado” planned for New York this December was canceled after it drew criticism over how its largely non-Asian cast planned to portray the stereotyped Japanese characters and culture that are often seen as central to the work, the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players announced on their website.

headline: Eerily Similar Dresses From Different New York Designers
text: During New York Fashion week, which wrapped up last night, three very different designers showed three very similar dresses. White as canvases and printed with colorful, watercolor-like designs, Adam Selman’s slip dress, Adam Lippes’s elegant silhouette and Marc Jacobs’s long-sleeved sheath suggest that come spring/summer 2016 the worlds of art and fashion will continue, as they’re wont to do, to collide.

text: HADERSLEV, Denmark — More than 120 years ago, Simon Hansen Sondergaard left this town in southwest Denmark for the United States. He settled in Iowa, along with four of his five siblings, where he farmed and raised a family.

headline: A Junkyard in the Adirondacks
text: After deadly and destructive explosions of oil tank cars in recent years, the federal government began requiring new, somewhat safer tankers to carry the explosive Bakken crude oil across the country.  Let’s hope that this is progress.  The problem now for those who transport this highly-combustible oil is what to do with the big outdated tankers.

text: It’s Corporate Governance 101: Company directors are supposed to respect the wishes of the shareholders they are duty bound to serve. And if the directors defy them, those shareholders are supposed to hold the directors accountable.

headline: 1965: Kosygin Offers To Mediate
text: MOSCOW — Soviet Premier Alexei N. Kosygin has proposed that Indian Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri and Pakistani President Mohammed Ayub Khan come to the Soviet Union to try to settle the undeclared war between their two countries, the news agency Tass announced tonight. Tass said Mr. Kosygin ‘‘could take part in such a meeting if India and Pakistan wished this.’’

text: The spokesman for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs commented on Friday about the repatriation by the United States of Yang Jinjun, a Chinese businessman accused of corruption.

headline: With ‘The Intern,’ Nancy Meyers Keeps Exploring Women’s Relationships
text: It was a line of dialogue that provoked volcanic laughter, echoed through bedrooms for a decade or two, and announced a distinctive comic voice.

headline: From EyeEm, Technology to See and Tag Photos
text: A little-known German start-up may have just made it a lot easier to search for photos online.

headline: Roland Emmerich’s ‘Stonewall’ Finds Controversy
text: The trailer for the drama “Stonewall,” due in theaters on Friday, Sept. 25, focuses on a fictional young, blond, white gay Midwesterner named Danny who arrives in New York City and soon becomes a leader in the historic uprising by lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender patrons of the West Village bar the Stonewall Inn in response to a police raid on June 28, 1969. During the roughly two-minute trailer, the tag line “inspired by the incredible true story of the unsung heroes whose courage broke down walls” scrolls dramatically across the screen.

headline: ‘The Walk’ Replays Philippe Petit’s High-Wire Act — but Was It Art?
text: Joseph Gordon-Levitt still has his ticket stub from a visit to the World Trade Center in July 2001. He was 20 years old and a fresh transplant from Southern California, doing what millions of tourists had done before him but few would do after. “I remember being up there,” he said recently. “There were clouds below you.” He likened it to being “halfway to the cosmos, not in a building that’s rooted on earth.”

headline: Garlic Soup That’s in a Rush
text: When the day gets away from me and I’m hungry but (uncharacteristically) haven’t given dinner a thought, I turn to garlic soup. Its very existence makes me feel secure. I know that a delicious dinner can be on the table in 30 minutes.

headline: With Help From Kickstarter, Chicago Gets a Museum That Relishes the Hot Dog
text: Foodseum opens its first exhibition, “The Hot Dog and Encased Meat of the World,” on Saturday at Block 37 in Chicago’s Loop; it runs through Dec. 20.

headline: ‘Finders Keepers,’ the Story of a Gnarled Leg and the Lives It Altered
text: The 911 call was unlike anything ever heard in Maiden, N.C., or probably anywhere else.

headline: A Fresh Look at ‘Daniel,’ ‘The Confession’ and the Trials of the Cold War
text: Sidney Lumet’s “Daniel” (1983) and Costa-Gavras’s “The Confession” (1970), new on Blu-ray and DVD from Olive and Criterion, are in some ways mirror images of each other — each has each been accused of distorting its subject.

headline: A Toxic Work World
text: FOR many Americans, life has become all competition all the time. Workers across the socioeconomic spectrum, from hotel housekeepers to surgeons, have stories about toiling 12- to 16-hour days (often without overtime pay) and experiencing anxiety attacks and exhaustion. Public health experts have begun talking about stress as an epidemic.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Receding NAIRU
text: I began my apprenticeship in economics as a research assistant to Bill Nordhaus, who was working on energy at the time (check the acknowledgments), and one thing I remember was the continual frustration over the failure of alternatives to conventional crude oil to materialize. That’s all changed now, of course; but at the time people used to cite “Weitzmann’s Law”, which said that the cost of alternatives to oil was 40 percent above the current price — whatever the current price happened to be.

text: Calvin Klein, RuPaul and others attended Susanne Bartsch’s “Fashion Underground” show at the Museum at F.I.T.

headline: Fathers Sue for Paid Time Off: Readers Respond
text: Lela Moore is a news assistant and comment moderator.

headline: For Zandra Rhodes, a Colorful and Triumphant Return
text: For her first show in London in seven years, the fashion designer worked with traditional Malaysian fabrics in a plethora of prints.

headline: Humanity as a Competitive Advantage
text: Earlier this week, I flew from New York to Boston and took off a full day to see a doctor about a medical condition I have. I went to these lengths because I understood him to be perhaps the world’s expert in this particular syndrome.

headline: Irving Police Chief Defends Response to Ahmed Mohamed’s Clock
text: DALLAS — Ahmed Mohamed, the 14-year-old high school student who was detained and handcuffed for bringing to school a homemade clock that was thought to be a fake bomb, was “overwhelmed” and is now “a little fatigued” from an eventful week, his father said on Friday.

headline: Donald Trump Cancels Appearance at Conservative Forum
text: Donald J. Trump canceled a planned appearance at a South Carolina presidential candidate forum being held Friday by a conservative group, citing a business transaction he had pending.

headline: Remembering a Force for Transformation in Hartford
text: A call came out of the blue this week from a man I haven’t spoken to in 30 years. After the pleasantries, Dick Suisman delivered the sad news: Nick Carbone, the legendary politician from Hartford, Conn., had died of leukemia at the age of 78.

headline: Georgia Tech’s Odd Problem: Its Defense Needs a Tight End
text: ATLANTA — There is an ample collection of running backs at Georgia Tech — 22 of them to be precise. There are also 13 former high school quarterbacks, many of them recruited because they were usually the best athletes at their high schools and capable of playing multiple positions.

headline: A Condo Near MoMA for $23 Million
text: A full-floor aerie near the top of the Baccarat Hotel and Residences, a new glass tower in Midtown by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill that sits opposite the Museum of Modern Art, sold to an unidentified buyer for $23,289,760.64 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: An Oboist and Administrator Changes Orchestras
text: James Roe was an oboist in the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra before he became its president and chief executive in 2013. Now he is moving on to lead another ensemble with which he once performed as a player: the Orchestra of St. Luke’s, which announced on Friday that Mr. Roe would become its president and executive director on Dec. 1.

headline: New Ecotourism Tours in Sarasota
text: Bays and Birds Ecko, a new ecotourism nonprofit program based in Sarasota, Fla., is offering a series of outdoor tours to highlight the Gulf Coast’s natural and cultural diversity. The debut tour, “Inspired Sarasota Bay,” departs Oct. 25 and will take guests to bays, islands and beaches, showcasing the environmental heritage of Sarasota Bay. Additional trips this year include the Manatee River area; the Myakka River, including portions that are not generally open to the public; Gulf Coast birding; and urban wildlife viewing by bike.

headline: Family Pond Boils at Center of a ‘Regulatory War’ in Wyoming
text: FORT BRIDGER, Wyo. — The sun was sinking and the brook trout were biting, so Andy Johnson and his daughter Aspen, 6, stepped onto their sun-bleached pier, hooked some mealworms and cast their lines into the most infamous pond in the West.

headline: Everett C. Parker, Who Won Landmark Fight Over Media Race Bias, Dies at 102
text: The Rev. Everett C. Parker, who won a landmark broadcasting case and led a civil rights crusade to hold television and radio stations accountable for presenting racially biased programming and for failing to hire blacks and other minorities, died on Thursday in White Plains. He was 102.

headline: Illustrated Interview | Andy Samberg
text: The comedian and writer, who hosts the Emmy Awards this weekend, sketches his responses to a brief questionnaire.

headline: Watching the Fed, and Remembering the Tequila Crisis
text: Lots of buzz concerning the impact of higher interest rates in the United States. A major trading partner creating shock waves in the global economy. Stock market volatility spreading around the world.

headline: Marie Kondo on the Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up — With Kids
text: About a year ago, I came across “The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up” by Marie Kondo on a bookstore table, and because I like to read about organization (more than I like to get organized, really) I bought it, only to toss is aside in frustration a few pages in. I was supposed to clean up all at once, not one room at a time? Pull out every article of clothing, even my carefully stored summer things? And focus on my own mess, not my messy family? This was not helpful. It was impossible, and it made me feel almost as bad as the clutter that still surrounded us.

headline: Denzel Washington Says He Will Bring 10 August Wilson Plays to HBO
text: During an interview at the Wallis Annenberg Center for the Performing Arts in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Thursday night Denzel Washington said that he would produce adaptations of all 10 plays in August Wilson’s cycle about African-American life in the 20th century for HBO.

headline: The Fashion News to Know Today
text: Now, who’s hot, who not?

headline: Popes in America
text: Highlights from previous papal visits to the United States.

headline: A Rose for Rugby
text: The image of a blooming rose projected onto the O2 arena in London encouraged support for the English team as the Rugby World Cup began.

headline: On Bryant Park, David Chipperfield’s First New York Building
text: The roster of high-profile international architects making their mark on New York City’s skyline continues to grow, and the latest to join the club is the British architect David Chipperfield.

headline: Ruling Will Encourage Debtor’s Sales in Bankruptcy
text: The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit — which includes Delaware, home to many large American companies – has issued an opinion that will have a significant impact on Chapter 11 bankruptcy practice.

headline: House Republicans Vote to Stop Funding Planned Parenthood
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans vented their rage against Planned Parenthood on Friday, voting to block all federal financing for the organization, which they accused of profiting from the sale of aborted fetuses for medical research. It was unclear, however, if the vote would mollify conservative lawmakers who have threatened to force a government shutdown over the abortion issue.

headline: How Cablevision Shareholders Have Fared
text: The Dolan family, who have agreed to sell Cablevision to Altice of France for some $17 billion, including debt, have been a lightning rod for many in New York City and Long Island. There is its management of the New York Knicks and Rangers, as well as its stewardship of the cable company.

headline: Caroline de Maigret, a Model and Parisian Muse
text: An ambassador of Parisian cool was in town, and she wanted a burrito. “Super-vegetarian,” said Caroline de Maigret, the model, music producer and co-author of “How to Be Parisian Wherever You Are,” pointing at the laminated menu at Lupe’s, a Mexican diner in TriBeCa. “It’s rice, beans, salad, guacamole. And no, it’s not very healthy.”

headline: Bank of America Merrill Lynch Hires a Senior Banker
text: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has hired a long-time deal maker from Deutsche Bank to serve as a senior banker, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Friday.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Raymond Pettibon
text: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from the artist Raymond Pettibon — who in November will release a tote-bag collaboration with MZ Wallace to benefit the New York Public Library. He shares his picks exclusively with T.

headline: Abstract Artworks with a Hint of Danger
text: “Everything I do is toxic,” jokes the artist Alex Hubbard, as lacquer fumes waft through the vast expanses of his downtown Los Angeles studio. A layer of gloss adds the finishing touches to the pieces in his latest show, “Basic Perversions,” paintings formed from pigmented industrial synthetics — urethane, resin and fiberglass — “all of which,” Hubbard notes, “are hazardous to my health.”

headline: Kerry on Military Talks With Russia
text: Secretary of State John Kerry, during an appearance with the foreign minister of the United Arab Emirates in London on Friday, said he hoped military talks with Russia on Syria would take place soon.

headline: Op-Photo: Protests on Two Continents
text: On the left, demonstrators in Helsinki, Finland on Friday protest against cuts to overtime pay and holidays. And on the right, also on Friday, protesters outside Japan’s parliament building in Tokyo oppose legislation that would let the country’s military play a bigger part in conflicts abroad.

headline: Willing to Spend $100 Million, Donald Trump Has So Far Reveled in Free Publicity
text: ROCHESTER, N.H. — Expressing confidence that American voters do not care if he lacks specifics, Donald J. Trump says he has yet to fully exploit his personal advantages over his Republican presidential rivals — chiefly his enormous wealth and celebrity — and that both will matter more to his political fate than debate performances like his shaky one this week.

headline: Lady Gaga’s New Video Is a PSA About Campus Sexual Assault
text: Lady Gaga is addressing campus rape in a raw new music video for “Til It Happens to You,” a song from the documentary “The Hunting Ground,” which examines the issue of sexual assault among college students.

headline: Alexis Tsipras Wields Charm to Appeal to Jaded Greek Voters
text: PATRAS, Greece — Alexis Tsipras, Greece’s prime minister until he resigned last month to call new elections, was campaigning in this port city recently, in many ways looking like the same charismatic young politician who swept into office only eight months ago.

headline: Suspect in 2 Deaths at Brooklyn and Manhattan Hotels Is Arrested
text: Joseph Danclair had a way with women, the police said. The Brooklyn man could easily strike up a conversation, they said, and in some cases, persuade them to go along with him.

headline: Bill Withers: Still Himself, but He’ll Allow the Attention
text: LOS ANGELES — For musical stars of a certain age, being inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame is usually a springboard for a career revival — tours, new albums, endorsement deals, all that.

headline: Planning the Pope’s Visit to Philadelphia
text: Scenes from the whirlwind preparations for the papal visit to Philadelphia — the first to that city since 1979.

headline: Review: In ‘Minority Report,’ a Case of Precognitive Dissonance
text: “Minority Report,” the TV series, appears to come from an alternative universe: one in which “Minority Report,” the movie, was never made.

headline: White House Faults Donald Trump for Not Rebuking Obama Muslim Assertion
text: Donald J. Trump was pandering for votes when he failed to correct a rally attendee who said President Obama was Muslim and not American, Josh Earnest, the White House’s press secretary, said Friday. He called the lapse part of a “cynical strategy” used by many Republicans.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: Battleships, diner patrons and Air Force One provide appealing backgrounds as the 2016 presidential campaign picks up.

headline: Kiki and Herb Plan Reunion at Joe’s Pub
text: The cabaret star Justin Vivian Bond had two surprises planned for Friday’s performance of “Dixie McCall’s Patterns for Living” at Joe’s Pub.

headline: Bowe Bergdahl Should Not Be Imprisoned, Army Investigator Says
text: SAN ANTONIO — The general who led the Army’s investigation into the disappearance of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl from his remote outpost in Afghanistan in 2009 said on Friday that sentencing the sergeant to prison would be “inappropriate.”

headline: Investors See Potential in Beer Merger
text: Anheuser-Busch InBev, brewer of Budweiser, has yet to make a firm offer for a rival brewer, SABMiller, but the market is already tipsy on the potential for value creation.

headline: The Many Faces of Grace Jones
text: The style icon, disco queen, model, actress and provocateur over the years.

headline: Refugees in Calais, Reading and Waiting
text: Calais, France — “YOU like the place?”

headline: Review: Attacca Quartet Continues Its Haydn Project
text: Completism is a curse on classical music. Our urge to present and to hear everything that a composer wrote in a genre, usually in a compressed period, can sometimes be productive. Mostly, though, the endless flood of Bach, Beethoven and Mahler cycles let loose by our major soloists, chamber ensembles and orchestras stifles the genuinely creative thinking that our art needs. Bankable though the idea may be, it tends to be boring.

headline: Review: ‘Nufonia Must Fall’ Shares the Heart of Kid Koala’s Robot Tale
text: “Nufonia Must Fall,” a Next Wave Festival show at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater through Sunday, might be called modern primitive multimedia. It mixes puppet theater, video, a string quartet and a nest of electric instruments.

headline: Jon Irabagon Paints Tradition in New Hues
text: The saxophonist Jon Irabagon closed a recent set at the Jazz Standard with “The Original J,” a brisk new tune in a willful state of flux. His quartet made it feel plunging and precarious, charged with fervor. Only gradually, during a piano solo by Matt Mitchell, did it become obvious that the tune’s chord progression had been borrowed from the standard songbook: specifically, Cole Porter’s “So in Love.”

headline: Pat Haden’s Joyous Nights at U.S.C. Outweigh the Sleepless Ones
text: LOS ANGELES — Pat Haden stood on the field at Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum on a hot afternoon in May and pointed to a spot in the stands dozens of rows above the west end zone. His father’s season tickets to Southern California football games were there, in Row 90.

headline: Wounded Soldiers Recount Pakistan Attack
text: Soldiers and officials from the Pakistani military recounted the Taliban attack on an air force base mosque.

headline: Modernizing a Historic Home in Portland, Ore.
text: The idea was simple: David and Sarah Altman planned to buy a large lot with a deteriorating house, tear it down and build something new. Something modern.

headline: On Location | Portland, Ore.
text: A classic 1910 Foursquare house in the Richmond neighborhood of Portland, Ore., gets a modern addition.

headline: U.A.W. Contract With Fiat Chrysler Would Give 2nd-Tier Workers Big Raise
text: DETROIT — The proposed contract between Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and the United Automobile Workers union includes wage increases that significantly close the gap in pay between veteran workers and entry-level employees.

headline: Bernie Sanders Bashes Billionaires at a Manhattan Fund-Raiser
text: The traditional campaign fund-raiser: a few dozen deep-pocketed donors in a quiet room, a trimmed-down stump speech from the candidate, a pantomime of intimacy.

headline: More Protection for a Nest Egg Has Some Brokers Upset
text: A DOZEN or so new victims file into Joseph Peiffer’s law offices each month.

headline: With Kelsey Grammer Still Away, ‘Neverland’ Finds a New Hook
text: Kelsey Grammer’s summer vacation has gotten longer.

headline: The Rationality of Rage
text: ANGER is a primal and destructive emotion, disrupting rational discourse and inflaming illogical passions — or so it often seems. Then again, anger also has its upsides. Expressing anger, for example, is known to be a useful tool in negotiations. Indeed, in the past few years, researchers have been learning more about when and how to deploy anger productively.

headline: Eric Fanning, Civilian Adviser, Named Secretary of the Army
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is nominating Eric K. Fanning, a close civilian adviser to Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter, to be the secretary of the Army, an appointment that would make him the first openly gay secretary of a military branch.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
text: Turkey and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: September 18, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Turkey, Croatia, Sri Lanka and Saudi Arabia.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Robert Johnson, Bronx District Attorney, Says He Wants to Become a State Judge
text: The longtime Bronx district attorney, Robert T. Johnson, said on Friday that he intended to seek a nomination to be a State Supreme Court justice, setting in motion his likely resignation and paving the way for Democratic Party officials in the borough to name his replacement.

headline: Amid Jerusalem Clashes, Israeli and Palestinian Leaders Try to Make Their Case
text: JERUSALEM — Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, called Pope Francis to brief him on the “ongoing Israeli aggression in occupied East Jerusalem, and particularly against Al Aqsa Mosque.”

headline: Europe Should See Refugees as a Boon, Not a Burden
text: Many European leaders have described the refugees who are risking their lives to get to the Continent as a burden. But there is good reason to believe that these immigrants will contribute more to Europe economically than they will take from it.

headline: Understanding Insurance Policies for Homes in Wildfire-Prone Areas
text: THE worst wildfire season in years is forcing many Californians from their homes and has caused the destruction of hundreds of houses, cars and other property.

headline: In Its 13th Year, the London Design Festival Spreads Out
text: As the London Design Festival prepares for its 13th year, the city is gearing up to host a range of activities including five major design shows and hundreds of installations and pop-ups across seven “design districts.” The festival, which runs from Sept. 19 to 27, has outgrown its original geographical confines: luxury design and large-scale installations in west London, and edgier work on view in the east. This year, LDF spans the whole city, with venues reaching into the north and south — including a number of independent shops, galleries and cafes that will be hosting their own events and exhibitions.

headline: The De-Reaganization of the Republican Party
text: On Oct. 9, 1986, Air Force One delivered President Ronald Reagan to Iceland, where he met with President Mikhail Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. The Reykjavik summit, as it was known, marked the beginning of the end of the Cold War.

headline: College Football Games to Watch This Weekend
text: No. 15 Mississippi at No. 2 Alabama

headline: An Aboriginal Artist’s Dizzying New York Moment
text: For at least the last century, it has always been a momentous occasion: An artist from the hinterlands arrives in New York for the first time, hoping for what the writer Willie Morris called “the tender security of fulfillment.” But for the painter Warlimpirrnga Tjapaltjarri, things were a little different.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 8
text: Calvin Klein, RuPaul and others attended Susanne Bartsch’s “Fashion Underground” show at the Museum at F.I.T.

headline: Port Antonio: Jamaica Unplugged
text: FOR MANY YEARS, Port Antonio, a junglehemmed town on Jamaica’s northeast coast, was synonymous with a specific kind of languorous glamour, best illustrated by a 1955 photograph of Patrice Flynn, a movie actress and wife of Errol. In it, she is riding on horseback along a sandy track as he walks beside her, his white shirt unbuttoned. Everything about it suggests a near future of Dark and Stormies at sundown on a veranda somewhere. This was the beginning of the town’s glory years, when it was the retreat of choice for Grace Kelly and Elizabeth Taylor, who used to arrive by yacht with Richard Burton.

headline: 5 Stand-Out Male Models at New York Fashion Week
text: Several spring/summer 2016 runways featured new (and newish) men’s faces. Here, a handful that caught T’s eye.

headline: Back to School — on the Runways
text: Each September, New York Fashion Week and back-to-school converge — sometimes even on the runway, where this season three designers nodded to the academic uniform. At Hood by Air, detention-bound models wore cropped white oxford shirts (buttoned all the way up to the neck, in accordance with dress code) and black leather skirts with zippered slits. In tailored jackets, knee socks and button-down shirts, Thom Browne’s schoolgirls were much more prim — though with a wacky twist — as they filed into a schoolhouse before their headmistress. And at DKNY, which debuted its first collection under new creative direction from Dao-Yi Chow and Maxwell Osborne of Public School, pleats and blazers came together for a more of-the-moment, urban feel.

headline: Mexican Tourists Wounded in Egyptian Air Attack Return Home
text: MEXICO CITY — The six Mexican survivors of an air attack by Egyptian security forces on a group of Mexican tourists and their Egyptian guides returned to their country on Friday as the Mexican government said it would seek compensation on their behalf from Egypt.

headline: Toronto Film Festival: Separating Contenders From Pretenders
text: The first time that a red carpet was rolled out may have been in “The Oresteia” when Clytemnestra orders her handmaidens to lay down crimson tapestries for the return of her long-absent husband, Agamemnon. The color evokes the blood that was spilled at Troy and signals the blood that will pour from Agamemnon when he’s killed by Clytemnestra, who holds him responsible the death of their daughter, Iphigenia. The red carpet has long held significantly different meanings, although given its grip on the movie world I have started to see it too as a river of blood, cascading from all the footsore celebrities, anxious festival programmers and weary journalists now on that death march called the awards season.

headline: The New Mods
text: This season, the prevailing archetype is the Pop dollybird clad in psychedelic geometrics.

headline: What’s Showing at the Toronto Film Festival? TV
text: TORONTO — “Have you heard of this movie?” a young woman asks her companion as they settle into their seats for something called “The Returned.” A man sitting in front of them turns and tells them they’ve fought their way through the crowds at the Toronto International Film Festival to see … a television show.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Backstage at Molly Goddard’s Sandwich Factory
text: A look at the designer’s spring/summer collection at London Fashion Week.

headline: The Power of Grace Jones
text: “I am so terribly sorry,” said the woman in a black blazer and leopard-print heels, hovering over Grace Jones. “There’s no way that I can have you keep doing this interview here.”

headline: The Mod Look of the ’60s, Revisited
text: THE IMAGE of the carefree 1960s girl is never far from designers’ minds, from the era’s innocent flower children to such sexy sophisticates as Bardot and Birkin. This season, the prevailing archetype is the Pop dollybird clad in psychedelic geometrics. Donatella Versace’s color-block dresses in acid-bright shades were shown with color-coordinated thigh-high boots: very Modesty Blaise. Louis Vuitton and Calvin Klein showed minis with keyhole cutouts, as Jonathan Saunders and Jeremy Scott reverted to trippy retro patterns. Valentino conjured the Vienna Secessionists, whose graphic sensibility had a big impact on the 1960s Op Art giants Bridget Riley and Victor Vasarely.

headline: Making New Memories in the Aftermath of a Quebec Train Disaster
text: Michel Huneault photographed the train explosion in Lac-Mégantic and then returned to document how the small village coped. He has received the Lange-Taylor Prize from Duke University’s Center for Documentary Studies for the project.

headline: Japan’s Parliament Approves Overseas Combat Role for Military
text: TOKYO — In a middle-of-the night vote that capped a tumultuous struggle with opposition parties in Parliament, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan secured final passage of legislation on Saturday authorizing overseas combat missions for his country’s military, overturning a decades-old policy of reserving the use of force for self-defense.

headline: Review: Joanna Kotze’s High-Speed Chase at Baryshnikov Arts Center
text: In 2013, Joanna Kotze won the Bessie Award for Outstanding Emerging Choreographer for her dense and stately evening-length “It happened it had happened it is happening it will happen.” Now in her follow-up, “Find Yourself Here,” choppier in tone, she places three dancers and three visual artists in the same space to blur the lines between task and choreography, movement and sound.

headline: Review: ‘Rice,’ by Cloud Gate Dance Theater of Taiwan, Honors a Crop and a People
text: Sex! Fire! Combat with sticks! The production by Cloud Gate Dance Theater of Taiwan that opened on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music has all of those things. And yet, somehow, it is about as exciting as the life cycle of rice.

headline: Staten Island Museum Is Reopening in Snug Harbor Complex
text: Sure, the Staten Island Museum has long owned a variety of treasures: a 16th-century suit of armor, a wooden statue from the 12th dynasty of ancient Egypt, a collection of portraits of prominent people from the borough.

headline: Review: The JACK Quartet, With Instruments of Destruction
text: The Miller Theater at Columbia University is known for its forward-thinking programming, but it opened its season Thursday with something truly wild: the JACK Quartet playing Schumann. Imperfectly.

headline: The Flea’s New Artistic Director Is Dreaming Big
text: When Niegel Smith got messages from three friends on a single day last winter, urging him to apply to succeed Jim Simpson, the founding artistic director of the Flea Theater, it didn’t seem to him like an obvious fit.

headline: ‘The Mikado’ Is Beheaded in New York
text: This is startling: The New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players, a small company dedicated to keeping those warhorse Victorian operettas alive and kicking, has just canceled its winter production of “The Mikado.”

headline: In London, a Fashion Show Becomes a Sandwich Factory
text: In a presentation space at London’s Institute of Contemporary Arts, the designer Molly Goddard is turning a group of models in party dresses into a no-nonsense sandwich-production line. A series of white tables fill the space, each with its own prop: a tub of chopped tomatoes; a foil tray of lettuce leaves; a platter of cheese slices — and, of course, piles upon piles of white bread. “It’s OK to look a bit bored,” she directs the models, arranging them in pairs. She herself looks entirely relaxed. There are seven minutes until show time.

headline: Friday Night Music: I’m Still Here
text: I was looking for something else, but this Elaine Stritch performance is so good I had to share:

headline: Bill Cunningham | Pant Shapes Expand
text: At New York Fashion Week, pants had a fresh proportion: the width of skirts and cut off at the calf. Other times they covered the shoe.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Pant Shapes Expand at New York Fashion Week
text: Pants have a fresh proportion: the width of skirts and cut off at the calf. Other times they cover the shoe. It was a look that many of the people attending New York Fashion Week wore. The idea was first seen at Céline in Paris over a year ago In New York, the idea was developed at J. Crew. Many of the long trousers suggest palazzo pajamas worn in Rome in the 1960s for informal evenings. A buyer from Saudi Arabia wore versions of this skirt pants every day last week.. Among the many pant shapes being worn is another attempt at the one-piece jumpsuit, which has always been difficult for women to handle in bathroom stalls.

headline: Photographing Marine Veterans on the Home Front
text: Todd Heisler photographed several Marine veterans of the Afghan war. Many of their comrades had died in combat; others killed themselves at home or attempted suicide.

headline: Review: In ‘How to Live on Earth,’ a Way Off the Planet
text: Mars is not especially hospitable to human life. It has minimal oxygen, a temperature of 200 degrees below at the poles and low gravity that can burst internal organs within minutes. To say nothing of the dust.

headline: Evening Hours | New York Fashion Week
text: Industry parties and the season’s kickoff gala.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘The Court and the World’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, John Fabian Witt reviews the Supreme Court Justice Stephen Breyer’s “The Court and the World,” which considers whether foreign law should have a place in interpreting the American Constitution. Mr. Witt writes:

headline: Israeli Settlers Publish Their Reality, with Palestine as Fiction
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli settlers have long asserted that the Palestinians are an invented people, that the West Bank’s real name is Judea and Samaria, and that it was liberated by Israeli soldiers in 1967. Now the settlers, apparently worried that their version of history is not reaching other Israelis, are promoting it in a Hebrew-language publication that resembles a comic book.

headline: A Murder at a Bronx Motel Lingers, Three Years Later
text: Michael Rocco arrived at home that morning shaken, and he was not easily shaken.

headline: A Humble Pope, Challenging the World
text: VATICAN CITY — Days after the election of Pope Francis, word reached the Vatican press office that the new pontiff was unexpectedly celebrating morning Mass. Other popes had presided over morning services, too, but as the world (and the Vatican press office) would soon realize, Francis did things his own way.

headline: Judge Rules That a Dog Visiting a Bronx Apartment Is Not an Illegal Tenant
text: The Pomeranian was dropped off at the Bronx apartment in the morning, snuggled there with a 17-year-old girl who had depression and a spine condition, and then returned at night to its owner’s home in New Jersey.

headline: ISIS Group Attacks Prison in Libya
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Four militants loyal to the Islamic State attacked a prison on Friday inside the air base that serves as the only working airport for Tripoli, the Libyan capital, according to statements by the group and by the political faction that controls the city. It was one of the group’s most aggressive forays into the capital.

headline: Mark Fuller, Former Federal District Court Judge, Could Be Impeached
text: A high-level committee of federal judges told Congress this month that lawmakers had reason to consider impeaching Mark E. Fuller, a former Federal District Court judge in Alabama, even though he had already resigned after being arrested and accused of striking his wife.

headline: Brazil to Keep Allowances for the Poor
text: Despite Brazil’s deepening economic travails and budget problems, there will be no cuts in a pioneering and widely admired program of monthly cash allowances to the poor, the official in charge of the effort said Friday.

headline: Roger Adelman, Prosecutor in Reagan Attacker’s Insanity Trial, Dies at 74
text: Roger M. Adelman, a government lawyer whose unsuccessful prosecution of John W. Hinckley Jr. in the 1981 shooting of President Ronald Reagan and his press secretary, James S. Brady, led to significant changes in the law governing the insanity defense in criminal trials, died on Sept. 12 at his home in Washington. He was 74.

headline: A Wet Winter Won’t Save California
text: STANFORD, Calif. — As wildfires rage, crops are abandoned, wells run dry and cities work to meet mandatory water cuts, drought-weary Californians are counting on a savior in the tropical ocean: El Niño.

headline: Nail Salon Owners Sue Cuomo and New York State Over Wage Bond Requirement
text: Two groups representing nail salon owners sued Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the State of New York this week over a new requirement that says salons must obtain wage bonds, a form of insurance meant to protect workers from wage theft.

headline: Room in Catholic School for Gay-Straight Alliance
text: One afternoon during the first week of classes this week at Xavier High School in Manhattan, as the various student clubs reconvened, Joseph Papeo walked into Alexander Lavy’s physics classroom. On the walls hung a crucifix and posters of Einstein and Homer Simpson. Two flags flanked the door. One was the American standard, while the other was the rainbow banner of gay pride.

headline: Deputy Clerk Questions Alterations to Kentucky Marriage Licenses
text: A deputy clerk in Rowan County, Ky., raised questions on Friday about whether a slapdash solution to a legal standoff about same-sex marriage licenses complied with the order of the federal judge who this month jailed the county’s clerk, Kim Davis.

headline: Jordan Spieth Breaks Par, but Jason Day Breaks Away
text: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — For five straight holes Friday afternoon, Jordan Spieth completely lost confidence in his putter, making the task of keeping pace with Jason Day, the world’s top golfer, even more daunting than normal.

headline: How the Pope Might Renew the Church
text: Sacramento — I AM a Catholic, born in 1921 of Italian and Irish families and raised in California seminaries. After decades of work as a priest, I was astonished that Pope Paul VI appointed me a bishop in San Francisco. I love my church, and every night I pray that I might die in her warm, loving arms.

headline: Enabling of Ad Blocking in Apple’s iOS 9 Prompts Backlash
text: For years, people have longed for ways to stop advertising from popping up on their iPhones and iPads. Now, software to block ads on these gadgets has arrived — and the harsh realities of the practice are causing second thoughts.

headline: Varied Pleas as Candidates Press Cases at Conservative Forum
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Gov. Scott Walker, eager to jump-start a flagging campaign, expressed support for a government shutdown over Planned Parenthood funding and likened his fights with lawmakers in Wisconsin to the movie “Braveheart.”

headline: The Fight for Unplanned Parenthood
text: Planned Parenthood! Government shutdown!

headline: Mets Test Yankees’ Ace, and Ace a Critical Test
text: The presence of the Yankees at Citi Field, this late in the season, is a mild novelty. Much more notable, for the Mets, is the fact that they are playing a competitive team at all.

headline: Gender Integration of Marines Brings Out Unusually Public Discord
text: The Marine Corps and its civilian leadership at the Pentagon are squaring off in an unusually public dispute over whether integrating women into the corps’s all-male combat units will undermine the units’ effectiveness, or whether the male-dominated Marine leadership is cherry-picking justifications to keep women out.

headline: Tourists Thwart Turtles from Nesting in Costa Rica
text: MEXICO CITY — The day-trippers swarmed onto the beach to watch one of nature’s most extraordinary sights, hundreds of thousands of olive ridley sea turtles crawling out of the ocean to lay their eggs in the sand.

headline: Impose Price Controls on Drugs?
text: To the Editor:

headline: United Nations Peacekeeping
text: To the Editor:

headline: Washington to Come to a Halt for Pope, Willingly or Not
text: WASHINGTON — The nation’s capital has been mired in gridlock for years, but next week’s snarls could be the worst ever — and this time it has nothing to do with politics.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s School Agenda
text: The education initiatives that Mayor Bill de Blasio outlined in a long-awaited speech earlier this week, though modest in scope, address some serious challenges facing the largest school system in the country. Collectively, they call for $186 million in new city investment, and in the abstract they appear wholly worthy. But the city has yet to provide details on how the initiatives will be rolled out or the benchmarks against which they will be judged. And for the reforms to fully realize their potential, some failing schools may have to be shut down and completely restaffed and restructured.

headline: Turn the Ferguson Moment Into Lasting Change
text: The track record of “riot commissions” convened after major public disturbances is that they gather dust once they assure the public that something vaguely positive seems to be happening. To its credit, the commission of community leaders appointed to look into the volatile racial protests that rocked Ferguson, Mo., last year did not make that mistake. The 198-page report issued by the Ferguson Commission this week warns from its very first pages that palliatives won’t do this time: Leaders must enact a raft of urgently needed changes, or St. Louis and its ring of disjointed suburbs will never get beyond the deeply troubling mix of racial prejudices and government abuses laid bare in Ferguson.

headline: Affordable Housing in Distressed Communities
text: To the Editor:

headline: Adrian Frutiger Dies at 87; His Type Designs Show You the Way
text: For more than 50 years, Adrian Frutiger made the world legible.

headline: Freelancing in the ‘Gig’ Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Zaha Hadid Withdraws From Competition to Design Tokyo Olympic Stadium
text: Two months after her design for a 2020 Olympic stadium in Tokyo was scrapped by the government because of spiraling costs, the prizewinning architect Zaha Hadid has taken herself out of the running for the project’s next round of competition.

headline: Migration and Morality
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Some Holy Alliances
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — We last saw constructor Kevin Adamick back in 2012, and he is back this time with a truly brain-twisting Saturday puzzle.

headline: Vanessa Ruiz and the Rolled R’s Rumpus
text: To the Editor:

headline: Buttons for Bernie, Not Billionaires
text: Senator Bernie Sanders, a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, rarely holds fund-raisers, but when he does, the focus isn’t on money.

headline: Lebanon Tribunal Gives Mixed Verdict in Confidential Witnesses Case
text: PARIS — An international court on Friday found Karma al-Khayat, an executive with Al Jadeed TV in Lebanon, guilty of contempt of court for ignoring its order to remove broadcasts about confidential witnesses from the station’s website. She was acquitted, however, of the more serious charge of obstruction of justice.

headline: Republican Job Killers and the Export-Import Bank
text: “At a time when we want to compete around the world, it is hard to believe what is happening in the U.S. Congress,” said Jeff Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric.

headline: A Selena Song Goes Out to Fans 20 Years After Her Death
text: A song released 20 years after the death of the Tejano singer Selena is the latest in a string of posthumous recordings coming out this year.

headline: Hungary Accuses Migrant Protesters of Terrorism for Clashing With Police
text: The Hungarian authorities appealed to the public on Friday for help in finding two migrants whom the government accused of terrorism for taking part in protests this week against the closing of the border with Serbia which degenerated into bloody clashes.

headline: Jeb Bush Says President Obama Is ‘an American’ and ‘a Christian’
text: Jeb Bush made it clear on Friday night that, unlike Donald J. Trump, he would not give credence to conspiracy theories about President Obama’s religion or nationality.

headline: Carly Fiorina Defends Her Comments on Planned Parenthood Video
text: Carly Fiorina, facing questions about the accuracy of her comments describing undercover Planned Parenthood videos, issued a sharp defense on Friday before a conservative forum in Greenville, S.C., insisting that the images she described were real.

headline: Corruption Inquiry Appears to Expand to a Signature Cuomo Program
text: The longstanding focus of Manhattan federal prosecutors on Albany corruption appeared to be expanding with the issuance of grand jury subpoenas seeking records related to one of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s signature upstate economic development programs.

headline: Video of Scuffle Prompts Anger at Stockton, Calif., Police
text: A video of nine officers arresting a black teenager accused of walking in a bus lane on Tuesday has prompted complaints of overzealous policing in Stockton, Calif.

headline: Masahiro Tanaka Gives the Yankees No Concern, at Least Now
text: While the Mets have been balancing the present and the future with their young pitchers, they are not the city’s only baseball team that is making calculations with its most prized arms.

headline: Mets Get a Taste of the Postseason, and Savor It, Against the Yankees
text: Juan Uribe dropped his bat and charged out of the box, waiting, watching like everyone else as his fly ball headed toward the right-field wall. Then thousands of Mets fans shot out of their seats in unison, holding their arms high, cheering wildly, waving towels and flags, shouting into the air and hugging the people next to them as Uribe rounded the bases with a skip in his step. He clapped his hands and let out a shout as he crossed home plate.

headline: Rangers Will Lean on New Acquisitions
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Having reached the Eastern Conference finals three of the past four seasons, the Rangers opened training camp on Friday still a favorite to make a championship run.

headline: Islanders Embrace Their Future in Brooklyn While Staying Connected With the Past
text: N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman was exuberant about the Islanders’ move to Brooklyn when he spoke to Barclays Center sponsors and ticket holders in Manhattan the night before the team opened training camp on Long Island.

headline: Once Again, Mystics Have Liberty’s Number
text: In their first playoff game at Madison Square Garden since 2010, the Liberty treated their fans to a thrilling 50 minutes of basketball, but they now stand one game away from elimination after an 86-83 double-overtime loss on Friday in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference semifinals.

headline: Mitchell L. Gaynor, 59, Dies; Oncologist and Author on Alternative Treatments
text: Dr. Mitchell L. Gaynor, a Manhattan oncologist and popular author who taught cancer patients to supplement conventional medicine with soothing music, diet and meditation — and practiced what he prescribed — was found dead on Tuesday at his country home in Hillsdale, N.Y. He was 59.

headline: Top Trustees at Carnegie Hall Deny Ronald Perelman’s Charges
text: With Carnegie Hall reeling from accusations leveled against it this week by its departing chairman, Ronald O. Perelman, a group of top trustees sent a letter on Friday to the rest of the board calling his charge — that they had failed to diligently respond to his concerns — “totally untrue.”

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 7 P.M. (AMC) THE GREAT GATSBY (2013) Leonardo DiCaprio stars as the enigmatic millionaire Jay Gatsby, and Carey Mulligan portrays Daisy Buchanan, the object of his obsession, in Baz Luhrmann’s stylized musical take on the F. Scott Fitzgerald novel. Tobey Maguire is Nick Carraway, the Yale graduate — and, conveniently, Daisy’s cousin — renting the cottage next to Gatsby’s colossal Long Island mansion. “Despite what you may have heard, it is an eminently enjoyable movie,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film, which won Oscars for best costume and production design. Still, is the tale “a credible love story?” he asked. “Fitzgerald himself was not sure, but Mr. Luhrmann, Mr. DiCaprio and Ms. Mulligan make it an effective one.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Many of the popes have certainly said the words about poverty. But what Francis has been able to do is put a focus on it that isn’t blurred or distracted by other things.”

headline: Corrections: September 19, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Meet Alpha: The Next ‘Next Generation’
text: For professional trend forecasters, a generation (as in Generation X, or Y) is less a collection of individuals than a commodity: to be processed into a manufactured unit, marketed and sold to clients. To get there first and define the next next generation is like staking a claim in a gold rush.

headline: Do Wild Dogs Sleep as Much as Your Pets?
text: Q. Do dogs in the wild sleep as much as domesticated animals?

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted on @nytimes this week took followers from an encounter with Usher in Havana to a 13th-century church in Norway.

headline: Unraveling a String of Veteran Marine Suicides, One by One
text: In the 105-degree heat of a Las Vegas parking lot last June, a handful of infantry veterans dressed in black started gathering by the side door of a small church.

headline: In Unit Stalked by Suicide, Veterans Try to Save One Another
text: After the sixth suicide in his old battalion, Manny Bojorquez sank onto his bed. With a half-empty bottle of Jim Beam beside him and a pistol in his hand, he began to cry.

headline: Photographing Marine Veterans on the Home Front
text: Todd Heisler, a New York Times staff photographer, worked with the reporter Dave Philipps on a report about suicides in the Second Battalion, Seventh Marine Regiment. In 2008, the 2/7 deployed to a wild swath of Helmand Province in Afghanistan and suffered more casualties than any other Marine battalion that year. Below, Mr. Heisler recounts his experiences during the reporting of the article.

headline: Terry Bowen: A Utility Player for the Elderly
text: Terry Bowen, 59, is a concierge for Aegis on Madison, a senior care center in Seattle.

headline: In Philadelphia, Putting on a Show for a Holy Headliner
text: More than a month before Pope Francis was scheduled to arrive in Philadelphia for two days of speeches, celebrations and communion, Scott Mirkin, a local concert producer, was staring at a grassy patch in front of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, trying to ensure that the papal visit also would be a decent piece of entertainment.

headline: Jonathan M. Tisch: Beware of the Thin Air at the Top
text: This interview with Jonathan M. Tisch, co-chairman of the board of the Loews Corporation and chairman of its subsidiary Loews Hotels & Resorts, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Thriving
text: Just a heads up for people in the New York area: on the 29th I’ll lead a discussion with Richard Layard and David M. Clark of their new book Thrive: How Better Mental Health Care Transforms Lives and Saves Money. It’s actually very important stuff.

headline: Sibling:Spring 2016 RTW
text: Looks from Sibling’s spring show.

headline: The Creativity of the Permahawks
text: Tim Taylor writes about low interest rates. As he notes, many economists see low rates as a natural (in both the colloquial and Wicksellian sense) response to a weak economy; but he respectfully cites the Bank for International Settlements, which argues that low rates are a source of terrible economic distortions. But it seems to me that there’s some context missing.

headline: 6 Entrepreneurship Lessons From Family Businesses
text: Entrepreneurs who have built companies that touch multiple generations share what they have learned along the way.

headline: The American Dream, Served Family Style
text: Gicela López started a taqueria in hopes of providing a better life for her children. Today the whole family works in the store, but her eldest wonders if the family’s sacrifice has been worthwhile.

headline: A Noisy Cafe Next Door
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Holly Fulton: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The latest designs from Holly Fulton.

headline: The Pint-Size C.E.O.
text: Moziah Bridges started making bow ties when he was 9 years old. Now he is 13 and at the helm of his own company, Mo’s Bows. But when it comes to the business, who is really in charge?

headline: The Next Generation of Yuengling Beer
text: D. G. Yuengling & Son has been a family-run brewery for five generations. Now its chief, Dick Yuengling, is struggling to pass the baton to his four daughters.

headline: Brothers of Invention
text: When Marcus Weller asked his brother, Mitchell, to help with his start-up, Skully Systems, he didn’t expect that it would also bring his family closer together.

headline: The Art of Shoji
text: At Miya Shoji, a father-son team takes a different approach to business and to life, keeping craft as the guiding principle.

headline: A Stakeholders’ Strike
text: When a family feud rocked the corporate ranks at the Market Basket supermarket chain, the families that worked and shopped at the store took matters into their own hands.
