text: This video is part of a series examining the world of the entrepreneurial family. Click here to view more.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Social Media Defends Ahmed Mohamed
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the industry.

headline: F.D.A. Nominee Califf’s Ties to Drug Makers Worry Some
text: WASHINGTON — At a DoubleTree Hotel in Durham, N.C., in May 2014, Dr. Robert M. Califf gave a presentation to a group of biomedical researchers, lawyers and industry experts. He spoke about ways to quicken the pace of biomedical innovation by transforming research. Toward the end he showed a slide that noted one barrier: regulation.

headline: After the Grateful Dead, Phil Lesh Shows He Has a Head for Business
text: A few times a month, Sam Satenstein lines up outside Terrapin Crossroads, a music hall and restaurant in San Rafael, Calif., for performances by the band Phil Lesh and Friends. The hall is owned by Mr. Lesh, the 75-year-old Grateful Dead bassist, and his wife, Jill. Mr. Satenstein is almost always first in line; when the doors open he rushes in to secure a spot on the side of the stage favored by Mr. Lesh. He plops down on the floor to protect the space.

headline: Hunter Original: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Designs from Hunter’s spring show.

headline: Loving the Job, but Loathing the Boss
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Abandoning Afghan War Zone in a Perilous Quest for Europe
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Najim Rahim says that when he looks around his neighborhood in the northern city of Kunduz now, “I feel lonely.”

headline: Farooq Kathwari: Classic American Design and a Classic American Success Story
text: We have 18 acres off Interstate 84 in Danbury, Conn. Years ago this was a farm. The company bought the farmland in the 1970s and moved the headquarters here from New York.

headline: Russian Buildup in Syria Raises Questions on Role
text: LONDON — Russia’s military buildup in Syria now includes surface-to-air missiles as well as combat aircraft with air-to-air capability, deployments that raise “serious questions” about Moscow’s role in the region, Secretary of State John Kerry said Saturday.

headline: Earrings with Fringe Appeal
text: Decadent accessories that dangle and sway with the vivacity of the Roaring Twenties.

headline: Variety: A Tipsy Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Ali Wentworth had a politically blueblood upbringing (her mother served as President Ronald Reagan’s White House social secretary), but that hasn’t stopped her from forging her own somewhat rebellious path: she’s a comedienne, author, actress and producer. You are most likely to remember her as Jerry Seinfeld’s girlfriend on the “Schmoopie”/Soup Nazi episode, but she’s come a long way since then. She’s like a more socially acceptable version of Chelsea Handler.

headline: Faustine Steinmetz’s Fine Line(s) and Poetic Presentation
text: The designer showed pleats, fringe and gauzy grids for spring/summer 2016.

headline: U.S. and China Seek Arms Deal for Cyberspace
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and China are negotiating what could become the first arms control accord for cyberspace, embracing a commitment by each country that it will not be the first to use cyberweapons to cripple the other’s critical infrastructure during peacetime, according to officials involved in the talks.

headline: Minnesota’s Mascot Turns Heads With Head Spins
text: MINNEAPOLIS — It usually happens spontaneously, by request, without any fanfare or cue.

headline: Party Rules to Streamline Race May Backfire for G.O.P.
text: LOS ANGELES — When gloomy Republican Party leaders regrouped after President Obama’s 2012 re-election, they were intent on enhancing the party’s chances of winning back the White House. The result: new rules to head off a prolonged and divisive nomination fight, and to make certain the Republican standard-bearer is not pulled too far to the right before Election Day.

headline: Top 10 Moments from New York Fashion Week
text: T’s market director recalls highlights from the spring/summer 2016 shows.

headline: Welcome to the Age of the Unfunny Joke
text: THE first half of Tig Notaro’s new comedy special, which was released in August on HBO, included jokes about swimming with gastrointestinal distress and a confused airport security worker. The crowd laughed with delight. Then, more than halfway through the show, Ms. Notaro removed her blazer and shirt and completed her performance naked to the waist, displaying the scars from her double mastectomy.

headline: Abstract New York
text: Collaborating with the elements, a city’s expressions of anger and anxiety turn into painterly abstractions.

headline: Bernie Sanders Lightens Up With Stephen Colbert
text: As the “Late Show With Stephen Colbert” began, the host joked at a potential awkwardness from having Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont on as his guest.

headline: What Solange Knowles Wore to New York Fashion Week
text: The singer attended numerous shows and parties — in a series of outfit changes. A rundown of what she wore.

headline: ‘White Only’ Signs in Art Project at SUNY Buffalo Draw Concern
text: A graduate student at the State University of New York at Buffalo hung “black only” and “white only” signs around campus this week as part of an art project, which she said was intended to provoke a searing conversation.

headline: Emilia Wickstead: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The latest looks from Emilia Wickstead’s spring show.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Going Gaga for Ohad Naharin
text: DANCE, ESPECIALLY BALLET, is often seen as a quest for perfection in human form. Not so for Ohad Naharin, the artistic director of the Tel Aviv-based Batsheva Dance Company. Rather than watch an hour of accomplished performance, Naharin would prefer to see five seconds of something sublime — that indefinable quality described by the thinker Edmund Burke as ‘‘delightful horror.’’ ‘‘This is where I wish to be, as a spectator and a creator,’’ Naharin says — and, judging from his inimitable oeuvre from the past 35 years, the choreographer, widely hailed as one of the most influential luminaries of contemporary dance, has succeeded in this desire.

headline: J.W. Anderson: Spring 2016 RTW
text: J.W. Anderson’s spring 2016 show.

headline: Rate Rage
text: OK, I should have seen that one coming, but didn’t: the banking industry has responded to the Fed’s decision not to hike rates with a primal cry of rage. And that, I think, tells us what we need to know about the political economy of permahawkery.

headline: Pope Francis Departs Rome for Cuba
text: Pope Francis boarded a flight at Rome’s Fiumicino airport on his way to Cuba, where he is expected on Saturday evening.

headline: Warily Eyeing China, Philippines May Invite U.S. Back to Subic Bay
text: SUBIC BAY, Philippines — In a flash of anticolonialist fervor nearly a quarter-century ago, lawmakers in the Philippines expelled the United States from an enormous naval base here, then the largest overseas outpost of the American military. Promising to break free from the “shackles of dictatorship,” they declared that foreign troops would never return.

headline: A Hockey Life Full of Turns in the Minors
text: TROUT CREEK, Mont. — There are several ways to get to Trout Creek. Roy Sommer, a hockey coach who knows the back ways of the professional game as well as anyone, likes the dirt road.

headline: When Purloined Letters Make News
text: With the pro football season in full swing, the discussion of Sony Pictures’ coming film, “Concussion,” could hardly be timelier.

headline: How Federer Thrives in an Age of Disruption
text: SUPPORT for Roger Federer out in Flushing last week at the United States Open’s men’s final was mob-loud and unruly. There was raucous cheering every time Novak Djokovic netted a first serve, and calculated yelling when he was in his service motion. This owed something to the three-hour rain delay, which, to judge from the lines snaking from the alcohol concessions at Arthur Ashe Stadium, led many fans to tailgate, albeit with pink drinks.

headline: The (Fake) Meat Revolution
text: IF only meat weren’t so delicious!

headline: Justice Falls Short in G.M. Case
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — WITH tough talk that its actions belie, the Justice Department announced last week that it was bringing criminal charges against General Motors for “concealing a potentially deadly safety defect” from regulators and “misleading consumers regarding the safety” of G.M. vehicles, which caused or contributed to at least 124 deaths in accidents when airbags failed to deploy.

headline: Evangelicals and the Carson Illusion
text: Why Ben Carson’s personal appeal to the religious right might be a greater folly than Trumpmania.

headline: How to Close Guantánamo
text: For almost 14 years, the United States’ military prison camp in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, has sat festering on the edge of the Caribbean and the Constitution. Opened by President George W. Bush in the panicky months after the Sept. 11 attacks, the detention center has had a powerful radicalizing effect, has severely tarnished America’s standing as a nation of laws and has cost taxpayers more than $5.2 billion.

headline: Making Government Logical
text: THERE wasn’t a lot of fanfare, but last week may turn out to be among the most consequential of President Obama’s second term. By executive order, Mr. Obama directed federal agencies to incorporate behavioral science — insights into how people actually make decisions — into their programs.

headline: Grading More Fairly
text: Readers discuss a letter by Elizabeth Wissner-Gross asserting that some college students who excel are not being given the A’s they deserve to avoid charges of grade inflation.

headline: Googling for God
text: IT has been a bad decade for God, at least so far. Despite the rising popularity of Pope Francis, who was elected in 2013, Google searches for churches are 15 percent lower in the first half of this decade than they were during the last half of the previous one. Searches questioning God’s existence are up. Many behaviors that he supposedly abhors have skyrocketed. Porn searches are up 83 percent. For heroin, it’s 32 percent.

headline: My Father, the Priest
text: WHEN anyone asks what my father does, I say he’s a retired teacher. He did, after all, teach high school science and Latin, so I’m not lying. I’m just not telling the whole story: My father, married to my mother for 45 years, is a Catholic priest. Not a former priest, but a member of the clergy in good standing in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport, Conn. Especially on a date, that’s a conversation stopper.

headline: Why I Use Trigger Warnings
text: TRIGGER warnings have been getting a lot of pushback lately. Professors who have adopted the practice of alerting their students to potentially disturbing content in a text or class are being accused of coddling millennials. And the students who request them are being called “infantile,” or worse. In a recent story in The Atlantic, the authors Greg Lukianoff and Jonathan Haidt describe them as part of a movement, “undirected and driven largely by students, to scrub campuses clean of words, ideas, and subjects that might cause discomfort or give offense.”

headline: Elizabeth Engelhardt
text: Elizabeth Engelhardt is a professor of Southern studies at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill. Her research focuses on the interplay of food, race, gender, sports, ecology and culture in the South.

headline: Arab Coalition Bombs Yemen’s Capital, Killing Dozens
text: SANA, Yemen — A Saudi-led military coalition bombarded government buildings and residential neighborhoods in Sana, the Yemeni capital, overnight on Saturday, killing more than two dozen people, officials and witnesses said, and destroying homes in Sana’s Old City, a Unesco World Heritage site.

headline: Facebook Group’s Push for Safe Land Passage for Migrants Founders
text: EDIRNE, Turkey — Doaa, a 25-year old Syrian, was lying in the shade one day last week, trying to shelter herself from the scorching sun in a makeshift camp near this northwestern border city. A pile of blankets next to her quivered, and a tiny hand emerged. Her son, Nassim, was just a week old.

headline: Cubans Have Mixed Opinions on Effect of Visit by Pope Francis
text: HAVANA — In a dilapidated eatery in Old Havana, Josef Fonseca, 92, sat in a worn plastic chair Saturday evening watching the arrival of Pope Francis in Cuba on a television with a snowy screen.

headline: In Long Run, Cardinals Hope That a Breather Helps
text: The St. Louis Cardinals, to nobody’s surprise, became the first team to reach 90 victories when they won in Milwaukee on Tuesday. The Cardinals could climb to 100 wins in the regular season, a feat unmatched since the Philadelphia Phillies did it in 2011. Naturally, the Cardinals beat those Phillies in the playoffs and went on to win the World Series.

headline: The Latest Jewels: Like Found Family Heirlooms
text: Warm metals, intricate designs and colored stones mimic make new designs seem timeless.

headline: Simone Rocha: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Simone Rocha presents her spring collection.

headline: Giants’ Defense Off to a Slow Start in Steve Spagnuolo’s Return Engagement
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Coach Tom Coughlin, trying to address failures that contributed to his team’s missing the playoffs each of the last three seasons, returned to a glorious chapter in the franchise’s past when he hired Steve Spagnuolo as defensive coordinator in January.

headline: Pope Francis, Arriving in Cuba, Seeks to Revive Church
text: HAVANA — In brokering the historic thaw between Cuba and the United States, Pope Francis stepped squarely into the thorny realm of geopolitics, sending letters to the presidents of both nations, playing host to secret meetings in the halls of the Vatican and nudging the Cold War enemies to put a half-century of vitriol and mistrust behind them.

headline: This Rugby Player Creates Rhymes and Rhythm
text: BRIGHTON AND HOVE, England — Just before Thanksgiving in 2013, Mike Petri and his wife, Lauren, were browsing in a bookstore in Bethlehem, Pa. Lauren was due to give birth to the couple’s first child in a few weeks, and so the couple were looking to fill out their collection of children’s books. They grabbed plenty of standards — “The Very Hungry Caterpillar,” some Dr. Seuss titles — but Petri was looking for something specific.

headline: J.W. Anderson’s Spring 2016 Space Adventure
text: The designer described his inspiration as a “women’s odyssey.”

headline: For a Day, the Yankees Do All the Right Things and Throttle the Mets
text: The division title is still possible for the Yankees, who played almost flawlessly in a 5-0 victory against the Mets on Saturday, but a wild-card berth would not be an embarrassment. The Yankees always have grander hopes, anyway.

headline: Gareth Pugh: Spring2016 RTW
text: Gareth Pugh’s spring collection.

headline: Thousands of Migrants Flood Into Austria
text: LONDON — Thousands of migrants poured into Austria on Saturday after being bounced around countries overwhelmed by their arrival and insistent that they keep moving.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, in Own Ways, Show Pull at New Hampshire Convention
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Hillary Rodham Clinton turned to New Hampshire Democratic officials and county leaders on Saturday for help in fighting the surging campaign of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, who holds a steady lead over her in state opinion polls in the 2016 presidential primary race.

headline: Carly Fiorina Draws Notice as Republicans, Hoping to Stand Out, Visit Michigan
text: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich. — Emboldened by a heralded debate performance, Carly Fiorina brought an air of political star power to this Michigan resort island in Lake Huron on Saturday, captivating a gathering of party activists with her toughness and vision for Republican leadership.

headline: With Chelsea and Arsenal, a Chilly Handshake Kicks Off a Heated Afternoon
text: LONDON — So, let’s begin with the important stuff: José Mourinho, the brilliant (and occasionally belligerent) manager of Chelsea, did, in fact, shake hands on Saturday with Arsène Wenger, the professorial (and occasionally petty) manager of Arsenal. Their palms touched!

headline: Assistant Coach With Potential Bides Time on Liberty
text: The first player Bill Laimbeer signed after becoming coach of the Liberty was Katie Smith, then a 14-year veteran. At 38, she was past her prime and an incongruous on-court addition for a team looking to rebuild around youth after a disappointing 15-19 season in 2012.

headline: Falcons (1-0) at Giants (0-1) Matchup
text: 1 p.m., Fox

headline: Put a Lid on It!
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today we welcome a new constructor. Jason Mueller, ably assisted by Jeff Chen, makes his New York Times debut with a theme that is absolutely charming. It’s the TOPS, in fact.

headline: At 88, Tom Benson Conducts Business as Usual for New Orleans Teams
text: NEW ORLEANS — In his three decades as owner of the Saints, Tom Benson has had his share of off-season drama. In 2005, he temporarily moved the team to Texas after Hurricane Katrina swamped New Orleans. Five years later, the Saints basked in the glow of their only Super Bowl victory. Then, in 2012, the N.F.L. penalized the team for rewarding players who hurt opponents.

headline: Latino Catholics See Reflection in a Friar Set for Sainthood
text: VENTURA, Calif. — On his way to Mass every morning at Mission San Buenaventura, Miguel Olivas drives past the bronze statue of the Catholic mission’s founder, Junípero Serra, a Spanish Franciscan friar, and murmurs a plea: “Pray for me, Father Serra. Watch over me.”

headline: In Case You Missed It: Top Articles of the Week
text: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from Sept. 11 to Sept. 17.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Patriots Inspire a Golf-Course Distraction

headline: Pope Francis Arrives in Havana
text: The pope is on a nine-day tour that will include visits to U.S. cities.

headline: International Organizations Providing Aid to Syrian Refugees
text: A number of nongovernmental organizations have contributed aid to Syrian refugees in Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey, but not enough to keep them from fleeing to Europe, according to the United Nations.

headline: The United Nations Syria Regional Refugee and Resilience Plan
text: One reason for the wave of migrants fleeing to Europe is the deterioration of the conditions that Syrians face in Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey, largely caused by sharp falls in international funding from United Nations countries.

headline: Versus: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Looks from Versus’s spring show.

headline: U.N. Funding Shortfalls and Cuts in Refugee Aid Fuel Exodus to Europe
text: LONDON — One of the prime reasons for the wave of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers washing into Europe is the deterioration of the conditions that Syrians face in Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey, a worsening largely caused by sharp falls in international funding from United Nations countries, officials and analysts say.

headline: Islamic Militants Kill 56 Captive Syrian Soldiers
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Islamic militants led by an affiliate of Al Qaeda gunned down dozens of Syrian government soldiers taken prisoner during the takeover of a military air base this month, antigovernment activists said Saturday.

headline: Score Is Lopsided in 22nd Straight Loss, but Columbia Finds Room for Optimism
text: As Columbia Coach Al Bagnoli led his team back to the visitors’ locker room after a 44-24 loss to Fordham on Saturday at Jack Coffey Field, excited fans who gathered along the pathway cheered even though the Lions had absorbed their 22nd consecutive defeat. But this loss was a hopeful one. It did not feel like so many others.

headline: Haunted by Memories for 100 Years
text: In 1915, Mamie Kirkland and her family fled Ellisville, Miss., in fear that her father would be lynched. She swore she would never return. But at age 107, she made the journey.

headline: Mets and Yankees Clash With One Eye on October
text: Wham! Wham! Whack. Wham! Whack.

headline: Jackie Collins, Best-Selling Novelist of Hollywood, Dies at 77
text: Jackie Collins, who wrote the kind of novels that tweedy English professors typically ignore or sniff at — sex-filled, escapist, utterly unpretentious — but that millions of readers devour and teenagers used to read by flashlight under the covers at night, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. She was 77.

headline: Horror Drove Her From South. 100 Years Later, She Returned.
text: ELLISVILLE, Miss. — The dark S.U.V. rented for the occasion stopped outside the one-story City Hall. A wheelchair was rolled up to receive a petite passenger wearing a baseball cap dappled with sparkles, her hair gray-white, her skin mocha brown, her socks hot pink.

headline: As Some Veteran Yankees Wear Down, Rested Ones Contribute to Victory
text: The way Carlos Beltran, 38, moves and carries himself these days — it’s a wonder he’s not sipping prune juice in the dugout — Noah Syndergaard, brash and blessed with one of baseball’s best arms, was surely thinking what other pitchers have thought this season: No way can he touch my best fastball.

headline: Donald Trump Tells Evangelicals He Handled Obama Ethnicity Question Better Than John McCain
text: DES MOINES – In front of several hundred evangelical Christians on Saturday, Donald J. Trump took a dig at Senator John McCain for a well-known incident in which Mr. McCain took away a microphone from a woman to correct her after she said that Barack Obama was an Arab.

headline: Pope Arrives in Havana
text: Francis arrived in Cuba on Saturday and was greeted by President Raúl Castro at the airport and by crowds of Cubans on the streets.

headline: Noël Verset, Vigneron Who Helped Save a Wine Tradition, Dies at 95
text: Noël Verset, whose perseverance laboring in the steep, granite vineyards of Cornas, in the Rhône Valley of France, helped the Cornas appellation survive to be discovered by a new generation of wine lovers, died on Sept. 11 in Guilherand-Granges, France. He was 95.

headline: Pope Francis Visits: Day 1 in Cuba
text: The latest from Pope Francis’ visit to Cuba and the United States.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 20, 2015
text: “It would be the first time that cyber is treated as a military capability that needs to be governed as nuclear, chemical and biological weapons are.”

headline: I Said We’d Never Hire a College Admissions Adviser. Then We Did.

Certainly the admissions process is hard, but hiring someone to help your kid through the process? That’s something that “those” parents do, and we were not going to be those parents.

headline: 1915: German Armies Occupy Vilna
text: Vilna, capital of the Government of that name and the biggest city of Lithuania, has been occupied by the Germans. Details of the city’s fall have not yet been made known, but there is every reason to suppose that the Russian army of occupation has withdrawn intact. For the last few days, as the HERALD indicated yesterday, the fate of Vilna had been in the balance. The enemy occupying Molodetchno and Vidsy, Vilna was practically cut off from all railway communication, and its evacuation, generally regarded as imminent, had doubtless been fully prepared for by the Russian high command. The fall of Vilna, says the “Times” Petrograd correspondent, will facilitate a further German advance along the northern routes and will increase Russia’s difficulties in the matter of transport, both of men and munitions. No official Russian statement has yet been issued, but even the German newspapers do not suggest that the army defending Vilna has been captured. Its escape may therefore be taken for granted, but its position is still a somewhat dangerous one, for an important enemy force threatens its flank from the east. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 21, 1915

headline: 1940: Rumania Wants Axis’ Help to Gain Province
text: BUCHAREST — One week after the formation of a National Legionary (Iron Guard) state, political order and totalitarian unity have been achieved in Rumania, and the government of Premier Gen. Ion Antonescu is ready to face the tremendous task of adjusting the country’s strained economic condition. The future of the regime and of Rumania depends upon the success of this effort, which also will determine the aid that Rumania can give Germany in its war effort. The Rumanian leaders hope to obtain axis help in re-creating a greater Rumania, which was partitioned this summer after the Nazis had said that the changes were necessary for peace in southeastern Europe. — New York Herald Tribune, September 21, 1940

headline: Metropolitan Opera Showcases Portraits for ‘Otello’ Opening
text: “These are portents; but yet I hope, I hope/They do not point on me,” says Desdemona in Shakespeare’s “Othello,” before her voice is stifled forever. The drawings and paintings of the British artist Celia Paul — dark, caustic self-portraits and portraits of women in her family — are nothing if not portentous. And 14 of her works will help kick off the Metropolitan Opera’s new season, in “Desdemona for Celia by Hilton,” a collaborative exhibition by Ms. Paul and the critic Hilton Als at Gallery Met, in conjunction with the opera’s new production of Verdi’s “Otello,” which opens Monday.

headline: A Fancy Melon Set, Reissued
text: A wedge of cantaloupe, its sweetness intensified by savory paper-thin prosciutto, is a sophisticated dish worthy of its own superlative utensils. The legendary Danish design house Georg Jensen rises to the challenge with this exquisite melon set made of radiant silver with a softly hammered surface — part graceful scalpel, part elegant spork. With furled leaves, tapered endpoints and handles like Ionic columns, the pattern represents the bridge between the house’s Art Nouveau roots and its embrace of Modernism. Out of production for decades, this set is part of a limited edition of reissued pieces, each crafted for luxuriously specialized tasks, from the Acorn collection created in 1915 by the designer Johan Rohde. Also on offer are a dainty grapefruit spoon and a new champagne saber, a Napoleonic-era tool that opens a bottle with one sharp blow to the neck.

headline: Republicans Ensnared in Questions of Identity Politics
text: As presidential candidates wrapped up busy weekends in South Carolina, Michigan, Iowa and other states, several took to the Sunday talk shows to clarify points and weigh in on new controversies. Identity politics have resurfaced on the Republican side and a new CNN/ORC poll shows that less than a week after the party’s second debate Donald J. Trump is clinging to his lead, while Carly Fiorina has surged into second place ahead of Ben Carson. Senator Marco Rubio of Florida is also showing signs of gaining traction, while Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin has fallen to the back of the pack. Here are the highlights.

Instead, for the 50th-anniversary tour that opened at the Winspear Opera House here on Friday and will conclude in New York in November, Ms. Tharp has fashioned a pair of new pieces: “Preludes and Fugues” and “Yowzie.”

text: It was a seemingly lovely afternoon to go out on the East River and do something memorable. For the group that left the marina in College Point, Queens, on Sunday in a dragon boat, the authorities said, that was exactly the plan.

headline: Review: New York Philharmonic Accompanies ‘On the Waterfront’ and ‘The Godfather’
text: The idea behind the Art of the Score series, one of the most popular innovations of the New York Philharmonic in recent years, could not be simpler: classic films are screened at Avery Fisher Hall with the Philharmonic playing the score live. But the execution of these projects is anything but simple.

headline: Review: Scott Shane’s ‘Objective Troy,’ on Killing the American Jihadist Anwar al-Awlaki
text: In September 2011, in northern Yemen, C.I.A. Predator drones killed Anwar al-Awlaki, an American citizen who was then 40 years old. He was a skinny, charismatic preacher educated at Colorado State University. As a younger man he had displayed a weakness for prostitutes and had devoured books about leadership like “The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People,” by Stephen R. Covey. At the time of his death, Mr. Awlaki advocated killing fellow Americans in the name of jihad. He had embraced Al Qaeda’s branch in Yemen and had participated in plots to blow up American airplanes.

headline: Review: A ‘Resurrection’ in Tune With the Atlanta Symphony’s Renewal
text: ATLANTA — Prescient as Mahlerians like to think their hero was, Mahler could not have imagined how useful his “Resurrection” Symphony would become in 21st-century America, with orchestra after orchestra emerging from a near-death crisis of one sort or another.

headline: Review: ‘Whistleblower,’ a Dance-Theater Take on Chelsea Manning
text: When the Army private Chelsea Manning, known at the time as Bradley Manning, leaked more than 700,000 sensitive documents, the possibility of a trial and sentence in a military prison may have been foreseeable. Less easy to predict was that the private’s situation would inspire “Whistleblower,” a piece of dance theater by the writer, director and choreographer Mark Dendy.

headline: Review: Banda de los Muertos Brings the Party for Its Album Debut
text: Banda de los Muertos locked into a boisterous churn almost from the start of its show on Friday night at Pioneer Works in Red Hook, Brooklyn. Playing “El Sinaloense,” a Mexican brass band standard, the group sputtered and blared, rolling hard with tumbling polyrhythm, filling the room with sound. As if on cue, dancing broke out in the audience, starting with a handful of couples near the foot of the stage.

headline: Review: In ‘Blindspot,’ an Amnesiac’s Tattoos Are the Clues
text: From its opening scene, a spine-tingling if-you-see-something-say-something moment, NBC’s “Blindspot” is an attention getter. Who knows whether its somewhat lurid central gimmick is sturdy enough to carry it for the long haul, but the show, which has its premiere Monday night, certainly gets off to an intriguing start.

headline: Review: In ‘Age & Beauty,’ Miguel Gutierrez Ponders the Personal and the Professional
text: If part of watching dance is piecing together afterimages, what is the effect of seeing a trilogy out of order? Enlightening. Miguel Gutierrez’s “Age & Beauty,” Parts 1 and 2, were reprised over the weekend in a co-presentation of New York Live Arts, where the works were performed, and Crossing the Line 2015.

headline: Review: Traditional Dance From Okinawa at Japan Society
text: For a dancegoer in New York, fall can feel like an onrush of the new, of premieres and untested experiments, by turns exciting and overwhelming. In the midst of all that, it was refreshing to spend time with something ancient on Friday, when the Japan Society offered “Traditional Dance From Okinawa With Live Music,” a rare and exquisite program showcasing the performing arts of Japan’s southwestern islands.

headline: Review: ‘Life in Pieces,’ a CBS Comedy, Told in Vignettes
text: “Life in Pieces,” which begins Monday on CBS, may be the ultimate antidote for those who find the supposed new golden age of television to be exhausting and time-eating. If that golden age is characterized by intricate, character-rich dramas that have to be watched from Season 1, Episode 1, here’s a half-hour comedy you can consume in six-minute bites, as many or as few as you want.

headline: ‘Masaan’ and Other Indian Films Steer Away From Bollywood Escapism
text: MUMBAI — At the beginning of “Masaan,” the most acclaimed Indian movie of the year, two lovers meet at a ramshackle motel in the holy northern city of Varanasi. In the middle of their clandestine sexual encounter, police officers barge into the room and threaten the couple, setting off a chain of events with devastating consequences. Composed of parallel yet interconnected tales, “Masaan” explores India’s forces of caste and social conservatism, which continue to hold sway as the country makes a dizzying passage into the modern world.

headline: Mary Katrantzou’s Cosmic Chaos
text: The designer focused on the theme of exploration for her spring/summer 2016 collection.

headline: Review: Argento Chamber Ensemble’s ‘Scelsi Rediscovered’
text: “Scelsi Rediscovered” was the title given to the Argento Chamber Ensemble’s simmering concert Friday evening at the Czech Center New York. But it hasn’t been all that long since this enigmatic, reclusive Italian master was discovered in the first place. Not until the years before Scelsi’s death in 1988 did his works — some more than 50 years old at that point — become widely known.

headline: Here Comes Trouble
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — A succinct scrutiny of the puzzle today: This one by Bruce Haight looks relatively non-challenging on the surface, but offers a “one-two punch” when you realize that, yes, this theme is merely a bunch of two-word “S-S” phrases, but they’re all either abutting each other or — even better — interlocking. That’s a neat surprise on a Monday.

headline: Alabama Church Shooting Wounds Infant and 2 Adults
text: A man walked into a church service in East Selma, Ala., on Sunday morning and opened fire with a handgun, shooting his 24-year-old girlfriend and their infant son and then the pastor before being disarmed by congregants, according to the police.

headline: Bipartisan Effort Fights Health Law Rule That Could Raise Premiums
text: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress from both parties, as well as some employers, insurers and state insurance commissioners, are calling for changes in the Affordable Care Act to prevent premium increases that are expected to affect workers at many small and midsize companies next year.

headline: Cowboys Search for Answers After Tony Romo Injury
text: Dealing a major blow to the Dallas Cowboys, their star quarterback Tony Romo left Sunday’s 20-10 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles with a broken left clavicle. He did not return and may be out for an extended amount of time.

headline: Clever, a Software Service, Gives Schools a Way to Manage Data Flow to Apps
text: For years, Mark Racine, the technology director of the Boston Public Schools, and his team plodded through a cumbersome exercise at the start of each school year: transferring student roster information from school databases to the various learning apps that teachers wanted to use in the classroom.

headline: Emmy Red Carpet Fashion
text: Looks from Taraji P. Henson, Kerry Washington, Laverne Cox and more at the 67th Emmy Awards.

headline: President ‘Heartbroken’ Over Death of Adviser
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said on Sunday that he was “heartbroken” at the death of a technology policy adviser, Jake Brewer, who was killed in a cycling accident on Saturday while participating in a charity ride to raise money for cancer research.

headline: ISIS Defectors Reveal Disillusionment
text: LONDON — A small but growing number of defectors from the Islamic State are risking reprisals and imprisonment to speak out about their disillusionment with the extremist group, according to a research organization that tracks former and current militants.

headline: Amid Protests, Nepal Adopts Constitution
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — After nearly a decade of delay marked by haggling and political infighting, Nepal formally adopted a constitution on Sunday, with President Ram Baran Yadav calling the moment a realization of “the continuous democratic movements initiated by Nepalese people” after he signed the document.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 21
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: A Rookie Brings Her Skills to the ‘Super Bowl’ of Social Planning
text: WASHINGTON — Imagine a week in which you arrange the halftime show for the Super Bowl, organize the trophy ceremony for the World Cup and then, for good measure, plan your daughter’s wedding.

headline: C. K. Williams, Poet, Dies at 78; Pulitzer Winner Tackled Politics and Morality
text: C. K. Williams, whose morally impassioned poems addressing war, poverty and climate change, as well as the imponderable mysteries of the psyche, won him a Pulitzer Prize and a National Book Award, died on Sunday at his home in Hopewell. N.J. He was 78.

headline: G.O.P. Field Wrestles With Questions on Islam and the Presidency
text: WASHINGTON — Faith and politics intersected on Sunday when discussions of how Donald J. Trump handled a question about President Obama’s religion evolved into an awkward debate over whether a Muslim could ever be commander in chief.

headline: Lawmakers Seek National Park in Honor of Stonewall
text: Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand of New York and Representative Jerrold Nadler of Manhattan unveiled a campaign on Sunday to create a national park honoring the Stonewall uprising, vowing that they would mount a petition drive urging President Obama to grant protected status to the site of a pivotal early clash in the movement for gay equality.

headline: In Courting Chinese Companies, Britain to Help Fund Planned Nuclear Plant
text: LONDON — The British government said on Monday that it would provide 2 billion pounds, or about $3.1 billion, in state aid for a nuclear power station planned for Hinkley Point in southwest England.

headline: Running Afoul of the Thai Monarchy
text: Thailand’s strict lèse-majesté laws make it a crime to insult the monarchy, an offense that includes a surprising number of activities.

headline: With King in Declining Health, Future of Monarchy in Thailand Is Uncertain
text: BANGKOK — After nearly seven decades on the throne, King Bhumibol Adulyadej, 87, the keystone of Thailand’s identity and a major unifying force for the country, is in declining health. With increasing frequency, the palace has issued medical bulletins detailing his ailments, and in recent days his youngest daughter has led prayer sessions following a Buddhist rite normally used for terminally ill patients.

headline: Kickstarter Focuses Its Mission on Altruism Over Profit
text: Many technology start-ups aim to become “unicorns,” the companies that get valued at $1 billion or more on their way to probable vast riches. Yancey Strickler and Perry Chen have no interest in that.

headline: Russian Project Honors Stalin’s Victims and Stirs Talk on Brutal Past
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — In a society stewing in nationalist sentiment, a little project called Last Address seems almost seditious.

headline: Tireless Star and Unorthodox Coach Help Lead Britain to Davis Cup Final
text: GLASGOW — Leon Smith was a curious choice when he was appointed captain of Britain’s Davis Cup team in April 2010. The team was on the verge of being relegated to the lowest levels of the competition, a tennis underworld populated by nations like San Marino and Liechtenstein and their squads of part-timers.

headline: Emmy Awards Red Carpet Fashion
text: The 67th prime time Emmy Awards on Sunday night in Los Angeles, brought television’s top performers, technicians and creators together for a night of self-congratulation and ceremony.

headline: Only Thing in Leonard Fournette’s Way: N.F.L. Rule Book
text: There was a rare moment of stillness at the beginning of Louisiana State’s 45-21 rout of visiting Auburn on Saturday. The Tigers — purple version — handed off to Leonard Fournette, and he stalled with some careful stutter-steps, letting L.S.U.’s offensive linemen clear his path.

headline: New York Military Academy’s Sudden Closing, After 126 Years
text: CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — Among its thousands of alumni, the 126-year-old New York Military Academy counts the unlikely grouping of Donald J. Trump, Stephen Sondheim and John A. Gotti. Yet all three have this in common: They remember their time at the prep school with deep affection.

headline: Apple Confirms Discovery of Malicious Code in Some App Store Products
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Hackers have found their way into Apple’s App Store.

headline: Mediators in Burkino Faso Issue Proposals to End Strife
text: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Mediators proposed ways to end a political crisis stemming from last week’s coup in Burkina Faso, just hours after the hotel where they were meeting on Sunday was stormed by supporters of the military.

headline: After Battling Safety Agency, Recaro Changes Course on Car Seat Recall
text: The recall seemed to be straightforward enough: Recaro Child Safety needed to fix some of its car seats so that they would not break free during a crash.

headline: The Refugee Crisis Has Produced One Winner: Organized Crime
text: IN the midst of the refugee crisis, the European Union has for the first time ever been considering deploying naval assets against organized crime. People smuggling, chiefly from Syria and the Horn of Africa, is now a multibillion-dollar business that is as profitable, if not more so, than the trade in illegal narcotics.

headline: Oregon’s Legal Sale of Marijuana Comes With Reprieve
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — About 15 years ago, when she was in her 20s, Erika Walton handed a bong to someone who turned out be a police officer, and was cited for marijuana possession. She paid the fine, she said, but the violation lingered on, haunting her record.

headline: On Instagram and Other Social Media, Redefining ‘User Engagement’
text: Shereen Way did not think twice about posting a photo on Instagram of her 4-year-old daughter wearing a green dress and pink Crocs sandals.

headline: Muscle Strain Will Keep Masahiro Tanaka From Making a Key Start in Toronto
text: Yankees Manager Joe Girardi opened his pregame news conference Sunday afternoon by saying he would start the proceedings. Normally, Girardi begins by fielding questions from reporters, so it was clear some kind of announcement was coming, and very likely it was bad news.

headline: A Game Changer for the Giants, for Better or Worse
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Fans tend to treat the N.F.L. season like an H. G. Wells science fiction story: Every week is Armageddon.

text: Dear Diary:

headline: A Firing at The Los Angeles Times Focuses Discontent
text: LOS ANGELES — In January, Jack Griffin, the chief executive of Tribune Publishing Company, took his senior management team to visit The Los Angeles Times, the jewel in his company’s portfolio of newspapers.

headline: Talented Pass Catcher Plays Defense for Jets
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Four of the five starters on the 2008-9 Hopkins High School boys’ basketball team, that season’s Minnesota state champion, received Division I scholarships. The exception was the 5-foot-11 point guard, who shot a little, passed a lot and relished his responsibility as a defensive stopper.

headline: Pope Francis Visits: Day 2 in Cuba
text: The latest from Pope Francis’ visit to Cuba and the United States.

headline: New York City to Add Housing for Domestic Violence Victims
text: New York City is planning to add more housing for homeless adults and children fleeing domestic violence, the latest effort by Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration to deal with a homelessness problem that has persisted as housing costs in the city have continued to soar.

headline: Jason Day Holds On to Win, and Grabs Top Ranking
text: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — Jason Day stood behind his second shot on the 465-yard 16th hole and took a moment to close his eyes to visualize his third.

headline: And the Emmy Goes to ...
text: Viola Davis made history as best lead actress in a drama series at Sunday night’s ceremony in Los Angeles.

headline: Government Declassifies Additional Portions of Once-Secret Report on Post-9/11 Surveillance
text: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by The New York Times, the government has declassified additional portions of a 2009 report by five agencies’ inspectors general about the Stellarwind program, the group of N.S.A. warrantless wiretapping and bulk phone and e-mail records collection activities initiated by President George W. Bush after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. In 2009, the government released a 43-page unclassified version which omitted discussion of many key facts that then remained secret. In April, the government released an earlier version of this report. The newly declassified portions largely consist of references to and descriptions of the text of Mr. Bush’s periodic authorizations to the N.S.A, which evolved over time — especially after a March 2004 confrontation with the Justice Department.

headline: Charter and Time Warner Vote, and Chinese Tech Meeting in Seattle
text: Shareholders of both Charter Communications and Time Warner Cable will vote on Monday on their proposed $56.7 billion merger. Announced in May, Charter’s takeover of Time Warner Cable, along with a deal for Bright House Networks, would create the country’s second-largest broadband Internet provider and third-largest video provider.

headline: Review: ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’ Tailored for Multitaskers
text: Everybody’s a Bottom in Eric Tucker’s riotous production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” in which a cast of five divides and multiplies like a troupe of stage-struck amoebas. Bottom the Weaver, you may recall, is the overeager amateur actor in this Shakespeare comedy of crazy mixed-up love — the one who wants to play all the parts, be they heroes, lions or ladies.

headline: ‘Fear the Walking Dead’ Recap: Wake Up, Travis
text: Season 1, Episode 4, “Not Fade Away”

headline: George W. Bush Made Retroactive N.S.A. ‘Fix’ After Hospital Room Showdown
text: WASHINGTON — President George W. Bush sought to retroactively authorize portions of the National Security Agency’s post-9/11 surveillance and data collection program after a now-famous incident in 2004 in which his attorney general refused to certify the program as lawful from his hospital bed, according to newly declassified portions of a government investigation.

headline: Years Ago, Mets Had Starters Who Finished With a Flourish
text: As the Mets try to win their first division title since 2006, their pitchers appear to be struggling physically down the stretch. A starting rotation that once seemed overpowering is looking a little gassed.

headline: Bike-Sharing Programs Gain a Toehold in New Jersey
text: JERSEY CITY — Last Wednesday, Steven M. Fulop, the mayor of Jersey City, got ready for one of his regular morning bike rides. He had his helmet on, but rather than his usual spandex jersey, he wore khakis, an oxford shirt and a light down vest. And instead of his $3,000 Kuota carbon-fiber racing bike, which Mr. Fulop, a former Marine, rides in triathlons, he mounted a hefty, bright blue Citi Bike.

headline: Mamdouha Bobst, Philanthropist and Public Health Advocate, Dies at 90
text: Mamdouha Bobst, a philanthropist and public health advocate whose donations benefited universities, hospitals and clinics for animals, died on Sept. 10 in Manhattan. She was 90.

headline: Red Carpet Trend at the 2015 Emmys? Trying to Stay Cool
text: It was hot, about 100 degrees hot, on some of the processional stops on the Emmys red carpet. To watch the two hours of coverage on E! — as grueling to observe as it must have been to sweat through — was to come away not with any single trend or theme, no runaway winner of the red-carpet lottery, but one simple message: It’s brutal out here.

text: LOS ANGELES — It was a night of firsts, and a night for establishment cable at the 67th Primetime Emmy Awards on Sunday.

headline: The 2015 Emmy Awards
text: Viola Davis’s win, for “How To Get Away With Murder,” is the first for an African-American actress in the drama category. Jon Hamm won his first Emmy Award for his role in “Mad Men.”

headline: Devils Lose Preseason Opener
text: Matt Irwin scored two power-play goals, leading the Boston Bruins to a 2-0 victory over the Devils in Providence, R.I., in the preseason opener for both teams.

headline: Jack Larson, a TV Jimmy Olsen Turned Playwright, Dies at 87
text: Jack Larson, the playwright and librettist who, as he often predicted with good-natured resignation, will be remembered best as the actor who played the cub reporter Jimmy Olsen on the television series “Adventures of Superman,” died on Sunday at his home in the Brentwood neighborhood of Los Angeles.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 9 P.M. (Fox) MINORITY REPORT This new series, based on the 2002 Steven Spielberg film starring Tom Cruise, travels ahead to 2065, by which time Pre-Crime — the ability to know in advance that a crime will be committed through foreknowledge gathered by psychics — has long been abolished and a young “precog” named Dash (Stark Sands) is trying to lead a civilian life despite continuing visions of bloodshed. Meanwhile in Washington, a police detective (Meagan Good) and a mayoral candidate (Peter Van Eyck) are struggling with the return of murder. “ ‘Minority Report,’ the TV series, appears to come from an alternative universe: one in which ‘Minority Report,’ the movie, was never made,” James Poniewozik wrote in The New York Times. “Taken on its own terms, then, ‘Minority Report’ is ... still not good,” he added. Though the future promises holographic phone calls, subway advertisements for marijuana goodies and the 75th season of “The Simpsons,” he wrote, “psychic powers make for dull detective work.” Season 2 of “Gotham,” which finds Detective Gordon (Ben McKenzie) seeking help from the Penguin after a shift in power at the Gotham City Police Department, leads in at 8. (Image: from left, Wilmer Valderrama, Li Jun Li and Ms. Good.)

headline: A Limit on Matt Harvey’s Innings Has New Fans: The Yankees
text: Matt Harvey walked into the dugout after the fifth inning, his head down, his face flushed from a hard day’s work. His teammates greeted him with high-fives and pats on the back for his performance. He stopped and chatted with Manager Terry Collins, found a water bottle and then found a seat where he could watch the rest of the game, because his day was evidently done.

headline: Aaron Rodgers and Packers Take Advantage of Seahawks Turnovers
text: For the second straight week, the Seattle Seahawks were left wondering what went wrong. The two-time defending N.F.C. champions lost to the Green Bay Packers, 27-17, on Sunday night, dropping to 0-2 for the season.

headline: 2 Colgate University Students Killed in Plane Crash
text: Two college students died on Sunday afternoon when the plane they were flying in crashed into a field in upstate New York shortly after takeoff, authorities said.

text: 8:30 p.m., ESPN, Ch. 11

headline: Emmy Awards 2015: A Show for a ‘Peak TV,’ Blockbuster Era
text: Awards shows often give tribute to how much excellence there is in their medium. Andy Samberg kicked off this year’s Emmy Awards with a musical tribute to, simply, how much there is.

headline: The Best of Week 2 in the N.F.L.
text: Coming off a game in which he turned two touches into 98 yards, the rookie David Johnson continued to shine for the Cardinals, returning the opening kickoff a club-record 108 yards for a touchdown to start a victory over the Bears. Johnson also ran for 42 yards on five carries with a touchdown. The rushing attack opened up things for Carson Palmer, who threw for four touchdowns.

headline: Making New Memories in the Aftermath of a Quebec Train Disaster
text: Early in the morning of July 6, 2013, when most of the inhabitants of the small Quebec town of Lac-Mégantic were asleep in their beds, a train transporting crude oil derailed and engulfed the town in flames.

headline: Can a GIF Work Better Than Words?
text: The GIF, or Graphics Interchange Format, was invented in 1987, honored as a “word of the year” in 2012 and has brought its creator a lifetime achievement award at the Webby Awards.

headline: OxyContin Is Not for Kids
text: Montpelier, Vt. — A YEAR and a half ago, I stood up before Vermonters and devoted my State of the State address to speaking about the opiate and heroin crisis affecting my state. Despite our best efforts since, this is not a battle we are winning. Now the Food and Drug Administration is recklessly making the problem worse with its decision to approve OxyContin for use by children as young as 11 years old.

headline: Let’s Not Move to Mars
text: IN the early years of the 20th century, zeppelins filled with flammable and explosive hydrogen were all the rage in Germany, a reckless infatuation that ended with the eruption and crash of the Hindenburg in 1937. Sometimes, technology is a triumph of wild-eyed enthusiasm over the unpleasant facts of the real world.

headline: The Pope and the Birth Control Ban
text: Pope Francis has taken a softer line than some of his predecessors on sexual and reproductive issues. He has said that the church should concentrate less on same-sex marriage, contraception and abortion, and this month he announced that during the church’s coming Holy Year of Mercy, all priests would be able to grant absolution for abortion.

headline: Mr. Putin’s Mixed Messages on Syria
text: President Vladimir Putin of Russia is trying to have it both ways in Syria. He is dangerously building up Russia’s military presence there, while positioning himself as the world’s savior against Islamic extremists and holding high-level military-to-military talks with the United States. President Obama should go one step further and be prepared to meet Mr. Putin later this month when the two are at the United Nations. If there is to be a solution to the Islamic State’s advance and to Syria’s war, both Russia and America will have to be involved.

headline: The Rage of the Bankers
text: Last week the Federal Reserve chose not to raise interest rates. It was the right decision. In fact, I’m among the economists wondering why we’re even thinking about raising rates right now.

headline: Don’t Coronate Carly Fiorina Just Yet
text: The media has a new darling in the Republican presidential disaster pageant: Carly Fiorina.

headline: Use Medicare’s Muscle to Lower Drug Prices
text: A poll last month by Consumer Reports found that a third of the patients who take prescription drugs are paying significantly more this year, forcing many to cut back on other necessities or load up on credit card debt. Another poll in August by the Kaiser Family Foundation found that about a quarter of those surveyed said they had trouble paying for prescription drugs.

headline: Volkswagen Stock Falls as Automaker Tries to Contain Fallout
text: FRANKFURT — Martin Winterkorn was uncharacteristically subdued last week when, on the eve of the Frankfurt auto show, he stepped into a beam of blue light to show off the latest products from the Volkswagen empire.

headline: Pope Francis’ U.S. Visit Could Benefit Both Left and Right
text: WASHINGTON — Pope Francis will arrive at a military base outside the capital on Tuesday afternoon to open his first visit to the United States, and President Obama will be there to welcome him. It is a gesture the president has extended to virtually no other foreign visitor.

headline: Ideas for E.L.L.s | Immigration
text: Note: Every Monday during the 2015-16 school year, we present a special post for English Language Learners. Each focuses on one topic, and offers an interactive quiz and a writing prompt.

headline: Can Russia Really Be a Partner to Bring Peace to Syria?
text: Can Russia be an ally in stabilizing Syria and fighting ISIS or is it too closely tied to the Assad regime?

headline: Zurich Insurance Ends Pursuit of RSA of Britain
text: LONDON — Zurich Insurance Group said on Monday that it was abandoning its pursuit of RSA Insurance Group, a smaller British rival, after a deterioration in its business performance, particularly in Zurich’s general insurance unit.

headline: Xi Jinping of China Arriving in U.S. at Moment of Vulnerability
text: BEIJING — President Xi Jinping of China looked regal as he stood in a limousine moving past Tiananmen Square this month, wearing a traditional suit of the kind favored by Mao and waving at parade troops assembled at attention. But the luster of Mr. Xi’s imperial presidency has dulled lately.

headline: Trading Meat for Tires as Bartering Economy Grows in Greece
text: ATHENS — Thodoris Roussos stood in his butcher’s shop and pointed to a large white delivery truck at the curb. For months, he had put off replacing the tires, because Greece’s financial crisis had cut into business. But recently, he upgraded the van with a set of good wheels at a price that could not be beat.

headline: France Rejects Google’s Efforts to Limit Application of Privacy Ruling
text: France’s privacy watchdog just will not take no for an answer.

headline: Foster Parenting: When to Explain, When to Let It Pass
text: “Is this your son’s first year of preschool?”

headline: David Brock’s ‘Killing the Messenger’
text: I’ve always wondered about the details of the reconciliation between Hillary Clinton and David Brock. As an investigative reporter for The American Spectator in the 1990s, Brock published whatever the Arkansas state troopers told him about Bill Clinton and his women and put the rumor about Vince Foster and Hillary into print. His tone and loose reporting ethics arguably unleashed two decades of cheap tabloid right-wing best sellers that still dog Hillary and Bill today. Is that really something the Clintons ever got past?

headline: ‘Black Silent Majority,’ by Michael Javen Fortner
text: For as long as I can remember, certain relatives of mine were always dismayed and often enraged by the daily headlines and nightly news stories of crime. As a kid I heard countless tales of the terrible outrages visited on black people by other black people: burglarizing homes, pulling guns and shooting at one another, too often claiming innocent bystanders in the crossfire. Some of these stories were personal testimonies of victimization. In my ’70s childhood on Chicago’s South Side, I was taught that some black people behaved despicably.

headline: Hillary Clinton Rates Unfavorably in New York State Poll
text: A rough political summer has left Hillary Rodham Clinton with negative favorability ratings in a New York State poll for the first time, a low mark in the state she represented as a senator for eight years.

headline: Cycling 101 Needn’t Be Collision Course
text: Cycling as recreation, sport and transport has exploded in recent years, with continued growth likely as more locales install bike lanes and bike-share programs. But as you might expect, with that growth has come an increase in bike-related injuries.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Morning Agenda: Second Chance for Tsipras
text: SECOND CHANCE FOR TSIPRAS | Greek voters returned Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece to power on Sunday, even though he had abandoned the anti-austerity platform he was elected on, Suzanne Daley reports in The New York Times. Many of them said he had fought hard to get a better deal for the country and deserved a second chance.

headline: 50 of Our Best
text: The New York Times recently passed a million digital-only subscribers, and we’d like our readers to be a part of the milestone.

headline: ScienceTake | Turtle Run
text: It’s hatching time for green sea turtles on the Atlantic Coast and a record year for the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge in Florida.

headline: A Quarter of the Country’s Green Sea Turtles Call Florida Refuge Home
text: Green sea turtles have had their ups and downs. They were so plentiful that they were commercially harvested for hundreds of years in the Atlantic, but are now listed as threatened or endangered under the Endangered Species Act, depending on the location.

headline: Indonesia’s ‘Mud Volcano’ and Nine Years of Debate About Its Muck
text: Nine years ago, a rice paddy in eastern Java suddenly cleaved open and began spewing steaming mud. Before long, it covered an area twice the size of Central Park; roads, factories and homes disappeared under a tide of reeking muck. Twenty lives were lost and nearly 40,000 people displaced, with damages topping $2.7 billion.

headline: As Fires Grow, a New Landscape Appears in the West
text: NEAR COCHITI CANYON, N.M. — The hills here are beautiful, a rolling, green landscape of grasses and shrubs under a late-summer sky. But it is starkly different from what was here before: vast forests of ponderosa pine. The repeated blazes that devastated the trees were caused by simple things: an improperly extinguished campfire in 1996, a tree falling on a power line in 2011.

headline: New York Today: A Whirlwind Week
text: Updated 9:37 a.m.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: Antonio Berardi: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Berardi’s spring 2016 collection.

headline: A Saudi-American Reset
text: WASHINGTON — After more than two years of perceived slights and supposed snubs, the new contours of a revitalized but evolving partnership between the United States and Saudi Arabia are beginning to take shape. This month’s visit to Washington by King Salman solidified the defense and security aspects of this new version of an old relationship. The Saudis are also strongly pushing an economic agenda as the centerpiece of what King Salman identified as a “new strategic alliance for the 21st century.”

headline: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love A.I.
text: The distinction between man and machine is under siege. The technology wizard Ray Kurzweil speaks with casual confidence of achieving electromagnetic immortality with our once-human selves eternally etched onto universal servers. For me, the possibility that machines will acquire the equivalent of human feelings and emotions is pure fantasy. And yet, as a neurologist, I cannot ignore advancing machine intelligence’s implications about the human mind.

headline: Trapped in the System: A Sick Doctor’s Story
text: We spend a lot of time talking about various metrics of quality or access in the American health care system. The problem with many of them is that they rarely seem to capture the issues that people face in dealing with care. Although many metrics are improving, problems remain that still seem insurmountable.

headline: New York Jets at Indianapolis Colts Preview
text: Jets (1-0) at Colts (0-1)

headline: Today in Politics: Republicans’ Comments Put Them on Other Side of Pope’s Message
text: Good Monday morning. Pope Francis has delivered an encyclical calling for increased action against climate change, denounced the role of global capitalism in increasing poverty, and enthusiastically supported the new nuclear accord with Iran, positions that have caused tensions in the Republican Party. Now the pope, whom American Catholics overwhelmingly support, arrives in the United States as Republicans wrestle with these issues and with perceptions of intolerance.

headline: Explaining the Flight News and Rules on Travel to Cuba
text: Nearly a year after the United States announced it would be loosening travel restrictions to Cuba, the two countries have reached an agreement on regularly scheduled commercial flights to the island, the Associated Press has reported. Coupled with the previous rule changes for travelers, commercial flights to the island from the United States would make it possible for practically anyone who wishes to visit Cuba to do so. Here is what you need to know before you go:

headline: Roksanda: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The latest looks from Roksanda.

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Why Allow a Racial Slur but Remove an Obscenity?
text: A reader, Adam Lawrence, of New York City, said he was “thrilled and engrossed” as he read the magazine piece this past weekend on the former basketball star, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, until he encountered a racial slur in the text. To his dismay, the word was repeated twice more as he kept reading.

headline: Erdem: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Erdem’s spring 2016 show.

headline: Esmail Kiram II, Self-Proclaimed Sultan of Sulu, Dies at 75
text: MANILA — Esmail Kiram II, the self-proclaimed sultan of Sulu who in 2013 encouraged a last-ditch, violent effort to regain what is now the Malaysian state of Sabah on the island of Borneo for the Philippines, died on Saturday at a hospital in Zamboanga City in the southern Philippines. He was 75.

headline: Alexis Tsipras’s Election Victory, and Greece’s Looming Challenges
text: Alexis Tsipras won an unexpectedly decisive victory in elections in Greece on Sunday, renewing his mandate to lead the austerity-weary nation, this time as a prime minister committed to supporting a bailout rather than to fighting one. Defying many experts’ predictions of a tight race, his leftist party, Syriza, received just over 35 percent of the vote, beating the main right-leaning opposition party by more than seven percentage points.

headline: A Simpler Financial-Aid Calculator Spreads
text: A simplified financial-aid calculator — much easier to use than the federally mandated calculators that most colleges create — has begun spreading beyond Wellesley College, where it began two years ago.

headline: Campaign in China Seeks to Reunite Abducted Children With Their Families
text: Read in Chinese | 点击查看本文中文版

headline: Starwood Waypoint Residential Trust to Acquire a Rival
text: Starwood Waypoint Residential Trust, an investment vehicle that owns thousands of single-family rental homes in the United States, said on Monday that it would buy its rival Colony American Homes in an all-stock deal that values Colony American at $1.5 billion.

headline: Highlights From the 2015 Emmy Awards
text: Best moments from the 67th Primetime Emmy Awards at the Microsoft Theatre in downtown Los Angeles, California.

headline: Daily Report: Kickstarter Becomes a ‘Public Benefit Corporation’
text: It is a common criticism of tech companies these days: They say they want to change the world, but what they really want to change is how much money they have in the bank. Or the horsepower of the car in the driveway. Or maybe the exotic locale of the third vacation home.

headline: 1940: Legionnaires Take Over Fair
text: With 75,000 members of the American Legion and their families attending, the New York World’s Fair had its biggest Saturday of 1940 yesterday, the paid admissions total mounting to 234,121 at midnight. The Legionnaires attended the fair as a prelude to the national convention which opens in Boston tomorrow. Congregated in the huge court were 15,000 legionnaires and members of their auxiliary organizations, most of them in uniform. There were so many flags in the parade that Legion members in uniform stood at attention and saluted for nearly an hour. — New York Herald Tribune, September 22, 1940

headline: Skype Service Problems for Some Users Worldwide
text: Users of Skype, Microsoft’s Internet calling unit, faced a lengthy blackout on Monday after people worldwide were not able to make calls or sign into the service.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Ruffles
text: Ladylike ruffles have spruced up neutral colors and conservative silhouettes in designers’ spring/summer 2016 collections. At Proenza Schouler, architectural bends grounded a light, gauzy layer that swished and swayed as the model walked. And Simone Rocha’s asymmetrical and artfully arranged ruffles defined womanly curves while the voluminous folds on a J. W. Anderson dress were just sweet — as a peach.

headline: Times Critics’ Guide: What to Do This Week
text: Looking to break out of a cultural rut and try something new?

headline: Netanyahu and Putin Spar Over Syrian Threat to Israel
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, disagreed here on Monday over the level of threat to Israel from Syria, backed by Iran.

headline: Soul-Searching Continues for Possible Joe Biden Run
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said that he is continuing to search his soul about running for president, and he acknowledged a decision might come after it is logistically too late to make a successful bid.

headline: KTZ’s Carefully Constructed Spring 2016 Collection
text: Influenced by London’s many construction sites, the label showed club kid looks on a minimal, menacing and urban runway.

headline: Pope Francis Invites U.S. Pilgrims
text: In a videotaped message released by the Vatican on Monday, Francis issued a personal invitation to pilgrims, saying “See you in Philadelphia.”

headline: Milton, Money, and Interest Rates
text: Still mulling over the political economy of permahawkery; and, unusually, I have a moderate disagreement with Brad DeLong. Brad has been arguing that demands for tight money are, in fact, contrary to the bankers’ own interests:

headline: 4chan Message Board Sold to Founder of 2Channel, a Japanese Web Culture Pioneer
text: If the Internet is the Wild West, you could call 4chan “The Good, the Bad and the Ugly.”

headline: Chancellor’s Absence and 0-2 Start Weigh on Seahawks
text: The Seattle Seahawks, the N.F.L.’s reigning N.F.C. champions, have started the season 0-2, and their vaunted defense is struggling, especially against the pass. An All-Pro strong safety who would help them a lot is sitting at home, embroiled in a contract dispute.

headline: Parents, Not Schools, Should Decide What to Pack for Lunch
text: Last year, when a teacher confiscated Oreos from a Colorado preschooler’s lunch, both The Daily News in New York and USA Today covered the story that set the Internet buzzing. The teacher’s note, sent home with the preschooler, asserted that Oreos were not “healthy” — those same Oreos that many of us enjoyed with a glass of milk in the 1970s and ’80s.

headline: Emmy Awards 2015: The Major Winners
text: Drama Series:  “Game of Thrones” (HBO)

headline: Hillary Clinton, in Louisiana, Gets a Health Care Challenge From Bobby Jindal
text: Gov. Bobby Jindal, looking for traction in the Republican presidential nomination contest, is welcoming Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday to his home state of Louisiana, where she plans to hold an event stressing the positive effects of President Obama’s health care law.

headline: When Dinner Proves Divisive: One Strategy, Many Dishes
text: Back when I cooked only to please myself and one or two other consenting adults, choosing recipes was a breeze. Nothing was off limits. Dishes with olives, stinky cheeses, bitter greens and mushrooms — sometimes all of the above — were on regular rotation. Then I began cooking for kids (picky, omnivorous and otherwise). With them came their nut-allergic friends, vegan guitar teachers and chile-fearing in-laws. Forced to adapt my NC-17 cooking style to a G-rated audience, I paged through cookbooks in search of “crowd pleasers” that proved elusive.

headline: A Beneficial Evolutionary Step for Chameleons
text: Chameleons have five digits, but in each hand and foot, these digits are split into two “bundles.” The arrangement permits them to grasp branches and climb with ease, excellent adaptations for life in the trees. A new study reports that the angle between the “bundles” in the tree-dwelling species depends on a large number of previously unknown skeletal elements in the wrist and ankle that fuse together as the embryonic chameleon develops. The fusion produces a ball-and-socket joint that chameleons can use to rotate their bodies while reaching for branches. The study appears in the journal BMC Evolutionary Biology.

headline: Earth Blamed for Cracks in Moon
text: The moon is shrinking, and Earth is to blame for how the moon’s crust has cracked.

headline: Burberry Prorsum: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Burberry Prorsum’s spring 2016 collection.

headline: Devoted to Simplicity, Pope Francis Creates Knotty Logistics With Visit
text: In New York, Roman Catholic officials have walked Pope Francis’ expected path through the National September 11 Memorial and timed it at five to seven minutes.

headline: VW’s Recall Troubles May Have Little Effect on China, Its Largest Market
text: HONG KONG — China is Volkswagen’s single-largest market, and the company vies with General Motors as the country’s biggest automaker. But Volkswagen’s diesel scandal is unlikely to have many repercussions in China.

headline: A Magna Carta Exhibition at New-York Historical Society
text: A 1217 version of the Magna Carta, on loan from Hereford Cathedral in England, will be exhibited for the first time at the New-York Historical Society for one week, from Sept. 23 to 30. The show will include the only known surviving copy of the King’s Writ of 1215, the instructions that King John issued at Runnymede to local sheriffs on how to carry out the new charter.

headline: Atomic Agency Defends How Iran Collected Evidence at Secret Base
text: TEHRAN — The director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency said Monday that Iran had turned over samples from a suspected site of nuclear experimentation, but confirmed that they had been collected by Iranians under the watchful eye of surveillance devices, rather than by outside nuclear inspectors.

headline: Patrizia Tenti Brings a Playful Energy to Milanese Design
text: She might be an architect by trade — but it’s her nomadic spirit that infuses her talent for making collectible design look like it belongs anywhere.

headline: How to Get Burberry Prorsum’s Lived-In Lipstick Look
text: “She’s an honest British girl, who’s not worried about what other people think,” said the makeup artist Wendy Rowe of the beauty inspiration backstage at Burberry’s spring/summer 2016 runway. The clean look — finished at times with a supermatte, gothic lip — complemented the heavily embellished, monochromatic mood of the collection (which by the way was debuted, before the show, on Snapchat).

headline: A Gypsy in Milan
text: The architect Patrizia Tenti brings T into her apartment and gallery.

headline: Many Messages in the G.M. Settlement
text: One of the biggest product defects in recent American manufacturing history, linked to at least 124 deaths and numerous injuries, was traceable to a mundane automobile part, the ignition switch. For General Motors, the debacle over how it handled that defect scarred the organization as it had to admit to repeated failures in simply identifying the problem that reflected a corporate culture that seemed to prize inaction and deflection.

headline: Ice-Pop Molds That Contained Walter Youngblood’s Enthusiasm
text: “I call it the cut-and-paste apartment,” Walter Youngblood, an artist and ice-cream man, said of the fourth-floor walk-up in East Harlem where he’s lived for 20 years.

headline: 1965: Thant Urges an Inclusive U.N.
text: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. — Secretary-General U Thant told the UN General Assembly as it opened its 20th session here today [Sept. 21] that the military conflicts in Asia and the disarmament deadlock have reinforced his view that all countries — including Communist China — should be represented at UN headquarters. In his annual report, Mr. Thant declared that the war in Vietnam had ‘‘cruelly set back’’ the trend toward East-West cooperation and revived the cold war. He added that the international situation ‘‘has again been disturbed’’ by the conflict between India and Pakistan. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 22, 1965

headline: New Poll Offers Hillary Clinton Some Comforting News
text: After months of seeing her polling advantage narrow, Hillary Rodham Clinton has widened her lead against Senator Bernie Sanders, according to a CNN/ORC International poll released on Monday.

headline: Tsipras Speaks After Winning Election
text: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece vowed to continue fighting for his country and to form a coalition government after his left-wing Syriza party on Sunday won the third national vote this year.
