text: The designer’s spring/summer 2016 included lace, tiered skirts and florals.

headline: E.U. Official Says ‘Europe in Bad Shape’
text: Martin Schulz, the president of the European Union’s parliament, said on Monday that member states seemed to be acting in their own interests while confronting the migration crisis.

headline: Mets Math: The Six-Game Lead That Really Isn’t
text: With 13 games to go in the regular season, the Mets (84-65) hold a shrunken, but still sturdy, six-game lead over the Washington Nationals in the National League East. That would seem safe enough, except for one small problem: The Mets’ lead is, in some respects, just three games, not six.

headline: Who Is Xi Jinping?
text: President Xi Jinping of China arrived in the United States on Tuesday for a state visit at a crucial crossroads in the Sino-American relationship.

headline: Details Emerge in Massachusetts ‘Baby Doe’ Case as Couple Are Arraigned
text: BOSTON — For months, a computer-generated image of a toddler’s face, with big eyes, long hair and chubby cheeks, appeared on billboards and fliers here and beyond. Her body had been found, clad in black and white leggings, in a trash bag on a rocky beach on Deer Island, along Boston Harbor. But for almost three months, despite an exhaustive search, investigators knew little more than that until last week.

headline: 1966 | Pynchon’s Bleak Survey of Race Relations
text: We won’t wade into the controversy over whether Thomas Pynchon might have written the novel “Cow Country” under a pen name.

headline: Street Style: London
text: The high energy streets of London get a dose of fashion week style.

headline: Facts & Figures: American Republicans May Be Alone on Climate Change
text: A study has found that the Republican Party in the United States lags behind conservative parties worldwide when it comes to accepting the reality of climate change, Tom Jacobs of Pacific Standard reports. The study’s author examined the platforms of the top conservative parties in each of nine countries — the United States, United Kingdom, Australia, Germany, Spain, Sweden, Norway, Canada and New Zealand — and found that the Republican Party here was the only one to deny the existence of human-caused climate change.

headline: Volkswagen’s Scandal Similar to One Involving Libor
text: Volkswagen has found itself in a situation not unlike the interest-rate scandal involving Libor.

headline: Street Style: London
text: The high energy streets of London get a dose of fashion week style.

headline: Matzo Fried Chicken Served to Go
text: Become a restaurant known for your matzo-meal fried chicken, and people will want to take some home. So, Richard Kimmel is opening a food shop, Kitty’s-a-Go-Go, next door to Kitty’s Canteen, his red-curtained boîte that serves the chicken. Jewish food with a Southern drawl is the specialty, inspired by the recipes of Kitty Kimmel, Mr. Kimmel’s grandmother who worked for a talent agency in New York. Jazz musicians taught her how to cook soul food. Kathy Johannes and Stephanie Teekaram, the chefs at Kitty’s, now make the chicken, hush kitties (hush puppies filled with pastrami), matzo-ball soup with mustard greens, and biscuits shaped like bagels, which are called bisgels, a name trademarked by Mr. Kimmel, whose business partner is Snoop Dogg: 11 Stanton Street (Chrystie Street), 212-477-7047, kittysagogo.com.

headline: Pope Francis Celebrates Mass in Cuba
text: Pope Francis celebrated Mass on Monday in Holguin, Cuba, as part of his trip to North and Central America.

headline: A New Design Shop That Aims to Elevate the Smoke-Filled Room
text: Tetra, a new online shop and lifestyle brand “dedicated to elevating the aesthetics of the smoking experience,” was first dreamed up by three friends at El Matador beach in Los Angeles. The project, launching today, was co-created by Monica Khemsurov, a design curator and writer and cofounder of the Sight Unseen design blog; Su Wu, an arts writer and founder of the inspiration blog I’m Revolting; and Eviana Hartman, a style and design writer and founder of the fashion line Bodkin. (All three happen to be regular T contributors, too.) It was born of the realization, Khemsurov explains, that even as a particular form of recreational smoking has rapidly gained mainstream acceptance (cough), there hasn’t been “a store dedicated to selling beautifully designed objects for smokers.”

headline: Christopher Kane: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Designs from Christopher Kane’s spring 2016 collection.

headline: Apple Improves the Watch, Slightly
text: The Apple Watch has been on sale since the spring, and like all Apple products, it has been the subject of intense speculation, criticism, fawning and doomsaying. Expect all of it to accelerate, because on Monday Apple is releasing the first major upgrade of the watch’s operating system. The new software had been scheduled for release last week, but Apple postponed the rollout at the last minute because of an unspecified bug. That bug has now been fixed.

headline: Pesticides Tied to Childhood Cancers
text: Childhood exposure to indoor insecticides is associated with an increased risk for certain childhood cancers, a new study has found.

headline: Young Quarterbacks Produce Rare Win-Win-Win-Win Situation
text: On Nov. 25, 2007, the Cleveland Browns, the Jacksonville Jaguars, the Oakland Raiders and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers all won. They were quarterbacked by Derek Anderson, David Garrard, Daunte Culpepper and Jeff Garcia. Until Sunday, that was the last time those four teams all won in the same week.

headline: Winners Flock to HBO’s Emmys Party

text: Viola Davis, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, the cast of “Game of Thrones” and others attend the HBO Emmy Awards after-party.

headline: An Unexpected Partner Helps Preserve a Manhattan Synagogue
text: The rolldown gate of the Garment Center Congregation has not risen in months, the lights are out, the menorahs and Torahs are gone, the vestibule is full of refuse.

headline: In London, Mary Katrantzou Star Gazes and Vivienne Westwood Makes a Political Statement
text: LONDON — Pay no attention to the men behind the curtain!

headline: Can’t Swallow a Pill? There’s Help for That
text: Ever since she was a child, Karen Quinn has had a terrible time swallowing pills. It doesn’t matter if it is a vitamin or an aspirin. The pill inevitably lodges in her throat, and she panics.

headline: Evercore Partners Hires Senior Banker From Lazard
text: Evercore Partners has poached yet another senior banker from a rival firm, as the investment bank continues to build its practices.

headline: Review: In ‘The Muppets’ on ABC, Kermit Is in a Mundane Midlife Crisis
text: Last spring, when Paul Lee, the president of ABC Entertainment, announced that the network’s new version of the Muppet franchise would be “more adult,” my inner Statler and Waldorf stirred in the balcony. There are certain things I don’t want to know, and where Muppet babies come from is among them.

headline: Use Life Hacks to Minimize Bad Decisions
text: A few years ago, a friend of mine who happens to be a really well-known journalist had a conversation with a really well-known academic. Because the conversation was private, I’m not mentioning names. But I did want to share one fascinating part of their discussion.

headline: Thomas Tait: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Looks from Thomas Tait’s spring 2016 show.

headline: Court Orders Versailles to Cover  Vandalism on Kapoor’s Work
text: A French court ordered the Palace of Versailles to cover anti-Semitic graffiti from the artist Anish Kapoor’s installation there this weekend, after a local politician, Fabien Bouglé, filed a complaint that Mr. Kapoor and the palace were inciting racial hatred by leaving the vandalism intact.

headline: Trump’s Minor Fall, Fiorina’s Major Lift
text: I didn’t have time to comment on the Republican debate last week, but in a way it’s better to offer an assessment a few days later, since we now have polls that help confirm the commentariat’s basic reaction: It was a great night for Carly Fiorina, a good night for Marco Rubio, a not-so-great night for the Donald, a meh night for most of the pack, and another lost evening for the plummeting Scott Walker. And now, a few observations on what it all might mean:

headline: Don Henley and Billy Joel, at 92nd Street Y, Trade Stories About a Lifetime of Songwriting
text: Billy Joel first met Don Henley in the early 1970s, when the two men were rising musicians based in Southern California. “I opened up for Don at the University of California at Berkeley,” Mr. Joel told the crowd Sunday night at the 92nd Street Y. “These were the days when the Eagles were all wearing Hawaiian shirts.”

headline: The Benefits of Allowing Bitcoin to Flourish
text: Policy makers should give careful consideration to a balanced approach when determining effective regulatory solutions for Bitcoin, the author writes.

headline: He’s Not Slowing Down
text: At the San Diego Senior Olympics on Sunday, Don Pellmann broke five records for men in the 100-and-over age group and tried to become the oldest man to record a height in the pole vault.

headline: 100 Years Old. 5 World Records.
text: SAN DIEGO — Don Pellmann had been at the San Diego Mesa College track for less than an hour Sunday morning and had already moved his lawn chair twice to remain in the shade, which was receding fast. By the time Pellmann set his fifth age-group world record, in the early afternoon, the temperature on the track was creeping toward 100, which also happens to be the birthday Pellmann recently celebrated.

headline: Condiments as Weapon Against Malnutrition
text: Condiments are becoming weapons in the fight to save malnourished children.

headline: Lincoln Center Theater to Offer ‘War’ by Branden Jacobs-Jenkins
text: “War,” a family drama by the young playwright Branden Jacobs-Jenkins, will receive a New York premiere next spring as part of the new season at Lincoln Center Theater.

headline: An Apology and a Vow to End Burkina Faso Coup
text: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — With troops converging on the capital on Monday and angry protests in the streets, the general who seized power last week in Burkina Faso apologized to the nation and promised to hand power back to the civilian authorities.

headline: Donald Trump Holds Q. and A. in Video Twitter Chat
text: How would you help the homeless? What would you do about student debt? And how good of a quarterback is Joe Flacco?

headline: Should You Watch NBC’s ‘Blindspot’?
text: SERIES: “Blindspot,” which premieres Monday on NBC. It was created by the writer Martin Gero of “The L.A. Complex” and produced by Greg Berlanti of “Arrow” and “The Flash” fame. (It’s a busy fall for the uber producer — his “Supergirl” lands on CBS next month and the superhero spinoff series “Legends of Tomorrow” is a midseason premiere.)

headline: Michel Faulkner, Harlem Minister, Announces G.O.P. Bid to Unseat Mayor de Blasio
text: With Mayor Bill de Blasio’s poll numbers in a prolonged slump, Republican leaders have vowed to put up a strong challenger in 2017. But to compete in strongly liberal New York City, Republicans would most likely need either a candidate of some political celebrity to challenge the Democratic mayor, or at least someone with vast personal wealth to spend on a campaign.

headline: Prescription Drug Costs Are Rising as a Campaign Issue
text: Both Bernie Sanders and Hillary Rodham Clinton are trying to make the rising cost of prescription drugs an issue in the presidential campaign.

headline: Oldest Find of Salmon Remains in North America
text: Salmon fishing in North America dates from the end of the last ice age, a new study reports.

headline: Getty Museum and Armenian Church Reach Agreement Over 13th-Century Manuscript
text: The J. Paul Getty Museum, after years of legal wrangling over eight pieces of colorful medieval parchment in its collection, announced on Monday that it has recognized a different rightful owner: the Western Prelacy of the Armenian Apostolic Church of America. The pages, which the illuminator T’oros Roslin painted in the 13th century, were somehow separated a century ago from the rest of a religious manuscript, the Zeyt’un Gospels, which has been preserved at the Matenadaran institute in Armenia.

headline: Emmy Awards Audience Drops to New Low
text: This year’s Emmy Awards were the least-watched in the show’s history, drawing just 11.9 million viewers on Sunday night, according to Nielsen.

headline: Albert Maysles Will Get a Tribute at the New York Film Festival
text: Albert Maysles, the pioneering documentary filmmaker who died in March, will receive a tribute hosted by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Maysles family, organizers announced Monday.

headline: How Much Junk Food Do Teenagers Eat?
text: American teenagers receive 16.9 percent of their calories from fast food, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported last week.

headline: Greece’s Leader Starts Big Economic Overhaul
text: ATHENS — Alexis Tsipras moved swiftly to form a new Greek government on Monday after his convincing victory in the national election a day earlier, with some officials close to him suggesting that he would create a new ministry solely dedicated to carrying out the tough bailout package he reluctantly agreed to last summer.

headline: Kathleen Kane, Pennsylvania Attorney General, Is Suspended From Practicing Law
text: PHILADELPHIA — The ability of Pennsylvania’s embattled attorney general to carry out her job was thrown into question Monday as the State Supreme Court issued a temporary suspension of her law license.

headline: Big Price Increase for Tuberculosis Drug Is Rescinded
text: A huge overnight price increase for an important tuberculosis drug has been rescinded after the company that acquired the drug gave it back to its previous owner under pressure, it was announced on Monday.

headline: Thousands Ricochet Across Europe: Inside the Migrant Crisis
text: Mary Ann Giordano provides an inside look at the nuts and bolts involved in covering a story breaking across the globe.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: The London Design Medal’s Winners on Their Working Philosophy
text: The British design duo Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby have won this year’s Panerai London Design Medal. The award, now in its 10th year, is one of the design industry’s highest accolades and celebrates excellence in design, plus contribution to the industry and to London. “We weren’t expecting it at all,” Barber says. “It’s not something that you ever anticipate.”

headline: Ignoring Sexual Abuse in Afghanistan
text: The incidents of sexual assault on children described by American service members who served in Afghanistan are sickening. Boys screaming in the night as Afghan police officers attacked them. Three or four Afghan men found lying on the floor of a room at a military base with children between them, presumably for sex play.

headline: More than 100 Killed by Boko Haram Bombings in Nigeria
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — More than 100 people were killed Sunday evening in northern Nigeria in a quick succession of what appeared to be carefully coordinated bombings by Boko Haram, the Islamist extremist group.

headline: Readers React to Afghan Allies’ Sexual Abuse of Boys
text: Again and again, American soldiers discovered that their Afghan counterparts were sexually abusing boys, sometimes on American military bases. But after reporting the crimes, they were told by their superiors to ignore them or punished for taking matters into their own hands.

headline: Ben Carson’s Comments Stir Anger Among Muslims
text: Emotions in the Muslim community remained roiled on Monday by Ben Carson’s assertion that followers of Islam are not fit to serve as president of the United States.

headline: The Pop-Up Pope
text: A self-styled “joyful band of Catholics” took a life-size likeness of Pope Francis to Philadelphia to promote Catholicism and the real pontiff’s United States’ visit.

headline: Scott Walker Ends His 2016 Presidential Run
text: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, whose early glow as a Republican presidential contender was snuffed out with the rise of anti-establishment rivals, announced Monday that he was quitting the race and urged some of his 15 rivals to do the same so the party could unite against the leading candidate, Donald J. Trump.

headline: Let the Voters Decide? Nah, Not in the Bronx
text: In one of the sleaziest maneuvers in a notoriously sleazy political world, the Democratic Party cabal in the Bronx is ready to hand-pick the borough’s next district attorney.  Normally, that would be an elected position, but the party bigwigs do their best to keep voters in their borough from getting overly involved. As a result, as Dick Dadey of Citizens Union told The Times, “Corruption will continue in the Bronx.”

headline: A Discussion of E.L. Doctorow’s ‘Homer & Langley’
text: The Collyer Brothers, American history’s best known hoarders and the subject of E.L. Doctorow’s 2009 novel, “Homer & Langley,” lived and died surrounded by more than 120 tons of rubbish and memorabilia in a Harlem brownstone at 128th Street and Fifth Avenue. The site is now empty, a pocket park where New Yorkers might sit and think on the horrors of overeager acquisition.

headline: When Radiation Isn’t the Real Risk
text: This spring, four years after the nuclear accident at Fukushima, a small group of scientists met in Tokyo to evaluate the deadly aftermath.

headline: Should You Watch Fox’s ‘Minority Report’?
text: SERIES: “Minority Report,” a crime drama premiering Monday on Fox. It was written and developed by Max Borenstein, who wrote the latest “Godzilla” movie.

headline: The Weeknd Dominates Billboard Chart, and Streaming Is Surging
text: This week on the music charts, the Weeknd’s “Beauty Behind the Madness” (XO/Republic) is taking a third victory lap at No. 1, and new industry statistics show that streaming now contributes about one-third of the revenue for the American record business.

headline: Not-So-Simple Shapes at Peter Pilotto
text: For spring/summer 2016, Pilotto and Christopher de Vos mixed zigzag lines, circles and triangles with mesh.

headline: A Little Floral, a Little Military at Burberry
text: Christopher Bailey’s spring/summer collection mixed hard-edged pieces with fluid silhouettes.

headline: New York City’s Cultural Affairs Commissioner Takes Leave Because of Illness
text: Tom Finkelpearl, the city’s Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, will take a leave of absence to treat a health issue, the de Blasio administration announced on Monday. In his absence, Mr. Finkelpearl’s deputy, Edwin Torres, will serve as acting commissioner.

headline: 1 in 4 Women Experience Sex Assault on Campus
text: In four years of college, more than one-fourth of undergraduate women at a large group of leading universities said they had been sexually assaulted by force or when they were incapacitated, according to one of the largest studies of its kind, released Monday.

headline: Cori Bargmann Puts Her Mind to How the Brain Works
text: Cornelia Bargmann, a neurobiologist at Rockefeller University in New York, studies how genes interact with neurons to create behavior. Two years ago, President Obama named Dr. Bargmann, who is known as Cori, a co-chairwoman of the advisory commission for the Brain Initiative, which he has described as “giving scientists the tools they need to get a dynamic picture of the brain in action.”

headline: Heidi Julavits at Home
text: In her Morningside Heights apartment, the writer and antiques lover shares some of her favorite secondhand objects.

headline: Review: ‘Sex of the Baby,’ a Tale of Desire and Betrayal
text: In Matthew-Lee Erlbach’s farcical ”Sex of the Baby,” boy meets girl at a job interview. Daniel, a sculptor, is screening prospective birth mothers for the child that he and his partner, Michael, want to have. Bekah, a bubbly honey-blond teacher with flawless skin and a sterling résumé, seems ideal.

headline: At Home — and on the Hunt for Antiques — With Heidi Julavits
text: The first item that the writer Heidi Julavits bought at a yard sale was a black, rayon dress — in Los Angeles, on a college cross-country road trip. The acquisition, she remembers, felt more than a commodity exchange; in a still unknown city, she says, “it felt like purchasing citizenship.”

headline: Russia Expands Fleet in Syria With Jets That Can Attack Targets on Ground
text: WASHINGTON — Russia has sharply increased the number of combat aircraft at an air base near Latakia, Syria, giving its forces a new ability to strike targets on the ground in the war-stricken country.

headline: Bird Flu Vaccine Conditionally Approved, but Still Can’t Be Sold
text: A vaccine to help protect the nation’s chickens from avian influenza after more than 48 million birds died during an outbreak this year has cleared a first hurdle, with the Agriculture Department granting its maker a “conditional” license.

headline: Pretty in Pink Men’s Wear
text: Masculine tailoring in the dandiest color.

headline: Review: Christopher Houlihan Adds Shine to a Restored Organ at Co-Cathedral of St. Joseph
text: For a Roman Catholic church, an organ is much more than an instrument. It has an almost sacramental power, resounding for godly glory. It sings hymns as another member of the congregation, a part of the community. It breathes new life as its community does.

headline: Two Finalists Shine, but Davis Cup Is Still in Need of Polish
text: It is a big week for Davis Cup tennis, and not only because Britain is back in the final for the first time in 37 years and Belgium for the first time in 111 years.

headline: Review: ‘Scream Queens’ Spoofs Horror Spoofs
text: If any of the fall’s new shows works harder to win us over than “Scream Queens,” I don’t want to hear about it — I’m exhausted just from watching Tuesday night’s two-hour premiere. The industriousness of this Fox horror spoof is reflected in the game performance of its lead, Emma Roberts, who marches through her role as a sorority-house storm trooper with a slightly grim determination, hunting down laughs that aren’t always there.

headline: Malaysia’s Leader, Najib Razak, Faces U.S. Corruption Inquiry
text: The embattled prime minister of Malaysia, facing mounting political turmoil and a parade of inquiries at home and abroad into a sovereign wealth fund that he oversees, is now coming under the scrutiny of American investigators as well.

headline: Airlines Find Travelers Accept Fees Wrapped Up in Bundles
text: As add-on fees make up a growing percentage of airlines’ profits, more carriers are introducing bundles of features on top of their base fares — and travelers are embracing them.

headline: Timeline of Scott Walker’s Presidential Campaign
text: Two months after announcing a presidential bid in which he promised to “wreak havoc” upon Washington, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin is ending his run. After a promising start in Iowa, the Harley-Davidson-riding candidate failed to gain traction nationally with his promises of repealing the Affordable Care Act and taking the fight to unions. As happened with former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, the first Republican to drop out of a crowded field, Mr. Walker was overshadowed by the emergence of Donald J. Trump, making it difficult for his message to break through the political noise.

headline: Robert E. Simon Jr., Who Created a Town, Reston, Va., Dies at 101
text: Robert E. Simon Jr., a New York real estate developer who founded Reston, Va., in the early 1960s as America’s first planned alternative to the postwar suburban sprawl of commuter towns with cookie-cutter houses on look-alike streets, died on Monday at his home in Reston. He was 101.

headline: Suspects Arraigned in ‘Baby Doe’ Case
text: Michael Patrick McCarthy and Rachelle Dee Bond both plead not guilty to charges in the death of  3-year-old Bella Bond, whose body was found on a Boston Harbor shoreline in June.

headline: Summer in Salento
text: The slow-paced, isolated villages that make up this region of southern Italy boast a stunning landscape, deep-blue seas and centuries of history.

headline: The Ancient Allure of Puglia
text: The slow-paced villages that make up Salento boast a stunning landscape, deep-blue seas, centuries of history — and are blissfully isolated from the 21st century.

headline: Review: ‘Paradise of the Pacific,’ the Hard Truths of Hawaii’s History
text: In Susanna Moore’s fiercely observed early novels “My Old Sweetheart,” “The Whiteness of Bones,” and “Sleeping Beauties,” Hawaii emerges as a damaged paradise — a place of violent, magical beauty, and its own social rules and hierarchies; a land haunted by its past and isolated from the real world beyond the waves.

headline: Review: ‘Limitless’ on CBS Stars Jake McDorman as a Brainiac
text: “Limitless,” which starts Tuesday night on CBS, traffics in two trends that television has already worked pretty hard: characters with heightened observational powers and shows based on movies. But it manages to feel reasonably fresh anyway, thanks to dashes of cheekiness and of Bradley Cooper.

headline: Tatars, Foes of Russia in Crimea, Block Shipments of Food
text: MOSCOW — Crimean Tatars, angered by Russia’s annexation of the Black Sea peninsula, said Monday that a blockade of food deliveries to Crimea from Ukraine would continue indefinitely.

headline: S.E.C. and First Eagle Investment Reach $40 Million Settlement
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Monday that it had reached a $40 million settlement with a New York-based investment adviser over charges that it had improperly used mutual fund assets to pay brokerage firms for the marketing and distribution of its funds.

headline: Rashaad Newsome’s King of Arms Ball
text: The artist brought the third iteration of his King of Arms Ball, a vogueing competition, to Brooklyn last night.

headline: When Contemporary Art Meets Ballroom Culture
text: Last night in Bushwick, the artist Rashaad Newsome staged the third annual edition of his King of Arms Ball — a proper “Paris Is Burning”-style vogueing ball, complete with acrobatic and athletic runway walks, plenty of accessories and exactly one peacock perched atop a contestant’s head.

headline: Mating Penguins Take Over Punta Tombo
text: Over a million Magellanic penguins are expected to arrive on the Argentine peninsula of Punta Tombo for their annual breeding season, and for some, it’s an opportunity to find a new mate.

headline: ‘Wicked’ Reclaims Its Spot as No. 2 on Broadway, Overtaking ‘Hamilton’
text: “Wicked” reclaimed its spot as the second-highest-grossing show on Broadway last week, passing “Hamilton” during a generally up week for the commercial theater business.

headline: Vatican, in Switch, Will Join Palestine in Flying Flag at U.N.
text: UNITED NATIONS — In a policy reversal that hints at the delicate diplomacy ahead of the visit by Pope Francis, the Vatican’s envoy to the United Nations said on Monday that the flag of the Holy See would be hoisted at the gates here for the first time, just before the pope addresses world leaders.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Splendor and Misery: Images of Prostitution,’ Captures a Profession in Paris Through Artists’ Eyes
text: PARIS — A skirt lifted above her ankle. A beauty mark painted on her cheek. A direct gaze. Sitting alone over a drink in a cafe.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Cuba and Elsewhere
text: Cuba and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: September 21, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Cuba, Croatia, India and Spain.

headline: Pope Francis to Find a Church in Upheaval
text: MERCED, Calif. — More than 5,000 parishioners packed the pews, the choir loft and the vestibule on a recent weekend at Sacred Heart Church here in California’s Central Valley for five Masses — four of them in Spanish. Young Hispanic families spilled outside onto the steps, straining to hear the homily over the roar of an elevated freeway across the street.

headline: Pope Francis on Abortion and Other Issues
text: A look at where Pope Francis stands on issues of particular importance to Americans.

headline: Rembrandt Portraits May Come Home, for Record Price, With Government Help
text: AMSTERDAM — The Dutch government on Monday pledged 80 million euros toward the purchase of a pair of Rembrandt portraits, half of the €160 million ($180.6 million) needed to buy the works from the French businessman Éric de Rothschild.

headline: Daniel Thompson, Whose Bagel Machine Altered the American Diet, Dies at 94
text: Daniel Thompson, who five decades ago automated the arcane art of bagel making, a development — seen variously as saving grace and sacrilege — that has sent billions of mass-produced bagels raining down on the American heartland, died on Sept. 3 in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 94.

headline: Newest Immigrants Assimilating as Fast as Previous Ones, Report Says
text: The newest generations of immigrants are assimilating into American society as fast and broadly as the previous ones, with their integration increasing over time “across all measurable outcomes,” according to a report published on Monday by the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine.

headline: Partisan Divides In Everything
text: Source.

headline: Deadly Car Bombing at Somalia’s Presidential Palace Is Claimed by Shabab
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A car loaded with explosives was detonated Monday at the gate of the presidential palace in Mogadishu, killing at least four people and wounding a dozen others, witnesses and officials said.

headline: Nutcases and Knut Cases
text: Monetary permahawkery takes two forms. One is obviously ridiculous, but nonetheless has a lot of influence on right-wing politicians. The other can sound serious and judicious, which makes it dangerous, because it might gain real traction with policymakers.

headline: Rugby World Cup: Japan’s Shocking Upset Commands Attention
text: When Japan beat South Africa over the weekend, there was no question that it was the biggest upset at a Rugby World Cup. Rather, the debate was whether it was the most shocking result in rugby history, or even in all of sports.

headline: Lessons From Scott Walker’s Early Exit
text: What’s so striking about this year’s huge field of Republican candidates is that so few of them appear to be plausible nominees, broadly acceptable across the party. With Scott Walker now out of the race, the short list of such candidates got even shorter.

headline: Scott Walker Drops Out
text: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin withdrew from the 2016 Republican presidential race on Monday, citing a need to “clear the field” for a “positive conservative message.”

headline: Surge in Homelessness Tests Wisconsin Capital’s Welcoming Spirit
text: MADISON, Wis. — As darkness fell on a humid Wisconsin night, some of the several dozen homeless people who sleep outside City Hall began to unfurl their sleeping bags and settle in. But Nancy Griswold, 49, was restless: She sat on a concrete bench next to a black roller bag full of her belongings and surveyed the scene with the crisp confidence of a docent at the state Capitol, only a block away.

headline: France Opens Trade Office in Iran
text: TEHRAN — France opened a trade office in Tehran on Monday, leading the charge of European countries angling for a share of the Iranian market after the July nuclear agreement.

headline: In Pelosi, Strong Catholic Faith and Abortion Rights Coexist
text: WASHINGTON — For Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, the issue of abortion rights has always been ancillary to her unwavering faith and deep approbation for generations of popes. “I actually agree with the pope on more issues than many Catholics who agree with him on one issue,” Ms. Pelosi said in an interview in her office at the Capitol last week.

headline: Empty Floor at Goldman Puts Change on Display
text: When Goldman Sachs moved into its new tower near the Hudson River in 2009, the sprawling trading desks on the fourth, fifth and sixth floors were some of the most active and lucrative in the world.

headline: Brooklyn Cherry Business to Plead Guilty Over Pollution and Marijuana
text: Seven months after its owner committed suicide as investigators closed in on the secret marijuana farm he had kept in the basement of his factory, a company based in Brooklyn will plead guilty on Tuesday to possessing marijuana and illegally dumping acidic wastewater into the sewer system, prosecutors said on Monday.

headline: Austria Takes Role of Distribution Center for Germany-Bound Migrants
text: NICKELSDORF, Austria — In the absence of a unified plan by the European Union, consistent national policies or any consensus on the best way to end the worst humanitarian crisis on the Continent since World War II, Austria is stepping up to house thousands of migrants from the Middle East and Asia, fast becoming Europe’s distribution center of people seeking safety and a better life.

headline: Carmen Balcells, Agent to Latin America’s Literary Lions, Dies at 85
text: Carmen Balcells, the formidable literary agent who shepherded a generation of Latin American writers, including Gabriel García Márquez and Mario Vargas Llosa, to international prominence, died on Sunday at her home in Barcelona. She was 85.

headline: Pope Lures Exiles Back to Cuba, Where a Lifetime Ago Is Yesterday
text: HAVANA — Gloria Arazoza, her step crimped just a touch by age, walked into what was once Cuba’s most formidable and ornate yacht club on Saturday afternoon and headed straight for the beach. Suddenly, a lifetime ago felt like yesterday.

headline: New Jersey Officer Pleads Not Guilty in Fatal Wrong-Way Crash on Staten Island
text: A New Jersey police officer accused of killing two friends while driving drunk in March pleaded not guilty on Monday in State Supreme Court on Staten Island to charges that included vehicular manslaughter and aggravated vehicular homicide.

headline: Discovering Beauty and Solidarity in the American West
text: Lucas Foglia set out to photograph the evolving landscape of the American West and the communities most affected by its changes.

headline: At Salvadoran Factory, Helping Troubled Youth Makes Business Sense
text: CIUDAD ARCE, El Salvador — The gang tattoo etched sharply on William Amaya Valladares would bar him from a regular job in much of the country.

headline: New York Zoning Plan Requires More Affordable Homes
text: Developers who want to build in certain areas of New York City would be required for the first time to set aside at least 25 percent of their units for lower-income residents under proposed zoning rules officially released Monday by the de Blasio administration.

headline: Without Calming Voice, G.O.P. Is Letting Divisive Ones Speak on Muslims
text: WASHINGTON — When Ben Carson said on Sunday that he would not want to see a Muslim elected president, he did not just reignite a volatile conversation about the role of Islam in American life — he also exposed another fissure between many Republican leaders and elements of the party’s grass roots.

headline: HBO, Longtime Emmy Favorite, Reigns Supreme
text: LOS ANGELES — Hours after the Emmy Awards ended, HBO executives, actors and writers were still busy celebrating the premium cable network’s dominance at a sweaty after-party at the Pacific Design Center.

headline: James Blake Praises Mayor de Blasio After Meeting on Mistaken Arrest
text: After an hourlong meeting on Monday with Mayor Bill de Blasio and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, the retired tennis star James Blake said that the mayor had been broadly sympathetic to his calls for greater police accountability.

headline: Fading Coal Industry in China May Offer Chance to Aid Climate
text: DATONG, China — Across China’s grimy coal heartland, mines have fallen silent, reduced production or shut down. Miners, owners and officials here wonder whether boom times will return for the “black gold” that has fed the nation’s craving for cheap but dirty energy.

headline: Clinton Defends Obama Health Law
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton said that she would refuse to let Republican lawmakers “start the health care debate all over again” by repealing the Affordable Care Act.

headline: U.S. Outrage and Resignation Over Afghans’ Rape of Boys
text: WASHINGTON — A report describing how American forces looked the other way as powerful Afghans raped boys with impunity — an issue that long plagued the war effort in Afghanistan — prompted declarations of outrage in Washington on Monday, but officials said the problem was ultimately for Afghans to solve.

headline: Driver Is Found Fatally Shot in His Livery Cab in the Bronx
text: In the modest apartment, a fourth-floor walk-up in the Bronx, the women — well over two dozen of them — lined the walls and sat on the floor. They prayed. They cried. And in a back room, more of them packed in around Kadiatou Jolloh, her face damp with tears, as she lay on a bed, grappling with the loss of her husband.

headline: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago Will Seek to Raise Taxes
text: CHICAGO — For years, ominous warnings about this city’s finances have come, one after the next. The pensions were vastly underfunded. Far steeper payments were due soon. Credit ratings were sinking.

headline: Apple Presses Ahead With Efforts to Create Car, Though Big Issues Remain
text: Apple is continuing its efforts to create a car, though some of the big questions around the project remain undecided.

headline: Georgia: 28-Year Sentence in Tainted Peanut Case
text: The former president of a peanut company was sentenced Monday to 28 years in prison for his role in a salmonella outbreak that killed nine people and sickened more than 700 others. The executive, Stewart Parnell, 61, was sentenced about a year after a Federal District Court jury in Albany convicted him of dozens of counts, including introduction of adulterated food into interstate commerce with intent to defraud or mislead. Prosecutors said Mr. Parnell’s company, Peanut Corporation of America, repeatedly sold contaminated peanut products and misled customers about test results. They also said the company, which was headquartered in Virginia but also had facilities in Texas and Georgia, sometimes shipped products that Mr. Parnell knew were tainted. The company filed for bankruptcy and no longer operates. The prison term fell far short of the 803 years that Mr. Parnell faced under sentencing guidelines. He plans to appeal his convictions.

headline: The Wrath of Volkswagen’s Drivers
text: Volkswagen’s stunning admission that it sold diesel-powered cars that intentionally faked emissions testing results has left many of their owners — who thought they were buying fuel-efficient and environmentally friendly vehicles — angry and feeling betrayed.

headline: Brian Williams Return Is Part of Revamp at MSNBC
text: Brian Williams was eating dinner in early June at the Bronxville, N.Y., house of his new boss, Andrew Lack, discussing his fate at NBC News.

headline: Amid Tumult, Giants Uncover Glimpses of Hope
text: There were not many overarching positive vibes coming from the Giants’ training complex Monday, the day after a second consecutive late-game collapse dropped the team’s record to 0-2. Wide receiver Victor Cruz, who has been sidelined by a calf injury since mid-August, did not practice, making him doubtful for Thursday’s game against the Washington Redskins at MetLife Stadium.

headline: It Took E.P.A. Pressure to Get VW to Admit Fault
text: Volkswagen executives told environmental regulators for more than a year that discrepancies between pollution tests on its diesel cars and the starkly higher levels out on the road were a technical error, not a deliberate attempt to deceive Washington officials.

headline: The Influence of Fiorina at Lucent, in Hindsight
text: As Carly Fiorina has risen in the polls over the last week, there is renewed focus on her controversial tenure as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard. Yet her career at Lucent Technologies has been treated as little more than a footnote. It shouldn’t be.

headline: Review: Thomas Bradshaw’s ‘Fulfillment,’ on One Man’s Ceiling, and His Frustrations
text: Being a shock artist like Thomas Bradshaw carries its own exacting burden. The knowing theatergoer attends this prolific playwright’s work in a state of anxious anticipation, fearing and hoping to be rattled by some fresh violation of the traditionally taboo.

headline: Wild and Wonderful
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — At first, I thought the theme of Victor Barocas’s and Tom Pepper’s puzzle was going to be “occupations that end in -IST.” Since I generally solve from top to bottom, themes like this one hit me in waves, with the final revealer acting like a tidal wave, providing the crucial “Aha!” moment.

headline: Mets Recall How to Win After a Night to Forget
text: Manager Terry Collins walked into the Mets’ clubhouse late Sunday and found his players sitting quietly at their lockers. The Mets had pulled their ace, Matt Harvey, from the game early, on purpose, as part of a plan to keep him healthy in his first season back after Tommy John surgery. The team fell apart from there and lost by nine runs.

headline: Muslim Advocacy Group Wants Carson Out
text: The executive director of the Council on American-Islamic Relations called for Ben Carson to withdraw from the presidential race after saying Muslims are not fit to serve as president.

headline: Blue Jays’ Ace Halts Yankees’ Momentum
text: TORONTO — When the Toronto Blue Jays acquired David Price just before the nonwaiver trading deadline at the end of July, it raised eyebrows not just around baseball but in the Yankees’ clubhouse.

headline: ‘Blindspot’ Series Premiere Recap: The Show Rests on Jaimie Alexander’s Heavily Tattooed Back
text: Season 1, Episode 1: “Pilot”

headline: Pope Francis Visits: Day 3 in Cuba
text: The latest from Pope Francis’ visit to Cuba and the United States.

headline: Philippines: Gunmen Abduct Foreigners
text: Four people — two Canadian men, a Norwegian man and a Filipino woman — were abducted on Monday night from a resort on the southern Philippine island of Mindanao, the police said Tuesday. The victims were identified as John Ridsdel and Robert Hall, both of Canada, and Kjartan Sekkingstad of Norway. The identity of the Filipino woman has not yet been confirmed. The four were taken from the Oceanview Resort on Samal island, off the southern coast of Mindanao, about 11:40 p.m. Mindanao has been a frequent site of kidnappings and violence between government troops and several rebel groups, including Muslim extremists that have pledged allegiance to the Islamic State. But Monday’s kidnapping is the first abduction of foreign tourists in Mindanao in more than two years. In 2012, a Swiss national, Lorenzo Vinciguerra, and Ewold Horn, from the Netherlands, were abducted while bird watching off the coast of Mindanao. Mr. Vinciguerra escaped last December. Mr. Horn is still being held.

headline: Egypt Destroying Far More Homes Than Buffer-Zone Plan Called For, Report Says
text: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt announced a sweeping plan last fall to tighten his crackdown on Islamist insurgents in the North Sinai: clearing a half-kilometer buffer zone along the length of the border with the Gaza Strip, to block any weapons or support from coming through tunnels from Hamas militants on the other side. The government said it would demolish 800 homes and displace as many as 10,000 people in the process.

headline: Baffling Colts, and Maybe Fans, Jets Go to 2-0
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Maybe, just maybe, this is how the Jets’ resurgence begins.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | swathe
text: swathe • \ˈswäth, ˈswȯth, ˈswath\ • verb and noun

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 1:35 P.M. (Starz) THE HOLIDAY (2006) A British wedding columnist (Kate Winslet) swaps places with a Los Angeles movie-trailer producer (Cameron Diaz) after guy troubles leave them in a tizzy in this romantic comedy about love — for men, for the movies — directed by Nancy Meyers. “There is something touching if willfully naïve about Ms. Meyers’s nostalgia for Hollywood’s golden age, when Louis B. Mayer ruled the very lot on which she shot part of this film,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “An old-studio producer would have recognized that there are several films jammed into this one and maybe called in Ben Hecht for a polish, even as he recognized that Ms. Meyers always has something to give.” (Image: Ms. Winslet and Jack Black.)

headline: 罗辛亚女性为逃离苦海却被卖做人妻
text: 上千罗辛亚妇女逃离了在缅甸受到的迫害和危险，但她们中的许多人受困于人贩子，被迫结婚，或走上了卖淫的道路。

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I thought I was in better shape.”

headline: China Formally Arrests U.S. Citizen Accused of Spying
text: BEIJING — An American businesswoman accused of spying has been formally arrested in China shortly before President Xi Jinping’s trip to the United States, her husband and a family lawyer said on Tuesday, adding to the brew of disputes that have dulled expectations for the visit.

headline: The Changing Landscape of the American West
text: In the late fall of 2009, the photographer Lucas Foglia set out on a rural road in Wyoming and got caught up in the vastness of the land.

headline: Pope Francis, the Prince of the Personal
text: One of Pope Francis’ favorite novels is “The Betrothed” by Alessandro Manzoni. It is about two lovers whose longing to marry is thwarted by a cowardly and morally mediocre priest and a grasping nobleman. A good simple friar shelters the suffering couple. Then a plague hits the country, reminding everyone of their mortality and vulnerability, and also bringing about a moral reckoning.

headline: How the U.S. Can Welcome Refugees
text: THE evidence from Europe in recent weeks is that many citizens are ahead of their governments when it comes to responding to the tide of human misery coming from the Middle East. Soccer clubs in Germany are setting up training academies. Austrians have turned out at railway stations. In Iceland, more than 15,000 people joined the “Syria is calling” Facebook page, many of whom apparently offered to house a refugee.

headline: Industry Can Lead on Climate Change
text: A NUMBER of major companies — from PepsiCo to Walmart to U.P.S. — have recognized that corporations have a responsibility to address the causes of climate change before it is too late.

headline: Greek Voters Give Alexis Tsipras Another Go as Prime Minister
text: Eight months after electing a left-wing political outlier, Alexis Tsipras, to reject more austerity, Greek voters have resoundingly re-elected the selfsame Alexis Tsipras, only this time with a mandate to manage austerity. That could prove to be a sage choice.

headline: Trump and Fiorina’s Snake Oil Sales
text: Business wonk that I am, my favorite moment in last week’s Republican debate came when Carly Fiorina and Donald Trump got into a spat over which of them had the lousier track record as business leaders.

headline: California’s Right-to-Die Bill
text: Gov. Jerry Brown of California is hearing plenty from opponents and supporters of a bill state lawmakers passed earlier this month that would allow some terminally ill patients to hasten their death. Modeled after the pioneering right-to-die bill Oregon put into effect in 1997, California’s End of Life Option Act would allow people in the advanced stages of a terminal illness to obtain a lethal dose of painkillers from a physician.

headline: Depressed? There's an App for That
text: Can apps be used to treat depression and anxiety?

headline: ‘Dear Parent, Your Child Has Had a Psychotic Break’
text: I sit in my small office at the university counseling center, sighing as I pick up the phone to make the call that I always dread. I have worked as a psychiatrist with college students for 20 years, and this part never gets easier. One, two, three rings, and the mother of a student who had been in my office minutes earlier answers the phone.

headline: Bible Belt Atheist
text: In this short documentary, a former Pentecostal preacher starts a secular congregation in the heart of the Bible Belt.

headline: ‘Bible Belt Atheist’
text: Growing up in Los Angeles and Paris, we both were raised secular and embraced atheism early and easily. It’s not that we didn’t ponder life’s mysteries; it’s just that after we reasoned away our religious questions, we stopped worrying about them and moved on. When we learned about the former pastor Jerry DeWitt’s struggles with being an “outed” atheist in rural Louisiana, we realized for the first time just how difficult being an atheist can be in some communities, where religion is woven deeply into the social fabric.

headline: News Q’s | A Bolt From the Past: Don Pellmann, at 100, Is Still Breaking Records
text: Before Reading ‘A Bolt From the Past: Don Pellmann, at 100, Is Still Breaking Records’

headline: Makeup for the Selfie Generation
text: For years CoverGirl has checked the performance of its foundations in different lighting — in bright sun or under the fluorescent bulbs of an office, for example. Recently, the company added another test for its makeup: the iPhone challenge.

headline: Larry Kudlow Weighs Run Against Senator Richard Blumenthal in Connecticut
text: Larry Kudlow, a conservative economist and media personality, has begun preparations for a possible campaign against Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut in 2016, raising the prospect of a costly and high-profile political clash in the heavily Democratic state.

headline: Senate Democrats Offer Climate Change Bill Aimed Not at Success Now, but in 2016
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democratic leaders on Tuesday introduced a measure intended to signal their support of President Obama’s aggressive climate change agenda to 2016 voters and to the rest of the world.

headline: As Others Flee to West, Most Syrian Refugees Remain in Region
text: ZAATARI REFUGEE CAMP, Jordan — Bicycles are the new basics for the world’s largest concentration of Syrians who have fled their country’s bloody civil war. Thousands traverse this camp’s few paved roads and acres of rocky dirt, souped up with extra seats and milk crates to ferry groceries, bulky fans and small children.

headline: Pope Francis, ‘People’s Pope,’ Is Security Teams’ Headache
text: WASHINGTON — As one of the lead Secret Service agents for President Obama on Inauguration Day in 2009, Joseph P. Clancy experienced the difficulty of protecting someone surrounded by throngs of supporters who want to get close to a leader they adore.

headline: Should Schools Teach Children How to Cook?
text: A recent Times article suggested five reasons parents should teach their children how to cook. But what if parents aren’t up to the task? Especially with our current obesity epidemic, should schools teach kids how to cook?

text: Editor’s note: this article has been slightly updated to help you put your best selfie (sorry) forward.

headline: Back-to-School Outfits on Fashion Students
text: Students at Parsons School of Design, a feeder school for the fashion industry, talk about their looks.

headline: Plan on Migrants Strains the Limits of Europe’s Unity
text: LONDON — After weeks of indecision, the European Union voted on Tuesday to distribute 120,000 asylum seekers among member states, a plan meant to display unity in the face of the largest movement of refugees on the Continent since World War II.

headline: What Happened to South African Democracy
text: LONDON — Most first-time visitors to Cape Town are mesmerized by the majesty of Table Mountain, and wowed by the vivacity of the Victorian-era waterfront. As a new visitor myself last month, I was captivated by both. But what has lodged most in my memory is something very different.

headline: ‘The Visiting Privilege,’ by Joy Williams
text: If the human race were ever put on trial — for crimes against the planet, animals and one another — it would be hard to think of a more ferocious prosecutor than Joy Williams. Is there a writer whose condemnations are more convincing, whose vision is more godless and bleak? And in case this all sounds too punishing for you, is there a funnier nihilist in the ranks of American writers?

headline: ‘Selfish,’ by Kim Kardashian West, and More
text: During her reign, Kim Kardashian has proved herself to be a person of towering if brittle self-regard. The brittleness is revealed in the floods of tears that attend even minor affronts to her sense of self: if a family member gently teases her; if she feels in any way misunderstood; if she realizes she may give birth to her third fiancé’s child before her second divorce is final. But the true nature of her self-­regard — river deep and mountain high — is revealed in just about all of her other actions, and particularly in her recently published collection of self-portraits, “Selfish.”

headline: 4 Kidnapped From Resort in Southern Philippines
text: MANILA — A group of 11 men posing as tourists kidnapped four people from a Philippine island resort on Monday, a military spokesman said on Tuesday.

headline: Deezer, French Music Streaming Service, Plans I.P.O.

headline: Microsoft Releases Office 2016, With Features Focused on Teamwork

text: Good Tuesday morning. Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin may have followed former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas off the trail to “clear the field,” but Washington is gaining both a boldface name and hundreds of thousands of members in his entourage. The pope descends on a Capitol ready for complicated logistics and full of competing voices claiming his message as their own.

headline: Volkswagen Says 11 Million Cars Worldwide Are Affected in Diesel Deception
text: FRANKFURT — A scandal that has battered Volkswagen’s image in the United States spread to the automaker’s core market in Europe on Tuesday, when the company said that 11 million of its diesel cars were equipped with software that could be used to cheat on emissions tests. That was more than 20 times the number of cars previously disclosed.

headline: 10 Things I Learned About Donald Trump in ‘The Art of the Deal’
text: When I wrote about “The Art of the Deal” for this weekend’s Times issue of Sunday Business, I couldn’t fit all the best nuggets from the book into a single article. So, here are some bonus takeaways from Donald Trump’s 1987 best-seller, the book he calls the second best in the world after the Bible.

headline: Asian Pantry Essentials
text: The basics of the pan-Asian pantry are condiments and starches: sauces and pastes that amplify flavors and rice and noodles to absorb them.

headline: Asian Essentials for Easy Weeknight Meals
text: “Soy sauce, fish sauce, miso paste.” Dale Talde was making a list. Pantry items you need if you want to cook better during the week. “Sambal oelek,” he continued, referring to the Indonesian chile sauce. “Gochujang,” the thick, fermented Korean red-pepper sauce. “Shrimp paste,” a mash of fermented ground shrimp blended with salt.

headline: TechFix | iPhone 6s Buyer’s Guide
text: In many respects the iPhone 6s bears a strong resemblance to its predecessor. But a few new features warrant a look if it’s time to upgrade.

headline: When Spell-Check Can’t Help
text: Here are the latest examples from the file of sound-alike mix-ups. We’ve seen them all before — make sure they’re on your better-check-twice list.

headline: Testing iPhone 6s’s 3D Touch and Live Photos Features
text: NOW that smartphones can do more than a million different things with apps, you have to wonder whether it matters when Apple adds two main new features to its latest iPhones.

headline: IPhone 6s’s Hands-Free Siri Is an Omen of the Future
text: The headline feature in Apple’s latest smartphones, the iPhone 6s and 6s Plus, is something called 3D Touch, which lets you activate shortcuts on the phone by pressing a bit harder on the screen. For now, though, I found a less novel, but far handier feature in the new iPhone — one that has long been the butt of jokes but is now becoming a necessary part of modern computing.

headline: The N.F.L. Extra Point Has Changed, but Deuces Still Aren’t Wild
text: The N.F.L.’s new try rule — “try” is the correct term, not point-after attempt, which applies only to kicks — is having the desired effect of making after-touchdown placement attempts no longer automatic. In the 2014 season, there were eight missed extra-point kicks. Already this season, with extra-point attempts snapped from the 15-yard line instead of the 2, there have been nine.

headline: A Butcher’s Extraordinary Past

headline: Lloyd Blankfein, Goldman Sachs C.E.O., Has Lymphoma

headline: A $1,000 Day in London for $100
text: “Are you Mr. Kugel?” asked the uniformed doorman in a town shell top hat as I approached the St. James's Hotel and Club, a scone’s throw from Buckingham Palace. I was there to meet Madeleine Calon, head concierge and the only female board member of the Society of the Golden Keys of Great Britain and the Commonwealth, a prestigious concierge organization.

headline: Anya Hindmarch: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Ms. Hindmarch’s latest collection.

headline: Rate Rage in 1932
text: Both Rob Johnson and Peter Temin direct me to a paper by Gerald Epstein and Thomas Ferguson on the Fed’s strange, destructive turn away from expansionary policy in 1932. They look carefully at the archival evidence, and find that a key factor was the complaints of commercial banks that low interest rates on government securities were squeezing their profits. That is, the turn to tight money in the face of deflation and a collapsing real economy was driven by the same narrow banker interests I have suggested explain current demands for higher rates despite low inflation.

headline: Daily Report: A New iPhone for the Slow Upgrade Crowd

headline: U.S. Trying to Protect Sage Grouse Without Listing It as an Endangered Species
text: HOUSTON — The Obama administration announced on Tuesday that the greater sage grouse, a flamboyant bird that roams across 11 Western states, does not warrant a listing as an endangered species, an action that could have damaged oil and natural gas interests and the economies of many local communities.

headline: Religions Are What People Make Them
text: The current crop of Republican presidential candidates is accomplishing something I would have considered impossible: making George W. Bush look like a statesman. Say what you like about his actions after 9/11 — and I did not like, at all — at least he made a point of not feeding anti-Muslim hysteria. But that was then.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Present Health Care Plan
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton will present on Tuesday a multipart plan to decrease the cost of prescription medication, as part of a series of campaign events this week devoted to health care policy and how she plans to “build on the progress” made under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Musée d’Orsay Reopens After Strike
text: PARIS — The Musée d’Orsay reopened here on Thursday after a two-day strike shut the museum down, delaying the opening of a highly anticipated show  on the artistic representation of prostitution.

headline: At Giles, Sweaty Strands Made Chic
text: Queen Elizabeth I was the regal template for the irregular braids backstage at the Giles spring/summer 2016 runway: The Toni&Guy team recreated the slightly shiny (ahem, sweaty) hair revealed once all those grand Tudor ladies took off their towering wigs. “Even though they’re braids, we didn’t want it to get too pretty,” said the hairstylist Indira Schauwecker, emphasizing the thinned-out quality of this anti-volume look. “It’s a lived-in and wet look with a masculine edge. The idea is that these braids have been destroyed by the wigs.”

headline: 1940: Nazis Torpedo Refugee Liner
text: LONDON — In one of the most tragic sea disasters of the war, 293 persons, including eighty-three children evacuated from England to escape Nazi bombs, lost their lives when a liner bound for Canada was torpedoed by a German submarine last Tuesday night 600 miles at sea, it was officially announced tonight [Sept. 22]. Only 113 persons out of a total complement of 406 aboard the vessel — which sailed Friday, the 13th — were rescued by British warships and landed last Friday at a northern British port. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 23, 1940

headline: Volkswagen: ‘We Have Totally Screwed Up’
text: Michael Horn, the president and chief executive of Volkswagen Group of America, spoke in September after the company admitted to cheating emissions tests in the United States.

headline: Colts Off to 0-2 Start Thanks to Andrew Luck’s Interceptions

headline: From Alaska to Iceland, Breaking Barriers to Arctic Travel
text: Growing up in New Hampshire, Sarah Aciego, 38, wanted to escape the cold, so she began her career as a scientist studying volcanoes. But when a research project sent her to Antarctica, she “fell in love with a whole different cold, a whole different kind of ice” and switched tracks completely.

headline: Catholics in White House Often Help Obama Build Support for Thorny Policy
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama’s decision to require religious organizations to provide insurance with free birth control encountered the fierce resistance of the nation’s Roman Catholic bishops, the president’s top aides — including Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services — set out to find a compromise.

headline: Donald Trump’s Old Queens Neighborhood Contrasts With the Diverse Area Around It
text: On a recent afternoon, Sabrina Dabakarov stood under the colonnaded portico of her family’s brick home on Midland Parkway in Queens and gestured at a neighborhood lined with oak trees and stately houses that for a century has played home to doctors, politicians and political bosses on 500 acres of hilly, meandering streets.

headline: Victory for the Chief and the Board at Bank of America Over a Dual Role
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — When the votes were in and his victory assured, Brian T. Moynihan of Bank of America hustled quickly off the stage, his face showing no hint of celebration.

headline: Report Stresses Importance of Agreement to Avoid Cyber Conflict
text: As China president Xi Jinping begins a trip to the United States that could include the first arms control accord for cyberspace between the United States and China, a new RAND report that rates the cyber warfare capabilities of the world’s two largest economies shows how important such an agreement could be.

headline: 1890: The War on Slavery
text: PARIS — The meeting of the anti-slavery congress in this city, convoked by Cardinal Lavigerie, will give a new impulse to the crusade against the African slave trade. The Powers that have divided Africa between them are now responsible. Now that the countries from which the slaves are brought are English, French, German, Belgian, Italian and Portuguese territories the European Governments are compelled to exercise a more active and extensive hostility to the trade. Fully 80,000 slaves are annually exported from Africa and as it is estimated that four-fifths of those brought down to the coast perish on the way, at least 400,000 negroes are annually torn from their homes. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 23, 1890

headline: Funding Dispute Over F.B.I. Headquarters Delays Next Step
text: WASHINGTON — The fate of the proposed new F.B.I. headquarters, to be built near the nation’s capital in return for its current building on Pennsylvania Avenue, is embroiled in a behind-the-scenes funding dispute involving the bureau, the General Services Administration and the federal Office of Management and Budget.

headline: 2 Are Killed in West Bank as Jewish and Muslim Holidays Approach
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian woman early Tuesday at a checkpoint in Hebron in the West Bank. The Israeli military said the woman had pulled out a knife, but a European advocate for Palestinian rights, who said he had witnessed the episode, said the woman appeared to be only trying to open her purse for inspection.

text: Hong Lei, a spokesman for the Chinese foreign ministry, said on Tuesday that Sandy Phan-Gillis, an American held in China on suspicion of espionage, is cooperating with an investigation.

headline: First Draft Focus: On the Edge of Their Seats for the Pope
text: Chairs were arranged for Pope Francis’s visit to Capitol Hill this week as the sun rose in Washington on Monday. The photo was taken from the speaker’s balcony, where the pope will wave to the crowd on Thursday.

headline: Tate Modern Announces Opening Date for New Extension
text: LONDON — It was the best year ever. So declared Tate officials at a news conference on Tuesday, held to release the organization’s annual report for 2014-15, and to announce the opening date of the long-awaited major extension to the Tate Modern. It will be June 17, 2016.

headline: Pope Francis’ Arrival in the U.S. Is a Low-Key Prelude to Pageantry
text: WASHINGTON — Pope Francis landed to a red-carpet welcome on Tuesday as he opened his first visit to the United States determined to press the world’s last superpower to do more to care for the planet and its most marginalized inhabitants.

headline: How to See Pope Francis During His U.S. Visit
text: Tens of thousands will flock to see Pope Francis this week during his three-city tour of the United States. If you’re not one of the comparatively few who have received tickets to the Masses, speeches or parades, have faith. There are still a few places where you can catch a glimpse of the pontiff — or get into the week’s spirit — in Washington, D.C., New York City and Philadelphia.

headline: WTA Chief Stacey Allaster Decides to Leave Hectic Job Behind
text: Stacey Allaster’s tennis counterpart Brad Drewett died in 2013 of Lou Gehrig’s disease at age 54. Her brother-in-law Greg Milkovich died of brain cancer in March at age 49.

headline: Jeb Bush Plans to Alter Federal Regulations to Invigorate Economy
text: Jeb Bush outlined a series of proposed changes to federal regulations on Tuesday, arguing that the Obama administration has stifled economic growth and pledging to freeze the publication of new rules until they are approved by an agency head that Mr. Bush nominates.

headline: De Blasio Says James Blake Has Handled Mistaken Arrest With ‘Selflessness’
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who the retired tennis star James Blake said had been cooperative and sympathetic to his calls for police reform during their meeting on Monday, returned the compliment on Tuesday, praising Mr. Blake for looking to spur change in the aftermath of his mistaken arrest.

headline: Exit Walker
text: About four hours passed yesterday between my hitting “publish” on a post suggesting that Scott Walker’s donors and supporters shouldn’t bail on him just yet and Walker surprising many of those same donors and supporters, as well as the political press, by deciding to drop out of the presidential race entirely. I was obviously among the surprised, and the sheer speed of Walker’s exit makes me think that all the savvy post-mortems might end up missing a key truth: Running for president is hard, unpleasant work, Walker had fought three intense campaigns in just four years, and it’s possible that he simply burned out on running for office sometime in the last two months.

headline: The Understated Elegance of the Airline Scarf
text: In an airport, there is not much to do but wait, and watch. Our fellow passengers tend to dress as if planning to attend a pajama party at 35,000 feet, of course, while the professionals dress professionally. Amid the terminal boredom, we find ourselves comforted by a pilot’s winged badge, oddly transfixed by a gate agent’s epaulets and charmed by what may be the last remaining glamorous thing about flying commercial, which is the scarf worn by the woman pleading for laggards to fold up their tray tables. While not all female flight attendants wear scarves, the attitude exemplified by Air Canada’s uniform guide — ”Wear your scarf at all times!” — is common enough to keep the item tightly knotted to the iconography of the job. In a traveler’s wishful moments, the panache of the scarf can perk up a slog of a trip with the hint of a colorful jaunt.

headline: David Petraeus Urges Stronger U.S. Military Effort in Syria
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s Syria policy came under sharp criticism Tuesday from one of its own former top military commanders and C.I.A. directors —David H. Petraeus — even as the White House is weighing new options for fighting the Islamic State in Syria.

headline: Gabriel Kreuther
text: European technique with a purpose at the chef’s new restaurant near Bryant Park.

headline: Restaurant Review: Gabriel Kreuther in Midtown
text: When the chef Gabriel Kreuther left the Modern in 2014, he seems to have packed up virtually everything except Picasso’s goat in the sculpture garden. He named the place he opened in June, across 42nd Street from Bryant Park, after himself, but it could just as easily be called the Modern in Exile.

text: It’s fall premiere season, and there’s more TV than ever. Here’s a quick survey of what’s new out there.

text: Balthus’s jewelry-designing daughter reflects on her ethereal life in a historic Swiss chalet — and on memories of a singular childhood.

text: Pope Francis celebrates Mass at the basilica in Santiago, Cuba, urging followers to build bridges and “plant seeds of reconciliation.”

headline: Inside a Jordanian Refugee Camp: Reporter’s Notebook
text: ZAATARI REFUGEE CAMP, Jordan — When I first visited Zaatari a few months after it opened in 2012, I wrote about the emerging marketplace: a couple dozen kiosks where people hawk used clothes, snacks, SIM cards and perfume. It was one of several signs of Syrians settling in, I said then; of realizing that they would “likely live in this camp for months, not days or weeks.”

headline: As London Fashion Week Ends, a Burberry Concert and Anya Hindmarch’s Fun House
text: LONDON — To paraphrase the Edwardian satirist H.H. Munro (better known as Saki, in one of English literature’s early feats of branding): They were good fashion shows, as fashion shows go, and as fashion shows go, they went.

headline: T.S.A. Defends Treatment of Transgender Air Traveler
