headline: Culture Project Cancels Play Directed by Cynthia Nixon
text: Citing serious financial trouble, the Culture Project on Tuesday abruptly canceled the premiere of a new play, backed by Rosie O’Donnell and directed by Cynthia Nixon, that was to have begun performances on Thursday.

headline: Buffy Sainte-Marie Wins Canada’s Polaris Prize
text: The veteran folk singer Buffy Sainte-Marie was awarded the 2015 Polaris Prize for Canadian album of the year at a ceremony in Toronto on Monday night. Ms. Sainte-Marie was honored for “Power in the Blood,” which was released in May, and will receive a prize of 50,000 Canadian dollars.

headline: Ben Carson Can’t Change Subject After Contentious Muslim Remark
text: Ben Carson, the retired neurosurgeon who is running for president, has seen his campaign’s first firestorm after remarks over the weekend in which he said that a Muslim should not be president of the United States.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates to Write Black Panther Comic for Marvel
text: Ta-Nehisi Coates can be identified in many ways: as a national correspondent for The Atlantic, as an author and, as of this month, as a nominee for the National Book Award’s nonfiction prize. But Mr. Coates also has a not-so-secret identity, as evidenced by some of his Atlantic blog posts and his Twitter feed: Marvel Comics superfan.

headline: Ben Carson Attacks ‘P.C. Culture’
text: In remarks on Tuesday, the Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson defended saying over the weekend that Muslims should not be president.

headline: Cardinals Are a Different Team When Carson Palmer Is Healthy
text: Over the final 10 weeks of the 2013 season, the Arizona Cardinals posted the second best record in the N.F.L. at 7-2. Then, over the first 11 weeks of the 2014 season, the Cardinals sat atop the N.F.L. standings with an 8-1 record. But quarterback injuries doomed the team, and Arizona lost its final three games of the season playing with a third-string quarterback, Ryan Lindley.

headline: Panda Express Takes a Second Run at New York
text: ROSEMEAD, Calif. — You tend to hear two prevailing views of Panda Express, a buffet-style chain that spoons up populist Chinese-American dishes at more than 1,800 locations around the world — and that plans on planting flags in New York City this year.

headline: An Emphasis on Lace and Organza at Marques’Almeida
text: The designers decided to play up textures in their spring/summer 2016 collection at London Fashion Week.

headline: Three’s a Trend: All-Over Cutouts
text: We’ve already discovered that spring/summer 2016 may well be the Season of the Shoulder. But shoulders aren’t the only body part that have been exposed on runways over the last few weeks — we’ve seen cutouts all over garments, particularly black ones, in New York and London. At Proenza Schouler, flamenco-inspired dresses included tidy cutouts at the waist (and shoulders, too). Across the pond, Anthony Vaccarello, the connoisseur of sporty-yet-sexy silhouettes, sent down a black tank with cutout detailing atop oversize, billowy black pants for Versus Versace. And a cutout form-fitting dress (in, you guessed it, black) showed up at Christopher Kane, whose collection was inspired by John Chamberlain’s “car crash” sculptures.

headline: San Francisco Opera Picks Matthew Shilvock, an Insider, to Be Its Leader
text: The San Francisco Opera mounted a 10-month international search to find a general director to succeed David Gockley when he steps down after this season. But in the end it decided that the best candidate was closer to home: On Tuesday the company announced that it would promote Matthew Shilvock, its associate general director, to the top job in August.

headline: ‘Lord of the Dance’ Creator Michael Flatley Announces His Farewell
text: Michael Flatley’s starring role in “Lord of the Dance: Dangerous Games” will mark more than one milestone for the 57-year-old who founded two major Irish dance franchises. It will be his Broadway debut — and his farewell.

headline: ConAgra Reports $1.2 Billion Quarterly Loss as Overhaul Continues
text: ConAgra Foods, which owns brands like Marie Callender’s, Reddi-wip and Chef Boyardee, reported a steep loss in its first quarter on Tuesday after knocking down the value of its beleaguered private label business.

headline: Volkswagen C.E.O. Apologizes for Fraud
text: Martin Winterkorn, the chief executive of Volkswagen, apologizes for the company’s diesel emissions deception but calls it “the mistakes of a few people.”

headline: Sadness vs. Euphoria: Fans Script Endings to Mets’ Season
text: Mets Win, and the World Is a Better Place

headline: Anguished 911 Call of Man Who Said He Had Tried to Drown His Children
text: The crime started in a dark North Carolina neighborhood and ended when two children were pulled alive from a nearby lake by an off-duty deputy, and the police said their father had tried to kill them.

headline: One Direction Announces November Album, Setting Up Battle With Bieber
text: Two of the biggest teen-pop acts in recent memory have picked the same day to grow up.

headline: Black Barn Takes Its Inspiration From the Farm
text: Black Barn Whitewashed barn board walls, steel paneling and an elaborate overhead maze of raw crisscrossed beams give new personality to the space that was the restaurant SD26. “Can you believe it?” asked the chef and owner John Doherty, pointing out the dramatic ceiling. The design, by Mark Zeff, who is also a partner, includes tables for larger parties in roomy alcoves and a chef’s table stationed to one side of the bright open kitchen. The resolutely farm-to-table menu executed by the chef, Matteo Bergamini, who was at SD26, only hints at Italy with an array of charcuterie, a black fig pizza, and porchetta with broccoli rabe. Mushroom toast, lobster salad and grilled corn salad are on the savory side of the menu. Sweets include an apple pudding with buckwheat croutons. There’s a long list of sparkling wines and Champagnes, some served at the compact oyster bar near the entrance: 19 East 26th Street, 212-265-5959, blackbarnrestaurant.com.

headline: Newfest Lineup Includes  Peter Greenaway and Todd Haynes Films
text: Films from seasoned directors join the work of newcomers in the lineup for Newfest, New York’s lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender film festival. Organizers announced Monday that the festival would open Oct. 22 with “Eisenstein in Guanajuato,” from Peter Greenaway, about the Russian director Sergei Eisenstein’s pivotal months  in Mexico in the 1930s. The film received a warm reception when it played in Berlin earlier this year.

headline: Palestinian Woman Is First to Oversee Muslim Wedding Vows
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Tahrir Hammad thinks women, including herself, are too emotional to serve as judges, and accepts without question an Islamic legal dictate that sees two women as equivalent to one male witness for official ceremonies.

headline: Bernie Sanders Joins Rally of Striking Federal Workers to Call for Wage Increase
text: Senator Bernie Sanders, the Democratic presidential candidate, is using the pope’s visit to Washington to amplify his call for a wage increase for federal workers.

headline: Video Review: The Ford Edge Adds a Touch of Luxury
text: ONE glance at your neighbor’s Chevrolet Suburban will confirm that Americans prefer roomier vehicles, so the dwindling number of midsize crossovers is puzzling. Honda Crosstour and Toyota Venza have been discontinued for lack of interest. That leaves the second-generation Ford Edge to do battle with the Sorento, Santa Fe, Murano and perhaps the raised wagon that is Outback.

headline: Driven | 2015 Ford Edge
text: The number of midsize crossover choices may be shrinking, but Ford has produced a new Edge and given it a premium feel and a sharp design.

headline: Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, Deposed President, Returns to Yemen
text: SANA, Yemen — President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi of Yemen flew back to his war-ravaged country on Tuesday for the first time since he was forced into exile six months ago, according to a senior Yemeni security official and a statement by his exiled government.

headline: Los Angeles Puts $100 Million Into Helping Homeless
text: LOS ANGELES — Flooded with homeless encampments from its freeway underpasses to the chic sidewalks of Venice Beach, municipal officials here declared a public emergency on Tuesday, making Los Angeles the first city in the nation to take such a drastic step in response to its mounting problem with street dwellers.

headline: Donald Trump Threatens to Sue Club for Growth Over Ad Campaign
text: Donald J. Trump is hitting back at the Club for Growth, threatening to sue the conservative organization unless it stops running advertisements asserting that he wants to raise taxes.

headline: Should You Watch CBS’s ‘Limitless’?
text: SERIES: “Limitless,” which premieres Tuesday on CBS, is based on the 2011 movie of the same title. Bradley Cooper, the star of the film, is an executive producer, is in the first episode and might appear on the show occassionally.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Asymmetrical Harnesses
text: We’ve seen plenty of unexpected skin in London this week, by way of creative cutouts. Another sexy trend that popped up this week: inventive, asymmetrical new plays on the harness. First, Simone Rocha sent innocent, girlie dresses down the runway bound with fabric or plastic harnesses. At Joseph, creative director Louise Trotter added a provocative touch — a double fabric harness, arcing over one shoulder and across the waist — to a simple ensemble comprised of a white top and black trousers. And true to form, Phoebe English delivered another collection filled with textures and layers, including a choppy cream skirt with suspenders that bound the arms.

headline: Is Bridge a Sport? The High Court Will Decide
text: Bridge, the trick-taking card game, has complex rules, prestigious international tournaments and a century of history.

headline: Petraeus Warns of Danger in Syria
text: Retired Gen. David H. Petraeus told the Senate Armed Services Committee that the effort to thwart the Islamic State and bring peace to Syria has been inadequate and lacked resources.

headline: French Law That Banned UberPop Service Survives Legal Challenge
text: The Constitutional Council in France upheld on Tuesday a law that banned Uber’s low-cost ride-hailing service, a much-awaited decision that underscores how national courts are enforcing limits on the company’s expansion into new markets.

headline: In Detroit, a 100-Foot Graphic Mural That Distills the Urban Experience
text: When Elysia Borowy-Reeder, the executive director of the Museum of Contemporary Art Detroit (MOCAD), first glimpsed the graphic geometric shapes and the vivid hues in the New York artist Andrew Kuo’s work, she immediately thought it would be perfect for MOCAD’s Woodward Avenue facade, a space previously covered with murals by the San Francisco artist Barry McGee and by Detroit’s Seventh Letter Crew.

headline: Why Some Policy Experts Question Clinton’s Plan to Contain Drug Costs
text: When critics complain about the high cost of a prescription drug, drug makers tend to have two main defenses. One is that developing drugs is an expensive, risky endeavor, and so companies need high prices to cover the cost of medical research. The second is that their products bring value by improving health and wellness, and the companies should be rewarded for those public benefits.

headline: 5 Easy Meals for the Distracted Cook
text: How many dishes can you cook on autopilot?

headline: Why Everything Is Bad for You
text: When I was growing up in the same New Jersey suburbs so expertly described in Todd Solondz movies and Tom Perrotta novels, the usual lunch for me was a sandwich consisting of Wonder Bread spread thick with Land O’ Lakes butter, a wad of Oscar Mayer bologna and a slice of American cheese.

headline: A Glittering After-Party Look at Ashish
text: For spring/summer 2016, the label featured shiny, upbeat garments worn by models with confetti in their hair.

headline: Donald Trump’s Letter to Club for Growth
text: Alan Garten, Mr. Trump's lawyer, sent a letter to Club for Growth's president, David McIntosh, accusing it of trying to damage Mr. Trump’s reputation by lying about his policies.

headline: A Religious Museum Expands in Amsterdam
text: The restored and expanded Our Lord in the Attic Museum (Museum Ons’ Lieve Heer op Solder) in Amsterdam makes its debut on Sept. 23, when visitors will enter the museum through a new entrance building connected by underground passage to the 17th-century house. The six-year, $12 million project adds a museum shop and cafe as well as more exhibit space to cover themes such as religious freedom historically through modern times. In its new layout, the museum also focuses on the stories of the various people who lived in the house.

headline: The Risk of a Billion-Dollar Valuation in Silicon Valley
text: Deep inside a Silicon Valley unicorn lurks a time bomb.

headline: Siri, Apple Music and Other iPhone Questions
text: We asked readers to send us questions about Apple’s newest smartphones, the iPhone 6s and 6s Plus, which go on sale on Friday. Brian X. Chen and Farhad Manjoo answer the queries.

headline: Why the Pope Should Scare Climate-Change Deniers
text: Perhaps unsurprisingly, conservatives are scrambling to condemn Pope Francis’s views on climate change in advance of his speech to Congress on Thursday.

headline: ‘The Martian’ Gets a Sneak Preview at the New York Film Festival
text: Days after being screened for the International Space Station, the Ridley Scott-Matt Damon nerd thriller “The Martian” will be shown on the planet of New York.

headline: Education Gap Between Rich and Poor Is Growing Wider
text: The wounds of segregation were still raw in the 1970s. With only rare exceptions, African-American children had nowhere near the same educational opportunities as whites.

headline: Pope Francis, Welcome to America
text: To the Editor:

headline: Robert Lewandowski Scores Five Goals in Nine Minutes for Bayern Munich
text: The goals came so quickly from Robert Lewandowski that it was hard to keep track of them.

headline: India Retracts Proposal on Encryption for Social Media Data After Outcry
text: NEW DELHI — Responding to a chorus of criticism, Indian officials on Tuesday hastily withdrew a draft policy on encryption that would have required users of social media and messaging applications to save plain-text versions of their messages for 90 days so that they could be shared with the police.

headline: Samu-Jussi Koski in Greece
text: The designer’s photographs from Athens, Serifos and the North Aegean Islands.

headline: A Finnish Designer Finds Inspiration — Truly — in the Greek Islands
text: Samu-Jussi Koski, the founder and head designer of the Helsinki-based fashion brand Samuji and its housewares line, Samuji Koti, cites nature as “a huge inspiration.” Hearing him describe the Greek landscape, it’s clear that phrase isn’t just a Q&A cop-out — he finds real motivation in, as he puts it, “the colors of the plants, the hills, the strange flowers, the ever-changing tone of the sky.” On the island Serifos, which he and his husband have visited each summer for the last decade or so, Koski likes to climb to the top of the highest hill at the edge of Chora, reaching a small church at either sunrise or sunset. “The sky that drops to the calm Mediterranean Sea at those times is something so beautiful,” he says. “One cannot find those colors anywhere else.”

headline: Should You Watch ABC’s ‘The Muppets’?
text: SERIES: “The Muppets,” the latest gig for Jim Henson’s menagerie, premieres Tuesday on ABC. It was created by Bill Prady, an executive producer of “The Big Bang Theory.”

headline: Pope Arrives in the U.S.
text: Pope Francis arrived on Tuesday at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland for his first visit to the United States.

headline: In Interview, Donald Trump Denies Report of Father’s Arrest in 1927
text: For a story about Donald J. Trump’s childhood home of Jamaica Estates, Queens, I talked to the presidential candidate about the role his father, Fred C. Trump, played in developing the neighborhood. I also asked him about a 1927 report in The New York Times, unearthed by the website Boing Boing, that listed Fred Trump as being among a group of people arrested, and then discharged, by the police in response to a Ku Klux Klan rally that had turned violent in Queens. The question, essentially, was, “Did you ever hear of this?”

headline: Should You Watch Fox’s ‘Scream Queens’?
text: SERIES: “Scream Queens,” which premieres Tuesday on Fox is the latest from Ryan Murphy, Brad Falchuk and Ian Brennan, the creators of “Glee.”

headline: Saudi Held at Guantánamo Is Repatriated, Reducing Number of Detainees to 114
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon announced on Tuesday that it had repatriated a Guantánamo Bay detainee who intelligence analysts had concluded was probably once a bodyguard for Osama bin Laden. The United States held the man as a wartime prisoner for more than 13 years, government files show.

headline: The Top 10 Moments From London Fashion Week
text: T’s market director recalls highlights from the spring/summer 2016 shows.

headline: I.R.S. Ruling Makes After-Tax Contributions More Attractive
text: Making pretax contributions to your 401(k) retirement plan is a no-brainer. But recent changes in federal tax rules may make it more attractive for serious savers to increase after-tax contributions, as well.

headline: Weeknight Recipes and Cooking Strategies
text: Cooking is a joy, a balm for mind and spirit. At its best it is a kind of magic, the transformation of groceries into art. But midweek cooking? Midweek cooking is a drag.

headline: Kardashian Sisters Off to Big Start With Their Own Web Channels
text: LOS ANGELES — And you thought the Kardashian-Jenner sisters had peaked.

headline: Harvard’s Endowment Earns 5.8%, but Lags Some of Its Peers
text: The Harvard University Management Company, which oversees an endowment of $37.6 billion, the academic world’s largest, generated a 5.8 percent return for its most recent fiscal year, significantly lower than several of its rivals.

headline: Ryan Lo’s Spring Romance
text: For his spring/summer 2016 collection, the designer used ruffles in a variety of pinks — and introduced prints.

headline: Why Scott Walker’s Campaign Failed
text: When a political campaign teeters on the edge of failure, the candidate and the campaign staff start to look for explanations. They blame the staff. They blame the press. They blame the weather. They blame everyone except the candidate.

headline: U.S. Targets Four States in Effort to Enroll the Uninsured
text: WASHINGTON — With the third open enrollment season under the Affordable Care Act beginning in about six weeks, Obama administration officials said Tuesday that they would focus efforts to expand health coverage to the uninsured in Dallas, Houston, northern New Jersey, Chicago and Miami.

headline: Review: In Fox’s ‘Rosewood,’ a Cocky Crime Pathologist in Sultry Miami
text: Miami occupies a special place among TV locations. “Dexter,” “Miami Vice,” “Nip/Tuck,” “CSI: Miami,” “Magic City,” HBO’s new “Ballers”: show after show is built on the idea that this city’s sun-drenched, hard-bodied exterior must hide corruption. No place, the implication is, can be that beautiful without being sick underneath.

headline: Hillary Clinton Says She Opposes Keystone Pipeline
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton said on Tuesday that she opposed building the Keystone XL oil pipeline, revealing her position on an issue that divides two Democratic constituencies, organized labor and environmentalists, and that she has long declined to address.

headline: Believing in Magic
text: A magician and his assistant, who travel the world performing, decide to tie the knot.

headline: A Conversation With Hamid R. Moghadam
text: Mr. Moghadam, 59, is the chairman and chief executive of Prologis, a publicly traded real estate investment trust, or REIT, based in San Francisco, that develops and owns about 700 million square feet of industrial property worldwide, including many sites in New Jersey.

headline: Xi Jinping Pledges to Work With U.S. to Stop Cybercrimes
text: SEATTLE — President Xi Jinping pledged in a speech here on Tuesday night to work with the United States on fighting cybercrime, saying that the Chinese government was a staunch defender of cybersecurity.

headline: ‘Empire’ Returns for Its Second Season, Still Juicy With Melodrama
text: “Empire” returns for its second season on Fox with a show of power. Several, actually.

headline: Tony Awards May Leave Radio City for Beacon Theater
text: It looks as if the Tonys are hitting the road again.

headline: Making Times Square’s Pedestrian Plazas Work
text: So the pedestrian plazas in Times Square aren’t going away. Last month’s tabloid flap over topless women and costumed panhandlers prompted William J. Bratton, the city’s police commissioner, to say he’d like to rip the plazas up. The mayor, Bill de Blasio, didn’t disagree, calling for a task force to study ways to improve the square.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: ‘Baby Doll,’ a Child-Woman at the Center of a Moral Sinkhole
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — Everyone onstage looks a little clammy at times in the enjoyable if slightly tame new stage adaptation of “Baby Doll” at the McCarter Theater Center here. The once-grand but now visibly crumbling mansion in which much of the action takes place looks as if it would give scant protection from the fierce Mississippi Delta sun. But the tensions that inflame its inhabitants are the primary cause of any excessive perspiration.

headline: Joshua Jay and Anna Kloots: A Magician Marries His Assistant
text: The groom? The magician Joshua Jay. The bride? Anna Kloots, his magician’s assistant. When Mr. Jay, 33, appears in a straitjacket, Ms. Kloots, 26, pulls in people from the audience to check the integrity of his bonds and his blindfold.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: What Scott Walker Could Have Learned From George W. Bush
text: The Internet is not wanting for explanations of the flameout of Gov. Scott Walker’s short and surprisingly anemic presidential campaign. Walker couldn’t lock down the Republican Party’s conservative base. His average-Joe persona was no match for the scene-stealing Donald Trump. He didn’t understand foreign policy. He didn’t understand domestic policy. He flip-flopped. He was too timid in the first debate. He was too gimmicky in the second debate. Above all, the Wisconsin governor’s downfall illustrates yet again how difficult and unforgiving the business of presidential campaigning is, even for a career politician like Walker.

headline: New York City Police Officer Pleads Guilty to Attempted Murder in Drunken Shooting
text: A New York City police officer pleaded guilty to attempted murder on Tuesday for firing a barrage of bullets at a car in Westchester County last year, an unprompted, drunken attack that seriously injured a 47-year-old passenger.

headline: Teaming Up, Together (Drake and Future) or Apart (Ryan Adams and Taylor Swift)
text: The idea of a partnership of equals is, at best, fallacy, and at worst, fantasy. Never is that more clear than when one-half of the team-up is Drake or Taylor Swift, the anchors of contemporary pop music.

headline: ‘Pizza Rat’ Prompts a Collective ‘Ew’ and Debate on Cleaning New York Subway
text: Even in a subway system often cluttered with trash, it stood out: a whole slice of pizza left carelessly on the floor.

headline: Giants Cut Receiver Preston Parker; Victor Cruz Runs in Practice
text: Preston Parker, the wide receiver who dropped several passes in the Giants’ first two games, was released by the team Tuesday. Just a few hours later, Victor Cruz, who has not played since early last season because of two leg injuries, was running in practice for the first time since mid-August.

headline: Quirky, an Invention Start-Up, Files for Bankruptcy
text: Quirky, an ambitious crowdsourced invention start-up, which raised $185 million from investors that included General Electric and leading venture capital firms, filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Salt and Pepper Roast Chicken
text: Melissa Clark makes a simple roast chicken.

headline: Review: ‘Pondling’ Looks Deep Into the Heart of a Disturbed Child
text: The rhyme about sugar and spice and everything nice has always been absurd. Anyone who’s ever been a little girl can tell you that much. But Madeleine, the faintly disheveled menace at the center of Genevieve Hulme-Beaman’s poignant and engrossing solo play, “Pondling,” is in particularly misleading disguise as a darling moppet.

headline: Review: In ‘Deep South,’ Paul Theroux Takes an Eye-Opening Road Trip
text: Paul Theroux is in a suspiciously good mood in “Deep South,” his 10th travel book. You begin to wonder if, in his relative old age — Mr. Theroux is 74 — this inimitably caustic novelist and nonfiction writer is mellowing.

headline: As Frustrations Build in Libya, So Do Calls for Help
text: TUNIS — For more than a year, Libyans have been watching their politicians shuttle between foreign capitals on rounds of peace talks, workshops and conferences in search of a solution to the worsening chaos at home. At one recent event in the Tunisian capital, frustrations at the slow progress were evident in the heartfelt questions and statements from the Libyan refugees in the audience.

headline: Scott Walker’s Dismal Finish Is a Fitting Result, Old Foes Say
text: MILWAUKEE — For the last 25 years, Representative Gwen Moore has sought to relinquish her claim to being the only politician ever to defeat Scott Walker.

headline: Late Rally for Doc Adams, a Jeter Before There Were Mitts
text: Before Derek Jeter made his mark as New York’s most illustrious shortstop, there was another player, popularly known as Doc Adams, who in the mid-1800s invented the position while playing for a different local powerhouse, the Knickerbocker Base Ball Club.

headline: Documenting Ukraine with a Different Visual Approach
text: Thomas de Wouters’s square, black-and white images of Ukraine look as if they were made by a 1960s-era New York street photographer set loose on the modern-day front between Russia and Ukraine.

headline: Pictures of the Day — Greece and Elsewhere
text: Greece and More: Pictures of the Day

headline: September 22, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Greece, Cuba, Ukraine and India.

headline: New York Prosecutor Accused of Attacking Woman at Bar Says She Was the Aggressor
text: On his first day back at work after Halloween last year, Eli Cherkasky, a prosecutor, told his co-workers at the Manhattan district attorney’s office that his bruised eye had been caused by the glasses he had worn as part of his Clark Kent costume.

headline: Brian Williams Back on Air After 7 Months
text: With little fanfare, Brian Williams returned to television Tuesday afternoon in his new position as a breaking-news anchor at MSNBC with coverage of Pope Francis’s arrival in the United States.

headline: Martin Shkreli, the Mercurial Man Behind the Drug Price Increase That Went Viral
text: Martin Shkreli is either the boy genius or the bad boy of pharmaceuticals, depending on one’s point of view.

headline: Judge Strikes Down New York City’s Ban on Foam Food Containers
text: New York City’s ban on plastic-foam food containers, the once-ubiquitous vessels for Chinese takeout and curbside halal food, has been overturned, rejecting a signature environmental initiative of two mayors and clearing the way for an industry-backed plan to buy and recycle the items.

headline: Coke Discloses Millions in Grants for Health Research and Community Programs
text: Coca-Cola, the world’s largest maker of sugary beverages, has spent almost $120 million in the past five years to pay for academic health research, partnerships with major medical groups and community fitness programs aimed at curbing the obesity epidemic.

headline: Clinton Breaks Silence on Keystone XL
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton came out in opposition to the oil pipeline at a campaign event in Des Moines.

headline: Tribune Publishing Lowers Its Profit Expectations
text: Tribune Publishing executives said in a conference call to investors on Tuesday that the company had reduced its guidance for the year based on what was described as a review of its holdings in Southern California.

headline: Alexis Tsipras Appoints New Greek Cabinet Much Like the Old
text: ATHENS — Greece’s newly re-elected prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, decided on Tuesday on a new cabinet with few new faces and returned the critical job of finance minister to Euclid Tsakalotos, the low-key economist who made headway with his eurozone peers in bailout negotiations.

headline: Pope Francis, in New York, Will Live Like a Diplomat
text: The signs of his arrival in the neighborhood will be less than subtle: a battalion of police officers, Secret Service agents and assorted security personnel monitoring every manhole and sidewalk crack; snipers on the rooftops; bomb-sniffing dogs at the ready.

headline: Ryan Fitzpatrick Gets Vote of Confidence From Jets Coach
text: The Jets’ surprising 2-0 start appears to be going a long way toward helping Ryan Fitzpatrick supplant Geno Smith as the starting quarterback.

headline: Volkswagen’s Diesel Fraud Makes Critic of Secret Code a Prophet
text: A Columbia University law professor stood in a hotel lobby one morning and noticed a sign apologizing for an elevator that was out of order. It had dropped unexpectedly three stories a few days earlier. The professor, Eben Moglen, tried to imagine what the world would be like if elevators were not built so that people could inspect them.

headline: The Republican Attack on Muslims
text: The Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson is drawing criticism over the bigoted comments he has been making recently about Muslims. It is well deserved, and is not a matter of “P.C. culture,” as Mr. Carson has claimed. Nor does Mr. Carson represent some minor fringe element in the Republican Party.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,349 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Mayor Rahm Emanuel Urges Tax Increases to Mend Chicago’s Finances
text: CHICAGO — Faced with a toxic combination of mounting pension payments and plunging credit ratings, Mayor Rahm Emanuel on Tuesday called for tax and fee increases unprecedented in this city’s modern history, including a “last resort” property tax increase of more than $500 million to be put in place over four years.

headline: Volkswagen’s Chief in the Vortex of the Storm
text: Striding past a car show model, Martin Winterkorn, trailed by aides, examined a Hyundai i30.

headline: The Plot Twist: E-Book Sales Slip, and Print Is Far From Dead
text: Five years ago, the book world was seized by collective panic over the uncertain future of print.

headline: Conflict Flavors Obama’s Meeting With Chinese Leader
text: WASHINGTON — For the past two years, the critical question confronting the Obama administration about Xi Jinping, the Chinese president who defied American predictions by challenging the United States’ superpower status early and directly, has been how forcefully to respond.

headline: Two Activists Visiting U.S. Call for Rights in Hong Kong
text: Two Hong Kong democracy activists — one young enough to be the other’s grandson — expressed deep distrust on Tuesday over China’s intentions and urged President Obama to press their cause when meeting his Chinese counterpart this week.

headline: Hillary Clinton Proposes Cap on Patients’ Drug Costs as Bernie Sanders Pushes His Plan
text: With voter fury rising over the high cost of prescription drugs, Hillary Rodham Clinton proposed capping out-of-pocket drug expenses at $250 a month on Tuesday while a rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, extolled his own plan and long record for pushing to lower drug costs.

headline: A Former Employee Speaks
text: An affidavit from Timothy Pierotti, who once worked for Martin Shkreli.

headline: Retrophin Complaint Against Shkreli
text: The company filed a lawsuit alleging its former chief executive, Martin Shkreli, had breached his duty of loyalty to the company.

headline: Iraq: Airstrike Kills an ISIS Leader
text: The Pentagon said Tuesday that coalition forces killed a senior leader of the Islamic State, Abu Bakr al-Turkmani, in an airstrike two weeks ago in northern Iraq. A Pentagon spokesman, Peter Cook, described Mr. Turkmani as an “administrative emir” of the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL, and a close associate of the group’s leaders. Mr. Cook also confirmed the death of a French jihadist, David Drugeon, in an airstrike in July in Syria. Mr. Drugeon was a member of the Khorasan Group, an offshoot of Al Qaeda, and an explosives expert, Mr. Cook said. Mr. Drugeon “trained other extremists in Syria and sought to plan other attacks against Western targets,” Mr. Cook said.

headline: Liberty Advance to Conference Finals
text: Epiphanny Prince missed 10 of her first 11 attempts from the field in Tuesday night’s decisive Game 3 Eastern Conference semifinal against the Washington Mystics at Madison Square Garden. With the Liberty’s franchise record for wins and best regular-season record in the W.N.B.A. this year withering away in the fourth quarter, Prince had passed up open looks, her confidence nearly shot.

headline: Sir David Willcocks, Conductor Who Influenced British Choral Music, Dies at 95
text: Sir David Willcocks, long considered Britain’s most esteemed choir director, who also led ensembles in the United States and even worked with the Rolling Stones, died on Thursday at his home in Cambridge, England. He was 95.

headline: Gov. Scott Walker Goes Back to His Day Job
text: MADISON, Wis. — Gov. Scott Walker went back to his regular job on Tuesday, and it sounded like just another day. The governor was at work in the Capitol, his aides said, holding private meetings and receiving briefings from his executive staff.

headline: ‘Scream Queens’ Series Premiere Recap: Funny or Scary?
text: Episodes 1 and 2: “Pilot” and “Hell Week”

headline: Perfect as a Sonnet
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — It’s football season once again, and I am aware of this for two reasons:

headline: Uber Introduces Carpooling Service for Commuters, Starting in China
text: Uber is growing like a weed in China, spending millions of dollars to push into the country. And it’s just getting started.

headline: Pope Francis Visits: Day 4

headline: Race and Class Collide in a Plan for Two Brooklyn Schools

headline: Anne-Marie Slaughter’s ‘Unfinished Business’
text: Three years ago, Anne-Marie Slaughter wrote an article for The Atlantic about the difficulty of career advancement for professional women with children. “Why Women Still Can’t Have It All,” which has now grown into “Unfinished Business,” electrified readers. Slaughter’s criticisms of workplace policies and attitudes were not new, but her article had the force of her own belated awakening to the problem. A law professor, author and ­Princeton University dean (now president of the nonpartisan think tank New America), Slaughter had just spent two years as director of policy planning in the State Department under Hillary Clinton — a “dream job” that she initially hoped would lead to further advancement within the agency. But after two years of punishing work hours and a weekly commute between Washington and Princeton, where her husband was taking care of their two sons, Slaughter was surprised to find herself declining more State Department stints. Sometimes a job just couldn’t be squared with family responsibilities, she concluded. She returned to her full-time academic post at Princeton, which offered flexible hours more conducive to family life, and was more or less satisfied with her decision.

headline: Starbucks Falls Short After Pledging Better Labor Practices
text: Last year, Starbucks  vowed to provide store employees with more consistent schedules from week to week, and to post their schedules at least 10 days in advance. The company said it would stop asking workers to endure the sleep-depriving ritual known as a “clopening,” which requires them to shut down a store at night only to return early the next morning to help open it.

headline: Consumers Are Embracing Full-Fat Foods
text: Public health authorities have long urged Americans to cut back on foods high in saturated fat like butter, meat and whole milk. But a new report on dietary-fat consumption suggests that the public is increasingly eating more, not less, of these foods.

headline: Margaret Atwood’s ‘The Heart Goes Last’
text: The world of “The Heart Goes Last” starts out feeling familiarly post-­apocalyptic: a destitute married couple, Charmaine and Stan, drift across a devastated landscape, forced to sleep in their car as roving bandits threaten attack each night. As the story expands, we see the novel’s reality is even more disturbing: This is not a different universe, just a slightly exaggerated version of our own. A world where the working class has been pushed off the edge of the economic cliff, and the middle-class dream is alive only as a living nightmare. One of the last sustainable industries is the prison system. “Prisons used to be about punishment, and then reform and penitence, and then keeping dangerous offenders inside. Then, for quite a few decades, they were about crowd control — penning up the young, aggressive, marginalized guys to keep them off the streets. And then, when they started to be run as private businesses, they were about the profit margins for the prepackaged jail-meal suppliers and the hired guards and so forth.”

headline: Trevor Noah on ‘The Daily Show’ and His ‘Jewish Yoda,’ Jon Stewart
text: Like the mostly vacant canvas that once hung outside the Midtown Manhattan studios of “The Daily Show,” advertising his Sept. 28 debut date and not much else, the office that Trevor Noah works from was nearly barren on a recent visit. The walls were unadorned, and the bookshelves were unfilled, except for a sound system that Mr. Noah was setting up so he could listen to jazz while he worked on his material. Perhaps the room’s only other distinguishing feature was a row of three TV sets, tuned to the NY1, CNN and BBC news channels, inundating Mr. Noah, 31, with a stream of information from around the world.

headline: In Europe’s Top Destinations, Hotels to Suit Your Wallet

But luxury isn’t limited to pampering hotels with bank-bleeding prices. Sometimes the extras — a bountiful breakfast buffet, historic settings or personal services like walking tours and hiking directions — provide equivalent value at cheaper lodgings. The following hotel pairs in six European destinations offer intriguing alternatives at either end of the budget spectrum.

headline: Peer Pressure (not Parent Pressure) Helps Picky Eaters Try New Foods
text: Many parents struggle to persuade their school-aged children to take to heart the value of eating a healthy, varied diet, one that is colorful, full of vegetables and fruits and light on the bland, refined white grains like bread, pasta and pizza that go down so easily with children. Marlo and Corey, parents of Brooke, 10, and Hunter, 7, want the whole family to sit down to eat one, balanced meal together, but Brooke refuses to eat many foods, preferring pasta with butter and cheese or ramen noodles. Her younger brother almost always follows her lead, and Marlo and Corey have been willing to prepare something different for each child just to be sure that they eat enough.

headline: 1915: Nurse Risks Gangrene Test
text: The most infectious, rapid and fatal of all diseases of the battlefield — gas gangrene — has probably been vanquished by science at the American Hospital at Neuilly. Through the heroism of a nurse, Miss Mary Davies, who inoculated herself with the bacilli, Dr. Kenneth Taylor, who recently announced in the ‘‘Lancet’’ successful experiments on guinea pigs with a new vaccine, was able to test the remedy for the first time on a human being. Although virulent gangrene symptoms rapidly developed in the young woman, Dr. Taylor has announced that she is now out of danger. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 24, 1915

headline: Chinese Spillovers

headline: 1965: French Reds Back Mitterrand
text: PARIS — The French Communist Party ended 17 years of political isolation today [Sept. 23] by endorsing the leftist presidential candidacy of François Mitterrand. The choice was necessary because a purely Communist candidacy against President Charles de Gaulle might have produced as little as half of its traditional 20 percent of the vote. With Communist, Socialist, and other leftist backing, Mr. Mitterrand can expect 5 to 6 million votes from an electorate of nearly 28 million. He has a good chance of getting more votes than any other candidate except Gen. de Gaulle in the Dec. 5 election. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 24, 1965

headline: A Summer of Treasure-Filled Balloons
text: On this first official day of fall, we celebrate summer’s end with a look back at one particularly seasonal, cross-country road trip. Last month, Sleepy Jones — the brand known for pajamas that look as appropriate on the street as they do at the breakfast table — released big red balloons at some of the nation’s most breathtaking environs: from the beaches of Montauk and the dunes of White Sands National Monument in New Mexico to the rocky shores of Malibu and the lush vineyards of Napa. It was a treasure hunt of sorts, and the locations were announced on Instagram. Each one was filled with Sleepy Jones pieces, money for the lucky finder’s troubles and, in one case, a party invitation from Miranda July.

headline: In Fashion, Food and Night Life, a New Energy in Milan

Apart from the influxes for fashion week and April’s Salone del Mobile design fair, visitors passed it by. But now, the city is on the edge of something of a renaissance, with new designers taking over at leading fashion houses, independent designers gaining more recognition and a host of new restaurants, bars and cultural activities on offer.

headline: Sultry, Desert-Inspired Makeup, the Alberta Ferretti Way
text: “I was thinking about a woman in the vast expanses of the desert. Unrestricted spaces allow a woman’s identity the freedom to emerge,” said the designer Alberta Ferretti backstage at the 18th-century Palazzo Serbelloni, moments before sending her collection — folk-inspired dresses in sunburnt variations of organza and lace — out on a catwalk made of sand.

headline: New York City Ballet Gambles on Unknown Choreographers
text: Sara Mearns, balanced on one square inch of a pointe shoe, her other leg bent in front of her, swiveled under Tyler Angle’s outstretched arm, ducking her head. “I can’t get through!” she shrieked as her neck caught under his elbow. Then both dancers fell out of the position, collapsing with laugher. Robert Binet, 24, smiled. “Let’s try a different way,” he said.

headline: Mayor de Blasio and Cardinal Dolan Highlight Plan to Add Beds for Homeless
text: A day before Pope Francis was to arrive in New York, Mayor Bill de Blasio and Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan said on Wednesday that a partnership between the Roman Catholic Church and the city would provide 150 beds this winter to homeless people who have been living on the street.

headline: A Yankee’s Forgiveness Won’t Be Forgotten
text: The overdue and gloriously unscripted sequel to Yogi Berra’s wonderful Yankees life began on a cold Tuesday evening in January 1999, when Berra, a Hall of Fame catcher, stood slightly hunched at the back-entrance doorstep of a recently opened museum named for him. He awaited the arrival of the man whose impulsive behavioral and operational tendencies had sent Berra into a 14-year self-imposed exile from his most cherished workplace, in the South Bronx.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 3: Waiver Wire Picks
text: The injuries did not stop in Week 2 of the N.F.L. season. Eddie Lacy exited with a high ankle sprain, Tony Romo fractured his collarbone and important players like Lamar Miller, Carlos Hyde and Davante Adams also left the field early with injuries. With some of these fantasy football starters potentially sidelined, that opens the door for other players to make an impact. Week 2 also proved that all of those overreactions from Week 1 were just that — overreactions. Adrian Peterson totaled nearly 200 all-purpose yards, Odell Beckham Jr. had nearly 150 yards and a touchdown, and Calvin Johnson and A.J. Green returned to pay dirt. Whether your team’s record is 2-0 or 0-2, the waiver wire can be a path to fantasy gold.

headline: 36 Hours in Paris, Right Bank
text: Think Left Bank, and the Latin Quarter and the Eiffel Tower spring to mind. The Right Bank, which is twice the size, has no clear identity. There are, in fact, many Right Banks. There is the Old Regime Right Bank, both monumental and orderly, with some of the city’s best-known sites — the Louvre, the Tuileries Gardens and the Palais Royal. There is the intimate, disorderly Marais, and the elegant open spaces of the revolutionary Right Bank (with the Bastille and Place de la Concorde, where Louis XVI, Marie Antoinette and Robespierre were guillotined). And there is the 19th-century financial Right Bank with its grand boulevards, covered arcades and department stores. Meanwhile, Right Bank villages like Montmartre, Passy and Belleville that were added to the city only in 1860 have struggled ever since to hold on to their local identities. Below is a selection of places that will let you discover the Right Bank’s multiple personalities.

headline: Yannick Noah Once Again Answers France’s Call

headline: Jumpsuits, 7 Days a Week at Totokaelo’s SoHo Store
text: There’s something deplorably corny about referring to a website as a “destination.” It’s like calling an advertisement “branded content” or referring to a person — any person — as a “thought leader.” But in the case of Totokaelo, the term actually makes sense. For the last five years or so, the website of this retailer really has provided a vantage point for surveying a certain fashion landscape.

headline: The Prime Minister Did What With a Pig’s Head?
text: IN Oxford in the 1980s, the covered market in the town center was a warren of small shops, selling everything from antiques to fruit and vegetables. There was an upstairs cafe and a butcher shop that displayed its wares in traditional fashion: Rows of carcasses hung above the entrance and across the front, so that in season it was almost comically festooned with dead game birds. Trays of trotters, liver and other kinds of offal completed the carnivorous tableau, usually arranged artfully around an obscenely grinning pig’s head.

headline: The Montreal Brothers Behind a Jet Set Leather Brand
text: MONTREAL — This is not a typical city to start a global luxury brand, but then again Want Les Essentiels de La Vie specializes in being atypical, beginning with that mouthful of a name and the company’s identical twin founders, Byron and Dexter Peart.

headline: Ashraf Ghani, Afghan President, Vows to Crack Down on Abuse of Boys

headline: Egypt Buys Two French Warships Originally Built for Russia

headline: How Brian Regan, Connoisseur of Clean Jokes, Became a Comic’s Comic
text: Brian Regan is a throwback, and not just because he is one of the last headlining comics who refuse to curse onstage.

headline: The Art, Drinks, Roads and Poems that Inspire Julia Holter
text: On paper, one could be forgiven for mistaking the music of the experimental pop singer Julia Holter for a particularly eclectic college syllabus. Over the course of Holter’s four albums, she’s taken inspiration from Euripides’s “Hippolytus” (her album “Tragedy”) and Frank O’Hara’s “Having a Coke With You” (her song “Moni Mon Ami”). On her last album, “Loud City Song,” Holter filtered contemporary celebrity through the lens of “Gigi,” a 1958 musical set in turn-of-the-century Paris, based on a novella by Colette. On her new record, “Have You in My Wilderness” (out Sept. 25 on Domino), however, Holter’s inspirations are less thematically unified — more free form — than in the past. “This record is less identifiable with influences,” she says. “It’s not that I don’t use a bit from books or legends or whatever, but each song is different; it’s not like I had loosely based the album on some kind of narrative.”

headline: The Instantly Gratifying Facial
text: Defining the contours of the face was once as easy as applying a bit of blush. Then bronzer became a (really big) thing. Then the duck face came along — as a not so discreet attempt to create the illusion of concave cheeks in selfies. Ultimately, a cheekbone-defining makeup technique called contouring took YouTube tutorials by storm, followed not too distantly by the Kardashian-approved highlighting method called strobing (on Instagram). Aestheticians and skin care companies get it: We will go to great lengths to mask a puffy face. So recently, they’ve taken to toning and depuffing skin — for real.

headline: Restoring Public Confidence in Government Isn’t Getting Any Easier in Ferguson, Mo.

The Department of Justice has found that this system abuses the rights of citizens — especially African Americans — in scheming to raise revenue.  And a recent tone-deaf response from the courts to calls for reform has only worsened the public’s fury.

Here, the National Brass Ensemble, made up of some of the country’s finest players, does splendid work with selections from Gabrieli’s Sacrae Symphoniae in an arrangement by Tim Higgins. John Williams’s breathless “Music for Brass,” a new work with more than a hint of “Star Wars” steel and sparkle, rounds out the program. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

headline: Review: ‘Finale’ by Thomas Mallon Moves Past ‘Watergate’ and Into the Reagan Era
text: Thomas Mallon’s latest historical novel, “Finale,” picks up effortlessly from his last. And “Watergate” (2012) is a tough act to follow. It’s a shockingly glamorous immersion in the Washington of the Nixon years, with a vast array of characters and a beautifully oblique way of maneuvering them. It makes no difference what knowledge of the Nixon presidency you bring to this marvel of a book. Mr. Mallon has found surprising perspectives from which to look at it and a way of siphoning emphasis away from the turf already trampled by historians. Only its deftly manipulative style keeps “Watergate” from being mistaken for nonfiction.

headline: Review: ‘Swan Lake’ Features an Authoritative Sara Mearns
text: Sara Mearns, leading the first of four casts of “Swan Lake” and opening New York City Ballet’s four-week fall season at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday, has moved light years beyond the melodramatic clichés with which this ballet is usually saddled. The foolish “Black Swan” notion of this ballet makes Odette the good, passive victim and Odile the actively evil demon, while Prince Siegfried looks like a moron for thinking one could be the other. Ms. Mearns, however, interpreting the double role with completely authoritative individuality, makes both heroines arrestingly multilayered. Her Odette reveals a capacity for voluptuous passion within doomed captivity; her Odile is extraordinarily cool, enigmatic, even poignant, notwithstanding sweeping brilliance.

headline: Viola Davis Speaks About Her Emmy, Diversity and Women on TV
text: When Viola Davis accepted her Emmy Award for best actress in a drama on Sunday night, she was the first African-American woman to ever do so. Feeling the weight of that moment, Ms. Davis quoted Harriet Tubman (“But I can’t seem to get there no how. I can’t seem to get over that line”) and put it plainly to the television industry about the lack of opportunities for black women. “You cannot win an Emmy for roles that are simply not there,” she said.

headline: The Billionaire, the Picassos and a $30 Million Gift to Shame a Middleman
text: MONACO — In what appears at first glance to be a simple, magnanimous act, a Russian billionaire is poised this week to return two Picassos, valued at $30 million, to the artist’s stepdaughter, who says the works, both portraits of her mother — Jacqueline Roque, Picasso’s second wife — were stolen from her.

headline: China’s President Confident of Growth
text: President Xi Jinping of China said the country was capable of maintaining a medium to high growth rate in the future.

headline: The Soft Bigotry of Ben Carson
text: The Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson said Sunday on NBC’s “Meet the Press,” “I would not advocate that we put a Muslim in charge of this nation. I absolutely would not agree with that.”

headline: Pentagon Says Chinese Pilot Flew Too Close to U.S. Spy Plane
text: WASHINGTON — A Chinese fighter jet performed an unsafe maneuver last week while close to a United States spy plane, Defense Department officials said Wednesday. It is the second time in just over a year that the Pentagon has accused Chinese pilots of inflaming tensions.

headline: Review: In a New Work, Camille A. Brown Plays With Empowerment
text: The choreographer Camille A. Brown may be tiny, but her latest dance isn’t the least bit diminutive. In “Black Girl: Linguistic Play,” which opened the Joyce Theater’s fall season on a high note Tuesday, Ms. Brown explores black female identity by transporting her dancers and audience to the playground. On a multilevel stage of platforms and mirrors, she uses the games of childhood as a source of empowerment.

headline: E.U. Leaders Say Common Ground Reached on Migrant Crisis
text: BRUSSELS — European Union leaders ended an emergency summit meeting on Wednesday saying that they had calmed divisions over a migrant crisis and agreed to increase financial support for displaced Syrians in the Middle East.

headline: Memories of Berra Well Up for Yankees Young and Old
text: TORONTO — One day in spring training about a decade ago, the Yankees’ clubhouse manager, Rob Cucuzza, came across Yogi Berra, who had plopped down in a chair. Cucuzza finally mustered the gumption to ask him a question.

headline: Jeremy P. Tarcher, Publisher of Nonfiction Best Sellers, Dies at 83
text: Jeremy P. Tarcher, who four decades ago founded the publishing house that bears his name, specializing in nonfiction books on health, psychology and New Age spirituality, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 83.

headline: Colombia Nears a Peace Deal With FARC Rebels
text: President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia and the leader of the country’s largest rebel group said Wednesday that they were close to completing a peace deal to end Latin America’s longest-running guerrilla war, announcing that they had reached breakthroughs on some of the most difficult issues dividing the two sides.

headline: Tribunal May Be Formed for Malaysia Flight 17 Jet Lost Over Ukraine

headline: Canada: Two Men Get Life Sentences in Plot to Derail Train From New York
text: Two men were sentenced Wednesday in Toronto to life in prison for plotting to derail a passenger train traveling from New York to Toronto and other terrorism-related charges. Chiheb Esseghaier, 33, and Raed Jaser, 37, were convicted this year largely on the strength of secret recordings made by an F.B.I. agent who posed as an Egyptian-American real estate developer with radical Islamist views. Mr. Esseghaier, who is from Montreal, had repeatedly said he would not participate in the trial because he recognized only the laws of the Quran. Two psychiatrists concluded that Mr. Esseghaier probably has schizophrenia but differed on whether he was fit to stand trial. But Justice Michael Code of the Ontario Superior Court found that the man was not delusional at the time of the plotting. The judge also rejected Mr. Jaser’s defense that he had been entrapped and played along with the agent only to get money to feed his drug addiction.

headline: Pilgrims Gather in Washington to See Pope Francis Canonize Junípero Serra
text: WASHINGTON — They came in sandals and dress shoes, in shorts and in their Sunday best.

headline: Where the Refugees Pour Into Germany, a 24-Hour Window
text: DORTMUND, Germany — The ramps and slopes of the skateboard hall are stacked with thousands of donated garments, all sorted into boxes by type and size. The bowling lanes are dormant. The concerts and dance classes are postponed. Nothing ordinary has been happening at the Dietrich Keuning Haus, a community center behind the main railway station, since Sept. 6.

headline: A Link in a Chain of Star Yankees Catchers
text: Yogi Berra, who died on Tuesday at 90, was a part of a tradition of outstanding Yankees catchers, who have done as much as any other players to define the team’s greatness over the decades.

headline: Discovery of Evidence Bag Adds Twist to Kane Case
text: BUFFALO — A lawyer for the woman who has accused the Chicago Blackhawks star Patrick Kane of rape announced at a news conference Wednesday that a rape-kit evidence bag was left on the doorstep of the accuser’s mother Tuesday afternoon. But police officials quickly dismissed the claim as untrue, even as it raised new questions about the investigation in the increasingly bizarre case.

headline: Military Analyst Again Raises Red Flags on Progress in Iraq

headline: North Carolina: 3-year-old Thrown Into Pond Dies
text: A 3-year-old girl who was thrown into a pond at an apartment complex by her father late Sunday died on Wednesday, the police in Durham, N.C., said. The girl and two siblings were thrown into the pond by Alan Lassiter, 29, of Raleigh, the police said. The girl and her 5-year-old sister were pulled out alive. Their 7-year-old brother escaped on his own and sought help, the police said. The older girl was released from a hospital. Mr. Lassiter is being held in the Durham County jail on three charges of attempted murder, although one of the counts is expected to be upgraded to murder. He told a 911 dispatcher that he tried to drown his children because the child protection authorities were trying to take them away as he was seeking help for sexual feelings toward children, the police said.

headline: Washington State Officers Are Cleared in Shooting
text: Three police officers who fatally shot a rock-throwing Hispanic man in Pasco, Wash., did not violate department policies or procedures in the February encounter, according to the findings of an internal investigation released Wednesday.

headline: Player of the Year? Someone With the Initial ‘J.’

headline: A Car Scandal Shoves Berlin Off High Ground
text: BERLIN — As Germany has emerged as the dominant actor in Europe, it has lectured Greece and other debtor nations on the virtues of thrift and lately wagged its finger at countries that balk at receiving a share of refugees from the killing fields of Syria. Its right to lead, based on a narrative of self-sacrifice and obedience to rules, was generally acknowledged.

headline: As Europe Wrangles Over Migrant Relocation, Reality Moves Faster
text: PIRAEUS, Greece — Amid the rancorous bickering this week by European leaders over a relocation plan to spread asylum seekers around the Continent, a Coast Guard officer stood on the dock here at Greece’s main port screaming a blunt command at a throng of rain-soaked new arrivals: Hurry up and relocate yourselves.

headline: Xi Jinping Hears Tough Complaints of American Business

headline: New York’s Transportation Command Prepares for the Papal Disruptions
text: Inside New York City’s bustling traffic command center in Queens, a mosaic of screens fills a long wall, broadcasting dozens of live feeds of vehicles moving about the city. Operators sit at monitors, scrolling through incident reports and updating electronic road signs to alert drivers to accidents.

headline: Phil Patton, Design Writer Who Scrutinized the Everyday, Dies at 63

headline: Missouri Governor Jay Nixon’s Legacy Firmly Linked to Ferguson

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (ABC) GREY’S ANATOMY In this season premiere, the doctors confront their pasts while trying to save the lives of two girls who are victims of bullying. Meredith (Ellen Pompeo), meanwhile, adjusts to living with new roommates, and Bailey (Chandra Wilson) fights to become the chief of surgery. In “Scandal,” at 9, Olivia (Kerry Washington) and Fitz (Tony Goldwyn) revel in their relationship until a royal visit turns tragic. And in “How to Get Away With Murder,” at 10, Annalise (Viola Davis, fresh off an Emmy win for best lead actress in a drama series) and her students must move on as though nothing has happened in the wake of Rebecca’s disappearance. headline: Young, Black, Female and Envisioning Corporate Life
text: Endia Beal is a North Carolina-based artist who uses photography and video to explore conversations about race and diversity in the corporate setting. Ms. Beal, 30, received her M.F.A. in photography from Yale Art School and currently works as an associate professor of photography at Winston-Salem State University and as director of the university’s Diggs Gallery. Her most notable portrait series, “Can I Touch It,” presents white women in corporate attire wearing traditionally black hairstyles. Earlier this year, Ms. Beal was one of 11 photographers to present their work at the National Geographic Photography Seminar.

headline: A Modest Step for the Refugees
text: The European Union finally did the very least it could do on Tuesday and voted to distribute 120,000 asylum seekers among member nations. That will relieve some of the pressure on the frontline countries flooded by the unending flow of refugees from the Middle East and North Africa. But the long delay in taking even this modest step, and the bitter resistance of four Central European states, offer a graphic display of the grave threat posed by the crisis to the fundamental principles of the union.

headline: The Pope and Clark Gable

One day I saw a picture of then-Pope Pius XII on the front page of the evening paper and I was shocked — Shocked! I had no idea that anybody in Ohio outside my immediate neighborhood knew who he was.

headline: A Pope for All Species

headline: Review: In ‘The Intern,’ She’s the Boss, but He’s the Star
text: The director Nancy Meyers doesn’t just make movies, she makes the kind of lifestyle fantasies you sink into like eiderdown. Her movies are frothy, playful, homogeneous, routinely maddening and generally pretty irresistible even when they’re not all that good. Her most notable visual signature is the immaculate, luxuriously appointed interiors she’s known to fuss over personally — they inevitably feature throw pillows that look as if they’ve been arranged with a measuring tape. These interiors are fetishized by moviegoers and Architectural Digest alike, ready-made for Pinterest and comment threads peppered with questions like, “Where do I get that hat?”

headline: After Volkswagen Revelation, Auto Emissions Tests Come Under Global Scrutiny
text: In the United States, automakers conduct their own emissions tests and submit the results to the government. In Europe, automakers pick who conducts the tests and where they are done. And these two regulatory systems are considered the world’s gold standards.

headline: Combination Drug May Ease the Agitation of Alzheimer’s
text: Agitation and aggression are common in Alzheimer’s patients, and there is no known safe and effective treatment. Now researchers report that a combination drug already in use for treating certain neurological problems may be a better remedy.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Secret Power
text: Stanford, Calif. — ON Monday, the Supreme Court will meet in private to perform one of its most consequential — yet least appreciated — functions: choosing the cases it will hear. The court’s nine justices hold regular conferences from late September to late June to perform this task. From the roughly 8,000 petitions that arrive at the court each year, the justices select about 75 cases. If four or more justices vote to take a case, it is added to the docket; otherwise, review is denied. Either way, an explanation for the court’s decision is almost never given, nor is it customary to indicate how the individual justices voted.

headline: ‘Empire’ and ‘black-ish’ Show Why Diversity Needs to Be Deep, Not Just Broad

With racial controversies, especially those involving African-Americans, increasingly making headlines over the past year, it would have been that much more glaring if there were only lily-white TV families to answer back.

Often, the police say, the immigrants, many of whom have crossed the border illegally, try to make a run for it when the vehicle is stopped.

headline: 1940: Sipping Aperitif From a Teacup
text: PARIS (via Berlin) — A bootleg and speakeasy industry that flourished in the United States during the dry era has made its appearance in France with the enforcement of partial prohibition. The new law throws a dry blanket on one of the gayest French customs — the aperitif hour. It fixes the alcoholic content of all drinks classed as aperitifs at not more than 16 per cent. The favourite dodge to get a drink of barred liquor is to enter a bar or cafe where you are known and order an ‘‘infusion,’’ which is the French word for herb tea. The bootleg drink is then served in a teacup. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 25, 1940

headline: Pulling Off Fendi’s Improperly Placed Eyeliner
text: For Fendi’s spring/summer 2016 collection — inspired as much by the military as by romance — the makeup artist Peter Philips drafted a look based on notes from Karl Lagerfeld: purity, the sunlit branches of a tree, “a runaway Mormon girl.” Using Dior Star foundation, he evened the models’ skin tone and left the face mostly clean — no mascara or lipstick, and just a touch of pink blush — so that a graphic line above the eye, centered between the lashes and the eyebrow, stood out. The effect is especially dramatic when it catches the light, like the tree in Lagerfeld’s vision.

headline: 1965: Russia Proposes Treaty to U.N.
text: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. — Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko proposed to the UN General Assembly a draft treaty on the nonproliferation of nuclear weapons. If accepted, the treaty would block plans for a NATO multilateral nuclear force. The Russians rejected a similar treaty put forward by the United States and its allies at the recent unsuccessful session of the 17-nation Geneva disarmament talks. The Western proposal allowed for the formation of an allied multinuclear force that would have included West Germany and other nations that do not have nuclear weapons. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 25, 1965

headline: Pilgrim Recounts Stampede Near Mecca

headline: Applying for Financial Aid Is About to Get Easier
text: Choosing a college and applying for aid is complicated — so much so that many smart, low-income students don’t make it past the initial hurdles. But last week, the federal government streamlined and simplified the Fafsa (the Free Application for Federal Student Aid), which is the gatekeeper for all federal aid for college, including Pell grants and Stafford loans.

headline: Pope Francis Skirts Environmental Tussles in Address to Congress

He also proved that he is as adept at navigating political environments as he was impassioned about defending the global environment in his encyclical.

Rich with familiar voices, it further cements their reputation as eager and willing collaborators. Here, they reflect on what it was like to record with a few famous friends.

headline: A Gay Muslim Filmmaker Goes Inside the Hajj
text: Arranging to meet the filmmaker Parvez Sharma is a little like setting up an appointment with an extremely polite spy. He asks to rendezvous in a public place — a Starbucks in SoHo where the noise level is high, the tables distant and the volume of customers great. His boundaries are clearly drawn: no discussion of his husband, his friends, his Manhattan neighborhood or his family. He arrives a half-hour early.

headline: The Potential Criminal Consequences for Volkswagen

headline: Stephen Karam’s Plays Treat Anguish as a Laughing Matter
text: The playwright Stephen Karam has short dark hair, bright dark eyes and a wide smile that occasionally overpowers the rest of his face like some sudden, bloodless coup. On a recent morning at a cafe near his Chinatown apartment in New York, he was eating a red pepper and spinach omelet, a brave attempt to add more vegetables to his diet. At 35, he still looks boyish, and when he talks about being a grown-up, it takes a few seconds to realize that he is actually talking about himself.

headline: Daily Fantasy Sports and the Hidden Cost of America’s Weird Gambling Laws

headline: Sharing With Thy Restaurant Neighbor
text: At the end of lunch at a nice restaurant, one of the two friends I was dining with noticed that the couple at the next table was leaving behind three-quarters of a yummy-looking dessert. She asked them for it, and they gladly handed it over. I laughed. Our other friend told me later that she was appalled. She said it reflected poorly on us, and was angry that I had laughed. I told her if it had been a nice bottle of wine, I may have asked myself. What’s your opinion?

headline: Sviatoslav Richter, Enigmatic Pianist, Playing With Contradictions
text: After Stalin’s death in 1953, the Soviet Union lifted a bit of the Iron Curtain to allow some major midcareer Russian artists to make debuts in America. Among them were the violinist David Oistrakh and the pianist Emil Gilels, both in 1955. Notably missing was the towering pianist Sviatoslav Richter, an artist of, in the best sense, demonic powers, whose performances combined stunning technique, myriad colorings and fierce integrity. Every time Gilels was lavished with praise by musicians in America, he would offer thanks, then add, “Wait until you hear Richter!”

headline: A Cult Streetwear Brand Gets a Sleek Update
text: For most kids growing up in the 1980s and ’90s, Stüssy was a beloved skater brand — the epitome of California cool. “For our generation, Stüssy, together with other U.S. brands like Nike, Levi’s and Champion, was the uniform at a certain age,” says Hannes Hogeman, who, along with his brother Simon, runs Très Bien, a Swedish store that sells men’s high fashion and streetwear. This Friday, the retailer will launch the Stüssy Très Bien collection, a special collaboration that offers, in the words of Hannes, a more “minimalistic take on street- and sportswear.” There are boxy T-shirts, oversize shorts and a coach jacket with the towns “Laguna” and “Malmö” written on the back (the hometowns of Shawn Stüssy and the Hogeman brothers in California and Sweden, respectively). The collection feels like Stüssy at heart — it features skater-inspired styles with a tinge of Scandinavian refinement thrown in. “The designs came effortlessly, to be honest,” Hannes says. “It was more about removing details, changing the cuts and adding some fabrics that you may not usually get from Stüssy.”

headline: São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro Are Expected to Ban Uber

headline: Motherhood, Screened Off
text: My mother’s address book is one of the small visual details of my childhood that I can perfectly conjure, although I am sure no photograph of it exists. Fake-leather-bound, filled with her formal, spidery script, it was, to me, barely legible, with addresses crossed out and replaced with new ones as friends’ lives shifted. I often was dispatched to grab it for her from a kitchen drawer. I knew when she was looking for someone’s phone number, which seems unremarkable, except that my own children do not know when I am searching for a phone number, because all they see is me, on my iPhone, intently focused on something mysterious and decidedly not them.

text: Back in 1970, Los Angeles was known as the smog capital of the world — a notorious example of industrialization largely unfettered by regard for health or the environment. Heavy pollution drove up respiratory and heart problems and shortened lives.

headline: The Art Insider’s Guide to Stockholm
text: “Stockholm, and what is typically Swedish, is changing,” says Saskia Neuman, a native of the city that’s lately seemed to churn out even more cultural heavyweights than it does tall, beautiful people. Before her days as Absolut’s global art manager, Neuman lived in London, Venice and Berlin — adding to her résumé stints as Hans Ulrich Obrist’s Girl Friday and Daniel Birnbaum’s exhibition coordinator for his Venice Biennale run — only to return home, where she’s now responsible for scouting worthy talent for the vodka label’s own art award. (This year’s winners, Frances Stark for artwork and Mark Godfrey for art writing, were feted this week.)

headline: In a New Group Show, Artists Look to the Sky
text: Since space exploration has only existed for some 60 years, any artist working before 1950 would be unfamiliar with the visual vocabulary of rockets, shuttles and astronauts. So it follows that “Space Age,” the latest group show at Galerie Thaddaeus Ropac in Pantin, northeast of central Paris, is resolutely contemporary. The show’s 30 works, some newly commissioned, span five decades and offer a vast range of depictions, from a standing diptych by Robert Longo in which the Russian astronaut Valentina Tereshkova (the first woman in space) faces a starry abyss, to a duo of James Rosenquist canvases covered in galactic brightly colored geometries. The newer of his fractal works features a rotating mirror bordered with the words “an intrinsic existence”: selfie or self-reflection, take your pick. Whereas Not Vital’s stainless steel moon sucks viewers into its cratered, spherical surface, Lee Bull engulfs her suspended debris in fog.

headline: Review: Martha Armstrong’s Nature Scenes at Bowery Gallery
text: Painting from nature is nearly as old as the hills. For years, Alex Katz was the most prominent keeper of its flame, but other devotees have lately come into clearer view — Mr. Katz’s contemporary, the great Lois Dodd, for one. In addition, younger painters like Maureen Gallace and the even younger Daniel Heidkamp and Aliza Nisenbaum have wholeheartedly or partly followed suit. Painting from various forms of life has become a thing — as they say — in the hipper reaches of the contemporary art world.

headline: Review: In ‘Early Soviet Photography, Early Soviet Film,’ Artists Edit Reality to Fit an Ideal
text: Revolutions sell utopias; that’s their job. Art, if it behaves itself and sticks to the right script, can be an important part of the promotional package. This is the basic tale told by “The Power of Pictures: Early Soviet Photography, Early Soviet Film” at the Jewish Museum, but with a question added: What happens to art and its makers when the script is drastically revised?

headline: Arriving in Manhattan, Pope Tells Clergy to Serve Humbly
text: In his first visit to New York City, the center of global finance and capitalism, Pope Francis used his remarks on Thursday evening to encourage the hundreds of clergy members, brothers and nuns gathered in St. Patrick’s Cathedral to live humbly and resist the temptation to treat their ministries as businesses, with success measured strictly by the bottom line.

headline: In ‘99 Homes,’ a Man Buffeted and Then Manipulated in Florida’s Foreclosure Disaster
text: “Don’t get emotional about real estate.” That bit of wisdom — among the mantras shared by a predatory broker named Rick Carver — is both upheld and defied by “99 Homes,” Ramin Bahrani’s stunningly effective melodrama of flipped houses and mortgaged souls. While the film hardly endorses Rick’s coldblooded, dog-eat-dog view of the world, it is too cleareyed to oppose his ruthlessness with soft, easy appeals to sentiment. The foreclosed properties Rick acquires and resells may be repositories of hopes, dreams and family memories, but they’re also economic units, “boxes” to be emptied out, refilled and written down on a balance sheet. That’s a fact of life, and also a tragic contradiction.
