text: THE COURT AND THE WORLD: American Law and the New Global Realities, by Stephen Breyer. (Knopf, $27.95.) The Supreme Court justice argues that American judges must increasingly understand and engage with foreign and international law.

headline: A Francis Effect for a Broken System
text: The petty, the partisan, the hateful fell away — most of it. The bickering, the backbiting, the treachery was tamed — for now. No one shouted “You lie!” The powerful were made to look powerless. Words were used to uplift instead of to wound.

headline: Queer Tango Brings Its Liberated Style to New York
text: Tango has evolved: Men are dancing with men, women with women; women are leading and men are learning to follow.

headline: New Books Analyze the Photographs of Frederick Douglass and Sojourner Truth
text: Douglass and Truth, two of the most famous 19th-century African-Americans, commissioned formal works of themselves as part of their public relations strategies.

headline: Review: ‘Strangers Drowning’ Examines Extreme Do-Gooders
text: In the introduction to his book “Class: A Guide Through the American Status System” (1983), Paul Fussell noted that he’d had trouble telling others what he was working on. Social class is a touchy subject. At parties, people edged away from him.

headline: Review: In ‘Tape,’ Performers Move Fluidly and Whimsically About a Grid
text: In craft circles, duct tape — in an array of patterns and colors — is all the rage. Slap it on a Ziploc bag and you have a dazzling neon zebra pouch. In “Tape” by Kenneth Kvarnstrom, a Finnish choreographer based in Sweden, the dancers use duct tape to create a grid of lines and squares on the stage. Alas, it’s just boring black, but Mr. Kvarnstrom’s idea of tape extends beyond the sticky stuff in this production.

headline: Moschino Goes to the Carwash
text: The house introduced a kitschy, upbeat spring collection — filled with thick-cut fringe and reflective detailing.

headline: Review: Adrián Villar Rojas Explores Space in New Show
text: Adrián Villar Rojas excels at site-specific works that oscillate among historical, symbolic and spatial effects. One brought him wide attention when he represented Argentina at the 2011 Venice Biennale. Since then, he has become a staple at these large international exhibitions. Working mostly in situ in cast concrete with a team of assistants, he may have single-handedly made a complement of “festivalist art,” originally a pejorative coined for the grandiose installations of such shows.

headline: David Nelson Exhibition Illuminates Evolution of His Work
text: Biography isn’t necessarily destiny, but it seems to have played a role in the work of the wonderful artist David Nelson (1960-2013), as this show attests. He studied art in New York in the late 1970s and ’80s and began primarily as a painter. In 1990, he and his longtime partner, David Knudsvig, also an artist, tested positive for H.I.V. Mr. Knudsvig died of AIDS three years later, and Mr. Nelson’s art began to change, moving from painting to distinctive forms of sculpture and photography.

headline: Review: ‘Stonewall’ Doesn’t Distinguish Between Facts and Fiction
text: “Stonewall,” Roland Emmerich’s would-be epic film about a turning point in the gay liberation movement in 1969, is far from the first historical movie to choke on its own noble intentions. For its two-hour-plus duration, the movie struggles to fuse incompatible concepts.

headline: Review: Trisha Baga Mixes Orlando, Fla., With ‘Orlando’
text: In her second solo show at this gallery, Trisha Baga cultivates the ambitious sprawl of media and narratives prominent in her double New York debut here and at the Whitney Museum in 2012. Her previous efforts coalesced into disorienting surrounds of video projections on walls and nearby objects, whose patchwork of subjects included the popular artsplainer Sister Wendy and Plymouth Rock. Her latest works keep the media more distinct, though not the themes.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Stonewall’
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Stonewall.”

headline: Review: ‘The New Morality,’ a Vintage Play at the Mint
text: In the third act of Harold Chapin’s “The New Morality,” a prewar artifact excavated by the Mint Theater Company, our heroine, Betty, prepares a late summer cocktail called a hock cup: She mixes white wine with maraschino liqueur, Cointreau, brandy and a whisper of soda water, muddling the lot with strawberries and cucumber. It’s a wonder audiences don’t rush the stage for a glass.

headline: Richard Prince Takes a New Approach to Cowboys
text: Richard Prince is circling back to familiar ground, on two counts, with the latest iteration of his cowboy theme, going on view on Saturday at the West 21st Street Chelsea gallery of Barbara Gladstone, who represented him from 1987 to 2008, when he left for Gagosian Gallery. This appears to be a rapprochement.

headline: Best of France (Ooh-La-La!) and Brooklyn’s Atlantic Antic
text: France and Brooklyn, two capitals of culture revered for their gastronomy, ability to set trends and distinctive facial hair, will be on display this weekend at festivals around New York.

headline: Review: Met Opera’s ‘Turandot’ Reveals Layers of Humanity
text: For the first time since the 2012–13 season, Franco Zeffirelli’s production of “Turandot” has been buffed up and sent out to draw the crowds at the Metropolitan Opera. Crowned by a thoughtful assumption of the title role by the soprano Christine Goerke, it opened with a solid performance and to a satisfied reception on Wednesday evening.

headline: When Shakespeare Is the Subject, Not the Scribe
text: Shakespeare in love? How about Shakespeare in a jam?

headline: New York Film Festival Walks the Tightrope Between Art and Commerce
text: This year’s New York Film Festival opens with a couple of virtuosic balancing acts. One, “The Walk,” the latest from Robert Zemeckis, features Philippe Petit’s nosebleed stroll from one World Trade Center tower to its twin on Aug. 7, 1974. The other high-wire act is far less dangerous, but comes with its own hazards because it means pleasing constituencies as different as film society patrons and everyday cinephiles, critics who complain that it’s too elitist and those who sniff at the very idea of pleasurable, old-fashioned entertainment. It’s a tough trick, one the festival pulls off by putting a crowd-pleaser like Mr. Zemeckis alongside the rarefied likes of Chantal Akerman.

headline: Deutsche Bank Picks Goldman Executive as Bank and Insurance Adviser
text: Deutsche Bank said on Thursday that it had hired a senior banker from Goldman Sachs to serve as one of its top advisers for banks and insurance companies.

headline: Pope Francis Arrives in New York
text: Francis arrived at Kennedy International Airport, where he was greeted by Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan.

headline: Op-Photo: Making Way for Pope Francis
text: A truck filled with ballast blocked a street near St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York City on Thursday, in advance of Pope Francis’s visit.

headline: Jamie Barton, Opera’s Nose-Studded Rock Star, Returns to the Met
text: Traditionalists don’t have to worry: Jamie Barton, the galvanizing young mezzo-soprano, will take out her silver nose stud before she takes the Metropolitan Opera stage on Saturday in Donizetti’s “Anna Bolena.” After all, it doesn’t exactly match the sumptuous Tudor costume she wears as the disloyal Jane Seymour in David McVicar’s moody production.

headline: Review: ‘Quantico’ Flips Between Jousting F.B.I. Recruits and a Terrorist Attack
text: Successful producers shape the TV business through the shows that they make. Monumental producers shape the TV business even through the shows that they don’t.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Intern’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Intern.”

headline: José James Celebrates Billie Holiday at the Blue Note
text: When a youngish jazz singer pays homage to a major precursor, you can usually brace yourself for a particular sort of pageantry: a dutiful nod to the time period, a guided tour of the repertory and especially a demonstration of influence, which often boils down to mannerism. José James is finding intriguing ways to tweak this formula in his tribute to Billie Holiday, which runs at the Blue Note through Sunday.

headline: Postal Service Failed to Protect Personal Data in Mail Surveillance, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — Employees of the United States Postal Service failed to properly safeguard documents that included the names, addresses and financial information used by its law enforcement arm to monitor the mail of people suspected of criminal activities or for national security purposes, an internal investigation found.

headline: Movie Review: ‘99 Homes’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “99 Homes.”

headline: With Ultrasound as Backdrop, Carly Fiorina Presses Attack on Planned Parenthood
text: SPARTANBURG, S.C. — As the sound of a fetal heartbeat filled the ultrasound room at a Christian pregnancy center here, Carly Fiorina grasped the elbow of the young woman on the table.

headline: Robert Zemeckis, Master of Illusion, Returns
text: This fall is the season of Robert Zemeckis, the 63-year-old Chicago-born writer-director who began making movies in the 1970s and changed American history, at least metaphorically, with his two huge hits “Back to the Future” (1985) and “Forrest Gump” (1994).

headline: Review: Trinity Restaurant, Italian Fare With Family’s Touch
text: Some restaurants labor in the footsteps of legends. For decades, Timothy’s, just off the Trinity College campus in Hartford, served comfort food at bargain prices, winning a cadre of fiercely loyal customers. And while I still think of its successor, Trinity Restaurant, as a newcomer, it has been around for almost seven years now, offering the college and its mythical-sounding “Behind the Rocks” neighborhood a low-key, fine-dining option.

headline: For Nathaniel Dorsky and Jerome Hiler, Film Is the Star
text: Every so often while watching the work of Nathaniel Dorsky, I let out a yelp of joy. Mr. Dorsky makes blissfully beautiful films that don’t tell stories but instead explore the world, the medium and our relationship with each. They’re short, averaging around 20 minutes, and visually dense, with layers of pulsing color, churning film grain, shifting light and mutating form. Their actors, as it were, are the objects, the flowers, trees, animals, people and cars that slip in and out of the frame, although it is film – fragile, alchemical, magical, lush and luminous – that is the star. Like the gold and silver used in illuminated manuscripts, film creates a radiant glow that suggests why Mr. Dorsky calls his art devotional cinema.

headline: Restaurant Review: Artaux Fine Foods Mixes Elegant and Homey
text: Artaux Fine Foods in Sea Cliff offers creative and delicious food in two equally entertaining yet diverse settings.

headline: Volunteers, Many Once Refugees Themselves, Help as Guides in Vienna
text: VIENNA — At the migration center in the east wing of the main train station here, Ragad al-Rachid, a petite 19-year-old psychology student and a Syrian Muslim, is immersed in the logistical details of helping dozens of people a day adjust to new lives in her adopted country.

headline: Pope Francis Visits: Day 6
text: Pope Francis traveled from Washington to New York. Here’s a roundup of the highlights on the sixth day of his trip to the United States and Cuba.

headline: Jafar Panahi, Iranian Filmmaker, Persists Despite a Ban
text: PARIS — There’s a memorable scene in “Taxi,” the latest film by the Iranian dissident director Jafar Panahi, in which his vivacious, now 11-year-old niece recites the rules for making a movie in Iran. They include: Respect Islamic headscarves, avoid contact between men and women, avoid violence, avoid discussing political or economic issues, avoid “sordid realism.”

headline: Brian De Palma Explains Himself in ‘De Palma’
text: In the documentary “De Palma,” a special event of the New York Film Festival on Wednesday, Sept. 30, the 75-year-old director who is its subject gives a film-by-film account of a career that includes such box-office triumphs as “Carrie” and “The Untouchables,” as well as a disastrous screen adaptation of Tom Wolfe’s “The Bonfire of the Vanities.” The film, by Noah Baumbach and Jake Paltrow, covers Brian De Palma’s evolution from a high school science nerd to a Young Turk of Hollywood to a patriarch of sorts.

headline: Terror and Corruption Prosecutor Leaves for Private Sector
text: For much of his 11-year career as an assistant United States attorney in the Southern District of New York, Jason P.W. Halperin straddled two worlds: public corruption and terrorism. He took 13 cases to trial and never lost one.

headline: Bridge Turkish & Mediterranean Grill Offers Reasons to Take Your Time
text: The usual array of Middle Eastern kebabs and falafel was being offered at Bridge Turkish & Mediterranean Grill in Highland Park, N.J., but I was looking for the Turkish stuff.

headline: 12 Indicted in Georgia in Crime Rings Run With Cellphones From Prisons
text: ATLANTA — Twelve people were indicted this week on suspicion of having roles in crime rings that the authorities said relied on cellphones that were smuggled into Georgia prisons and allowed inmates to order killings, sell drugs to customers hundreds of miles away and try to steal identities.

headline: Central Park Fence for Pope Gets Strong Reactions
text: For days Upper West Siders saw signs of the impending visit to Central Park by the pope. There were the vendors hawking I ♥ Pope Francis T-shirts at Columbus Circle, a parking ban along the lower half of Central Park West, the removal of Citi Bike rentals. But nothing prepared them for the fence.

headline: President Xi’s Double Talk on Doing Business in China
text: At the start of his visit to the United States, President Xi Jinping of China sought to reassure American companies that his government was committed to protecting the interests of foreign companies and fighting cybercrime.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Saudi Arabia and Elsewhere
text: Pictures of the Day — Saudi Arabia and More

headline: Restaurant Review: Coming Home to Kelly’s Sea Level
text: Jerry McGuire, the co-owner of Kelly’s Sea Level in Rye, says that one of the reasons people enjoy the place so much is that it’s “homey.”

headline: September 24, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Saudi Arabia, Greece, India and the United States.

headline: For the Philharmonic’s Opening Night, a New Name and a Big Gift
text: The opening of the New York Philharmonic’s 174th season on Thursday felt like the start of a new chapter, as the orchestra played for the first time in the newly rechristened David Geffen Hall and announced that it was getting the largest individual donation in its history: a $25 million gift from Oscar S. Schafer, the chairman of its board, and his wife, Didi.

headline: Review: The Good Old Tasteless Days in ‘Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead’
text: “Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of The National Lampoon” looks longingly back at the 1970s when a smart, tasteless joke could make you laugh out loud without worrying about hurting someone’s feelings or being attacked on social media. Hedonism was in full sway and political correctness in its infancy.

headline: In the Bronx, Photographing a Church for the Poor
text: For Ángel Franco, photographing religious experience in New York allows him to set aside his own beliefs as he immerses himself in rituals and relationships that sustain communities of faith.

headline: Pope Francis’ Homily at St. Patrick’s Cathedral
text: Following is the English translation of Pope Francis’ homily during vespers at St. Patrick’s Cathedral on Wednesday evening. His speech, delivered in Spanish, was prepared for delivery and released by the Vatican:

headline: Review: ‘Mississippi Grind’ Keeps Its Cards Close
text: Even if you are not a sucker, as I am, for any movie about gambling with an American geographical reference in the title — “California Split,” “The Cincinnati Kid,” “Atlantic City” — you will find a lot to like about “Mississippi Grind,” a low-key road movie written and directed by Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck. Who can resist a soundtrack full of well-chosen blues and country-and-western songs, many of which offer further testimony to the place of cards, poker chips, dice and racehorses in our national mythology? There is also a cameo from James Toback, screenwriter of “The Gambler” (the good one, from 1974, with James Caan), and as such a kind of tutelary deity of long odds and risky bets.

headline: Review: ‘Finders Keepers’ Finds Humor and Humanity in the Bizarre
text: An amputated leg leads everyone in a merry dance in “Finders Keepers,” the kind of documentary that makes you suspect that Christopher Guest is hiding behind the curtain. But this shockingly funny, weirdly touching custody battle between John Wood, the aggrieved amputee, and Shannon Whisnant, the fast-talking entrepreneur who unwittingly bought the appendage in a storage-unit auction, is as authentic as the North Carolina vernacular in which it unfolds.

headline: Elizabeth M. Fink, a Lawyer for Attica Inmates and Radicals, Dies at 70
text: Elizabeth M. Fink, a fiery advocate for society’s outcasts who devoted much of her law career to vindicating and compensating inmate victims of the 1971 Attica prison uprising, died on Tuesday in Brooklyn. She was 70.

headline: Israel Acts to Combat Violence in Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s security cabinet approved a series of measures on Thursday as part of a crackdown on rock throwing and firebombing by Palestinians in Jerusalem, including minimum sentences and greater leeway for the police to open fire — steps that opponents say contravene basic legal principles and may only escalate the violence.

headline: Police Program Aims to Pinpoint Those Most Likely to Commit Crimes
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — At the request of his probation officer, Tyrone C. Brown came to a community auditorium here in June and sat alongside about 30 other mostly young black men with criminal records — men who were being watched closely by the police, just as he was.

headline: Review: ‘Mission to Lars’ Follows Siblings’ Quest to Fulfill Their Disabled Brother’s Dream
text: Documentaries about disabilities don’t come any smarter or more touching than “Mission to Lars,” a beautiful sibling road trip tale with a heavy-metal flourish.

headline: Saudis Seek to Fend Off U.N. Inquiry on Yemen
text: GENEVA — As Saudi Arabia and its Arab allies pressed their military offensive against Houthi rebels in Yemen, Saudi diplomats were waging their own battle to fend off calls in the United Nations Human Rights Council for an international inquiry into abuses by all parties to the Yemeni conflict.

headline: Review: ‘A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story,’ One Woman’s Push for Acceptance
text: The makers of “A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story” leave a few too many questions unanswered, but their subject’s immense optimism steamrolls through the documentary’s shortcomings. Indeed, there seems to be little this woman can’t vanquish.

headline: Review: ‘Western’ Chronicles Borderland Traditions, Both Charming and Violent
text: As TV and movies make abundantly clear, the western has evolved, the genre now updated as a setting for wars among murderous drug cartels and police agencies (the latest exhibit: “Sicario”).

headline: Aide Recants Ordering Attack on Texas Referee
text: A high school football assistant coach told his supervisors that he had ordered the attack on a Texas referee that has been seen by millions, but later recanted, saying that he had taken the blame to protect the players who delivered the blows, school officials said Thursday.

headline: A Confluence of Big Events for 3 Faiths
text: For Tony Carnes, editor and publisher of the web magazine A Journey Through NYC Religions, this week is like a “World Series,” he said. Or, offering another metaphor, he said, “It’s like the sun and the moon creating a high tide.”

headline: Iraq: Yazidis Turn to International Court
text: Members of Iraq’s Yazidi minority on Thursday urged the International Criminal Court to investigate accusations of atrocities committed by militants of the Islamic State, which they said constituted genocide against their people. Murad Ismael, a member of the delegation, said the Free Yezidi Foundation and the Yazda group handed court prosecutors a report with accounts of killings, abductions of women and children, sexual enslavement and the destruction of religious sites. Luis Moreno Ocampo, the court’s former chief prosecutor, served as the group’s “legal and strategic adviser,” Mr. Ismael said. Fatou Bensouda, the court’s current chief prosecutor, has condemned crimes by Islamic State militants in Syria and Iraq, but she has said that because those countries have not joined the court, it has no jurisdiction over matters that take place in Syria or Iraq. But Mr. Ismael said the involvement of Islamic State militants from countries that are court members, including Tunisia, Georgia and Australia, in such critical roles as training, fund-raising or organizing crimes against Yazidi women and girls might allow the court to proceed with an investigation.

headline: Review: ‘Wildlike’ Pits a Teenage Girl Against the Alaskan Wilderness
text: In “Wildlike,” Mackenzie (Ella Purnell), a 14-year-old from Seattle whose father has died and whose mother is in rehab, is sent to live with her uncle in Alaska for the summer. But when the creep starts molesting her, she runs away, alone and desperate in strange if beautiful country. Scrambling to stay ahead of her uncle, Mackenzie eventually attaches to Bartlett (Bruce Greenwood), a middle-aged backpacker headed to Denali National Park, in the unspoken hope that he’ll help her get home.

headline: Antiquities Still at Risk, Experts Warn
text: The pillaging of antiquities by Islamic State militants is thriving in Syria and Iraq despite efforts to counter it, Middle East officials and archaeological experts  said Thursday at a conference on the illicit trafficking of artifacts. Irina Bokova, the director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, said all six Unesco World Heritage sites in Syria had been damaged in that country’s war, including the most recent destruction in the ancient city of Palmyra. “Culture has always been a victim of war, but what we’re seeing today is new,” Ms. Bokova said at the Asia Society in New York.

headline: Review: In ‘The Green Inferno,’ Eli Roth Turns Collegians Into Prey
text: It’s a homage written in blood. It’s an excursion into the forbidden land of unpalatable ideas, with the severed limbs and disemboweled bodies of idealistic young college students serving as signposts.

headline: Review: ‘Lost in Hong Kong’ Is Part Music Video, Part Buddy Film
text: “Lost in Hong Kong” is a very, very, very, long-feeling movie with identity problems: At times it seems like an extended, sappy pop-music video; at others, a buddy film, with no love lost between the buddies. An unresolved love lies at the center, and a tacked-on homicide unreels into an irrelevant side plot. Perhaps because it tries too hard to be too many things, the movie loses its punch.

headline: Alabama Vote Is Rare Win in the South for the U.A.W.
text: When the results of a vote to join the United Automobile Workers union was announced late Wednesday at the Commercial Vehicle Group (C.V.G.) in Piedmont, Ala., the “hollering and whooping” echoed throughout the plant, said Alan Amos, a welder there.

headline: Review: In ‘Misunderstood,’ a Girl Seeks Relief From a Turbulent Household
text: “Misunderstood,” a buoyantly funny, sometimes desperately sad film about a child searching for love and home, could easily be titled “The Girl, Her Bag and Her Beautiful Cat.” These three are the film’s holy trinity and its defining image, one that is almost Chaplinesque in its graphic clarity and emotional punch. The director, Asia Argento, has a finely tuned sense of the absurd, but isn’t afraid of tears. This may be because she once shared the name of the 9-year-old girl, Aria, who observes this turbulent world as if it were a drama she might one day stage.

headline: Sharp Drop in Currency Adds to Growing List of Woes in Brazil
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Since it was created in 1994, the Brazilian currency, the real, has been synonymous with the country’s return to financial stability and its subsequent ascent as an economic power.

headline: Pomp and Prayers in New York
text: After arriving from Washington in the middle of his six-day trip to the United States, Pope Francis attended a prayer service at St. Patrick’s Cathedral.

headline: Bernie Sanders Eclipses Hillary Clinton in New Hampshire Poll
text: As summer turned to fall, a chilly wind was blowing in New Hampshire for Hillary Rodham Clinton: A new poll on Thursday showed Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont surging ahead of Mrs. Clinton with 46 percent of the vote to 30 percent for her.

headline: Port Authority Remains Divided on Plan to Replace Manhattan Bus Terminal
text: Two years after starting to plan for the replacement of the main bus terminal in Manhattan, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey still does not have a plan, its appointed leaders admitted on Thursday.

headline: In Lunch for the Homeless, a Sacred Mission for Pope Francis
text: WASHINGTON — The residents of the Harriet Tubman Women’s Shelter rose at 3 a.m. on Thursday to give everyone time to shower, fix their hair and get dressed in the best clothes they had after years on and off the streets, coping with evictions, abuse and jobs that disappeared.

headline: Tensions Build as M.T.A. Chief Keeps Pressing New York City for More Money
text: A year after the Metropolitan Transportation Authority unveiled a capital plan to address the system’s deteriorating infrastructure and increasing ridership, the chairman of the agency has grown increasingly combative toward New York City, faulting the mayor for not assuming more of the $29 billion proposal’s costs.

headline: Review: At Hartford Stage, Expectations of Love and the Weight of Memory in ‘An Opening in Time’
text: HARTFORD — Though fall has only just begun according to the calendar, it is nearing its end at Hartford Stage, and winter is coming on fast. The mortal chill of waning days and lengthening nights pervades “An Opening in Time,” the anxiously wistful new play by Christopher Shinn that runs here through Oct. 11.

headline: Darrelle Revis and Two Other Top Jets May Miss Game Against Eagles
text: The Jets could be without some prominent players Sunday when they try to defeat the Philadelphia Eagles for the first time in franchise history.

headline: Review: In ‘Sleepless in New York,’ the Misery of the Lovelorn
text: Cinema may be fluent in the language of romance, but breakups are another, excruciating story, and Christian Frei is happy to chronicle them in “Sleepless in New York.” Following three lovelorn city dwellers over an extended period, Mr. Frei’s raw documentary plumbs the soul-searching, pain and dark, obsessive thoughts that afflict these victims of lost love.

headline: Review: In ‘Hotel Transylvania 2,’ Dracula Yearns for a Little Monster of a Grandson
text: In the 2012 animated picture “Hotel Transylvania,” the comedy stalwart Adam Sandler voiced a Dracula who juggled concerns over his troubled spooky-lodging business with concerns over losing his vampire daughter, Mavis, to the outside world. Mr. Sandler’s cronies and frequent co-stars in live-action movies voiced Dracula’s classic-monster cohort. As a homage to beloved old-movie myths, it fell into the “each man kills the thing he loves” category of tribute, setting a level of sacrilege so high that its sequel, “Hotel Transylvania 2,” directed by the returning Genndy Tartakovsky, is more tolerable simply by dint of inoculation.

headline: Robert Streb, Tortoise Among Hares, Stands Out as PGA Tour Finale Begins
text: ATLANTA — Two players from a youth traveling hockey team in Oklahoma in the late 1990s grew up to be professional athletes. Even more mind-boggling, the first one to grace the playoffs in his sport was not Sam Bradford, the Philadelphia Eagles quarterback drafted by the St. Louis Rams with the No. 1 pick in 2010.

headline: Review: In ‘The Keeping Room,’ 3 Women Under Siege in the Civil War
text: The ravages of the Civil War shouldn’t require much jazzing up for the movies, but the British director Daniel Barber labors to impress with his Southern period thriller “The Keeping Room.”

headline: Daniel Levins, Dancer in Classical Ballet and Films, Dies at 61
text: Daniel Levins, a dancer sometimes known professionally as Daniel Levans, who gained notice as a teenager in Eliot Feld’s acclaimed American Ballet Company and as a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater in the 1970s, died on Sept. 15 in Brooklyn. He was 61.

headline: Document Signed by Hillary Clinton in 2012 Regarding Huma Abedin’s New Job
text: The document, part of a process by which Huma Abedin, an aide to Hillary Rodham Clinton, became a special government employee at the State Department, describes Ms. Abedin’s new title as “senior advisor.”

headline: Where Hercules Slew the Lion
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I was of two minds about this puzzle.

headline: Hillary Clinton Personally Signed Off on Job Change for Huma Abedin
text: Update: According to a document obtained by The New York Times, the certification of a new employment position for one of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s senior aides at the State Department was signed by Mrs. Clinton’s then chief of staff, Cheryl D. Mills, who was authorized to sign such documents for Mrs. Clinton.

headline: Review: In ‘Pay the Ghost,’ Nicolas Cage Is on a Mission
text: Good actors making poor choices — especially when the actor is Nicolas Cage — is nothing new, but I worry that the dross in his career ledger is rapidly outpacing the gold. A compellingly idiosyncratic performer, he has languished too long in movies unworthy of his commitment and with no room for the seat-of-the-pants improvisations that make him so riveting.

headline: Review: ‘Becoming Bulletproof’ Follows a Group of Disabled Adults in a Film Within a Film
text: The film inside the film seems a bit slapdash. But that’s the only false note in “Becoming Bulletproof,” a wonderful documentary that follows a group of disabled adults who work together to make a movie.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Sept. 25
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include Pope Francis, the New York Military Academy and filming of “Gotham” in the Bronx.

headline: Review: ‘Ashby’ Pairs a Retired C.I.A. Killer With a High School Nerd
text: Mickey Rourke, who plays the title character in “Ashby,” is a bizarre sight in this overstuffed semicomedy, which has no idea what it wants to say. In his towering gray pompadour, Ashby suggests a vain, surgically altered Mafioso relocated to Virginia through the witness protection program. In fact, Ashby is something even more exotic: a retired C.I.A. assassin who by his own account killed 93 people in the line of duty. Is he a heroic patriot or a sociopath? The movie doesn’t dare ask, but Mr. Rourke’s gruff, sentimental performance suggests a little of both, tilting toward patriot.

headline: An Email on Libya Sent to Hillary Clinton
text: This April 2011 email is among those that are being reviewed by F.B.I investigators to determine if aides of Hillary Rodham Clinton mishandled sensitive national security information when communicating with her via email while she was secretary of state.

headline: Hillary Clinton Email Inquiry Weighs if Aides Erred at ‘Send’
text: WASHINGTON — The email described a deteriorating situation in Libya, with snipers shooting people in the streets as rebels tried to unseat President Muammar el-Qaddafi and worried American diplomats in the midst of a “phased checkout” from Benghazi. It arrived in the private email account of Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, one Sunday morning in April 2011, with unforeseen consequences.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
text: Museum of the Moving Image Fall Family Day

headline: Spare Times for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
text: Museums and Sites

headline: Pope Visits St. Patrick’s Cathedral
text: Pope Francis attends an evening prayer service at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York after a short procession down Fifth Avenue.

headline: Jazz Listings for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.★ Barry Altschul and the 3dom Factor (Saturday) Mr. Altschul, a drummer of deep experience in the post-1960s avant-garde, has a new album, “Tales of the Unforeseen,” with the excellent trio he calls 3dom Factor. Featuring the saxophonist Jon Irabagon and the bassist Joe Fonda, it’s a tough, elastic band that moves in and out of phase. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, Greenwich Village; 212-989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com. (Nate Chinen)

headline: What’s on Television Friday
text: 3 P.M. (FXX) FLIGHT (2012) It’s hard to take your eyes off Denzel Washington as Whip Whitaker, a crack airline pilot who manages to land a plane — at one point flying it upside down — after catastrophe strikes during a storm in this thriller from Robert Zemeckis. But Whip’s life takes a nose dive when an inquiry reveals his lust for drinking and drugs, and suggests that he may not have been sober during his heroic feat. “He’s high as a kite, and you may be, too, lifted by the contact high that great filmmaking gives you,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. She added: “It’s no surprise that ‘Flight’ has salvation in mind. The shock is how deep Mr. Zemeckis and Mr. Washington journey into the abyss and how long they stay there. It can be tough for stars to play such unrepentantly compromised characters, as Mr. Washington does brilliantly here.”

headline: Owing to the Greeks
text: It is rare that a contemporary political state of affairs perfectly corresponds with a classical literary one — when the contours of the two align so entirely that not only does the latter help explain the former, but the new situation, with all its messy contingencies, seems to follow the carefully wrought logic of its aesthetic predecessor with such precision as to appear like a manifestation, or symptom, of it. Yet this is the case (I would argue) with the economic imbroglio between Germany and Greece.

headline: Inside the List
text: His and Hers, Part I: You could think of Lauren Groff’s third novel, “Fates and ­Furies” — new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 7 — as a sort of “Gone Girl” minus the murderous psychopathology. Both tell the story of a marriage first from the husband’s somewhat complacent perspective, then change course midway to reveal a wife far more active and vengeful than expected. But “Fates and Furies” is also, as the title suggests, a meditation on classical ideas of destiny and human agency, with the golden boy Lotto (short for Lancelot) representing submission to the Fates while his wife, Mathilde, rides with the Furies and shapes reality to her liking. I asked Groff which view she endorses, if either. “I wobble between action and somewhat optimistic fatalism,” she replied by email. “In the middle of the night, I side more with Ma­thilde’s pragmatic anxiety; during the slow, hot Florida daylight hours, I’m a little sunnier, a little more like Lotto. I thought, going into the book, that I was 89 percent Lotto, and this book is in some ways an elaborate apologia to my husband for often being wrapped up in my writing to the exclusion of actual life. But Mathilde is a terrifying sister of my heart, and I find myself in her in equal measure. It’s not exactly Flaubert’s ‘Madame Bovary, c’est moi.’ In truth both Lotto and Mathilde, c’est moi. I am both of them and neither of them in equal measure, and their lives and ambivalence and desires have elements of mine, all snarled up in this one big wild knot.”

headline: ‘The Invention of Nature,’ by Andrea Wulf
text: Alexander von Humboldt was the pre-eminent scientist of his time. Contemporaries spoke of him as second in fame only to Napoleon. All over the Americas and the English-speaking world, towns and rivers are still named after him, along with mountain ranges, bays, waterfalls, 300 plants and more than 100 animals. There is a Humboldt glacier, a Humboldt asteroid, a Humboldt hog-nosed skunk. Off the coast of Peru and Chile, the giant Humboldt squid swims in the Humboldt Current, and even on the moon there is an area called Mare Humboldtianum. Darwin called him the “greatest scientific traveler who ever lived.”

headline: The Contenders

headline: ‘This Is Your Life, Harriet Chance!’ by Jonathan Evison
text: It’s been more than 50 years since “This Is Your Life,” the early reality show after which Jonathan Evison’s new novel is named, aired the final episode of its initial television run. The concept of the program might seem quaint to the generation that grew up on the Internet — the host, Ralph Edwards, would surprise his guests (some celebrities, some not) with a retrospective of their lives, accompanied by special appearances from friends and family members out of their pasts.

headline: John Banville’s ‘The Blue Guitar’
text: Here is “rufous-headed, roly-poly” Oliver Orme, “the hypochondriacs’ hypochondriac,” a man with “no fortitude, no sticking power; no grit,” but inexplicable charisma. “I’m pushing 50,” John ­Banville’s latest narrator announces, “and feel a hundred.” His heart is still beating, though: “A thief’s heart is an impetuous organ,” and Orme is compulsive. He’s been stealing since he pocketed a tube of zinc white paint as a child. Even though he is married to the youthful Gloria, he cannot keep his hands off the wife of his friend Marcus, the local watch repairman. “I pinched Polly,” he boasts. “Polly I ­purloined.”

headline: David Maraniss’s ‘Once in a Great City: A Detroit Story’
text: David Maraniss’s “Once in a Great City” concerns Detroit in 1963 — a crucial year, this book asserts, in the city’s history, marking the end of its boom times and the beginning of its end times. Though my Detroit birth and upbringing were still a decade off, 1963 was a big year for me, too. My dad graduated from high school in the city that spring, and my mom would begin her senior year that fall. For their first date, they went to see “It’s a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World.” The ingredients for the city’s apocalypse would seem to have come together along with those of my ­existence.

headline: In Milan, a Designer Aims for ‘The Edge of Good Taste’
text: “This place is very Milan,” said the designer Arthur Arbesser as he slid into a wooden chair at Bottiglieria Bulloni, a wine shop and bar established in 1933. It’s a place so truly Milanese that it closes immediately after aperitivo at 9 p.m. Arbesser — the newly appointed creative director of Iceberg — was taking a break from preparing for his first collection for the house, which debuts today. It will be followed by the first runway presentation of his namesake line a few days later. Having already skipped lunch, it seemed that a glass of Franciacorta (Italian sparkling wine that has been called the official drink of Milan Fashion Week) and aperitivo snacks would constitute his dinner before returning to the studio.

headline: Me and My Jetta: How VW Broke My Heart

The engine was softly idling, and as I reached to shut it off, he told me not to bother. The minimal amount of fuel this car burned — sipped, in the automotive argot — was its great selling point. That, and the almost complete removal of hazardous exhaust that had made earlier diesel vehicles notorious.

headline: Eighty Years of Penguin Books
text: Before Allen Lane began his publishing house in 1935, good books were the purview of the privileged, costing more than many Londoners spent on a week’s rent. But that all changed when Lane, then managing director of the Bodley Head, bought the rights to 10 already popular hardcovers (including Ernest Hemingway’s “A Farewell to Arms” and Agatha Christie’s “The Mysterious Affair at Styles”), redesigning each with a uniform set of specs so simple that even small, inexperienced print shops could mass-produce them on the cheap. The color-coded, pocket-size paperbacks — numbered in the order of their release — were a hit, and Lane’s house, Penguin, eventually became a favorite of collectors eager to snap up everything from coffee mugs to deck chairs bearing its logo. Eighty years on, a cover-to-cover look at the iconic publisher’s ongoing legacy.

The women wore black-and-white-striped prison uniforms — the kind of throwbacks tourists don for photographs near Alcatraz — with the words “Sheriff’s Inmate” on their backs. Arpaio wore a black suit, black shoes and a white shirt. He looked as if he had raided Johnny Cash’s closet.

headline: All in the Family
text: BECAUSE THIS IS an especially large edition of T, requiring fairly heroic effort on the part of the staff, I’d like to share a bit of the behind-the-scenes action here at The New York Times. The size of any magazine is generally a function of how many advertisers have bought space in it: the more ad pages, the more editorial stories. A couple of weeks before this issue was due to head off to the printer, ad-sales figures spiked 75 percent above what was expected — a fantastic boon in the beleaguered world of print journalism. Of course, we were excited by the news, but whereas we normally have several months to conceive, plan and execute ideas, we now had two weeks to make 40 additional pages.

headline: Citi Bike App Gets an Upgrade
text: When I last looked at the Citi Bike app, in June 2013, New York’s bike-sharing program had just started. The app was rudimentary, consisting almost entirely of data about nearby docking stations and the availability of bicycles, information that was sometimes inaccurate. It was fitting for a program that quickly became notorious for faulty software and subpar customer service.

headline: Preparing Pinstripes for New Players
text: Q. The Yankees often notify their principal farm team that a player must report to Yankee Stadium “tonight or tomorrow” for possible duty in the next game. How does the club outfit a player with a properly fitting uniform with his number on it so quickly?

headline: Breakdown of U.N. Sustainable Development Goals
text: The Sustainable Development Goals adopted by the United Nations at a summit meeting in New York on Friday lay out a sweeping vision for improving the lives of people all over the world over the next 15 years.

headline: U.N. Adopts Ambitious Global Goals After Years of Negotiations
text: UNITED NATIONS — The last time Amina J. Mohammed went home to see her extended family in northern Nigeria, her cousins asked her to skip her usual gifts of clothes and sweets and bring them something that they really needed: body scanners for the gates of the local mosque, to guard against suicide bombers sent by Boko Haram.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: New Drugs Prove More Effective in Treatment of Kidney Cancer, Studies Find
text: New studies of two drugs, showing that each works better than the standard treatment for advanced kidney cancer, should lead to changes in patient care, researchers said on Friday.

headline: No End in Sight to Tide of Migrants Entering Europe, U.N. Says
text: LONDON — The flood of Syrian refugees pouring into the heart of Europe is unlikely to ease anytime soon, and worsening conditions in Iraq could send new waves of displaced people onto the Continent, United Nations officials warned on Friday.

headline: Major Changes Under Rhode Island Pension Overhaul
text: As states and municipalities struggle with rising pension costs, the governor, legislature and labor organizations in Rhode Island were able to agree on reductions to pension obligations and avoid tax increases or other financial burdens. Here are some of the most significant changes.

headline: Rhode Island Averts Pension Disaster Without Raising Taxes
text: Chicago is facing its biggest tax increase in memory, to raise money for pension payments. Illinois is stymied by a $110 billion pension shortfall. In New Jersey, public workers are in court over a failed pension deal. From Pennsylvania to California, pensions costs are crowding out aid for public education.

headline: Ruffles, Lace and Crochet at Philosophy
text: For spring/summer 2016, Lorenzo Seraphini opted for a dreamy collection of flowing silhouettes.

headline: Review: ‘Zero One’ Plays With Difference at Danspace
text: Yasuko Yokoshi’s “Zero One” is a dance of twos: two alternating worlds, on screen and onstage; two performers at the center of each; two dance cultures mingling. This haunting new work, which opened Danspace Project’s fall season on Thursday at St. Mark’s Church, layers a live duet by the identical twins Manami and Sawami Fukuoka with excerpts from Ms. Yokoshi’s film “Hangman Takuzo,” named for a 67-year-old Japanese performance artist who hangs himself — safely — each day in his garden.

headline: For ‘Dr. Ken,’ a Comic Returns to Medicine
text: Apparently the way to get a TV show these days is to be a stand-up comic and pitch a series about your life before you started telling jokes for a living. In recent weeks, NBC offered both “Mr. Robinson,” featuring Craig Robinson, and “The Carmichael Show,” with Jerrod Carmichael, and on Friday, Oct. 2, ABC unveils “Dr. Ken,” starring Ken Jeong, who was a doctor before he became a comic.

headline: Review: In ‘Indian Summers,’ British Expatriates Misbehave
text: With the end of “Downton Abbey” in sight — only nine more episodes, already being shown in Britain! — the search for a reasonable substitute takes on new urgency. PBS makes a major play to keep the “Downton” audience with the premiere of “Indian Summers” on Sunday night on “Masterpiece.” It’s a different animal — leaning more toward sex-charged melodrama than genteel parlor comedy — but if you have a taste for good-looking British people misbehaving in beautiful surroundings, it may do just fine.

headline: Review: ABC’s ‘Blood & Oil,’ Washing Away the Past
text: Petroleum, land, money, bravado, ego and intrafamily tensions, but about 1,200 miles north of Dallas. It’s the new ABC drama “Blood & Oil,” which gets off to a tolerable start on Sunday, though, of course, drawing attention on television’s most jam-packed night is always tough.

headline: Review: ‘Disclosures,’ Bruno Isakovic’s Show and Tell
text: For about an hour on Wednesday night, six performers undressed and confessed in the Underground Theater at Abrons Arts Center. They talked about their relationships to their bodies, revealing everything from circumcisions and mastectomies to sexual fantasies and ruminations on gender. By the end, we knew all about them, their genitals and their lives, in selective but intimate detail.

headline: How Lee Child, Author of the Jack Reacher Novels, Spends His Sundays
text: Lee Child, the author of the Jack Reacher crime novels, starts a new book each September and finishes sometime in spring, 20 books in 20 years. The most recent, “Make Me,” just took over the No. 1 spot on the New York Times best-seller list. He spends Sundays the way many writers do, in his own bubble. “It’s hard for others to understand, because you’re living in this made-up zone of fantasy, where that seems real to you, and the real real stuff seems odd,” he said. Mr. Child, 60, whose real name is Jim Grant, lives on the Upper West Side with his wife, Jane Grant.

headline: ‘Up and Away,’ for Young Audiences Who Don’t Want Surprises
text: You arrive and are assigned your own cast member, who will escort you to the performance space — where five colorful life-size replicas of hot-air balloons fill the room — and sit right next to you throughout the show. Your personal attaché will even walk you to the elevator and wave goodbye at the end.

headline: At Ali Baba’s Terrace, Frequent Fliers With Gridlock in Mind
text: Midtown East is already a busy part of town, but on Tuesday, the neighborhood was especially abuzz. It was the first day of the United Nations General Assembly session, and representatives from around the world had descended on the area in droves. Traffic was at a standstill, helicopters hovered overhead and talk of Pope Francis’ arrival in two days was everywhere, including at Ali Baba’s Terrace, a Turkish restaurant just down the street from the United Nations headquarters.

headline: Pope Francis’ Homily During Mass at Madison Square Garden
text: Following is the English translation of Pope Francis’ homily during Mass at Madison Square Garden on Friday evening. His homily, delivered in Spanish, was prepared for delivery and released by the Vatican:

headline: OxyContin and Children: The F.D.A. Responds
text: To the Editor:

headline: Drug Companies Hire New Lobbyist to Answer Critics
text: WASHINGTON — The drug industry chose a new top lobbyist Friday to help pharmaceutical companies defend themselves against criticism from patients, doctors and government officials who say they are charging exorbitant prices for many medicines.

headline: Walker Campaign Money
text: To the Editor:

headline: Homeless and Mentally Ill
text: To the Editor:

headline: Aspirational Couture
text: Maison Kitsuné, in the NoMad section of Manhattan, steeps itself in preppy fashions with French and Japanese influences.

headline: Browsing to the Beat at Maison Kitsuné
text: Maison Kitsuné does not merely hang its clothes on pedestrian racks. Rather, its latest collection is carefully arranged on sparely populated rails. The boutique (1170 Broadway, at 28th Street) is an oasis of moneyed calm in a bustling and quickly gentrifying neighborhood, and its offerings manage to be eclectic, youthful and sporty, while at the same time intimidatingly priced pieces of high fashion.

headline: Ukraine to Ban Flights by Major Russian Airlines
text: Ukraine will ban major Russian airlines including Aeroflot, the Russian national airline, from flying to its airports starting next month as part of a broad set of trade sanctions imposed on Russia for supporting a separatist revolt in Ukraine.

headline: Kim Davis Joining G.O.P.
text: Kim Davis, the county clerk in Kentucky who was jailed for refusing to issue marriage licenses to gay couples, said on Friday that she and her family have switched to the Republican Party.

headline: A Day for an Ecology-Minded Pope and Sustainable Development Goals
text: So a few things happened today, not including House Speaker John Boehner announcing he was stepping down and Volkswagen and the Environmental Protection Agency trying to bolster pollution controls.

headline: Sweet Smell of Not Today: Press Agents Wait Out ‘This Pope Thing’
text: Pope Francis has brought joy to thousands of New Yorkers with his easy grace and common touch.

headline: Football, Cheerleading and Hometown Glory
text: After seeing the film “Bring It On,” the photographer Brian Finke began a project on cheerleading and football, two historically related, but increasingly independent, competitive sports.

headline: Wolfgang Tillmans Takes Pictures of Modern Life, Backlit by the Past
text: The photographer Wolfgang Tillmans is a material guy. He has always embraced the physicality of photos. As a boy in Remscheid, a small city in western Germany, he photocopied printed images and bought his first camera so he could obtain more material for the copy machine. Achieving prominence in the early 1990s, when his pictures of Hamburg night life were published in i-D, a British periodical known for its cutting-edge design, he prized his work not as it existed in its original form but as it appeared laid out in the magazine.

headline: Prosecutors Struggling to Keep Up With Cases of Violence From Rikers
text: Already struggling to contain surging violence at Rikers Island, New York City officials are now facing further hurdles as they try to prosecute the inmates they say are responsible for it.

headline: Kevin McCarthy Expected to Seek Speaker John Boehner’s Post in House
text: WASHINGTON — When John A. Boehner announced his retirement on Friday, speculation about who would succeed him as speaker immediately centered on the No. 2 House Republican: Kevin McCarthy, a 50-year-old Californian who has had a rapid rise through the party ranks.

headline: Patricia Hoffbauer Takes Dance in a Wry, Irreverent Direction
text: Dancing about making dances is nothing new, but Patricia Hoffbauer’s approach may be singular. In “Dances for Intimate Spaces and Friendly People,” 14 dancers from many backgrounds and generations take over the studios at Gibney Dance’s Lower Manhattan outpost, including the postmodern luminaries Yvonne Rainer and Sara Rudner. Isolated duets, trios and quartets, converging at the end, carry the audience from space to space, while a video exhibition in the lobby documents the process of the work’s creation.

headline: Stromae, a European Star With French Songs, Aims for U.S. Acclaim
text: Can a European superstar conquer Madison Square Garden?

headline: Truce Struck in 2 Areas of Syria
text: ISTANBUL — In one of the most ambitious deals yet struck between combatants in the multisided war in Syria, supporters and opponents of President Bashar al-Assad will essentially trade territory in two different parts of the country, stop bombing and besieging one another’s civilians and pledge to observe a six-month cease-fire.

headline: Harlem Kids Thrilled After Meeting Pope
text: New York City students said that meeting the pope on Friday was a life-changing experience.

headline: National Sawdust, a New-Music Space, Opens in Brooklyn
text: An experimental venture could bring a jolt to the new-music scene in New York: the opening of National Sawdust, a nonprofit performance space and recording facility in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The building’s intimate, adaptable main hall has been built from the shell of an old sawdust factory. The goal is to foster the creation of original works. It opens on Thursday, Oct. 1, with a program titled “Discover the Space” Vol. 1 and Vol. 2, (nationalsawdust.org).

headline: Francisco Oller Exhibition Explores Impressionism and the Caribbean
text: In the 19th century, Modernism traveled the world, and one of the places it flourished was in Puerto Rico, where the painter Francisco Oller was born in 1833. He had his initial art training in San Juan, then went abroad for further study in Spain and France. In Paris, he fell in with avant-garde artists who favored Courbet-inspired realism and a brand-new style, Impressionism. He painted side by side with Claude Monet and introduced Camille Pissarro, another Caribbean native, to Paul Cézanne. Unlike Pissarro, though, Oller didn’t stay in Europe. He returned to Puerto Rico, then still a Spanish colony, and made life there the theme of his art in landscape paintings of sugar plantations and still-lifes of tropical fruit.

headline: Costa Rica to Shield Sea Turtles
text: Two weeks after an onslaught of tourists disrupted thousands of olive ridley sea turtles nesting on a Costa Rican beach, the turtles have arrived again to lay their eggs. Absent this time were the selfie-taking tourists who had wandered among them, causing international outrage on social media and leading to stricter security measures.

headline: Pope Francis Visits: Day 7
text: The pope toured Manhattan beginning with an address at the the United Nations General Assembly and ending with an evening mass at Madison Square Garden.

headline: A Solution for Puerto Rico
text: To the Editor:

headline: Immigration Advocates in Philadelphia See Affirmation in Pope’s Visit
text: PHILADELPHIA — Immigration weighs heavily on the parishioners of Old St. Joseph’s Church, a centuries-old Jesuit parish that spread Catholicism through colonial America and now flies a “Welcome Pope Francis” banner over its gate.

headline: Refugee Crisis in Syria Raises Fears in South Carolina
text: DUNCAN, S.C. — The worried citizens gathered in the high school cafeteria, about 200 strong. Patriotic songs played on the stereo, a man in a blue blazer from the John Birch Society hovered by a well-stocked literature table, and Lauren L. Martel, a lawyer from Hilton Head, told the crowd that 25 Syrian refugees were already living among them.

headline: Governor Cuomo and Raúl Castro of Cuba Meet
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, seeking to expand the state’s relationship with Cuba, met on Friday with its president, Raúl Castro, for the first time, the governor’s office said.

headline: In a Void Created by Religious Violence, Pope Francis Shares Prayers for Peace
text: Pope Francis stood flanked by an imam in a skullcap and a rabbi in a prayer shawl on what amounts to hallowed ground: an underground chamber where the victims of the attacks on the World Trade Center are memorialized.

headline: California Board Backs New Limits on Carbon From Gas and Diesel
text: LOS ANGELES — California air regulators on Friday approved a substantial cut to carbon pollution from gasoline and diesel fuels, a move that will force oil producers to reduce the amount of carbon generated by all transportation fuels in the state at least 10 percent by 2020.

headline: Evening Hours | Celebrating Music at Lincoln Center
text: The New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera has season-opening parties.

headline: Nigeria: Polio Contained, W.H.O. Says
text: Polio is no longer endemic in Nigeria, which means that it has conquered the disease, the World Health Organization declared Friday. Polio remains endemic in just two countries, Pakistan and Afghanistan, which have never eliminated the virus. As of last month, all of Africa had gone a full year without a case of polio paralysis. The last case anywhere in Africa was detected in Somalia on Aug. 11, 2014; it was caused by a strain of the virus that had originated in Nigeria. The last case in Nigeria was recorded on July 24, 2014. Despite Friday’s announcement, Nigeria cannot be declared “polio free” until two more years have passed with no paralysis cases and no virus detected in sewage. As recently as 2012, Nigeria accounted for more than half of all the world’s polio cases.

headline: String of Emails Raises Questions About When Hillary Clinton Began Using Personal Account
text: WASHINGTON — A string of emails that has been provided to the State Department raises new questions about whether Hillary Rodham Clinton has accurately described her use of a personal account when she was secretary of state.

headline: John McNeill, Priest Who Pushed Catholic Church to Welcome Gays, Dies at 90
text: The Rev. John McNeill, an openly gay Roman Catholic priest who, from the 1970s onward, publicly pressed the church to welcome gay men and lesbians — and who was expelled from his order as a result — died on Tuesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 90.

headline: No. 1 Ranking Remains a Slippery Spot for Day, Spieth and McIlroy
text: ATLANTA — Jason Day followed Rory McIlroy to the interview room Wednesday at the Tour Championship and, after taking his seat, smiled and slyly observed, “Rory warmed the seat for me.” Day’s playful aside summed up the variability at the top in men’s golf.

headline: Eric Cantor: The G.O.P., After John Boehner
text: Richmond, Va. — LIKE so many others, I was stunned by Speaker John A. Boehner’s announcement on Friday that he would step down at the end of October. For nearly six years — first as Republican whip and then as majority leader — I met with John on a daily, sometimes hourly, basis as we worked to lead the House Republican Conference. It is no secret that we had different styles and personalities, but he was always selfless, a man who put the nation, his constituents, the House of Representatives and the party before himself.

headline: A Day Laborer, on His Way to See Pope Francis
text: This week brought Pope Francis to the South Lawn of the White House, where he spoke to a crowd of thousands and greeted President Obama. It brought Juan Tapia to a house outside Yonkers, where he spent days painting the living room blue — “the color of the sky today,” he said on Thursday.

headline: Bill Cunningham | New York Fashion Week
text: Here, five of the outstanding collections and settings.

headline: Bill Cunningham | New York Fashion Week
text: The New York Fashion Week of spring 2016 designs has spoken. Here, five of the outstanding collections and settings. Held on the anniversary of 9/11 with the Financial District as a backdrop, Riccardo Tisci’s Givenchy show was reverential of the day. Here are the other shows.

headline: State Dinner for Xi Jinping Has High-Tech Flavor
text: WASHINGTON — In a reflection of just how important Washington’s relationship with Beijing has become, President Obama on Friday held his second state dinner for China, the only country to receive such a double honor from him.

headline: Donald Trump Sees in Marco Rubio a New Rival to Taunt, but Gets Plenty of Salvos in Return
text: WASHINGTON — After training his fire for much of the summer on former Gov. Jeb Bush, Donald J. Trump has found a new favorite Republican rival to taunt: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida.

headline: Finding Common Ground With China
text: Despite growing strains between their countries, President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China made progress on two key issues during their meeting on Friday, offering some reassurance that they may be able to manage the challenges ahead.

headline: Limiting Security Breaches May Be Impossible Task for U.S. and China
text: WASHINGTON — When the United States and the Soviet Union made their first tentative steps toward limiting nuclear arms more than 50 years ago, distrust was sky high but they could, at least, count each other’s missiles and bombers and warheads.

headline: The Prospect of Peace in Colombia
text: BARICHARA, Colombia — It was not a heartfelt handshake. It was tentative and awkward. And yet, I watched in stunned silence as President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia shook hands with Rodrigo Londoño (no relation), the leader of the country’s largest guerrilla group, on Wednesday night after the two announced a major breakthrough in peace talks.

headline: Beijing Puts Ball Back in Washington’s Court on Climate Change
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama tried to tackle climate change in his first term, he pushed Congress to limit and put a price on carbon pollution, but the so-called cap-and-trade bill died in the Senate in 2010. Among the chief reasons: Lawmakers from both parties feared that any law to cut greenhouse gas emissions would harm the nation’s competitiveness compared with China, which was then emerging as the world’s largest polluter.

headline: How Surgery Can Fight Global Poverty
text: EARLIER this year in Madagascar, a man in his 60s named Sambany made international news after volunteer surgeons from Mercy Ships removed a 16-pound tumor from his face. For decades, he had sought treatment at 10 hospitals, most of which lacked surgeons. He was ostracized, then physically unable to work. His family had to sell a rice field just to pay for the cost of getting to the hospital (the surgery itself was provided free).

headline: Colombia’s President Says Peace Talks Overcame Late Surprise
text: When President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia met with the leader of his country’s largest guerrilla group this week to seal the outline of a deal to end more than five decades of war, he received an unsettling shock. At the last minute, he said, the rebel leader, Rodrigo Londoño, tried to back out of a crucial part of the newly negotiated framework.

headline: Bye, Bye, John Boehner
text: Farewell, John Boehner, farewell.

headline: Faculty Council at Rutgers Says Coach’s Punishment Is Too Lenient
text: The New Brunswick Faculty Council, a group of Rutgers professors, said on Friday that punishing Kyle Flood, the head football coach, with a three-game suspension and a $50,000 fine for contacting a player’s professor to try to make the player eligible was too lenient a penalty.

headline: Malawi: U.N. Warns of a Food Crisis
text: The World Food Program, the hunger-fighting agency of the United Nations, warned Friday of an impending crisis in the southeastern African nation of Malawi, saying that more than 2.8 million people there will lack enough to eat over the next several months because of severe floods and a drought that ruined the 2015 harvest. The agency said the floods this year in Malawi were “the worst in living memory,” flushing away stockpiles of food and ruining fertile land. Crops that survived the floods, the agency said, succumbed later to “intense dry spells.” The agency, which is financed by voluntary contributions, said its Malawi relief operation was less than 25 percent funded and required more than $80 million.

headline: Up-to-the-Minute
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Be careful what you wish for, my friends, because you just might get it.

headline: Of Peanuts and Prosecutions
text: Salmonella poisoning is an awful affliction. It is marked by diarrhea, abdominal cramps, dehydration and fever that can last as long as a week. Many people wind up in the hospital. Others develop something called reactive arthritis. And in a small number of cases, the victims die.

headline: In Pope Francis’ Words
text: Pope Francis spoke directly to New Yorkers and the world on Friday, in gatherings large and small.

headline: Carly Fiorina Really Was That Bad
text: HER silver tongue honed by decades in corporate marketing, Carly Fiorina has used two debates, and a steely determination on the campaign trail, to climb near the top of the polls for the Republican nomination.

headline: Two Weeks After Scare, Jets Rookie Is Set to Return
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Lorenzo Mauldin practiced in full on Friday.

headline: New York City Council Initiates Steps to Ban the Manufacture of K2
text: Seeking to curb what city officials are calling a public health crisis, the New York City Council took initial steps on Friday to approve three bills that would ban the manufacturing of a popular synthetic drug, known as K2, and punish business owners for selling it.

headline: For Better or Worse, These Knicks Belong to Phil Jackson
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — When Phil Jackson agreed to preside over the Knicks in March 2014, he hoped to reshape the team into a championship contender. In the 557 days since, the Knicks have won 27 games — including 17 games last season, when they steamrollered franchise records for futility.

headline: Mets Clinch at Least a Tie for the East Title After Thrashing the Reds
text: CINCINNATI — If the Mets are on the verge of clinching the National League East title here this weekend, ballpark employees plan to prepare for the celebration while the Mets-Reds game is still going on. They will remove the furniture from the visiting team’s clubhouse, cover the room in plastic, and stock tubs with ice, beer and champagne.

headline: U.S. Says Rebel It Trained Surrendered Matériel in Syria
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon said Friday that an American-trained rebel commander in Syria had surrendered trucks and ammunition this week to forces affiliated with an offshoot of Al Qaeda.

headline: Yankees Get Mixed News on Tanaka and Bad News on the Field
text: Masahiro Tanaka emerged from the back of the clubhouse at Yankee Stadium on Friday with ice packs wrapped tightly around his right shoulder, elbow and thigh. Earlier in the afternoon, Tanaka threw off a mound for the first time since straining a hamstring against the Mets, a noteworthy milepost in the high-pressure stretch run of September.

headline: In Return, Mats Zuccarello Plays Well but Plays It Down
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Mats Zuccarello missed the Rangers’ last 14 playoff games and their first two preseason contests, but he returned to the ice with a flourish Thursday against the Boston Bruins.

headline: David Haggerty of U.S. Will Lead International Tennis Federation
text: David Haggerty, a recent president of the United States Tennis Association and a longtime tennis industry executive, was elected president of the International Tennis Federation on Friday in a close vote in Santiago, Chile.

headline: The Giants’ Wait for Victor Cruz Could Be Nearing an End
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A day after the first Giants victory of the season, there was more good news for the team. Coach Tom Coughlin indicated on Friday that wide receiver Victor Cruz, who has not played in roughly a year, should resume practicing next week, which would put him on schedule to rejoin the team on Oct. 4 for its next game, against the Buffalo Bills.

headline: Met Opera Crowd Cheers Ailing Russian Baritone
text: Three months after announcing he had a brain tumor, and still in the midst of treatment, the cherished Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday evening as the Count di Luna in Verdi’s “Il Trovatore.”

headline: Don Francisco Walks Us Through His Final Day on ‘Sábado Gigante’
text: This will be Mario Kreutzberger’s first free Saturday in 41 years. The host of “Sábado Gigante,” which ended its 53-year run last Saturday, he took his last day off in 1974, after the death of his mother. Since then Mr. Kreutzberger, more commonly known by his stage name, Don Francisco, has appeared on that Spanish-language variety show, which aired on Univision in the United States, every weekend without fail. Mr. Kreutzberger recalled his final day on “Sábado Gigante” in this account, which has been condensed and edited for clarity.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) UNBROKEN (2014) Angelina Jolie descends from the heavens into hell in this tale about Louis Zamperini (Jack O’Connell), the Olympic track star turned World War II hero, who survived a plane crash in the Pacific in 1943 and drifted for nearly seven weeks on a life raft before being imprisoned and tortured by the Japanese for two years. Joel Coen, Ethan Coen, Richard LaGravenese and William Nicholson condensed Laura Hillenbrand’s 2010 best seller, “Unbroken: A World War II Story of Survival, Resilience, and Redemption,” which covers the first 25 years or so of Mr. Zamperini’s life, into a 2-hour-17-minute screenplay. That’s still hardly enough time to cover each chapter in his life, and though Ms. Jolie does fine work throughout, the strain shows. Her “tendency to go David Lean in this material works against her,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “What the movie ends up in desperate need of is a sense of life made real and palpable through dreadful, transporting details, not a life embalmed in hagiographic awe.”

headline: Corrections: September 26, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “In big cities, beneath the roar of traffic, beneath the rapid pace of change, so many faces pass by unnoticed because they have no ‘right’ to be there, no right to be part of the city.”

headline: Pope Francis in New York
text: The pope addressed a gathering of world leaders at the United Nations, honored those killed in the Sept. 11 attacks and visited a school in East Harlem.

headline: New Yorkers Fast, Jostle, Wait and Cook as Pope Visits
text: Two hours before the security gates opened at Central Park, and eight hours before Pope Francis was set to arrive, the line at one gate stretched two and a half blocks long and a dozen people wide.

headline: Review: ‘The Awful Truth,’ Modern Woman and Not-So-Modern Men
text: The acting isn’t great, but the Metropolitan Playhouse production of “The Awful Truth” provides a rewarding sense of rediscovery, even for those unfamiliar with the work. It’s the rediscovery of the truth that our forebears weren’t as quaint and pristine as we might have thought.

headline: Reviving a Traditional Irish Women’s Sport in New York
text: When Aisling Daly moved to New York two years ago, she knew she would miss two things from her native Ireland: family and camogie.

headline: At Independence Hall, Pope Offers a Broad Vision of Religious Freedom
text: PHILADELPHIA — Standing near Independence Hall, where America’s founding documents were signed, Pope Francis on Saturday called religious freedom a “fundamental right” and laid out a broad and tolerant vision of what it should be, but also warned about its perversion “as a pretext for hatred and brutality.”

headline: On the Front Line of Campus Sexual Misconduct
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Sarah Daniels stood at the front of an auditorium on the University of Michigan campus and looked out at the 120 or so students before her on an unseasonably cool day in late August.

headline: Complex Car Software Becomes the Weak Spot Under the Hood
text: For all the sophistication of modern cars, recent hacking episodes and the Volkswagen scandal show the risks that come with advances.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from the U.S. Capitol to the Los Angeles River.

headline: Bottega Veneta: Spring 2016 RTW
text: The latest looks from Bottega Veneta.

headline: Menu for Pope Francis in New York
text: Pope Francis, known for his penchant for simplicity, had a menu that was anything but.

headline: The Root of Pope Francis’s Appeal Among Secular Sustainability Seekers
text: I’ve been musing on why Pope Francis has attracted so many secular scientists and others trying to chart a low-impact path for humanity in a crowding, turbulent, fast-forward century?*

headline: Roberto Cavalli: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Roberto Cavalli’s spring collection.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: No Jokes, Just China
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the industry.

headline: On Syria, Putin Is Catering to an Audience at Home
text: MOSCOW — A funny thing happened on the way to the United Nations General Assembly, where President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will speak on Monday for the first time in 10 years.

headline: Dealing With a Menacing Landlord
text: Dementia or an Agenda?

headline: Economics: What Went Right
text: Sorry about lack of music. I was traveling while suffering from a cold, and the combination of congestion and pressure changes was really, really unpleasant. OK now, I think.

headline: Michelle Obama’s State Dinner Fashion
text: Updated Oct. 18, 2016: Obamas’ final state dinner

headline: U.N. Summit Meeting on Women’s Rights Highlights More Tension Between U.S. and China
text: UNITED NATIONS — After the South China Sea and cyberspace, the rivalry between the United States and China has found a new front: women’s rights.

headline: At Versace, Individualistic Beauty Reigns
text: For spring, Donatella Versace wants women to show their individuality — and, as a result, heavy makeup was replaced by bare faces. Identity, evidently, is in. With a soundtrack blaring messages of positive female reinforcement, Versace presented a collection that ranged from uniforms of khaki and military green to full-on Versace leopard-heavy camouflage prints in vibrant greens, oranges and neon yellows.

headline: Edie Jackson: Signer With the Band

headline: Empty Promises and Broken Surfboards
text: In the years that the Haggler has been fighting on behalf of aggrieved consumers, he has compiled a win-loss record exceeded only by Floyd Mayweather, the boxer whose undefeated professional career now stands at 49 wins. But this greatly oversells the Haggler’s achievements — he has lost far more bouts than readers know. It’s just that he rarely writes about the losses.

headline: Long Hidden Away, Columbia’s Football Program Is Put on Display
text: It was just after 3 p.m. Friday when scores of curious onlookers, mostly wearing backpacks, began to line the yew hedges around Columbia’s South Lawn, snapping pictures of a sight unfamiliar to these grounds for decades. Before them, only a few feet away, was the football team, long a source of considerable embarrassment for a proud Ivy League fan base. But the team was out in the warm sunshine on this September afternoon.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword Puzzle
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — So you’ve made some considerable progress in your solving, you’re regularly solving the late-week, trickier puzzles, and you feel ready to climb some new mountains. Why not try a cryptic crossword, like this terrific one by Daniel Raymon?

headline: The Post-Boehner Congress and Washington’s Sense of Dread

headline: John Boehner Exits, Donald Trump Storms On

headline: Review: ‘The Walk’ Captures High-Wire Bravado at World Trade Center
text: “Now I’ve seen everything,” an anonymous New Yorker remarks, marveling at the spectacle unfolding more than a hundred stories above street level. It’s the morning of Aug. 7, 1974, and Philippe Petit is walking across a steel cable strung between the towers of the World Trade Center. Amid the gasps and murmurs, that line stands out, and invites a bit of pondering. It’s an expression of wonder, for sure, but it also carries an implication of jadedness, especially for moviegoers. All the surround-sound bells and whistles and digitally enhanced fireworks in the world can’t quite shake us out of the feeling that we’ve seen it all before.

headline: At Versace, Military Silhouettes in Wild Prints

headline: How Not to Be a Networking Leech: Tips for Seeking Professional Advice

headline: At Roberto Cavalli, a Little ’80s Glam
text: The designer Peter Dundas debuted a collection for Roberto Cavalli today after a 10-year intermission — or, as he called it backstage, “a nice homecoming.” He said that spring/summer 2016 felt like “the right time to ease the Cavalli woman up” with styles that could be “just thrown on, comfortable pieces in washed fabrics.” That included acid-washed denim, leather — and even chain mail for an effect that was a little ’80s glam.

headline: Smaller, Faster, Cheaper, Over: The Future of Computer Chips

headline: To Get a Job in Your 50s, Maintain Friendships in Your 40s
text: We hear it all the time: People who are over 50 take longer to find jobs than younger people. Connie Wanberg, a professor at the Carlson School of Management at the University of Minnesota, had long heard gloom-and-doom stories to that effect, but she wondered how strong the data was to support them.

headline: As Volkswagen Pushed to Be No. 1, Ambitions Fueled a Scandal

The company, he said, was in the midst of a plan to more than triple its sales in the United States in just a decade — setting it on a course to sweep by Toyota to become the world’s largest automaker.

headline: Malala Yousafzai’s Fight Continues
