text: This is the third post in an occasional series looking at The Times’s efforts to survive and thrive in the digital age.

headline: For Weight Control, Fruit and Vegetable Choice May Matter
text: Eating more fruits and vegetables can help control weight, but a new study suggests that it depends on which fruits and vegetables you eat.

headline: Nexstar Offers to Buy Media General for $1.85 Billion
text: The Nexstar Broadcasting Group said on Monday that it had made an unsolicited offer to buy Media General for $1.85 billion in cash and stock, potentially upending Media General’s recent bid for the Meredith Corporation.

headline: Afghan Forces Are Pushed Back in Kunduz
text: Security personnel attempted to defend the city in northern Afghanistan after Taliban fighters launched an assault on Monday, raising their flag in at least one neighborhood.

headline: Broncos and Peyton Manning Reclaim Their Airspace Against Lions
text: Peyton Manning finally completed a pass that traveled more than 20 yards in the air, but even with the 45-yard touchdown to Demaryius Thomas, it felt like an underwhelming performance for the Denver Broncos’ quarterback on Sunday.

headline: Vocus of Australia to Merge With Rival M2 Group
text: Vocus Communications of Australia said Monday it would merge with its local rival M2 Group in an all-stock deal valued at 1.93 billion Australian dollars, or $1.35 billion, in an effort to provide households and corporations with a range of integrated Internet services.

headline: How Patent Law Can Block Even Lifesaving Drugs
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s prescription drug policy proposal, released last week, would hold drug manufacturers accountable to their level of investment in research. But there are some potentially valuable drugs we’ll never get drug companies to invest in — those that cannot be patented.

headline: Liberal Feminists Ponder Friends, Foes and Carly Fiorina
text: When the novelist Jennifer Weiner watched the second Republican presidential debate with her two daughters on Sept. 16, she felt a sense of pride at seeing the lone woman on stage, Carly Fiorina, hold her own against Donald J. Trump.

headline: Energy Transfer to Buy Williams in $37.7 Billion Deal
text: Energy Transfer Equity said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the Williams Companies for $37.7 billion, including the assumption of debt, concluding a monthslong saga to make the combined company one of the largest in the energy industry.

headline: Apple iPhone 6s Breaks First-Weekend Sales Record
text: Apple’s iPhone juggernaut is showing no signs of slowing down — at least where first-weekend sales are concerned.

headline: 1915: Allies Stand Behind Balkans
text: LONDON — Sir Edward Grey made an important statement in the House of Commons this afternoon [Sept. 28] on the Balkan situation. He declared, replying to Sir P. Magnus, that Great Britain had no hostility toward the Bulgarian people, but, on the contrary, entertained a feeling of warm sympathy toward their aspirations. If, however, the mobilization in Bulgaria was not for defensive purposes and if Bulgaria assumed an aggressive attitude on the side of the enemy, Great Britain was prepared to give its Balkan friends all the support in its power, in concert with Britain’s Allies. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 29, 1915

headline: Study Offers Support for Cancer Treatment During Pregnancy
text: It is among the most delicate and difficult dilemmas in medicine: Should a pregnant woman who has received a cancer diagnosis begin treatment before her child is born? Some hesitant doctors counsel women to deliver preterm or even terminate the pregnancy first.

headline: Times Critics’ Guide: What to Do This Week
text: Want to find something new to do?

headline: A Very British Tea Party at the Spotted Pig
text: Though she’s American, Claire Ptak loves a good British tea service. “The entire ritual is greater than the sum of its parts,” explains Ptak, the owner and chef behind London’s popular Violet Cakes bakery and cafe, before listing her favorite components: “the scones with cream and jam, and of course the dainty little sandwiches. The top plate of perfect cake is exciting too.” It’s rather fitting then that tomorrow, to celebrate the stateside debut of Ptak’s “The Violet Bakery Cookbook” ($30, Ten Speed Press), the California-born baker will import a touch of that Brit tradition to New York, with a tea party at the Spotted Pig.

headline: Stripes and Peplums at Arthur Arbesser
text: The designer presented an upbeat collection filled with flower prints for spring.

headline: Journalism in Pakistan: Fear and Favor
text: KARACHI — In this summer’s feel-good Indian movie “Bajrangi Bhaijaan,” a Pakistani TV reporter telephones his boss to tell him he has an explosive story about an Indian spy on Pakistani territory who’s not actually a spy, but a man trying to help a lost Pakistani child find her parents. The boss tells him the story isn’t sensational enough, then hangs up, leaving the reporter grumbling that the channel’s executives care only about making money, rather than telling a good story.

headline: Daily Report: Narendra Modi, Indian Prime Minister, Conquers Silicon Valley
text: Narendra Modi, India’s prime minister, came to Silicon Valley over the weekend and wooed and wowed the tech crowd.

headline: Joe Biden Eligible for October Debate — if He Declares
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has an open invitation to participate in the first Democratic presidential debate next month.

headline: How to Share Water Along the Nile
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — On the Blue Nile in Ethiopia, construction is underway on a public works project of gigantic physical proportions and exquisite political delicacy. The Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam, now about halfway finished, amounts to a test: With water becoming precious enough to be the stuff of war, can nations find ways to share it?

headline: When Teammates Fight: An Ugly History
text: Sports is a rough-and-tumble business, and tempers will flare from time to time. Opposing players get into fights in just about every sport.

headline: Mars Shows Signs of Having Flowing Water, Possible Niches for Life, NASA Says
text: Scientists have for the first time confirmed liquid water flowing on the surface of present-day Mars, a finding that will add to speculation that life, if it ever arose there, could persist now.

headline: Google Virtual-Reality System Aims to Enliven Education
text: As part of a class last year on “Romeo and Juliet,” Jennie Choi, an English teacher at Mariano Azuela Elementary School in Chicago, took her sixth-grade students on a tour of Verona, the Italian city where Shakespeare’s play transpires.

headline: At Giorgio Armani, Woven Jackets And Geometric Prints
text: The spring/summer 2016 collection closed out Milan Fashion Week on a high note.

headline: Five and a Half Hours’ Wait, 15 Memorable Minutes
text: My morning with Pope Francis at the National September 11 Memorial on Friday did not begin auspiciously. Breakfast was a bowl of toasted-oat cereal smothered in orange juice.

headline: Joyce Mitchell, Ex-Prison Employee, Is Sentenced
text: A former prison employee who admitted to helping two convicted killers escape from a maximum-security prison in northern New York, leading to one of the largest manhunts in the state’s history, was sentenced on Monday to at least two years and four months in prison.

headline: 1965: Wilson Warns on Race Issue
text: Blackpool, England — Prime Minister Harold Wilson warned today [Sept. 28] that ‘‘a social explosion of the kind we have seen abroad’’ might soon burst in Britain unless the government acts swiftly to curb the illegal flow of non-white immigrants. Addressing the annual convention of the Labour party, Mr. Wilson rejected charges that his policy is based on racial prejudice. In August, the government issued an executive order cutting Commonwealth immigration from 20,300 a year to 8,500. The restriction had its heaviest effect on immigration from the West Indies, India and Pakistan. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 29, 1965

headline: Warburg Pincus to Invest Up to $60 Million in Civitas Learning
text: With sophisticated data analysis seeping into nearly every industry, a start-up focused on higher education has drawn the big private equity firm Warburg Pincus as its latest investor.

headline: Streaks of Flowing Water on Mars
text: Images showing what scientists say is definitive evidence of salty liquid water flowing on Mars.

headline: Obama Addresses U.N. General Assembly
text: President Obama said “there are no easy answers to Syria” and called for the cooperation of all the states in the United Nations General Assembly to end the fighting and help the victims.

headline: Paris Looks to Depose Keepers of a Different Throne
text: PARIS — “Dames pipi,” as the ladies who clean public toilets here are known, have been a fixture of Parisian neighborhoods, alongside the proprietors of corner cafes, since the days when many buildings lacked indoor plumbing.

headline: Momentum Grows for Jack Dorsey to Be Twitter’s Permanent C.E.O.
text: Steve Jobs simultaneously led two companies, Apple and Pixar, as chief executive. Elon Musk is running Tesla and SpaceX. Now more people are saying that Jack Dorsey can permanently run two companies at the same time, too.

headline: Masks and Other Air Pollution Defenses
text: Q. I commute by car through an area of bad highway air pollution. Would wearing a surgical mask help protect me from health problems?

headline: As Golf’s Best Player, Jordan Spieth Is Determined to Get Better
text: ATLANTA — How will Jordan Spieth improve upon one of the greatest seasons in golf? A clue could be found on the seventh hole Sunday here at East Lake Golf Club.

headline: Brazil’s Leader Addresses U.N.
text: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil said that her country has its “arms open to welcome refugees“ of global conflicts and declared Brazil to be economically strong.

headline: The Touching Puzzle
text: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Tim Chartier, and appeared in “Math Bytes.” his recently-released book that uses math and computing to demystify Angry Birds, March Madness, Google’s PageRank and many other algorithms that surround us. This week’s challenge is from the chapter “Doodling Into a Labyrinth.”  Let’s try —

headline: Hilary Mantel, Salman Rushdie and Other Authors Will Donate Profits to Help Syrian Refugees
text: LONDON — Hilary Mantel, Salman Rushdie, David Nicholls, Ian Rankin and Ali Smith are among a group of authors who have agreed to donate the profits of their top-selling titles at the Waterstones bookstore chain to raise money for Oxfam’s Syria crisis fund-raiser.

headline: Decades-Old Questions Over Trump’s Wealth and Education
text: Thirty-one years ago, the estimable William E. Geist — not to be confused with his son Willie, of “Morning Joe” and “Today” show fame — spent a day or so following Donald Trump around New York and wrote about it in a memorable New York Times Magazine cover story. Mr. Geist’s tale has a certain familiar quality to it. “Spending a day with Donald Trump is like driving a Ferrari without the windshield,” he wrote. “It’s exhilarating; he gets a few bugs in his teeth.”

headline: Airstrikes in Yemen Hit Wedding Party, Killing Dozens
text: SANA, Yemen — Warplanes with the Saudi Arabia-led military coalition bombed a wedding party on Yemen’s Red Sea coast on Monday, killing at least 70 civilians, according to two local officials and a relative of one of the victims.

headline: Selfie With a Talib
text: In a video clip sent to the Afghan television channel Tolo on Monday, a resident posed with a Taliban fighter in the city of Kunduz after the insurgents expelled government forces.

headline: Anthony Bourdain’s Food Market Takes Shape
text: It was a far cry from the bustling, kaleidoscopic street scenes that Anthony Bourdain routinely plunges into during his television travelogues: an empty, dimly lit pier building on the Hudson River at the edge of the meatpacking district.

headline: Jeb Bush Reserves Ad Time With Heavy Focus on New Hampshire
text: Jeb Bush’s campaign said Monday that it was reserving millions of dollars in television ad time for January and February in early voting states, setting aside $4.6 million in New Hampshire alone.

headline: 1956: Bernie Sanders, Running Hard
text: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Leave a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Young Offensive Players Give Raiders Fast Start and Bright Future
text: The Oakland Raiders are one of the surprise N.F.L. teams of 2015. With a 2-1 record, they have a winning record after three games for just the second time in the last 11 seasons (the Raiders also began 2011 with a 2-1 record).

headline: Ex-Prison Employee Is Sentenced
text: Joyce E. Mitchell is given up to seven years in prison for helping two convicted murderers escape from a maximum-security prison in upstate New York in June.

headline: Dealing With an Investing Blind Spot
text: Psst. Excuse me. I’ve got a secret.

headline: On the Amalfi Coast, Music of Sinatra and Chopin
text: If it weren’t heavenly enough to hike the winding Paths of the Gods trails that float 1,640 feet above the Amalfi Coast, the city of Praiano’s Town Hall and the Pelagos Tourist Office of Praiano organize a free, open-air concert series of classical and jazz music in May, September and October.

headline: Putin Addresses U.N. on Syria
text: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia defended his country’s support of the Syrian government and criticized other western states’ policies in the Middle East.

headline: Gigi Hadid Defends Herself Against Online Critics
text: The model Gigi Hadid, who is possessed of, by her own admission, a more womanly figure than many of the other models working fashion’s runways, appeared in the Versace show in Milan and has arrived in Paris for the fashion shows here.

headline: Trump Plan Is Tax Cut for the Rich, Even Hedge Fund Managers
text: Donald Trump’s tax plan, released Monday, does not live up to the populist language he has offered on taxes all summer.

headline: Juilliard’s China Plans Move Forward
text: The Juilliard School announced on Monday that it was moving forward with plans to expand in China, saying that it had received “preliminary approval” to build, with several Chinese partners, a school in Tianjin that would offer a master’s degree program.

headline: Review: ‘The Theater of War’: Applying Greek Tragedies to Our Own
text: Many roads lead to a career in the healing professions, but the route Bryan Doerries describes in his memoir is as unique as the place it landed him.

headline: Trump Announces Tax Plan
text: Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential candidate, outlined his tax plan on Monday at a news conference in New York.

headline: A New View of a Nebula Full of Newborn Stars
text: A dazzling image of Messier 17, a reddish nebula 5,500 light-years from Earth, provides a detailed view of its newborn stars, gas clouds and dust. The gas in the nebula has a mass about 30,000 times that of the sun, astronomers estimate. The center of the nebula is home to more than 800 stars, and more are forming in the outer regions. The nebula is near the plane of the Milky Way, in the constellation Sagittarius, and is named after Charles Messier, who discovered it in 1764. The image was captured by a telescope at La Silla Observatory in Chile.

headline: London Cafe’s Cereal, at $5 a Bowl, Sets Off Wrath
text: The owner of a cereal cafe in rapidly gentrifying East London said his business had been unfairly targeted by demonstrators who attacked it over the weekend with smoke bombs and paint.

headline: One Fish Stands Watch While Another Eats
text: Rabbitfish help one another in a way that had been observed only in mammals and highly social birds, according to a new study.

headline: Gigi Hadid’s Fashion Month
text: Ms. Hadid walking various runways this season.

headline: Allen Katz Finds Romance in His Food Mill
text: At the age of 16, Allen Katz tried to debone a rabbit in his family’s kitchen in Baltimore. He wanted to make rabbit pâté for Thanksgiving, though he had no idea what it should taste like.

headline: Materials From Banksy’s Theme Park Going to a Migrant Camp in France
text: LONDON — “Coming soon … Dismaland Calais.” The graffiti artist Banksy announced on his website on Sunday that timber and other materials from his glum parody theme park Dismaland would be sent to the “jungle” — a camp for migrants and refugees in Calais, France.

headline: Review: For DanceNow’s 20th Anniversary, an Encore at Joe’s Pub
text: At Joe’s Pub on Thursday, a woman at one table was salting her food heavily. In a thick New York accent, she complained about her husband. She tossed salt over her shoulder in great arcs, but no one was hit because she had a tiny bit more space around her than everyone else. She was onstage.

headline: Sia and Charli XCX Cover Bleachers on a Women-Led Version of ‘Strange Desire’
text: Cover albums are having a big month.

headline: President Obama’s Speech to the United Nations General Assembly 2015
text: The following speech was delivered by President Obama at the United Nations General Assembly as transcribed and released by the White House.

headline: Donald Trump Unveils Plan to Overhaul Tax Code With Broad Cuts
text: Calling it his personal “wheelhouse,” Donald J. Trump laid out a plan on Monday to revamp the tax code, seeking to reduce taxes for people at most income levels with simplification and by reducing rates, while also eliminating deductions and certain breaks that allow the wealthy and corporations to avoid paying extra.

headline: Maxwell Anderson Resigns as Director of Dallas Museum of Art
text: The Dallas Museum of Art announced on Monday that Maxwell L. Anderson — who has served as its director for almost four years and helped increase attendance while expanding the museum’s scope into areas like Islamic art — had resigned. A statement from the museum did not explain Mr. Anderson’s unexpected departure, except to say that he had accepted a position as director of grant programs at the New Cities Foundation in New York.

headline: Review: ‘Grandfathered’ and ‘The Grinder,’ Two New Fox Sitcoms
text: “I’m a 50-year-old bachelor,” says Jimmy Martino (John Stamos), the protagonist of “Grandfathered.” “We’re society’s most worthless people.”

headline: Super Blood Moon Photos: The Good and the Bad
text: Those lucky enough to have clear skies on Sunday night were treated to a rare astronomical phenomenon.

headline: Armani and Missoni: In the Shadow of the Supermoon
text: MILAN — Milan Fashion Week came to a close just after a total lunar eclipse, the sort that indicates heavenly bodies in perfect alignment. As portents go, it doesn’t get much better than that.

headline: Nation’s Rail Service Is Threatened as Deadline for Safety System Looms
text: WASHINGTON — Even after spending nearly $6 billion, the rail industry says it will not be able to meet its year-end government-imposed deadline to install a system known as positive train control, which is intended to prevent collisions or derailments caused by excessive speed.

headline: Edith Wharton House Museum Retires Debt
text: The Mount, the former home of Edith Wharton, has announced that it has made final payments to its lenders and no longer carries any debt, bringing to a close a financial saga that might have come from the pages of a novel by its onetime owner.

headline: Children With H.I.V. More Likely to Die of Malaria
text: Children infected with H.I.V. appear much more likely than those who are not to die with severe malaria, a new study has found. It may make sense to give these children malaria drugs protectively, the authors said.

headline: Espelette Pepper Expands Reach to Butter
text: Lately, it seems as though the French will dust almost anything, even ice cream, with Espelette pepper, which is made from chiles grown in a designated area of the Basque Country. Now, imported Espelette butter has hit the American market, joining mustards, oils, mayonnaise and other items fueled with the ruddy spice. Slice the ingots of cultured, hand-churned, forcefully seasoned butter into pats to top a steak or fish. Or simply spread the butter on toast or crackers for canapés, perhaps crowned with a patch of cured ham: Beurre des Aldudes with Espelette pepper, $6 for 5.3 ounces at Le District, 225 Liberty Street (West Street), 212-981-8588, ledistrict.com.

headline: Rouhani Addresses U.N. General Assembly
text: The president of Iran, Hassan Rouhani, said a new chapter had started in his country’s relations with the world in his speech at the United Nations.

headline: Nationals’ Jonathan Papelbon Suspended for Fight With Bryce Harper
text: Washington Nationals closer Jonathan Papelbon will miss the rest of the season after the team suspended him Monday for grabbing Bryce Harper by the throat in the dugout Sunday.

headline: Is It Old Age, or A.D.H.D.?
text: The 73-year-old widow came to see Dr. David Goodman, an assistant professor in the psychiatry and behavioral sciences department at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, after her daughter had urged her to “see somebody” for her increasing forgetfulness. She was often losing her pocketbook and keys and had trouble following conversations, and 15 minutes later couldn’t remember much of what was said.

headline: As Banks Retreat, Private Equity Rushes to Buy Troubled Home Mortgages
text: Private equity and hedge fund firms have bought more than 100,000 troubled mortgages at a discount from banks and federal housing agencies, emerging as aggressive liquidators for the remains of the mortgage crisis that erupted nearly a decade ago.

headline: Lies, Carly Fiorina and Abortion
text: There has been an impressive amount of angry liberal commentary, which has spilled over into the mainstream press coverage (or do I repeat myself?) of the issue, about how in the last Republican presidential debate Carly Fiorina allegedly cited an entirely imaginary video in order to make a crazy claim about Planned Parenthood’s brain-harvesting ghoulishness that’s totally unsupported by the facts. Here’s Slate’s Dahlia Lithwick, in a representative rant, attacking Fiorina’s “big fib,” the sheer “enormity” of which has shaken Lithwick’s faith in honesty in politics and journalism:

headline: Many Conservative Republicans Believe Climate Change Is a Real Threat
text: WASHINGTON — A majority of Republicans — including 54 percent of self-described conservative Republicans — believe the world’s climate is changing and that mankind plays some role in the change, according to a new survey conducted by three prominent Republican pollsters.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
text: Yes, there are Champions League games this week, and yes, you should probably take a peek at Bayer Leverkusen at Barcelona on Tuesday (2:45 p.m., Eastern time, Fox Sports 1), if only to see how Barça functions without a certain Argentine who will be out the next two months. But outside of that, watching soccer this week is pretty simple.

headline: Scientists on Evidence of Water on Mars
text: NASA scientists said Monday that they had found evidence of liquid water on Mars.

headline: Hip-Hop and R&B Fans Embrace Streaming Music Services
text: On this week’s music charts, “What a Time to Be Alive,” a new mix tape by the star rappers Drake and Future, opened at No. 1 by a wide margin, it was announced on Monday — a victory for Apple, which had an exclusive deal to release the album first.

headline: The Secret Gardens of New York
text: Six hidden gardens where weary city dwellers and visitors can slip in for a quick sip of nature, or linger through an afternoon.

headline: Facts & Figures: Even Republicans Don’t Want to Shut Down the Government
text: A majority of Americans — and a smaller majority of Republicans — say they don’t support a government shutdown over Planned Parenthood funding, according to a new poll.

headline: Toledo Museum to Return Four Antiquities Bought From Dealer Now Accused of Smuggling
text: The Toledo Museum of Art has decided to return four pieces of rare Indian artwork on display there to India after concluding that their provenance had been falsified or could not be verified. All four of the ancient objects had been purchased from Subhash Kapoor, a former New York art dealer who is awaiting trial in India on charges of theft and smuggling.

headline: France’s Hollande Addresses U.N.
text: President François Hollande of France spoke to the General Assembly on Monday about climate change and the role of Bashar al-Assad in Syria.

headline: Giants’ Victor Cruz Returns to Practice
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants wide receiver Victor Cruz returned to practice Monday for the first time in more than a month and ran about 20 pass routes without discomfort in either his surgically rebuilt right knee or his strained left calf muscle. Cruz said after the hourlong workout that he was convinced that he would play when the Giants visit the surging Buffalo Bills on Sunday.

headline: Burkina Faso Coup Plotters Refuse to Give Up Arms, Imperiling Deal
text: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — The troops who staged a failed coup in Burkina Faso have refused to give up their weapons under a political deal negotiated last week by West African leaders, the country’s transitional government said on Monday.

headline: Plea Deal for Dennis Hastert Is Being Discussed, Lawyers Say
text: CHICAGO — Lawyers for J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House of Representatives, have been discussing a possible plea agreement with prosecutors to resolve charges that Mr. Hastert lied to F.B.I. agents and illegally structured bank withdrawals, a federal court hearing revealed on Monday.

headline: Who Should Have Access to DNA Evidence?
text: Next week, the West Virginia Supreme Court will hear a case in which 30 former prosecutors from around the country have taken the unusual step of siding with the defense. It’s a battle over a DNA test, and whether prosecutors must turn the results over to a defendant when they point to his innocence — even if he has made the decision to plead guilty.

headline: 7 New Legionnaires’ Cases in Bronx Prompt Investigation
text: Seven people in the Morris Park section of the Bronx have Legionnaires’ disease, officials said on Monday, spurring an investigation into the potential source.

headline: New York Film Festivals Past
text: Images from previous iterations of the New York Film Festival.

headline: Roger Waters on Reinventing ‘The Wall’ and Plans for a Final Arena Show
text: Roger Waters keeps returning to “The Wall,” the 1979 concept album he wrote when he was the leader of Pink Floyd. But he is not simply looking back.

headline: Taliban Pose for Victory Selfies in Afghan City
text: As some veteran foreign correspondents pointed out, watching Taliban insurgents storm into the northern Afghan city of Kunduz on Monday and declare their intention to govern according to Islamic law seemed to echo the way the city was taken by Western-backed, Islamist mujahedeen in 1988, just days after the withdrawal of Soviet troops.

headline: Getting Older After the Apocalypse
text: Every now and then the Internet serves up something perfectly pitched to what you assumed were your own very individual fears.

headline: Silent Barn, a Brooklyn Arts Space, Is Damaged in a Fire
text: Silent Barn, the D.I.Y. arts space in Bushwick, Brooklyn, known for its sweaty punk shows and its strong support for performers, is in rebuilding mode after a fire on Friday in its residential area led to significant damage.

headline: Planned Parenthood to Offer Free S.T.D. Testing on National Pink Out Day
text: It’s not unusual for contenders in political battles to try to win support with giveaways, a candidate offering tax cuts, for instance, or a labor union giving out free coffee and donuts at a rally. But Planned Parenthood, now embroiled in a fierce fight with Congressional Republicans, is taking the concept to a whole new level: free testing for sexually transmitted diseases.

headline: Drake and Future Lead a Billboard Chart Featuring Two Versions of ‘1989’
text: In a busy week of new music releases, Drake and Future’s mixtape “What a Time to Be Alive” opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart, followed by new albums by Lana Del Rey, Mac Miller, David Gilmour and Ryan Adams.

headline: Jeff Daniels and Michelle Williams to Star in ‘Blackbird’ on Broadway
text: Nine years after he played the same role Off Broadway, the actor Jeff Daniels will star in a Broadway production of “Blackbird” as a man who sexually abused a young girl.

headline: Former C.E.O. of VW Under Investigation
text: Prosecutors announced that they are investigating Martin Winterkorn, who resigned as Volkswagen’s chief executive following revelations of emissions cheating software in the company’s cars.

headline: A New Effort Has Doctors Turn Patients Into Donors
text: A well-to-do cancer patient is nearing the end of her treatments. During an office visit, she says to her doctor, “I can’t thank you enough for the care you provided.”

headline: British Labour Party, Wary of Old Image, Puts Its Focus on Prudence
text: BRIGHTON, England — When the Labour Party chose Jeremy Corbyn, an outsider from the party’s hard left, as its new leader this month, critics worried that a turn away from centrist policies would relegate the party to Britain’s political sidelines, as it was in the 1980s during the Margaret Thatcher years.

headline: A Small Step in Changing S.E.C. Administrative Proceedings
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has been pestered with complaints over its move to file more administrative proceedings before in-house judges, including proceedings involving complex matters like insider trading and accounting fraud that used to be brought in federal district courts.

headline: Broadway Takes a Hit as a Pope and a Holiday Distract New York
text: The combination of Yom Kippur and a papal visit took a whack out of Broadway grosses last week, when all but a handful of shows experienced declines at the box office.

headline: Review: In ‘I Must Be Living Twice’ and ‘Chelsea Girls,’ Eileen Myles Ruminates
text: “I had always figured if I had a book I’d want my face all over it,” the narrator of Eileen Myles’s autobiographical cult novel “Chelsea Girls” (1994) thinks to herself at a party for one of her early poetry collections.

headline: How Many Deaths Did Volkswagen’s Deception Cause in the U.S.?
text: Volkswagen’s diesel deception unleashed tons of extra pollutants in the United States, pollutants that can harm human health. So while many commentators have been quick to say that the cheating engines are not a highway safety concern, safety — as in health — is still an issue.

headline: Review: TruTV’s ‘Adam Ruins Everything’ Challenges Beliefs About Giving
text: Adam Conover’s new television series isn’t the first dedicated to the fine art of debunking, but it’s one of the most entertaining.

headline: Xi Jinping Addresses General Assembly
text: President Xi of China spoke to the United Nations General Assembly on Monday and pledged the country’s support for peacekeeping forces and the African Union.

headline: Defining Australian Cuisine at the Sydney Opera House
text: “I feel a gigantic responsibility to get it right,” says the Australian chef Peter Gilmore as he surveys the cathedral-like dining room of Sydney Opera House’s Bennelong restaurant, which he newly helms. It is a highly scrutinized stage; and in the 42 years since the Sydney Opera House first welcomed diners at Bennelong, a succession of high-profile restaurateurs have run the famous kitchen — and ultimately been brought undone by the unique pressures of operating under the iconic white sails.

headline: The Raft Economy: Reporter’s Notebook
text: The smuggler met us at a busy kebab restaurant in Izmir, Turkey, and instead of sitting at an inside table where he could discuss his work privately, he chose seats on the sidewalk, clearly visible to pedestrians, the police and anyone else who happened to be passing by.

headline: Michelle Obama’s Recent Looks
text: Mrs. Obama has embraced an enviable position at the intersection of pop culture and politics — just because she can.

headline: At State Dinner, Michelle Obama Grabs Back the Spotlight
text: Friday night may have been a watershed for Michelle Obama. At the White House dinner for the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, the first lady summoned previously untapped, and perhaps unsuspected, reserves of glamour.

headline: Charles Masson Finds a New Home
text: Charles Masson, the restaurateur who left La Grenouille last year as a result of a family spat and was briefly at Chevalier in the Baccarat Hotel & Residences, will be the managing director of a new restaurant on the Upper East Side.

headline: First Draft Focus: The World’s Undivided Attention
text: First Draft Focus: The World’s Undivided Attention. President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia addressed the United Nations General Assembly on Monday.

headline: Amazon Envisions a New Tech Hub as It Expands Its Detroit Presence
text: Amazon plans to expand its Detroit office, adding more full-time jobs in hopes of creating a technology hub.

headline: London Gets in the Halloween Spirit
text: From witches to a Victorian medium and ghost tours, London is ready for Halloween.

headline: Inside the Vibrant New Rooms of Paris’s Hotel Montana
text: La Montana was a popular Parisian jazz club in the 1950s — just a stone’s throw from Les Deux Magots, it drew a Left-Bank literary crowd that included James Baldwin and Parisian polymath Boris Vian. In the ‘60s, the designer Jean-Charles de Castelbajac frequented Montana — and soon it became, as it is today, one of Paris’s most exclusive clubs.

headline: Paris’s Vibrant (And Surrealist) Hotel Montana
text: Each room in the hotel, which was designed by Vincent Darré, is inspired by a different creative person.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Arthur Arbesser
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Giorgio Armani
text: T plucks the best jewelry right off the runway.

headline: Hotel Owners Looking to Stay Current Put Money in Properties
text: Investing at record levels, owners of hotels across the United States are doing everything from rewiring their rooms and buying smart TVs, to replacing bathtubs with more easily maintained walk-in showers.

headline: Hillary Clinton Calls Jeb Bush’s ‘Free Stuff’ Comment ‘Deeply Insulting’
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton unloaded on Jeb Bush on Monday, calling it “deeply insulting” that he had suggested that Democratic presidential candidates had tried to appeal to black voters by offering “free stuff.”

headline: From Cheap Oil to ‘#ShellNo’ Protests, a Look at Factors in Shell’s Arctic Retreat
text: Given the complex array of factors shaping any decision related to energy, it’s always wise to consider an Agatha Christie “everyone did it” explanation when something big happens.

headline: Driving to Work With Keith Hernandez, the Real Mr. Met
text: You wander down a gravel driveway, past oaks and purple-red Japanese maples toward Keith Hernandez’s Sag Harbor, N.Y., pad, a handsome single-floor house.

headline: Newborn Is Found Dead After Fall From Bronx Building
text: Detectives are investigating the death of a newborn — her umbilical cord still attached — who fell several stories from a Bronx apartment building into an alleyway on Monday, the authorities said.

headline: The Daily Bag: Trussardi
text: T plucks the best bags right off the runway.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Volkswagen Faces Harsher Penalties Than a U.S. Company Might
text: Volkswagen picked the wrong market for its emissions trickery. The German carmaker has come up against the United States legal system, which extracts bigger fines and more guilty pleas from overseas companies than from their American counterparts. Differences in the cases may explain the discrepancy. But any prosecutorial bias may attract as much scrutiny as VW’s dirty tricks.

headline: Coke Spends Lavishly on Pediatricians and Dietitians
text: When the American Academy of Pediatrics needed support for a website it created to promote children’s health, it turned to a surprising partner: Coca-Cola.

headline: U.S. Commerce Chief Heading to Cuba for Talks
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will dispatch Penny Pritzker, the commerce secretary, to Cuba next week to discuss a raft of new rules easing American travel and business between the nations, the first such high-level talks since he announced he was normalizing relations with a Cold War adversary.

headline: Ridley Scott Learned About Water on Mars Before We Did, but Not in Time to Change ‘Martian’
text: NASA surprised the world on Monday with its announcement that it had found water on Mars. This wasn’t news, though, to the director Ridley Scott, whose latest film, “The Martian,” opens on Friday, and revolves around the struggles of a stranded astronaut and botanist, played by Matt Damon, to survive on the red planet by himself for more than a year.

headline: ‘Giorgio Armani’
text: The life of a legend, in pictures.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Vote Fails to Settle Dispute on Secession by Catalonia
text: BARCELONA, Spain — For three years, Catalonia has been at loggerheads with the central government in Madrid over whether the prosperous northeastern region — a fifth of Spain’s economy — could secede.

headline: Volkswagen Scandal Highlights European Stalling on New Emissions Tests
text: BRUSSELS — European legislators got a jolt this month in their long-running effort to update auto-emissions standards when a German member of the European Parliament suddenly proposed exempting a whole class of vehicles.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: ‘Asking for It’ Uses Wit to Tackle Cultural Norms About Rape
text: At the Creek and the Cave, the club-turned-bar-turned-Mexicali-joint now hosting Adrienne Truscott’s “Asking for It,” there is a two-for-one margarita offer. Go ahead and get your order in. This hourlong show, a performance-art riff on rape performed by a mostly naked woman, is both chirpy and blistering. It rewards and invites a strong drink.

headline: Review: In ‘Chambre,’ Jack Ferver and Marc Swanson Refract a Tale of Murderous Maids
text: The choreographer Jack Ferver specializes in prickly, playful queer dance theater, sometimes inspired by classics (“Antony and Cleopatra”), sometimes by cult favorites (“Poltergeist”). In “Chambre,” an impish if insubstantial piece for the French Institute Alliance Française’s annual Crossing the Line festival, he takes a barbed feather duster to Jean Genet’s “The Maids,” inspired by a real-life pair of murderous domestics.

headline: 12 Projects to Know from the London Design Festival
text: Moreso than most other design fairs, the London Design Festival — which takes place every September at shops and venues across the city — is known for showcasing the ingenuity of its local talents, rather than international brands or bussed-in superstars. From the 2015 London Design Medal, presented to Barber Osgerby, to the 60-foot-tall Swarovski totem by young up-and-comer Kim Thome that greeted visitors at the Victoria & Albert Museum, last week’s show was no exception. It proved, too, that the London scene is as strong as ever, with RCA grads like Thome, Marcin Rusak and Silo Studio making intriguing innovations in process and materials while brands like SCP (with new pieces by Peter Marigold and Oscar Coakley), Benchmark (with a new collection of spartan wood furniture by Max Lamb) and 1882 Ltd. (with new ceramics by young designer Maria Jeglinska) continue to connect the dots between British designers and British factories. See below for some of the homegrown highlights from this year’s Festival.

headline: Review: In ‘Elements of Oz,’ Smartphones Enhance a Celebration of ‘The Wizard of Oz’ Film
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — “Next time I’ll bring one of my grandsons,” cracked a woman behind me at “Elements of Oz,” a technologically sophisticated new show from the Builders Association that riffs on the celebrated movie “The Wizard of Oz.”

headline: The World of Giorgio Armani
text: In celebration of 40 years in fashion, the opening of a new museum and his first-ever book, a tribute to Giorgio Armani.

headline: Q. and A.: Eugenio B. Bito-onon Jr. on China’s Island Expansion
text: Eugenio B. Bito-onon Jr., the mayor of Pag-asa, a small island off the west coast of the Philippines, is accustomed to worrying about the well-being of the island’s 142 chickens, or haranguing fishermen about the dangers of Emperador brandy, a local favorite. But lately, Mr. Bito-onon, 59, has been preoccupied by a different problem.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Greece and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Most Americans Say Planned Parenthood Fight Isn’t Worth a Shutdown, Poll Finds
text: The American public isn’t paying much attention as the deadline looms to fund the government and avoid a government shutdown. Yet, there is strong bipartisan agreement that it is unacceptable for members of Congress to threaten a government shutdown as a bargaining tactic, and most Americans think Planned Parenthood should continue to receive government funding, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: September 28, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Greece, India, Italy and the United States.

headline: The Deities of Men’s Style
text: Though roughly 330 million deities populate the Hindu heavens, there are only a handful most people worship daily and know by name. Similarly, though there are about 330 billion images of celebrity divinities floating around the web empyrean at any given moment, when it comes down to it we seem inevitably to worship the same group of guys. This is meant in terms of style.

headline: Treasury Lawyer to Join Paul Weiss Law Firm
text: A top lawyer at the Treasury Department will soon join Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, bolstering the firm’s litigation practice in Washington.

headline: Chip Cards Will Require Users to Dip Rather Than Swipe
text: In the hustle and rush of New York, some diners at the Stage Door Deli in Manhattan may not even notice the extra three or four seconds it takes to buy their lunch.

headline: A Breast Cancer Surgeon Who Keeps Challenging the Status Quo
text: Late one afternoon this summer, Dr. Laura J. Esserman, a breast cancer surgeon at the University of California, San Francisco, sat in a darkened room scrutinizing a breast M.R.I. With a clutch of other clinicians at her side, she quickly homed in on a spot smaller than a pencil eraser.

headline: Yahoo to Go Forward With Alibaba Stake Spinoff
text: Yahoo signaled on Monday that it was willing to risk a fight with the federal government to spin off its 15 percent stake in the Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet giant.

headline: ‘Elements of Oz’
text: Scenes from the Builders Association show at Montclair State University.

headline: As Online Data Theft Escalates, Banks Look to Retailers to Bear the Losses
text: On Sept. 1 last year, the website Rescator, known as the “Amazon.com of the black market,” alerted its customers that huge quantities of stolen debit and credit card data would go on sale the next day.

headline: Raúl Castro Addresses U.N.
text: The Cuban president spoke out against the “militarization of cyberspace.”

headline: Keurig Aims to Lift Profits With Cold Drinks Machine
text: Keurig Green Mountain, the struggling coffee and coffee maker company, is hoping a pricey new machine for concocting cold drinks will help improve its fortunes.

headline: Senate Backs Spending Measure to Avert Shutdown
text: WASHINGTON — After a brief trading of angry recriminations, Senate Republicans and Democrats voted Monday to advance a temporary spending measure that would avert a shutdown of the federal government on Wednesday night but also signals a battle in the weeks ahead.

headline: Competing Worldviews
text: President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia addressed the United Nations General Assembly in September and presented two very different views of world events.

headline: Nepal Rations Fuel as Political Crisis With India Worsens
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Nepal began rationing fuel on Monday to cope with a worsening shortage brought on by continuing unrest over the country’s new Constitution and a dispute with neighboring India.

headline: Chick Corea and Béla Fleck, Reveling in Their High-Wire Interplay
text: The greatest commonality between the pianist Chick Corea and the banjoist Béla Fleck — an uncorked, virtuoso ebullience that transcends the limits of traditionalism — also poses their only potential stumbling block. The duo probably understood this when they made their first joint album, “The Enchantment” (Concord), eight years ago. But it took some time to find their conversational rhythm, a high-wire interplay responsive and engaging enough to avoid diminishing returns.

headline: Knicks Cast Eyes Ahead, Not Back at Their Wreck
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — For one full week late this summer, the self-described centerpiece of the Knicks tutored the future of the organization (or so the hope goes) by playing game after game of one-on-one. Each contest between Carmelo Anthony and Kristaps Porzingis went to 5 points. Each player was permitted only two dribbles per possession.

headline: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Parking Rules Suspended on Tuesday
text: Because of Sukkot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: The Syria Problem at the United Nations
text: At the 70th annual session of the United Nations General Assembly, world leaders addressed the war in Syria, which has contributed to the rise to ISIS and a global migrant crisis.

headline: Seeking the Unexpected During Fashion Week
text: As hundreds of photographers descend on Paris this week to capture the latest fashion trends, Landon Nordeman prefers to turn his camera on his subjects with unexpected angles, patterns and textures.

headline: Covert Electronic Surveillance Prompts Calls for Transparency
text: Law enforcement officials across the United States have become enamored of the StingRay, an electronic surveillance device that can covertly track criminal suspects and is being used with little public disclosure and often under uncertain legal authority. Now, though, some states are pushing back, and are requiring the police to get a court order and local consent before turning to the high-tech tool.

headline: In Florida, Senator Marco Rubio Talks With Retirees About Age
text: THE VILLAGES, Fla. — Senator Marco Rubio, his presidential campaign enjoying a jolt of sudden popularity, came to this sprawling retirement community on Monday and asked nearly 1,000 people who were old enough to be his parents to take a gamble on a young guy for president.

headline: The Music May Stop at a Storied Manhattan Studio
text: “Like a Virgin.” “Born in the U.S.A.” “Tattoo You.” Clapton’s “Unplugged.”

headline: No, You Don’t Need to Post a Facebook Copyright Status
text: In recent days, you might have seen Facebook statuses imploring you to post legalish language that purports to shield your photographs and other information from copyright violations.

headline: Yankees Have a High Payroll, Sure, but They Make Smart Moves, Too
text: The Yankees reported for work Monday with a chance to do something they had not done in three years, something that once was easy to take for granted. If they beat the Boston Red Sox, and three other teams lost, the Yankees could clinch a spot in the postseason.

headline: Facebook and Google, Two Giants in Digital Ads, Seek More
text: Madison Avenue is still the heart of the advertising business. But on the first day of Advertising Week, a top industry convention in Manhattan, it was clear how much influence resides in Silicon Valley.

headline: Colleges Vow to Simplify Application Process
text: Seeking to make college application easier for disadvantaged students, a coalition of selective colleges and universities said Monday that it would design a simplified application and an online program for college planning throughout high school. The coalition of more than 80 public and private schools includes many of the most prestigious in the country. The online tools, which will be unveiled next year, would give students a place to store schoolwork, get advice, and collect information on colleges and financial aid and link it to the new application. If it is adopted by high schools and community groups, coalition members say, it could partly make up for the fact that many low-income students receive little guidance on getting into college. The simplified application would be an alternative to others now in use, like the Common Application, but would not replace them.

headline: Some Counts Dismissed in Indictment of Robert Menendez
text: A federal judge on Monday threw out four bribery charges against Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey and a wealthy political benefactor, but kept largely intact the lengthy corruption indictment against Mr. Menendez and his longtime patron.

headline: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Failure of Training Syrian Rebels
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton said on Sunday that the inability of the United States military to train Syrian rebels to fight against the Islamic State on the ground had exacerbated the crises in the region.

headline: Donald Trump Will Appear on Fox Again After All
text: Less than a week after he said he would not be “doing any more Fox shows for the foreseeable future,” Donald J. Trump is set to appear Tuesday night on the network’s “The O’Reilly Factor,” the network confirmed.

headline: Oklahoma Court Rejects Death Row Inmate’s Plea for Hearing
text: The execution of an Oklahoma inmate can proceed on Wednesday, a deeply divided state appellate court ruled Monday, rejecting his lawyers’ request for a new hearing to present evidence that they say shows he is innocent.

headline: Sheri M. Goldhirsch, Who Nurtured Young Playwrights, Dies at 55
text: Sheri M. Goldhirsch, the artistic director of Young Playwrights Inc., an organization that produces the work of dramatists who are no more than 18, died on Sept. 22 in Manhattan. She was 55.

headline: Investors’ Fears on Commodities Add to Pressure on Share Prices
text: Stocks fell sharply on Monday as investors added new fears to the list of concerns that have weighed on global markets in recent weeks.

headline: Putin and Obama Have Profound Differences on Syria
text: Speaking at the United Nations on Monday, President Obama and President Vladimir Putin of Russia affirmed the need for international cooperation. But those sentiments are undermined by profound differences on the nature of the Syrian crisis — differences that provide little hope for resolving a conflict that has killed more than 250,000 people.

headline: Puerto Rico Officials to Testify on Debt Crisis Before Senate Panel
text: Puerto Rican officials will appear before a skeptical United States Senate panel on Tuesday to explain why the island may need federal assistance by the end of the year and how lawmakers preoccupied with the federal debt might help without setting an unwelcome precedent.

headline: Obama and Putin Play Diplomatic Poker Over Syria
text: UNITED NATIONS — After circling each other for the past year, President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia squared off on Monday at the United Nations in dueling speeches that presented starkly different views on the Syrian crisis and how to bring stability to the Middle East.

headline: The Perils of Forcing a Sale of Illiquid Assets
text: Boaz Weinstein, the hedge fund manager famous for betting against the JPMorgan Chase trader known as the “London Whale,” is being accused of his own accounting chicanery.

headline: Rallying Global Support, Obama Pledges Larger U.S. Role in Peacekeeping Missions
text: UNITED NATIONS — President Obama announced Monday that the United States would bolster its support for United Nations peacekeeping missions worldwide, as he rallied more than 50 countries to promise to expand their contributions, amounting to around 40,000 new soldiers and police officers.

headline: As Worries Rise and Players Flee, a Missouri School Board Cuts Football
text: MAPLEWOOD, Mo. — Students and families at Maplewood Richmond Heights High School are looking forward to homecoming, the highlight of the autumn school calendar for decades. But for the first time, the centerpiece event will be soccer, not football.

headline: Fiat Chrysler Union Contract Faces Hurdles
text: The tentative contract deal between Fiat Chrysler and its autoworkers union is encountering stiff resistance in early voting, with several plants rejecting it outright and endangering an agreement that would serve as a template for talks with General Motors and Ford Motor.

headline: Lebanon: TV Executive Is Fined in Case Tied to Hariri Tribunal
text: A judge at an international tribunal on Monday fined Karma al-Khayat, an executive with Al Jadeed TV in Lebanon, 10,000 euros — more than $11,000 — for contempt of court. The judge, Nicola Lettieri of Italy, had earlier found Ms. Khayat guilty of ignoring a court order relating to confidential witnesses in the investigation of the 2005 killing of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri of Lebanon. Interviews in the disputed TV series from 2012 exposed 11 men whom it described as being on “a confidential list from the witness protection program” of the Special Tribunal for Lebanon. Ms. Khayat, who was deputy head of news at the time, said the broadcasts, in which names were withheld, aimed to show there were leaks from the court. But Judge Lettieri said that “the journalistic profession may not be used as an impenetrable shield.”

headline: Exuberance and Disappointment at Shell’s About-Face in the Arctic
text: SEATTLE — For many Alaskans, Monday was “a huge disappointment, a really big disappointment,” as Gov. Bill Walker put it, reflecting on the tax revenue, jobs and investments that may be lost as Royal Dutch Shell abandons its plan to drill for oil in the Alaskan Arctic.

headline: Search for Speaker to Replace John Boehner Falls to Splintered Republicans
text: WASHINGTON — The right flank of John A. Boehner’s party may have pushed him out of the House speaker’s chair, but it will take members of every faction of the House Republicans to choose his successor. As the scramble to replace Mr. Boehner — and fill the leadership posts beneath him — begins in earnest this week, a few dozen members who spent several years tormenting the speaker feel deeply empowered in determining the outcome.

headline: Review: Revisiting Gertrude Stein’s Writings in ‘Reread Another’
text: “Reread Another,” which opened at the Bushwick Starr in January, reopened on Monday at the Brick. Here are excerpts from Ben Brantley’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on Jan. 12; the full text is here.

headline: Review: ‘Fondly, Collette Richland’ Offers Open-Eyed Dreaming
text: Let’s go dreaming, shall we? C’mon, it’ll be fun. Nothing will make any sense at all, and everything will make perfect sense. You’ll feel that you’re in a wild, bright land that you didn’t know existed, but one that you’re still somehow sure that you’ve visited before. What’s more, this is a dream — one of the most entertaining you’re ever likely to have — that you get to experience while you’re wide-awake.

headline: A Very Long Time
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — I ran into a few different speed bumps in Kurt Krauss’s puzzle, which is unusual for me on a Tuesday. EDGAR Lee Masters was EDWIN for a while, and ACE TEN was ACE’S UP.

headline: Staten Island Ferry Riders Helping to Pick New Seats
text: While tourists gather on one side of the Staten Island Ferry to catch a glimpse of the Statue of Liberty, commuters often have another priority in mind: finding a quiet place to sit during the maritime leg of their journey.

headline: Lawsuit Filed Against Porsche in ‘Fast & Furious’ Actor’s Death
text: Meadow Rain Walker, the daughter of the “Fast & Furious” star Paul Walker, on Monday filed suit in Los Angeles against Porsche Cars North America and its parent company, among others, claiming the carmaker left crucial safety features off the high-powered Carrera GT in which Mr. Walker died in 2013. The lawsuit, filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court, seeks unspecified damages for the defects that Ms. Walker’s lawyers say kept the actor trapped inside the car when it crashed and burst into flames. The lawsuit says the car lacked an electronic stability control system, and had side reinforcement bars that were weaker, for instance, than those on mass-market cars like the Honda Civic. Porsche representatives did not immediately respond to queries. Mr. Walker died while on a break in the filming of “Furious 7,” the latest in the Universal Pictures franchise.

headline: Possible Candidates for a Brokered House Speaker Race
text: With Representative Kevin McCarthy’s stunning decision to withdraw from the race for speaker on Thursday, the Republican leadership elections were turned upside down. The competitive races were supposed to be those for lower-tier positions. Now the big uncertainty is who the next speaker will be.

headline: Owner of Grand Central Sues Developer and City for $1.1 Billion Over Air Rights
text: When he bought Grand Central Terminal nine years ago, Andrew S. Penson figured that the unused development rights, or air rights, over the country’s busiest train station were worth a fortune.

headline: U.S. Discloses 2014 Warrantless Surveillance Program Court Documents
text: In response to an ongoing Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by the New York Times, the Obama administration on Monday declassified and provided a set of documents related to the government’s annual request for court approval for the warrantless surveillance activities authorized by the FISA Amendments Act.

headline: After Defeat, Jets Share Blame, Which Is Plentiful
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Brandon Marshall sleeps eight hours every night — or tries to, anyway. He gets up a few times because of all the water he drinks, although on Sunday he had trouble getting back to bed for an altogether different reason.

headline: ‘Blindspot’ Episode 2 Recap: Drones, Scars and Big Booms
text: Season 1, Episode 2: “A Stray Howl”

headline: Even Before Opening, Training Center Has the Nets Feeling a Weight
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Since moving to a condominium in Brooklyn Heights this summer, Thaddeus Young has been learning things about New York, including that it can take an incredibly long time to drive a shockingly short distance.

headline: Navigating Maze to Playoffs, Yanks Seem Lost Against Lowly Rivals
text: The math was almost too complicated to agonize over. With a win on Monday and losses by three other teams chasing them in the American League — including one playing in the Pacific Time Zone — the Yankees could clinch a wild-card berth while curled up in their beds.

headline: MacArthur ‘Genius Grant’ Winners for 2015 Are Announced
text: Lin-Manuel Miranda, the writer and star of the hit Broadway musical “Hamilton,” thought it was the cable company calling to beg him to reconsider his recent service cancellation.

headline: Thumbtack Raises New Funding at a $1.3 Billion Valuation
text: Thumbtack, which handles marketing and job listings for professionals like yoga instructors and electricians, has raised $125 million and is now valued at about $1.3 billion.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | goad
text: goad • \ˈgod\ • verb and noun

headline: Sounding the Islanders’ Arrival in Brooklyn
text: As the Islanders approach their first regular-season game at Barclays Center on Oct. 9, the arena experience is a work in progress as team and arena officials try to find the right mix of Long Island and Brooklyn.

headline: What’s On TV Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (Flix) VENUS (2006) The elderly actor Maurice (Peter O’Toole, in an Oscar-nominated performance) takes an interest in Jessie (Jodie Whittaker), the great-niece of his friend Ian (Leslie Phillips), who has arrived in London to care for her great-uncle — and perhaps break into modeling. Ian is horrified by Jessie’s working-class habits. Maurice, on the other hand, sees in her a target for his charm. “Their unlikely, uneven friendship provides the movie with a thin, wobbly dramatic peg, but it turns out to be just enough for Mr. O’Toole to show the younger guys out there — the Leos and the Brads and, for that matter, the Daniel Craigs — how the thing is done properly,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this meditation on age and beauty, directed by Roger Michell and based on a screenplay by Hanif Kureishi. In “Dirty Pretty Things” (2002), at 9:35, Chiwetel Ejiofor portrays a Nigerian doctor on the run who discovers an organ-smuggling ring while working illegally as a hotel porter in London. Audrey Tautou is his Turkish roommate, who pines for him. “ ‘Dirty Pretty Things’ plays it straight and cool,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The Times about this Stephen Frears drama. He added, “After watching Mr. Frears ply his refined skills in mainstream studio fare, it’s enthralling to see him employ that jazziness to spark his ticking impatience with injustice.” (Image: Mr. O’Toole and Ms. Whittaker.)

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “We haven’t been able to answer the question, ‘Does life exist beyond Earth?’ But following the water is a critical element of that.”

headline: Corrections: September 29, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Typhoon Dujuan Batters Taiwan With Heavy Rain and Winds
text: Typhoon Dujuan pounded Taiwan with heavy rain and powerful winds on Monday night, killing three people and leaving hundreds injured, according to Taiwan’s National Fire Agency.

headline: Seeking the Unexpected During Fashion Week
text: Great Danes and poodles, not Gucci and Prada, introduced the photographer Landon Nordeman to the fashion world.

headline: G.O.P. Attack on Planned Parenthood
text: To the Editor:

headline: Unfunny Jokes? Nah
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mr. Boehner’s October Miracle?
text: John Boehner’s looming departure from the House leadership stems from his frustration at leading his Republican caucus, particularly its implacable obstructionists who refused to be led. Farewell tributes have highlighted Mr. Boehner’s folksy decency and bought into his self-description as the grown-up in a legislative playpen. By this account, he was undone by Tea Party toddlers who were endlessly willing to be stupid or destructive to get their way or make a point.

headline: Disciplining Police Officers: Stronger Penalties
text: To the Editor:

headline: Is Donald Trump Serious?
text: As part of his ongoing effort to make a mockery of the American political process, Donald Trump released his tax plan on Monday morning. This is the third official policy position he has laid out in the three and a half months he’s been running for president.

headline: Pope Francis, Clerical Sex Abuse and Women in the Church
text: To the Editor:

headline: Anarchy in the House
text: REPUBLICANS aren’t big fans of Karl Marx, but perhaps they should ponder his observation that history repeats itself first as tragedy, then as farce. As preposterous presidential candidates dominate the polls and extremists topple congressional leaders, the Republican Party is headed for a replay of the catastrophic Goldwater revolt of the early 1960s. It may be an entertaining spectacle, but it’s dangerous.

headline: Speaker Boehner’s Decision: What Led to It?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The World Needs to Build on Its Success Against Malaria
text: Malaria will kill about 438,000 people this year, most of them in sub-Saharan Africa. That large number is tragic, but it still represents an improvement over earlier decades. The death rate of the mosquito-borne disease has fallen by 60 percent since 2000 and the rate of infection is down 37 percent, according to a recent report by the World Health Organization and Unicef. This progress shows what can be achieved when the world makes a serious attempt to deal with a major public health problem.

headline: The Prison Problem
text: Pretty much everybody from Barack Obama to Carly Fiorina seems to agree that far too many Americans are stuck behind bars. And pretty much everybody seems to have the same explanation for how this destructive era of mass incarceration came about.

headline: How Dragging Our Feet on Refugees Creates More Terrorists
text: THE Syrian refugee crisis, building in a horrifying crescendo over the past four years, has set in motion a debate in this country: Should America open her arms to the “huddled masses yearning to breathe free,” or fold them in a defensive posture born out of fear that refugees will harbor terrorists among them?

headline: Is Honesty for Suckers?
text: Has the pervasiveness of cheating made moral behavior passé?

headline: Would I Accept My Patient’s Gift?
text: In our first session after I returned from vacation, my patient Tim handed me a box of homemade candy. “I wouldn’t eat this myself if I were in your place,” he said. “After all, how do you know this candy hasn’t been doctored? I might have put in some bad stuff.”

headline: Stock Sell-Off Extends to Asia, but Glencore Edges Higher
text: LONDON — Stocks fell in Asia on Tuesday, a day after a sell-off in the United States and Europe, as concerns about global growth and weaknesses in commodity prices continued to rattle investors.

headline: News Q’s | At U.N., Obama and Putin Trade Blunt Criticisms Over Syria
text: Before Reading ‘At U.N., Obama and Putin Trade Blunt Criticisms Over Syria’:

headline: Donald Trump Is Not Going Anywhere
text: ‘I don’t worry about anything,’’ Donald J. Trump told me aboard his 757 as we were flying to the recent Republican debate at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, Calif. He was dividing his attention between the brick-size slice of red-velvet cake he was annihilating and the CNN commentator on the 57-inch television who at that moment was talking about Trump, as most commentators have been at pretty much every moment for the last three months. The commentator, Dylan Byers, was saying that Trump now ran the risk of ‘‘jumping the shark’’ because voters were becoming so familiar with his act. ‘‘Nah,’’ Trump said, smirking at the screen. As the real estate and reality-­show tycoon sees things, this is all win-win for him. Peggy Noonan of The Wall Street Journal wrote something to this effect recently, Trump told me, explaining that even if he loses, ‘‘he goes back to being Donald Trump, but even bigger.’’

headline: Oiselle, Women’s Athletic-Apparel Brand, Lines Up With Yale
text: Since it was founded in 2007, the upstart women’s athletic-apparel brand Oiselle has collected an eclectic group of women, including national track champions, supermodels and the first female Saudi Olympic runner, while staying mostly out of the mainstream. This fall it adds a new elite squad to its roster, becoming the first solely women’s sports brand to outfit a major college running program: the cross-country and track teams of Yale.

headline: Molly Ringwald Shares Her Beauty Routine, and Likes Her Freckles
text: A 1980s screen queen, known for her roles in “Sixteen Candles,” “The Breakfast Club” and “Pretty in Pink,” Molly Ringwald, 47, is still thriving in film, theater and music (she is quite the jazz musician). You can see her next as Mrs. Bailey in “Jem and the Holograms,” out Oct. 23. When she is not filming, Ms. Ringwald, the mother of three, lives in the Hudson Valley in New York, where she is working on her third book — a novel.

headline: Is That Cappuccino You’re Drinking Really a Cappuccino?
text: What if the cappuccino you had this morning was not, in fact, a cappuccino? Scary. More worrisome still: What if your flat white was?

headline: Generals Sought More Positive Coverage on Head Injuries, Document Shows
text: Two top Army generals recently discussed trying to kill an article in The New York Times on concussions at West Point by withholding information so the Army could encourage competing news organizations to publish a more favorable story, according to an Army document.

headline: Concussions in a Required Class: Boxing at Military Academies
text: WEST POINT, N.Y. — A bell clanged and two cadets in boxing gloves surged from their corners in a gym at the United States Military Academy last week, throwing jabs and uppercuts while other cadets yelled, “Keep working him!” and, “Use the hook!”

headline: Are You Distracted by Your Phone?
text: Do you think you pay full attention to the people you are with? Are you engaged in what’s happening around you? Or are you distracted by your phone? And are the people in your life — your family, friends, even teachers — distracted by theirs?

headline: Inside the Southern Tier
text: Years ago, the New York region was a manufacturing powerhouse, a place where business thrived, but over time the companies have downsized or left.

headline: New York’s Southern Tier, Once a Home for Big Business, Is Struggling
text: CONKLIN, N.Y. — The main grocery store here was replaced by a Family Dollar store, already faded. The historic front of the town hall, a castle no less, is crumbling, and donations are being solicited. The funds earmarked to strip off the lead paint from the castle’s exterior went instead to clear mold from the basement.

headline: Dressing Up at the Toronto Film Festival
text: The film festival’s rising stars reveal their wardrobe choices.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: Sloane Crosley’s ‘The Clasp’
text: “How strange life is, how fickle! How little is needed to ruin or to save!” These lines come late in Guy de Maupassant’s “The Necklace,” a story that serves as both the inspiration for and central prop to Sloane Crosley’s first novel, a shrewd ­exploration of the modern-day late-quarter-life crisis, disguised as a ­caper.

headline: Afghan Crisis Grows as Push to Retake Kunduz From Taliban Fails
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan was plunged deeper into crisis a day after the Taliban seized the northern city of Kunduz, as the insurgents on Tuesday kept assaulting the reeling Afghan security forces and the government struggled to mount a credible response.

text: There are about 140 watch companies based in China, a country where, purchases totaled about $10.2 billion in 2014.

headline: ISIS Says It Killed Italian Aid Worker in Bangladesh
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — The Islamic State has claimed responsibility for the shooting death of an Italian aid worker in this city’s diplomatic quarter. If the claim is verified, the killing on Monday night will have been the Islamic State’s first attack in Bangladesh, a country that has been grappling this year with a series of attacks on bloggers who have written critically of Islam.

headline: Morning Agenda: Commodity Fears Add to Pressure on Shares
text: COMMODITY FEARS ADD TO PRESSURE ON SHARES | Monday’s sell-off continued into Tuesday with stocks falling across Asia and markets opening lower in Europe.

headline: Corbyn at War With the Military
text: LONDON — The election of Jeremy Corbyn as leader of the Labour Party is an extraordinary choice in many respects — not least for the geopolitical signal it sends out.

headline: Big Donors Seek Larger Roles in Presidential Campaigns
text: Before the first Republican presidential debate in August, Julian H. Gingold coached Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin on Chinese currency manipulation and the nuances of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

headline: U.N. Adds Four British Members of ISIS to Sanctions List
text: LONDON — Hoping to stem the flow of recruits to the Islamic State, the United Nations has imposed sanctions on four British members of the militant group, including an aspiring doctor, a former punk rocker and a former security guard for a grocery.

headline: Today in Politics: Tea Leaves Trail Joe Biden to United Nations
text: Good Tuesday morning. As the excitement and confetti of Pope Francis’ visit clears, the threat of a government shutdown loses some momentum (and NASA confirms signs of water on Mars!), the trail refills with old intrigues, especially those involving a certain vice president who has a schedule full of items to parse.

headline: Xi Jinping Adviser Has Long Pushed for Powerful Leadership
text: Read in Chinese | 点击查看本文中文版

headline: Is Cultural Appropriation Always Wrong?
text: It’s a truth only selectively acknowledged that all cultures are mongrel. One of the first Indian words to be brought into English was the Hindi ‘‘loot’’ — ‘‘plunder.’’ Some of the Ku Klux Klan's 19th-century costumes were, of all things, inspired in part by the festival wear of West African slaves; the traditional wax-print designs we associate with West Africa are apparently Indonesian — by way of the Netherlands. Gandhi cribbed nonviolence from the Sermon on the Mount.

headline: ‘Star Wars’: Coming to a Theme Park Near You
text: The seventh film in the “Star Wars” franchise, “Star Wars: The Force Awakens,” won’t open until December, but already its droids, Jedis and Stormtroopers are flooding the travel world via new “Star Wars” theme park attractions, custom jets and a related museum.

headline: No, Student Borrowers Don’t Need to Worry About Loan Market Turmoil
text: Turmoil in a financial market has caused some speculation that college students will face higher rates on federal loans — or see them dry up completely. Are student borrowers at risk?

headline: Chef José Andrés on Giving and Getting Back in Haiti
text: The Spanish-born chef José Andrés, 46, has 21 restaurants around the country and in Puerto Rico, including the hot-ticket Minibar in Washington, D.C.

headline: Humans Connect Around Rare Eclipse of the Moon, But Not Our Rare Earth?
text: Before saying goodbye to the global blitz of “super blood moon” eclipse photography and chatter (already supplanted by the momentous NASA confirmation of signs that water flows on present-day Mars), I wanted to post a short note I received Monday morning from Deborah Hamon, an environment-focused artist from Marin County, Calif. (You can see her Arctic “pompom project” here.)

headline: In the Age of Memoir, What’s the Legacy of the Confessional Mode?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Leslie Jamison and Charles McGrath discuss whether, 50 years after Sylvia Plath’s “Ariel” was published, the confessional mode has been co-opted by the memoir.

headline: Is Your Financial Adviser Making Money Off Your Bad Investments?
text: EARLIER this year the Obama administration proposed a “conflict of interest” rule, designed to ensure that when it comes to saving for retirement, financial advisers always put their clients’ interests above their own — instead of, say, nudging their clients into investment products that pay the advisers more for their recommendation, but offer less return for the investors.

headline: Dance This Week: Balanchine Classics, Percussive Feet and Tango
text: Busy is the word for the dance scene in the coming days, with New York stages offering a variety of styles and a range of works old and new.

headline: The Case of Who v. Whom
text: It’s an unpleasant task, comparable to reminding colleagues that singular subjects need singular verbs. But after a rash of recent missteps, I am compelled once again to point out that “who” should be used as the subject of a verb and “whom” as an object.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Sept. 22-28, 2015

headline: Grover Norquist, Anti-Tax Crusader, Says Carried Interest Tax ‘Doesn’t Matter’
