headline: Reynold Levy Takes His Fund-Raising Skills to the Robin Hood Foundation
text: When Reynold Levy stepped down from Lincoln Center in 2013 after 11 years as president of the performing arts center, he said he would not pursue another full-time position, and that his one solid plan for the future involved “beaches and books.”

headline: Residents Flee Fighting in Kunduz
text: Residents of Kunduz in northern Afghanistan fled Wednesday after the Taliban took over the city on Monday. Afghan security forces are trying to regain control.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Dries Van Noten’s spring 2016 collection.

headline: Reactions to Senate Spending Measure
text: The Republican majority leader, Mitch McConnell, and the Democratic minority leader, Harry Reid, commented on the approval of a temporary spending measure to avoid a government shutdown.

headline: Recent History
text: Middle-grade readers today are part of what’s becoming known as Generation Z, born between 1996 and 2011 (give or take a year or so on either end). As this newspaper has noted, they have by now their own generational sensibility: more Lorde than Lady Gaga, more Snapchat than Facebook. Growing up entirely in a digital era, they are more private, sensible and cautious than their Millennial elders. Perhaps that’s because they are being raised not by high-flying boomers but by Generation X, which one Times article calls “a relatively small, jaded generation that came of age in the post-Watergate, post-Vietnam funk of the 1970s, when horizons seemed limited.” Much of the current helicopter-parenting phenomenon, it has been speculated, is a result of these Gen-Xers overcorrecting with their offspring for the strange and often jarring empty spaces that characterized their own 1970s childhoods. Back then, I think it is safe to say, “parenting” as a verb — a life-defining, life-consuming activity — had not been invented, even as the world had become more treacherous for children to navigate. It seems appropriate, then, that one of the best books I have yet read about growing up in the 1970s is a graphic novel for middle-grade readers: “Sunny Side Up,” by Jennifer L. Holm and Matthew Holm.

headline: The Essence of New Hampshire, Distilled
text: At Tamworth Distilling & Mercantile, which opened earlier this year on the grounds of a dilapidated New Hampshire inn, high-proof grain alcohol embodies the anachronistic, utilitarian charm of something you might have once found at a general store — or today, at the Vermont Country Store. According to its label — printed with, according to the product’s illustrator and namesake, Reverend Michael Alan, “a mixture of English and Latin, the Theban, and Adamic alphabets, and various magickal sigils for peace and love and prosperity” — the potent stuff can wipe away mascara and refresh stained furniture. The Alcohol, Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau has deemed it the most complicated label they have ever approved.

headline: At Rochas, Natural Beauty With a ’90s Touch
text: “Nineties fresh-faced gorgeous cool girl,” was how the makeup artist Lucia Pieroni described the pared-back look at the Rochas show today — a nice balance with the designer Alessandro Dell’Acqua’s exquisitely detailed designs. “We used a very light foundation and lots of highlighters from Clé de Peau to get that really radiant skin,” Pieroni said backstage before the show. Next, a light eyeshadow was applied to the eyelid followed by eyeliner, just along the waterline — “like you had mascara on a few days ago and forgot to take it off,” she said. Lips were merely a shade of the softest pink, smudged on just so with the fingertips.

headline: At Dries Van Noten, Artful Layering
text: For spring/summer 2016, the designer beautifully combined a range of colorful prints, lush fabrics and off-kilter silhouettes.

headline: France Opens Criminal Investigation of Torture in Syria Under Assad
text: PARIS — France has opened the world’s first criminal inquiry into torture under President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, officials and rights advocates said Wednesday, an indirect rebuke to Russia and its efforts to rehabilitate Mr. Assad as part of an international anti-Islamist coalition.

headline: Mob in India Kills Muslim Man Over Rumors of Cow Slaughter
text: NEW DELHI — A 52-year-old Muslim man died this week after he was beaten with bricks and sticks by a mob in a village outside New Delhi in response to rumors that he had slaughtered a cow and eaten beef.

headline: Hurricane Joaquin Drifting to the Bahamas, but Path Remains Uncertain
text: A tropical storm that has been churning the Atlantic Ocean this week strengthened into a hurricane on Wednesday, and meteorologists are now trying to determine whether its path will take it to the East Coast.

headline: Jeremy Corbyn, Labour Party Leader, Says He’d Never Use Nuclear Weapons
text: LONDON — The desire of Jeremy Corbyn, the new leader of the Labour Party, to scrap Britain’s nuclear arsenal is well known, but when he said on Wednesday that he would order the military not to use nuclear weapons if he were prime minister, it created a firestorm of criticism.

headline: Abbas Addresses U.N. General Assembly
text: President Mahmoud Abbas declared on Wednesday that the Palestinian Authority would no longer be bound by the Oslo Peace Accords that formed the two-state solution with Israel.

headline: Poll Shows Donald Trump Still Ahead, With Some Warning Signs
text: Donald J. Trump is maintaining a solid lead atop the crowded Republican field of presidential candidates despite what some analysts described as a subpar debate performance this month, according to a new Suffolk University/USA Today poll.

headline: Fever Follow Tamika Catchings’s Lead, Right Into W.N.B.A. Finals
text: In a perfect world, the Liberty would have returned home to a rocking Madison Square Garden after a dismal loss to the Indiana Fever in Game 2 and won.

headline: Michelin Announces Its New York Stars
text: Michelin, the Paris-based purveyor of gastronomic guides, has released its annual list of starred ratings for New York City restaurants. While much anticipated, it is short on surprises.

headline: A Lifesaving Smartphone App Inspired by a Brush With Tragedy
text: During a 2014 winter storm, Charles Martin climbed onto the roof of his rural Rockport, Ind., home to clear off a foot of heavy, wet snow. With his wife at work, Mr. Martin, a family counselor, slipped and fell off the roof, breaking his wrist and shattering his hip. Lying on his icy driveway in severe pain, he tried to call 911 on his cellphone, but the call would not go through. He lay in 20-degree cold for two hours until his wife arrived and dialed the emergency number from the landline inside the house.

headline: From Marc Jacobs to Ralph Lauren, the Best Mentors in Fashion
text: Here are a few established names who appear to be particularly adept at talent-spotting in the early stages, and the stars they have nurtured.

headline: Achieving Liftoff at Margiela and Courrèges
text: PARIS — Might there be life on Mars? Well, there are definitely signs of life in the revived space-age brand Courrèges. Ah, the cosmic coincidence. Welcome to Paris.

headline: U.S. Base Seen as Monument to Futility as Afghans Watch Kunduz Fall
text: The base was not much to behold when the American soldiers arrived in Kunduz in 2010. Nestled atop a vast plateau, it was little more than a collection of stucco buildings with chipping paint, a small airstrip on one side, a graveyard of rusting Soviet vehicles on the other. And everywhere was the Afghan dust, so fine it would puff like dry mountain snow with every step.

headline: Limón Dance Thrives, Decades After Its Founder’s Death
text: The future of American modern dance — and the issue of who will carry on the torch — is very much an open question, particularly since the death of Merce Cunningham in 2009 and the closing of his company. What happens when the founding genius, the original voice, is gone? Martha Graham died in 1991, but her troupe survives, thanks to “contextual” presentations and new works by living choreographers; Paul Taylor, still actively producing work, is 85. His company, too, is making moves to widen its repertory.

headline: Refugee Crisis in Europe Prompts Western Engagement in Syria
text: UNITED NATIONS — Over the last four years, as four million Syrian refugees poured into neighboring countries and slipped inexorably into poverty, António Guterres, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, said he had pleaded in vain with world leaders to take their plight more seriously.

headline: Rochas: Spring 2016 RTW
text: Rochas spring 2016 collection.

headline: Classical Duets of a Singular Nature
text: “To him for whom it was written” Johannes Brahms inscribed on the manuscript of his 1887 Double Concerto for violin, cello and orchestra. At first, the gesture appears perfunctory: concertos are often dedicated to their performers. But why, for a work for two soloists, “him” and not “them”?

headline: Fantasy Football Week 4: Waiver Wire Picks
text: Welcome to Week 4!

headline: David Cameron Grapples With Issue of Slavery Reparations in Jamaica
text: LONDON — As Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain visits Jamaica this week, he has been confronted with an old and awkward moral conundrum resonating in Europe and the United States: Should a country pay reparations for slavery?

text: Indian villagers found a leopard that had been searching for water stuck with unusual headgear; humans stepped in to help.

headline: The Great Outdoors Begins in Brooklyn Heights
text: “I’m not in love with the lumberjack thing,” said Jed Lubin, the 29-year-old manager of Hatchet Outdoor Supply Company, a store in Brooklyn Heights. The “lumberjack thing” Mr. Lubin referred to is a certain look common to the city streets (Iron Ranger boots, neoprene shell jackets) sometimes favored by those whose idea of adventure may be an Uber ride to Greenpoint. But Hatchet caters to those who immerse themselves in the great outdoors. In addition to classic clothing brands like Filson, the store stocks portable stoves, backpack tents and, yes, hatchets.

headline: 36 Hours in Bologna
text: Bologna is a culinary traveler’s delight, but there is plenty worth checking out in the culture and nightlife arenas.

headline: Effectiveness of Talk Therapy Is Overstated, a Study Says
text: Medical literature has overstated the benefits of talk therapy for depression, in part because studies with poor results have rarely made it into journals, researchers reported Wednesday.

headline: Vittorio De Sica Retrospective at Film Forum Will End on a High
text: Film Forum concludes its monthlong retrospective of Vittorio De Sica (1901-1974) with a week of high points. On Monday, Oct. 5, there’s “A Farewell to Arms,” David O. Selznick’s 1957 production of Ernest Hemingway’s World War I novel. Much panned, it still earned De Sica, playing Major Rinaldi, his only Oscar nomination for acting.

headline: For VW, Costs of Emissions-Test Cheating Will Outweigh Gains
text: Cheating on emissions tests has left Volkswagen with criminal investigations, potentially enormous fines and a corporate governance crisis. One might think the rewards for behaving badly must have been high indeed. Not so.

headline: 36 Hours in Bologna, Italy
text: Scrappy, scruffy Bologna could easily coast on its history, if not just on its culinary history. Home to one of the world’s oldest universities, this northern Italian city has contributed dozens of classic recipes and foods to the repertory of Italian cooking, including tortellini, tagliatelle and mortadella — the cold cut whose imitation is known as “Bologna” — as well as ragù Bolognese. As the capital of the region of Emilia-Romagna, Bologna is one of the best places to sample the cheeses, cured hams and vinegars that originate in the area, many of which have been famous for centuries. But modern Bologna is not just about the past. Dozens of cool new attractions have changed the face of the city, from new ways of eating to new museums and new bars. And although several of the city’s brightest attractions have appeared only within the last two or three years, many more are yet to come, including Eataly World, a huge culinary theme park scheduled to open here sometime in the next few months.

headline: Melania Trump, the Silent Partner
text: Lying prone on a rug adorned with the Great Seal of the United States, the woman who might someday be first lady is wearing high-heeled sandals and a crimson bikini.

headline: Jeb Bush Turns Personal in Confronting Heroin’s Toll in New Hampshire

headline: Republican Hypocrisy on Planned Parenthood
text: House Republicans called for an investigation of Planned Parenthood this summer, after a series of deceptively edited videos issued by an anti-abortion group, the Center for Medical Progress, alleged that Planned Parenthood profits from the sale of tissue from fetuses. But at a hearing on Tuesday, members of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee deluged Cecile Richards, Planned Parenthood’s president, with a variety of questions entirely unrelated to that issue.

text: Merger volume has surged so far in 2015, reaching levels just shy of a record for this century.

text: When the Dodgers face the Mets in their divisional series starting Oct. 9, they will have the benefit of a 1-2 pitching combination that is not merely the best in baseball this year, but, by some measures, the best in decades.

text: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen moved on Wednesday to fill a key management gap created last week by repercussions from the diesel emissions scandal.

text: Fashion trends may change with seasons, but one that has never gone out of style is the appetite for brand acquisition by groups both in and out of the 230 billion euro luxury sector.

headline: A Grab Bag of Software for the Apple Watch Upgrade
text: The Apple Watch that I wear generates a constant stream of questions from friends and strangers alike. One thing they always ask is whether the device is actually useful. headline: 3 Hillary Clinton Emails Deemed ‘Secret’ in State Dept. Review of 6,300 Pages
text: WASHINGTON — Three emails sent to Hillary Rodham Clinton in 2011 when she was secretary of state contained information that should have been considered “secret,” the government’s second-highest classification, according to a State Department review of about 6,300 pages of her emails made public on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Rothschild & Sons,’ a Reimagined Show From a Beloved Songwriting Team
text: What’s this? A new musical from the beloved songwriting team of Jerry Bock and Sheldon Harnick, whose “Fiddler on the Roof” returns to Broadway this fall? Mr. Harnick is still with us (huzzah!), but Mr. Bock died in 2010. Strictly speaking, “Rothschild & Sons,” which begins performances on Tuesday, Oct. 6, at the York Theater Company, is not a thoroughly new show. It’s being described as an “intimate one-act reimagining” of “The Rothschilds,” the 1970 musical, with a book by Sherman Yellen, about the Jewish dynasty that rose from obscurity and oppression in late 18th-century Germany and became a banking powerhouse. Mr. Yellen is also, happily, still with us. He has restructured his book to focus on the relationships among the patriarch, Mayer Rothschild, played by Robert Cuccioli, his wife and their five sons. The score will include some previously unheard Bock-Harnick songs and others revised by Mr. Harnick. For musical theater lovers, this makes for a must-have ticket. (yorktheatre.org.)

headline: Three’s a Trend: Slouchy White T-Shirts
text: The best part, perhaps, of one trend popping up on the spring/summer 2016 runways: It can already be found in your closet. A number of designers have show plain — and a little oversized — white T-shirts. Anthony Vaccarello and Tod’s both styled off-the-shoulder versions with black skirts (the former, slit up to there, and the latter, in embellished and perforated leather). The brand Off-White went for an all-white look, using a neckline cutout, ruffles and frayed edges to break up the monochromatic look.

headline: Who Is Fighting Whom in Syria
text: The Syrian civil war, now in its fifth year, involves multiple countries with overlapping and at times conflicting agendas. Competing visions of how to manage the conflict, which has led to a major global refugee crisis as well as the rise of the Islamic State, dominated discussions at the United Nations General Assembly last month. But despite days of meetings and diplomatic maneuvering, the crisis only intensified. Here is where some of the main foreign actors stand.

headline: ‘The Gray Man,’ a Tale of Spooky Disappearances
text: “The Gray Man” is so ambitious that its faults are worth overlooking. Indeed, for every nit to pick here, there’s a moment to admire.

headline: As Alexander Wang Exits Balenciaga, Three Potential Successors Emerge
text: In January, when he was appointed creative director of Gucci, Alessandro Michele was barely known to fashion’s press corps and buying teams, let alone the wider world. After working quietly behind the scenes for years, he had succeeded his former boss, Frida Giannini, who had been ousted from the position. Few had ever heard his name.

headline: Pentagon Is Reviewing Russian Airstrikes
text: The White House said it was too early to be sure what targets Russia was hitting inside Syria to support President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: D’Angelo Cancels Performance at Bill Withers Tribute Show
text: When a tribute to Bill Withers takes over Carnegie Hall on Thursday, it will go on without one of its star attractions, the R&B singer D’Angelo.

headline: Unisplendour of China Buys 15% Stake in Western Digital
text: HONG KONG — A multibillion-dollar shopping spree continued on Wednesday for the Chinese hardware manufacturer and vendor Unisplendour, as it agreed to pay $3.78 billion for a 15 percent stake in the American hard disk drive maker Western Digital.

headline: Tony Stewart’s Plan: Retire After ’16 Sprint Cup Season but Stay Active
text: KANNAPOLIS, N.C. — When news leaked late Sunday that Tony Stewart intended to retire from Sprint Cup racing after next season, he began to fume. He had wanted the announcement to come on his terms, with his words, at his chosen time.

headline: Easing Screen-Based Eyestrain
text: Q. I have upgraded to Windows 10 and would like to tint the text area when working with Word. I only have one eye and the bright screen is uncomfortable.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Position on Washington Redskins Offends Some Native Americans
text: Jeb Bush waded into the politics of professional football this week and was hit by Native American groups on Wednesday for saying that the Washington Redskins was not an offensive team name.

headline: High Cost of Inmates’ Phone Calls May End
text: The Federal Communications Commission will decide next month whether to limit rates and service fees for phone calls made by prison and jail inmates, a senior agency official said Wednesday.

headline: Robert Curvin, Scholar Who Fought Bias and Poverty in Newark, Dies at 81
text: Robert Curvin, a fiercely loyal advocate for Newark who never gave up on his troubled city and devoted a scholarly career to alleviating urban poverty, died on Tuesday at his home in the Vailsburg section of the city. He was 81.

headline: A Celebrity Struggle: Staying Off Twitter, for Good
text: Lena Dunham announced Monday that she was no longer managing her own Twitter account.

headline: Julianne Moore and Ellen Page Attend ‘Freeheld’ Screening
text: Julianne Moore has played characters who are gay (“The Kids Are All Right”), afflicted (“Still Alice”) and based on real life (Sarah Palin in “Game Change”). In her latest film, “Freeheld,” which had a screening at the Museum of Modern Art on Monday night, she does all of the above.

headline: Russia May Not Have Attacked ISIS
text: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said the Russian airstrikes in Syria were probably not in areas with Islamic State forces.

headline: Una emergencia dental y, al final, champaña: Don Francisco relata su último ‘Sábado Gigante’
text: El 26 de septiembre fue el primer sábado libre de Mario Kreutzberger en 41 años. El anfitrión de “Sábado Gigante” – programa que llegó a su fin el pasado 19 de septiembre después de 53 años al aire – tomó su ultimo día libre en 1974, después del fallecimiento de su madre. Desde entonces, Kreutzberger, mejor conocido como Don Francisco, se presentó sin excepción alguna cada fin de semana en el programa de variedades que transmitía la cadena Univisión en Estados Unidos. Kreutzberger recordó su último día en “Sábado Gigante” en esta nota.

headline: The Pope Sought Out Kim Davis for a Blessing
text: In an intriguing postscript to Pope Francis’s whirlwind visit to the United States, a private papal meeting with Kim Davis, the Kentucky county clerk who defied a court order to license the marriage of same-sex couples, remained a well-kept secret until he headed home. The meeting, which occurred last Thursday afternoon at the Vatican Embassy in Washington, was arranged at the behest of the Vatican and not through the American church hierarchy, according to Mathew Staver, the lawyer for Ms. Davis, who said Francis thanked her for her courage, promised to pray for her, and urged her to “stay strong.”

headline: Two Critics’ Choice Awards Shows to Merge Into One
text: Two prominent seasonal awards shows — the Critics’ Choice Movie Awards and the Critics’ Choice Television Awards — are about to become one.

headline: Next Republican Debate Is Likely to Have a Smaller Field
text: The next Republican presidential debate will have stricter polling criteria for candidates to make the main stage, potentially winnowing the field, the debate’s sponsor said Wednesday.

headline: Giants’ Victor Cruz Leaves Practice After Calf Injury Setback
text: The star wide receiver Victor Cruz, who was expected to return to the Giants’ lineup on Sunday for the first time in nearly a year, aggravated a strained left calf muscle that had been bothering him since mid-August and left practice Wednesday.

headline: Text to Text | ‘The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks’ and ‘The Sequel’
text: How private should your genetic information be? Can scientific researchers and pharmaceutical companies use your cells for the sake of scientific advancement? These are not just hypothetical questions. For the descendants of Henrietta Lacks, and for more and more patients and their families, these are pressing ethical questions that need answers and clear policies.

headline: Tulsa Sheriff to Resign Over Killing by Deputy
text: TULSA, Okla. — A grand jury here indicted the sheriff of Tulsa County on misconduct charges on Wednesday, and the sheriff’s lawyer said he will step down, six months after a volunteer reserve deputy accidentally shot and killed an unarmed man during an arrest.

headline: 12 Sentenced in 2006 Bombings of Mumbai Commuter Trains
text: NEW DELHI — An Indian court has sentenced five people to death and seven to life imprisonment for their roles in a series of bombings of Mumbai’s commuter trains in 2006, which killed at least 180 people and wounded 800 others. The seven nearly simultaneous blasts took place during the evening rush hours.

headline: The Pre-Aged Genius of Bill Withers
text: “I’m not going to let anybody con me out of being an old guy,” Bill Withers told The Times in an interview earlier this month. Now 77, the recent Rock & Roll Hall of Fame inductee was referring to the fact that he didn’t feel under any pressure to make new music. But even at the peak of his career, Withers was, in a sense, old. He was already 33 when his first hit, “Ain’t No Sunshine,” quietly strode out of radios in the late summer of 1971, a time when 30 was still at least nominally the expiration date for the relevancy of anything pop-cultural.

headline: A New Track From a Saint Laurent and Alexander Wang-Approved Funk Rebel
text: Inspired by “those who don’t blend in,” the British disco-punk musician Ebony Bones has played musical muse to Saint Laurent, who chose her music for the “Guess We’ll Always Have NY” campaign, and Alexander Wang, who featured it on the New York Fashion Week runway for his spring 2014 collection. And sauntering through the lobby of Berlin’s Park Inn Hotel, it’s clear that Bones, born Ebony Thomas, has the personality to match her bona fides. “I’m going through a yeti stage,” she says of what she’s wearing — a synthetic hair outfit by Franziska Michael — as she sits down on a plush couch. “Fashion for me is something you read in a magazine, but style is always a reflection of personality.”

headline: Verbatim: Ben Carson on Avoiding the Police as a Child
text: — Ben Carson, after describing how as a child he could hop fences to get away from police officers after playfully “throwing rocks at cars,” before quickly saying that he was kidding and that he had “a tremendous amount of respect for police because they put their lives on the line every day.” He made the remarks at an event in Durham, N.H.

headline: Classical Playlist: Ornstein, Foss, ‘Divine Redeemer’ and More
text: ORNSTEIN: Piano Quintet; String Quartet No. 2Marc-André Hamelin, piano; Pacifica Quartet(Hyperion)“So gorgeous I want to inject it into my veins.” Those were the words I blurted out to a fellow critic about the slow movement of Leo Ornstein’s stunning Piano Quintet after I first heard it performed by this first-rate group of musicians two years ago at Carnegie Hall. Here, finally, is a recording of this epically proportioned forgotten treasure, written in 1927 in Philadelphia by Ornstein, a Ukrainian-born piano virtuoso and composer who died in 2002 at the age of 108. Ornstein goes for the jugular in the febrile outer movements, shot through with Russian folk material and rhythmic fire, but offers respite in the achingly tender Andante Lamentoso. His nervous, simmering String Quartet No. 2, written around 1929, is another interesting document of Ornstein’s late Romantic style, but it’s the Quintet that now ought to be picked up by intrepid performers and presenters and given its due in the chamber music canon. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

headline: Chick-fil-A Brings Its Sandwich, and Its Values, to New York
text: Will New Yorkers “eat mor chikin”?

headline: Picholine to Find a New Home
text: After 22 years, the chef Terrance Brennan has decided to close Picholine, his elegant restaurant on West 64th Street near Lincoln Center.

headline: The Fed Puzzle
text: OK, maybe it’s the ear infection, but I’m having a very hard time understanding what Peter Gourevitch is saying in this article name-checking me. Stuff is complicated? What?

headline: “The Mini Show”
text: A first look at a tiny show of miniature artworks in L.A.

headline: A Tiny Show of Very Miniature Works by Big Artists
text: “The Mini Show” has all of the trappings of a very big exhibition: big-name artists (Ed Ruscha, Geoff McFetridge, Tierney Gearon); a big, broad theme (memory); and an address (L.A.’s the Lodge) frequented by big Hollywood types (Sia, Rose Byrne, Jacqui Getty).

text: T plucks the best bags right off the runway.

headline: Murder Case Against Mother Spurs Review of ’08 Death of Another Child
text: Prosecutors in Westchester County said on Wednesday that they would review the 2008 death of a baby born to the woman accused of throwing her newborn girl from the seventh-floor window of a Bronx apartment this week.

headline: What the Oslo Accords Accomplished
text: When President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority told the United Nations on Wednesday that the Palestinian people “cannot continue to be bound by” agreements with Israel, what was he repudiating?

headline: A Reason to Keep Coming Back to Tomorrowland
text: The only thing sadder than an empty closet is a full one. The empty one symbolizes lack, but also potential: It is a space of one’s own, to be filled as circumstance, taste and resources allow. Look at it the right way, and an empty closet means hope, a platform for the life you may lead.

headline: Viacom Names Sean Atkins Head of MTV
text: Viacom announced Wednesday that it had hired Sean Atkins as the new president of its MTV division, the ratings-challenged network group that has struggled to shift its business as younger viewers abandon traditional television.

headline: Model-Morphosis: Willow at Rochas

headline: One Dead in New Bronx Outbreak of Legionnaires’ Disease
text: One person who contracted Legionnaires’ disease amid a cluster of cases in the Morris Park section of the Bronx has died, the authorities said on Wednesday, as health officials ordered cooling towers infected with the bacteria to be cleaned.

headline: Review: In ‘Dr. Ken’ on ABC, Ken Jeong Is a Physician With Jokes
text: It’s one thing to tempt fate. It was another order of hubris entirely to write this exchange into the first episode of the new ABC comedy “Dr. Ken”:

headline: Review: ‘Benders’ Features Hip Checks and Humiliations
text: As a producer and writer, Denis Leary is steadily building a library of shows about 21st-century manhood, and they don’t present a pretty picture.

headline: The New York Film Festival Contrasts the Human Pulse and the Digital
text: Can a single movie haunt an entire film festival? “Steve Jobs,” Danny Boyle’s scathing, scary, biographical portrait starring Michael Fassbender, may leave you with the creepy sensation that its subject has crawled inside your head and hijacked your mind. As I watched the movie — the New York Film Festival’s centerpiece, to be shown Saturday at Lincoln Center — I thought of a cult leader wheedling his worshipful flock to follow him and drink the Kool-Aid. The alternative was expulsion from Jobs’s inner circle, which for those in his orbit was the equivalent of banishment to Siberia.

headline: Review: ‘A Little Life,’ Hanya Yanagihara’s Traumatic Tale of Male Friendship
text: Hanya Yanagihara’s “A Little Life,” published in March, turned out to be one of the most talked-about novels of the summer. It’s a big, emotional, trauma-packed read with a voluptuous prose style that wavers between the exquisite and the overdone. A potboiler about very intense male friendship, it’s a sui generis phenomenon that became a runaway hit. And it is now a shortlisted contender for the Man Booker Prize, which will be awarded on Oct. 13.

headline: All 15 Republican Candidates File for South Carolina Primary
text: All 15 Republican presidential candidates have paid the $40,000 required to run in the South Carolina Republican primary next year, the first ballot-access test in the G.O.P. race.

headline: September 30, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Greece, Kenya, Germany and the United States.

headline: For Amy Schumer, Multimillion-Dollar Book Deal Is All in the Timing
text: When news broke last week that the comedian Amy Schumer had sold a memoir  to Simon & Schuster in a high-seven-figure deal, some publishing executives experienced a sense of déjà vu. Hadn’t Ms. Schumer already sold a book of autobiographical essays for seven figures two years ago?

headline: A New and Improved Look for Kenzo’s Milan Store
text: Humberto Leon and Carol Lim revamp the Kenzo store in the heart of a Milan.

headline: Debating ‘Otello,’ Blackface and Casting Trends
text: When the Metropolitan Opera announced it would forgo the traditional darkening makeup for the title character in its new production of Verdi’s “Otello,” it set off the latest in an ongoing series of debates about the depiction of race in theatrical settings. In an email exchange, two critics for The New York Times — Ben Brantley, whose specialty is theater, and Anthony Tommasini, whose area is classical music — discussed the “Otello” staging, the uses of blackface, casting trends and more. Here are excerpts from their conversation.

headline: Review: Janet Jackson’s ‘Unbreakable’ Focuses on Love Outside the Bedroom
text: Meet a sweeter, more chaste Janet Jackson. “Unbreakable,” her first album in seven years, arrives after two major events: the 2009 death of her brother Michael and her 2012 marriage to a Qatari businessman, Wissam Al Mana. Through 17 songs, Ms. Jackson sings about love, loyalty and compassion, and about memories as well as anticipation. The word “sex” never appears in the lyrics.

headline: Kenzo’s Milan Store: Under New Management
text: For years, Kenzo has kept quarters on the Via Alessandro Manzoni, one of a cluster of several streets in the touristy thick of central Milan where fashion brands vie to set up shop. The location has not changed, but much else has.

headline: Chvrches Offer Hymns From the Altar of ’80s New Wave at SummerStage
text: On its 2013 debut album, “The Bones of What You Believe,” the Scottish band Chvrches knelt at the altar of new wave romanticism. The singer Lauren Mayberry has an almost metallic voice, plaintive but precise, and she used it primarily to convey ache. Her band mates, Iain Cook and Martin Doherty, are adept multi-instrumentalists, fluent in the whole range of 1980s sparkle. The album was something of a revelation, a revisiting of a distant time that didn’t feel studied.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: Batsheva Dance Company’s Young Ensemble Embodies a Signature Litheness
text: It helps to be young, or at least youthful in body, to perform the work of Ohad Naharin, the Israeli choreographer and artistic director of Batsheva Dance Company. His oozy style, grounded in Gaga, his trademarked and globally disseminated movement method, calls for a special litheness and resilience, the kind that facilitates, say, a precipitous backbend and its swift reversal, or a knock-kneed crumpling to the floor, or a deliberately high-impact collision with a partner.

headline: Review: Yarn/Wire Provides Two Flavors of Thrill
text: Yarn/Wire’s concert on Tuesday ended without Yarn/Wire. It speaks to this unusual, insightful ensemble’s self-effacing focus on composers and their music that after playing Mark Fell’s “core, self, oscillation,” the four members — two pianists and two percussionists, celebrating the start of their 10th season together — left the stage and listened along with the audience to an electronic version of the same piece.

headline: Toxic Algae Outbreak Overwhelms a Polluted Ohio River
text: The Ohio River, transformed by mining and industrial waste and sewage overflows into the nation’s most polluted major waterway, has a new and unexpected tormentor this fall: carpets of poisonous algae.

headline: Review: Ensemble Signal’s Musicians Do Solo Turns in ‘Theatricals’
text: There was only one possible criticism of the trombonist Steven Parker’s wonderful performance of Luciano Berio’s “Sequenza V” (1966) on Tuesday evening, part of a Pop-Up concert at Miller Theater: a sorry lack of clown shoes.

headline: Carole Little, Fashion Designer for Working Women, Dies at 80
text: Carole Little, a Los Angeles fashion designer whose sportswear found an eager audience among working women looking for affordable style, died on Sept. 19 at her home in San Diego. She was 80.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Lemaire
text: T picks the best jewels right off the runway.

headline: Microsoft and Google Call an End to Patent Battles
text: Peace has broken out between Google and Microsoft, which agreed to dismiss all of their pending patent lawsuits against each other.

headline: Where Is the Vegan Julia Child? Readers React to ‘Vegan Glam’
text: Readers were quick to respond to Jeff Gordinier’s article about the movement to bring the vegan lifestyle to the masses. While many discussed the merits of a plant-based diet, others talked about the need to make vegan choices accessible to more than just the wealthy. Selections from those comments are below; some have been edited for space.

headline: Military Deaths in ISIS Operations
text: The Department of Defense has identified seven American service members who have died supporting the operation to eliminate the Islamic State militant group. It confirmed the death of the following American recently.

headline: Syrian Rebels Say Russia Is Targeting Them Rather Than ISIS
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — “They are the most violent strikes,” says a man filming the grim aftermath of what he asserts was a Russian air attack on the town of Talbiseh, in the Homs Province of Syria. “This is the Russian criminal regime.” The voice then trails off into laments and prayers: “Oh God, oh God, oh God. God is all we need.”

headline: Saudi Objections Halt U.N. Inquiry of Yemen War
text: GENEVA — In a U-turn at the United Nations Human Rights Council, Western governments dropped plans Wednesday for an international inquiry into human rights violations by all parties in the war in Yemen that has killed thousands of civilians in the last six months.

headline: Fiat Chrysler Workers Appear to Reject Contract Proposal
text: DETROIT — Hourly workers at Fiat Chrysler Automobiles appear to have soundly rejected a proposed new union contract that set no limit on the number of lower-paid workers and that contained no mechanism to move them up to top-wage status.

headline: Hillary Clinton Calls Kevin McCarthy’s Remarks on Benghazi Inquiry ‘Deeply Distressing’
text: Remarks by Representative Kevin McCarthy linking Hillary Rodham Clinton’s sinking poll numbers to a House committee’s investigation into the 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya, were “deeply distressing,” Mrs. Clinton said in an interview to be shown this weekend.

headline: Judge Blocks Obama Administration Rules on Fracking
text: A federal judge on Wednesday blocked the Obama administration’s first major regulations on hydraulic fracturing, a technique for oil and gas drilling that has led to a boom in American energy production but has also raised concerns about health and safety risks.

headline: Parsing YouTube Evidence of Russian Strikes in Syria
text: The start of the Russian air campaign against Syrian rebels on Wednesday unfolded in territory largely off limits to journalists, but at least some of the bombing runs appear to have been well documented on YouTube. Within hours of the first sorties, Russia’s Air Force released aerial views of some strikes, and footage recorded by militants and activists on the ground appeared to show the impact of the bombing.

headline: How to Wear Burgundy, the Hot Color for Fall
text: The color is everywhere and can be worn with much more than you think.

headline: How to Wear Burgundy, the Hot Color for Fall
text: If the front row at fashion week and the fall goods now arriving in stores are any indication, burgundy is officially the new navy. The shade, called oxblood in fall 2012 when it broke out as that season’s signature color, is everywhere, a moody tone signifying that summer has come to an end (although it’s showing on spring 2016 runways, too). The appeal is much like navy: It can be worn with much more than you would think. Here’s how.

headline: Rick Owens and the Leather Jacket That Changed His Career
text: Years ago, watching Rick Owens and his wife, Michele Lamy, beavering away in Los Angeles in a garret-like space at the Chateau Marmont, which was then crumbling, few fashion insiders would have bet on Mr. Owens’s staying power.

headline: Pioneering Female Photographers in Mexico
text: A new show in New York offers a 90-year survey of women who helped shape the visual narrative of Mexico starting in the decades after its revolution.

headline: Mets Must Deal With Injuries to Yoenis Cespedes, Steven Matz and Wilmer Flores
text: PHILADELPHIA — During the third inning of a lazy game Wednesday, an 89-mile-per-hour fastball drifted high and tight toward Yoenis Cespedes and struck him on his left hand, pinching his middle finger between the ball and the bat.

headline: The SoHo Block Party and More Shopping Events and Sales Happening in New York
text: On Saturday, the Canadian label Mackage is opening a pop-up shop where you’ll find cozy outerwear for the cooler months, like a pebble leather moto jacket ($1,050) and a wool coat with fur collar ($790). At 1122 Madison Avenue.

headline: Bernie Sanders Raises $26 Million, Powered by Online Donations Exceeding Obama’s 2008 Pace
text: Update: The campaign of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has since revised their numbers: It had raised about $26 million since July and has more than $26 million in cash on hand.

headline: Border Havoc as Nepalis Accuse India of Payback
text: NEW DELHI — Days after Nepal adopted a constitution in a way that appeared to infuriate India, Kuldiep Singh, an official with India’s border security force, received his orders: Thoroughly search every single truck trying to cross into Nepal.
